HEADLINE: LEAP IN U.S. DEFICIT IS SEEN NEXT YEAR DESPITE 1990 LAW

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office said today that even though the recession has ended, the Federal budget deficit will leap to a record $362 billion in the coming year, from $279 billion this year, because of increased spending to rescue troubled financial institutions and their depositors, and an "explosion of Medicaid costs."
The nonpartisan agency said it "now projects much bigger deficits" than it did last winter, despite the budget package devised last fall by Congress and President Bush in an effort to reduce the deficit. 
 The director of the Congressional Budget Office, Robert D. Reischauer, praised last year's legislation, saying that without it the deficit would be even bigger. But in a report to Congress today he said, "The budget outlook now appears worse than it did in January."
 
White House Estimate Is Lower
 The budget office's deficit estimate is larger than that of the Bush Administration. In July, the White House Office of Management and Budget estimated that the deficit would reach $348 billion in 1992. The main reason for the difference is that the Administration assumed enactment of several tax and spending proposals that Mr. Bush has made.
If the Congressional estimate is accurate, it implies that there would be less saving, less investment and lower economic growth in the next five years, with a result of slightly lower living standards than might have otherwise occurred.
Comparing today's estimates with those made by his agency in January, Mr. Reischauer attributed the "gloomier outlook" to many factors: lower economic growth; lower personal incomes; lower tax collections; higher outlays for Medicaid, food stamps and unemployment insurance; bigger deficits; higher interest rates and therefore higher costs for interest payments on the Federal debt.
"The deterioration in the budget outlook doesn't signify that deficit reduction measures enacted last fall are ineffective or not living up to expectations," Mr. Reischauer said in a telephone interview from Colorado, where he was attending a conference. "But very substantial additional measures will be required to put us on the path to the promised land."
Neither Congress nor Mr. Bush has displayed any desire to undertake such measures as increasing taxes or making further cuts in domestic spending before the November elections.
 
This Was Balanced Budget Year
 This was the year when the Government was to have a balanced budget, under the law passed in 1985. But today's report says that the vision of a balanced budget in that Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law "has faded even further into the future."
The budget law still sets annual goals for the deficit, but they are not very meaningful because they are adjusted for changes in the economy and for increases in the cost of Government programs under existing laws.
The Congressional Budget Office said in today's report that it believed the recession began in the third quarter of 1990 and ended in the second quarter of 1991, but the agency said the Federal budget deficit would rise next year nevertheless
Mr. Reischauer's report also notes that the amount of Federal debt held by the public next year will, for the first time, exceed $3 trillion, or 51 percent of the gross national product, a percentage not seen since the mid-1950's, when the Government still owed the huge sums that had helped finance World War II.
In a departure from its normal understated tone, the budget office said Federal spending to clean up the wreckage of the savings and loan industry and to protect bank depositors "will reach a whopping $115 billion" next year. This represents a huge increase from spending for such deposit insurance in previous years: $22 billion in 1989, $58 billion in 1990 and $77 billion projected for this year.
 
Government's Obligation
 "Deposit insurance is a mandatory obligation of the Government," the report says. "Having promised to protect depositors, the Government must honor its pledge."
The deficit would have been slightly larger this year if the budget office had counted borrowing by Government-sponsored corporations created solely to raise money for the bailout of the savings and loan industry.
Mr. Reischauer's report warns Congress that delaying the purchase of insolvent savings and loan associations may substantially increase the eventual cost to the Federal Treasury, by allowing the institutions to stay in business for several additional years.
The budget office estimates that Federal spending for Medicaid will increase to $61.7 billion next year and to $105 billion in 1996, from $52 billion this year and $41 billion in 1990. The surge reflects Congressional actions to expand the Federal-state medical program for poor people, a rise in medical costs, court decisions requiring the Government to increase payments for some services and state efforts to maximize Federal contributions to the program.
Today's report said that Congress and the Administration were adhering to the fiscal discipline embodied in last year's budget agreement.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the United States will receive $48 billion in cash contributions from other countries this year to help pay for the war in the Persian Gulf. In addition, the United States is getting $6 billion worth of food, fuel and other goods and services from abroad. Taken together, these contributions will cover most of the costs of the war, estimated at $61 billion, the budget office said.
For both this year and next year, the budget office is projecting lower revenues than it projected just five months ago. The estimate for 1991 has dropped $35 billion, to $1,058 billion. The estimate for 1992 fell $28 billion, to $1,141 billion.
The budget office has slightly lowered its expectations of economic growth and it notes that "tax collections to date in 1991, especially personal income tax receipts, have been weaker" than expected. The recession "dampened the growth in personal income more than expected, and this, in turn, dampened growth in income and payroll taxes," the report says.
Despite these revenue weaknesses, the budget office said that tax increases passed last year would eventually generate additional revenue to help reduce the deficit as lawmakers intended.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
American Express is setting out to help increase tourism in Eastern Europe with a $500,000 allocation to train students going into the tourism business. "Tourism will be a major source of jobs and hard currency for countries in Central and Eastern Europe, which are reshaping their economies," said TOMMASO ZANZOTTO, the president of American Express Travel Related Services International in New York.
He announced this week that the money would go for tourism training in Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland. 
 American Express has had offices in those countries since the mid-1970's in conjunction with Government tourism offices but is now establishing independent operations. The company opened its own offices in June in Warsaw and in January in Budapest, where the initial staff of 6 was expanded to 24 within six months. A new office is to open in Prague later this year.

HEADLINE: Two Good Guardians at the F.D.I.C.

 BODY:
President Bush's nomination of William Taylor to head the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation removes some of the bad odor from last year's attempt to dump the incumbent, William Seidman. Mr. Seidman has been too independent for the Administration's taste, but a worthy public servant. Mr. Taylor, with a strong background in regulating banks for the Federal Reserve, should prove an able successor.
The F.D.I.C. was created in the Depression to insure bank deposits and regulate state-chartered banks that aren't Fed members. It has grown in role and stature of late, in response to crises in the savings and loan industry and now in banking. 
 Congress put Mr. Seidman in charge of the multibillion-dollar sale of real estate and other assets held by failed S.& L.'s. It also gave the F.D.I.C. the insurance fund for S.& L. deposits. Meanwhile, the surge in bank failures has stretched the agency's regular operations and drained the insurance fund for bank deposits.
Mr. Seidman has juggled these jobs well, no small feat considering the potential for manipulation, bungling and even panic. But when he challenged official understatements of the bailout cost and the banking crisis, the White House chief of staff, John Sununu, wanted him out. He hung on, and will stay out his term until October. Assuming Congress votes the needed funds, he will leave his agency in good shape for the work ahead.
Mr. Taylor is in for a grilling at his confirmation hearings on why the Fed failed to uncover the scandalous global rampage by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. His defense, which seems credible on the evidence so far, is that the bank masked its skulduggery so completely that no regulator anywhere in the world could get a handle on it. And amazingly, the Central Intelligence Agency's early discovery that B.C.C.I. owned a large Washington bank was not relayed to the Fed until two weeks ago.
B.C.C.I. notwithstanding, Mr. Taylor has an admirable record as a tough regulator. He looks like a good choice to fill Mr. Seidman's big shoes.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Glad, Not Grateful

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The diplomats from the West, Israel and the United Nations who are trying to get the hostages freed are keeping their mouths zipped about some of the basic realities underlying the negotiations process.
That is fair enough. It is not the job of those diplomats to serve as educators of the public about the whole vicious story of hostage-taking, how it works, or the dangers of it happening again. Their job is to get the hostages out as soon as possible. 
 But it is important for the rest of us to understand what is going on -- mostly for the sake of the hostages. In case not all of them are freed, it will help to get them out eventually if the world knows who is keeping them chained.
And if all are freed soon the speaking of the truth might just conceivably dissuade decent nations of the world from following policies that encourage kidnappers to take more hostages, for leverage and reward.
The first reality is that if a deal is worked out and all hostages are freed it will not be because of the negotiations themselves. It will be because the sponsors and masters of the kidnappers, Iran and Syria, have in their own sweet time decided that it is in their best economic, military and political interests to free their victims, at least some.
Iran desperately wants help from the West to patch up an economy shattered by years of fear and fanaticism. So it is calling in the investment it has made in the kidnap gangs, the years of investment of financial and political capital. These gangs, which use the name of God to carry out the work of the Devil, were organized and sent into Lebanon by Teheran and have paid off by giving Iran years of political leverage.
With fine candor, Prof. R. K. Ramazani of the University of Virginia summed it all up in a New York Times Op-Ed article urging the United States now to fulfill Iran's desire for a major role in the Persian Gulf.
"The prospect of the October peace talks reduces the usefulness of Western hostages as a lever to pressure the U.S. and Israel on issues important to Iran," he explains.
Plain enough?
Iran could not have protected the gangs without Syria. The gangs seized their victims in Syrian-dominated Lebanon and kept them mostly in the Bekaa Valley. That bears about the same relationship to Syria as Parris Island does to the United States Marine Corps. Now Syria finds itself without Soviet aid, and eager to be removed from Washington's short, select pariah list of terrorist nations.
Could Iran and Syria have freed the hostages years ago? Of course. The Syrians say they did not want to risk the lives of the hostages. But Syria never used the obvious weapon: a threat to execute all kidnappers if one hostage was injured. The Iranians don't say anything very much; at least they have that much respect for our intelligence.
So this is the end game -- Syria and Iran trying to make a profitable exit from an enterprise no longer paying off. But even now the diplomats do not know whether all the hostages will be released or some kept for future body-bargaining.
Another reality: The terrorists and their sponsors have carried off a fine piece of moral and political fakery. They have linked and equated the prisoners taken by Israel with the hostages. A hostage is a person who has no relationship to a fight between two parties but is kidnapped by one to exert pressure on the other, or on a third party, like the always-available U.S. That definition precisely fits the Western victims taken in Lebanon but not most of the prisoners of war, terrorists or gang leaders captured by the Israelis.
Maybe that fraud will help free the hostages; let's pray. But if we fail to see and state the difference we will be setting ourselves up for another round of hostage-taking -- a point that I have heard only Henry Kissinger make clearly and bravely, on ABC's "Nightline."
Hostages have been released because after years of hideous captivity the value has been sucked out of them. Soviet political prisoners gave exactly the right reaction when they were released from their own long captivity: glad, not grateful.
If the kidnappers and their masters are rewarded with trade, arms and absolution, hostages will be taken again. Why not -- low risk, good payoff. Then the West can find at least one responsible party, by looking in its own mirror.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 647 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Judge Blocks Plan for All-Male Public Schools in Detroit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Saying that girls must be offered an equal education, a Federal judge ruled today that the Detroit public school system's plan for three all-male academies was unconstitutional.
On Aug. 5, the American Civil Liberties Union and the NOW Legal Defense Fund filed a suit to allow girls to attend the schools. The groups argued that while focusing attention on the plight of black males was admirable, it denied girls the right to an equal education. 
 United States District Judge George Woods ruled that excluding girls from the schools violated Federal and State laws. The judge said that no matter how important it was to improve the education of black males in Detroit, any plan that excluded girls was not permissible.
"There is no evidence the school system is failing males because girls attend schools with them," Judge Woods said. "Girls fail too."
The proposed schools would have been the first of their kind in the nation. All-male curriculums have been developed in Milwaukee, San Diego and Baltimore. But single-sex schools similar to those planned in Detroit stalled in Miami and Milwaukee after officials sought legal opinions from the United States Department of Education.
The 170,000-student Detroit school district intended to have the experimental schools, officially named the Male Academy, open to boys of all races but aimed at blacks. The curriculum stresses discipline, civic responsibility, high academic standards and a curriculum with special emphasis on African and African-American history.
The groups filed the lawsuit on behalf of a Detroit mother with three daughters attending public schools.
The woman, who requested anonymity and was referred to as Nancy Doe in the complaint, said the application process for the schools and the name, Male Academy, made it clear that girls need not apply.
Community support for the all-male schools is strong. When the school district's attorney, Michele Edwards, closed her arguments in court with a reminder about the Detroits soaring high-school dropout rate among boys, spectators broke into applause.
"This is a situation that cannot be delayed one second longer," Ms. Edwards said.
Arthur Carter, the school district's acting deputy superintendent, said in an affidavit disclosed Thursday that girls could apply to the academies and would be considered on an equal basis with boys. One girl and 599 boys were admitted, he said.
 
All-Male Focus
 But in promoting the plan, the district had stressed the school's all-male focus.
A.C.L.U. lawyer Dick Soble said he was surprised to learn that the district had claimed admission was open to girls. Mr. Carter refused to comment outside court.
The judge ordered the Detroit Board of Education, the A.C.L.U. and the NOW Legal Defense Fund, which is not affiliated with the National Organization for Women, to work out a schedule under which girls could be admitted to the academies. A meeting was tentatively scheduled for Friday.
The schools had been scheduled to open Aug. 27. If a compromise cannot be worked out, the opening will be delayed indefinitely.
The controversy surrounding the schools is not racial. About 90 percent of the city's schoolchildren are black.
Another mother, 24-year-old Shawn Garrett, dropped out of the lawsuit about 30 minutes before today's hearing because she had been harassed and threatened by people in the community, said Howard Simon, the Michigan A.C.L.U.'s executive director.
The school board created the male academies to combat social and economic problems it said disproportionately affect black males.
On Tuesday, the Detroit school board voted to set up an all-girls academy in 1992.
But Mr. Simon, said: "Single, separate schools is not the issue. . . . Special programs were going to be opening in three weeks, and they were going to be opening with the special exclusion of girls."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 17, 1991, Saturday

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Search for Yields Requires Caution

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
With short-term interest rates pushed down to the area of 5 percent, many people are scrambling to get a better return than they can now earn on money market funds, certificates of deposit, bank savings and Treasury bills.
The trouble, financial experts say, is that often in their quest for a better yield people are making inappropriate choices, unwittingly exposing their principal to risks. 
 "This summer an inordinate amount of C.D. money came due," said Joel S. Isaacson, a partner in Weber Lipshie & Company in New York, "and people went into real shock and started buying bond funds without considering what's in the fund, as far as quality and maturity."
Tim Kochis, a partner in Kochis & Fitz, personal financial consultants in San Francisco, recalled reviewing a new client's portfolio. "Well, I see you have some money in junk bonds," he told the client. The man was aghast. He was unaware that "high yield" was a synonym for "junk" in the bond world and assumed that since the holding had been sold by a reputable firm, it was O.K.
It is O.K. for people who want to speculate, who are willing to risk principal in a volatile market in the hope that the bonds' prices will climb, as they have recently. But consultants caution that junk bonds are no place for a conservative investor. Prices can also plunge, or issuers can default.
Richard Ganz, president of the Fixed Income Management Group of Melville, L.I., who advises brokers and financial planners on bonds, said: "Today I think it is very important for people to move to quality. You can't concentrate on yield alone." Rather, he advised, people should look at total return, the combined result of income and any price change in their holdings.
He recommends Treasury securities or highly rated municipal securities as appropriate for conservative investors -- and he is bullish on the outlook for the municipal market. He sees demand outstripping supply, but stresses the quality of the bond, warning people away from bonds that are rated triple-A only because they are insured.
In another area, Mr. Ganz said, "A hot product today is C.M.O.'s," referring to collateralized mortgage obligations. "Everyone is selling them," he added, "but these are a hybrid-type product and must be understood."
Similarly, Mr. Isaacson noted that some investors seeking better yields have turned to funds that invest in securities backed by the Government National Mortgage Association, unaware that if rates decline the value of their holdings would go down because homeowners would rush to refinance the underlying mortgages.
Mr. Kochis said, "The first question is: 'Do bonds have a place in your portolio at all?' " His answer is yes, for people who need to lock in a predictable income stream within a one-to-five-year period, like retirees, or people who must pay college tuition bills.
In such cases, he favors "maturity matching," buying a bond that comes due as the money is needed. That way, even if the bond's market value goes down in the meantime, holders will get the face amount back at maturity. People who buy bond mutual funds, in contrast, do not have the protection of a maturity date, he noted.
When money is being invested for longer-term needs, like retirement in 15 or 20 years, Mr. Kochis favors stocks, possibly through a no-load index fund, like the Vanguard Index Trust or the Dreyfus Index 500, because historically the long-term total return on equities has been greater than on debt. Because of volatility, stocks are not appropriate when the money will be needed in less than five years, he added.
"I advise my clients to take the long view," he said. "History says invest in ownership. Owners get compensated. Creditors barely get paid back, and after taxes and inflation, they are negative."
Taxes are an important consideration for the bond portion of a portfolio. Jack Tierney, vice president of Van Kampen Merritt in Lisle, Ill., and product manager for its unit investment trusts, said his firm last week had sold out a triple-tax-exempt New York issue that yields 6.5 percent. For a New York City investor in the 31 percent Federal bracket, that return is equivalent to 11 percent on a taxable investment -- a rate available today only on corporate issues with some risk.
Investors should consider market risk, as well as credit risk. Longer-term bonds tend to fluctuate in price more than shorter-term issues because when interest rates rise, prices of outstanding bonds decline. Those who are uncomfortable with that risk may simply have to forgo some yield at present.
Steven E. Norwitz, a vice president of T. Rowe Price, the mutual fund and investment advisory group, gave these figures: If interest rates rise 1 percent, the price of a five-year issue with an 8 percent coupon will fall 3.96 percent; a 30-year bond's price will fall 10.32 percent. If rates drop 1 percent, the 5-year note will rise 4.16 percent in price and the 30-year bond 12.47 percent.
For a 10-year bond with an 8 percent coupon the total return for a year would be cut to 1.5 percent if rates go up 1 percent and it would be a negative 4.5 percent if they go up 2 percent. But, Mr. Norwitz noted, "those glamorous yields" of a decade ago "were a reaction to double-digit inflation." Today's low yields are still ahead of inflation.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum Rises by Over $5 After Three Days of Losses

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices rose more than $5 an ounce yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, ending a three-day string of losses, on news of a work slowdown at the world's second-largest platinum mining company.
Platinum for delivery in October rose $5.10, to $346.10, an ounce after falling a total of $15.60 in the three previous sessions. 
 The rebound was largely a reaction to news that 75 percent of the workers of South Africa's Impala Platinum Holdings began working half-days Thursday in a wage dispute. But analysts said platinum demand was so weak and prices had fallen so low that the Impala slowdown was unlikely to have a lasting effect.
"Only if this were to go on for an extended period of time, and I'm talking about months, is this likely to have a material impact on the market," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures in New York.
Impala typically forces an end to strikes and slowdowns quickly by hiring replacement workers, said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc.
"They're pretty rigid in their treatment of strikers," she said.
The likeliest result, Mr. O'Neill said, is a quick resumption of platinum's recent tailspin. Prices reached their lowest level in more than five years this week.
Silver futures rose sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange, partly in sympathy with platinum, partly on stronger technical signals and partly in reaction to signs the economy is improving.
Silver for September delivery settled at $3.995 a troy ounce, up 6.5 cents; August gold rose $1, to $358 a troy ounce.
Crude oil slipped yesterday in quiet trading on the New York Merc as the market appeared to ignore the United Nations' approval of a plan to allow Iraq to sell $1.6 billion worth of oil to pay for food and medicine.
Crude oil for delivery in September settled at $21.30 a barrel, down 14 cents; September unleaded gasoline settled at 66.98 cents a gallon, up 0.14 cent; September home heating oil rose 0.26 cent, to 60.67 cents a gallon; September natural gas prices settled at $1.278 per 1,000 cubic feet, down 0.01 cent.
Cattle futures rose slightly on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, extending their recent advance from three-year lows on continued strength in the cash market. Near-term hog futures soared the permitted daily limit of 1.5 cents, also in reaction to higher-than-expected prices in the cash livestock market.
Live cattle for August delivery finished 0.32 cent higher at 68.72 cents a pound; August feeder cattle were 0.13 cent higher at 85.70 cents a pound; August hogs rose 1.5 cents, to 50.85 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies for August delivery fell 1.05 cents, to 39.87 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Broad Advance; Mark Fails to Draw Buyers

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar staged another broad advance yesterday in foreign exchange trading that dealers traced largely to internal market conditions.
Dealers said the dollar's movement reflected relief that Thursday's widely expected interest rate rises by Germany's central bank failed to attract much buying of the mark. 
 "Everybody was waiting for the Germans to raise rates," said Hugh Walsh, an assistant vice president for foreign exchange at the Algemene Bank Nederland in New York. "Germany has rolled the dice and their market didn't strengthen."
Daniel Scherman, senior foreign exchange dealer at the Bank of Boston, said there was "an extensive amount of corporate interest" in buying dollars in the wake of the weak response to the German rate rise.
In trading in Europe, the dollar jumped to 1.7605 German marks, from 1.7320 late Thursday, and in New York it rose to 1.7645 marks, from 1.7490.
Mr. Scherman said that yesterday's reports showing a contraction in the United States trade deficit to its lowest level in eight years, $4 billion, and a rise of five-tenths of a percent in industrial production failed to inspire much activity.
Dealers in Europe said earlier, however, that the reports showed the United States economy was recovering from the recession, a development that would help the dollar.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 136.90 Japanese yen, from 136.59 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 137.25 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 137.30 yen, from 137.05 yen late Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.6870, from $1.6610 late Thursday. The pound fell to $1.65745 in New York, from $1.6720 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5440 Swiss francs, up from 1.5355; 5.9975 French francs, up from 5.9485; 1.320.25 Italian lire, up from 1,310.75, and 1.14495 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14355.

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Climbed 0.5% Last Month

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Production at United States factories, mines and utilities rose for a fourth straight month in July, the Federal Reserve Board said today, buoyed by higher output of autos and construction goods.
The gain of five-tenths of 1 percent in industrial output last month followed revised increases of six-tenths of 1 percent in June and eight-tenths in May. Production increased in April by five-tenths of 1 percent. 
 The steady gains in industrial production support the contention by the White House and many private economists that the recession has ended.
 
A Lackluster Recovery
 But the recovery is not regarded as a strong one, and there have been calls from some in the Bush Administration for further cuts in interest rates to stimulate activity.
The Federal Reserve, the nation's central bank, controls interest rates. Its policy-making Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet Tuesday.
In today's report, the Federal Reserve said that the output of consumer goods during July was up four-tenths of 1 percent after a gain of six-tenths of 1 percent in June but that the rise was entirely attributable to a surge in auto production.
"Apart from motor vehicles, output of durable consumer goods declined, as production of appliances, which had surged in June, fell back last month," the Fed said. Durable goods, like major appliances, are long-lasting and relatively expensive. They are closely monitored as a bellwether of consumer willingness to make large financial commitments.
One concern about the current recovery is that a tight job market might restrict consumer incomes and so choke off any spending increases. During July, 51,000 jobs disappeared, according to the latest Labor Department report on employment.
 
Other Categories Up
 Among other major categories in the report on industrial output, production by manufacturing industries was up in July by six-tenths of 1 percent, after an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in June. Utilities increased their output by seven-tenths of 1 percent, after falling back 1.4 percent in June.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of auto assemblies picked up in July to 6 million units, from 5.4 million in June.
Over all, industries like manufacturing, mining and utilities were running at 79.7 percent of capacity in July, up from 79.5 percent in June. It was the strongest pace since January, when they were at 80 percent.
Despite the improvement, capacity use was still significantly below the rate of 83.8 percent set in July 1990, the month that has been designated as the start of the recession.

HEADLINE: U.S. Issues Steady in Light Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in light trading yesterday, as dealers kept one eye on new economic data and the other on the unfolding scandal at Salomon Brothers.
Reports on merchandise trade and industrial production were viewed as mildly negative by credit market participants, and bond prices eased after the figures were released. 
 The increase of five-tenths of a percent in industrial production for July, the fourth straight monthly rise, was a particularly nasty surprise to traders, who prefer evidence of weakness in the economy to curb inflation and hold down interest rates. Before the figures were released, most analysts had been projecting that factory output rose by two-tenths or perhaps three-tenths of a percent last month.
"I was surprised the market held in as well as it did" after the production numbers were released, said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
 
Salomon Troubles Cited
 Traders cited the troubles at Salomon as the main reason why Treasury prices recovered later in the day.
Reports that Moody's Investors Services and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the nation's two major ratings agencies, were considering downgrading Salomon's outstanding debt obligations followed rumors that the firm was repurchasing its commercial paper.
Those rumors were subsequently denied, but worries about the firm's finances spilled over into the stock market. And nervous investors departing equities poured their money into high-quality Treasury issues, especially short-term bills.
 
'A Flight to Quality'
 "The rumors about Solly produced a flight to quality, and that helped to push the whole market up," Mr. McCarthy said.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 15/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.08 percent, the same as late Thursday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 3/8 in late trading, up 2/32, to yield 7.82 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 3/32, up 1/32, to yield 6.26 percent.
In the secondary market for short-term Treasury bills, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.22 percent late yesterday, down five basis points, or five one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.27 percent.
The announcement that Salomon's two top executives, John H. Gutfreund and Thomas W. Strauss, intend to submit their resignations at a special meeting of the firm's board tomorrow helped to lift the prices of Salomon's outstanding bonds.
 
Issues Rebound Strongly
 Salomon issues, which fell sharply on Thursday, rebounded strongly. For example, an 8 percent note issue maturing in 1996 was offered late yesterday at a price of 97 5/8, up nearly four points from late Thursday.
In the new-issue market for investment-grade corporate securities, the First Union Corporation offered $150 million worth of 10-year subordinated notes through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 9.45 percent notes, which mature Aug. 15, 2001, were priced at $99.80 to yield 9.481 percent, 1.64 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB-plus by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT LOWEST IN 8 YEARS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
A resurgence of exports of manufactured goods, low oil prices and shrinking demand for imports narrowed the trade deficit in June to $4.02 billion, the lowest monthly level in eight years, the Commerce Department said today.
Together with an announcement today by the Federal Reserve that output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities grew in July for the fourth straight month, the reduced trade deficit provided another indication of renewed strength in the manufacturing sector. The growing competitiveness of American manufacturers in world markets, combined with oil prices below $25 a barrel, has now produced four straight monthly deficits of less than $5 billion. 
 The deficit was $4.79 billion in May, $4.51 billion in April and $4.07 billion in March, when a surge in exports to the European Community produced a sharp drop in the deficit.
 
Annual Rate Is Shrinking
 As a result, the seasonally adjusted trade deficit during the first half of the year was accumulating at an annual rate of just $60 billion, compared with $102 billion last year.
"This year we're going to get the full benefit of the improvement in manufactures," said Stephen L. Cooney, the director of international investment and finance at the National Association of Manufacturers, a Washington-based trade group. "You're getting a double whammy on the good side this year."
Exports of manufactured goods expanded strongly last year, but this was masked by a large increase in the cost of the nation's oil imports after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, 1990. The deficit in manufactured products has narrowed from $93 billion in 1989 to $73 billion last year and may be as little as $40 billion this year, Mr. Cooney said.
But experts disagree on the extent to which the improvement in trade may also reflect slumping demand for imports in a recession. "These numbers are automatically improved, of course, because of the recession," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research center.
Exports dropped by $400 million in June from May. But exports of manufactured goods in June were slightly above May's level and significantly above the average for the first five months of this year. As for overall imports, they decreased by $1.2 billion.
"The increasing competitiveness of manufactured exports bodes well for additional gains in export sales in the months ahead," Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said today.
 
Effects of an Economic Slump
 Each percentage point drop in the nation's annual economic growth below the long-run trend of 2 percent to 2.5 percent produces roughly a $15 billion improvement in the trade balance, Mr. Bergsten said. So if the economy shows no growth this year, the trade deficit might be comparable to a $100 billion deficit in a year of normal growth.
The deficit last year was $101.72 billion, down from a peak of $152.13 billion in 1987.
The last time the monthly trade deficit fell below $4 billion was in June 1983, when it was $3.96 billion. The last trade surplus was $291 million in April 1982, in the middle of a deep recession.
Mr. Cooney, however, said two-thirds of the improvement in the trade deficit in the first half of this year from the first half of 1990 reflected an increase in exports. Exports grew by $13 billion, while imports fell by only $7.5 billion, he said.
A trade deficit affects Americans in three ways, Mr. Bergsten said.
When the economy is not running at full employment, it represents forgone jobs and output. Persistent trade deficits tend to reduce the value of the dollar on currency markets, driving up the price of foreign travel, imports and those domestic products that compete mainly with imports. And trade deficits also increase the proportion of American assets, from dollar bills to factories and real estate, transferred to foreign control to pay for the extra imports.
Not all industries have fared equally well in trade. Exports of high-technology products, for example, have thrived, rising to $8.9 billion in June from $8.1 billion in May, while imports only crept up to $5.3 billion from $5.1 billion.
 
China Trade Is Issue
 But the trade deficit in textiles and apparel rose to $1.91 billion in June from $1.63 billion in May. Neil H. Hightower, president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, a Washington-based trade group, said in a statement, "Our concern over the recent import growth is heightened by the fact that textile imports continued to climb during the most recent recessionary period while U.S. textile mill shipments were down."
The trade surpluses with Western Europe and Mexico increased in June, but the controversial deficits with Japan and China increased. Imports from Japan exceeded exports by $3.23 billion in June, compared with $2.43 billion the month before.
The United States trade deficit with China rose in June to $1.02 billion from $743.4 million in May. There are efforts in Congress to limit China's access to the United States market but the Bush Administration has indicated it will veto the measures proposed so far.
A decline in imports from Germany increased the trade surplus with Western Europe. The German central bank raised interest rates on Thursday, a move that increases the incentives for international investment there and tends to support the mark's value against the dollar.
The dollar has strengthened somewhat this summer, but not by enough to have a significant effect on trade, Mr. Cooney said.

HEADLINE: Magazine Sale In California

BYLINE: By AP

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16

 BODY:
A Santa Monica, Calif., trade-magazine publisher has purchased S.F. and Angeles, glossy home-design and fashion monthlies that appeared doomed when their parent company went under last month.
Steve Goldstein said in a telephone interview that he had purchased all of the assets "and none of the liabilities" of the two publications. A sister magazine, California, was not included in the deal. 
 "S.F. and Angeles were pretty much where they were supposed to be, and climbing," he said. "Their problem was high overhead since they shared staff with California, which had offices in New York, and San Diego, L.A., San Francisco."
The three magazines were owned by the Australian Consolidated Press. The publications were closed last month because of declining ad revenue and the recession.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS SUMMARY

 BODY:

Upheaval at Salomon
John H. Gutfreund said he would resign from Salomon Brothers in the wake of the widening scandal involving illegal bidding in the Treasury securities market. The powerful chairman molded the firm into the premier bond-trading house on Wall Street. The firm's president, Thomas W. Strauss, also said he would step down, and Warren E. Buffett, who has a big stake in the firm, said he would step in as chairman temporarily. [Page 1.]
For Gutfreund, the move was a shocking and abrupt end to an otherwise impressive 38-year career. He has led the firm for 13 years and was once dubbed the "King of Wall Street." [33.]
Buffett has a reputation for high integrity, brilliant investing and a caustic attitude regarding the foibles of Wall Street. And with a $700 million investment, he has a big interest in getting Salomon straightened out. [33.]
Salomon still faces many legal and regulatory problems. It is too early to say how they will eventually affect the firm. [44.]
John W. Meriwether did not offer to resign. It is unclear whether the fiercely competitive vice chairman will stay. [44.]
 
 The Economy
The trade deficit narrowed in June to $4.02 billion, the lowest monthly level in eight years, on a resurgence of exports of manufactured goods, low oil prices and shrinking demand for imports, the Commerce Department said. [1.]
Bush said he would sign a bill providing extended unemployment benefits but would block spending of the $5.8 billion. [1.]
Production rose at U.S. factories, mines and utilities for a fourth straight month in July, the Fed said. [34.]
 
 Companies
Mazda is expected to announce details of a new luxury-car division next week that will begin operating in the U.S. in 1994. Mazda hopes to challenge the Infiniti Q-45 and Lexus LS 400. [33.]
Chevron, Mobil, Shell and Texaco agreed to settle a long-running price-fixing case for more than $180 million, California officials said. Each company agreed to pay $45 million. [33.]
Pioneer Hi-Bred's bumpy ride through the 1980's illustrates that the pursuit of wonder products does not necessarily yield wonder profits. [33.]
Orion Pictures has struck a deal with bondholders that will keep it out of bankruptcy court, and the company's shares plunged. John W. Kluge, Orion's majority stockholder, will put in $50 million in exchange for the bondholders forgiving $267 million in debt. [35.]
Electronic Data Systems said it had won its hostile bid for control of SD-Scicon, a British computer services company. [35.]
 
 Markets
The stock market dropped sharply, shaken by the turmoil at Salomon Brothers and some spotty bad news on earnings. The Dow ended at 2,968.02, off 30.41 for the day and 28.18 for the week. [33.]
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed, as dealers kept one eye on new economic data and the other on Salomon. [36.]
The dollar staged another broad advance, with dealers saying the rise reflected relief that rate increases by Germany's central bank failed to attract much buying of the mark. [41.]
Platinum futures prices rose more than $5, ending a three-day string of losses. [41.]
 
 Today's Columns
Many people are scrambling to get a better return with short-term interest rates down to about 5 percent, but in doing so they often expose their principal to risk. Your Money. [34.]
A "magic wheel," which expands and contracts and looks something like a circular accordion, has been patented by a professor of mechanical engineering. Among the strange device's many applications: truck wheels that change diameter to meet the demands of different terrain. Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: Pretoria Said to Advise Zairian Army

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Aug. 15

 BODY:
In a sign of the political realignment taking place in Africa, South African military advisers have begun training units of the Zairian Army, Western diplomats said today.
It is believed to be the first time that South Africa has been asked to provide military aid to a black-ruled nation. 
 Zaire has publicly supported trade sanctions and other measures against South Africa until remaining racial barriers are dismantled. But like many sub-Saharan countries, Zaire maintains low-level diplomatic links with Pretoria and even in the 1970's and early 80's, when all African nations said they were shunning South Africa, this country had secret ties to Pretoria and South African produce filled the shelves of Kinshasa's supermarkets.
 
No South African Response
 But an overt military presence is a different matter. The current deployment of about 15 South African Army instructors to train Zairian troops, which has been reported by Western diplomats, marks an important step in South Africa's intensifying efforts to find friends and partners on the continent.
The diplomats said the South Africans had been posted to a military base near Kitona, a town in the southwestern corner of this sprawling Central African country. South African engineers were also sent to build living quarters for the advisers. Officials in the South African trade mission here, who maintain a very low profile, did not return calls over three days and no Zairian officials could be found who said they knew about the South Africans.
It was unclear when the training started, Western diplomats said, but reports of the exercises began to circulate in May and June of this year. Zaire's Army, with about 26,000 troops, is one of the largest on the continent.
Meanwhile, local newspapers here have reported that South African advisers have been involved in the establishment of special units of the Zairian Army -- men known locally as the "hiboux," or owls -- whom they say have been accused of harassing political opponents of Zaire's President, Mobutu Sese Seko.
Zairian Government officials denied that such groups exist.
The growing military ties between South Africa and Zaire come at a time of rising civil unrest here as opponents of Mr. Mobutu have mounted a sustained campaign to force him to allow greater political and social freedom.
During his 26 years as this country's leader, President Mobutu has been adept at enlisting the support of foreign forces to put down armed challenges to his rule. In the mid-1970's, when a rebel force twice sought to take control of Shaba province, a copper-mining region, it was repulsed largely by troops from France, Belgium and Morocco while the United States flew in military supplies.
In an effort to quell the current protests and disturbances, groups of soldiers bearing automatic rifles have been positioned along nearly every thoroughfare. Meanwhile, the Zairian capital is rife with almost daily rumors of attacks by soldiers on unarmed civilians.
These reports could not be independently confirmed.
 
Government and Opposition Feud
 At the moment, a national political conference called to chart Zaire's future has been suspended by feuding between Government and opposition leaders over the selection of delegates. A coalition of 165 opposition groups has accused the Government of vote-rigging and intimidation, a charge that the Prime Minister, Mulumba Lukoji, has strongly denied.
Also unresolved is the question of whether the conference is to be legally binding, as opposition leaders insist, or merely advisory, as President Mobutu wants.
While Zaire's military ties with South Africa are apparently recent, its has long been a steady business partner. South African Airways now schedules direct flights to Lubumbashi, the capital of Zaire's southern region. Since November 1989, South Africans and Zairians no longer need visas to visit each other's countries for two weeks or less. And the two countries are soon expected to establish full diplomatic links.
President Mobutu can use new sources of trade and investment right now. Zaire, once a cold-war flash point, as the United States and the Soviet Union vied for influence in Africa, is no longer so vital an interest to Washington.
As such, Western donors have been increasingly unwilling to overlook shortcomings of the Mobutu Government, accusing the 60-year-old leader of corruption and human rights violations.
Last year, amid allegations of a massacre of several dozen students at the Univerisity of Lubumbashi, the United States Congress voted to cut all military and economic aid to Zaire. Belgium and Canada, two of Zaire's biggest trading partners, have also stopped sending aid money in the wake of the Lubumbashi killings.

HEADLINE: For Fall Travelers, Bargains Aplenty

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
If you are planning a vacation this fall, there will be plenty of bargains. The travel business is still reeling from the recession and the Persian Gulf war, when travel declined sharply. Autumn is a traditionally slow season for travel, anyway, so there may be even more bargains than usual.
But there is an if, and sometimes it's a big if. Bargains usually exist if the consumer can buy tickets in advance and travel in a certain time period. 
 "You'll probably see a barrage of air-fare promotions because demand is so soft," said James. V. Camissa Jr., publisher of Travel Industry Indicators, a newsletter published in Miami. Labor Day to the week before Thanksgiving is traditionally when fares drop 15 to 20 percent below summer rates.
Morton Ehrlich, president of Lifeco Services, a travel management company in New York, said there will be bargains into the fall "for the traveler who can plan a little bit ahead; there will be a lot of deeply discounted fares."
 
Excursion Tickets
 Some of the discounting has already begun. This week British Airways introduced round-trip flights between New York and London for $428 on weekdays and $478 on weekends; departure must be between Oct. 15 and Dec. 13. American Airlines, Continental Airlines and United Airlines, competitors on the trans-Atlantic route, quickly followed.
Tickets must be bought by Sept. 11 and trips must be for 7 to 21 days. The regular fare for tickets bought 30 days in advance is $499 on weekdays and $549 on weekends.
Also, Virgin Atlantic Airways cut economy fares on New York-London flights by about 12 percent. Pan Am reduced fares by 25 percent to most of its destinations this fall as long as tickets are bought by Aug. 31.
Through Sept. 14, USAir is selling weekend excursion tickets to a number of American cities; the tickets are good for a year.
The discount fare between New York and Kansas City, Mo., is $198, compared with the regular fare of $258; a ticket between Washington and Buffalo is $118, compared with the regular fare of $178. To qualify, passengers must fly before noon on Friday and return on Sunday morning or after noon on Monday.
"It's a great time for the consumer," said David S. Paresky, chairman of Thomas Cook Travel in Cambridge, Mass. "You could see some more aggressive air promotions very soon." He cited a discount rate that will be available on round-trip flights between New York and San Francisco on many airlines this fall -- $428 with only two requirements: a 14-day advance purchase and a Saturday night stay.
Cruise lines are also slashing prices for the fall. Carnival Cruise Lines is cutting the fare for a seven-day Caribbean cruise by $300 a person; the new prices will range from $849 to $1,389.
Hotels are trying to increase their occupancy rates by offering special packages, too. For example, most Sheraton hotels in North America are participating in an "endless weekend" promotion that features 50 percent off rates from Thursday through Sunday; with the discount, prices range between $49 and $149 per room per day.
 
Three Nights for $1
 American Airlines Fly Away Vacations has a program through Nov. 15 that combines air fares and hotel rooms in Australia and New Zealand. Travelers flying round trip to Sydney for $1,601 or to Auckland for $1,505, with tickets bought 21 days in advance, get three nights at a hotel and a harbor cruise, all for only $1.
James Pazienza, president of Uni globe Travel in Washington, said, "Most of the travel agencies get faxes from suppliers regularly showing what specials are being run, so the more flexible you are, the greater the opportunity to get savings."
With so many discounts in the offing, experts advise potential travelers to be wary of scams.
"Many a consumer who has gotten a bargain ticket could not fly because the airline is not around," said Alexander Anolik, a lawyer in San Francisco. "So check the bargains with a reliable agent."
 
Don't Pay Cash
 Consumers should also charge their tickets on a credit card, rather than pay by cash or check. If problems arise, the Federal Fair Credit Billing Act gives holders of credit cards the right to refuse to pay for services that are not rendered, as long as they notify the credit-card company within 60 days after receiving the charge.
Also, the types of flights, cruises and accommodations available at discounted prices might not be acceptable to some travelers.
"Be realistic in terms of your own expectations," said Hal Norvell, director of travel-industry relations of the American Association of Retired Persons. "A bargain can often be very expensive if you don't get the value you are seeking."
 
 
FOR UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION, CALL A TRAVEL AGENT
 If you are looking for travel bargains this fall, it's a good idea to work with a travel agent. Agents have the latest facts about discounts, and they can tell you when a travel company adds or withdraws a discounted rate.
If you want to do preliminary research before you talk to an agent, here are the addresses and phone numbers of some airlines, cruise lines and hotel chains offering discount programs.
British Airways -- 75-20 Astoria Boulevard, Jackson Heights, N.Y. 11370; (800) AIRWAYS.
USAir -- 2345 Crystal Drive, Arlington, Va. 22227; (800) 428-4322.
Carnival Cruise Lines -- 3655 NW 87th Avenue, Miami, Fla. 33178; (305) 599-2600.
Sheraton Hotels -- 60 State Street, Boston, Mass. 02109; (800) 325-3535.
American Airlines Fly Away Vacations -- P.O. Box 619616, Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, Tex. 75261; (800) 832-8383.
Thomas Cook Travel, a travel agency that operates nationwide, provides information about discount programs to anyone who calls or writes. The address is 39 John F. Kennedy Street, Cambridge, Mass. 02138; (800) 457-3988.

HEADLINE: Bush Chides Protesters on 'Excesses'

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 16

 BODY:
In a rebuke of disruptive protests, including anti-abortion demonstrations, President Bush today counseled against "excesses" and said that demonstrators sometimes actually harmed their own cause.
Although the President has said he supports the Justice Department's recent decision to intervene on behalf of anti-abortion demonstrators in Wichita, Kan., his remarks today seemed to indicate that he was displeased at the way these and other protestors had behaved. 
 The protests in Kansas, organized by the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue with the intention of shutting down Wichita abortion clinics, have resulted in nearly 2,000 arrests since late July. The protesters are defying a court order to refrain from blocking the entrances to the clinics, asserting that Federal courts lack jurisdiction to enforce abortion rights.
 
'Within the Law'
 "We've got to understand that some of these things go with the territory, go with my job," Mr. Bush said. "And yet my appeal would be, to those who demonstrate, please do it so it doesn't inconvenience the other person's life, and please do it so it is within the law. Whether it's at an abortion clinic, or whether it's at a protest for AIDS activists, or whatever it may be. Because I'm convinced that the excesses of this work against the cause, whatever it is."
In an interview with Maine reporters this morning at his family's estate here, Mr. Bush apologized to residents of Kennebunkport for any disruption caused by a demonstration today protesting the President's refusal to make available $5.8 billion in unemployment benefits for those who have exhausted the 26 weeks of eligibility.
A few dozen demonstrators from several labor unions in the Northeast held a news conference and then marched to Walker's Point, Mr. Bush's home. Some protesters held signs reading: "Robbing George steals from the jobless to give to savings and loans."
Mr. Bush said he was also worried about a demonstration planned for Labor Day weekend by members of the advocacy group Act-Up, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power.
"Well, Act-Up has a reputation as being less than moderate," he said. "They have every right to exercise their First Amendment rights. But does it trouble me that they might descend on this town, this small little town here, and have some adverse effect on the people here? Yes, it troubles me."
Mr. Bush also said that he was trying not to get overconfident about the 1992 election, despite the narrow field of Democratic opponents so far.
"They'll get their act together," he said. "I think they've come upon a theme: Go after the President on no domestic policy. And I will be retaliating at the proper time."
Later, on the golf course, Mr. Bush mocked the idea that the Democrats were in disarray, pointing out that they were organized enough to attack him.
"It's just terrible," he said, feigning a wounded tone in referring to two of Washington's most powerful Democrats. "They've gotten together under the leadership of Ron Brown and Pamela Harriman. What the heck, what can a guy do?"
 
DOLE CRITICIZES PROTESTS
 WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, today criticized the monthlong anti-abortion protests in his state, saying they had done a "lot of harm" to the anti-abortion cause.
Senator Dole, who opposes abortion, said the Operation Rescue blockades of the three abortion clinics in Wichita should stop because the protesters were "in violation of the law, and I don't think they win many friends with some of their conduct."

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO SIGN JOBLESS MEASURE BUT BLOCK MONEY

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he would sign a bill providing extended benefits for three million people who have been out of work more than half a year but said he would block actual spending of the bill's $5.8 billion in benefits.
He said at a news conference in Kennebunkport, Me., that while he sympathized with the unemployed, he would not carry out the bill because "I won't bust the budget." 
 Mr. Bush said Congress could do more for the unemployed if it cut taxes on capital gains, which "would create jobs almost instantly." He said a strong recovery from the recession depended on having sound fiscal policies and not letting "the Federal Government keep doing what often in the past it's done, recklessly spend money."
 
No Budget Emergency
 Because of the budget act provisions, the legislation gave Mr. Bush the opportunity to take one symbolic step, signing the bill, that was friendly to the unemployed even without the other that would have sent money. He took advantage of that opportunity on a midsummer Friday, when the audience for news is at one of its lowest points all year.
The President said that to show his concern for the unemployed, he would sign the benefits bill Democrats pushed through Congress two weeks ago. "It at least demonstrates I am concerned," he said. He has until midnight Saturday night to sign or veto the bill or let it become law without his signature.
But he said he would not sign the declaration of a budget emergency, which the bill also required before the money could be spent for up to 20 weeks of extended benefits for people who exhausted the basic 26 weeks. Under last year's budget act, both Congress and the President must agree that there is an emergency before the Federal deficit can be increased.
In another effort to cool what the Democrats have seized on as a hot political issue, Mr. Bush insisted he would have carried out a more modest, $3.2 billion proposal from Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader. That bill would have been financed by a Government auction of radio frequencies.
 
Democrats to Try Again
 Congressional Democrats immediately vowed to try again in September after they return from vacation. Today they concentrated on attacking Mr. Bush's decision as unfeeling.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said it was "the height of cynicism" for Mr. Bush to say signing the bill showed his concern for the jobless when he kept them from getting the money.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, sounded a growing Democratic theme when he said the President's decision -- coming after declaring emergencies to aid Kurds, Turks and Israelis -- showed that Mr. Bush was "more concerned about emergencies abroad than emergencies here at home."
Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Long Island Democrat who was the chief House sponsor of the bill, predicted that Congress would pass the measure again when it returns from its August recess. He said this time it would be done in a form that would waive the budget act and require Mr. Bush to veto the bill and face the risk of being overridden if he wanted to block the benefits again.
 
'Possibility' of Override
 In today's news conference, Mr. Bush acknowledged that there was "a possibility" that Congress could muster the two-thirds majorities required to override a veto. The Senate passed the bill on Aug. 1 by a voice vote, with no opposition heard. The House adopted it the next day by a vote of 375 to 45, with even Republicans backing it 118 to 44.
The bill cleared Congress a few hours after the Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate dropped slightly last month, to 6.8 percent from 7 percent. But the report showed that the reason for the improvement was that more people had dropped out of the labor market, not that more workers had jobs. Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House, said that next month Congress would send Mr. Bush "legislation that's going to require a choice" so that the President could not "give with one hand and take back with another, as he's done today."
Mr. Foley told reporters at the Capitol that he hoped Mr. Bush would then join with Congress to "provide the same concern and compassion at home as we provide abroad."
Mr. Bush said the recession was ending, but acknowledged "It's pretty hard to say to someone that's out of work, 'Hey, things are getting better,' not necessarily getting better for their families."
He said some of the statistics were "very good," including unemployment figures for July.
 
Recovery Predicted
 Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, predicted a slow recovery and said, "The economy may or may not be turning the corner, but it will be some time before these workers have any reasonable prospect for going back to work."
Unemployment insurance, which covers about half of all workers, provides compensation for up to 26 weeks in most states. Benefits are about half of past salaries, up to ceilings that vary greatly from state to state. The benefits nationally now average $160 per week. The highest state average last year was $217 a week in Massachusetts, and the lowest was $79 a week in Louisiana.
Current law does provide extended benefits of up to 13 weeks, paid for equally from state and Federal funds. That program can take effect when joblessness among a state's workers who are covered by unemployment insurance reaches 6 percent, or when the rate reaches 5 percent if the level of the uninsured jobless exceeds by one-fifth the average level in that state over the last two years.
Unemployment among insured workers is much lower than the total unemployment rate, and as a result only in Alaska, Maine, Rhode Island and Puerto Rico were extended benefits being paid when the bill was passed. Since then, Maine has been dropped from that list.
 
Different Standard for States
 Under the bill sent to Mr. Bush, the measuring standard used would be total unemployment, not insured unemployment. In states with 8 percent unemployment, averaged over the last six months, an additional 20 weeks of benefits could be paid. If the law were in effect today, Maine would go back on the list, and Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi and West Virginia would also be added to the states now eligible.
In states with 7 percent unemployment, an extra 13 weeks of benefits could be paid. Workers in the nation's two most populous states, California and New York, would qualify. In states with 6 percent unemployment, 7 additional weeks could be paid, and in all others, an additional 4 weeks of benefits could bne paid.
These changes would be temporary and would expire next July. There are some retroactive payments, so the total number of workers who would be paid is about 3 million. The money would be paid entirely from a Federal trust fund for extended benefits that now has about $8 billion in it.
One other major change in the bill would be permanent. It would make people who leave the armed services eligible for 26 weeks of benefits, instead of the current 13 weeks. They would also be able to start collecting after one week, instead of the current four. Under both changes, they would be treated like civilian workers who leave a job.
Besides Mr. Bush, Senator Dole was the only prominent Republican heard from on the subject today. He accused the Democrats of leaving "America's unemployed in the lurch." He said it was obvious they wanted "A political issue, not a bipartisan solution" when they rejected his bill.
The Democrats' only announced presidential candidate, former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts, alluded to Mr. Bush's majority in 1988, when he said that of the 3 million whom the bill would have helped, "There are approximately 1.6 million people who voted for George Bush who just found out what he is all about. He is not their President."

HEADLINE: Guidepost;
An Interest in Interest

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:

The sharp decline in interest rates for money-market deposits and certificates of deposit has sent investors in search of higher rates. Some analysts recommend fixed-income securities like Treasury instruments, which are exempt from state and local income taxes, with maturities of not more than five years. They recommend a "laddering technique" so the securities come due in consecutive years or at other regular intervals. Buying directly from the Treasury saves commission fees. Auction dates are announced in many newspapers and in phone messages at Federal Reserve Banks and branches. Here are the securities available at auction and the most recent average yield.
 
Bills: Maturities are 3 months (5.3%), 6 months (5.39%) and 1 year (5.88%). Minimum purchase $10,000.
 
Notes: Maturities are 2 years (6.94%) to 10 years (7.94%); 2- and 3-year notes can be purchased for $5,000 or for multiples of $5,000; 4- to 10-year notes, for $1,000 or multiples of $1,000.
 
Bonds: The 30-year bond (8.17%) can be purchased for $1,000 or multiples of $1,000.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Run, Mario, Run

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
The hot topic is how the Democrats can win in '92, and Lord, how poor is the outlook. No matter who prognosticates about the future, about the Clintons and the Wilders and the Gores, the consensus seems to be that unseating George Bush will require something akin to multiplying the loaves and fishes.
I'm not worried about figuring out which Democrat can win, because worrying about winning is part of the problem. I want the Democrat who doesn't mind losing for the good of the nation. 
 That's why Mario Cuomo should run.
I've been thinking about this ever since I spent an hour with Paul Tsongas. The former Senator from Massachusetts has a certain droll humor about the fact that he is the only announced Democrat and no one's noticed. "Just because people don't think you can win doesn't mean they're not going to vote for you," he said, sounding like a smart fortune cookie.
I love this idea: Forget about winning and give the people something to vote for. The Democrats don't need a candidate they think can win. They need a candidate who will engage, who will speak with candor and with heat of the overwhelming economic and social problems of this country, who won't approach the podium like a prom date hoping his corsage will match your dress.
George Bush isn't going to be reelected because he's a great leader. He's not. The gulf war glow has faded; the economy is a mess and Americans are desperate for decent jobs, health care, schools and housing.
But Mr. Bush, like Ronald Reagan, is a Teflon President. Even the recession has not dented his popularity, yet if you ask people what he stands for, few can tell you. I still don't know what a thousand points of light are, and I don't care.
"More than metaphors," should be the Democratic slogan in 1992. And Mario Cuomo should be the candidate.
There are problems with a Cuomo candidacy. Mr. Cuomo will carry the millstone of New York State; he will be held accountable for everything from Eastern liberalism to the A train. He has no foreign policy experience, unless you count once running for mayor of New York City.
But Mr. Cuomo is this country's most eloquent elected official, and he will engage. He is the kind of man who will argue, not only about how many angels can dance on the head of a pin, but about whether they're doing the mambo, and whether they are doing it right. He could run a substantive campaign, a campaign that takes on George Bush's empty platitudes and policies and sets a clear agenda for a party that has lost its way in a welter of polling and positioning. If Mr. Cuomo was the candidate, the Presidential debates could be more than talking podiums.
The Republicans might still prevail. But there would have been a race, a contest, a real national debate over who we are and what we want, instead of a consumer survey on dueling slogans. And the Democrats would have left footprints -- maybe not to the White House, but footprints nonetheless.
Mr. Cuomo's dark and complex personality is ill suited to a popularity contest. He has a self-righteous streak that detractors say will do him in on the national stage; he is the kind of man who, when described as self-righteous, will call to tell you you're wrong about that. He rarely admits mistakes; what that means is that he sticks with some positions he should modify, and sticks with others, like his often unpopular opposition to the death penalty, that are worth sticking with. To say he is principled is an understatement. He can also be unlikable.
His virtues are not cuddly: a great mind, a keen sense of right and wrong, an ability to get to the heart of an argument. He communicates the agita of the immigrant child who simultaneously sees the dream gone wrong and believes it can come true. His patience with handlers would be short, his patience with pap and obfuscation shorter still. He is not politic, an odd thing for a politician and maybe a refreshing thing, too.
The Democrats need to stop worrying about winning and start concentrating on speaking up, on fighting hard, on setting their own agenda, on giving people something to vote for for a change. By stature, intellect and disposition, Mr. Cuomo is best qualified to do that. And so he should.

HEADLINE: George Washington Acted on His Anti-Slavery Convictions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your July 29 article about a long-forgotten member of the Virginia planter aristocracy, Robert Carter 3d, who arranged for the manumission of his slaves, erroneously suggests that George Washington did not feel similarly "compelled to extend freedom to the dark-skinned people" under his ownership. 
 All of Washington's slaves were set free in December 1800, pursuant to a provision in the general's will. In the words of James Thomas Flexner, Washington's biographer, the country's first President "proved to be the only Virginia founding father to free all his slaves."
Mr. Flexner's voluminous writings on Washington trace a growing anxiety, leading to obsession, with the moral and practical dilemmas posed by slavery. At some point in Washington's early adulthood, he made a decision not to buy and sell slaves, choosing rather to encourage his slaves to marry and lead some sort of settled family life.
The practical effects of this decision led to Washington's eventually having to support a large, unproductive slave population, consisting of the very young and the very old, several times larger than what would have been needed to perform the labor at Mount Vernon and his other properties. But his convictions forbade any attempts at breaking up families, and he never wavered from his early decision against participating in the slave trade.
Like virtually all of his contemporaries, Washington was baffled by the question of how slaves could be set free and, in effect, set adrift in a society that was ill prepared to absorb them. On a public level, according to Mr. Flexner, Washington supported Alexander Hamilton's financial proposals because the kind of mercantile economy Hamilton envisioned "had no need for slavery."
Privately, Washington entertained thoughts about renting his properties to English farmers, who would then have been expected to hire as field workers the slaves who were freed when his properties were put up for lease. He also experimented with a kind of vocational training that would have given his slaves at least a minimal training in the skills and trades that might make them employable in a fully free society.
In the end, Washington had to settle for a blanket manumission. Under the terms of his will (Washington died on Dec. 14, 1799), all of his slaves were to be set free when his wife died. He further required his heirs to feed and clothe all aged and ailing former slaves as long as they remained living. Mrs. Washington freed all of the slaves more than a year before her own death, and the Washington family continued making payments of various kinds to former slaves until 1833.
 
DAVID LONIE
Washington, Aug. 5, 1991
