HEADLINE: On Language;
Chinese Relations

BYLINE: BY NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; Nicholas D. Kristof is chief of The New York Times bureau in Beijing. William Safire is on vacation.

 BODY:
ARABIC IS A RICH language. There are words for losing one's children, for a carriage taking a virgin into battle, for a disease striking camels in the head. But when I was sweltering in Cairo in the early 1980's, while studying Arabic, what struck me most was that there was only one word, talg, that refers, if somewhat hazily, to either ice or snow.
At the time I was yearning for a good talg-fall in Cairo, I learned that the Eskimo language has several dozen words for "snow." Which makes perfect sense: the diversity in a language reflects the interests and obsessions of the society speaking it. As a continuing student of the Chinese language, I find that Chinese is especially rich in the specific areas one would expect, given the culture. 
 There are at least 19 words for silk, for example, and 8 for rice. Why? Well, gao refers to a tough, white silk; qi is a patterned silk; qian is a blue-red silk fabric; kuang is uncombed silk thread; si is regular silk thread; chou is another term for silk fabrics, and so on. As for rice, fan refers to the cooked product; dao to the rice when it is still in the paddy; xian to long-grained rice; mi to the husked kernels, and, in some dialects, gu means unhusked kernels.
Since the Chinese care even more for their families than they do for their rice or silk, there is a profusion of words for relations. For instance, Chinese has five words for "uncle." It depends on whether he is your father's older or younger brother, or your mother's brother, or your father's sister's husband, or your mother's sister's husband. In English, the word "cousin" is applied to males as well as females, older people as well as younger people, maternal as well as paternal relations. Not so in Chinese; the rules that apply to "uncle" also apply to "cousin."
When Americans hurl abuse at each other, they sometimes question each other's paternity or bring in each other's mothers. But the Chinese denounce uncles and grandfathers as well as parents, and one common insult calumniates the preceding 18 generations of the accursed one's family.
Chinese has about two dozen expressions for "wife," but in this case the richness of the language doesn't indicate any special esteem. On the contrary, most of the terms are unflattering: "the inside person," "the old woman," "the one on the bed," "the children's mother," "the cook." One reason for the many expressions may be that until early this century it wasn't unusual for peasant women not to have given names. As they grew up, they were identified by numbers: second sister, fourth sister and so on.
"My mother didn't have a name, as far as I know," says an octogenarian friend who grew up in the countryside. I asked him what his father called his mother, and his brow furrowed. Then his face lighted up. " 'Hey,' " he said triumphantly. "He called her 'Hey.' "
Where English is particularly rich, and Chinese poor, is in the areas of science and democracy -- the two slogans that since 1919 have been a rallying cry for change. Indeed, "science" and "democracy" are sometimes known as S  Xiansheng (Mr. S) and D Xiansheng (Mr. D), to signify that they are foreign guests who still have not taken up Chinese residency.
Although law, fa, is an ancient concept in China, it historically wasn't a champion of individual rights but a means of punishment. Indeed, the only area of the law in which the Chinese language distinguishes itself is in the designation of punishments. Gua refers to execution by slicing (a convict literally cut into pieces); yi refers to the cutting off of a felon's nose. (Both are mercifully no longer judicial sentences.)
Most of China's political vocabulary is relatively recent. Chinese expressions for "freedom," "politics," "democracy" and "economy" are all only about a century old. And words like "individualism" or "privacy" still have a negative connotation in Chinese, reflecting the traditional lack of concern for individual rights.
"This is a factional language, based on groups rather than individuals, and an inclusive language," says Geremie Barme, an Australian scholar whose mastery of the Chinese language gives other foreigners the "red eye disease" (one of the many expressions for "jealousy").
What's an inclusive language? In English, we tend to hold each other verbally at arm's length; it's the opposite in Chinese. Friends address each other as "Big Brother" or "Big Sister," as a sign of respect, and children are required to address adults who are friends or acquaintances of the family as "Auntie" or "Uncle." This has to be done carefully, however. I once disconcerted a Chinese friend by calling her "Little Sister" -- often a prelude to a pickup.
The two ways of saying "we" in Chinese help explain the usefulness of an inclusive expression. The first kind, women (pronounced waugh-mun), refers to the speaker and one or more other people but doesn't include the person being addressed. The second kind, zamen, includes the person being addressed. Thus, a young woman going out with her boyfriend might tell her parents that "women are leaving," but a group of boys flirting with some girls will suggest that "zamen go to a movie." By comparison, English looks rather aloof and threadbare for lacking an inclusive "we." But never mind. Za men have another area, besides science and democracy, where English triumphs: sex.
English seems to have far more words that are sex-related than contemporary Chinese. (Ancient Chinese pornography is another matter, but that rich vocabulary has been largely forgotten.) No one knows if this is because Americans are obsessed with sex or because the Chinese take lots of cold showers -- hot-water heaters still being a rarity in China. A researcher of sexuality in Shanghai is stumped by the linguistic challenge of polling Chinese about their sexual practices. There are no common expressions for "foreplay" or "orgasm," and so surveys must resort to vaguer terms that people will at least understand. Instead of inquiring about the frequency of "a sexual high tide" -- the technical term for "climax" -- the surveys simply ask women how often they enjoy "a pleasant feeling."
It would be rash to draw conclusions on what this says about the Chinese, especially when there are more than 1.1 billion of them. Still, it's nice to know that English has the edge in a few areas. Science. Democracy. Sex. A language could do worse.

LENGTH: 1990 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
It's a Tough Job, but Somebody's Got to Want It

BYLINE: By HILARY DE VRIES; Hilary de Vries writes about theater and film for The Los Angeles Times and other publications.

 BODY:
When Andre Bishop, artistic director of Playwrights Horizons, was named the new head of Lincoln Center Theater in March, he seemed the logical choice: the leader of one of Off Broadway's most successful theaters was simply moving to a larger complex Off Broadway.
Mr. Bishop's appointment, after a two-month search, is the most visible in a number of job shifts now occurring in the nation's regional theaters. In Lincoln Center's case, they got their man. But within the last year 14 not-for-profit theaters have put up "help wanted" signs for their top artistic jobs -- and in some cases, the postman has rung only once, if at all. 
 At a time of tight money and increasing deficits, when an artistic director has to wear a number of hats, the vacancies -- at such theaters as the Cincinnati Playhouse, the Dallas Theater Center, the New Mexico Repertory Theater and the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco -- prompt questions about the future of not-for-profit theater in this country.
"There is a real tenuousness to the industry now," says one managing director who requested anonymity. "All this shifting around of artistic directors is deadly to a sense of personal artistic vision. When a director leaves, the continuity of the theater becomes the responsibility of the trustees and not the artists. More and more it is a question of 'Here's our theater. Can you run it?' "
That scenario, some say -- especially when it involves retirement by a theater's artistic founder -- may slowly but surely be transforming the nature of American regional theater from a place of idiosyncratic art to a committee-run institution in which directors will be looked upon more as employees than as leaders.
But for the short term, filling the vacancies is a priority. "There are not enough artistic directors to go around," says Zelda Fichandler, co-founder of the Arena Stage in Washington and artistic director of the Acting Company in New York. "The question is, Can we find enough new people willing and able to take on the demands of the job?"
At first glance, a job description that may include courting some of the country's top playwrights and actors, and attending gala openings while mingling with a community's financial elite can sound like a dream. But this cluster of vacancies comes at a particularly critical juncture -- when a recession economy and cuts in Federal, state and private arts support are forcing theaters to shorten seasons, reduce operations and mount more conservative repertories, which hamper artistic innovation. Though theaters, like other arts organizations, have weathered adverse economies before, the recession, magnified by the cutbacks in arts support, has had the effect of a one-two punch that many directors have never experienced. While the 300-plus regional theaters provide more work for artists than the commercial theater, almost half the regionals now operate in the red, with budget deficits ranging from a few thousand dollars to more than half a million dollars annually. Last year seven theaters, unable to bridge the gap, closed.
For a number of stage directors, running a not-for-profit theater -- even at a salary that can range from $25,000 to above $100,000 -- is less and less about artistry and more and more about managing a business venture in which the needs of actors, playwrights and directors may at times be secondary. Regional theaters are no longer tiny pioneering stages. Most are multimillion-dollar institutions with hefty subscriber lists, extensive boards of directors, large administrative staffs, impressive budgets -- and, too often, impressive deficits. As one regional board member put it: "We are looking for an artist who can also be a C.E.O."
The recent rash of vacancies -- from resignations, retirements, deaths and, in some cases, terminations -- is occurring at large prestigious theaters like Lincoln Center, where annual budgets can reach $14 million, as well as at smaller companies, like the Seattle Group Theater, that operate on several hundred thousand dollars a year.
Almost all theater boards have created managing director positions to reduce the growing administrative tasks. But the artistic director of a regional theater -- unlike the director of a major orchestra or ballet company, who is often free of such duties -- is required to select and stage a season, direct several productions, oversee extensive fund-raising and marketing campaigns, negotiate medical and other union benefits, and at the same time manage a large staff.
"You are expected to be both a Balanchine and a Lincoln Kirstein," says David Chambers, an associate professor at the Yale University School of Drama and former chairman of the theater panel of the National Endowment for the Arts. "But one of the questions I think we have to ask is whether anyone's work has gotten better because they've served as an artistic director. In most instances, it has not."
According to Peter Zeisler, executive director of the Theater Communications Group, the service organization for not-for-profit theater, "These are just less attractive jobs now. There isn't one theater that has more money this year than it had last year, and we are beginning to see artistic directors stepping down simply because of these limited and declining resources." According to his organization's figures, endowment grants to theaters have fallen below the rate of inflation for the last five years. Last year, collectively, they fell by 5 percent. In addition, many states, including New York and New Jersey, have cut their arts budgets from as much as 30 to 80 percent -- "draconian" amounts, Mr. Zeisler says.
In a number of recent interviews with directors leaving theaters this year, one of the most frequently cited reasons was financial pressure.
David Frank, the artistic director of the Studio Theater in Buffalo (budget: $3 million; deficit: $500,000), resigned this year after 11 seasons. "There have been radical shifts in our theater's financial dynamics," he says (this year's budget is $600,000 less than last year's). "We've all had to contract, do smaller, more conservative shows. I realized this was not the theater where I was going to get to do my 'Hamlet.' "
Charles Towers, who left the Virginia Stage Company (budget: $1.2 million; deficit: $500,000) in June when his contract lapsed, says: "We all grew up thinking that regional theaters were a continuously expanding operation. But every city in the country may not be able to afford a regional theater today." (The Stage Company's current budget is $800,000 less than last year's.)
Several second-generation artistic directors -- namely Garland Wright at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, Des McAnuff at the La Jolla Playhouse in California and Robert Falls at the Goodman Theater in Chicago -- have made long-term commitments to their institutions while continuing to create innovative work. But the overall challenge remains -- how to maintain a theater's vigor and purpose at a time when fiscal and artistic challenges are redefining the role of the theaters and their artistic directors.
To date, four of the 14 theaters seeking artistic directors this year have found replacements. Ten are still searching for new artistic leaders to replace directors who have retired (such as Edward Hastings from the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco) or moved on to larger theaters or other arts organizations (such as Stan Wojewodski Jr., who left the Center Stage in Baltimore to take over the Yale Repertory Theater, and Ruben Sierra, founder of the Seattle Group Theater, who now works for the California Institute of Arts). In some instances, there have been unforeseen, and occasionally acrimonious, departures (such as Worth Gardner's resignation from the Cincinnati Playhouse in June). In the case of two theaters -- the Dallas Theater Center (including the Arts District Theater) and the Indiana Repertory Theater -- the deaths of the directors have prompted the search.
Although the causes of these departures are different -- and indeed the theater sizes range from 2,000 subscribers at the Seattle Group Theater to 16,000 at the American Conservatory Theater -- there are several common factors in seeking replacements.
In most cases theaters conduct a campaign for a new director by setting up a search committee. Frequently boards hire independent arts consultants to aid the search, which can begin with a list of dozens of names -- many of them directors whose work the boards will not have seen. Although the lists are frequently made up of freelance and existing artistic directors, because so many theaters are seeking new leadership, the boards are increasingly considering actors, dramaturgs, designers and even playwrights as candidates. "A lot of people want these jobs because there's no freelance work out there," says Ms. Fichandler. "But I don't think scene designers and dramaturgs are that qualified. An artistic director should, ideally, be a director." While no one would speak for attribution, it is not uncommon for theaters to settle for their second or third choices when the more in-demand directors decline these jobs for better prospects.
And then there is the allure of Hollywood: Andrew Shea, the founder of the New Mexico Repertory Theater, resigned this spring after eight years at the helm to pursue a career in film and television. Last year, he says, "I looked carefully at the resources in this community available to support this theater and what I found in New Mexico was very, very slow -- if any -- growth."
Under Mr. Shea's direction the theater has grown from a $500,000-a-year fledgling operation ("where I personally typed the letters to all potential donors") to a $1.4 million company serving two communities -- Santa Fe and Albuquerque. The theater has no operating deficit, but Mr. Shea trimmed this year's budget by more than $300,000. "The recession is terrible here," he says, "and there are no major corporate donors in the state. I got to the point where I wondered if all the time I was spending on cultivating donors and grant makers wasn't better spent on developing my own work."
Several departing artistic directors say that financial difficulties are only part of a larger problem -- how to preserve a theater's original artistic intent.
"We've become no different from summer stock or the commercial theater -- we're simply playing for zip codes," says Gary Gisselman, who resigned as artistic director of the Arizona Theater Company this year to take over the Children's Theater Company in Minneapolis. "The big problem in regional theater today is how do we define success, and the most common answers are percentage of capacity and bottom line. I finally had to ask myself why I was here."
The focus should always be on artistic vision, insists Mr. McAnuff of the La Jolla Playhouse. "It is possible to get access to the expertise you need to run a multimillion-dollar theater. You should be able to have a partner in your managing director."
At the Goodman Theater in Chicago the idea of teamwork was expanded to include two associate artistic directors in addition to Mr. Falls, the artistic director. That troika was seen by some arts consultants as a model for other large regional theaters. But for smaller, poorer companies, multiple directorships remain prohibitively expensive.
For many artistic directors, the rewards of running a regional theater, be it large or small, continue to outweigh the challenges.
"It's still a great job," says Richard Hamburger, artistic director of the Portland Stage Company in Maine (budget: $1 million; deficit in 1990: $20,000). "It's definitely a harder job. But the feeling we have is that this financial adversity will pass. And running a theater is the only way you can create a body of work within a community that can share your vision."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1966 words

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
By Any Name, Roseanne Is Roseanne Is Roseanne

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
Ladies and gentlemen, meet the first, er, lady of Prime-Time Television, Roseanne Barr. Wait a minute. Make that Roseanne Arnold.
Whether as Barr or Arnold, Roseanne clearly loves to keep friends, fans and enemies off balance. She is not easy. She has cast aside many of the people who were crucial to her initial success, including her manager and agent. A prototypical outsider -- she grew up in Utah as a Jew who attended Mormon services -- she thumbs her nose at the Hollywood establishment and, indeed, all establishments. But even in that, she is not predictable; Roseanne promised her second husband, Tom Arnold, that she would take his name if he converted to Judaism, and has now asked to be referred to as Mrs. Arnold. 
 The comedienne has gone down a bumpy and often dangerous road in the five years since her career began taking off nationally. It has been a journey that, in all likelihood, would have destroyed any other entertainer. She has certainly paid a public-relations price.
This year, once again, the good citizens who confer the Emmy Awards have failed even to nominate Roseanne Arnold or her hit television show "Roseanne." But their uppity insult serves only to make the Emmys (which will be given out next Sunday, in a ceremony to be broadcast live on the Fox network at 8 P.M.) all the more irrelevant.
In an era of skinny worship, she unapologetically vacillates between being fat and very fat, bragging with Rabelaisian gusto of her active sex life. After screeching her way through the National Anthem at a baseball game last summer, she even had George Bush denouncing her as "disgraceful."
Professing to be a militant feminist, she makes many prominent feminists uneasy, in some instances, apparently, because she's not terribly, well, feminine. An outspoken supporter of rights for gay men and lesbians, she can make wisecracks that leave both of those groups wincing. She refuses to take men seriously ("They are so funny to me, I just find them hysterical"). And her raucous antics, public and private, are calculated affronts to middle-class propriety.
One fact, no doubt unsettling to the Emmy-conferring Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, just won't go away. Despite the fervent ill wishes of many bruised egos on the sidelines, "Roseanne," on Tuesday nights at 9 on ABC, continues to be one of commercial television's biggest hits, this past season remaining in the top 10, more often in the top 5 (detractors are often reduced to sputtering that it could have been a bigger hit).
For three years now, some experts, taking note of backstage chaos, have been predicting the demise of the show. In a recent magazine poll, posing the question: "Which of the following people, if any, would you least like to take a very long ride with?" Mrs. Arnold was first, ahead of Andrew Dice Clay.
But, obviously, a good many people out there like her. The ratings, as advertisers attest, can't be ignored. Who connects with this fiercely independent, caustic and difficult woman? The demographics indicate that her most loyal fans are women between the ages of 18 and 34. But that doesn't tell you much. The comic Alan King, on his Comedy Central interview series called "Inside the Comedy Mind," came closer when, opening a recent session with Mrs. Arnold, he rattled off a list of viewers she supposedly represents:
"The hopeless underclass of the female sex. Polyester-clad, overweight occupants of the slow track. Fast-food waitresses, factory workers, housewives -- members of the invisible pink-collar army. The despised, the jilted, the underpaid."
Mrs. Arnold, her face lighting up with delight, said, "In other words, the coolest people." At the end of the half hour, Mr. King reminded Roseanne that she had once described herself as "one happy fat" woman. Would she stick with that? Laughing, Roseanne said she would only add two words: "One happy, smart, fat, rich" woman. Don't underestimate the "smart" element. Tackle Roseanne Arnold at your own risk.
Arsenio Hall got a taste of her wrath in January in a Home Box Office special called "Roseanne: Live From Trump Castle." Near the end of the embarrassingly messy show -- she said it was meant to be a takeoff of aging stars doing glitzy Las Vegas turns, but nobody got the joke -- the comedienne announced that she was fed up with Mr. Hall constantly using her as the butt of insulting fat jokes. She proceeded to issue a warning in the form of a capsule autobiography:
"I'm 37 years old. I've got four kids. I'm Jewish and I was raised in Salt Lake City, Utah. I was raised a Mormon and my dad sold crucifixes door-to-door to Mexicans. When I was 7, I fell down and bit off my whole lip and had to have that sewn back on. When I was 16, I got hit by a car and got my head impaled on the hood ornament. I got pregnant the first time I ever had sex. My parents made me give her up for adoption. I found her 18 years later after her face was splashed across the front page of The National Enquirer. Spent eight months in a state mental institution. Hitchhiked across country three times all by myself -- with hepatitis. Lived in a car, a cabin and a cave. Married a guy just because he had a [bleep] bathtub. Had three more kids. He treated me like [bleep] for 16 years and when I finally had the guts to dump that s.o.b., I have to pay him half the money I make for the rest of my goddamn life."
The message to Mr. Hall: You want to mess with me? Don't even think about it. I've been through it all, and I'm as tough as they come.
All of which seems belligerently clear enough, but then there are the inevitable Roseanne contradictions. During the same act, she sarcastically offered to say one nice thing about Mr. Hall: "It's not that often that we get to see a black nerd on television." Hoots from the audience. Then the Roseanne kicker: "I mean most nerds are white people, like you." More laughter, this time with a nervous edge. Then, inevitably, a month or so ago, Mrs. Arnold appeared on "The Arsenio Hall Show," and host and guest positively cooed over each other, promising to get together more often. The not to be overlooked upshot: Mr. Hall is no longer telling Roseanne fat jokes.
Autobiography is an integral part of the Roseanne routine. The dividing line between the performer and woman is just about invisible. Her early "domestic goddess" act was all the more hilarious for its quite evident authenticity. And even stuffed into the formula of a sitcom, the comedienne transcends the working-class housewife character of Roseanne Conner with her own unmistakable personality.
The series had its gestation in a 1987 HBO special that, tongue in cheek, constructed a sitcom framework around her stand-up performance. The current ABC series carries the credit "created by Matt Williams" but "developed by" would be more apt.
Mrs. Arnold herself is clearly the creator in this territory. Much of the off-camera tumult has stemmed from her dissatisfaction with producers and writers she considered too bound to the traditional rules, or cliches, of weekly sitcom. Saying that she was being reduced to little more than zingy one-liners, she has insisted that more of her own concerns be allowed to emerge in the scripts.
She has not been, to put it mildly, diplomatic. One executive producer, Jeff Harris, announced his 1990 departure with a large ad inVariety: "I have chosen not to return to the show next season. Instead, my wife and I have decided to share a vacation in the relative peace and quiet of Beirut." The star's subsequent comment: "Yeah, they're not going to think you're very funny in Beirut, either."
This past season, Mrs. Arnold said that the series was trying to recruit writers among comics who have never written for television, people who "are off the beaten track and are real angry." In fact, much to the consternation of her detractors, the show is generally better (although some of the scripts attributed to Tom Arnold have been noticeably ragged). Beneath the sitcom surface, beyond the family crises that can be tidily solved in 22 minutes, "Roseanne" can be slyly subversive.
This sitcom simply refuses to act like most of the others. Here is a show on which, not infrequently, people don't have enough money to buy things -- right in the heart of Consumerland. This particular family is strong enough to admit that they don't always like one another very much. Dan (John Goodman) is a construction worker who can't always find work. Roseanne has led a factory strike, been unemployed and now struggles along as a minimum-wage waitress in a coffee shop. She and the show don't bat an eye when her boss (Martin Mull) casually reveals that he is gay.
This is not "Leave It to Beaver," obviously. It's also not "All in the Family." Far from being a dingbat like Edith Bunker, Roseanne Conner is in charge, and her big teddy-bear of a husband, still clearly lusting for her, couldn't be happier. Mrs. Arnold has acknowledged some debt to Jackie Gleason, another top banana who never got even an honorary award from the Emmy people, but his Ralph Kramden was a considerably safer character than the militant Roseanne Conner.
Writing in The New Republic magazine, Barbara Ehrenreich describes Mrs. Arnold's stance as "proletarian feminism," something that is not "a professional, careerist woman's thing." In The National Review, on the other hand, Jim Atkinson, referring to the comedienne as "the Hulk Hogan of feminism," perceives her as "a cunning marketeer who has figured out how to parlay a form of vulgar reverse sexism into stardom." Tom Arnold, grinning affably during a television interview, put still another spin on the Roseanne phenomenon: "We're America's worst nightmare -- white trash with money."
There are those among her former and present colleagues who insist that Mrs. Arnold thrives on discord, working best in conditions of turmoil. There is always the possibility that, at any given moment, she may stumble across the threshold of career disintegration. One thing is certain: she will not sit still long enough to be pigeonholed.
 
 
RARELY A DULL MOMENT
 Some of the more memorable events in Roseanne Barr's life as a star:
October 1988: "Roseanne" has its debut on ABC and becomes one of the top three series on TV.
January 1989: Matt Williams, an executive producer for "Roseanne" credited with its creation, is forced off the show by the star, who says either he goes or she will.
September 1989: "Roseanne: My Life as a Woman" is published and becomes a best seller.
December 1989: Her film debut, in "She-Devil" co-starring Meryl Streep, bombs at the box office.
Jan. 20, 1990: Ms. Barr marries Tom Arnold, a comedian six years younger than she.
March 1990: Jeff Harris, the series' executive producer, resigns and places an ad in Variety saying that he has decided to "vacation in the relative peace and quiet of Beirut."
PUB-DATE: July 25, 1990:
September 1990: "Little Rosie," an animated children's show featuring the comedienne's voice, has its debut on ABC but lasts only one season, because the network insists that more boys be added and the star refuses.
December 1990: Ms. Barr provides the voice of a wisecracking little girl in the film "Look Who's Talking Too."
June 1991: Roseanne and Tom Arnold settle a $35 million lawsuit against The National Enquirer and The Star and regain their love letters, published by the tabloids. Terms of the settlement are not disclosed. The couple renews their marriage vows in a religious ceremony and Ms. Barr changes her professional name to Roseanne Arnold. -- Michael Kuby

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1219 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Motel Guests And Security

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
THE issue of personal safety in budget-rate motels has been thrust to the forefront. Last month, The Wall Street Journal reported on a $10 million settlement made by Motel 6 on a woman who was attacked, robbed and raped in 1988 by two ex-convicts at one of the chain's motels in Fort Worth.
A week later, the victim, using the pseudonym "Mary," appeared on the Larry King Live show on CNN along with a former Fort Worth police chief and a security consultant from New York. 
 Motel 6 declined to talk to The Times about the case, except to say that the safety and security of guests was the essence of the hospitality industry. The chain has the largest share of business in the "budget" category, according to Ida Simmons of D. K. Shifflet, a travel research company in McLean, Va.
A number of security experts interviewed for this article pointed out that the safety of a motel guest depends not only on the security offered by the individual motel but also on its location: If the motel is in a high-crime area, it will hold the same risks as neighboring businesses and public areas. "A sign is not a guarantee of safety," said Anthony G. Marshall, dean of the School of Hospitality Management of Florida International University.
In motels, it is impossible to assess the likelihood of crime either by chain name or by price level, according to Charles G. Slepian, a New York lawyer and security consultant who says he has advised every major chain. Hotels and motels consider their crime statistics proprietary information, he said. "But my gut feeling is that the rate is a lot smaller for the hotel and motel industry overall than for apartment houses, shopping malls, theaters and parking lots," Mr. Slepian said.
"It may be the safest part of the commercial world because of the landlord's obligation to care for the guest, a duty under law that goes back to the Middle Ages."
Like others who deal with hoteliers' legal liabilities, Mr. Marshall emphasized that a motel had to exercise "reasonable care" for the safety of its guests. This is based on what the motel has experienced in the past, so that a luxury hotel with a clientele that is likely to carry valuable jewelry might be expected to have room safes. Or a budget motel with a history of burglaries might be expected to have window grilles.
It was the breach of this responsibility to provide for the guest's safety, of course, that led to the Fort Worth negligence suit after the two ex-convicts, who had been loitering around the motel, barged into the room when the guest opened the door to leave for supper, raped her repeatedly, stole her professional camera equipment and drove off in her auto.
 
Assessing Risk
There are questions that prospective guests can ask to help them assess their risk, and there are practical measures to safeguard against attacks in the parking lot and break-ins and thefts in the hallway.
If a motel is very inexpensive and is in a high-crime area, it is probably wise to pass by; no action by the motel that does not violate basic liberties is likely to be adequate to keep drug dealers from renting rooms, or to prevent criminals from preying on guests in a place where drugs or prostitution are prevalent. And one hotelier said that people loitering in the parking lot should "send up your antenna." Mr. Slepian said, "If there are steel bars and plates of glass between you and the room clerk, it puts you on notice."
If you do not like what you see, and you have guaranteed your reservation with a credit-card number, call from down the road and cancel it. Even after 6 P.M., some motels will not penalize you.
Asking a motel on the phone if it has security guards is bootless, the experts agree. If there are guards they're unlikely to be on duty around the clock all week.
The Fort Worth case raises the question of whether women traveling alone, who are more vulnerable to sex crimes, would be smarter to stay in higher-priced places with enclosed parking areas, avoiding economy lodgings altogether. Because 38 percent of business travelers today are women, this question affects many people on the road.
Most of the experts responded that higher price was no automatic guarantee. The question of the surroundings was considered a better way to judge.
Women who travel on business say they prefer a brightly lighted fenced outdoor parking lot to an underground park-it-yourself garage, where you may end up parking a long way from the elevator entrance.
As for room locale, if it is next to the motel office, it may not be so quiet as elsewhere, but it may enhance your ability to get help if you need it.
 
Suspiciously Cheap
 A room rate that is too low should be a warning: at the range of $12 to $20, no matter where you are, one hotelier said, the motel is probably not hiring staff of a caliber that will be alert to dangers, to broken locks and doorknobs, to missing bars for sliding doors. The margin has been cut too thin.
Small rural motels where the proprietors do the cleaning, mow the lawn and run the front office are a different matter, but larger motels under $20 a night may clear a profit in ways that do not augur well for safety: advertising rooms for rent by the hour, for example.
If the place appears clean, safe and well-lighted, there are other things to check. Rooms that open off a corridor entered with a key give better privacy.
Many new inside-corridor motels are built with only one entrance -- past the front desk, which also enhances safety.
Door chains are of use only if they will not rip out under great pressure. Separate deadbolts into the door frame, in addition to doorknob locks, are much better. Mr. Marshall said that 95 percent of all hotels have them now.
The standard metal key with an engraved room number is a virtual invitation to thieves. If all a motel provides is the doorknob and a key, and there is a break-in, insurers and judges in Florida, Texas and Wisconsin have decided in guests' favor. Ray Ellis, head of risk management for the American Hotel and Motel Association, advised his members that if they provided only a doorknob and a key, and were involved in break-ins, "you settle out of court."
If the keys have been cross-coded so that the number is not the same as the room number, you are better off. Doors that open with electronic punch cards are recoded after each occupancy and the previous guest cannot get into your room.
At Sleep Inns, the budget category in the Choice Hotels chain, you enter both the corridor and your room by inserting your own credit card into an electronic slot. The 10 Sleep Inns are all new and these lock systems cost $500 a room, according to Bob Hazard, chief executive officer of Choice Hotels. He used a customary industry estimate that each $1,000 of expense to build a room results in a $1 increase in the room rate. Others in the hotel business say it has now probably reached $2.
To go back and redo an older lock system this way would cost $650 a room, Mr. Hazard estimated, which might mean a nightly rate increase of $2 to $ 4: You are not likely to find such gadgets at an old $18 motel.
Every guest room door should have a peephole; it is a trivial expense. Whatever the key, it is no help if you open your door to a stranger.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (77%);

HEADLINE: LINCOLN CENTER;
New York: City of Commerce

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Paul Goldberger's essay "A Shot of Cultural Adrenaline at Lincoln Center" [July 28] very reluctantly accepts "Faustian pacts with the world of private real-estate development": "We like to pretend that our cultural institutions are clean and pure, not sullied by their connections to commerce." The "pact" was the financing of new facilities for Lincoln Center through a new condominium development on its property. 
 Mr. Goldberger's essay is replete with diatribes about "watching real-estate developers get rich for two decades" and a cultural "institution whose real estate has made profits for so many others."
Such specious attacks on "commerce" in a city that is by its nature, predominantly, a commercial center and whose cultural activities are greatly dependent upon the prosperity of its commercial base is indicative of the economic illiteracy that pervades much of the city. The availability of an adequate return on investment, pejoratively known as "profit," is as essential to a healthy future for New York as any environmental concern. Certainly this should now be crystal clear considering the current high level of investment without return. The consequent damaging effect on city revenues and fiscal conditions has already resulted in substantial (and could lead to more severe) cutbacks in social services, education and, yes, cultural activities.
The essay continuously rails against the 60-story condominium tower, which enabled Lincoln Center facilities to be improved. But the residences in this one building represent a meaningful proportion of the meager 6,000 apartments for which construction permits were filed during all of last year, despite the city's extremely deficient and overaged housing supply.
I, and all the developers I know, could not care less about these constant vituperations against us, in particular, and development, in general. But 7.5 million people live in this city and 8 million work here, and they are dependent on its commerce and its housing supply.
Mr. Goldberger concludes by calling for a strengthening of "the city's cultural presence at a moment when the need could not be more urgent." Even more urgent is the need for understanding that this can be accomplished only through stimulating -- rather than haranguing -- the city's development and economy.
 
SEYMOUR B. DURST
New York
 
The writer is the chief executive officer and president of the Durst Organization, a real-estate development company.
 
 Paul Goldberger replies: Mr. Durst has read my piece with such a bias that he missed the point altogether. He is so defensive about the role of real estate in New York that he accuses me of "haranguing" real-estate developers and attacking the profit motive when all I did was question the intimate connections between commercial developers and supposedly independent cultural institutions.

HEADLINE: Battling Barriers To Affordable Homes

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
THE Interfaith Housing Development Corporation of Bucks County, Pa., wanted to build five subsidized one-family houses on land donated by a local church so that a few low-income families could afford to own homes in one of the East Coast's most affluent areas.
Neighbors, however, had other ideas. 
 "The town board demanded that we make a lot of expensive and irrelevant improvements to the road before we could get the permits," said the Rev. Alfred Krass, director of the nonprofit housing group. "Then they said we would have to pave the parking lot at my church and install lights and curbs and drains, even though the housing would have off-street parking. They just harassed us and made the project so expensive that it would no longer be affordable."
What Mr. Krass and his nonprofit housing group encountered seems almost a hallowed tradition in most American suburbs -- measures that make housing ever-more expensive to build, thereby making the community less affordable to the less affluent. Whether done by banning apartments, requiring large building lots or imposing environmental or strict planning rules, the results are often the same: Affordably priced housing is hard to produce.
The matter got an airing at the White House in June with with the delivery to President Bush of a special report on regulatory barriers to affordable housing from a special panel assembled by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The report, titled, "Not In My Backyard -- Removing Barriers to Affordable Housing," made a Federal case out of a local issue when it declared:
"Millions of Americans are being priced out of buying or renting the kind of housing they otherwise could afford were it not for a web of government regulations. For them, America -- the land of opportunity -- has become the land of a frustrating and often unrewarded search for an affordable home."
Just how many millions of Americans are being priced out of a home in the suburbs was spelled out in a separate report, issued by the Census Bureau in May. It found that 57 percent of American families -- 56 million of them -- could not afford a median-priced home in the area where they live. Among these, it found, were three-quarters of black and Hispanic families, amounting to 9.9 million families, and 94 percent of couples under 25, or 3.4 million families.
Even with a 10 percent down payment, instead of the usual 20 percent, only 20 percent of white people who are now renting and 4 percent of current black renters can afford to buy a house, according to the 1990 State of the Nation's Housing report from the Joint Center on Housing Studies at Harvard University.
In some areas, including New Jersey, according to the H.U.D. report, restrictive zoning rules, gold-plated construction standards, strict environmental rules, requirements for expensive off-site improvements and multi-layered approval procedures push housing costs up by 25 to 35 percent in some areas, putting homes beyond the means of even middle-class buyers.
But by focusing on zoning rules and payments imposed on builders to the exclusion of other reasons that many people cannot afford decent housing, the H.U.D. report becomes a political as well as an analytical document. The panel advances an essentially conservative way, deregulation, to reach a progressive goal -- affordable housing.
The report gives only scant attention to what many housing advocates consider the key problem of housing affordability in the country, the low incomes of many citizens. One of the advocates' key solutions has been higher Federal subsidies for housing production so prices or rents can be lowered to where low-income people can afford them.
In past decades, the Federal Government had expensive housing construction and rental subsidy programs to compensate for poverty. But those outlays started to drop during President Jimmy Carter's Administration and fell steeply under President Ronald Reagan as rent subsidies for new construction under the so-called Section 8 program wound down. H.U.D. used $27.8 billion to build low-income housing in 1977, for example, while in 1987 the figure was $5.1 billion.
The H.U.D. report is silent on Federal aid to housing, however.
"We were told that we could not make recommendations for money," said Gale Cincotta, a Chicago housing advocate who was a member of the Advisory Commission on Regulatory Barriers to Affordable Housing, which drew up the report. The commission was headed by Thomas H. Kean, former Governor of New Jersey.
"Affordable" housing is generally taken by housing advocates to mean housing within the reach of low-income people. At one time that meant incomes no higher than 80 percent of the local median income, once the upper limit of qualification for Section 8 subsidies. Nowadays "low income" is more often taken to mean households with incomes below 60 percent of the median, which draws in a higher proportion of the poor, the unemployed and people on welfare.
To others in the housing field, "affordable" refers less to buyers' income level than to the drive to pare construction costs by whittling away at regulations and excessive locally imposed costs. But without subsidies, a house in an area of high land values would still be beyond the means of low-income people, however defined.
Despite the limited focus of the Federal report, housing advocates gave the Bush Administration high marks for raising the issue of barriers to affordable housing.
"This is hardly new ground that they are breaking, but it is always important to get a report at this level," said Barry Zigas, president of the National Low Income Housing Coalition, an advocacy group for housing the poor and the homeless.
APART from the income issue, to Mr. Zigas and others the root cause of the affordability problem is the effort of middle-class suburbanites to keep their communities exclusive by raising barriers to low-cost production. The object is to keep property values from being compromised by new houses worth less than those that already exist. The H.U.D. report hints at this, and a dozen experts said it outright.
"That's what drives it," Mr. Zigas said. "It's 'I moved here to be in a community like this and I don't want those people moving in and ruining it.' "
Larry Raffle, a former New York advertising executive who led the opposition to Mr. Krass's modest Bucks County housing project, agreed that property values have a lot to do with it.
"I don't think there is such an animal as affordable housing for people who won't go out and work," he said in an interview. "The people he would get into those homes were either going to be on unemployment or on welfare, and he would put them into the single best section of the township without any regard to the difference between the property he had and the rest of the community."
And because the church housing group intended to retain ownership of the land under the five new houses, thus keeping them affordable for future owners, Mr. Raffle argued that the new owners would never get a chance to fit in to the community.
"They will be more like renters than owners," he said. "They would never be able to assimilate into the community."
And besides, he added, Bristol Township already has done its share with a large number of low-cost housing units for the elderly.
As a general rule, the greater the number of housing units to the acre, the lower the price will be. Many local governments, including New York City's, have "inclusionary zoning" rules that grant density bonuses to builders willing to reserve a portion of a new project, typically 20 percent, for people on small incomes.
The courts have generally allowed builders to unravel restrictive zoning rules on grounds that include the civil right to decent housing. New Jersey's Mount Laurel statutes, which assign an affordable housing obligation to all municipalities in the state, and developer suits in Mount Kisco and in North Salem in New York's Westchester County were based on such claims.
But when the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People sued the Town of Brookhaven, on Long Island, recently, the suit was thrown out partly on tha ground that the group was not actually trying to build affordable houses.
The H.U.D. report's recommendations focused on the states' obligations to help overcome local barriers to affordable housing. It singled out two state programs, the Mount Laurel housing program and antisnob zoning rules in Massachusetts, as examples worth copying elsewhere. Results from these two programs have been mixed.
In New Jersey, the Mount Laurel laws are based on state court rulings that exclusionary zoning is unconstitutional. But although the state identified a need for 145,700 affordable housing units throughout the state, only about 8,000 have been built so far.
The law allows builders higher densities in exchange for designating 20 percent of a housing project as affordable. And some builders believe that Mount Laurel housing has come at the cost of greater local resistance.
"Prior to Mount Laurel, people wouldn't sit around and define what kind of community they wanted to be," said Patrick O'Keefe, director of the New Jersey Builders Association. "But after Mount Laurel many communities looked at themselves and asked, 'If we want to maintain our community character, how do we discourage this kind of undesirable development?' So in the 1970's and 80's there was a lot of downzoning to large-lot, single-family zoning, and a shift of zoning toward commercial development, to limit the amount of available land."
The Massachussetts law presumes illegal exclusionary zoning in communities with lot minimums of one acre or more per dwelling and allows developers to get state-issued building permits, including density bonuses for affordable units, when local governments refuse to increase densities enough to make affordable housing economically feasible.
Permits for about 20,000 units of new housing have been issued, including about 4,000 subsidized to affordable levels, under the antisnob rules since the program was created in 1969.
But state programs depend on the construction of normal market-rate housing along with the affordable component, and with the current slump in new construction, particularly in the northeast, development of affordable housing by commercial builders has all but stopped.
"There's not much being built these days, affordable or otherwise," said Peter Reinhart, vice president and legal counsel at K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, N.J., one of the East Coast's largest home builders and a pioneer of Mount Laurel housing. "It's a combination of the due process that municipalities have to keep out development, the slowdown in the real estate sector and the regulatory barriers at the state level that apply to all real estate, with no exemption for low-income housing."
New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection staff members recently drew up an internal proposal to relax some environmental rules, such as buffer areas around wetlands, to facilitate low-income housing construction, but the department's enforcement division sidetracked the initiative.
Mr. Reinhart's company recently won a battle of more than three years with Lawrence Township, in central New Jersey, over the company's attempts to build a 700-unit housing project in adjoining Hopewell Township, at a site on the Lawrence line. But neither Hopewell nor Lawrence will have to accept any low-income or affordable units as part of the deal.
Like Civil War draftees who paid others to take their place in the ranks, Hopewell Township was able to shift part of its affordable housing share to Trenton, by forcing Hovnanian to pay $2 million in housing rehabilitation funds to the nearby city of Trenton.
Just a year ago, the Continental Building Company of Bronxville, N.Y., won a landmark case against the Town of North Salem in Westchester County by arguing that the town's zoning for large-lot, one-family homes violated the civil rights of the majority of Westchester residents who could not, as a consequence of the zoning, afford to live there.
"THEY decided that they were going to stop multi-family housing, period," said Stuart R. Shamberg, with the firm of Shamberg Marwell Cherneff, a prominent Westchester land-use law firm. "Why? You've got to know North Salem. These are wealthy people who ride horses and like six-acre estates and want North Salem to stay exactly the way it is."
But Marshall Belkin, North Salem's Town Supervisor, said that Mr. Shamberg's argument "in this case is a bogus argument, even though he did it very well."
"Continental never came to the town to build affordable housing," he said. "They never presented an affordable housing plan. So if you want to talk about affordable housing, I'll be glad to do it, but this case had nothing to do with the subject."
North Salem was simply trying to protect its environment by holding to low-density zoning, Mr. Belkin said. And another builder, Banker North Salem Associates, has plans to build affordable housing in the town.
George M. Raymond, a Manhattan planning consultant who has served several times as court-appointed special master in court-ordered open zoning cases, testified on behalf of Mr. Shamberg's client because he believes that the answer to breaking down barriers to affordable housing lie in the courts applying civil rights and equal access laws that legislatures have already passed.
"As long as the courts are firm," he said in an interview, "antisocial, snobbery objections that are raised to affordable housing are not going to get anywhere."

HEADLINE: In the Slump, a Push to Save Open Space

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
FOLLOWING the example of county governments elsewhere, Dutchess County has announced plans for a land-acquisition program to take advantage of favorable prices in the soft real-estate market.
The Department of Planning has proposed a fund that would provide $3.4 million a year for seven years to acquire more public land for recreation and open space and to buy farmers' development rights in the county, which is 70 miles north of New York City. 
 In recent years, county governments throughout the Northeast have been finding ways of getting as much of their open space as possible under protection before the economy rebounds and developers return. They have bought land outright, contributed to purchases by nonprofit groups and acquired conservation easements, which essentially means buying an owner's development rights to insure that the land remains open.
Counties in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Maryland have in these ways already placed hundreds of thousands of acres of farmland, open space and environmentally sensitive land under long-term protection.
"During the boom growth years in the mid-1980's, land went so fast we didn't have time to do anything about it," said Holly L. Thomas, senior planner with Dutchess County's Department of Planning. "Now we have some breathing room, but we have to act fast."
According to its Planning Department, the county's current land usage makes it ripe for future overdevelopment. It has one of the lowest percentages of publicly owned land in its region, 3.4 percent compared to the regional average of 10.7.
Primarily agricultural a generation ago, Dutchess now has 124,000 acres of farmland left, covering about one-fourth of the county. Since 1982 it has been losing it at a rate of 2,700 acres a year.
The program's long-term goals would include preserving 60,000 acres of farmland and 40,000 acres of environmentally sensitive land and acquiring an additional 2,970 acres of recreational space. The County Legislature is now reviewing the proposal and exploring financing options through a special land stewardship committee.
"Everyone in the county thinks it's a great idea," Ms. Thomas said. "But they don't know where the money will come from."
In its report on the plan, the Planning Department recommended earmarking a portion of the county's sales tax for land preservation or imposing a real estate transfer tax.
"Once we have a program in place," Ms. Thomas said, "we'd also be eligible for Federal, state and municipal matching funds."
Under a largely state-financed program, 15 New Jersey counties will have completed buying development rights to 17,000 acres of farmland by the end of this year.
"They probably won't get much more, since the state may run out of money by the end of the year," said Eleanor S. Campbell, special projects coordinator for the New Jersey Conservation Foundation, a nonprofit group that advises county governments on how to conserve land. "We've been encouraging counties to come up with the own funding."
Several New Jersey counties have done so, including Mercer, Mommouth, Cape May and Atlantic. Last fall, voters in Atlantic County approved a special tax for land preservation.
In Chester County, Pa., 82 percent of voters approved $50 million for preserving agricultural land and acquiring land for two county parks.
"It's amazing to me how much support these programs have," said Daniel P. O'Connell, an investment banker with Sturdivant & Company of Camden, N.J., who is a consultant to counties on land acquisition. "Even in these tough economic times, people realize how important it is to acquire land. The next building push could be the one that changes the landscape forever."
In recent years, however, state-financed programs have not met with such enthusiasm. Last fall, several state environmental bond acts were defeated, including one in New York that would have provided $800 million to preserve and protect open land.
"WHEN we realized we weren't going to get that money, we knew we had to do something ourselves to protect our land," said Arlene Miller, associate planner with Rockland County's Department of Planning.
In its 1990 budget, Rockland allocated $1.5 million a year for six years to acquire "greenways," land along streams and ridge lines. Of particular concern to the county is the future of the Long Path, a 225-mile hiking trail operated by the New York/New Jersey Trail Conference. It runs from the George Washington Bridge to the Catskill Mountains, with 33 miles passing through Rockland.
"We're always worried about developers building too close to the trail and compromising its integrity and obscuring the views from it," Ms. Miller said. "It would be great to have some control over some of that land."
The county would also like to use the money to buy land with access to the Hudson River. "There are several towns that now have no clear way to get to the water," Ms. Miller said.
In formulating their land programs, many counties look to the success of Howard County, Md., which has had an agricultural acquisition program since 1974.
By the end of this year, Howard will have placed 17,000 acres of farmland under easement, said John W. Musselman, coordinator for the program. "Our goal is 30,000 acres, which would be one-third of the western part of the county."
HOWARD'S method of obtaining land rights has become a national model. Using an innovative formula, the county buys a farmer's development rights through a long-term installment purchase agreement offering tax-exempt income, with the bulk of the principal due at the end of the term, usually 30 years.
"It works out well for all parties," said Daniel O'Connell, Howard's financial adviser. "The county pays 50 to 60 percent of the appraised value of the land, which is an extremely cost-effective way for municipalities to get land."
In addition, he said, the farmer gets to stay on his land, "and he doesn't have to pay taxes on the money he gets until he receives the full purchase price."
The purchases are financed through zero-coupon Federal Treasury Bonds. In February 1991, Fitch Investor Service gave the county an AAA bond rating, citing in its report the "county's clearly defined goal of maintaining a high quality of life by carefully planning for and controlling development."
Another innovative aspect of the program is the "tourism package," Mr. Musselman, the program coordinator, said. "We subsidize sideline businesses that will help enable a farmer to stay in business," like bed and breakfast operations and farm tours.
Following Howard's example, Dutchess County may also offer farmers financial incentives to stay on the land. Under a proposed tax-abatement program, farmers would be relieved of their property taxes for one year in exchange for a two-year commitment to continue farming.
ALSO frequently cited as a model in land acquisition is Suffolk County on Long Island, which has already committed $180 million to three land conservation programs, including buying the development rights to farmland, open-space acquisition and watershed preservation.
The county expects to spend $300 million on the programs by the year 2000. Two of the programs are financed by county allocations from general funds and the watershed program is financed by a .25-cent sales tax.
By the end of this year, Suffolk will have under protection 30,000 acres of open space, 28,000 acres of recreational land and 6,500 acres of watershed. Its farm program was instituted in 1974, the same year as Howard's. Since then, 7,000 acres of farmland has been placed under easement, said Arthur H. Kunz, Suffolk's planning director.
"With this program, we've been able to hold onto our vintners and young farmers," he said, which is vital for the county's tourism business.
"One of the main attractions for people who come out here are the fresh vegetables and flowers sold from roadside stands," Mr. Kunz said. "Without careful planning, that could very easily disappear."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dutchess County is planning a land acquisition program, which involves buying farmers' development rights; farm in Pleasant Valley. Holly L. Thomas, the county's senior planner, believes the planning department must act quickly. (Photographs by Alan Zale for The New York Times)

GEOGRAPHIC: ;DUTCHESS COUNTY (NY) UNITED STATES (92%); NEW JERSEY, USA (92%); NEW YORK, USA (92%); MARYLAND, USA (79%); PENNSYLVANIA, USA (79%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Late Maintenance Charge
 
Question: I understand co-op maintenance fees received by the 15th of the month are legally considered paid on time. Lately my building's management company has begun tacking on $100-a-month "late" fees, even though my payments are always received by the 15th, which I can prove with certified mail receipts. Do I have any recourse? . . . Barbara Henryson, Manhattan 

Answer: Probably not. Marc Luxemburg, a lawyer and president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said there is no law that covers this subject.
"According to the proprietary leases of the majority of co-ops," he said, "maintenance is due on the first of each month. If there is a grace period it has been set by the co-op, not by the management company."
The policy is either a result of a board resolution or proprietary lease rule. You can ask the managing agent for a copy of any resolution authorizing the late fee or the pertinent section of the proprietary lease. Mr. Luxemburg said that if the late fee is part of the proprietary lease, your refusal to pay it could be interpreted as being a breach of the lease.
 
Mechanic's Lien
 
Question: A contractor who did work for me didn't finish the job. After many unsuccessful reminders I finished it myself and withheld the last payment. Can the contractor place a mechanic's lien on the property without my knowledge? . . . Elizabeth Weiss, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. Michael Finder, a lawyer specializing in real estate matters, said that the contractor must notify you of the lien within 30 days and that the lien can remain in place for one year unless there is a notice of action to foreclose on it or an extension is filed. Another requirement is that liens must be filed within eight months of the end of the job or the last work performed. Liens against one-family homes must be filed within four months of the end of the job or the last work done.
 
Vacancy Surcharge
 
Question: I have lived in a two-bedroom rent-stabilized apartment for two and a half years. I moved in with my cousin who had been living in the apartment for about three years. We notified the owner that I would be moving and he agreed. Since the lease was coming up for renewal I was allowed to sign it, but we were charged a vacancy surcharge of 20 percent.
My cousin moved out six months ago. Was the vacancy renewal legal? . . . Diana Feit, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. But the surcharge may not have been correctly calculated. Joseph De Gosta, an assistant commissioner with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said that because you were not a tenant since the start of the lease, the landlord could treat the lease you and your cousin signed as a new one. This could apply only if the owner had not received a vacancy increase for the previous lease period.
The vacancy increase allowed in accordance with rent guidelines for leases signed between Oct. 1, 1987, and Sept. 30, 1988, was 10 percent plus a 3.5 increase for a one-year lease and a 5 increase for a two-year lease. Leases signed between Oct. 1, 1988, and Sept. 30, 1989, could carry 12 percent vacancy increases in addition to a 9 percent increase for a two-year agreement. The current allowable increase on a vacancy lease is 5 percent plus the 4.5 percent increase for one-year and 7 percent for two-year leases.
If you believe you were overcharged, ask the landlord how the calculation was done. If you are not satisfied you can file an overcharge complaint with the state's housing agency. Forms are available by calling the Rent Hotline at (718) 739-6400.

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: The Bank of the United States in the Bronx;
The First Domino In the Depression

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
EACH succeeding story of a bank failure conjures up the same image: first a sudden stock-market collapse, then a nationwide bank crisis -- perhaps the start of another Great Depression.
The first big bank collapse after the Crash of 1929 began at a little limestone branch built in 1921 at the southeast corner of Freeman Street and Southern Boulevard in the Morrisania section of the Bronx. Now little more than a shell, it is a ruined monument in the history of American finance. 
 The modest structure was the first Bronx branch of the grandly titled Bank of the United States, begun in 1913 by Joseph S. Marcus, a Lower East Side garment manufacturer and financier. It served both established and newly arrived immigrants and its ambitious name was apparently chosen to impress (or confuse). It had no Government connection and in 1926 such an appellation was outlawed, but the legislation was not retroactive.
The Bronx branch was built in 1921. A tiny little neo-classical limestone structure with a chamfered corner and great bronze torchieres outside, it was designed by Louis Allen Abramson.
Marcus died in 1927 and his son Bernard took over during the bank's expansion through mergers from five branches in 1925 to 62 throughout New York City in 1930.
The bank's stock was publicly traded and there were rumors in the financial community in mid-1929 that the institution was shaky, but it weathered the October 1929 stock market disaster. However, either continuing reports of its shaky finances or just depositors' needs for cash as the Depression began dropped its reserves from over $200 million in October 1930 to $160 million in December. And on Dec. 8 a previously announced merger with three other banks was called off.
On Dec. 10, a Wednesday, $2 million was withdrawn from the Bronx branch by 2,500 depositors, one of whom stood in line for two hours to empty a $2 savings account. The commotion attracted a crowd of over 20,000.
The next day, The New York Times attributed the rush to a "false rumor" by a disgruntled investor. Nevertheless, nervous depositors formed long lines at other branches. An unidentified bank officer contended that the trouble was started by brokers seeking commissions from panic selling of the bank's stock. But on Dec. 11, Joseph A. Broderick, New York State Superintendent of Banks, closed the institution. It never reopened.
The bank had 400,000 depositors -- more than any other in the country -- and immediately hurt were garment businesses that needed money for their payrolls. Claims began to be processed in an orderly manner, but on Dec. 21 a crowd of 3,000 shouting "We want our money!" tried to storm the padlocked Bronx branch. Six people were arrested, all Bronx residents. Charges were dropped the next day.
"A Monetary History of the United States" by Milton Friedman and Anna Jacobson Schwartz, calls its failure the largest ever in American banking up to that time. The bank ultimately paid out over 80 percent on its deposits. But the obvious public panic set the stage for a series of bank failures that continued until 1933.
IN public hearings, it was disclosed that two months prior to its closure bank officers had burned ledgers and other records in the incinerator of the Beresford Apartments on Central Park West, which it had helped finance. According to "Skyscraper Dreams," by Tom Schactman, the Beresford, the San Remo and the Century were ultimately sold at distress prices to satisfy loans from the Bank of the United States.
Photographs from the 1940's show the building in operation as The National Bronx Bank but now it is only a boarded-up shell. The floor is littered with fallen plaster and skylight framing hangs crazily down from the ceiling -- anyone can enter through the roof. The marble facing of the tellers' cages is falling away.
The city's Department of General Services has owned the building since 1984. A sale at auction to a private owner in 1985 fell through and in another auction in 1989 the building went for $65,000 to two investors, Jose Medina and Raoul Santiago. Mr. Medina says that he planned to renovate for store occupancy, but that city regulations regarding reconstruction were too restrictive. The Department of General Services has declared them in default and the investors lost their $13,000 deposit.
Lisa Ryan, a spokeswoman for the agency, said the city will auction the building again. No date has been set.

HEADLINE: Paramus Journal;
Dinosaurs Are Fun, But the Zoo Fee Is Not

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: PARAMUS

 BODY:
AMONG the bleating goats and crowing roosters there is another sound at the Van Saun Park County Zoo this summer: the chilling roar of thunder lizards and their varied kin. While these animated dinosaurs have delighted thousands of children clutching barrier ropes with ice-pop-stained fingers, many parents have voiced shock and dismay.
The exhibition is stunning, they say, and its price of admission was expected. But not an entrance fee to the zoo, which for decades has been free to all who enter. 
 "I can't believe this," said Angela Lomagno of Saddle Brook, who with a friend brought a group of children on a recent Sunday to visit the exhibition and the zoo.
"I've been coming here since I can remember, and there's never been a fee to get into the zoo," she said. "I guess my tax money doesn't go as far as it used to, but I still don't think this is right."
 
Charged Only on Weekends
 Zoo and county park officials say that the admission fee of $2 for adults and $1 for children over 12 years of age is charged only on weekends and that the revenue is badly needed to offset budget cuts in the county park system.
The fee is permanent, said Wolfgang Albrecht Jr., director of the Bergen County Department of Parks, and will help finance "educational challenges that lie ahead of us and allow for its growth." Weekday fees are unlikely, he added.
To gain entry to the dinosaur exhibition, visitors must pay fees of $4 for adults and $2 for children, as well as the zoo admission.
For Tim Gunther, the county zoo's director, the zoo fee is a sign of tough economic times and a mixed blessing as well.
 
'We've All Been Spoiled'
 "Our budget has not changed at all over the last two years," he said. "I've lost three staff members to attrition who I do not expect to be replaced. Many people are upset about the zoo fee, especially county residents, but you know, when you have such a thing available free of charge for all these years, you fall into the trap of taking it for granted."
In a way, Mr. Gunther said, "we've all been spoiled." He said he hoped that the modest fee would be rechanneled in part to improve the zoo. .
The zoo fee has been designated for the county park system general fund and not specifically earmarked for zoo improvements, even though administrators at Van Saun have been promised that the zoo will share in the benefits.
The fee order was put into effect by the Bergen County Executive's office after the Van Saun Zoological Society arranged last year to be host to the dinosaur exhibition. Some say privately that the fee was imposed to take advantage of large crowds expected for the summerlong display, which began on June 1 and will run through Sept. 2, but that it may have backfired since weekend attendance has dropped from anticipated numbers.
Though average weekend attendance at the popular zoo and park is nearly 15,000 in the summer, it has dwindled to nearly half that number. Van Saun includes a children's pony ride concession and a scale-model steam engine railroad that meanders through the zoo's perimeter.
"Before school let out, we were mobbed on weekends, but then the attendance started falling off, and I think some of that has to do with families going away for the summer down to the Shore," Mr. Gunther said.
County park officials say the attendance will eventually pick up once visitors accept the fee and see zoo improvements.
Not all visitors are opposed to the admission price.
"I have no problem with it as long as the money is used for making improvements at the zoo," said Joseph Drigon of Kearney on a recent visit with his wife, Sue, and their three children. "If they need it, why not?"
Mrs. Drigon said that the double admission policy did not seem fair and that allowances should be made for those who wanted to visit either the park or the exhibition.
John McCarthy of Glen Rock said, "I think that they're taking advantage here a little bit with these fees, but I really don't mind too much because the kids love this so." Mr. McCarthy, his wife, Bonnie, and their two young daughters were making a day at the park.
 
'The Money Goes to a Good Cause'
 "The money goes to a good cause, and that's all that really matters," Mrs. McCarthy said as her daughters pulled at her arm to venture to an adjacent playground.
But for park employees, the new fee has been a nightmare of explanations and dealing with enraged visitors.
"Hey, they don't pay me enough to take this kind of lip from people," said one employee, who refused to be identified as he tore tickets by the zoo's main entrance. "I tell people, 'If you go out of the zoo and want to come back, you've got to pay again,' " he said with a degree of frustration. "I tell them that I don't make the rules and if they've got a complaint, call the County Executive's office in Hackensack."
"I was in the service for four years," he added, "and I never heard cussing like what I've heard here, mostly from people who aren't from the area."
Some visitors voiced surprise at other changes as well. The steam engine ride this year has also increased in price. Tickets for adults and children above 3 years of age have gone from 35 cents to 50 cents.
"They've kind of got you coming and going, and what I don't appreciate is that all these fees were passed and sprung on everybody," said Connie Lomagno, also of Saddle Brook. "This should be a place where one can have a good time without having to stare at their wallets, because with a whole family, you're going to wind up spending lots of money."
Regardless of resentment about admission fees, the dinosaur exhibition's popularity can be a moving experience for children, parents and exhibition volunteers alike.
In a tent-enclosed display, primeval shadows fall among towering predators and prey, whose lifelike movements are operated on compressed air. The sound of horrific roars mixes with the excited squeals of young children, many finding themselves thrust into their parents' arms.
 
'Look at the Wonder in Their Eyes'
 "Look at the wonder in their eyes -- just look at it," said Kathy Lopes of Fair Lawn, a docent volunteer for the Zoological Society's Education Center. As a mechanical apatosaurus cranes its neck and seems to gaze at a handful of children, they unconsciously take a half step back.
"In this setting, you can see how they relate to the dinosaurs," Mrs. Lopes said. "For them, they are no longer drawings in a storybook or a collection of bones in a museum."
A 4-year-old boy, arm wrapped around his mother's leg, watched in fascination as a young triceratops grazed near its protective mechanical mother.
"That's its baby, Momma," the little boy said as his mother smiled and stroked his flaxen hair.
"The magic, as you can see," Mrs. Lopes said, "is not just limited to children."
