HEADLINE: 90's Denim: Relaxed And Blue and More

BYLINE: By DEBORAH HOFMANN

 BODY:
Denim takes on the attitude of each generation: torn, scruffy blue jeans in the 1960's, a second skin in the 70's, a designer look in the 80's. That decade ended with deliberate shredding on thighs and knees and a sack shape -- a reaction against leggings.
"The trends this fall include color, trims of leather and plastic, prints, a relaxed fit and a continuation of the baggy look," said Jean Driscoll, a spokeswoman for Jeanswear Communications, a newsletter for the denim industry. 
 For those who prefer a snug fit, she said, "Stretch Lycra and denim hybrids are giving denim a fresh appeal."
 
Strong Sales in Weak Economy
 Blue jeans peaked in 1981, when 502 million pairs were sold. Now, sales are up again, spurred by an economy in which denim's durability means value. In the first quarter of 1991, sales of denim jeans were about 68 million pairs, up about 7 percent from the same period of 1990, Ms. Driscoll said. Denim mills are booked months ahead, she said.
Designers are looking at denim again -- among them Donna Karan (for her DKNY line), Anne Klein's A Line, Moschino and others, including new companies. And traditional manufacturers, like Lee, Wrangler and Levi, are becoming more aggressive at marketing their jeans.
Express makes a five-pocket stirrup jean of pre-washed stretch blue denim with a touch of Lycra ($46) and a denim legging with elasticized waist and higher Lycra content ($39), which comes in black, off-white and faded blue. It's sold at 575 Express stores nationwide, including nine in Manhattan.
 
Patent Leather and Color Blocks
 A new manufacturer, the Manhattan-based Fly Jeans, makes a stretch denim jean with stirrups, in red or black ($65). An oversized stone-washed jean comes with the fly and front details in back and the seat pockets in front ($72).
Fly Jeans also makes denims trimmed with quilted black patent leather or plastic wedges. Mondrian-inspired color-blocked jeans are made with denim squares in several colors. These two styles are $60 to $70. Fly Jeans are sold at Bloomingdale's.
Another new manufacturer, the Los Angeles-based L.E.I., makes Chap Jeans: denim jeans with leather panels sewn down the front and sometimes also down the back. The look is inspired by riding wear, which the company also makes.
L.E.I.'s indigo denim jeans come with chaps in a choice of eight colors -- black, blue, tan, hunter green, burgundy, red, navy or eggplant -- or in styles with denim dyed to match, $38 to $48 at Bloomingdale's and Macy's.
 
Relaxed and Baggy Revisited
 Marithe and Francois Girbaud's jeans come in 12 colors. Girbaud dyes T-shirts and jackets to match. A "skinny cowboy" style has extra room in the thigh and seat ($62). It does look skinny compared to the "baggy cowboy" style ($72), which has about two inches more fabric through the thighs and most of the rest of the garment.
"Baggy cowboy shorts," which go over the knees, are worn over leggings and cat suits ($56). A sailor-inspired gray-green "vintage denim" is supple and pajamalike, $62. It's worn cinched at the waist, with the cuffs rolled up. The jeans are sold at Bloomingdale's, Macy's and Urban Outfitters.
Ruff Hewn's Westwood jeans of stone-washed indigo denim are a hybrid style for those who want a roomier classic jean without the baggy silhouette. They are faded along seams and tension points. The style is $72 at Lord & Taylor.
Lee's Relaxed Rider five-pocket jean ($35) is roomy in the thighs and seat. The waist is cut in a bit, curving to a rounded hip. The Elastic Rider ($35) has a pocketless seat and elastic waistline, geared to a fuller figure. Both come in 14 shades of indigo. Lee plans to introduce a red-purple indigo in December.

HEADLINE: Deirdre O'Connor Plans to Marry

 BODY:
Mr. and Mrs. James J. O'Connor of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deirdre Anne O'Connor to Joseph William Martini, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Martini of Merrick, L.I. An October wedding is planned.
Miss O'Connor and Mr. Martini are both 30 years old and assistant United States Attorneys in Bridgeport, Conn. Miss O'Connor graduated from New York University and received a law degree from the University of Bridgeport. Her father is the president of the Annamor Group, a New York importer of Irish products. 
 Mr. Martini is a cum laude graduate of Gettysburg College and received a law degree from Brooklyn Law School. His parents are retired. His father taught physical education at Uniondale (L.I.) High School and his mother, Beverly Martini, taught home economics at Valley Stream (L.I.) Memorial Junior High School.

LENGTH: 1721 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/August 11-16

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
The Price of Breaking the Street's Code of Ethics 

When Salomon Brothers Inc. admitted last week that it had broken Wall Street's rules by buying more than 35 percent of the offerings at certain Treasury auctions, it did more than sully its name. It went against Wall Street's code of ethics, which, combined with the work of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is the way the Street is policed. The breach may cost the firm its future. Last week it cost John H. Gutfreund, Salomon's chairman, and Thomas W. Strauss, its president, their jobs. The problem is not just that Salomon Brothers bought way more than the 35 percent maximum and that the purchases may have skewed bond prices in its favor. It's that Mr. Gutfreund and two others failed to inform the Government when they first learned of at least one of the violations. So much for the honor system. Until a new chairman is found, Warren Buffett, the Omaha investor with a stake in Salomon, will act as chairman.
 
No. 2 -- for the Moment
 
Everyone knows fame is fleeting, but so is being the nation's No. 2 bank. For barely a month the Chemical Bank Corporation was going to be No. 2, after announcing it would merge with the Manufactures Hanover Corporation. Last week, BankAmerica Corporation took that title away when it said it would acquire the Security Pacific Corporation for about $4.12 billion in stock. The combined bank will have $190 billion in assets. "Security Pacific is very good with its technology and processing services; BankAmerica has tremendous distribution," said Les Dinkin, managing principal of NBW Consulting in New York. Richard M. Rosenberg, chairman of BankAmerica, will become chairman of the new bank. "The new bank will have capital for more acquisitions," said Mr. Dinkin. Watch out No. 1.
 
And Pan Am Is the Prize
 
Delta Air Lines won a prize of dubious value last week -- 45 percent of ailing Pan American World Airways. A Federal bankruptcy judge approved Delta's $1.7 billion bid for nearly half of the carrier's assets. But in addition to winning a stake in Pan Am -- it will share it with a handful of creditors -- Delta also gets something of real value: Pan Am's profitable shuttle operations, its European routes and a huge assortment of spare parts. The deal calls for Delta to kick in $621 million in cash and assume $720 million in Pan Am's liabilities. Though Pan Am is a shadow of its former globe-girdling self, it will continue to fly. The deal, according to Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, will put Delta "in the same league as American and United." That is to say, the big leagues.
 
Clark Clifford's Exit
 
In a statement to the press, Clark M. Clifford tried to put his resignation as chairman of First American Corporation in the best light. He and his law partner, Robert A. Altman, First American's president, were stepping down voluntarily to save the bank from adverse publicity, he said. But eyebrows were raised all around. Mr. Clifford, a former Presidential adviser and Defense Secretary, was in fact given the boot, said Federal banking regulators and First American's own board. Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, a former Attorney General, was brought in to clean up the mess. First American was owned by the Bank of Credit and Commerce International -- the bank accused of misdeeds like laundering money for drug lords around the world. But Mr. Clifford, who was also B.C.C.I.'s highly paid counsel, claimed he did not know that. To make that claim stick, Mr. Clifford -- known for his savvy and wise advice -- must convince a lot of people that he turned gullible.
 
Sears Needs More Time to Pay
 
With consumer spending still depressed, retailers are hurting. Sears Roebuck & Company, the nation's third-biggest retailer, said last week it will extend its payment period for vendors from 30 days to 60 days. A Sears spokesman said the action does not imply the company is in a cash bind. Perhaps not, but how about the suppliers?
 
Just the Latest Scandal . . .
 
Fingers are wagging everywhere as details of new scandals are released. The latest involves the General Electric Company. G.E. was accused in a lawsuit filed by Chester Walsh, a G.E. employee, of defrauding the Pentagon out of more than $30 million in the sale of jet engines and services to the Israeli Air Force. Last week the Justice Department joined the suit. G.E. said it is conducting an internal investigation -- but then again so are Salomon Brothers, B.C.C.I. and the Japanese securities industry.
 
A Paul Simon Industry
 
The title of last week's Central Park concert by Paul Simon could have been "synergy" -- a word companies use to justify often high prices they pay for a company in a related business. But this time the synergy was real. Units of Time Warner Inc. put up about $1.2 million to cover the cost of the free concert. In return, they got the right to broadcast it live, show reruns and sell videos. There is even talk about a record. All that's missing is a book on how the deal was made and an article in Fortune.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
A New Regime at F.D.I.C.
 
L. William Seidman, who is retiring as head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Resolution Trust Corporation in October, must have pretty big shoes. The White House has nominated William Taylor to fill just one of them. The Administration wants Mr. Taylor, the top banking regulator at the Federal Reserve, to head only the F.D.I.C. It will appoint someone else to the newly created post of chief executive of the trust corporation to oversee the savings and loan bailout. When asked about his nomination, Mr. Taylor, who still must be confirmed by the Senate, said "no comment," something Mr. Seidman rarely says.
 
Sleepy Retail Sales
 
The July gain in retail sales was about as exciting as a late-afternoon yawn. According to the Commerce Department, sales increased by barely 0.5 percent last month. Since consumers account for the lion's share of all economic activity in the United States, slow growth in retail sales means a slow recovery. "The bottom line," said David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York, "is that there is a bit of a pickup, but some real question about whether it is sustainable." A number of other economists have their doubts.
 
Affordable Vegetables
 
Vegetables have been giving the economy a lot of trouble lately. Their prices rose enough last spring to bring on an inflation scare. But now, some good news. According to the Labor Department, vegetable prices fell enough to keep consumer prices almost steady in June. The Consumer Price Index, the Government's primary tool for gauging inflation, rose by 0.2 percent. So far this year, inflation has been running at 2.7 percent. That scanty an increase would make even the Germans and Japanese proud these days. With inflation lying low, the Federal Reserve can contemplate a further easing of interest rates.
 
A Rule Goes Topsy-Turvy
 
Back when economics in the real world resembled economics in the textbook, the rule of thumb was that when the nation's factories hummed along at more than 77 percent of capacity, inflation would soon perk up. The old rule does not seem to prevail anymore. Capacity was running at 79.7 percent in July, up from 79.5 for June, said the Federal Reserve Board, yet inflation is almost nil. The question economists must answer is why growth has barely made it into the single digits when all those factories are running almost flat out.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
The Love of Japanese Goods
 
Japan's exports are still climbing. According to the Finance Ministry, Japan's trade surplus with the rest of the world surged by 25.2 percent to $6.68 billion in July. An astounding increase from an already high base. And while nearly every country in the world has been moaning about all those Japanese cars and stereos, they still love to buy them. Americans love buying those goodies most. Nearly half of Japan's surplus last month -- $3.01 billion -- was with the United States.
 
No Monopoly on Scheming
 
Who says "entrepreneurialism" is exclusively American? Toyo Shinkin Bank in Osaka, a cross between a credit union and a savings and loan, said last week that one of its branch managers, Asami Maekawa, had been involved in issuing false certificates of deposit worth about $2.48 billion. The bank only has about $2.58 billion in deposits. The certificates found their way into the hands of a nearby restaurant owner, Nui Onoue, and she used them to borrow money from other banks. According to the Ministry of Finance, that money was used to speculate on stocks. The size of the scheme, officials said, may mean that Ms. Onoue was working in cahoots with the yakuza, Japan's very well organized mob. No indictments have been issued yet, but the ministry is looking into the case. The Bank of Japan, fearing a run on Toyo Shinkin, moved quickly to protect all depositors.
 
Germany's Inflation-Fighter
 
Helmut Schlesinger, the new president of Germany's central bank, is known as a hawk on inflation. Last week he strutted his stuff in public for the first time. The Bundesbank announced it was raising Germany's discount rate from 6.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The discount rate is what the Buba -- as the Bundesbank is affectionately known -- charges Germany's banks to borrow. The Bundesbank raised the Lombard funding rate to 9.25 percent from 9 percent. The reason for the rise in rates was the alarming "surge" in Germany's inflation rate -- from 3.5 percent in June to 4.4 percent in July. With budget deficits in the Federal Republic climbing, as eastern Germany is integrated into the west, many observers say Mr. Schlesinger will raise rates even further.
 
A Country Without a Lender
 
Pity the poor Soviet Union. It needs to borrow money to buy grain -- a mere $600 million. But no American bank is willing to lend the money even though the United States Government will guarantee repayment of most of the principal and half of the interest. Even with the guarantees, the banks are still skeptical that they will be paid. That makes some observers wonder which nation the bankers have ceased to trust.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
An Appetite for Mergers

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation's planned acquisition of the Security Pacific Corporation, announced last week, could become the biggest banking merger in history. Frank N. Newman, BankAmerica's chief financial officer and vice chairman, has been preparing for it for a long time.
Mr. Newman, 49, has been a key player in BankAmerica's expansion binge. The San Francisco-based bank bought more than a dozen smaller banks and thrift institutions in Western states in the last year and a half, and also made an unsuccessful bid for the Bank of New England. More purchases are expected. 
 The corporate development department, which carries out the acquisitions, reports to Mr. Newman, and he has often served as the spokesman for the bank on its expansion strategy. "We have a really tremendous opportunity to do it right," he told financial analysts last Monday, explaining the "financial engineering" that will be used on the Security Pacific purchase to allow the combined bank to start life in "terrific shape" while still increasing reserves for bad loans.
A native of Quincy, Mass., with an economics degree from Harvard, Mr. Newman was the chief financial officer at Wells Fargo & Company in 1986 when it acquired Crocker Bank.
That acquisition, huge for its time, demonstrated that merging two banks in the same region could produce large savings and improve earnings by eliminating overlapping employees and branches. Some analysts are referring to the Security Pacific deal as "Crocker II."
Mr. Newman has seen takeovers from the other side as well. He joined BankAmerica in October 1986, when it was struggling with loan losses. On his first day on the job, BankAmerica announced it had received a takeover offer from First Interstate Bancorp. By week's end, Samuel H. Armacost, the BankAmerica chief executive who had hired him, was ousted.
But Mr. Newman stayed. He coordinated the successful defense against First Interstate and helped nurse BankAmerica back to financial health.

HEADLINE: All About/In-Store Promotions;
Influencing Shoppers During the Moment of Decision

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
Everybody is trying to cash in on the fast-growing trend toward in-store promotions. Supermarkets are charging fees to place these sales displays in their aisles. Display companies, many of them bought by advertising agencies in recent years, are charging food manufacturers to design and produce campaigns. And venture capitalists are investing in new technologies to get in on the burst of interest in the activity. Known as supermarket point-of-purchase advertising and promotion, the technique uses high and low technology, from video terminals to hand-out coupons, to communicate sales messages and influence buying habits.
Food manufacturers see these promotions, which often play on people's impulses, as a quick fix for sagging sales. And with thousands of new products introduced each year -- 1,837 in July alone, according to Gorman's New Product News, an supermarket industry magazine -- marketers are fighting for ways to keep their products from getting lost. 
 For the nation's supermarket chains, which charge for the displays placed on their floors, this form of advertising and promotion has been a boon. A growing share of the money that food manufacturers would have spent on other advertising media, like television, radio and newspapers, is now being spent to put displays inside stores. For example, of the millions of dollars to be spent next month by the M.& M. Mars Company on its annual Halloween campaign, slightly more than half will be spent inside the stores on displays and renting space.
Practitioners of the in-store arts predict solid growth for their medium. To back up their argument, they refer to the research findings of the Point of Purchase Advertising Institute, an industry association in Englewood, N.J., that says 66 percent of all buying decisions are made after the consumer enters the supermarket.
 
The Medium Grows
A Bigger Share of the Ad Pie
 It is difficult to calculate exactly how much is spent on in-store promotions, analysts say, since promotional expenditures are often lumped in with other costs in a company's marketing budget. Most analysts, however, agree that the in-store promotion and advertising business is growing much faster than traditional advertising.
According to the Point of Purchase Advertising Institute, the use of in-store promotions and advertising has been growing by 10 to 15 percent annually over the last five years, compared with growth of just 4 to 6 percent for traditional advertising.
But despite its growth, in-store promotions and advertising remain a small part of the nation's total advertising outlays. In-store promotional and advertising expenditures totaled $14.8 billion in 1989, according to the institute, which estimates that about one-third of that money was spent in supermarkets and smaller food stores, as opposed to other retail outlets like drug and convenience stores. Traditional advertising expenditures were about $128.6 billion that year.
Traditional advertising and promotions companies are often rivals for the same dollars. They are often in conflict on the design of their campaigns. Each camp argues that its method of reaching the customer is superior. But there are signs of reconciliation. A growing number of advertising agencies, like Foote, Cone & Belding and more recently Earle Palmer Brown, have established or acquired their own promotional units. For these companies, in-store displays are seen as one more media tool.
"Point of purchase can't be an orphan," said David Essertier, a senior vice president at Promotional Innovations Inc. and a former advertising executive at Saatchi & Saatchi. "It is at its best when used with the other forms of advertising."
 
Enriching Stores
Manufacturers Must Pay a Commission

The growth of in-store programs is largely due to the peculiarities of supermarket economics. Most supermarket chains operate on wafer-thin margins of 1 percent. As a result, in-store promotions and advertising are an important source of revenue since manufacturers pay stores a commission for the chance to display their messages.
Industry experts say that about 35 percent of the money spent on a typical promotions campaign goes to the store. The stores, in return, must provide data on sales to the manufacturers, increase their stocks of the featured products and mention the product in the supermarket's regular advertising circulars and flyers. Some of the larger chains can take in as much as $430,000 from a typical two-week campaign for a single product.
Paul Bernish, a spokesman for the Kroger Company, one of the country's largest supermarket chains, declined to provide the amount that chain earned from in-store advertising, though he described it as a "moderate source of revenue." But he added that in-store displays were more a matter of increasing the store's sales than providing direct revenue. "We want to increase foot traffic in the store," he said.

 
 
The Money Flows
Venture Capitalists
Take to the Idea
 The largest company in the in-store market is Actmedia, which was established 18 years ago in Norwalk, Conn., and had revenues of $156.3 million in 1990 with earnings of $23.3 million. Acquired two years ago by the Dallas-based Heritage Media Corporation, which owns television and radio stations, Actmedia's operations cover 25,800 supermarkets, drugstores and mass merchandisers.
Actmedia's products range from basic signs clipped onto shelves and hung over aisles to coupon machines placed next to the discounted products. It sends teams of employees to thousands of stores to promote products and has a radio network that plays music and pitches over the stores' sound systems. With Turner Broadcasting, Actmedia is planning to test TV programming for supermarkets.
Five years ago, Actmedia had no significant competition, but analysts say there is a new influx of venture capital into the field. The industry still consists largely of thousands of entrepreneurs -- many of whom work from their homes and consider themselves inventors -- as well as dozens of promotional companies hired by manufacturers to design specific campaigns. But recently, a few other companies, like Media One in New York and the Catalina Marketing Corporation in Anaheim, Calif., -- both privately owned -- have established in-store promotional networks that cover thousands of supermarkets, though they offer a more limited array of services than Actmedia.
Another company, Videocart Inc., in Chicago, has generated much attention with its plans to supply stores with carts equipped with video displays. By pushing a button on the cart, a customer can automatically receive an electronic coupon that will be recorded at the cashier in front. The Videocart company is still in a fledgling state, having just completed its testing stage in supermarkets around the country [page 13].
There is some concern among marketers, manufacturers and retailers that the supermarket could become so overwhelmed with promotional gadgets that shoppers could be turned off.
But others dismiss the possibility that the industry could stop growing soon. "There's still so much unused space in the supermarket," said John M. Kawula, the institute's president.
 
 
 
THE DIFFICULTY IN DEEP FREEZES
 The challenge for promotional companies is to get their products noticed. But some sections of the supermarket are better than others at doing that.
"The two deadliest displays are the upright freezer section of the supermarket and the open fresh-dairy case display," said Lee Weinblatt, chief executive of Pretesting Company Inc., in Englewood, N.J., which provides advertising research using hidden video cameras in stores. "Shoppers are not willing to keep opening and closing the freezer doors to compare products in different sections of the upright freezers."
Attempts to put promotions in the freezer space have sometimes met with disaster. But one solution being examined by several companies is to create small, separate cold displays.
James Richardson, an industrial designer and consultant in Weston, Conn., said he first began working on concepts for "secondary freezer display space" five years ago. This week, Mr. Richardson's latest project -- a small portable freezer -- will be tested at supermarkets in Montreal, its second round of tests in the last two years.
The portable freezer stands about three feet tall and four feet wide, with posters on all four sides to promote the product inside. It can be assembled and taken apart for moving in less than an hour. The cooling unit is separate from the storage space.
In tests last year in about 40 A.& P. stores in Toronto and at Overmaitea supermarkets in Vancouver, British Columbia, the freezers produced a sales increase of as much as 100 percent for McCains Super Fries and Campbell's Le Menu frozen dinners.
"Any time you feature a product in-store with a separate display, it will increase sales -- that's a given," said Mr. Richardson. "The problem is how you stock it and get it into the store."
The first version of Mr. Richardson's mini-freezer was dubbed the Cold Thief because it stole cold air from nearby freezers. It was inexpensive to manufacture but met with disapproval from store managers because it had to be located near an existing freezer unit. Another version of the freezer, which could be located anywhere, proved too expensive to make and did not keep the product cold enough.
The latest version of the freezer, if next week's tests prove successful, could soon appear in stores throughout North America.
Then again, it could be like thousands of other products that are developed for supermarkets and fall by the wayside. "Until the tests are completed," Mr. Richardson said, "you never can tell what can be a problem and how it will affect the store."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Tax-Free Funds: Mirage of Security?

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The collapse of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company in late July has set off ripples of uneasiness among sponsors of tax-exempt mutual funds.
The insurer had backed $41 million of bonds held by John Nuveen & Company in its $2.4 billion Nuveen Tax-Exempt Money Market Fund. Mutual Benefit's role had been to guarantee that bondholders could redeem their holdings. After the collapse Nuveen quickly bought insurance from other concerns, guaranteeing that its shareholders remained protected. 
 Nuveen was not alone among mutual funds in owning bonds backed by Mutual Benefit, although other funds have not publicly admitted their holdings.
The incident should be a warning to investors in tax-free money funds. Tax-free funds may well be more risky than taxable funds, according to A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J.
This is so even though only taxable money funds have experienced defaults among the securities in their portfolios. After issuers defaulted on commercial paper held by the funds in 1989 and 1990, the Securities and Exchange Commission set tough standards for taxable money funds that took effect on June 1. The agency forced funds to upgrade their investments and cut the funds' average maturity to 90 from 120 days.
Tax-free money funds were largely excluded from the new rules, but the S.E.C. has since begun reviewing the rules governing tax-free funds. While S.E.C. officials will not disclose the agenda, two issues probably top the list: the quality of the funds' investments and their average maturity.
The chief appeal of tax-free money funds, of course, is that the interest is not subject to Federal income tax; in some cases, it is also free from state and local taxes.
The funds are enormously popular. Of the 88 new money funds in 1990, 49 were tax-free funds, says Martha Wittbrodt, editor of IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report in Holliston, Mass. Total tax-free fund assets are nearly $90 billion, some 16 percent of the $550 billion money market industry.
There have been no reported defaults involving the paper held by the tax-free funds in their 10 year-plus history, but it is harder to evaluate credit quality for tax-free funds than for taxable funds, says Russell E. Long, assistant vice president for Standard & Poor's mutual fund group in New York.
For one, municipal issues come in many types, with varying elements of risk. The tax-free funds' holdings include arcane investments like "demand notes," which entitle the holder to principal at any time; revenue and general obligation notes; tax-free commercial paper, and "put bonds," which entitle a holder to receive the principal amount of the underlying security at specified intervals.
Furthermore, many municipal issues are unrated because small regional issuers do not want to pay the fees charged by independent rating organizations.
And, even where ratings exist, many municipal issues are being downgraded because of the economic downturn. Compounding the problem is the eroding quality of banks and insurers, like Mutual Benefit, that write letters of credit or insurance to back securities.
Lately, managers of tax-free money funds have been caught between rising demand for their funds and a shrinking supply of high-quality short-term paper. In fact, last year several fund groups that sponsor "single-state" tax-exempt funds, which invest in issues of a single state and its municipalities, temporarily invested in out-of-state debt because the funds could not find enough municipal issues to fill their portfolios.
To meet the growing demand, banks and brokerage firms have recently manufactured a new kind of "derivative" security called "synthetic floaters." Essentially, these are bonds repackaged as floating-rate tax-exempt securities. Issuers use the interest from a long-term, fixed-rate municipal bond to provide the variable-rate short-term interest paid on the floaters. Investors in the floaters can hold them to maturity or "put" them back to the issuer for cash or a share of the underlying bonds.
The new product has caught on with some funds. A survey by IBC/Donoghue's found 41 percent of tax-free funds invest in synthetic floaters. But tax-free funds that do not own floaters say they are too risky, Donoghue reports. The problem with floaters is that investors sometimes cannot put the bond back to issuers. This happens if the bond defaults or is downgraded to BBB or below.
Still, tax-free money fund investors can take steps to protect themselves. First, in evaluating tax-free funds, look to buy funds with below-average maturities, Mr. Lipper said. In general, the shorter the maturity, the safer the issue. The average maturity for the 259 funds tracked by Lipper is 52 days.
As for diversity, investors in "national" tax-free funds -- which invest in issues of many states -- should make sure that one state does not dominate the fund's holdings.
Finally, look for portfolios heavily invested in government-issued paper, Mr. Lipper said. The quality of these holdings is higher than on industrial revenue issues, which are supported by streams of revenue from a specific project like a toll bridge, not by a government's taxing powers.

HEADLINE: Managing;
What Makes a Given Industry Tick?

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
American universities do a pretty thorough job of grounding students in marketing, financial and engineering skills. But do they add much to the understanding of what makes different industries tick?
Ralph E. Gomory, president of the New York-based Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, a nonprofit institution founded in 1934 to promote research into science, industrial competitiveness and other national issues, doesn't think so. What's more, he believes that lumping industries together intellectually fosters the idea that a cure-all can be found for all their problems -- a scenario Mr. Gomory finds as likely as the emergence of a pill that cures both cancer and heart disease. 
 Thus, at Mr. Gomory's urging, the foundation is backing the Massachussetts Institute of Technology's existing center to study the global auto industry. And it has dispensed $15 million -- with more in the pipeline -- to Harvard, Carnegie Mellon and several other universities to set up similar centers of learning about other industries.
Mr. Gomory, one of President Bush's science and technical advisers and a former head of the International Business Machines Corporation's global research operations, hopes that the industry-specific centers will not only generate new products and processes, but also provide forums where academia and industry can capitalize on each other's strengths.
Question: Why do our industries have such chronic problems retaining their competitive edge?
Answer: Americans excel at founding industries based on scientific ideas. We are the ones who translated the fundamentals of solid-state physics into semiconductors, the ones who are turning molecular biology into biotechnology. But our difficulties start when our industries move from the ladder stage, when engineers keep refining scientific advancements until they yield a new product, to the cycle stage, when those products have to go through continuous rounds of incremental improvements.
Semiconductors were an American-dominated industry in the ladder stage. But as soon as competitiveness meant making constant incremental improvements in, say, the amount of memory you can put on a chip, the Japanese became a significant factor. They are the real innovators in manufacturing, the ones who have developed better techniques.
Q. Why is manufacturing innovation beyond our grasp?
A. Americans have just never found manufacturing to be interesting, and you don't excel at something that doesn't interest you. Our pay scales also make our priorities clear, in that we tend to pay people in research better than those in manufacturing.
Most people graduate from college without understanding where products come from. They meet scientists, marketers, financiers at universities. But they don't meet product developers or manufacturing experts.
Q. It seems, then, that adding a few manufacturing courses would solve the problem.
A. Nonsense. You can't apply the same manufacturing fixes to pharmaceuticals and textiles, to automobiles and semiconductors. The Japanese got their costs of cars down by shaving the number of hours it took to make a car. That's entirely different from semiconductors, where they continuously manufacture incrementally improved products.
Our universities have been too busy teaching functional specialties to really develop a detailed, reality-based understanding of such industrial differences.
Q. But university professors consult to industry all the time. Doesn't that give them a dose of industrial reality?
A. They still don't get a total, coherent picture. A materials professor may consult about materials to use in building an airplane without understanding what makes the airplane industry competitive. Same thing in textiles -- a marketing professor would not be much help in spotting problems with buying tools; a textiles engineer would not understand who the foreign competition is.
The universities and businesses have to send people back and forth to each other's worlds. That's where the industry-specific centers come in. They will be a source of knowledge about what is happening in any given industry. They will interact with companies from around the world to give them insights into what matters. They can be like laboratories, where people study industry much as an anthropologist studies villages.
Q. Do you envision these centers as interacting only with business schools?
A. Quite the contrary. The whole world around us is being created by these industries, and that means they have a tremendous impact on our cultures and lives. If we can get people to think that modern industry matters as a subject, as French history does, then historians will teach about modern industrial history.
The centers will serve as resources for every school and will draw on the business school and the economics faculty and the engineering school. You'll have Ph.D. students writing theses about new techniques or new ways of relating to vendors in their industry. You'll even have faculty members testifying to Congress, influencing laws and policies that affect industries.
Q. Don't we have enough corporate lobbyists pleading their cases in Washington?
A. Individuals lobbying for their companies are not the same as faculty members, who would give a more dispassionate view. There is a vacuum in people's thinking when it comes to industry, and that is reflected in government policy. The universities can fill that vacuum.
This is not just a narrow issue of money or even competitiveness. It is a broad societal issue. Doing industry right, correctly, effectively, is the key to whether our children live as well or better than we do. That's why it is worth studying.

HEADLINE: Getting Through Recession On Real Estate's Pricey Side

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

DATELINE: HUNTINGDON VALLEY, Pa.

 BODY:
One thing is clear: Bob and Bruce Toll are business conservatives. In most industries, that penchant might brand them as plodding conformists. But among people who develop residential communities, it has made them consummate contrarians.
Other developers willingly buy overpriced land, figuring that it will rise even higher; in the 24 years since Robert I. Toll and Bruce E. Toll started Toll Brothers Inc. here, they have not bought anything they did not think they could flip immediately at a minimum 10 percent profit. And while other developers ride a boom to its exhilarating peak in hopes of making enough money to last them through the inevitable and wrenching market plunge, Toll opts for incremental growth, foregoing the highs to avoid the lows. 
 Toll may have missed some deals because of its approach, but it has also made it through three recessions without a stain of red ink. Countless developers have gone under in the last year. But Toll, which builds as many as 800 homes a year, will probably manage to hold its revenues steady this year, at about $200 million, making it among the nation's largest residential real estate developers. And analysts and Toll executives alike say there's a good chance that the flurry of development the company is currently indulging in -- as it picks over the carcasses of the dead and dying -- could ratchet those revenues to $250 million next year.
"There are builders out here who, 20 years ago, were bigger than we dared hope we could ever be," said Bruce Toll, the 48-year-old president. "Now we're buying their properties at fire-sale prices -- and we don't even have to worry about smoke damage."
While most of the industry drowns in debt, Toll has slashed its debt in half, to $50 million. And it has tons of cash at its fingertips. With more than $200 million in revolving lines of credit, it need not apply for construction loans, which the badly burned banks are refusing to make even to the healthiest developers. And that's on top of the $16 million Toll raised despite the building downturn in a secondary stock offering last May.
"Toll Brothers simply does a better job of creating an image than anyone they compete against," said James M. Meyer, an analyst with Janney Montgomery Scott Inc., who recently put Toll stock, which was has been trading at close to $8 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, on his "buy" list.
Still, Toll will need every one of these advantages in the coming years. The much-touted post-Persian Gulf War consumer spending spree lasted all of two months as far as new housing went. The National Association of Home Builders anticipates 1.05 million housing starts for 1991, the lowest level in 45 years. Even during the depths of the 1980-82 recession, housing starts did not drop below 1.06 million per year. "The credit crunch has literally stopped builders in their tracks," said Kent W. Colton, the association's executive vice president.
And the Northeast corridor, Toll's mainstay area, is recovering even more slowly than the West and Midwest. Home values are continuing to decline in New Hampshire, Maine and New Jersey, where Toll concentrates its building, according to Runzheimer International in Rochester, Wisc., which tracks selling prices of existing homes. And Mr. Colton says that values of new and old homes "absolutely track each other."
Moreover, Toll is about to enter one of the most hotly competitive eras in its history. Until now, Toll, whose homes generally sell in the $300,000 to $700,000 range, has competed primarily with local and regional builders -- exactly the folks who are having financial troubles. Toll peacefully coexisted with the few other well-capitalized, publicly traded development companies around because most of them emphasized starter homes, which rarely approach even $200,000.
But now, the bulk of the American population is moving into the 35-to-50 age range, when people trade up to larger, more expensive houses -- the kind that Toll builds. And the heavy hitters of real estate are following those aging baby boomers into that market.
K. Hovnanian & Company, for example, has introduced three new home models to appeal to this older, more affluent buyer. The huge New Jersey company, which stresses volume sales over high per-house profits, is unlikely to go much above $230,000 as a top price. But that number still butts up against the lower end of Toll's market.
"We may still be a Honda to their Mercedes, but we are definitely moving upscale," said Ara Hovnanian, the firm's president. "In this business demographics is destiny."
It is the sort of concept that also plays well with the Toll Brothers. Based as they are on immutable birth patterns from the past, demographics are easy to plan against. And plan the brothers did, though certainly not with the speculative, risk-taking gusto of mose other real estate dealers.
Throughout the last two decades, when other companies flocked to the fast-expanding Sun Belt, Toll stuck to the Northeast areas whose climates and tastes they knew well. And they stuck to the similarly familiar ground of single-family homes for upper-income people, lying in wait for the boomers who made starter homes the high-volume sellers in the mid-to-late 1980's.
Throughout the early to mid-1980's, real estate developers gobbled up land, improved it and built houses on it, all on the assumption that land values and housing prices would continually appreciate. But not Toll. "We analyze every deal on the basis of what it could bring us now, not what it might bring later," said Bob Toll, 50, the chief executive. "Sure, we missed some good deals, but I refuse to bet on a roll of the dice."
Despite its caution, Toll has made costly mistakes. It had to write down a total of $8 million in property in Boston in 1989 and 1990, when real estate values plummeted faster than Toll had anticipated. And the lingering recession has kept prices depressed at several of its developments.
To make matters worse, Toll is now competing with builders whose Crazy-Eddie styles of marketing attract not only attention, but buyers. Hovnanian, particularly, is known for its flamboyance: it once filled the Brendan Berne arena at the Meadowlands with some 10,000 people vying to buy homes at below-market prices. As Hovnanian starts building on Toll's turf, the marketing hoopla that it generates could prove a formidable distraction from Toll's more elegant, low-key sales methods.
Not coincidentally, Toll is rolling out heavy marketing artillery of its own. It has a reputation as a master of effective gimmicks like baking bread and boiling cinammon sticks in model houses to give them a homey atmosphere, or placing a fountain near the model house to mask the noise of traffic on a nearby highway. It was among the first real estate companies to put out four-color brochures for each development, and to run videotape presentations in the family rooms of its model homes.
But Toll is not relying purely on atmospherics. It has garnered a lot of customer good will by offering two pre-move-in inspections, one at which the buyer delineates the mop-up fixes that are needed, and the other to make sure they have been done.
Recently, Toll deliberately changed some features on its newer home models so that it could charge less for them and still retain the option of selling older, same-quality houses at prerecession prices.
Its salespeople also have in their desk drawers a list of extra-cost options -- fancy kinds of lighting or staircases, say -- that are not listed in the regular options manual, so customers think they have access to design features that most other buyers don't get.
And it is stirring its people into a selling frenzy. It just started a companywide contest in which salespeople compete for a trip to the Bahamas or Aruba. It recently held an in-house phone-a-thon in which sales managers called every prospect they had to induce them to make appointments.
"We've established goals for our salespeople, and we will do whatever it takes to help them attain them," said Zvi Barzilay, executive vice president of operations.
In many ways, Toll operates more like a basic manufacturing plant than a real estate company. It is one of the only real estate developers large enough to warrant a central buying and distribution office for key building materials like lumber and windows, and to manufacture its own roof trusses and wall panels. It has weekly sales meetings, project manager meetings and vice president meetings, all of which double as training sessions. Project managers can review each other's reports and numbers or listen to vendor presentations in search of optimum materials, sales approaches and cost reduction methods.
"There isn't a problem that someone else hasn't experienced somewhere," said Kira Hann, marketing director.
The project managers file weekly sales reports, and regularly compare their homes and prices with those of competing developments. They are expected to continually measure how their projects perform against cost and revenue projections.
"You've got to constantly factor in weather, or other things that affect the budgets but can't be controlled," said Joel H. Rassman, chief financial officer.
The most telling of those factors, of course, is how soon the still-elusive recovery will fully blossom. Until it does, though, Toll seems well positioned to capitalize on its competitors' woes. As Bruce Toll crows, "Our cash flow is tremendous."
 
 
BOB AND BRUCE, STUDY IN CONTRASTS
 Toll Brothers Inc. has professional managers and an outside board. But Bruce and Bob Toll, who together own 55 percent of the stock, run the show. And they have the division of duties down pat.
"Bob deals with the banks, with the press, with the outside world," said president Bruce. "I read the managers' reports and ask, 'How come streets cost you 18 percent of costs and the other guy's cost 13 percent?' "
Their staff also describes them as complementary, not similar. "They are not interchangeable," said Kira Hann, the marketing director. "They have different strengths, different loves, different interests."
Indeed they do. Bruce is an accountant, Bob is a lawyer. Both men have apartments in the tony part of New York's Upper East Side. But Bruce visits his only occasionally, spending most of his time at his home near the office. Bob has a home near New Hope, Pa., but does most of his socializing in New York. Bruce collects French Impressionistic paintings; Bob is an avid sailor.
Bruce describes himself as a "middle of the road Republican," and his brother Bob as a "very liberal Democrat." Bruce's philanthropy of choice is a Philadelphia hospital, where he sits on the board of trustees. Bob has "adopted" a third-grade class of 58 disadvantaged youngsters in West Philadelphia and is paying for counselors to work with these students and their families to "give them the types of advantages that point middle-class kids toward college."
The Tolls come from a solid middle class background themselves. Their father, Albert, now 85, was also a homebuilder, albeit on a smaller scale than his sons. Today he is a licensed real estate broker with an office at his sons' headquarters. Toll Brothers' staffers say he's in often, although mainly to manage his investments and kibbitz with his sons.
Both brothers have invested their own money in apartment houses and other real estate activities not linked to the company. Bruce also owns several car dealerships and a good chunk of Berwick Inc., a Warminster, Pa., biotechnology business that makes products that can isolate DNA in blood, that he hopes to take public soon.
Although they had no other siblings, both men opted to have large families -- Bruce has four children, Bob has five. Neither is forcing his kids into the business. A couple of the daughters have indicated possible interest, but for now at least, Zvi Barzilay, the 45-year-old executive vice president of operations, is generally considered next in line to run Toll.

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
Taking a Bug's-Eye View of the World

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
THERE is nothing like getting an insect's view of flowers and plants. Although many backyard gardeners may not even think about such a scheme, it is a rewarding exercise outdoors and well within the realm of possibility. How? Very simply with a hand lens, or pocket magnifier as it is sometimes called.
The lens concentrates the focus on the details of a flower in an amazing way and opens up a new view of the world around us. The lens can be held close to a flower or leaf without picking it, or for a closer look, the flower or leaf can be picked and brought indoors, where it can be handled closely and held to the light. The lens's magnification makes it possible to see the intricate designs of what have heretofore been thought of as rather ordinary plants, flowers and leaves. 
 One thing is certain: the use of such a lens even for a day's adventure will open one's eyes and help one to look upon the world of plants differently. Such awareness will at least allow for a brighter appreciation of the beauty of the flora around us. And there will be more to see than just color, which is usually the first feature that helps identify plants.
The hand lens is an essential tool used by serious botanists who want to get the identification of a plant species right. No true taxonomist would ever want to be in the field without one. Illustrators and painters who draw plants are particularly keen on learning the details of their makeup.
Although this sort of hand lens is sometimes hard to find, the better ones, that magnify to 10 power at least, are often found in nature centers or stores where cameras and optical equipment are sold. They range in price, but a good 10-power hand lens can be obtained for about $10. Better ones, and cheaper ones with less magnification, are also available. In the field the lens is usually carried on a string or cord hung around the neck.
This type of lens is essential for anyone who is working with a botanical key to identify a plant. Students particularly need to own such a vital tool. But the average gardener would probably not dissect a plant as carefully as those who are learning to know its special identity.
How else can someone determine if a plant has minute natural scales on the backs of its leaves (true of many small-leaved rhododendrons) or tiny hairs along the leaf veins? These sorts of detail are best left to the taxonomists.
This type of plant magnification is especially appealing to children who are eager to have a closer look at how flowers and leaves are put together.
One of the most fascinating things that a magnifying hand lens can reveal is the route that an insect takes when it pollinates a flower. Route is the right word, too, for the flower's beauty, though pleasing to the gardener's eye, is essentially part of nature's plan for pollination.
In her delightful book "Botany for All Ages" Jori Hunken offers this clue: "Each flower face is a set of instructions as to how to enter the blossom and procure the promised nectar or pollen. In general, a bright and showy surface or alluring scent catches insects' attention from a distance."
Then she goes on to describe how flowers are constructed, with guides to the pollinators to entice them into the flower. All of these minute mechanisms are visible with the magnification of the hand lens.
Yellow, blue and lavender flowers tend to attract bees while flies go for the white flowers. Hummingbirds, it is well known, are attracted to the color red. A butterfly inserts its proboscis deep into each flower for a moment, then it is off just as quickly and beautifully to the next flower.
If the butterfly's brief visit is followed by an examination of the flowers with a hand lens, the goal of the butterfly's visit will be revealed, and it will be possible to see the route it followed into the flower to sip the nectar.
Though it has taken eight years, the book "Common-Sense Pest Control" (Taunton Press, Newtown, Conn., $39.95) has arrived. The authors -- William Olkowski, Sheila Daar and Helga Olkowski -- founded the Bio-Integral Resource Center headquartered in Berkeley, Calif., and since 1978 their organization has helped municipal and Federal agencies to get rid of economically damaging pests.
Always on the sidelines, however, were the pests faced by home gardeners. The researchers found that a modern approach to pest control with environmentally sound methods provides worthy dividends, and they have described it in this excellent reference, worthy of space in any library.

HEADLINE: Japan Deports Chinese but Others Are Hopeful

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Japan has deported another group of Chinese seeking to stay here, including a Chinese woman who sought political asylum. But lawyers for Chinese dissidents here say they are still hopeful that students who may face political persecution in China will be allowed to stay in Japan.
But the lawyers said they were somewhat shaken by Japan's abrupt decision on Wednesday to deport the 62 Chinese, sending them from the southern city of Nagasaki to Shanghai on a chartered Chinese plane. They called on the Government to provide a fuller explanation of its actions. 
 Nearly 2,900 refugees from China and Vietnam have arrived in boats in Japan since 1989, and the Government has insisted that they be sent back, saying they are seeking jobs, not political freedom. Of these, 2,425 have been sent back, including the 62 on Wednesday.
The latest deportations drew particular attention because they came after Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu had spent several days in China, toasting Japanese-Chinese friendship as the first leader of a major industrial democracy to visit China since the crackdown on the democracy movement at Tiananmen Square in 1989.
Under Mr. Kaifu, Japan has resumed its aid to China and sought to plead Beijing's case that it not be "isolated" because of its human rights violations. Japanese business executives are also eager to see ties resume to protect and increase trade and investments.
Japan has been severely criticized by human rights groups for its handling of Chinese students. Asia Watch, based in the United States, said last year that Japan had "forcibly repatriated" dissidents, impeded their access to lawyers and shown hostility to their political concerns.
Among those deported on Wednesday was Lin Guizhen, 24 years old, who had fought deportation because she said she had taken part in the pro-democracy protests in 1989 at Tiananmen Square in Beijing before the Chinese Government's crackdown.
But Japanese officials, explaining her expulsion, said today that she fell into a different category from the Chinese students in Japan who engaged in anti-Government protests at the time of the Tiananmen crackdown, in that she arrived by boat with so-called "economic refugees" in December 1989.
"This lady is not a political refugee," a Japanese official said. "She was not a student in Japan. She arrived with 230 other people on the same boat."
According to Asia Watch, 15,000 Chinese students were in Japan last year, and 48,000 more were in language schools, the largest number in any country outside of China. But in recent months, news reports have focused on about 70 or 80 students who are seeking political asylum.
 
Status Is Precarious
 Supporters of this group say that although Japan has promised to deal with them case by case and has not forced them back, their status is very precarious and they cannot find employment. Some supporters of the students said recently that progress had been made on their status.
A Government official, asking not to be identified, said today that a first group of 23 students would probably be given formal political asylum soon. And a lawyer for the students said asylum might be granted to more than this first group.
 "We are convinced that we are making progress with other students," said Katsutoshi Fujimori, a Tokyo lawyer supporting the Chinese students. "If we don't make progress, we will have to raise our voices again." He said the case of Ms. Lin did not discourage him, although he opposed her deporation.
Supporters of Ms. Lin said today that she was in danger of being persecuted when she returned home to China, and that she and other refugees also had political motives because they were seeking freedom. They said Japan was belittling their cause unfairly.

HEADLINE: U.S. IS ENCOURAGED BY HANOI CABINET

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
A major Cabinet reorganization in Vietnam has improved the prospects for settling the Cambodian civil war and accelerating the thaw in relations with Washington, senior Administration officials say.
American officials expressed hope that the changes in the Cabinet would reduce tensions between Vietnam and China, particularly since the departing officials include the Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, who has long been hostile to Beijing. 
 They say a rapprochement between China and Vietnam should help the two rivals reach a settlement in their proxy war in Cambodia, which in turn would meet the most important condition set by the United States for opening full diplomatic relations with Vietnam.
"The road to a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia and a normalization of relations with Vietnam is open," said a senior Administration official who monitors Asia. "This is the beginning of the coming to power of a new generation in Hanoi. The question is, are we at the Andropov stage, the Chernenko stage or the Gorbachev stage?"
 
4 Ministers From the South
 Administration officials note that four of Vietnam's seven new ministers are from the south and have been associated with efforts toward economic reform. The officials say they believe the new Cabinet reflects a decision by the Communist Party Politburo to emulate the Chinese model, in which steps to expand private enterprise are accompanied by tight, centralized control over the nation's politics.
Vo Van Kiet, the new Prime Minister, declared soon after his election by the National Assembly that Hanoi and Washington must put the Vietnam War behind them by quickly opening relations. As a token of his commitment, he promised to press the search for American servicemen who are still unaccounted for.
The State Department publicly shrugged off Mr. Kiet's plea and demanded that Vietnam withdraw its 5,000 remaining advisers from Cambodia as part of a peace settlement there.
But senior Administration officials have privately praised Mr. Kiet as a practical reformer who would work with the new Ministers of Trade and State Planning to encourage private enterprise and open the way for loans from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
 
New M.I.A. Office
 Washington has blocked any agreements between Vietnam and the lending institutions. But a change in that policy is now being weighed as a gesture of appreciation for Hanoi's decision to let the Pentagon open an office in the Vietnamese capital last month to search for American servicemen missing since the Vietnam War.
John R. Bolton, Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, said he doubted that a removal of that embargo and full relations were imminent. But he said the Cabinet changes "would seem to give more promise for us to go forward."
Administration officials view the replacement of Mr. Thach, who is known in diplomatic circles for his abrasiveness, as particularly significant. The hostility that often characterized the Foreign Minister's exchanges with Beijing officials was apparently rooted in China's invasion of Vietnam in 1979.
Mr. Thach has also bitterly criticized Beijing for supplying the Khmer Rouge rebels fighting the Cambodian Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen, which was installed by Vietnam.
 
Effect of Soviet Aid Cutoff
 "A common theory in Hanoi is that the departure of Thach is a sop to the Chinese," said Douglas Pike, director of Indochina studies at the University of California at Berkeley, who recently visited Vietnam.
But an impression among senior Vietnamese officers that Mr. Thach was ineffectual in securing military aid from Moscow contributed equally if not more to his ouster, he said.
The new Foreign Minister, Nguyen Manh Cam, a former Ambassador to Moscow, is thought to be convinced that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will continue to cut aid to Vietnam, and that Hanoi must therefore broaden its ties with other countries.
There are signs that Vietnam's foreign policy is already shifting. Officials of Thailand said Friday that Vietnam had agreed to send a delegate to Cambodian peace talks on Aug. 26 at the Thai resort of Pattaya.
American officials hope that Vietnam will advise the Cambodian Government in Phomn Penh to accept the installation by the end of this year of the Supreme National Council, a reconciliation body led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk that includes representatives of the Government, the Khmer Rouge and two other rebel groups.
 
Obstacles to Peace Plan
 Under a peace plan promoted by the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, the Supreme National Council would help the United Nations supervise a demobilization of the warring forces and prepare the country for elections.
Vietnam has traditionally opposed the idea of letting Khmer Rouge representatives re-enter Phnom Penh, a position that China contends precludes a peaceful settlement. American officials said they hoped that China would in turn stop sending military aid to the Khmer Rouge once it is assured that Vietnam no longer intends to station troops in Cambodia.
American officials said they hoped Vietnam and China could agree to support the peace plan without seeking unfair advantage for their clients.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK IS SEEING HINTS OF RECOVERY

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Economists who are paid to watch every twitch and hiccup of the New York City economy are starting to see signs of life. Not dramatic signs -- certainly not enough to justify buying a magnum of Dom Perignon -- but stirrings across a broad-enough spectrum to indicate that the economy's four-year free fall may be ending.
The rate of job losses in the metropolitan area is finally slowing. Wall Street is having its first good run of business in three years. The market for midtown Manhattan office space is showing the first signs of firming up. And stores and hotels are reporting a slight increase in business. 
 These are just a few of the straws in the wind that are giving economists reason for what they like to call cautious optimism. "We're not vaulting out of recession -- or even jumping out -- but we are taking small steps," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Of course, not everything is rosy. More than 1,000 companies in New York City failed in the first half of 1991, nearly double last year's rate. And there are no clear signs yet that claims for unemployment insurance in the tri-state area are abating. That may be a reason why there is no obvious improvement yet in the public mood.
There are also more job losses coming -- with big layoffs expected at Pan Am, Manufacturers Hanover, the Chemical Bank and the city government -- that will act as a drag on the economy. And it is hard to ignore the risk of the national economy tumbling back into recession, which could dampen New York's prospects for recovery, although the linkage between the two economies is not exact.
In the 1981-82 recession, for instance, the New York area did not suffer nearly as badly as the nation. And this time around, the region entered its recession 17 months before the national economy sagged, so it may be further through the wringing-out process and readier for rebound.
Despite all of these caveats, many New York area economists are willing to put their necks out and say there is a change in the air. "There are a few positive signs out there, and we haven't had any at all for four years," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
 
Clues in the Job Market
 One of the best clues to future economic prospects is the job market. According to Mr. Ehrenhalt, the 23 counties in the metropolitan region that span New York and New Jersey lost 90,400 jobs in the first half of the year. While that is nothing to cheer about, it is a considerable improvement over the 115,500 jobs that were lost in the last six months of last year. And Mr. Ehrenhalt notes that the unemployment rate for New York State and New Jersey has been holding fairly steady for the last two months, after rising sharply earlier this year.
Within the job market, the brightest single spot is Wall Street. The securities industry seems to be near the tail end of a large-scale restructuring, during which it has reduced jobs and overhead back. The results of that reconfiguring are becoming apparent: Profits were stronger in the first half of the year than they have been since 1987. Merrill Lynch & Company and Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company reported record earnings in the second quarter, and Bear, Stearns & Company recently increased its bonuses by an average of 15 percent over last year.
 
'A Very Important Floor'
 With the return of profits, the number of people on the industry's payroll has started to grow again. Since salaries on Wall Street are the highest in the region, averaging around $78,000 a year, that can quickly translate into more restaurant bills, clothing purchases and co-op sales.
"This puts a very important floor under the recession for the city," Ms. Scanlon said.
Already, there are some signs that New Yorkers are renewing their interest in shopping. Retail sales in the region are still far from robust. But in every month since January, the pace of decline has been slower than in the comparable period a year earlier. In June, sales were actually higher than a year earlier.
In what seemed like a confirmation of this trend, R. H. Macy & Company reported last week that its sales had increased for the first time in four quarters, a development that it termed "a significant reversal."
Macy's would not divulge what portion of that improvement was a result of business in the New York area. But Julian Taub, a senior vice president at Bloomingdale's, said his New York stores were reporting healthy back-to-school sales and double-digit increases in sales of fashion accessories, handbags and men's wear. He attributed the improvement to promotions and the arrival of new merchandise.
"I see slightly improved sales for Bloomingdale's in the metropolitan area," he said, explaining that "slightly" meant less than 5 percent.
 
An Increase in Tourism
 Mr. Taub said he could not tell whether the improvement in sales was a result of increased buying by tourists or New York residents. But there are signs that more visitors are coming to the New York area. Since February, airport arrivals have been higher than they were the previous month. And the average occupancy rate in city hotels for June was 74.6 percent, compared with 73.8 percent a year earlier.
Although this is a modest improvement, and only for one month, "it is significant because it's the first year-over-year increase we've had for 18 months," said John A. Fox, a principal at the New York accounting firm of Pannell Kerr Forster, which monitors the hotel industry.
There are other, more general signs that economic life in New York is improving. A spokesman for the Consolidated Edison Company said the number of customers who were late in paying their bills was beginning to decline, albeit modestly. And city officials were pleasantly surprised in May and June to see a $100 million surge in the revenues they collected from the general corporation tax, the unincorporated business tax and the bank tax.
The sense that business is finally beginning to pick up seems to have spurred some companies to make one of the hardest decisions of all -- to commit to leasing office space. James Vanderslice, a managing director at the realty concern Cushman & Wakefield, said many companies had been sitting on the sidelines for months, watching as rents tumbled and landlords offered such incentives as several months of free rent to attract tenants.
 
A Dip in the Vacancy Rate
 Now, he said, he detects a change in outlook, in which people are beginning to think that if this is not the bottom of the market, it is exceedingly close. "Companies are starting to make decisions now to go forward on real estate," he said, a change that is reflected in the office vacancy rate.
After several months of stabilizing, the primary vacancy rate for midtown office space actually dipped in June, to 16.2 percent from 17.4 percent, for the first time since October. The downtown rate declined in April and May, and remained at 17 percent in June.
More office space will be coming on the market in the next few years as a result of the merger of the Chemical Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. Still, Mr. Vanderslice said, he believes that most of the large blocks of office space that are likely to become vacant have already been identified.
The sharp decline in new construction is also likely to shore up the market in the near term, he said.
 
Signs of Stabilization
 What all of these indicators suggest is that the New York economy is stabilizing, which as every business owner and employee knows, is far different from growing. Just as many economists have concluded that the national recovery will be tepid, so those who study the local tea leaves are expecting a generally sluggish period until at least early next year.
Although the Federal Reserve Board has recently pushed down interest rates again to help insure that the recovery does not fizzle, that may not be enough. The latest Federal Reserve survey of banks in the New York area found that over the last three months, a majority of them had tightened their credit standards even more.
"There's definitely something there," Mr. Ehrenhalt said, taking note of the many slivers of light. "But the situation is still fragile."

HEADLINE: Economy Kills Contested Plan for Flushing Project

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
New York City is dropping a bitterly contested plan to build a large apartment and commercial complex, Flushing Center, on a city-owned parking lot in Queens.
But city officials say it is not the opposition of many residents and civic groups in the surrounding Flushing area that has killed the five-year-old plan but the current recession, which they say has made the project no longer financially viable. 
 If this is the case, the $180 million Flushing Center development is the latest casualty of an economic climate that has killed or paralyzed a number of big development schemes, publicly or privately promoted, across New York City.
Carl Weisbrod, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said the decision to give up on Flushing Center was a "mutual decision" between his agency and the private developer that the agency had chosen for the site, a group whose managing partner is the builder William Zeckendorf Jr. The decision, Mr. Weisbrod said, was "based on the developer's assessment that the project was not economically viable." Mr. Zeckendorf could not be reached for comment.
 
Other Abandoned Projects
 "There is much more reluctance to lend for real-estate projects and particularly, as in this instance, on a somewhat speculative basis," Mr. Weisbrodsaid on Friday. "So projects that would have been easily financable and doable in the mid-80's are becoming much more difficult even in areas like Flushing, a vibrant area."
Mr. Weisbrod said in an interview that other major projects that the recession had forced his agency to drop were those involving a planned retail and restaurant complex in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, and the South Ferry project, involving a planned office tower at the foot of lower Manhattan.
Pointing out that there were also many Flushing residents and civic groups that favored the Flushing Center proposal, Mr. Weisbrod said that "if the project had been viable and we thought it was a good project we would have gone forward with it." The latest work on it involved re-designing it to scale it down in an effort to meet the objections of local opponents, who denounced the original plan as too large.
They called it an example of unplanned development that they said was turning the downtown Flushing commercial section into a congested district.
By contrast, local supporters of the project said it would help carry forward what they saw as a welcome revival of downtown Flushing, which declined in the 1970's but was rejuvenated in the 80's into one of the city's most dynamic retail districts, in which new office buildings also rose and a new hotel is nearing completion.
The project would have risen on a sprawling parking lot of nearly six acres at Union Street and 39th Avenue. The original proposal called for two 16-story towers and a row of town houses with a total of almost 400 condominium apartments; a six-story office building, and a mall with more than 70 stores and a multi-screen movie complex. The apartments would not have been publicly subsidized and would have sold at "market rates" under the plan. The cost of building the complex was put at $180 million in early 1990.
But after criticism by local opponents, Queens Community Board 7, whose purview includes downtown Flushing, recommended changes to reduce the project's scope, including elimination of one of the apartment towers, and city officials and the developer said they would try to incorporate the suggestions in a re-design.
 
Mixed Reaction
 But in recent months, as the recession deepened, work on the re-design appeared to have slowed, if not stopped altogether, some Flushing civic leaders said. Mr. Weisbrod said that in view of the proposal's unlikely prospects "for the foreseeable future" it "didn't make sense to keep it alive."
The reaction to the project's demise mirrored the sentiment toward it when it was alive.
"I think there's general hallelujah around," Pam Keating, until recently president of the Off-Broadway Homeowners Association, one of the Flushing groups that opposed the project, said yesterday.
"A lot of people are sorry that we are losing a quality development," said Myra Baird Herce, a consultant to the Flushing Business Association, which supported a scaled-down version of the proposal.
But both women said they were worried because of the uncertain future of the site, where, they agreed, the current parking lot was deteriorating, the city having avoided spending money on it while the redevelopment possibility was alive.
Mr. Weisbrod said, "We will go back to the drawing boards and look at what sort of project we should have here in light of these times and the community's views."
