HEADLINE: IRAN TAKING LEAD IN THE BARGAINING TO FREE HOSTAGES

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Iran's Government, using secret intermediaries and shuttle diplomacy, has taken the lead in negotiating the terms and conditions for the release of the 10 remaining Western hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militants, high-level Western officials say.
The full mobilization of Iran's diplomatic corps in the negotiations now under way with the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, suggests that Iran's President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, may have overcome powerful opposition in the Teheran leadership to force a resolution of the hostage crisis, these officials say. 
 The presence of senior Iranian officials in the three-way talks with Mr. Perez de Cuellar and Israeli negotiators also indicates that Syria is playing a secondary role, though Damascus is supporting Teheran's initiative and providing security in Lebanon.
 
Obstacles in Lebanon
 But Iran faces daunting obstacles of diplomacy and local politics in Lebanon before it can claim success, say United States officials, who note the unresolved demands of the Lebanese kidnappers and of Israeli officials who are bargaining for the return of seven missing servicemen.
Calls by Shiite Muslim clerics and Iranian officials on Friday for Israel to make an early gesture of good will to match the recent releases of the hostages John McCarthy and Edward Austin Tracy reflect the intense pressures on the negotiating process.
Western officials, seeking to understand why Iran's long-stalemated leadership has finally decided to move forcefully on the hostage front, have concluded from their discussions with senior Iranians that Teheran was compelled to break out of its isolation paradoxically because the Persian Gulf war thoroughly undermined its longtime rival, Iraq, as a regional power.
 
A Fundamental Choice
 If Iran's moribund economy and desperate need for Western investment and technology were not incentive enough, the allied defeat of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, and the prospect of a Middle East conference this fall featuring the first face-to-face peace talks between Israel and its Arab enemies have presented Iran's leaders with a fundamental choice, these officials said.
Teheran could remain isolated, threatened by growing domestic unrest, or its leaders could seize an opportunity to supplant Iraq as the region's dominant power by re-engaging the West, said Western officials interviewed in the United States and Europe.
A reconstruction of events shows that senior Iranian envoys, particularly Iran's delegate to the United Nations, Kamal Kharrazi, have assumed pivotal roles in the United Nations effort to bridge differences between the kidnappers and Israel.
From the interviews, it is possible to discern some of the most important channels of communication used by the kidnappers and their patrons. The messages that moved through these channels have been cited by President Bush and his advisers as the cause of their qualified optimism on the hostages.
The earliest word that two hostages would be released this month came from a series of diplomatic messages by Teheran. One of the first occurred in a face-to-face meeting in Bonn during the first days of August between Iran's Ambassador to Germany, Hussein Musavian, and Hans-Dietrich Genscher, Germany's Foreign Minister.
Mr. Musavian's message that a hostage breakthrough was imminent prompted Mr. Genscher to brief British and American officials. As he was doing so, Iranian Foreign Ministry officials in Teheran called in the British charge d'affaires, David N. Reddaway, and a Swiss diplomat to give them the same message: Two hostages, one British and one American, would be released as a gesture of good will.
The messages were just being absorbed when on Aug. 6, the kidnappers who hold Terry A. Anderson and Thomas M. Sutherland, both Americans, issued a communique asserting that they were sending an "envoy" within 48 hours to meet with Mr. Perez de Cuellar. At the same time, The Teheran Times, an English-language newspaper that is close to the Foreign Ministry and was once edited by Mr. Musavian, reported that an American and a British hostage would be released by the end of the week.
Within hours of these public developments, Mr. Kharrazi, Iran's United Nations delegate, began a series of secret visits to the United Nations Secretariat for long consultations with Mr. Perez de Cuellar, Western officials said. From this point onward, the Secretary General dealt exclusively with Iranian Government officials on matters dealing with the Lebanese kidnappers' demands, Western officials said.
 
Journalists Kept in Dark
 United Nations officials were instructed to shield these meetings from journalists, who had staked out the Secretariat.
Mr. Kharrazi, a trusted member of President Rafsanjani's inner circle for years, returned to the Secretary General's offices several times on Aug. 7, and after a marathon meeting that began that evening, Mr. Perez de Cuellar instructed his principal aide, Giandomenico Picco, to leave the next morning for Damascus and Beirut.
A Bush Administration official said Mr. Picco's presence at Mr. McCarthy's release had come as a surprise as Washington watched the events from the sidelines.
Mr. McCarthy's emergence, with the letter from the kidnappers for Mr. Perez de Cuellar, set the stage for a meeting with the Secretary General on Aug. 11 at the Lyneham air base near London.
 
Letter Called Unspecific
 Upon reading the letter, the Secretary General returned to Geneva expressing disappointment that the text lacked the kind of diplomatic specificity needed to formulate a deal between the kidnappers and Israel.
Still, Mr. McCarthy told Mr. Perez de Cuellar of more specific terms that the kidnappers had in mind for a trade: all the Western hostages in return for Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid, who was abducted in an Israeli commando raid in July 1989, and about 400 Lebanese and Palestinian detainees in Israel's detention camp at Khiam.
The next day, Mr. Kharrazi appeared in Geneva and went straight to the Secretary General's suite at La Reserve Hotel. Mr. Kharrazi indicated that Teheran believed that it could secure the release of all 10 Western hostages in exchange for the Sheik and the prisoners at Khiam.
United Nations officials were impressed by the similarity between Mr. McCarthy's and Mr. Kharazzi's messages. Nonetheless, Mr. Perez de Cuellar wanted clarifications, given the nebulous language of the kidnappers' letter.
 
Iran 'Very, Very Useful'
 After this two-hour meeting, Mr. Kharrazi departed for Teheran, and the Secretary General told reporters outside his hotel, "I explained to him what I have already done, and I asked them to continue helping me in my efforts." Then he added, "Iran has been very, very useful to me in all this process."
At the Geneva meeting, Mr. Kharrazi also reported that despite statements by groups claiming to hold Israelis or their remains in Lebanon, Iran could account for only two of the seven missing, and that both were dead. Iran, he said, could guarantee the return of the remains.
On another difficult point, Mr. Kharrazi also said Iran understood the legal problems in securing the release of accused terrorists in European jails. Though no solution has been found, United Nations officials have discussed the idea of European governments making public statements about the sentences and prospects for parole for these terrorists.
 
Meeting With Israeli
 As Iran mulled the reaction of the United States and Israel to the release of Mr. McCarthy and Mr. Tracy, the Secretary General met with Israel's chief hostage negotiator, Uri Lubrani, who made clear that Israel would agree to release Arab detainees at Khiam, including Sheik Obeid, but would not act until it received authoritative word on its seven servicemen.
After a second meeting with the Israeli team on Thursday, Mr. Perez de Cuellar made a telephone call from Geneva to Mr. Kharrazi in Teheran to relay the specifics of Israel's demand for information.
As of today, Mr. Kharrazi had not reported back, and United Nations officials say they hope that Iran has undertaken a thorough investigation through the kidnappers and other groups in Lebanon that have held prisoners.
Such an effort could probably not occur without Syrian assistance, since the Syrian Army remains dominant in Lebanon. It is assumed by United Nations officials that intense Syrian pressure was behind the release of Jerome Leyraud, a French relief worker briefly held after Mr. McCarthy was freed.
With the Iranian investigation apparently under way at the end of the week, the hostage diplomacy came to a pause. Western officials said the Secretary General left for a vacation in Portugal with hopes that by the time he returns to Geneva on Aug. 25, the "process" he started will have borne fruit.
 
Lack of Rancor Toward Iran
 Western officials who observed the process noted a remarkable lack of rancor about the decisiveness of Teheran's actions. The difference between this episode and earlier ones was that key Iranian figures all were allies of Mr. Rafsanjani.
Bush Administration officials say that for practical and political reasons, they have intentionally stayed on the sidelines as Mr. Perez de Cuellar has negotiated with a half-dozen or more countries that have influence or interests in the hostage problem.
There have been no inter-agency or other high-level Bush Administration meetings in Washington to consider hostage developments, an Administration official said, and the reports coming from diplomatic and intelligence sources have a limited distribution to Mr. Bush, Secretary of States James A. Baker 3d, the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and his deputy, Robert M. Gates, the official said.
"Things are not trickling down," the official said. "Part of it is Bush's style, and part of it is that we have to be able to say we were not involved."

HEADLINE: Shadow on a Market

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The admission by Salomon Brothers that it had violated Treasury market rules and the resignation on Friday of its top two executives have focused new attention on this huge but little understood and lightly regulated market, and generated renewed calls for tighter regulation.
The resignations of the top two executives of Salomon Brothers Inc., John H. Gutfreund, the chairman and chief executive, and Thomas W. Strauss, the president, which the board is expected to accept today, followed the furor over their failure to disclose promptly the firm's irregular activities in buying Treasury securities. 
 The abuses took place in the little-known but important corner of the market, the when-issued market in which new Treasury securities -- the bonds that are sold to finance the Government's ever-growing national debt -- are traded even before they are sold by the Government. That pre-sale trading helps insure that the bonds slide easily into the marketplace when they do arrive.
Over all, the Treasury market dwarfs most others in size, with more than $2 trillion in bonds outstanding and more than $100 billion of them traded each day. By contrast, the value of the more than 1,800 companies on the New York Stock Exchange exceeds $3 trillion, but daily trading volume is less than $10 billion. Many of those buying and selling bonds are large institutions, including pension funds, insurance companies and mutual funds, in which most Americans have a stake.
Because there is no risk of default by the bond issuer -- the Federal Government is presumed to be able to print dollars, if necessary -- this market has largely escaped the extensive regulation of others.
 
Importance of Dealers
 The Treasury Department conducts a series of auctions of bills, of up to a year; notes, of up to 10 years; and bonds, generally up to 30 years. Individuals may place direct orders, too. But dealers usually account for much of the auction, buying for themselves or their customers.
Salomon has long been one of a select group of firms, the Federal Reserve's primary dealers, that are required to bid at every auction. They are the only firms the Federal Reserve deals with in the open market transactions it uses to make adjustments to interest rates and the money supply. Besides being required to participate in all auctions, primary dealers must make markets in all Treasury securities and report weekly to the Fed on their volume and their market positions.
To qualify for the Fed's inner circle, these firms -- there are now 40 -- must meet certain criteria. They must account for at least 1 percent of the trading for customers (as opposed to inter-dealer trading) in Government securities, and the Fed must be satisfied with their finances.
 
Before the Auctions
 Even before the auctions, there is a good deal of action in the when-issued segment of the market. While it may seem odd for firms to be trading securities that have not yet been issued, it is considered necessary to allow investors and dealers to estimate demand for the bonds. But the market is also subject to abuse. Although there are no public statistics on this market, it is clear that billions are traded during the intense activity that accompanies the auctions.
When-issued trading begins as soon as the Treasury announces just how large a bond sale will be. For example, on Wednesday it will announce the size of a two-year note auction, to be held Aug. 27, and a five-year note auction to be held the following day. The bonds will be issued on Aug. 30.
While some dealers and investors are buying bonds, other will be selling them, on a when-issued basis, expecting to buy them at the auctions. They are betting that interest rates will rise, and bond prices decline, by the time the actual auction is held.
Treasury rules bar bidders from buying more than 35 percent of the issue, including whatever bonds have been previously bought in the when-issued market. The 35 percent rule is one of the rules that Salomon has admitted breaking. It has also said it bought bonds for itself using customer names, without their authorization.
 
Preventing a 'Squeeze'
 The reason for the 35 percent rule is to prevent a "squeeze" from developing. In such a case, those who had sold bonds in the when-issued market would be forced to buy them from the few dealers who had possession of the actual bonds, and thereby be forced to pay higher prices than overall market levels would indicate.
The Treasury Department believes such a squeeze occurred last May, in an auction of two-year notes. Salomon has admitted buying at least 44 percent of the issue, saying the violation was inadvertent. The Government has not said how much, if at all, it thinks the squeeze did move rates. There was a spike in rates at the time of the auction.
But even as Salomon's board moves to name Warren E. Buffett, the respected chairman of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and a Salomon director, as an interim successor to Mr. Gutfreund, there will be intense scrutiny of the workings of the Treasury markets -- and of Salomon's actions and their consequences.
Decisions for the Government
It is expected that any Government action against Salomon will include fines but could stop short of putting the firm out of the Treasury bond business. The Government needs to sell bonds, and Salomon's withdrawal from the market could make that more difficult. At the same time, a perception that an important part of the market is being abused could cost the Government money if buyers shy away.
The Treasury says that as a result of the squeeze, some dealers lost money, and it has expressed concern about future auctions. "If dealers are not reasonably comfortable that they can deliver securities that they have sold prior to the auction, they will be less likely to participate in pre-auction distribution of new issues," Assistant Secretary Mary C. Sophos wrote in a letter to Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts.
Representative Markey, the chairman of the subcommittee on telecommunications and finance, said the Salomon scandal "underscores the need for improvements in regulation."
Those changes could include requirements to make more information about pricing available to the public and to open trading practices to closer scrutiny. The Securities and Exchange Commission would like to get jurisdiction over such trading, a desire that bond dealers have resisted.

HEADLINE: As Telephones Multiply, Dialing Will Take Longer

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The nation is rapidly running out of telephone numbers.
As facsimile machines, cellular phones, pocket pagers, computer modems and business telephones proliferate, the supply of unassigned numbers is being exhausted in the area codes serving the largest American cities, like 212 for Manhattan and the Bronx and 213 for Los Angeles. 
 When that happened in the past, an area code was split into two, based on geography, but today only three unallocated area codes remain: 210, 810 and 910, and they may not be enough to satisfy the booming demand.
Yet they must last until July 1995, when a new numbering plan is scheduled to take effect, telephone industry executives say. The expansion cannot take place until then because all of the nation's telephone switches must be reprogrammed -- a complex and time-consuming task.
"You have four full years to go," said Frank J. Saletel, director of major-market access planning for New York Telephone. "It's not a New York City concern as such, but there could be some areas of the country that may have to resort to rationing their delivery of numbers."
 
Costly and Frustrating
 The change in the numbering system planned by Bellcore, the telephone industry research organization responsible for allocating phone numbers in North America, will permit the creation of area codes that do not have a "0" or a "1" as the middle digit. Computerized telephone switching equipment currently looks at the second digit of an area code to determine whether a long-distance call is being made.
Some telephone industry executives say the needed changes may be costly and frustrating and will require many callers to dial 11 digits, rather than 7, even when calling a neighbor in the same area code. They also say the change will be difficult for the telephone companies and create serious problems for businesses.
Further confusion will be created because of differences in how toll calls are dialed within area codes. Bellcore cannot enforce standards, but can only recommend changes to individual state public utility commissions. So far the Bellcore plan has been put in place in 23 area codes, and about half of those require callers to dial "1" plus their own area code before the number, while the others just have to dial the number.
A number of alternative solutions to the Bellcore plan are being proposed. Some industry people are backing an idea that would increase the local dialing sequence to eight digits, rather than seven, and several smaller telephone companies have proposed shifting to a four-digit area code. No serious consideration is being given to the idea of combining lightly used area codes to provide more numbers to congested areas.
 
'Lambs to the Slaughter'
 "Like lambs to the slaughter, American telephone users are being led into a course that will have far worse implications than what most of us see at the moment," said David C. Henny, president of the Whidbey Telephone Company in Langley, Wash.
In a recent industry technical journal, Mr. Henny proposed a system of four-digit area codes, which he says would be a simpler alternative to the Bellcore plan and provide a 10-fold increase in area codes. He says his plan would require fewer changes in telephone switching systems and would result in numbers that are easier for people to remember.
Bellcore officials say that their plan is the most efficient and inexpensive method of coping with the proliferation of telephone numbers and that their system will last well into the next century.
They also say the alternatives would likely cause more confusion or would be more expensive because every telephone customer would have a new number. Such a switch would force businesses across the country to change stationery and business cards, among other adjustments.
Bellcore's interchangeable area code plan will increase the potential number of phone numbers to approximately six billion. The plan would add 640 area codes to the current supply of 152. These area codes allow a potential of 900 million numbers, with about 250 million numbers in use now. Within each area code, there are 792 available prefixes, consisting of 10,000 numbers. Area codes and prefixes that begin with 0 or 1 are avoided, and some numbers like "800" and "900" are reserved for special uses.
The plan will also create overlapping area codes. Rather than carve Manhattan into two geographic areas with different codes, in January New York Telephone will add a second area code, 917, to overlap Manhattan's existing 212 dialing area. The 917 code will initially be used for assigning new numbers for cellular phones, pagers and New York Telephone's internal operations, but officials say they may eventually distribute numbers in the new area code to computer users and regular telephone customers.
 
Proliferating Area Codes
 This model, in which one geographic region will have a pool of two or more area codes, will ultimately require callers to dial 11 digits for both local and long-distance calls. For example, a Manhattan resident with a 212 area code might have a next-door neighbor in the 917 area, and eventually, a third neighbor might end up in yet another new area code.
The Bellcore officials prefer a standard nationwide 11-digit dialing sequence to avoid different dialing procedures in different parts of the country.
"People are going to get used to 10-digit numbers," said Ron Conners, the Bellcore district administrator in charge of the North American numbering plan (People in the telephone industry often refer to the 11-digit numbers as 1 plus 10.) "Psychological studies have shown people don't care what they have to dial, as long as it's consistent."
Although the rapid growth in phone numbers has stemmed partly from new technologies like cellular phones, facsimile machines and computer modems, advanced corporate PBX (private branch exchange) systems -- which assign a separate number to each employee of a company -- have also played a role. Some telecommunications analysts also say the existing pool of phone numbers is poorly managed.
"We have a practice where large blocks of phone numbers can be warehoused by corporations or organizations to provide for future growth," said Eli Noam, a telcommunications expert at Columbia University. "As an economist, that seems to be a wasteful practice."

HEADLINE: In an Assault on Tradition, More Schools Last All Year

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PLANO, Tex., Aug. 11

 BODY:
In a head-on attack on an American institution -- the long, lazy summer -- a small but fast-growing number of schools around the nation are slashing the summer vacation by weeks and moving their students to a year-round calendar of shorter but more frequent breaks.
And they are increasingly making the switch for purely educational reasons, maintaining that since it is easier for children to retain information over short breaks than over long ones the new schedule improves learning and frees teachers to teach more and review less. 
 Some educators also see the year-round schedule as a step toward a more radical change -- lengthening the school year -- that they say would make the American educational system more competitive with those of Europe and Japan.
The year-round schedule "breaks the tradition of the traditional calendar," said Charles Ballinger, executive director of the National Association for Year-Round Education, a San Diego-based lobbying group. "It also allows a rethinking of the curriculum on how best to deliver instruction to the students."
Here in this Dallas suburb, the Carlisle Elementary School decided that its 730 students would benefit even from a comparatively mild schedule change that shortens summer by one month and adds a two-week break in October and an extra week's vacation in winter and spring. The experiment started July 29, as a pilot project for the Plano school district, which has more than 20 schools.
"It's wonderful," said Lynne Gardner, a third-grade teacher in the Carlisle school. "The children are getting a head start on so many things. Three months is a long time for them to be on vacation."
Dr. Michael Kirst, a professor of education at Stanford University, agreed, saying, "There are a lot of merits to the year-round arguments." But he added, "What we need are some good, solid studies that support them."
Professor Kirst sees the situation like this: "To me, the deepest problem is that the summer vacation is embedded in American culture. It is one of the cultural historical traditions of America. And I think changing that is difficult politically."
Objections come from parents who say they have trouble adjusting to the new vacation pattern and from camps and other summer recreational industries.
 
Coming Change Is Predicted
 Despite such objections, Dr. Jeremiah Floyd, associate director of the National School Boards Association, said, "By the year 2001, my personal prediction is that virtually all schools are going to be on this kind of calendar."
Dr. Ballinger estimated that 1.3 million students in 1,600 schools in 23 states would attend year-round schools in the coming school year.
He said that number, which represents about 2.5 percent of American students from kindergarten through 12th grade, is more than double the 522,000 students in 629 schools who were on a year-round schedule two years ago. A decade ago, there were 278,000 students in 349 year-round schools.
Significantly, Dr. Ballinger said, up to 40 percent of these schools today are on a schedule in which all students take the same breaks at the same time. Fifteen years ago, he said, the year-round calendar was almost always used in a multitrack system in which students were divided into groups, or tracks, with one group on vacation at any given time and the school open and occupied all year. The staggered schedules allowed schools to accommodate more students.
Many of these schools dropped the year-round schedule when pressures of overcrowding eased, and before momentum had built to stay with the new calendar but in a single-track system.
The most common configurations of year-round schedules offer nine weeks of school followed by three weeks off, in addition to normal holidays, similar to a college's quarter program. Some schools alternate in larger blocks of 90 school days and 30 vacation days, effectively dividing the summer vacation into two equal parts.
In California, 20 percent of the 5 million schoolchildren are on a year-round schedule. Many of these are in Los Angeles, the country's second-largest school district, which this summer, after years of controversy, is completing the conversion of its 646 schools to a multitrack calendar to relieve overcrowding.
 
Educational Needs Cited
 Proponents of year-round schedules say there are compelling educational reasons to punctuate the school year with shorter, more frequent vacations. The traditional school calendar, they note, was created to serve an agrarian economy that needed children to work on farms during the summer. They also say year-round schedules conform to children's learning patterns, which do not take a three-month break in summer.
"Our teachers prior to year-round were spending most of the month of September in review, and that is not an educationally efficient use of teacher time and of the instructional process," said Norman Brekke, superintendent of the Oxnard School District in Oxnard, Calif., which phased in year-round schools staring in 1976. "During the school year we were taking two steps forward with these youngsters, and in the three-month summer hiatus we were taking one step back."
Proponents also say studies show that the year-round calendar is a better learning environment for students with limited English, learning difficulties or emotional problems.
"A traditional school can help a student only after he fails, in summer school," said Charles McCasland, the Carlisle school principal, referring to the possibility of offering remedial courses. "That's like allowing a swimmer to drown before rescuing him."
Year-round schedules, supporters say, make better use of school buildings, which often are unused through the long vacation, and keep urban teen-agers in high-crime areas indoors and occupied during the summer.
They say the new schedule also offers a more flexible framework for possible longer school years, allowing for the incremental shortening of the break periods and, equally important, breaking the psychological barrier of the long summer vacation.
Among industrialized nations, only Belgium, with 160 days, has a shorter school calendar than the United States, where most states offer 180 days. Japan has the longest school year, with about 240 days.
"A Nation at Risk," a 1983 report by a national commission on reforming schools, strongly recommended a school year of 200 to 220 days. Unlike the shift to a year-round schedule, a lengthening of the school year would require additional money for the staff.
And year-round schedules are already encountering strong opposition. Carlisle's plunge into a new school calendar, for example, met with resistance from some parents with older children at other schools, who are on different vacation schedules.
"I have four children, and it does create problems when you have different children at different schools on different schedules," said Sue Potter, who works as a volunteer in the Carlisle school library. "I'm waiting to see how it's going to work out."
But she said: "As a mother, I would prefer them all to be on this calendar. It's a little bit more sane to me. June, July, August: They don't need that much time off. My seventh grader is bored to tears. She's sitting at home watching TV now. I'm ready for her to go to school yesterday."
Kristin Willardson, a third grader, described the human toll of the year-round experiment this way: "I get real mad because I have to go to bed and my brothers and sisters get to stay up late and watch movies and in the mornings they get to sleep in and I'm like, 'I don't want to go to school,' and I have to go downstairs and get my hair brushed and my little sister gets to lie down on the couch and watch TV."
Strong opposition to the year-round schedule has come from groups with an economic interest in a long summer, like the American Camping Association. That group's president, John A. Miller, argued that summer camps offer children an essential learning environment that is "positive, rather than critical."
 
Teachers Are Enthusiastic
 Few teachers have objected to the new calendars. "In most cases, we have no problem with year-round schools as long as the different school systems negotiate the working conditions for the teachers," said Scott Treibitz, a spokesman for the American Federation of Teachers.
Mr. McCasland said that in the Carlisle experiment the parents of about 30 students elected to have their children bused to other schools when the schedule was shifted, but a comparable number of parents applied to have their children transfer to Carlisle.
In Mrs. Gardner's third-grade class, Andrew Byers said it was "kind of fun" being in school, but he voiced a wistful regret that he could not be out with his older brothers eating pizza.
"Well, Andrew," said Whitney Rowland, a fellow pupil, bringing some perspective to the discussion. "We are going to have pizza today anyway. It's Friday."

HEADLINE: Tax on A-Plant Riles New Hampshire's Neighbors

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEABROOK, N.H., Aug. 13

 BODY:
Among the six New England states, relations have traditionally been cordial and cooperative, except when it comes to the subject of New Hampshire and taxes.
In the early 1970's, New Hampshire, the only state that has never had a general sales or income tax, imposed an income tax on out-of-state commuters. In 1982, it proposed charging neighboring states higher rates for hydro-electric power generated on the Connecticut River within its borders. 
 Both efforts at raising local revenue by reaching into out-of-state pockets were struck down by the United States Supreme Court.
Now, facing tough fiscal times, this stubbornly anti-tax state once again appears to be looking for support in the form of taxes from its neighbors. And once again, it is not getting a warm response.
In June, the state Legislature and the Republican Governor, Judd Gregg, approved a bill that levies a property tax of 0.64 of 1 percent on the utility companies that jointly own the Seabrook nuclear power plant, which is two miles inside this state, close to the Massachusetts border. A majority interest in the plant is owned by companies outside New Hampshire.
In response to the legislation, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut plan to sue New Hampshire next month. Utility customers in those three states will owe about two-thirds of the $22.4 million annual tax. Because it is a state-against-state case, the suit will originate in the Supreme Court.
 
Break for In-State Owners
 It is not the tax itself the other states object to. Other nuclear power plants, like Vermont Yankee, in Vernon, Vt., tax out-of-state owners, and the Seabrook tax will have only a minor impact on consumers. But under New Hampshire's plan, the utilities within the state that are part owners of Seabrook will be exempt from another 1 percent tax now levied on their receipts.
In short, that means all the Seabrook owners pay, but the New Hampshire owners will get a rebate. Opponents say this violates a Federal interstate utility law.
"The thrust of what they've done is to offset the effect of the tax for New Hampshire companies by offering other relief," said the Connecticut Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, who has joined the lawsuit with Attorneys General Scott Harschbarger of Massachusetts and James E. O'Neil of Rhode Island. Since Maine has no ownership interest in Seabrook and Vermont has an interest of only 0.4 of 1 percent, neither has joined the lawsuit.
The plan "is divisive and destructive at a time when, now particularly, we should be uniting and cooperating to help New England as a region overcome the recession," Mr. Blumenthal said in a telephone interview.
The large-share owners of Seabrook include the Public Service Company of New Hampshire (35 percent); the United Illuminating Company of New Haven, Conn., (17.5 percent); the New England Electric System of Westborough, Mass., (10 percent), and the Connecticut subsidiary of Northeast Utilities of Berlin, Conn., (4 percent).
 
A 'Fiscal War' Is Predicted
 The other states' opposition to the new tax was not unexpected. In May, Mr. Blumenthal and Mr. O'Neil testified against the tax at a New Hampshire legislative committee hearing. At that time, Mr. O'Neil warned lawmakers that the levy could cause a "fiscal war between the states in a region characterized by interstate cooperation."
The Seabrook plan is part of a tax package intended to raise $110 million over the next two years, and New Hampshire officials argue it is justified.
Harold T. Judd, an assistant attorney general, said that without the exemptions for New Hampshire companies those utilities would be taxed twice, since they already pay taxes on sales within the state.
"We are removing inequities," Mr. Judd said. "This is not to take away taxes for New Hampshire companies. What we are doing is equally applying them to all those who own Seabrook."
Other New Hampshire officials note that Public Service Company of New Hampshire will pay the largest single portion of the property tax. But its share will be largely offset by the exemption, which means New Hampshire consumers should not see a change in their electric bills.
Residents in other states will see an increase of 3 cents to 30 cents a month, utility company officials say.
 
Lawmaker Tries to Retaliate
 Thomas Connell, a spokesman for Mr. O'Neil, the Rhode Island Attorney General, said the tax plan might also set a dangerous precedent.
"Once New Hampshire does this, other states would conceivably devise ways to shift their budget problems onto other states," he said.
Earlier this summer, as an act of retaliation, one Connecticut senator prepared an amendment for his state that mirrored the Seabrook tax, Mr. Blumenthal said. Though the amendment was killed before being formally proposed, other such measures could arise in other states, he said.
Charles Brereton, the author of several books on New Hampshire politics, said the tax has "elevated to an art form the ability to make sure out-of-staters help pay our bills."
"Our frugality gets a little carried away," he added, noting that the state has positioned many revenue producers like liquor stores and dog and horse tracks near its borders, where out-of-state visitors tend to stop.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Mulling the Idea of Affirmative Action for Poor Whites

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the nation struggles to come to grips with issues of race and how to rectify past and present racial discrimination, a thought-provoking notion is beginning to be voiced: shift the emphasis of affirmative action programs from race to class.
It is an idea being espoused by conservatives such as Antonin Scalia, the Supreme Court Justice, and William Julius Wilson, the liberal sociologist from the University of Chicago, and Stuart E. Eizenstat, who was Jimmy Carter's domestic policy adviser. The rationale is that class-based affirmative action would still overwhelmingly benefit blacks, who are disproportionately represented in the ranks of the poor. But at the same time it would eliminate the appearance of so-called reverse discrimination. 
 Recently, Richard Cohen, the liberal columnist for the Washington Post, added his voice to those calling for a rethinking of affirmative action.
"If economic need, not race, became the basis for what we now call affirmative action, most Americans would not object," he wrote. "Whites, too, could be helped as, indeed, they should be. After all, poor is poor, although a disproportionate number of them are black."
To some proponents of race- or gender-based preference programs, such a notion is a wacky idea that will fold under close scrutiny. Anti-poverty programs are supposed to aid the poor, they say. Affirmative action is designed to remedy past and current discrimination. Some black politicians go further, charging that those putting forward the idea are merely trying to cloak a retreat from a commitment to remedying racial discrimination.
"Don't you recognize a diversion when you see one?" asked Elenanor Holmes Norton, the Democratic delegate from the District of Columbia.
 
No Proposals
 Indeed, to date, no proponent of class-based affirmative action has come fourth with any specific proposals for applying it in employment or education. And in many cases, such as consent decrees aimed at remedying discrimination against blacks in police and fire departments, class-based affirmative action would seem to have no application. And the fact is that race- and sex-based programs exist in most cases because it is illegal to dicriminate on the basis of race or sex. It is not illegal to discriminate against people simply because they are poor.
Some of those who argue for shifting the focus of affirmative action say that race-based preference programs have been a resounding success. A recent study by the Population Reference Bureau noted that the number of black families with annual incomes of $50,000 or more in constant dollars rose to one in seven in 1989, up from one in every 17 in 1967. Affirmative action programs had much to do with that jump. Butthe question is raised whether the sons and daughters of these success stories should be accorded the same preferences as their parents.
"Affirmative action, as envisioned by President Johnson in his famous Howard University speech in 1965 where he first put forward the idea, was a transition program," said Mr. Eizenstat. "It was not a permanent program. There is always a question of how long does that last.'
With the sons and daughter of middle class blacks entering college, some say that another of affirmative action's major justifications, that it promotes diversity, is becoming more difficult to defend.
"I have almost no students whose parents are union members, and very few students who come from what you would call the blue-collar working class," Clyde Summers, a professor of law at the University of Pennsylvania said of his black and white students. "What that means is that no one has any idea what life is like on the other side of the tracks. That leads to a very sterile discussion when it comes to labor law."
Some advocates of a new order for affirmative action argue that race or sex-based preferences should not be tossed out altogether. Michael L. Williams the assistant Secretary for Civil Rights in the Department of Education who has suggested scrapping scholarships set aside exclusively for minorities, said that in cases of egregious discrimination by a particular employer, courts should still impose plans based on racial or sexual fairness.
"Wrongdoers must remedy their wrongdoing," he said. "The question is in situations where someone adopts a voluntary program."
Democratic proponents of a class-based affirmative action say it would also help establish a national consensus on civil rights and for increased spending on domestic social programs to help the poor and working class.
Political support for such programs, these proponents say, will only occur through the building of a coalition of racial minorities and blue-collar whites who have been deserting the party, in no small part because of affirmative action.
"The reason I like the proposal, and reason liberals should embrace it is that it's a way for them to find their way out of the thicket of race and move towards economic justice," said Jim Sleeper, the author of "The Closest of Strangers: Liberalism and the Politics of Race in New York."
In fact, the benefits of most government social programs are already accorded on the basis of income rather than race. Everything from welfare payments to child care is predicated on income, and many poor whites benefit. For example, 33 per cent of the youngsters enrolled in Head Start are white, as are 31 per cent of those in the Job Corps and 35 per cent in Upward Bound, a Federal program that provides special instruction to prepare low-income high school students for college. These programs, all outgrowths of the Great Society, have one thing in common: they retain widespread political support in Congress.
"No one tinkers with them," said a House Democratic Congressional aide. "They may not be funded as much as we would like. But they are not embroiled in the type of hand-to-hand combat you see over affirmative action."
Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said he is not opposed in theory to the notion of class-based affirmative action. But he, Ms. Norton, and others, including the columnist Michael Kinsley, raise a troubling question about the concept: Just how would it work? Who would get the preference and who would not?
"Does Clarence Thomas, the sharecropper's kid, get more or fewer preference points than the unemployed miner's son from Appalachia?" Mr. Kinsley wrote in a recent column. "Is a large, suburban public high school a bigger or a smaller minus than a second-rank prep school?"
Programs based on race or sex could have one big advantage -- simplicity. And when you are caught in a zero-sum game of dividing up finite resources, simplicity carries its own virtues.

HEADLINE: Safe Distance;
Bush Has Much To Gain in U.N.'s Handling Hostages

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
EVERYONE knows it's the official American policy that Washington does not negotiate with hostage takers. But everyone also knows that in the end, some kind of negotiation almost always takes place and a deal is struck in which both sides proclaim that they never blinked.
That is what seems to have been happening in the past two weeks, even though it is far from clear that the 10 Western hostages in the Middle East will be freed after years of captivity. President Bush's problem has been to keep his distance from a process that he is otherwise encouraging -- a negotiation for the release of the hostages -- and to find a morally and politically acceptable formula for such a process. 
 If trading arms for hostages is wrong, as the Reagan Administration declared even while trying it with disastrous results, and trading frozen Iranian bank accounts for hostages is wrong, as Teheran once suggested, the Bush Administration may just find it acceptable to trade prisoners for hostages or hostages for hostages.
That would be especially true if Terry Anderson and the other hostages are freed without the United States being directly connected to the deal.
What is important, Administration officials say, is that appearances are maintained and principles are not overtly violated. Beyond that, domestic political damage must be avoided, a consideration that has to be central to a President who is facing a re-election campaign in which the Democratic Party is renewing scrutiny of the failed hostage tactics of the Reagan-Bush Administration.
"The President has said it's in the hands of the U.N. and that's a perfect position to be in," an Administration official said. "Whatever Perez de Cuellar can come up with, fine," the official said, referring to United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. "We're able to funnel information through him or whatever. If you can achieve a solution through a third party, great. If you don't reach a solution, then Perez de Cuellar has to take the heat for it."
Last week, the fate of the hostages did indeed seem in the hands of Mr. Perez de Cuellar after the Muslim fundamentalist groups who are holding the Western hostages, central among them the Party of God, released an American, Edward Austin Tracy. He emerged from his ordeal, frail and disoriented, about a week after the Briton James McCarthy was set free.
 
No Master Plan
 Mr. Perez de Cuellar met in Geneva with a delegation from Iran, the country believed to hold the most sway over the hostage takers. The aim was now to provide Israel an accounting of seven of its servicemen long missing in Lebanon; in exchange, the Israelis said they would be "very flexible" about releasing their 400 Arab prisoners.
Administration officials say Mr. Bush did not set out with a master plan to trigger these developments. "It just fell into our laps," one said, although officials acknowledged that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had put pressure on President Hafez al-Assad to work for the hostages' release and that Washington had sent the message once again to Iran that there will be no normalization of relations until they are free.
It will not be clear until after the hostages are freed, if then, whether this was the genuine state of affairs, or another aspect of the Administration's effort to keep its distance from any negotiations and thus avoid long and potentially damaging Congressional investigations if things go wrong.
But Administration officials and Middle Eastern analysts outside the Government point to a confluence of events and political currents that could explain why even the cautious Mr. Bush has started to talk optimistically about an end to the hostage stalemate. White House officials often quote Mr. Bush's assertion that the victory over Iraq has raised the credibility of the United States as a force in Middle Eastern politics.
"Since the war, it has become clear that we're the ones you have to do business with in the Middle East and we've made it clear that for some players -- especially Iran -- there will be no business while there are American hostages still being held," an official said.
But Graham Fuller, who was the Central Intelligence Agency's chief officer on the Middle East in the mid-1980's, said, "The reason things seem to be changing on the hostages is that the political equation in the Middle East has been shifting consistently since the major changes in the Soviet Union. We're moving ever closer to the possibility of a peaceful settlement that no outside player has an interest in foiling. The regional players, especially the Syrians, recognize that the number of games open to them is dwindling." Administration officials said the coming peace conference puts pressure on Israel to be more flexible on prisoner exchanges.
Iran, Mr. Fuller argued, is less interested in an overall regional settlement than in getting "back to the real world so they can be accepted and get on with solving their economic problems." The problem, American officials said, is that Mr. Bush -- for whom the memory of Iran-contra is fresh -- was adamant about not getting involved in negotiations. Enter Mr. Perez de Cuellar.
A senior official said, "The U.N. simply wants to resolve this and is willing to engage, if you will, in conditional release of hostages, as, for example, are the Israelis. They have no opposition to the idea of swaps. It would be ridiculous for us to refuse to accept hostages that are released as part of a larger deal that was not our doing." Doesn't that mean the United States is at least tacitly encouraging the negotiations? "Those are your words, not mine," the official said.
All of this raises certain questions about the way governments deal with hostage takers. Richard Murphy, a former State Department official who supervised Middle East policy for most of the 1980's, said past failures prove the importance of avoiding negotiations, at least for the United States.
"We did do it -- we negotiated and we got Irangate," he said. "But it is another thing for the United Nations to negotiate or for Israel to negotiate. We have to be conscious of raising the hopes of other would-be captors around the world, but we've never objected to the Israelis bargaining like mad to get their people back. Is it inconsistent? Sure."
William B. Quandt, a former Carter aide who helped shape the Camp David accord between Israel and Egypt, said the United States had not crossed what he called "a red line" in dealing with terrorists.
"Insofar as we are putting anything in the mix, it's not necessarily restricted to freeing hostages," he said. "It is to develop relations with Syria to set up the peace process and signaling to the Iranians that if and when this is over, we might normalize relations. That goes beyond getting hostages out."
But Mr. Fuller said that the no-talks-with-terrorists policy has "an element of unreality." He added, "It sounds good and if you could deter something that way, I would be more in favor of it. Or if we really meant it and stuck to it. But we don't."

HEADLINE: The World;
For Many Albanians, Freedom Means a Shot At Leaving Forever

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR Albanians, this could be seen in some respects as a banner year: A popular uprising brought free elections in March after more than four decades of brutal rule by a Communist regime. The fledgling democracy was hailed by the United States and the rest of the international community.
But in everyday life it is a somber time for the more than 6 million Albanians, who face either wholesale privation or wholesale repression, depending on where they reside on the Balkan peninsula. 
 Albanians have also learned painfully that promises of aid, including from the United States, remain words, not deeds.
"It is a catastrophe," said Briseida Mema, a journalist, by telephone from Tirana last week. "There is no bread in the bakeries, no milk. There is a shortage of salt. Fifty thousand are unemployed. Thousands of others are getting only 80 percent of their wages."
More than any other European people, the Albanians are divided. About 3.5 million live in the Republic of Albania. The others are in neighboring Yugoslavia and, in smaller numbers, in Greece and Turkey.
In Albania, there has been a wrenching exodus of more than 100,000 by sea and by land in the last year -- perhaps the greatest migration of Albanians since the Turkish conquest and occupation of Albanian lands more than 400 years ago.
In the last six months Italy has been the destination of 40,000 of those fleeing. Earlier this month, more than 19,000 of the Albanians reached Italian ports in a motley fleet of vessels commandeered at knife- or gunpoint. Most were repatriated by ferry or plane last week, while 1,700 hard-core holdouts were permitted to stay temporarily to have their cases reviewed. At least 20 Albanians drowned during attempts to flee a country whose frontiers have been open for months.
 
Aboard Sagging Rustbuckets
 Alarmed by the host of uninvited visitors, President Francesco Cossiga of Italy flew to Tirana on Tuesday to coordinate maritime control of the Adriatic's narrow Strait of Otranto with the Albanians. He also conveyed a promise of $115 million in emergency assistance, mostly food supplies.
What drove Albanians to overwhelm harbor guards and flee their ancient homeland across the sea to foreign shores, swarming as thickly as bees aboard sagging rustbuckets -- for the second time since February?
Ylli Bufi, chosen prime minister of a coalition government last June, said in an interview last week that he had reason to believe the exodus had been "incited by internal and external enemies" who spread a rumor at the beginning of August that ships were sailing to the ports of Vlore and Durres to pick up Albanians desiring to go to Italy.
 
Finding Blame
 In a separate interview, Dr. Sali Berisha, head of the Democratic Party, more specifically blamed remnants of the former Communist Party and of the former secret police organization called Sigurimi for spreading the rumor with the aim of disrupting the fragile process of democratization.
As in other countries in the throes of post-Communist evolution, Albania is discovering that in the wake of an era of Leninist lies, deceptions and manipulations, many citizens give more credence to rumors than to facts as presented by the government or even by foreign broadcasters.
Mr. Bufi, Dr. Berisha and others acknowledge that Albania's desolate straits, shadowed by four years of drought, have fueled the exodus. In many areas, especially the mountainous northeast, the country is as wretchedly poor as it was described 83 years ago by Edith Durham in her trailblazing account, "High Albania."
Last April, an Albanian peasant hitchhiking to his farm near Koplik gave a foreign reporter a glimpse of his people's destitution. He proudly displayed his treasure, an imported jar of preserved plums he had purchased in the capital of a country that should be rich in such fruits. Then he brandished a red-covered document, saying, "I got my passport. Now I can get out of here."
Aside from the Italian emergency aid, which is also a form of insurance against future mass migrations across the Adriatic, the Western response to Albania's plight has been minimal.
Buoyed last June by a welcoming throng of half a million Albanians in Tirana, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d vowed that $6 million in assistance would be sent through the Agency for International Development. But until now, only several thousand pounds of powdered milk has been ticketed for Albania, and A.I.D. officials were unable to say last week whether any had arrived.
"A.I.D. is the problem," said an Administration official concerned with Albania. "They've sent six fact-finding missions by last count, but no aid."
Frustrated by the delay, Mr. Baker turned to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who dispatched 280,000 pounds of foodstuffs left over from the Persian Gulf conflict to Tirana's Rinas Airport in late July.
At this point, the only other American assistance reaching Albania is that organized by Albanian-Americans like Skender Perolli, a New York businessman who heads the Albanian American Humanitarian Foundation, and Donald Leka, a young Washingtonian who arranged a shipment of badly needed syringes to cope with heptatis-B infections.
It is hardly the kind of large-scale assistance the Albanians had anticipated to help them awaken and acclimate after a half century of isolation. Instead, many Albanians are finding that the better life they dreamed of will for now remain tantalizingly out of their reach.
"All are disillusioned," said Ms. Mema. "There is no money and no hope."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Forget the Last Picture Show; in Some Towns The Bank and the High School Are Closing Too

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: VENANGO, Neb.

 BODY:
IT was Saturday night on Main Street, and nickel-a-hand gamblers played cards and sipped beers at Ethel's Cafe. Teen-agers swayed to the music inside the Venango dance hall. And at the town cinema, matinee idols flickered across the big screen.
"Those were wonderful times," mused Hazel Dodson, an 85-year-old widow, as she gazed out her living room window at a town of lifeless streets and weather-beaten houses, some of them empty. "Now what's to become of us?" 
 Like giant tombstones marking the ghosts of commerce, most of the shops along Main Street now stand shuttered, as stark and still as the flat, unbroken plains of western Nebraska. The latest blow, and perhaps the most devastating, comes later this month, when the bank closes its doors.
"It's like dying a slow death," said Dennis Ekdahl, who has taught shop class at Venango High School for 24 years.
Across the country, but especially in the Farm Belt, life is ebbing from the little towns that have long been revered as a cornerstone of American society. In the 1980's, 72 percent of towns with populations under 2,500 lost residents. Venango, once home to more than 400, declined from 230 to 180 in the last decade. Most of those left are elderly people, who usually live alone.
"In an economic sense, a lot of these little places just aren't needed anymore," said Calvin Beale, a demographer for the Department of Agriculture in Washington. "We've seen it coming. But we were really surprised by the severity of the loss. It's more radical than anything we saw even 30 or 40 years ago, when so many people were leaving the farms and small towns for urban areas."
The exodus from the country to the cities and suburbs has been going on since the turn of the century. The farm crisis of the 1980's accelerated the change, leaving many small towns in economic ruins, as machinery outlets, grain elevators, clothing stores and restaurants lost their customers. For small towns beyond a reasonable commuting distance to larger cities, the decline appears to be inexorable.
In Venango, several houses are vacant. Others have been torn down and plowed over. The highest rents run about $150 a month. A house can be purchased for $10,000, even less. But a buyer would need private financing, since banks do not lend money for houses that have no market.
The exodus from rural America has been especially acute among young people, who are frustrated by the lack of job opportunities at home and yearn for a more exciting life. Some people in small towns complain of a brain drain, as the best students, who have talents that could be put to use in rural areas, leave for college and never return.
Of last year's graduating class of seven at Venango High School, six have enrolled in college; the seventh joined the Navy. The enrollment at the high school this year is 19. There is one sophomore and no juniors. Everyone agrees that school consolidation is just around the corner, and then Venango students will be bused to Grant, 18 miles away.
As towns like Venango wither and die, the rest of the country feels barely a ripple. Today the American hometown is the suburb, where people do not have to drive 20 miles to a drug store, or 38 miles to a department store, as they do in Venango.
Those who study rural life, or were nurtured by it, warn that the country is diminished with the passing of each Venango. To be sure, small towns are not white-picket bastions of purity and innocence. There are no fences that insulate them from drugs, divorce, poverty and domestic violence. But certain values still thrive, in ways they cannot in larger places.
A person in trouble is harder to ignore when the face is familiar. When there is only one restaurant in town, the banker dines with the janitor. Without the luxury of anonymity, people are stuck with being themselves. Life in a small town can be a great motivator. Failure is more harsh, and triumph more glorious, when everyone knows about it.
Venango residents celebrated when Violet Bedell, 78, earned her high school diploma a few years ago. They clapped the shoulders of David Johnson, John Paul Arias and his brother Junior Arias, when they returned safely from duty in the Persian Gulf. And they organized suppers and dances to defray medical costs for Sheri Bazan, a 35-year-old woman stricken with cancer, who left two small children when she died last month.
 
Fighting Stereotypes
 "People in small towns, from a very early age, learn that the social unit depends upon them," said Paul Olson, an English professor at the University of Nebraska and the president of the Center for Rural Affairs, a research organization that Mr. Olson described as "an intellectual version of populism."
In Mr. Olson's view, the decline of rural life has been hastened by a government that ignores the assets of small towns and a popular culture that often denigrates rural society.
"Very few curricula include works that celebrate rural life," he said, noting that few schoolchildren, even in small towns, are familiar with authors like Willa Cather, Sophus Winther, Ole Rolvaag or Marie Sandoz, who conveyed the challenge and struggle of rural life. "Instead, they will read a whole bookshelf of works which suggest that small towns are provincial, bigoted, unimaginative. And when they watch television and movies, they generally see rural people portrayed as nincompoops."
On Saturday night in Venango, Main Street is dark and silent except for a dimly lit tavern, Swazi, where a handful of men play cards and a young woman flips through the pages of a magazine as she nurses a diet soda.
The bar owner, Marlon Prottsman, a tall, bearded, amiable man in bib overalls, named the place after the nation of Swaziland, where he served in the Peace Corps. A map of the African country hangs on a wall, near a sign that tells customers they can smoke anywhere they want.
One of the patrons, Dick Ourada, a 50-year-old wheat farmer, stared into a glass of beer and spoke of the old days, when Venango was rich with promise. His father and grandfather came to town in 1920 on a boxcar, on the so-called immigrant trains. After traveling from Czechoslovakia, they thought they had found a place to set down roots for generations to come. But Mr. Ourada's five children, like most young people here, have all left in search of a new promise.
"I guess that's progress," he said, and ordered another beer.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Investing In America

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER; Leslie H. Gelb is on vacation.

 BODY:
When will President Bush stop telling us all's well with the economy, when anyone with bills to pay knows better? When, if ever, will he get on with the real task before him -- putting Americans back to work and restoring their prosperity?
The recession's over, the White House insists. Baloney. Jobs are disappearing, layoffs are up, consumption is down, unemployment is nearly 7 percent, retail sales are lagging, real estate is a disaster area, banks are failing, credit is tight, wages are stagnant, and among 16- to 19-year-olds only half -- the lowest level in two decades -- hold or are even looking for jobs. 
 Last year's budget agreement with Congress, it says here, got a grip on the Federal deficit. More baloney. The Congressional Budget Office has just announced that despite stringent spending limits, new taxes and the alleged end of the recession, the deficit will rise from $279 billion in fiscal 1991 to $362 billion next year.
Even the President's own budget director concedes the deficit will reach $348 billion; and in that neighborhood that's a distinction without much difference. So the prospect is that the geniuses who gave you the recession and the deficit will now raise your taxes and cut spending again, both deflationary steps, in holy pursuit of that elusive Grail, a balanced budget.
From New England to California, moreover, states and cities have been hard-hit on one side by recession-depleted revenues and smashed on the other by drastically reduced Federal aid. The result is a triple disaster -- rising state and local taxes, declining state and local services and extensive worker layoffs. Does anyone believe that this combination will not have further depressing impact on an economy already gasping for breath?
The Federal Reserve, another source of fatuous reassurance, periodically belies its own words with minor and inadequate cuts in interest rates, which may or may not make it slightly easier for Main Street to get loans; but which do little to restore the necessary economic confidence of those who are now afraid to start or expand a business, even if they could get a loan.
And where did the myth come from that conservatives handle the economy more capably than liberals? Jeff Madrick, a business correspondent for NBC News, pointed out in an Op-Ed article for The New York Times on Aug. 14 that during the 11 years since Ronald Reagan's election, real gross national product is up only about 30 percent. During the terms of Presidents Kennedy and Johnson and the first three years of Richard Nixon, the 11-year gain in real G.N.P. was almost 50 percent.
So here's an unorthodox program to renew American prosperity -- one that can hardly produce worse results than the pious economic orthodoxies the nation has followed right out the window:
* Let's stop worrying so much about the deficit, a vastly overrated threat, and invest, for a change, in America and the American people.
* Let's stop fretting about the supposedly imminent return of inflation and see what the combination of sharply reduced interest rates and increased public spending can do.
* Specifically, let's invest -- or prime the pump, if you insist -- by pouring billions into infrastructure, building and repairing roads, bridges, sewers, city streets, public works of all kind; this is not only a needed program in itself, but it will put people to work as nothing has done since the construction of the interstate highway system in the 1950's (and not incidentally, it will train thousands of idle, mostly hopeless Americans in essential, marketable skills).
* Let's also start returning more Federal money to states and localities, earmarked as far as possible for putting people to work at essential services rather than throwing them on the unemployment rolls while the garbage goes uncollected.
* Before anyone shouts "deficit spending," remember that for every point the unemployment rate declines, $30 billion to $40 billion can be cut from the deficit, owing to additional revenues and reduced outlays for the jobless. Thus, unemployment reduced in, say, five years from 7 to 4 percent would cut the deficit by perhaps $90 billion to $120 billion, not counting the larger effects of a revived economy.
Old-fashioned, big-spending liberalism? Maybe so, but weren't you better off when that was the rule? And what has this trickle-down crowd in Washington done for you lately?

HEADLINE: Bush Got It Right in the Soviet Union

BYLINE: By Brent Scowcroft; Brent Scowcroft is President Bush's national security adviser.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Critics claim that President Bush's comments before the Supreme Soviet of the Ukraine placed him "with" Mikhail Gorbachev and "against" independence movements in the Soviet republics. But his Aug. 1 Kiev speech and July 30 address at the Moscow State Institute for International Relations made no such commitment.
The two speeches set forth the principles of American policy toward a Soviet Union that no longer looms as the totalitarian colossus of cold war days, but whose future shape runs the gamut of possibilities, from good to bad to very ugly. In the face of hope for peaceful and democratic change, the President conveyed encouragement and support. Faced with the staggering complexity of Soviet realities, he demonstrated flexibility and an appreciation for nuance. And confronted by the real potential for economic misery, ethnic strife, repression and bloodshed, he delivered serious and responsible words of caution. 
 The core of the Kiev speech was the assertion that the United States would "support those in the center and the republics who pursue freedom, democracy and economic liberty." In other words, we will build our policy on principles, not around personalities. Two corollaries flow from this. First, we will support leaders in the republics and the center who pursue democracy, but we won't choose sides between and among them. Second, democracy requires respect for minority rights.
The President sent a message to the central Government and to the independence movements. In the Moscow speech, he laid out a vision of a historic partnership between our two countries. We can build such a partnership only with a central Government moving, as he said in Kiev, "toward the goals of freedom, democracy and economic liberty." He did not offer a partnership with the central Government per se -- and certainly not with one moving backward in an effort to restore the Stalinist imperium.
The President delivered a similarly qualified message to the republics. The passage in the Kiev speech that has drawn the most fire declared that the U.S. will not aid "those who promote a suicidal nationalism based upon ethnic hatred."
In other words, the United States will not support independence movements per se, any more than it will support the central Government per se. As the President put it, "We will support those who want to build democracy." To draw a distinction, as he did, between freedom and independence simply acknowledges the unfortunate fact that anti-democratic hard-liners and ethnic hatemongers have in some instances crept under the independence tent. The U.S. does not oppose nationalist aspirations of true democrats, including those in the Rukh coalition in the Ukraine, who want to follow the example of Hamilton, Madison and Jefferson.
The President's plea for tolerance arises from legitimate concerns. Many Soviet citizens of virtually all nationalities find themselves outnumbered at the local level by ethnic neighbors. Nationalities have been scattered throughout the U.S.S.R. A history of hatred and mistrust divides them; they seldom have lived together in peace. If they do not develop habits of pluralism and respect for individual and minority rights, they will face a bleak Hobbesian future.
Democracy involves much more than filling out ballots. Soviet citizens voted for years without enjoying free elections. When we support democracy, we support a truly open society, not just a method for counting votes.
Hence our support for a nine-plus-one process -- not a particular treaty, but a process -- by which the republics can, through dialogue, define the terms of their relations with the Kremlin. Our support for this process does not imply preference for any "side" or any particular result.
The President also urged reformers at all levels to support lofty words with appropriate deeds. We will not support forces that repress people trying to exercise basic freedoms. We have never recognized the Baltics' incorporation into the Soviet Union, and we support the Baltic people's aspirations. We continue to call on the center to conduct good-faith negotiations with the Baltic states to that end.
The Kiev speech concluded with sound advice: Know what you can achieve. The republics cannot break free from old relationships and enjoy instant prosperity. Indeed, they have deliberately preserved existing trade ties through new republic-to-republic trade agreements. The President encouraged his audiences to establish property rights, impartial judicial systems, contract law, civil rights, free speech, sound currencies -- in short, to build the institutions necessary to survive and thrive in the marketplace beyond republic borders.
If we have learned anything in recent years, it is that freedom is difficult to win and even more difficult to preserve. Those in Kiev -- or Tbilisi, Kishinev, Baku, Tashkent, Yerevan, Dushanbe -- may want to make Moscow the scapegoat for all ills that befall them. They may want the President to repudiate the center and assure republics that independence will deliver them to a brilliant future. But freedom imposes responsibilities that free people must take seriously.
The President's aim in the Ukraine was not to make a splash. It was to make a difference. He appreciates the consequences of his words, especially in an atmosphere as highly charged as that in the Soviet Union; they may have repercussions for peace and security beyond Soviet borders, and for the prospects for a New World Order.
Our words cannot deliver the Soviet peoples from their dilemmas and decisions. But injudicious promises could raise impossible hopes that might, in turn, affect the calculations of those at either extreme.
Once upon a time, we measured our cold war victories by the temperature of our rhetoric. But we won the cold war and we face the tougher, more mundane challenge of building democracy -- of forging a New World Order. Change in the Soviet Union will come regardless of what we say or do. The status quo is not the issue at all. What is at issue is whether this change will be peaceful and democratic. President Bush will continue to urge everyone that it be so, whether they appreciate his message or not.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: Israel, Most of All, Needs a Just Settlement

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Middle East analysis (Week in Review, July 28) helps to sustain a dangerous delusion of grandeur among some Israelis and their supporters. Israel's victory is complete, you say, with Iraq as well as the Palestinians vanquished and the Soviet Union no longer able to provide military aid to Syria. Arabs, therefore, will be responsible for any further Middle East conflict, because it is they who refuse to let Israel enjoy the fruits of victory. 
 But Israel's victory is hardly complete. Iraq has demonstrated that a small country needn't be a piece on any superpower's chessboard to get itself armed, nor does it have to be any nation's soul mate. All it needs is money to buy weapons and the wile and determination to do it. For now, the Middle East countries capable of generating enough wealth to arm themselves are in the pocket of the United States, but that cannot last.
Israel, on the other hand, needs huge United States subsidies to keep its economy afloat and maintain its military strength. Two factors in the United States, one demographic and one economic, will combine to make it impossible for the United States to continue providing this kind of aid, just as Israel's need for it increases.
Demographically, the United States is becoming more Hispanic, African-American, Asian and Islamic. The Hispanic and Asian populations are a wild card when it comes to support for Israel, but Muslims are not. There are or soon will be more Muslims than Jews in the United States. And blacks won't want their tax money propping up Israel. Given that blacks are the major losers as the nation's cities go broke, it's hard to see why they should.
You could argue that black antipathy toward Israel is class-based and that, as blacks move into the middle class, they become like everybody else: mostly pro-Israel or indifferent enough not to present an obstacle to United States support. That's doubtful, but in any case irrelevant, because of the overriding economic fact that the United States cannot absorb more than a token of low-income blacks into the middle class.
On the contrary, despite what you and virtually the entire United States news media like to render as "the triumph of capitalism over Communism," the prognosis for the United States is continued dissolution of the middle class. In the last 10 years, under cover of various crackpot economic theories, the United States has made great progress toward becoming the kind of class-riven society that we grew up associating with banana republics. Nothing on the political horizon points to any change in that trend. Is this a country that will want to spend $4 billion a year keeping Israel afloat -- and $10 billion more to resettle Soviet Jews?
Israel, in its own interest, should think less about gathering the fruits of victory and more about judiciously sharing them. Israel more than any other nation in the region needs a just settlement so that long-neglected business can be attended to. The best hope for defusing the nationalist and religious time bombs in the Middle East lies in increased aid and investment, whether from socialists, capitalists or from anybody's church plate, to achieve minimum standards of human comfort and sustained economic development throughout the region. A good place to start would be the hellhole we know as the Gaza Strip.
 
DAVID RUBENSTEIN
Chicago, Aug. 5, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter
