HEADLINE: FOCUS;
In a Downturn, It's Back to Home Building

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STOFFEL

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
After nearly three decades of rigorous activity in commercial development across the country, the Wolstein Group is responding to the industry slowdown by returning to its home base in Cleveland and putting its future in residential projects.
With more than 125 shopping centers in 36 states as well as several industrial and hotel properties under their belts, principals of the private development firm believe that it is in home building that the flagging real estate industry will rebound in the 1990's. 
 The firm's newest project, a $350 million upscale residential community, is being built around a golf course designed by Jack Nicklaus in suburban Aurora, 30 miles southeast of Cleveland. It is considered locally as an ambitious expansion of suburban growth in a sluggish market at best, especially in view of sagging demand for high-priced homes in recent months.
The developers say the decision to shift from commercial to residential business was made not out of choice, but out of necessity.
"It is not an easy transition," said Scott Wolstein, a general principal in the firm and son of the founder, Bart Wolstein. "But a lot of commercial developers are going into forced retirement in this market."
Indeed, the lending climate for all categories of commercial development remains tight because of new regulations and careful scrutiny by lenders, according to "Real Estate 1991," a study of the real estate industry released in April by Ernst & Young.
If Wolstein "is going to stay in business," said Lee E. Harkelroad, regional director of real estate advisory services with Ernst & Young in Dayton, Ohio, "his only real alternative is in residential."
"And," Mr. Harkelroad added, "we're not seeing anyone that is not well capitalized getting any money to do these kind of large-scale land-development projects."
The Wolstein Group's residential project, called Barrington, is large for the Cleveland area. It is going up on heavily treed land that was undisturbed for years as the 315-acre Breezy Point Farm and on an adjacent 300-acre site that was bought in 1989 from the Warner & Swazey Company, a local manufacturer, which abandoned plans for expansion there.
When completed in 1999, the project is expected to include 425 one-family houses built around a country club and a fitness center, as well as the $5 million, 190-acre, 18-hole golf course. While exact terms were not available, the Wolsteins were able to get financing from Ohio Savings Bank and National City Bank.
So far, $12 million has been spent on land improvements and utilities for the first phase. Land has also been cleared for the golf course.
Initial planning for the farmland section alone called for a mixed-use apartment project and a $15 million shopping center. That plan is on hold pending the resolution of a zoning dispute.
While it is common for developers to buy more land than is needed for commercial projects and to sell the excess to residential developers -- which the Wolsteins have done in the past -- the Wolsteins are taking a different approach with Barrington. They are hanging their hopes for marketing it on a resurgence of demand for large, custom-built, luxury homes and on the expansion of suburbia, as well as on the lure of the golf club and fitness center. They see their primary targets as professionals 35 to 55 years old and empty-nesters or retirees.
The suburbs in the far eastern reaches of Cleveland, like Solon and Twinsburg, have been among the fastest growing in the metropolitan area. The outward expansion has not bypassed Aurora. A new four-lane extension of Route 422 links Aurora and Cleveland and other eastern suburbs.
While the median house price in the formerly quiet city is a modest $170,000, city planners anticipate that several residential projects begun in recent years will change the character of the community.
The number of housing units is expected to increase by 52 percent by the year 2000, planning study earlier this year by the Portage County Regional Planning Commission. Aurora's population is expected to grow to 15,000 from 10,700.
The commission, which is already concerned about traffic congestion, the capacity of city water and sewage systems, the potential loss of green space and the area's rural character, is proposing a new long-range plan for the city.
"We've entered the real world of growth and development," said David Lipstreu, the city's planning director and chairman of the regional planning group. "But we don't want to become another Twinsburg or Solon."
Mr. Lipstreu said that those two suburbs have no green space, no rural character, a hodge-podge of housing developments and heavy traffic congestion.
Although the city is feeling the pressure of residential development, the scale and price range of the Barrington project put it in a category by itself. And while officials are pleased that the property will be developed into homes rather than into the industrial site that was originally anticipated, there is some doubt about the project's suitability.
"I don't see where the market for this is," Mr. Lipstreu said. "Sure, there is some money in this community, but where I see a big demand for houses is on the lower end, for the first-time buyer."
But it is the upscale amenities -- the golf course, a racquet club and a security-gate system -- that the Wolsteins believe will attract buyers. And, with waiting lists at private country clubs in the area, the golf course is expected to be a major draw. Since sales beganin March, 100 golf club memberships have been sold at $36,000 each to individuals and corporations.
The Wolsteins also point to the initial success of their Glenmoor, a $250 million, 420-acre upscale residential project begun in 1989 in Canton, Ohio. It is to have 400 homes and a Jack Nicklaus golf course.
Homes in Glenmoor are priced from $235,000 for 2,500 square feet on quarter-acre lots to $1 million for 4,000 square feet on lots larger than an acre. So far, 50 lots have been sold and more than 20 houses are under construction.
In addition to the golf course, Glenmoor includes an elaborate fitness center with enclosed tennis courts, swimming pool and health spa, and a guard-gate entrance.
"There are plenty of places to buy lots, but we've tried to come up with the amenities to attract people," Bart Wolstein said. "And we're attracting buyers who weren't interested in building a home until they saw our projects. We've tried to create a mystique."
Barrington's first phase is to include 99 lots ranging from one-quarter to one acre and selling for $100,000 to $200,000. Sixty-nine custom homes on these lots in the first phase will range from 3,200 to 4,200 square feet and will be in three distinct neighborhoods. Ten of these lots have been sold to individuals since the initial offering in March. Home prices are expected to begin at $400,000.
Thirty smaller homes, from 2,500 to 3,000 square feet, on one-quarter to one-half acre, are being built by Three M Construction Company, a local builder. To be priced from $300,000, the smaller homes will be sold with a condominium-type maintenance agreement.
The Wolsteins still plan to develop the adjacent 15-acre parcel of former farmland into apartments and a $15 million shopping center. While the city granted preliminary approval for a zoning change there from residential to commercial, a citizens referendum in Aurora in May turned down the change. In response, the developers are suing the city for arbitrary zoning restrictions.

LENGTH: 1559 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: CHRISTOPHER PERCY;
Building Support for Coastal Waters

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
CHRISTOPHER PERCY is president of the Sounds Conservancy, a group he helped start in 1984 that is dedicated to improving conditions in the six bodies of water in southern New England: Long Island, Fishers Island, Block Island, Rhode Island, Vineyard and Nantucket Sounds.
For the last six years Mr. Percy and his group have been among the most ardent advocates of a study of how to restore the 740-acre Quiambaug Cove in Stonington. Once the cove was productive; now it is a dead body of water with the bottom covered with two to six feet of black, acidic, rotting organic muck, a condition Mr. Percy and others say is the result of the construction of causeways to support the railroad and Route 1 along the Connecticut coast. 
 The Sounds Conservancy's support comes from private sources, he said. It has an annual budget of about $20,000 a year, from 300 family, individual and corporate members.
In an interview on the banks of the Quiambaug, Mr. Percy answered questions about coastal resources and the Sounds Conservancy. Here are excerpts from the conversation.
Q. Why should we be worried about saving these coves?
A. Quiambaug Cove, according to a state fisheries commission report from the 1880's, produced more flounder than any other cove in Connecticut, and now it produces no flounder and no shellfish. Look at what we're losing in terms of shell- and finfish. In terms of shellfish alone, Connecticut alone is losing 15 to 20 million dollars a year of shellfish product, the result of closures because of water quality, in large part because we don't get the tidal flushing to provide a better mix.
We also need to tackle the problems of failed septic systems and combined sewer systems in our urban areas. Overall, in southern New England, we're losing well over $100 million a year in shellfish product, and they use a multiplier effect for the total impact on the economy, which is sometimes six times the real dollar value, which would mean more than a half-billion dollar loss to the economy. I think it's well worth the investment to bring back into the economy not only the dollar value but the protein value of these shell- and finfish resources.
Q. What will the study accomplish?
A. It's an $85,000 study for one year of intensive study on the sedimentology and hydrology of Quiambaug Cove, leading to recommendations as to how best to open the cove up to tidal flushing and what to do with the accumulated silts. We're also pleased Senator Steve Spellman has secured bonding for Quiambaug Cove that appropriates $3 million to implement the findings of the study. We don't know whether that will be enough until the study is complete, but what it does say is this will not be another study that will languish on the shelf when it's complete.
Quiambaug Cove will be a prototype study for the other coves that are affected. The models that will be developed here will be easily usable for the other impacted coves, so we don't have to reinvent the wheel each time we move into a new area.
Q. How many coves are affected in all?
A. There are 12 coves in eastern Connecticut that are cut off by the Amtrak causeways and the Route 1 causeways, sort of a double whammy. From New Haven west, the railroad swings inland a little bit, so the impact is less in western Connecticut.
Q. Why are there so many causeways affected in Connecticut compared with other states?
A. The railroad follows the coastline up all the way from New York City, then turns inland after Stonington. There were, at one time, trestles, which allowed for tidal flow, the tidal exchange, from Long Island Sound into the coves, and that's when they were the most prolific in terms of shellfish and finfish. But the trestles were replaced, starting at the turn of the century and ending in the 1930's. There's a tremendous cost associated with putting in the wood or concrete pilings for a trestle and then maintaining them, as opposed to just solid fill for a causeway.
Q. Why was Quiambaug Cove chosen?
A. We had the most historical information available on Quiambaug Cove, going back to the fisheries commission reports in the 1880's and references in the newspapers and journals about the cove.
And the professors and scientists at the nearby University of Connecticut Avery Point campus have studied Quiambaug Cove, so we have a good baseline of data about Quiambaug Cove. The more information we have about historical productivity, the easier it is to nominate those coves for restoration.
Q. Is it possible to bring a "dead" cove back?
A. I know it can be done. There is some evidence that Alewife Cove in Waterford and New London is beginning to get some resurgence of marine life back into what was once a stagnant area. That involved the sanding in of a coastal creek. These projects are going to be much larger because they involve the Amtrak causeways and the highway causeways. In Alewife Cove there was a stone groin built, the cove was dredged, and they realigned the channel to allow for tidal exchange.
Q. Are these coves going to require trestles again?
A. Ideally we'd like to go back to trestles. That would be the ideal solution. At the least we will have to put in additional culverts. The culverts there now are roughly 35 feet wide. Quiambaug Cove, the natural opening, was about an eighth of a mile. When you narrow something down from an eighth of a mile to 35 feet, of course you're going to have problems.
Q. What other kinds of research is the Sounds Conservancy promoting?
A. We have a dedicated fund, our Marine Conservation, Education and Research Program, to support student research in southern New England, and we correspond with 60 colleges and universities in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut and New York. We award up to $2,500 per project. We have funded now about 18 student research projects. The fund now stands at close to $300,000.
The types of project we have funded run from the impact on anti-fouling boat paints, particularly tributyl tins, TBT's, on shellfish, to the uptake of nitrate in eelgrass beds. The projects have typically been by graduate students, though we're beginning to reach into the undergraduate ranks now. We want to encourage careers in the marine science and conservation fields.
Q. Your organization has also published several booklets on marine resources, hasn't it?
A. Yes, we've done three and are working on a fourth. These come under the research and education program. We've done "Planning for Sea Level Rise in Southern New England," "The Intertidal Flats: Their Value and Legal Status," and a small monograph, "Tracking Hurricanes."
Currently we're working on a major report covering the four states, as the others have, on shellfisheries of southern New England. It will look at the dollar loss, what's caused it, and how we can bring it back. People who are interested in copies can write to the Sounds Conservancy at P.O. Box 266, Essex, Conn. 06426. There is a small charge to cover the mailing costs, so people could call first, 767-1933.
Q. Why does the Sounds Conservancy cover five sounds? Isn't that stretching itself a bit thin?
A. That makes up the marine region of southern New England, from the East River to Cape Cod. It really is a hydrologic unit in a sense, just like a river in a way. And it's a geological unit, it was all created by the glaciers, by terminal moraines.
Q. Since you've been all over the region, which sound is in the best shape, and which is in the worst?
A. If you start at the East River and go east, it gets better as you go along. And that makes sense because the urbanization is heaviest at the western end of the Sound. There's no real problem in Rhode Island Sound, and it's interesting that it's even called a sound, since it's wide open to the ocean. Long Island Sound is the most confined, and that's why the western Sound, from New Haven to the East River, is really a sink.
Q. Do you see any signs things are improving?
A. I think we're holding our own. I don't think we're losing ground in the eastern part of Long Island Sound, although we are losing ground in the western part of Long Island Sound.
Q. Can we have a technologically modern society and a clean environment?
A. Yes, but we need to develop new technologies to deal with our problems. Here's an example: we don't think there should be a tri-town sewage treatment plant at the mouth of the Connecticut River in Old Saybrook. The answer is looking at technologies such as solar aquatic wastewater treatment. It puts out better quality water than any treatment plant available today, drinkable quality water. It's being developed in Providence and up on Cape Cod.
Tied into that, for small areas where there are problems, you have to have individual homeowners upgrade their septic systems, put in low-flow devices in their homes and pump out their septic systems every two years. Once you put in a tri-town sewage treatment plant, you're going to get growth and development all along its trunk lines, and you're creating demand for the plant. The same could apply to composting sewer sludge and reusing it. Hartford has a plant, Fairfield has a plant, and it's definitely the way to go, rather than putting it in the water.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christopher Percy, president of the Sounds Conservancy.
(Bruce Johnson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A la Carte: End of an Era as Nicola Zanghi Moves

BYLINE: By RICHARD SCHOLEM

 BODY:
A LONG ISLAND restaurant dynasty will come to an end late this fall when the Zanghi family sells Nicola's of Glen Cove and moves to Connecticut. The chef and owner, Nicola Zanghi, his wife, Trisch, and sister Nina have been at the 50 Forest Avenue location in Glen Cove since 1974. For most of that period, Nicola's was called Restaurant Zanghi.
Mr. and Mrs. Zanghi will operate a restaurant double the size of the 68-seat Nicola's, in Westport, Conn. It will occupy the first floor of National Hall, an 1875 landmark building on the Saugatuck River that is the anchor of a complex being restored by Arthur Tauck, president of Tauck Tours. 
 The Italianate National Hall, in an area called the Historical Design District, is a handsome brick building that will be a huge inn with 13 suites upstairs and a restaurant downstairs.
Most of Nicola's kitchen staff will go to Westport with the Zanghis. Many of the dining-room personnel are expected to remain in Glen Cove. Some of them will work for the owners of the Romantico Restaurant at 45A Shore Road in Port Washington, who will transfer their hearty regional Italian operation to Forest Avenue. Romantico's site will be filled by another Italian restaurant, La Sirena.
Mr. Zanghi began his restaurant career in 1961 at the age of 13 in his parents' restaurant in Valley Stream. Nino's Pavilion, as it was then known, spawned Restaurant Zanghi, which became Nicola's a year ago.
Long Island's culinary landscape was quite different in the 60's and 70's. It offered far less diversity and sophistication. The Zanghis were path blazers. They introduced imaginative innovative dishes of a sort that were not available elsewhere in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
They served fresh game, and they exhibited a delicate touch with fish and seafood. Meal courses were separated by cranberry or cassis sorbet. Complementary hors d'ouevres like smoked-salmon mousse preceded meals. In an area inundated with copycat Chinese and pasta-and-pizza spots, Zanghi's made dishes with rabbit, pheasant and monkfish commonplace.
When the recession arrived on the Island, luxury restaurants like Zanghi's were hit hardest. The impact set off the change from Zanghi's to Nicola's, a more casual second-tier fine-dining restaurant. Although Nicola's is less of a special-occasion spot than Zanghi's, it has been a success.
Now Mr. Zanghi, at 43 and with three children and another on the way, wants to move on while he isyoung and enthusiastic enough to start a major venture. He says he and his wife will miss their special friends, but not the petty headaches of Long Island living.
Although the Zanghis will move to Fairfield, Conn., next month, Nicola's will stay open for a few months. As a parting gesture for its last month, diners will be able to order fine old Burgundy and Bordeaux wines for 50 percent less than their regular prices.
Georgio's, a high-profile high-priced Italian restaurant in the Garden City Hotel that has been dormant, is to reopen in the fall as a sea grill. The hotel food and beverage director, Charles Hamann, decided to move to light food and decor after a three-week foray in California during which he ate at cutting-edge restaurants.
Mr. Hamann's scouting expedition will result in a bright-light Mediterranean style at the Garden City Hotel Restaurant. It will stress the grilling of fish, especially exotic ones like pompano and mahi-mahi. The healthwise menu will also offer nine types of oysters in an appetizer sampler dish.
The executive chef at the Polo Grill in the hotel, Stephen Meade, and his wife, a cardiac nurse, have conducted research for a menu for the new restaurant. Heavy preparations and sauces will be omitted and easy-on-the-heart dishes will be emphasized on the changing daily menu.
George Labeau will be the chef. He has worked at the Greenbrier Hotel in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., and the Riverbay in Williston Park. The sea grill's pastry chef, Christopher Junda, comes to Long Island after working at a number of Manhattan restaurants. Although Mr. Junda's creations include low-cholesterol selections like fresh fruit and Key lime pie, other desserts might well tempt all but the most disciplined eaters.
The new sea grill will be open five nights a week Wednesdays through Sundays.
Changes: The American Bistro of King's Park will operate a courtside cafe for the Hamlet Challenge Cup tennis tournament at the Hamlet Golf and Country Club in Commack from tomorrow to Saturday. Their lunch dinner menu includes grilled chicken on focaccia with walnut pesto dressing, Caesar salad Santa Cruz, Maryland crab cake with Southern slaw, chicken and duck sausage with pine nuts and sun-dried tomatoes with a trio of mustards.
Chatham's, a new seafood restaurant at 107 Forest Avenue in Locust Valley, where Marbles had been, offers an early-bird special. The dinner at dusk, costing $11.95, is served from 5 to 6:30 and features six main courses. A complete clambake for $15.95 is also available at those hours.
CoCo's Water Cafe at 117 New York Avenue in Huntington features a two-and-a-half-pound lobster dinner for $19.95. The lobster is served with corn on the cob and a watermelon dessert in the outdoor summer garden only on Tuesday and Thursday nights.
Fabio's at 62 Stewart Avenue in Huntington is changing its name to Pomodoro and its menu from Brazilian-Italian to all Italian.
Fountaine's Beacon, formerly the Beacon, at 322 West Montauk Highway in Hampton Bays, has added New Orleans dishes to its Creole-Cajun menu. Sean Fountaine, his mother, father and sister own and operate the Louisiana-style restaurant.
Mr. Foutaine's additions include flounder Rockefeller with spinach, pernod stuffing and Hollandaise sauce and scallops Arnaud, broiled scallops with fresh tomatoes and Hollandaise sauce. They join standards like jambalaya, shrimp and chicken creole and shrimp Bordelaise.
La Vigna, a big-deal Italian restaurant at 64 Glen Cove Road in Greenvale, has reopened as a family style operation.
Pasta Pasta, a 30-seat trattoria that made a name for itself in Rocky Point, moved in the spring to 234 Main Street in Port Jefferson. It now seats 60. That move, combined with a slight drop in prices (main-course pastas cost as little as $7), has resulted in reservations-only business on weekends.
Piccolo, a deservedly popular little shopping-center storefront continental restaurant at 215 Wall Street Huntington, is now open on Mondays.
Opening: This month the Elk Hotel, which opened in 1919 in Port Jefferson, will become Harrington's Cafe Americain. The restaurant is called an urban oasis by Doug Harrington, who, along with his partner Bill Farnum, hope to recapture the aura and ambience of traditional old New York restaurants. Live jazz and the work of local artists will be featured.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
You've Got to Stop And Plant the Roses . . .

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
Every weekend, rain or shine, Charles Borrok leaves his city apartment and races to his country house in Westchester. Straightaway, he inspects his garden to see which blossoms have popped open. "I'm highly committed to my garden," said Mr. Borrok, president of the New York real estate firm of William A. White/Grubb & Ellis. "I work on it until December, and then I'm back by March."
Mr. Borrok is among a growing group of executive gardeners who claim kneeling, weeding and digging is therapeutic for the muscles as well as the mind. At summer cocktail parties, they rattle off the Latin names for plants and swap stories about handmade English tools. In the office, they pore over mail-order garden catalogues as if they were annual reports and discuss compost piles as if they were junk bonds. 
 According to a recent survey by the National Gardener's Association in Burlington, Vt., professionals and business people bought about half of all garden-related merchandise last year. They spent $9.2 billion, up from $7.2 billion in 1986.
Experts say the surge has as much to do with changes in the social climate -- the ostentatious 80's have given way to the naturalistic 90's -- as with the stagnant economy. "During a recession, gardening usually picks up," said Bruce Butterfield, a spokesman for the association. "People spend more time at home, and they try to make it a more enjoyable and interesting place to be."
For executives, gardening has a particular allure. "If you spend all day pushing paper around or fiddling with spreadsheets, the prospect of using your hands to make things grow is quite rewarding," said Michael Pollan, author of "Second Nature," a recently -published gardening book. "It used to be thought of as a pasttime for little old ladies. If men gardened, they grew a few tomatoes or zucchini. But now men are comfortable growing flowers."
Consider Robert Hubbard, a partner in the New York law firm of Satterlee, Stephens, Burke & Burke. Mr. Hubbard says the solitary nature of tending to the dozen beds on his four-acre property outside of Albany is less stressful than country-club sports. "If you go out on a golf course or a tennis court and you don't play well, you end up frustrated," he said. "But when you battle trees and shrubs, you almost always win."
Mr. Hubbard, who is president of the New York Horticultural Society, is so devoted to his garden that he won't allow his wife to invite houseguests until July or August. "In May and June, I'm too tired from putting in new plants," he said. "I'm also covered with dirt and sheep manure."
Some executives find gardening at odds with their work schedules. "I've found that flowers bloom on Monday morning and die by Friday evening," said Edward Lee Cave, who runs his own real estate brokerage in New York. He tricks them by taking three-day weekends at his Connecticut home.
At work, "I probably spend half an hour to an hour each day looking at catalogues or books and talking on the phone to my gardening assistants," he said, adding that garden talk is a prerequisite with several of his business associates, including his banker at U. S. Trust. "Whenever I call him to talk about my money, the conversation invariably gets around to gardening," he said.
Then there are the friendly feuds between weekend gardeners. Ed Hayes, the Manhattan attorney who represented Andy Warhol's estate and has a passion for pruning shrubs, rhapsodizes about a battery-operated hedge trimmer that cuts his English boxwoods perfectly. It is the cause of a running dispute with his Bellport, L.I., neighbor, David Shaffer, a child psychologist who is married to Vogue editor Anna Wintour. "David likes to let things grow naturally," Mr. Hayes said. "So we argue about the merits of shaping."
While showmanship is generally acceptable in gardening circles, one-upmanship is not. Mr. Borrok, the real estate man, boasts that his seven-acre country garden includes 55,000 tulips, 3,800 rhododendrums and 4,500 azaleas. "People who give you numbers haven't left the office behind," sniffed Mr. Pollan. "My advice to them: don't count your bulbs. Just watch them grow." In fact,for Mr. Borrok, just supervising his staff of three to five gardeners would seem to take him away from the part of gardening he likes best.
Indeed, most executives are not your garden-variety gardeners. "People who are successful in business don't want to grow just anything," said Steve Frowine, a horticulturist at White Flower Farm, a Litchfield, Conn., nursery. "A lot of executives are getting into perennials. They like them because they're so complex. They appeal to the detail-oriented type."
Mr. Frowine reports hardy sales of fern-leaf peonies, at $70 apiece, and tuberous begonias, at $26.50. Many customers, he says, are collectors, demanding one-of-a-kind specimens with important pedigrees. "They want plants none of their friends have heard of," Mr. Frowine said. "It's like going to a tiny village in Europe nobody's ever heard of. It has terrific snob value."
Of course, such showpieces cannot be tended with just any tools. Susan Colley, who recently left a career on Wall Street selling Government bonds to open a Manhattan shop called Lexington Gardens, does a brisk business in $150 watering cans and $25 spades. "The 80's were about interior decorating," she said. "The 90's are about gardening."
Could plants really be the power symbol in these poorer, politically correct times? Mr. Butterfield of the gardening association likes to think so. "Now, it's not who's got the Mercedes-Benz or BMW in the driveway, it's who's got the biggest tomato or the most colorful perennials," he said.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: He Knew How to Blow Things Up

BYLINE: By Edward Hower; Edward Hower is the author of two novels and, most recently, "The Pomegranate Princess," a book of folk tales he collected in India.

 BODY:

THE NIGHT TRAVELLERS
By Elizabeth Spencer.
366 pp. New York: Viking. $21.95. 
 Another wave of nostalgia for the 1960's seems inevitable. As the recession of the 90's deepens, as the post-Iraq "new world order" becomes increasingly difficult to maintain, we may be tempted to escape into reveries about an era when life seemed simpler and more prosperous. The nostalgia will be marketed in psychedelic colors to blur the political issues over which we agonized 25 years ago. We'll be urged to believe that the antiwar protesters were romantic, though misguided, figures from the past whose slogans were indistinguishable from the lyrics of Beatles songs. To resist the hype, we're going to need reports from people who clearly remember the Vietnam War era, and who know that swallowing myths about our military history can lead to our having to repeat its disasters.
Many good novelists have written about the war in Vietnam itself, but Elizabeth Spencer, in "The Night Travellers," is one of the few who have dealt with the lives of the civilians who resisted the conflict. It's always hard to write about political idealists -- especially those on the left -- without sounding condescending or preachy, but Ms. Spencer succeeds in making her antiwar protesters plausible. Both their courage and their flaws make them sympathetic characters.
Jeff, a graduate student from the Louisiana backwoods, learned about the seamier aspects of capitalism when, as an oil rig worker, he was duped by his boss into blowing up his company's property for the insurance money. Years later, he uses his demolition skills to damage a California munitions factory in an attempt to cripple the war effort. In between these experiences, he marries Mary, an apolitical dance student from a "good" North Carolina family, and fathers a child. He also makes a name for himself as a guerrilla journalist and a dissident. He and Mary become "pilgrim wanderers . . . homeless, trusting, lost and innocent."
Ms. Spencer's accounts of the militants' rap sessions and correspondence capture the charged atmosphere that hangs over their lives as oppressively as the clouds of tear gas and the roar of police helicopters hovering above their protest rallies. As the war grinds on, political commitment loses its romance. Protesters go underground, sacrificing their careers and sometimes their families as well.
Becoming a fugitive, Jeff finds that he no longer has a choice about which is more important to him, his cause or his family. His ability to continue working for the movement while on the run and also to maintain his ties to his wife is a kind of triumph for him. But Mary and their daughter, Kathy, pay a high price for his idealism. Stranded in Canada when Jeff goes underground, Mary must depend on the support of a succession of well-meaning friends to survive.
Mary's mother, Kate, has never approved of her daughter's marriage and keeps trying to control Mary, to lure her back to the United States, in Jeff's absence. Kate is a scientist with no qualms about killing lab animals in her war-related research. She cannot forgive Jeff when his organization destroys her laboratory and, indirectly, her career.
Mary's only desires are to be true to her husband and to continue her career as a dancer. But neutrality in these times is impossible. She becomes the pawn of both the left and the right, her husband and her mother. Whenever Jeff, a traveler by night, always on the run, manages to get in touch with her, she drops everything to follow his instructions, but their meetings don't always come off.
Mary loves, fears and resents her mother, rarely breaking free enough to live without Kate's financial support. Her mother reaches out for her, trying to make contact; then, when Mary gets too close, she rejects her, fleeing from intimacy. Their mutual dependence does as much to destroy them as to sustain them. Kate begins to withdraw into alcoholism while Mary slowly gains some maturity, creating a life for herself and her daughter in Montreal.
A central character too often controlled by forces stronger than she is can be a liability in any novel. That the author writes beautifully about Mary and her predicament helps a great deal to keep our interest in her alive. Ms. Spencer, the author of "The Light in the Piazza" and "The Salt Line," among other books, has gained a well-deserved reputation as an accomplished stylist. Her portraits of everyone in "The Night Travellers" are moving and insightful.
Still, I couldn't help getting exasperated with her heroine. Mary is plausible enough -- we've all seen long-haired waifs like her wandering through fringe neighborhoods -- but she can't carry the novel by herself, as she's often called upon to do. I sometimes wanted to kick her, just to get her to make a decision on her own and follow it through. Eloquent writing and interesting secondary characters compensate for Mary's passivity, but the softness at the book's center weakens the narrative.
In addition, telling the story from multiple points of view -- those of the author, the main characters and several secondary characters -- sometimes causes confusion. The book is divided into very brief chapters, which heighten the sense of the characters' fragmented lives but also frustrate our efforts to follow the plot. There's too much aimless movement of people from place to place; the book could have been shorter.
When a writer as good as Elizabeth Spencer, however, tries unconventional techniques in the service of her ambitious vision, we're compelled to read on, hoping that she will succeed. "The Night Travellers" mixes political issues with several complex and interesting love stories -- no easy task, but Ms. Spencer carries it off, despite some problems. The book is finally more a novel about relationships than about historical events, and this is one of its greatest strengths.
By shedding light on the people whose lives were disrupted by the strife of the 1960's, and those who fought, in Jeff's words, "to restore some sense of . . . purpose and pride" to their country, she helps us to see the period more clearly, and to recognize in it both the political and the human conflicts still facing us today.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newspapers See a Threat Of Spreading Sales Taxes

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
AFTER being largely exempt from sales taxes on circulation, newspapers and magazines have come under mounting pressure from state legislatures looking for new revenues to balance budgets ravaged by the recession.
In July, California repealed its long-established exemption on sales taxes for all periodicals, which means newspapers and magazines must now pay up to 8.25 percent in taxes on circulation revenues, plus bear the added administrative costs involved with such a tax. 
 California is considered a bellwether state and both the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the Magazine Publishers Association fear that the repeal of the exemption could prompt a flurry of similar tax proposals.
While a number of such tax laws were stopped in various states in the last year, California's action is going to make them much harder to derail.
"I think that it's going to be very difficult to fight the battle unless and until state treasuries are less in need of additional revenue," said W. Terry Maguire, general counsel of the newspaper association.
Newspapers can pass along the cost of the new tax by increasing prices for both single copies and subscriptions. But with advertising sales lagging, many papers had hoped to use increased circulation rates to bolster their own bottom lines.
The California Legislature goes into session for three weeks starting today and newspapers are mounting a big effort to re-establish the exemption. Thomas Newton, general counsel for the California Newspaper Publishers Association, said that as an alternative, the association would suggest an increase in cigarette taxes.
But Gov. Pete Wilson is against the newspapers' effort, and the press is generally unpopular in the Legislature, in part because of its widespread support for an initiative last year limiting the number of terms that legislators can serve.
"No one at this time believes there is any realistic chance," said George Gross, executive vice president for government affairs of the Magazine Publishers Association. He added that the association was so pessimistic that it would not join the newspaper effort in California.
Free publications have been particularly hard hit by the California law. For them, the tax is being levied on printing costs, but they have no way to pass the expense on by raising subscription and single-copy prices. There are proposals in the Legislature to re-establish the exemption for them, which are more likely to pass.
According to the magazine association, newspapers are exempt from sales taxes in 31 of the 45 states that levy sales or some similar taxes. Three of the states with a tax apply it only to single-copy sales.
Magazine subscriptions, which account for about 75 percent of magazine sales, are exempt in 22 states, but this number includes New York, Illinois and most of the other states where large magazines are published. The political clout of local newspapers in state houses is the principal reason why, in 12 states and the District of Columbia, newspapers are exempt and magazines are not.
Since before the United States was founded, governments have tried to tax the sale of newspapers and newspapers have strenuously resisted.
In 1765, Britain was searching for a way to cut the budget deficit caused by the French and Indian War and, among other solutions, levied a tax on newspapers in the Colonies. This was the notorious Stamp Act, which radicalized many papers and prompted editorial thundering for rebellion.
In the centuries since then, newspapers have paid their corporate and income taxes, but have argued that a tax on newspaper circulation did not promote the First Amendment's underlying policy of encouraging the free flow of information.
Efforts to tax advertising have also been tried. In 1987, Florida passed a tax on advertising and other services, including lawn-mowing and legal advice. Such services are rarely taxed in this country and the law prompted such a huge outcry that it was repealed six months later.
Mr. Maguire of the newspaper association said the prospect of a widespread effort to tax advertising was more remote than the expected blitzkrieg of efforts to tax the newspaper itself, which is considered a manufactured product rather than a service.
While newspapers and magazines have generally been allies in the fight to avoid sales taxes, the willingness of state legislatures to tax magazines, while exempting newspapers, sometimes puts them in opposing camps. Magazines have filed suit, arguing that they should not be singled out.
The United States Supreme Court has ruled that in certain cases, states may tax magazines and not newspapers. They may not make a distinction for tax purposes on the basis of content, which would amount to censorship. But the court also said that if the basis of the tax distinction was the form of the publication, rather than the content, then states might tax one and not the other.
Refining the distinction between form and content will probably be tested later this year because of a law passed early this month by the Pennsylvania Legislature that repeals the sales tax exemption on magazines, but leaves newspapers exempt.
Mr. Gross of the magazine association said the state's magazine publishers intended to file suit.

HEADLINE: With New Talks Near, Cypriots Wonder How the Divide Can Be Bridged

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 13

 BODY:
In the quiet no man's land between the feuding Greek and Turkish Cypriots, the sandbags and barbed-wire fences loom like images from the cold war, a mean place of rival flags and minefields that have partitioned this island nation for 17 years.
But in the flurry of diplomatic activity that has followed the end of the Persian Gulf war, Muslim Turks and Christian Greeks are cautiously measuring whether the time has come to heal old wounds and reunite the broken halves of Cyprus. 
 Many of the 700,000 inhabitants, above all the Greeks in the south, are eagerly following news of the latest peacemaking moves, all too aware that nothing came of many previous efforts to end the deadlock since Turkish forces seized the northern part of the island in 1974 and set up a breakaway state there recognized only by Turkey.
This time, with the influence of the United States newly at work here, refugees on both sides of the barricades are wondering whether sometime soon they will again be able to see their birthplaces. But in the confines of this island, where each side sees conspiracy in the gesture of the other, there is also great apprehension about a peace conference to be held next month in the United States.
 
Talks Announced by Bush
 The conference, with the United Nations as host, was announced by President Bush after he visited Greece and Turkey last month. It aims to bring together for the first time representatives of the two Cypriot sides as well as their protectors in Greece and Turkey. To prepare the ground, a special American envoy, Nelson Ledsky, visited the island last week, and United Nations negotiators are due later this month.
But such are the bitter memories of the near civil war of the 1950's and 60's and the Turkish invasion of 1974 that the obstacles to normalization remain enormous.
The mood is ambivalent, for example, in the living room of Caliope Christofi in Stromvoli, one of the many refugee settlements that ring Nicosia, the capital. A Greek refugee from the north, Mrs. Christofi brings out photographs of the dead and talks of the instant her life turned.
It was quarter to six in the evening, Mrs. Christofi said, when she learned that Turkish troops had landed. She grabbed her four young sons, hid in a cave and then fled south, walking from village to village. Her husband, a lighthouse guard, fell ill on the journey and died. Turkish soldiers killed her brother's 17-year-old son and 22-year-old son-in-law, she said.
 
'How Can We Forget?'
 "How can we forget this?" she asked. "Of course I would like to go back to my house. But how could I? How could my brother live again with a Turkish neighbor?"
On the other side of the barbed frontier, a 118-mile line patrolled by United Nations troops, Turkish feelings are just as intense. At the only crossing point, a startling street exhibit, titled "Years of Terror -- 1955, 1963, 1974," shows close-up photographs of slain adults and children and images of burned and bullet-ridden homes and mosques. The scenes are described as the work of Greek nationalists determined to terrorize Turkish Cypriots and drive them from the land the nationalists considered Greek.
Hamac Osman was among the Turks who became refugees in 1974. He now runs a small electronics store in Kyrenia, in the north. "I will not go back and live with Greeks," he said.
His sister Mevhibe blurted: "We don't want them back. We lost our childhood there. We were always afraid."
It is in the north where people appear least interested in a settlement. An accord is likely to involve the Turks' giving up part of the occupied territory and some prime property as well as a withdrawal of most or all Turkish soldiers. United Nations officials estimate that 30,000 Turkish troops are stationed here.
 
Turkish Demands Rejected
 Rauf Denktash, the Turkish Cypriot leader, is said to have wide support for his demand that any solution must include the right for Turkey to intervene unilaterally to defend his people, who make up a fifth of the population. Such a demand is unacceptable to Greek Cypriots and to Athens, which keeps about 2,000 soldiers here. While Ankara argues that it sent troops to protect its ethnic compatriots and to stop a pro-Greek coup from forcing a union with Greece, Athens has never stopped arguing that the Turkish presence is an invasion that went unpunished.
The United States, which has not regarded the Cyprus problem as pressing for several decades, has become involved in the months since the gulf war, partly as a result of Greece's arguments that only Washington can persuade the Turks to leave Cyprus. But Washington is also worried that the continuing feud between Greece and Turkey could create more friction in the eastern flank of NATO at a time of delicate change in the Eastern Mediterranean and growing instability in the Balkans.
While the binoculars and blue banners of the United Nations have kept the peace here, they have been unable to stop the two peoples from growing apart in ways that may be difficult to bridge. One problematic issue is the fate of the settlers imported here from mainland Turkey, among them Kurds from the east, Muslims who fled Bulgaria and poor farmers from all over Anatolia. Many of them were given the land and homes of expelled or fleeing Greek Cypriots.
Several small Turkish partis in the north also argue that the 60,000 settlers have little in common with the 120,000 Westernized Turkish islanders. These groups also accuse Mr. Denktash of using the immigrants to bolster his position at the polls.
Mustafa Kortum, an official of the Denktash government, said: "We needed labor. These people work the land and had children. They came legally and they must stay."
 
Some Progress Reported
 In recent weeks, though, some progress has reportedly been made on the difficult question of how much land now in the Turkish zone should be returned to the Greek side. Reports have leaked that Turkey was willing to reduce the current 37 percent of the land it occupies to 25 or 30 percent.
The two sides differ widely over how many Greek refugees may return to the north and reclaim their property. In the southern city of Limassol, where many have settled, older people almost beg to go. Akinoi Mortis and her family were among the 180,000 Greeks who fled or were forced to move south after the Turkish invasion. At the same time, 80,000 Turks were forced north.
"How would the people of New York feel if they were expelled to Texas, and those from Texas were sent to Chicago?" said Akinoi Mortis. She says she cannot wait to give up her little grocery, once owned by Turks, and go back to Famagusta. "Every night I pray to go home," she said.
In a unified Cyprus, Mr. Denktash wants to have two virtually autonomous parts of a federation, with separate governments and separate rules of commerce. Northern businessmen have reportedly demanded protectionist measures because they fear competition from tougher and more up-to-date Greek entrepreneurs.
From a rooftop overlooking Nicosia, the view itself is a reflection of the astonishing range of differences that have sprung from years of de facto partition. A line of tall, competing pennants marks the line dividing the city's two sectors since 1963. Low, red-tiled roofs stretch across the north of the city, homes to craftsmen and shopkeepers, a place punctuated by minarets and calls for prayer.
 
Southern Side Prospers
 To the south, the skyline is an enormous wall of high-rises built to house offices and apartments of bankers and traders, many of whom moved here from Lebanon after the collapse of Beirut.
The southern side has disco music, flashy electronics and youths on motorcycles. Along the nearby coast, Greeks have built a rash of identical modern hotels to accommodate a flourishing tourist industry. The post-invasion boom here has left Greek Cypriots with per capita earnings of some $8,000 a year, about three times that of the north, where half the budget is made up by Turkey.
Bridging that economic gap is also a subject of the coming talks. Yet the promise of material welfare for the north appears to offer little enticement for Mr. Denktash, who has become personally wealthy.
Only last week, according to a well-placed United Nations official, Mr. Denktash apparently reassured his hard-line supporters that even a smooth peae conference would have to be followed by long follow-up talks. Final application of new rules in Cyprus, he reportedly told them, might well take years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Every night I pray to go home," said Akinoi Mortis, who was among the 180,000 Greeks who fled or were forced to move south after the 1974 Turkish invasion. She says she cannot wait to give up her store, which was once owned by Turks, in the southern city of Limassol, and return to Famagusta. (Marlise Simons/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
New York State Account Is Lost by Wells Rich

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
The New York State travel and tourism advertising account, famous for its longtime "I Love New York" slogan, is leaving its agency of 14 years, Wells Rich Greene BDDP, for McCann-Erickson New York.
"I'm disappointed, but I'm not surprised," Kenneth S. Olshan, chairman and chief executive of Wells Rich, said Friday. Billings, which ran as high as $15 million during the campaign's heyday in the 1980's, have fallen to around $2.5 million. 
 The shift of the account, following a regular review conducted every three years, is expected to be announced today by the New York State Department of Economic Development. At one point, 10 agencies, including Wells Rich and McCann, were finalists in the review.
The development of the slogan, which had a heart symbol replacing the word "love" and generated legions of imitators, is generally credited to Charlie Moss, Wells Rich's vice chairman and corporate creative director. The campaign is considered the inspiration for a wave of marketing campaigns by states seeking to promote themselves as vacation destinations the way consumer-products companies market soap and soup.
Mr. Olshan said Mr. Moss described the loss of the account, which has not been a profit-maker for the agency, as "good news, because maybe now we can go after something exciting and romantic where we'll have to travel to see the client."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Peoples' Defender Retains a Taste For New Causes

BYLINE: By E. R. SHIPP

 BODY:
The news that the head of the Transit Authority had suggested cutting services in those areas not organized enough to offer opposition was no news to low-income New Yorkers, especially those who are black or Hispanic.
For years they have seen reduced services and hazardous sites in their midst -- often when communities with more political and economic clout retained services and kept those projects out of their backyards. 
 On the environmental front, it is a pattern seen throughout the nation, as the United Church of Christ's Commission for Racial Justice documented several years ago in a study directed by Charles Lee of the commission.
"There's been a pattern in terms of racial inequity: Communities 'on the other side of the tracks,' so to speak, get the most noxious type facilities," Mr. Lee said recently.
By the time the commission released its study in 1987, L. Ann Rocker already knew that. By then, the former teacher and director of a South Bronx community-development program had joined the growing ranks of blacks, Hispanic-Americans and American Indians who have begun to fight back.
In New York, such efforts seem to have begun in earnest in the last five years and range from the Toxic Avengers, a youth group combating a radioactive-waste site in Williamsburg to several groups focusing on lead poisoning.
More often than not, they do not call themselves environmentalists, thinking perhaps that that word is reserved for people trying to save the whales or some other endangered species.
For Mrs. Rocker, a resident of West Harlem for 26 years, the most endangered species are her family and her neighbors. Her conver sion from merely being annoyed to doing some thing about it began on July 4, 1986 -- a few months after a sewage- treatment plant opened across the street from her apart ment building on Riverside Drive.
The plant, which the city had decided to build before World War II, was to have been placed farther downtown along the Hudson. But that area had clout. Harlem did not. So the plant stretches from 137th Street to 145th Street.
It was not until the stench from the plant ruined her Fourth of July barbecue that she decided to do something. "I was so angry that the next morning I got myself together and I found out about D.E.P.," she said. That is the city's Department of Environmental Protection, which operates the plant.
But she got the brushoff there and when she tried to convince local community leaders to do something, they begged off: The issue was too technical, the bureaucracy too complicated for them. Some did suggest that she start a petition drive or organize a march. But she said no.
You know, that's just going out there hollering and saying really nothing, she said the other day. "I knew that we must get deeper than that."
Since then she has gotten deeper -- learning how the plant came to be placed in Harlem, its design and how it is supposed to function, its shortcomings and, most important, who in government should be doing something about it.
Mrs. Rocker, who is married and the mother of three, led her neighbors in forming the North River Community Environmental Review Board, which monitors conditions at the plant.
But Mrs. Rocker has not stopped there. Her efforts led the city to shut an illegal garbage dump last fall. Several years ago, she helped get the meatpackers in the Manhattanville section to stop dumping their waste along the banks of the Hudson, where "the rats, rodents, snakes and everything else were enjoying themselves."
She has joined with others in complaining about air pollution from the crematorium at the Trinity Church cemetery and an incinerator at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She recently added to her growing list of environmental concerns the Amtrak trains that speed through Harlem, polluting the air and endangering lives where there are no fences to keep the public off the tracks, especially those tracks that run through city parks.
She has also added to her list a plan that would increase traffic and remove some trees on Riverside Drive, which she said would add to the pollution problem.
She has studied the new City Charter and its promise to spread unwanted public projects around the city in a more equitable manner. But she has become convinced that black and Hispanic New Yorkers are still going to suffer unless they become more diligent. Most of all, she said, they must begin to hold their elected officials accountable.
Because of her impatience with small talk -- or any talk in lieu of action -- she often comes across as abrupt and abrasive. She does not suffer fools or politicians. But if any of them are in search of causes to champion, she says: "We've got a bowl full of issues right here. Close your eyes and pull one."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS: UPHEAVAL AT SALOMON;
Disruption Of Bonds Is Doubted

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Treasury Department's curious handling of the way Salomon Brothers operates in the government securities market will probably have little influence on the future course of interest rates, credit market analysts and Wall Street executives said yesterday.
Indeed, while the Treasury's disciplinary action is likely to be a big topic of conversation this week, traders said any movement in bond yields was more likely to be precipitated by the Federal Reserve, whose policy-making Open Market Committee is expected to meet in Washington tomorrow. 
 On the surface, any action that the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve might take against Salomon would seem to carry at least some risk of disrupting the market. As arguably the most aggressive firm in the government securities market, Salomon has long been a leading, if not dominant, force in bidding for and then distributing Federal debt obligations.
 
Part of Order Rescinded
 The Treasury seemed to acknowledge that risk when it chose to rescind part of an order it issued early yesterday that would have barred Salomon from bidding in upcoming auctions of government securities. The action follows Salomon's admission that it had violated Federal rules during Treasury auctions this year.
After Salomon's three top executives resigned yesterday afternoon, however, the Treasury amended its original order. Salomon can bid for its own account, but is prevented from placing orders for customers until the various investigations are finished.
Wall Street executives said that while the Treasury Department appeared indecisive and worried, its amended order made sense.
"I can see how people might think the Treasury backed off because of concerns about taking Salomon out of the market," the head of a rival primary dealer said. "But that just isn't the case. When you look at who owns U.S. Treasury debt around the world, Salomon has a tiny percentage. Denying them access to their clients is a real penalty to them. But those customers will still have to operate in the market, and will still be buyers of securities."
Moreover, barring Salomon from bidding for its own account at upcoming auctions would have little practical effect, the executive said, since Salomon could easily place bids for the issues through other primary dealers.
Traders and analysts said they did not expect bidding at today's regular auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills to be affected by the Treasury Department's announcements. A truer test will come next week, they added, when new two-year and five-year notes are expected to be sold. Even then the impact will probably be quite marginal, they said.
"At the margin, the Treasury's action should lessen the bid at the auctions," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "But my first impression is that it is unlikely to have any measurable impact" on the yields those bids produce at the auctions.
Mr. Fine and others said the Treasury Department's investigation, which forced the resignation of Salomon's three top executives, would almost certainly make the firm much more cautious about taking market risks than it has been in the past.
Depending on what the Government investigation turns up, Salomon could still lose its status as a primary dealer of Treasury securities. But credit market participants said a Salomon departure would not have much impact.
Primary dealers have seen their profit margins shrivel in the last few years, in large part, people in the industry argue, because there are so many primary dealers. Absorbing Salomon's share of the market would not pose much of a challenge, these people said.
"It really doesn't matter much to investors which primary dealer they work with," one trader said. "The idea that the I.B.M. pension fund or a big bank isn't going to own Treasuries because they can't buy them through Salomon Brothers is preposterous."
By contrast, the notion that the Federal Reserve may vote to lower short-term interest rates at tomorrow's meeting of the Open Market Committee is much more likely, according to credit market analysts.
 
Toublesome Signs
 The meeting will take place against a backdrop of weak money growth, an improving inflation outlook and troublesome signs that the economic recovery may be flagging.
The central bank surprised credit market participants earlier this month by lowering the overnight rate on bank loans in the Federal funds market by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent. Given its deliberate nature, another Fed move so soon would be unusual, and could stall or reverse the recent sharp improvement in long-term interest rates.
Still, in the judgment of many private economists, another modest easing of monetary policy would not hurt. The only question, these analysts say, is when the Fed might decide to move.
"If I were over there, I would do it right after the meeting, and I think they will," said Lyle E. Gramley, a former Fed governor who is now chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association.
 
Tranquil Attitude Cited
 "Given the market's fairly tranquil attitude, they can probably get away with lowering the funds rate without much risk," he said. "In my view, the risk of seeing the economy grind to a halt if they don't do anything is a lot more serious than the possibility that the recovery is a lot stronger than they think."
The week's key economic release, a Government report on new orders for durable goods in July, is not expected until Friday. Most analysts are forecasting that this highly volatile number will show that new orders rose by a full percentage point last month.
At this juncture, Mr. Gramley and other analysts said another quarter-point cut in the Federal funds rate would almost certainly be accompanied by a half-point reduction in the Fed's discount rate, currently 5.50 percent. A cut in the discount rate, in turn, would probably force commercial banks to lower their prime lending rate by half a point, to 8 percent.
A cut in the funds rate might well be justified, but other analysts said the Fed was likely to postpone any move until after it had a chance to examine economic data for August, especially the employment report expected on Sept. 6.
"Right now, the Fed has the leeway to lower the funds rate another 25 basis points, but there is every reason to be cautious," said Henry Kaufman, chief executive of Henry Kaufman & Company, a money management firm. "It would not be unusual if they waited to see the August economic numbers."
 
Flirting With 8 Percent
 The Fed almost certainly does not want to discourage the bond market rally. Long-term interest rates have fallen by nearly half a point in the last six weeks, and are again flirting with 8 percent, a floor that has been all but inpenetrable for the last five years.
Given the market's current tone, analysts and traders said bond yields could again go below 8 percent, as they did briefly in February. But there are serious doubts about whether yields can remain under that level.
David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International, said, "it wouldn't surprise me" if bond yields fell by as much as a full percentage point between now and the end of the year.
"The economic fundamentals justifying that sort of a move are already there," he said. "The question is, how long will it take for people to realize that. A big part of that is that there has to be a realization that the inflation news we are seeing is sustainable, even if the economy is growing."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The New Pan Am Rumbas Ahead

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
One of the first things Pan Am did after it got court permission last week to sell its trans-Atlantic routes and Northeast shuttle to Delta Air Lines and to reorganize as a Latin American carrier was to slash its prices 25 percent on tickets to many popular destinations.
"I call it our 'staying in business' sale," said Thomas G. Plaskett, chairman of Pan American World Airways. 
 The goal of the sale is to entice people to keep flying Pan Am long enough for the ailing airline to complete its deal with Delta. But Pam Am executives also hope to get fliers and the nation's travel industry acquainted with a Pan Am that is not only smaller but also refocused -- largely on service to Latin America.
Compared with the old Pan Am, a leader in commercial aviation for much of its 64-year history, the portrait that emerges might seem jolting. And it has not dispelled many of the doubts among industry analysts and consultants about how long the airline can survive.
Mr. Plaskett insists the airline will remain a familiar presence on the national scene. Or as he chanted this last week over and over again, almost like a mantra, "It'll still be a major airline."
Certainly, though, not as major as it used to be. The airline that is expected to emerge from bankruptcy by Dec. 1 looks like it will have about $1 billion in revenues, roughly one-quarter of what Pan Am took in last year. That would make it comparable to midsize airlines like America West or Southwest, placing it about 10th or 11th in the domestic rankings this year, down from 8th last year.
Though it will still fly between its main hub in Miami and 10 United States cities, including New York, Boston, Chicago and Washington, the new Pan Am will primarily service South America, Central America and the Caribbean.
Using Miami as its gateway to Latin America, Pan Am will move its Park Avenue headquarters to some vacant office space it owns in Miami. Mr. Plaskett estimated that the move would eliminate about 2,200 more jobs from the New York area, on top of the 2,800 or so that were lost as part of a companywide cutback announced earlier this month.
 
No Public Shareholders
 Another big difference is that the new airline will no longer be publicly traded. Creditors will own 55 percent of the stock in the reorganized company, and the rest will go to Delta, which has promised to feed connecting passengers from all over the country into Miami and to use its marketing muscle to insure the venture's success.
Because Pan Am's Latin American division has historically operated at a profit, both Pan Am and Delta expect the new airline to make money from the start.
The creditors say that Delta's financial advisers, Goldman, Sachs & Company, have told them that the airline's after-tax profit could jump from a projected $18 million in 1992 to $83 million in 1995. Even with the chill the Persian Gulf war gave international traffic last year, Pan Am's Latin American division earned $87 million in operating profits on revenues of $810 million in 1990, versus $102 million on revenues of $724 million the year before.
 
High-Paying Passengers
 Pan Am gives two reasons for that performance, the only bright spot in its 1990 results.
One is the higher-than-usual mix of first-class and business travelers going to Latin America. These high-paying passengers help give Pan Am higher yields, or revenues per passenger-mile, on those routes. For instance, Pan Am's 747 jets on routes from New York to Paris and from New York to Los Angeles have 21 first-class seats out of 412. The 747's flying from New York to Rio de Janeiro have 39 out of 377.
The other reason the Latin American routes have always bobbed atop the company's sea of red ink is the protectionist walls that many Latin American countries have erected around their markets.
Though much of the Caribbean is fair game for United States carriers, many South American countries restrict their entry to protect their local state-owned airlines and they regulate fares to limit price competition.
 
Mainly a Three-Way Competition
 The upshot: while 30 or 40 carriers regularly fly over the Atlantic, only 3 have any meaningful market share in Latin America: Pan Am; Varig, Brazil's national airline, and American Airlines, which took over Eastern Airlines' Latin American routes last summer.
"Relative to Europe, there is less competition and higher yields on those routes," Mr. Plaskett said.
That is changing. "Pan Am can survive in the short run if the South American economies come back," said Daniel M. Kasper, a Boston consultant who used to teach at the Harvard Business School. "But I don't see what's defensible about that niche over the long pull."
He noted that many South American countries were gradually opening up their borders, most recently Colombia, which has agreed to let an additional United States carrier into its market in exchange for having a second Colombian airline authorized to serve the United States.
Mr. Plaskett acknowledged that increased competition could soon start munching on Pan Am's bread and butter. But he is confident that the same pressures that are forcing those governments to open up their airports to new carriers will also help Latin America become "the next major economic boom area in the world."
"What's happening in Mexico is the precursor to what's going to happen in other Latin American countries," he said. "It's booming, and its move to less Government control is opening up enormous business opportunities."
Donald Tatzin, a consultant with Arthur D. Little Inc., is not so sure. He said Pan Am might be too dependent on Delta's assurances of a steady stream of Latin America-bound passengers. "When Pan Am sold its London routes to United, United was going to come in and do all these wonderful things for them, and they didn't," he said.
Delta, of course, has a stronger financial incentive than United did to live up to its promises, since it has put $305 million into the new airline in exchange for some debt and it has its equity stake. But its good intentions could change if Delta gets too many complaints from its customers about the service on the Pan Am leg of their trip. And what if some juicy routes open up in Latin America that Delta covets for its very own?
For instance, Delta, which until now has had no routes to South America, has applied for Government permission to fly from Los Angeles and Atlanta to Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo, and it plans to pursue the applications despite last week's deal. Those routes would compete indirectly with Pan Am's New York-Brazil and Miami-Brazil routes. "There will be routes where we compete with them," said Neil A. Monroe, a Delta spokesman.
 
'A Marketing Disadvantage'
 Industry consultants also fret that a Delta-Pan Am partnership will be hard pressed to compete with American, which can take passengers from many points in the United States to Latin America without changing airlines.
"It's a marketing disadvantage," Mr. Kasper said of the Pan Am-Delta tandem.
Delta could solve that problem by buying the rest of Pan Am, analysts say, but that is unlikely to happen anytime soon.
The biggest reason why not is that the new Pan Am is expected to have about $600 million in losses that it can use to shelter taxable income for years to come. Those valuable tax breaks would be jeopardized if the creditors' stake dropped below 55 percent in the next three years, since the Internal Revenue Service would probably deem it a change in control.
 
Assurance Enough for Delta
 Delta is also said to be uninterested in tying up its borrowing capacity by adding Pan Am's debt to its own balance sheet.
For all of those reasons, some say Delta has the best of both worlds with a stake that is big enough to give it virtual control but not so big that Pan Am is no longer at least a quasi-independent entity.
"Delta's objective has already been reached," said George W. James, chairman of Airline Economics Inc. in Washington. "By picking up 45 percent of the ownership, they have some assurance it will not be sold to some competitor."

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL AT SALOMON;
Suddenly, an Outsider Becomes 'Mr. Inside'

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Deryck C. Maughan, the newly appointed chief operating officer of Salomon Brothers, began the job of Mr. Inside yesterday in the effort to rescue the investment bank from the trading scandal that has rocked it in the last week.
As Warren E. Buffett, the interim chairman, deals with the consequences of the scandal, the investigation and the new direction of Salomon, Mr. Maughan will be running the firm's day-to-day business. He will do the hiring and firing.He will see that new rules governing trading, and efforts to steer Salomon's culture into safer waters, are followed. And perhaps most important, he will have to set a tone in the management of the firm that will reassure customers and give many talented employees the will and desire to ride out the storm. 
 "I don't think we want to remove all the elements that led to our success," Mr. Maughan said at the news conference yesterday at Salomon's Manhattan headquarters, where his appointment was announced. This means refining the aggressive, often arrogant style of Salomon Brothers that brought both large profits and, he acknowldged, the scandal that propelled him into his new job.
Then he added: "We need to assure a more open and cooperative sense -- I like the term partnership. And there must be an absolute insistence on the correct moral and legal behavior."
Mr. Maughan, who is 43 years old, is an Englishman and a professional manager, both unlikely attributes for an operating boss at a firm whose heart beats to the rhythm of the trading room. And Mr. Maughan knows it. Asked if he found his appointment surprising, he said: "I am not an American and I am not a trader. I am as astonished as my questioner."
But his immediate background as the chairman of Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd., which included operations in Japan, Asia and Australia, gave him, in the words of one Salomon vice chairman, Stanley Shopkorn, the experience of "running a smaller version of the organization in Tokyo."
Samuel L. Hayes 3d, an investment banking professor at the Harvard Business School who has written a book that, in part, focuses on Mr. Maughan's job in Tokyo, said: "While Salomon was making real mistakes in its home market in the United States, its crown jewel was Tokyo. Maughan is someone who has shown how to use to the best advantage the strategic and comparative advantages of Salomon's trading muscle."
But while Mr. Hayes called Mr. Maughan a "white hat," he added that it is a "tossup" whether he could parlay this job into the chairmanship of the firm's parent, Salomon Inc., in the future. And that is because he is not part of the trading culture of the firm. "You cannot graft the head of an investment banker onto the body of a trader and not get tissue rejection," he said.
People who know him say Mr. Maughan is not cut in the Salomon mode. Ego is less central to his style, they say. In Tokyo, where his management skills made him popular, he was able to step back and let his top lieutenants run their own operations without interference.
Mr. Maughan took over his new job yesterday with what appeared to be a sense of quiet confidence, a touch of humor and a little bewilderment.
Mr. Maughan said that when he woke up in his hotel in New York, "I didn't expect this to happen." But hours later he was easing into the routine of the grilling by news organizations. As he left the press conference, he referred to himself as a "captive" as he talked to colleagues.
Before going to Stanford, he worked in the British Treasury from 1969 to 1979 as an adviser on international economic and financial affairs. He joined Salomon Brothers in 1983 and became a managing director in 1986. He was appointed a vice chairman in January 1991, when he was named the co-head of Salomon's investment banking department. He was brought into that job in an effort to revive the department.
In his new job, he has to insure that the firm can demonstrate all of this and that the investment bank can put the scandal behind it and regain the confidence of its customers, competitors and the financial markets in general.
"I think the confidence has bounced with the resignation of senior manangement and the arrival of Mr. Buffett," he said. "We are looking forward to the opening of the markets tomorrow."
