HEADLINE: Faltering Mexican Opposition Back on Defensive

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Three years after their stunning gains moved President Carlos Salinas de Gortari to declare an end to the era of one-party control in Mexico, the country's opposition parties went into mid-term elections today with slim hopes.
While the rightist opposition has struggled and that on the left has splintered and lost ground, the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party has capitalized on the success of Mr. Salinas's market-oriented economic policies to reassert its political dominance. 
 Final election results are not expected for several days, but pre-election polls indicate that the PRI, as the governing party is known, could regain the two-thirds margin in the Chamber of Deputies that would enable it to dictate constitutional changes and a free trade agreement with the United States.
 
How Much Has Changed?
 Even critics say the PRI's campaign has been its most sophisticated ever. But the election has called into question the pace at which Mr. Salinas might usher in real democracy. Though the voting may well emerge as some of the cleanest in a long, soiled history of elections in this country, the campaign has underscored the seeming permanence of the PRI's hold on power, and its failure to convince many Mexicans that times have changed.
"Around here, it's, 'Long live the King!' when they say so, and 'Death to the King!' when they say so," said Rosalinda Perez, a 30-year-old teacher in the old mining city of San Luis Potosi. She said she would vote for the opposition, which is in coalition there.
The campaigning for legislative, state and local offices in Mexico has taken place amid some of the more dramatic changes in its modern history. Yet important issues, from the trade agreement to the possible admittance of foreign oil companies to plans for sweeping changes in agriculture and education, have been largely absent from election debate.
 
'Means as Ends' <HE
Instead, while the Government has trumpeted its new electoral system as proof of an end to traditional fraud, the opposition has pointed to the familiar, unequal nature of the contest. "The struggle is still focused on the means as ends,"said Lorenzo Meyer, a political scientist.
Opposition leaders say they haven't had much choice. To protest the conduct of the campaign, for instance, they have had to turn to an "independent" elections council filled with former Government officials.
Independent election observers, of which the country has only a handful, had expected the growing force of opposition poll-watchers and innovations like clear-plastic ballot boxes to limit blatant fraud. But they have sharply criticized the way in which new registration cards have been handed out to 36.4 million of the 43.5 million Mexicans eligible to vote.
Opposition leaders have said that far fewer cards were delivered in areas that voted strongly against the PRI in the past. Government officials have denied that claim, emphasizing that Mr. Salinas has ordered clean elections.
Contrary to the expectations of a cleaner vote, opposition party officials denounced what they called serious irregularities at polling places around the country, including missing ballots, the failure to open voting booths and the theft of at least one ballot box. They said the problems were concentrated in the hotly contested states of San Luis Potosi and Guanajuato.
The Federal Electoral Institute acknowledged that about 3 percent of the polling places had not opened but suggested that the opposition assertions were exaggerated.
 
Imbalance of Resources
 The disparity of campaign resources is not in dispute. In the only competitive governor's races -- in San Luis Potosi and Guanajuato -- opposition candidates have been especially overwhelmed by the money, manpower and control over the media of the governing party.
Even in Guanajuato, where the conservative National Action Party, or PAN, says it has spent $1 million, the party's propaganda is almost invisible amid that of the omnipresent PRI. Officials would not disclose PRI campaign spending.
As ever, the official machinery has cranked up to the task. For party rallies, Government resources are loaned, peasants who depend on Government credits are bused in by the thousands, and people who work for the Government or the unions it controls applaud and wave flags regardless of their sympathies.
"They give us certain benefits, and we give them this," said Jose Luis Hernandez, a member of the Guanajuato taxi drivers' union who spoke beneath a large PRI banner at a party rally. Mr. Hernandez said he worked for years as a driver for state officials and had been disgusted by their corruption. But that did not keep him away.
"In one way or another," he said, "everyone here depends on them."
 
Low Turnout Expected
 The Government's energy, the opposition's languor and their endless fight over the playing field all appear to have deepened voter apathy and cynicism. A poll taken last month found that more than half of Mexicans of voting age favored no political party. A Government poll predicted that voter turnout today would be about 42 percent.
According to most surveys, anti-Government candidates stand to lose at least five of the six governorships at stake. The PRI will likely fall short of the two-thirds majority in the Chamber of Deputies that would enable it to amend the Constitution at will, but some officials said that a need to negotiate some aspects of future reforms was politically expedient. And after losing its first handful of Senate races ever in 1988, polls show the PRI in position to win a strong majority of the 32 seats at stake today.
Even if the PRI recovery is more modest, it will confound memories like that of the leftist candidate, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, claiming the presidency in 1988 and the announcement of Mr. Salinas's narrow win after a mysterious breakdown in the vote-counting computers.
But Mr. Salinas's policies have steadily gained support here as the effects of restructuring have begun to be felt. An annual inflation rate that was above 150 percent before Mr. Salinas took over is expected to drop to about 16 percent this year. While minimum wages continue to fall in real terms, fewer and fewer workers earn them. Funding for social programs has skyrocketed. And polls show that more than half of Mexicans expect their lot to improve next year.
 
Opposition Group Falters
 As the dire economic straits that pulled many voters to Mr. Cardenas's National Democratic Front in 1988 have abated, polls have shown the coalition's successor, the Democratic Revolutionary Party, falling to between a third to a half of the 31 percent that Mr. Cardenas polled.
Some of the party's problems have been congenital. Even more than the Front, it has had trouble blending its mix of leftists with PRI dissidents like Mr. Cardenas and Porfirio Munoz Ledo, one of the party's four senators and its beleaguered candidate for governor in Guanajuato.
These splits have been abetted by Mr. Salinas. The Government has used social programs to forge near-alliances with local Democratic Revolutionary Party leaders in Michoacan state, trying to lure party leaders of uncertain commitment. Just last week, the party's floor leader in congress, Ignacio Castillo Mena, defected to become Mexico's Ambassador to Ecuador.
 
Rightist Party Divided
 The PAN has had some similar problems. Long divided between old-line conservatives and younger free-market advocates anguished by the economic nationalism of successive PRI governments, the PAN now finds itself additionally split between those members who favor alliances with the PRI and those who do not.
"There are a lot of issues they've taken away from us," said Vicente Fox, the PAN leader running a strong race for governor in Guanajuato. "We've lost a lot of ground to Salinas."
The left and right have forged a coalition in San Luis Potosi, but that kind of cooperation is a singular exception. In Guanajuato, Mr. Munoz Ledo may draw enough votes from Mr. Fox to allow the PRI candidate, Ramon Aguirre, to win.
Mr. Fox, described by Government officials as the opposition candidate most likely to win a governorship, said he had been abandoned by a handful of businessmen who funded his successful run for the Chamber of Deputies in 1988. He concluded that the financiers now needed Mr. Salinas more than they needed him.
A Businessman's Price
"With a sandwich, a soft drink and a truck, you can get a peasant to a political meeting," Mr. Fox said. "With champagne, a little caviar and an airplane, you can get a businessman."
In interviews last week, Government and PRI officials said that Mr. Salinas's 1988 pronouncement notwithstanding, the party's expected return to clear political hegemony was not a matter of one election's recovery.
For instance, a public works program called Solidarity, which critics have derided as an effort at vote-buying, in fact serves a much longer-range political strategy, said the president of the PRI, Luis Donaldo Colosio. By putting poor people in charge of their own development projects, the initiative will develop new grass-roots leaders to whom the PRI would turn as it breaks the hold of old party and union bosses. "That," Mr. Colosio said, "is the new PRI."
Along with other officials, the 43-year-old economics graduate of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School contended that the PRI's candidates today were as a group more attractive, better packaged, and more closely advised about campaign marketing than any of their predecessors.
Where Government officials spoke not long ago of a future in which the PRI would take on other parties in legitimate competition, Government officials spoke again last week of the democracy that would take place within a more inclusive governing party. "We want to legitimize our scheme," one said, "a la Mexicana."

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Text of Statement by Acting Soviet President

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement carried by the English-language service of the official Soviet news agency, Tass, on the replacement of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. It was signed by Vice President Gennady I. Yanayev and addressed to heads of state and government and the United Nations Secretary General:
At the instruction of the Soviet leadership I hereby notify that a state of emergency is introduced in individual localities of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics for a period of six months from Aug. 19, 1991, in keeping with the Constitution and laws of the U.S.S.R. 
 All power in the country is transferred for this period to the State Committee for the State of Emergency in the U.S.S.R.
The measures that are being adopted are temporary. They in no way mean renunciation of the course toward profound reforms in all spheres of life of the state and society.
These are forced measures, dictated by the vital need to save the economy from ruin and the country from hunger, to prevent the escalation of the threat of a large-scale civil conflict with unpredictable consequences for the peoples of the U.S.S.R. and the entire international community.
The most important objective of the state of emergency is to secure conditions that would guarantee each citizen personal safety and the safety of his or her property.
It is envisaged to liquidate anti-constitutional, ungovernable and essentially criminal military formations spreading moral and physical terror in several regions of the U.S.S.R. and serving as a catalyst for disintegration processes.
The entire range of measures adopted is directed at the earliest stabilization of the situation in the U.S.S.R., the normalization of socio-economic life, the implementation of necessary transformations and the creation of conditions for the country's all-round development.
Any other way would lead to enhanced confrontation and violence, to the innumerable suffering of our peoples and the creation of a dangerous focus of tension from the viewpoint of international security.
The temporary emergency measures in no mean affect international commitments assumed by the Soviet Union under existing treaties and agreements.
The U.S.S.R. is prepared to develop further its relations with all states on the basis of universally recognized principles of good-neighborliness, equality, mutual benefit and non-interference in internal affairs of each other.
We are convinced that our current difficulties are transitory in character and the Soviet Union's contribution to preserving peace and consolidating international security will remain substantial.
The leadership of the U.S.S.R. hopes that the temporary emergency measures will find proper understanding on the part of the peoples and governments, and the United Nations Organization."

HEADLINE: Katherine Dunham's Mission: Giving Children a Gift of Dance

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill.

 BODY:
The summer heat bears down on a scrubby lawn in East St. Louis, a small desolated city on the banks of the Mississippi River that has become a national symbol of poverty and despair.
But the air also throbs with excitement and pride as the young dancers of the Katherine Dunham Children's Workshop here expertly move through pieces in a wide variety of styles. Well-schooled, they dance with a rare expansiveness and joy. All are black and what the world calls disadvantaged. But each is a member of an elect group. Each is a dancer, moving across the makeshift stage of the workshop with an easy, gracious consciousness of self. 
 That has been the mission of Miss Dunham, whose vibrantly theatrical productions of traditional Caribbean, African and American choreography for the dance stage, Broadway and films turned her and her company into stars throughout the United States and Europe in the 1940's and 50's. It is a mission that has faltered in recent hard economic times. But now that mission has been embraced by a group of cultural, social and business leaders in bustling St. Louis, just across the river.
 
Of Plans and Money
 Under the leadership of Elizabeth Sayad, a public relations consultant, musician and writer, the group is working as a newly constituted board of directors to raise money to meet Miss Dunham's personal and professional needs and to support and strengthen her training programs. There are also plans to extend the programs to centers to be built in urban areas throughout the country.There are plans to raise money to preserve her influential technique and dances along with her collection of art and artifacts, housed in her handsome little Dynamic Museum, a few blocks from her home in East St. Louis.
"You can stick your head in the sand," said Kenneth H. Bitting Jr., a former Anheuser-Busch executive, who is the vice president of the Dunham board and a self-described cynic, as he spoke of the problems of that city. "And why not? It's a different state. Then you meet someone like Katherine Dunham."
Miss Dunham, who worked her way out of an impoverished, tumultuous childhood in the Midwest to become not only an internationally recognized dancer and choreographer but also an anthropolgist, writer and teacher, settled in East St. Louis in 1967, dividing her time between her small, neat house, school and museum and a home in Haiti. Her mission, urged on her by officials of the University of Illinois, was to imbue the angry, forsaken youngsters of East St. Louis with a sense of a larger, better world to which they could also have access.
 
'Culturally Heroic Society'
 "I was trying to steer them into something more constructive than genocide," the 82-year-old Miss Dunham said in a recent interview in St. Louis. "Everyone needs, if not a culture hero, a culturally heroic society. There is nothing stronger in a man than the need to grow."
She and an international staff taught languages and photography, anatomy and woodcarving, music, many forms of dance and even karate, which troubled some institutional sponsors of the school. "We told them we were only teaching the theory of martial arts," Miss Dunham said with her low, earthy laugh. "A very small lie. The martial arts were it for the young men. They loved that."
Faced with an influx of violent, confused young veterans of the Vietnam War, she took some to New York City to talk about violence with the psychologist Erich Fromm, a friend of hers. She watched as some of the children she worked with grew up to be public figures, including Reginald and Warrington Hudlin, the film makers, and Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the Olympic long jumper, and university graduates, doctors, teachers and performers.
But Miss Dunham's financial resources have dwindled drastically over the last decade. Most of the programs, which serve about 40 children, ages 4 to 16, have been cut and it has become hard to properly maintain the museum's holdings, which include artifacts, art and musical instruments of African, Caribbean and North American black traditional and modern society, paintings by Miss Dunham and exquisite costumes designed by John Pratt, her late husband, for the Dunham company.
 
Leading to a Board
 Admirers of Miss Dunham grew concerned. In 1989, after the success of a "Magic of Katherine Dunham" gala that opened the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's spring season in St. Louis, the dance presenter Adam Pinsker commissioned a study, paid with a Ford Foundation grant, that led to the formation of a board incorporated in St. Louis and East St. Louis in the spring of 1990.
A few friends and colleagues, chief among them Jeanelle Stover, Miss Dunham's longtime personal assistant and now a member of the board's executive committee, had struggled to help Miss Dunham continue her work.
Ms. Sayad, who studied dance with Miss Dunham in the early 1970's, said, "Katherine is beginning to understand that in order to accomplish her mission she has got to have a larger frame of reference." The 18 members of the new board represent "resources she just wouldn't have access to in East St. Louis," Ms. Sayad added.
The eighth annual Dunham Technique Seminar, which ended on Sunday at the Center of Contemporary Arts in University City in St. Louis, was preceded by a gala dinner and performance in early August that raised close to $35,000 to meet a matching grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.
At the gala, in one corner of the poolside party Miss Dunham greeted the guests who came over to her, often a little timidly, to shake her hand. Dark eyes glowing, she was both matter of fact and regal, submitting graciously to the cosseting of early Dunham dancers who had come to St. Louis to teach in the seminar.
There was an extra gentleness in Miss Dunham's voice as she gravely spoke of her conversations with her young goddaughter, Tikati, about the future of the earth. And she watched with affection as Vanoye Aikens, who had partnered her, charmed the crowd with his extravagant repartee as the master of ceremonies. "He lifted me, heavy or light, for about 30 years," she murmured.
The next morning, Mr. Aikens, Talley Beatty, Lucille Ellis and Tommy Gomez were teaching dancers, teachers and agile dance lovers from across the nation and abroad the fine points of the sensuous Dunham technique. In one studio, Mr. Aikens coaxed a jazz step he called the chocolate shake out of his students. In another, Mr. Gomez quietly analyzed the correct body placement of a Dunham dancer and spoke of a head movement associated with Uday Shankar, the Indian dancer.
Mr. Beatty's instructions were interspersed with anecdotes about Miss Madam Dunham, as he called her, delivered with wry detachment. And Miss Ellis drove her students to dance with space-gobbling abandon. Together again, the four spoke of their days with Miss Dunham with laughter and admiration.
"Dancers came into the company like mice and walked out as straight as cornstalks," said Miss Ellis, who teaches at her own studio in Chicago. "Miss D. taught people to be proud of themselves."
The company, which disbanded in 1962 after two decades of performing, wove its way through the United States refusing to perform for segregated audiences.
"We were with her when she broke the nightclub barriers in Chicago," Miss Ellis said. "That's all we did. We broke barriers all along. We didn't know that. We just wanted to work. We loved what we were doing. We survived because of love and pride."
Those days may be long gone, and the notion of a new Dunham company merely a cherished dream, but Miss Dunham is still surrounded by loyal colleagues. At the gala, a son of the Senegalese drummer Mor Thiam performed beside his genial father, whom Miss Dunham described as the Pied Piper who helped to draw children to the school over the years. Three of the four elegant, glowing dancers had been reared in East St. Louis and trained at the Dunham school. Miss Dunham watched them intently, drumming a soft rhythmic counterpoint on the table edge as they danced.
"It can be done," she said. "Don't tell me no."

HEADLINE: At the New York Film Festival, Works on Art

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
"What delighted me and my colleagues is that we found a number of films by directors whose work has previously been seen at the festival but who are now showing a new side, giving a little more of themselves."
Richard Pena, the chairman of the selection committee of the New York Film Festival and the program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, which sponsors the festival, was discussing what will be new at festival this year. 
 The 29th annual New York Film Festival will present 30 films from Sept. 20 to Oct. 6. The date of each is to be announced this month.
 
Change in Styles
 "Take the opening and closing selections," Mr. Pena continued. "We open with 'The Double Life of Veronique' by the Polish director Krzysztof Kieslowski, who is best known for his gritty, visceral style in films like 'A Short Film About Killing,' which was in the festival in 1989."
"The Double Life of Veronique," he said, shows Mr. Kieslowski's poetic side. It is a tale about a Polish woman and a French woman, played by the same actress, Irene Jacob, whose lives are marked by extraordinary coincidences. The film is said to leave audiences with a mystical sense that life is controlled by forces beyond human comprehension.
The festival closes with David Mamet's "Homicide." "Mamet's work has been compared to that of Fritz Lang because it is always so meticulously plotted and almost mechanical in the way it is structured," Mr. Pena said. " 'Homicide,' however, is his most personal film. It's about a detective who in the course of an investigation must come to terms with his own identity as a Jew."
 
On Creating Art
 Another theme in this year's festival is reflected in films dealing with artists and the process of making art. Jacques Rivette's "Belle Noiseuse" deals with the life of a painter; the main character in a Finnish film called "Zombie and the Ghost Train" is an unemployed musician; a Chinese film directed by Chen Kaige called "Life on a String" concerns a musician; "The Other Eye" is a German documentary about the Viennese film maker G. W. Pabst who died in 1967, and "Prospero's Books" is a version of Shakespeare's "Tempest" with Sir John Gielgud playing Shakespeare and the artist and magician Prospero.
"It wasn't our conscious intent to have such a theme in the festival," Mr. Pena said, "but as I go down the list I see the emphasis is there. After all the revolutions and upheavals in the world, maybe a time for self-reflection is at hand, and movie makers see themselves in league with poets, painters and musicians."
Still another theme, Mr. Pena said, is internationalism. The 30 films to be shown represent 18 different nations, including Eqypt, Austria, the Netherlands and 3 from South or Central America. "World cinema has really become world cinema," he said.
A first for the festival will be the showing of a work in progress. The new Disney animated film "Beauty and the Beast" will be shown in a state described as "60 percent complete."
Reached in a Los Angeles studio, Don Hahn, who has worked for Disney for 15 years and who is the producer of the film, said his company had decided to show "Beauty and the Beast" as a work in progress "because of the resurgence of interest in animation," which he said dated back to "Who Framed Roger Rabbit," another Disney film, in 1988.
"People are beginning to realize," he said, "that animators have to solve all the same problems an actor has to solve. Whether you're Dustin Hoffman or an animator, if you're doing a scene from 'Beauty and the Beast' when two characters fall in love you have to find the exact expressions that convey that feeling. Animators are closet actors. They spend hours in from of the mirror trying to solve these problems."
The finished version of "Beauty and the Beast," Mr. Hahn said, will open commercially on Nov. 22. Most other entries in the festival do not yet have distributors.
The opening and closing showings of the festival will be at Avery Fisher Hall, with the other screenings at Alice Tully Hall.
The festival box office at Alice Tully Hall will open on Sept. 8. Tickets are $7 and $10, except for opening and closing nights, for which tickets cost $10 and $15. Beginning at noon on Sept. 1, tickets can be bought through Centercharge at (212) 721-6500 for an additional charge of $3.50 a ticket.

HEADLINE: PAN AMERICAN GAMES;
For Cubans, 17 Days of Cheering

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Anybody who has visited Cuba for the last 17 days will surely leave humming the "Himno Nacional." It was played 140 times at gold-medal ceremonies for the Pan American Games, giving this proud island bragging rights over the United States, which won 130 gold medals.
While international meets do not emphasize a national total of medals, everybody was aware of the count and could not miss the major accomplishment for an island of 10 million residents over a nation of 250 million. 
 The United States, which has traditionally dominated this event since its inception in 1951, sent secondary teams in several sports, and still won the overall medal count, with a total of 352. Cuba ended up with 265.
The games cost Cuba an estimated $156 million during hard times here, but they gave many of the people the chance to cheer for 17 days.
 
Castro, Castro Everywhere
 The ultimate victory of the games came Saturday night when the Cuban baseball team poleaxed Puerto Rico, 18-3, for the gold medal, and continued into today when 11 Cubans won gold-medal matches in boxing. Steve Johnston of the United States outpointed Edgar Ruiz Burges of Mexico for the only other boxing gold medal.
President Fidel Castro applauded as one Cuban boxer after another caused the national anthem, sometimes known as "El Bayomesa," for the city of Bayamo, to be played. The esteemed President was seen so often at so many medal ceremonies during these games that sometimes, with all due respect, it seemed he was like a department-store Santa, with six or eight of them taking turns handing out the gold.
"For us the Cuban people, Fidel is kind of like a sane drug," said boxer Juan Hernandez Sierra, after he had dispatched Gregory Johnson of Canada.
All of the Cuban medals raised the spirits on an island where people ask strangers for empty plastic bottles of imported Canadian water. Cubans do not have many containers to hold precious local water when it is available.
 
No Way Home
 Another sign of the times is that lovely Latin-American Stadium had only 35,000 spectators using the 60,000 free seats at the baseball slugfest Saturday night.
Some said it was because the United States had not qualified for the final game. Others said it was because there are not enough buses running during the gasoline shortages to take a chance on going to the ball park for a game that would end after midnight.
The gold medal for baseball put Cuba behind in the medal count, 124-123, going into today. The host nation rectified that early and often at boxing, and then announced triumphs in volleyball and rhythmic gymnastics at other sites. Each time the gold-medal count was announced, the crowd roared and a percussion band blared into the microphones.
It was nuts, and it was fun, except for the boxers who lost to the Cubans. Under the Cuban sports system, all athletes are state-supported amateurs, with the same age and experience as professionals in many other countries.
 
Uneven Matchups
 Most United States athletes here were in their late teens or early 20's. The track and field, swimming and boxing federations sent mostly second- and third-string squads because the top athletes were preparing for world championships.
A young United States soccer team won a gold medal, helped when powers like Brazil and Argentina did not send development squads. The United States sent college-age squads in basketball and baseball, which won the bronze medals.
The great majority of Cuban fans did not know or care that the United States has professional leagues in those sports. What mattered was that Cuba won more gold than the nation that has imposed economic sanctions on it since the early 1960's.
In fact, the three questions asked most frequently were these: "What are your impressions of Cuba?" and "What do you think of our sports?" and "Why does the U.S. continue the blockade?"
 
Sent Reeling
 Today the question was, "Did you get the number of that bus?"
The buses, spelled "guagua" and pronounced "wa-wa," do not run very frequently during the gasoline shortage, but a number of boxers were left sprawling and bleeding today as if hit by the proverbial bus.
The most obvious victim was Shannon Briggs, a 19-year-old heavyweight who said he started boxing only two years ago as a way of avoiding gang warfare in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.
Only one other heavyweight decided to come to Cuba to face Felix Savon, perennially the world's best amateur in the division, so Briggs received a bye straight into the finals. For two weeks, Briggs had no sparring partners, lost 5 pounds due to lack of food and stomach problems and did a lot of talking about the distinctive reddish pile of dreadlocks on top of his head.
Today, it was Felix Savon time. Briggs came out mimicking Savon's calisthenics, which is never a good idea. When the bell rang, Savon cornered him, knocked him down for an 8-count, and then sent him sprawling or running toward the ropes. The United States cornermen stopped the fight at 2:45 of the first round.
"Not taking anything away from Savon, but it was just his day," Briggs said.
Actually, it was Cuba's day. And Cuba's week. And Cuba's Pan American Games.

HEADLINE: Screening for Breast Cancer: Questions of Cost and Quality

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
Sandra Thomas snapped her wallet shut and walked out of the Breast Cancer Detection Center in Charlotte, N.C., recently, $39 poorer but the very model of the modern medical consumer.
In the course of 15 minutes, her breasts had been X-rayed, films had been developed to be sure the pictures were complete and she was on her way back to work six miles away. 
 Ms. Thomas, 43 years old, says her annual mammography routine is just "common sense." But her common sense is uncommon among her peers.
 
Wide Ramifications
 "A lot of women are frightened," said Kathleen Lacombe, 58, a fabric saleswoman in South Portland, Me. "I wanted to have one and I didn't want to have one. I wanted to know if I had a problem and I didn't want to know."
How to get millions of women together with the machines that could help them is a crucial question, with ramifications not just for women's health but also for the business of medicine and the nation's health costs, now more than 12 percent of the gross national product.
About 52 million women fall under the mammographic screening guidelines of the National Cancer Institute, the American College of Radiology and the American Cancer Society. These groups recommend regular mammographic screening for women over 40, either annually or once every two years, depending on a woman's age and medical history.
Some 18 million women like Mrs. Thomas use the procedure regularly. According to the cancer institute's statistics, this is eight million more than four years ago but still barely more than a third of those for whom annual or semiannual screening mammography is recommended.
The rest, about 34 million women, stay away. Some four million of these are expected to contract breast cancer in their lives. According to calculations by Martin Brown, an economist with the National Cancer Institute, regular mammography screening leading to early treatment for breast cancer will add 1 to 10 years to their life expectancy.
The interests, the well-being and the lives of these absent women have become the banners waved by the two newest wings of professionals in the mammography business, who are engaged in a polite but earnest struggle that exemplifies the tensions between cost and care in American medicine.
Some practitioners say the way to get women in for screenings is to lower the costs, which now average $100 and can exceed $300, to $60, $50 or $40. In practice this means promoting a limited number of heavily used clinics where the economies of scale bring down costs. Other practitioners say the answer is to spread mammographic screening devices in doctors' offices around the country, promoting convenience but insuring inefficiency and increased cost.
Andrea Camp, an aide to Representative Patricia Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat who is active in women's health issues, said: "How do you make the machines good, and how do you get the women to the good machines? How do make them good at a cost that will allow the women to get to the machines? Those are the questions."
The questions of cost and quality are now surfacing, more and more contentiously, in a Congress newly sensitive to women's health issues. Since January, thanks to the efforts of Representative Mary Rose Oakar, Democrat of Ohio, Medicare, the Federal insurance program that covers people over 65, has reimbursed mammography providers.
Now other legislators are showing an interest. Senators Dave Durenburger, Republican of Minnesota, and Brock Adams, Democrat of Washington, and Representative Schroeder have either sponsored legislation or held hearings on mammography's quality and cost.
The current debate over mammography costs shows in microcosm the struggle over the future of mammography, who will do it, how well and for how much.
Ms. Thomas, who works for a marketing company, has been getting regular mammograms for about five years. She came into the Breast Diagnostic Center at midday recently, waited about 10 minutes, had an exam lasting 10 to 15 minutes, paid in cash and left.
At the end of the day, Ms. Thomas's films and those of the 37 other women who had mammograms that day were sent a few miles away to the offices of Richard E. Bird, one of the leading evangelists of high-volume, low-cost screening mammography. There, Dr. Bird or a partner spends a couple of hours reading the films and sorting them into two groups: the vast majority whose pictures appear normal and those whose pictures show danger signs -- abnormal densities, growths and lesions -- that call for further investigation.
The separation of asymptomatic women from those who should be examined more closely is the basic concept behind screening mammography. According to a registry of more than 23,000 Colorado women having regular screenings kept in a program sponsored by the Federal Centers for Disease Control, about 10 percent to 12 percent of women who have screening need to return for a second mammogram or other tests.
This second or "diagnostic" mammogram, taken because the radiologist believes there is something there to look for, is more expensive -- $120 to $300 -- in part because the suspicious area must be carefully examined, and because the radiologist also spends time talking with the patient after the exam, discussing whether there is cause to suspect cancer.
 
Effort to Cut Cost
 In an interview, Dr. Bird said he had been the younger doctor in a joint practice in the early 1980's when he decided that the costs of mammography could be reduced significantly using this technique, first widely used in Sweden by Dr. Lazlo Tabar, whom experts regard as the father of modern mammography screening.
Dr. Bird's partner was not enthusiastic. When the partner retired, Dr. Bird started talking to other colleagues around town. "I didn't get a tremendous response," he said.
But Dr. Bird's plan for screening mammography proved to be a better mousetrap. He has just opened a fourth screening clinic in the Charlotte area. The newer ones average 25 to 30 mammograms per machine per day, the older ones closer to 40.
He and others who advocate this methods, like Dr. Daniel Kopans, who heads the Breast Center at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, argue that there is an added benefit. The more procedures done, they argue, the better the technologist knows how to do them, and the better the radiologist knows how to read the film.
 
Early Detection
 Dr. Bird proffers his calculations of the health benefits to a visitor almost vehemently. It is the figures that make him messianic on spreading the technology. His study shows that in his centers 70 percent of all breast cancers detected are caught before the disease has spread to the lymph nodes. A National Cancer Institute study of breast cancer patients from 1974 to 1986 showed that less than half of the cases diagnosed were caught before they spread to the lymph nodes.
If all the women for whom mammograms are recommended used such centers, the country's 11,000 mammographic screening devices would be more than enough. But many women find the clinics inconvenient and prefer an exam in their doctor's office or close by. Dr. Buell Miller, a gynecologist in South Portland, Me., and five colleagues used to refer patients to the Maine Medical Center in nearby Portland for mammograms. More often than not, the women never turned up.
"There weren't enough people coming in," said Dr. Miller in a recent telephone interview. "They didn't come in even when the hospital offered a weekend of free mammograms."
So the radiologists at the Maine Medical Center opened Imaging Diagnostics Center, a joint venture with Dr. Miller and his colleagues in a building next to their medical offices. The gynecologists referred their patients there, the radiologists read the film, and together they paid $60,000 to $70,000 for a machine. The center does 14 to 22 studies a day, at $110 apiece.
 
'Don't Have the Volumen'
 "We don't have the volume Dr. Bird does," Dr. Miller said. "We're not going to get it unless a whole bunch of other mammographic facilities shut up shop. There are seven or eight in the area."
Are that many needed? "It depends on what you mean by 'need,' " Dr. Miller said. "For high-volume studies, no. For patient convenience for different enclaves of populations, yeah, it makes sense. If a patient has to drive 15 miles to get a low-cost screening mammogram, I doubt they'd do it if they have the money to get one conveniently next door."
His words are echoed by other doctors, including Bruce H. Drukker, chairman of the obstetrics and gynecology department at Michigan State University in East Lansing, and Richard F. Jones 3d, a Hartford gynecologist and president-elect of the American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology.
"At the present time I'd give a guesstimate that less than 10 percent of gynecologists, perhaps one or two percent, have mammographic equipment in their offices," Dr. Drukker said.
Dr. Jones has leased from a company in Windsor, Conn., Spectrascan Imaging Services, which has placed machines in "hundreds," of doctors' offices in 35 states, says its president, Alan Ware.
In its advertising, the company includes a chart that shows at a charge of $100 per mammogram, the annual profits to a practice using the Spectra scan system run from $30,000 (at a rate of 6 mammograms per day) to $60,000 (for 12 mammograms per day).
On average, Mr. Ware said, Spectrascan machines are used 6 to 8 times a day. But he and Dr. Jones said that convenient machines increase women's willingness to get mammograms.
"I say, 'You need a mammogram. Would you like to have it here today?' " Dr. Jones said. "Compliance has gone to 80 percent. " The films taken in his office are read by a local radiologist. The total charge is $125.
Dr. Jones's office-based service is accredited by the American College of Radiology, which runs a voluntary program. But only about 25 percent of the offices or clinics where mammograms are given are accredited.
 
Some Failures
 Helene Toiv, an auditor with the General Accounting Office, argues against blind faith in the technology, which can sometimes fail or be used by people who can make mistakes. "A bad mammogram," she said, "is worse than no mammogram at all."
One woman in York, Pa., had two successive annual mammograms that, according to the initial radiologist, showed no abnormality. Concerned about a lump she could feel, she sought an opinion from another doctor who identified suspicious lesions clearly visible in both the 1989 and 1990 films.
Aside from errors, some radiologists estimate that as many as 1 in 10 "negative" mammogram results mask an unseen malignancy. Such "false negatives" and the "false positive" tests which mean unnecessary, expensive costly and unnerving follow-up tests, have made quality a paramount concern.
R. Edward Hendrick, an associate professor of radiological sciences at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center in Boulder who helped develop the accrediting standards, said about 30 percent of first-time applicants fail to meet them. But more than 87 percent of those centers that fail to win accreditation the first time win it on the second try. He said he suspected that those percentages would be less likely to hold true for the centers that have not volunteered.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Democrat's Invisible Man Specializes In Making Inequity to Poor Easy to See

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Few things give Wendell Primus as much pleasure as a bar chart that looks like this:
Few things in recent years have given the Republican Party more grief. 
 Mr. Primus, a little-known but influential aide on the House Ways and Means Committee, is the architect of the latest version of the "fairness debate" -- the Democrats' quadrennial charge that a decade of Republican rule has helped the rich but hurt the poor.
His bar charts measure how rich and poor, and those in between, fare when Congress changes spending and taxes. When the bars on the left rise, as they did after last year's watershed budget negotiations, poor people gain. This makes Mr. Primus happy.
 
Resounding Whispers
 If it is true, as President Bush hyperbolically contends, that the Democrats seek class warfare, Mr. Primus might be considered their chief of intelligence, with his bar charts providing a kind of aerial surveillance of the landscape of financial inequality.
Mr. Primus (pronounced PRY-mus) is an unlikely dragon slayer: a quiet, devoutly religious economist who grew up in poverty on an Iowa farm and thought his only view of Congress might come from the window of a tour bus. But his mastery of social policy esoterica has offered proof that on Capitol Hill, knowledge is power, when whispered into the right ears.
"I was the prime teacher here -- the one, if you will, who had to educate the chairman," said Mr. Primus, referring to his role last year in persuading his boss, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Ways and Means chairman, that the Republican plan for cutting the deficit could be portrayed as unfair.
At last year's drawn-out budget conference, Mr. Primus's bar charts seemed to be everywhere -- on the negotiating table at Andrews Air Force Base, in the newspapers, and in the craw of top Bush Administration officials, like the chief of staff, John H. Sununu, who favored deficit reduction proposals that hit more heavily on low-income groups.
Stirred by Mr. Primus's analyses, Congress spurned the summit plan and passed one that took much more of its bite from the wealthy.
"The thing that drove me up the wall is that the Republicans never put a plan on the table that called for the richest 1 percent to sacrifice," Mr. Primus said. "I thought to myself, 'If the American people ever knew.' Over time, that dribbled out, and it was not one of Mr. Sununu's better days."
Having left his fingerprints on $500 billion of deficit reduction, Mr. Primus this spring accepted a new job on a Ways and Means subcommittee that promises to put him in the middle of another national debate, the one on child poverty. The Subcommittee on Human Resources, led by Representative Thomas J. Downey, oversees the nation's welfare, child support and foster care program.
"I don't think there's any question that this man has made a pivotal difference in the way that Congress encounters tax and budget issues," said Mr. Downey, a Suffolk Democrat.
 
The Woodwork Type
 Stung by Mr. Primus's analyses, some Congressional Republicans have begun a counterattack. Several have asserted that Mr. Primus doctors the data to lay a case for bigger government and higher taxes. Others have cited different statistics to argue that Republican rule has helped rich and poor alike.
Among Mr. Primus's talents is a flair for invisibility, a useful quality in a world where aides are expected to remain colorless servants of their elected bosses. He works reporters but is never quoted.
Even his build is indistinct, round but not plump, with hair somewhere along a journey from brown to gray. A taciturn man of 44 years, Mr. Primus operates in English with none of the precision that he brings to his economic analysis, fuzzing out the ends of his sentences with the favorite phrase, "et cetera, et cetera."
For a man who seems at home in a pew, the partnership with Mr. Rostenkowski, a backroom politician of the old school, appears a puzzle. It points to another side of Mr. Primus: his desire to get things done.
 
Guiding the Leaders
 When he speaks of Mr. Rostenkowski, he can barely keep awe from his voice. "He's a leader in a way that I could never be," he said, referring to his boss's "body language" but growing flustered at the reference. "This is sensitive -- I mean, if anything could get me in trouble," he said.
At times like these, Mr. Primus sounds like the precocious teen-ager who tutored the high school football stars. Laughing at the analogy, he said, "I guess I'd like to be known as an educator on how to think about the issues."
The origins of Mr. Primus's views can be found in Eldora, Iowa, population 3,000, where as a child Mr. Primus watched his father work long hours for scant rewards.
"I grew up in a poor, working dairy farm environment," said Mr. Primus, putting equal emphasis on working and poor. "My Dad had to milk cows twice a day, for seven days a week."
Is his career, in part, an attempt to better reward laborers like his father? "That is a fair statement, yes," he said.
Among the chief influences on Mr. Primus's thinking has been the Christian Reformed Church, of which he has been a lifelong member. While emphasizing conservative social mores, Mr. Primus said, the church also stresses "that Jesus was very concerned about justice."
Though devoted to progressive taxes, Mr. Primus said he is not "a flaming liberal." He stresses the need for the poor to help themselves by working and taking care of their children. Divorced and remarried, he pays child support and bristles when other fathers do not. "I'm concerned about behavior," he said.
Mr. Primus grew up planning to follow in his father's farming footsteps. But he won a scholarship to Iowa State University, where he wound up with a doctorate in economics.
He earned a reputation as a data whiz in the mid-1970's while working as a consultant to the House Agriculture Committee during a fierce debate over food stamps. The success of his analyses earned him a permanent job on the Ways and Means Committee, where he rose to chief economist.
 
Fixation on Fairness
 Fairness had long been a concern -- some might say fixation. A 1984 hearing he organized on the tax burdens of the poor helped shape the landmark 1986 legislation that removed from the tax rolls more than four million low-income Americans. For the past several years, Mr. Primus has included data on income inequality in the Green Book, the influential compilation of social welfare statistics put out yearly by the Ways and Means panel, which he edits.
Predicting several years ago that Congress would make major changes to cut the deficit, he began to lay the groundwork to protect the poor when it happened. Working with Rick Kasten, an economist with the Congressional Budget Office, Mr. Primus helped devise a computer model that showed how any package of tax increases or spending cuts would affect rich and poor.
As each new proposal hit the table during negotiations last year at Andrews, Mr. Primus would phone in the data to Mr. Kasten. An hour later, the Andrews fax machine would start spewing charts and graphs showing the impact on rich and poor. Pointing to the figures, Democratic negotiators would rail at the Republicans.
Indeed, the fairness argument became so persuasive that junior House Democrats eventually voted down the agreement endorsed by their own leaders, largely because it did not go far enough to help the poor.
 
Noticeable Difference
 The behind-the-scenes influence of the Primus-Kasten team can be summarized with these numbers from the budget office:
The Administration's first proposal would have reduced the after-tax income of the poorest fifth of Americans by 1.4 percent; the one that passed gave them a 1.4 percent increase.
The first Administration plan would have given the richest 1 percent an increase in income of 1.4 percent; the one that passed took a 2.2 percent bite.
Despite Republican attacks, most academic experts have defended Mr. Primus's statistical methods.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, interprets the numbers differently. In an article in the summer issue of Policy Review, he argues that the incomes of the poor started to sag under President Jimmy Carter. Republican influence, he writes, can best be seen in post-1983 figures that show rising incomes for both rich and poor.
This spring, when Mr. Primus accepted his new job, the Congressional rumor mill buzzed with speculation that he was pushed from the full committee by colleagues jealous of his influence with Mr. Rostenkowski.
Mr. Primus downplays the tension with colleagues and says he wanted the new job, which gives him a staff and plunges him into a new debate. The subcommittee he joined is pushing a plan to raise taxes on the wealthiest Americans in order to give tax breaks to families with children.
Asked whether his new perch will give him unusual influence on child poverty issues, Mr. Primus, the formerly impoverished child, couldn't suppress a grin. "I'd like the world to think that, yeah," he said.

HEADLINE: A Smart Start in Haiti

 BODY:
The impossible keeps happening in Haiti. The long dictatorship, too entrenched to be ousted, is gone. The people too poor to care about a democracy have created one. And now the President too radical to avoid destructive confrontations has completed six solid months in office.
The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide once electrified audiences with his blasts at American neocolonialism and angry attacks on the lending policies of the International Monetary Fund. He excoriated military leaders for their complicity with the old regime. And he promised that if he were elected, he would propel a popular tidal wave of revolutionary change. 
 But since coming to office in February, President Aristide has modulated his style. He has developed a particularly warm relationship with U.S. Ambassador Alvin Adams. His Government has negotiated seriously with the I.M.F. for assistance. He has received crucial support from the armed forces. Most impressive of all, he has proved more willing than most of his predecessors to respect constitutional norms.
This moderation has provoked predictable grumbling from impatient voices on the left. As predictably, it hasn't dented the distrust of the right. Conservatives are probably correct in assuming that Father Aristide remains faithful to his revolutionary beliefs. For all his moderation, he has already brought substantial change.
He has started replacing corrupt and authoritarian officials with reformers and democrats, in the armed forces as well as in civilian administration. He has shifted rural police powers from military to civilian hands. And he has begun bringing to justice the thuggish leaders of the Tontons Macoute, the Duvalier family's private army.
President Aristide has made no visible progress in stimulating Haiti's long-depressed economy. In fact, some of his reforms, like trimming 5,000 unaffordable jobs from the public sector and demanding better treatment for Haitian migrant workers in the Dominican Republic, have increased unemployment, at least temporarily.
But the new President is betting that renewed flows of foreign aid and investment will bring revival over the longer term. That probably explains his willingness to consider policy compromises in exchange for an I.M.F. seal of approval. Realistically, he has no alternative. After years of looting by its elites, Haiti is today too poor to finance its own development.
Six months into his five-year term, only interim judgments are possible. But President Aristide is clearly off to a smart start.

HEADLINE: Katherine Dunham's Mission: Giving Children a Gift of Dance

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill.

 BODY:
The summer heat bears down on a scrubby lawn in East St. Louis, a small desolated city on the banks of the Mississippi River that has become a national symbol of poverty and despair.
But the air also throbs with excitement and pride as the young dancers of the Katherine Dunham Children's Workshop here expertly move through pieces in a wide variety of styles. Well-schooled, they dance with a rare expansiveness and joy. All are black and what the world calls disadvantaged. But each is a member of an elect group. Each is a dancer, moving across the makeshift stage of the workshop with an easy, gracious consciousness of self. 
 That has been the mission of Miss Dunham, whose vibrantly theatrical productions of traditional Caribbean, African and American choreography for the dance stage, Broadway and films turned her and her company into stars throughout the United States and Europe in the 1940's and 50's. It is a mission that has faltered in recent hard economic times. But now that mission has been embraced by a group of cultural, social and business leaders in bustling St. Louis, just across the river.
 
Of Plans and Money
 Under the leadership of Elizabeth Sayad, a public relations consultant, musician and writer, the group is working as a newly constituted board of directors to raise money to meet Miss Dunham's personal and professional needs and to support and strengthen her training programs. There are also plans to extend the programs to centers to be built in urban areas throughout the country.There are plans to raise money to preserve her influential technique and dances along with her collection of art and artifacts, housed in her handsome little Dynamic Museum, a few blocks from her home in East St. Louis.
"You can stick your head in the sand," said Kenneth H. Bitting Jr., a former Anheuser-Busch executive, who is the vice president of the Dunham board and a self-described cynic, as he spoke of the problems of that city. "And why not? It's a different state. Then you meet someone like Katherine Dunham."
Miss Dunham, who worked her way out of an impoverished, tumultuous childhood in the Midwest to become not only an internationally recognized dancer and choreographer but also an anthropolgist, writer and teacher, settled in East St. Louis in 1967, dividing her time between her small, neat house, school and museum and a home in Haiti. Her mission, urged on her by officials of the University of Illinois, was to imbue the angry, forsaken youngsters of East St. Louis with a sense of a larger, better world to which they could also have access.
 
'Culturally Heroic Society'
 "I was trying to steer them into something more constructive than genocide," the 82-year-old Miss Dunham said in a recent interview in St. Louis. "Everyone needs, if not a culture hero, a culturally heroic society. There is nothing stronger in a man than the need to grow."
She and an international staff taught languages and photography, anatomy and woodcarving, music, many forms of dance and even karate, which troubled some institutional sponsors of the school. "We told them we were only teaching the theory of martial arts," Miss Dunham said with her low, earthy laugh. "A very small lie. The martial arts were it for the young men. They loved that."
Faced with an influx of violent, confused young veterans of the Vietnam War, she took some to New York City to talk about violence with the psychologist Erich Fromm, a friend of hers. She watched as some of the children she worked with grew up to be public figures, including Reginald and Warrington Hudlin, the film makers, and Jackie Joyner-Kersee, the Olympic long jumper, and university graduates, doctors, teachers and performers.
But Miss Dunham's financial resources have dwindled drastically over the last decade. Most of the programs, which serve about 40 children, ages 4 to 16, have been cut and it has become hard to properly maintain the museum's holdings, which include artifacts, art and musical instruments of African, Caribbean and North American black traditional and modern society, paintings by Miss Dunham and exquisite costumes designed by John Pratt, her late husband, for the Dunham company.
 
Leading to a Board
 Admirers of Miss Dunham grew concerned. In 1989, after the success of a "Magic of Katherine Dunham" gala that opened the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's spring season in St. Louis, the dance presenter Adam Pinsker commissioned a study, paid with a Ford Foundation grant, that led to the formation of a board incorporated in St. Louis and East St. Louis in the spring of 1990.
A few friends and colleagues, chief among them Jeanelle Stover, Miss Dunham's longtime personal assistant and now a member of the board's executive committee, had struggled to help Miss Dunham continue her work.
Ms. Sayad, who studied dance with Miss Dunham in the early 1970's, said, "Katherine is beginning to understand that in order to accomplish her mission she has got to have a larger frame of reference." The 18 members of the new board represent "resources she just wouldn't have access to in East St. Louis," Ms. Sayad added.
The eighth annual Dunham Technique Seminar, which ended on Sunday at the Center of Contemporary Arts in University City in St. Louis, was preceded by a gala dinner and performance in early August that raised close to $35,000 to meet a matching grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.
At the gala, in one corner of the poolside party Miss Dunham greeted the guests who came over to her, often a little timidly, to shake her hand. Dark eyes glowing, she was both matter of fact and regal, submitting graciously to the cosseting of early Dunham dancers who had come to St. Louis to teach in the seminar.
There was an extra gentleness in Miss Dunham's voice as she gravely spoke of her conversations with her young goddaughter, Tikati, about the future of the earth. And she watched with affection as Vanoye Aikens, who had partnered her, charmed the crowd with his extravagant repartee as the master of ceremonies. "He lifted me, heavy or light, for about 30 years," she murmured.
The next morning, Mr. Aikens, Talley Beatty, Lucille Ellis and Tommy Gomez were teaching dancers, teachers and agile dance lovers from across the nation and abroad the fine points of the sensuous Dunham technique. In one studio, Mr. Aikens coaxed a jazz step he called the chocolate shake out of his students. In another, Mr. Gomez quietly analyzed the correct body placement of a Dunham dancer and spoke of a head movement associated with Uday Shankar, the Indian dancer.
Mr. Beatty's instructions were interspersed with anecdotes about Miss Madam Dunham, as he called her, delivered with wry detachment. And Miss Ellis drove her students to dance with space-gobbling abandon. Together again, the four spoke of their days with Miss Dunham with laughter and admiration.
"Dancers came into the company like mice and walked out as straight as cornstalks," said Miss Ellis, who teaches at her own studio in Chicago. "Miss D. taught people to be proud of themselves."
The company, which disbanded in 1962 after two decades of performing, wove its way through the United States refusing to perform for segregated audiences.
"We were with her when she broke the nightclub barriers in Chicago," Miss Ellis said. "That's all we did. We broke barriers all along. We didn't know that. We just wanted to work. We loved what we were doing. We survived because of love and pride."
Those days may be long gone, and the notion of a new Dunham company merely a cherished dream, but Miss Dunham is still surrounded by loyal colleagues. At the gala, a son of the Senegalese drummer Mor Thiam performed beside his genial father, whom Miss Dunham described as the Pied Piper who helped to draw children to the school over the years. Three of the four elegant, glowing dancers had been reared in East St. Louis and trained at the Dunham school. Miss Dunham watched them intently, drumming a soft rhythmic counterpoint on the table edge as they danced.
"It can be done," she said. "Don't tell me no."

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Bush Monitors 'Serious Situation' As U.S. Scrambles for Information

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Monday, Aug. 19

 BODY:
President Bush was caught by surprise today by reports of the ouster of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and was closely monitoring the "serious situation," a White House official said.
Mr. Bush was informed of the dramatic change by Brent Scowcroft, the White House national security adviser, who learned of the announcement through news reports. 
 "We are aware of the press reports concerning President Gorbachev," said Roman Popadiuk, a White House spokesman. "We have no details at this time."
"We are continuing to seek details," he said.
 
No Advance Notice
 Mr. Bush was given no advance notice that Gorbachev would be replaced, said several officials who themselves voiced shock at the development.
Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Bush met in Moscow two weeks ago for a summit meeting that saw the two superpowers agree to slash their long-range nuclear missile arsenals and endorse a new drive for a Middle East peace conference in October.
The signing of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty had been opposed by conservatives in the Soviet Union, but Administration officials were reluctant to interpret the abrupt change of power at the Kremlin.
"We really aren't sure what's happening at this point," said one official who acknowledged being stunned by the announcement carried by the official Tass news agency.
Another official said "we have no independent knowledge of what's going on" in Moscow.
The United States Embassy in Moscow was immediately directed to make urgent checks to clarify the situation, said one official, who added that it was not known how quickly a clear picture would emerge.
Mr. Bush has helped Mr. Gorbachev to move his country toward a market economy, using his trip to Moscow to announce that he would seek most-favored-nation trade status for the Soviet Union.
Under that trade status Moscow would be given the most beneficial tariff rates available for its goods sold in the United States.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Those Who Have Taken Leadership in the Kremlin

 BODY:

Gennadi Ivanovic Yanayev Vice President 
Appointed Vice President a year and a half ago by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. . . . Liberals and reformers in the Party said he was a committed member of the right wing. . , . But Mr. Yanayev calls himself "a Communist to the depths of my soul." . . . Born in Gorky region of Russia in 1937. . . . Graduated from the Gorky Agricultual Institute and the All-Union Law Institute. . . . Holds an advanced degree in history. . . . Rose through Soviet youth groups locally and nationally until he earned a place on the Politboro in 1990. . . . His rise to vice president disappointed reformers who had hoped for a more aggressive supporter. . . . Many saw him and Mr. Gorbachev as kindred spirits. . . . Initially an active proponent of perestroika, which caused some to say Mr. Gorbachev had found a yes man. . . . But he told the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, "I'm a normal guy, I assure you," and Mr. Gorbachev pleaded, "I want someone alongside me I can trust."
 
Vladimir A. Kryuchkov
Chairman, K.G.B.
 Accompanied Mikhail S. Gorbachev to Washington in December 1988 for a summit meeting with President Reagan, and thus startled both American experts and some in the Communist Party itself since it was one of the few times that a senior Soviet intelligence officer had accompanied a Soviet leader to the United States, and Mr. Kryuchkov leaped over several others in the party to achieve such a prominent and visible role. . . .Worried the Bush Administration last year by assailing Mr. Gorbachev's reforms as "blind radicalism," giving a firm indication that Mr. Gorbachev's position in power was anything but secure. . . .A hardliner, Mr. Kryuchkov joined the party in 1944. . . .As a young diplomat, was chosen as an assistant to Ambassador Yuri V. Andropov, who played an important role in the invasion of Hungary in 1956. When Mr. Andropov became director of the K.G.B. in 1967, Mr. Kryuchkov moved with him as a senior aide. . . .According to many American officials, he next served at the United Nations as the Soviet Union's senior spy, or "rezidant."
 
Valentin S. Pavlov
Prime Minister
 Appointed prime minister in January, follwing a term as Finance Minister. . . . In February he said Mr. Gorbachev's plan to order large ruble notes out of circulation was intended to foil a Western bankers' plot to topple the Government by cornering billions in rubles and destablizing the economy. . . . Had led the push in October 1969 to raise prices of beer, cigarettes and delicacies. . . . Defended the decision as necessary to pay for social benefits, including payments to rail workers, police officers and school teachers. . . . Not a popular move in a country of heavy smokers and drinkers.
 
Dmitri T. Yazov
Minister of Defense
 Appointed Defense Minister in May 1987, plucked by Mr. Gorbachev from his command of the Soviet army's Far Eastern strategic forces. . . . Typical of most Soviet appointments, he was not well known to Western analysts. . . . At 67, Mr. Yazov has already headed two of the Soviet Union's 16 military districts -- the Far East and Central Asia -- and has commanded Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia. . . . Mr. Gorbachev seemed to rely on his breadth of experience. . . . Most important, he had spent the years from 1977 to 1987 out of the country, which many analyists believed made him free of political entanglements at home.
 
Boris Karlovich Pugo
Minister of Internal Affairs

Rose to power as a party leader in Latvia for four years, beginning in 1984. . . . Joined the KGB in 1976, rising to head the Statet Security Committee of Latvia. . . . Occupied various party and Komsomol Communist Youth posts since 1961, including party boss of Riga, Latvia's capital.

HEADLINE: Hard Times at Auction Houses: Has the Art Market Hit Bottom?

 BODY:
In one week in May 1990, the Japanese industrialist Ryoel Saito paid $160 million for two paintings bought in New York: $82.5 million for van Gogh's "Portrait of Dr. Gachet" (1890) at Christie's and $78.1 million for Renoir's "At the Moulin de la Galette" (1876) at Sotheby's. This year, by comparison, the most expensive work auctioned was Degas's "Racehorses" (1870's), which was sold for $9.7 million in June to an unidentified buyer at Christie's in London.
 After five years of rapidly rising prices, the frenzied buying of art at auction is over. Sotheby's and Christie's have gone into reverse: the two aucton houses, the world's largest, announced record declines in total sales for the season, which ends on Aug. 31. Sotheby's is projecting a 59 percent decline in international sales, to $1.3 billion from a record $3.2 billion in 1990. Christie's worldwide sales are expected to fall 50 percent, to $1.2 billion from $2.4 billion. 
At both houses the sagging sales figures are attributed to the worldwide economic recession and the Persian Gulf war.
 
Contrasting Assessments
 Additional reasons are cited by knowledgeable auctiongoers, especially in the categories of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art, where the greatest declines occurred. At the top of the list is the retreat of the Japanese, who regularly toppled auction records for five years. This season, though, they stayed away as economic problems and financial scandals - some relating to art buying - spread to Tokyo. Throughout the year, Japanese dealers and collectors bid and bought infrequently.
 "The Japanese stockmarket peaked early last year and then came skating down," said Robert S. Salomon Jr., the chief investment officer of the asset management subsidiary of Salomon Brothers. "They certainly have money but they are feeling a lot poorer."
 The absence of Japanese buyers contributed to a decline in sales of artworks produced over the last century to one quarter of last season's volume. At Sotheby's, sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary works slid to $406 million from a record $1.6 billion, and at Christie's they declied to $325 million from $1.25 billion. Significantly, the figures at both houses dropped to levels last seen in the 1986-87 season, just before art prices took off.
 Despite the figures, Michael L. Ainslie, the president and chief executive officer of Sotheby's Holdings, the parent company of the auction house, expressed optimism. "I think we have seen the bottom of the market," he said. "I think we are going to see a gradual recovery. I don't think there will be a dramatic recovery until the leading economies of the world begin to show much more strength."
 Christopher Burge, the president of the downturn was no surprise. "We said right along it was going back to where it was in 1987," he said. 'My next prediction is you will see the present pattern holding for the next three or four years."
 Others, however, are not so sanguine.
 Allan Stone, a New York contemporary-art dealer, said: "We are in a market which is searching for its bottom. We're in tough times and we're going to be in tough times for four or five years."
 Thomas W. Weisel, the chairman of Montgomery Securities of San Francisco, and a contemporary-art collector, said buyers were having a variety of business problems. "It's going to be a long time before this area bottoms out,"he said. "Anytime you have a pendulum that has swung so far one way it takes time for it to swing back."
 Richard Gray, a Chicago art dealer, said: "The market is very, very soft. I went to London in June with the hope and expectation that we had bottomed out and might see an upturn. It did not happen. We've had some very good business, but it's been very, very slow.
 "I don't even think it's the fact that money is tight. People are not optimistic. By and large this market has always been supported by people who have money. I don't think that money has gone away. Most people are just scared."
 Donald B. Marron, the chairman of the Paine Webber Group and vice chairman of the Museum of Modern Art, attributed part of the decline in sales to the quality of artworks available. "We all know about the run-up in the art market and that certain marvelous pictures only came for sale because the market moved up so much," he said. "Right now there is a real dearth of absolutely first-class pictures."
 Meanwhile, the number of unsold artworks has increased drastically. In sales if Impressionist, modern and contemporary art this season as many as 40 to 50 percent of the artworks offerd did not sell compared with as few as 10 percent a year ago.
 There were however, some minor improvements in the sales of contemporary art in May in New York and in June in London.
 "In both sets of sales there was considerably more enthusiasm, more bidding and collecting activity in contemporary art," said David Nash, who heads Sotheby's fine art sales internationally. "This compres with the almost sluggish bidding for Impressionist paintings."
 Auction-house officials say that regardless of the period of the works, prices of important paintings from prominent collections that have not been for sale for many years will hold firm. The most important test of this will be at Christie's in New York on Nov. 5 and 12, when 50 artworks from the 20th-century collection of Burton G. and Emily Hall Tremaine, holdings that include paintings by Leger, Mondrian, Miro, Juan Gris, Georges Braque and Jasper Johns, are estimated by the house to bring $35 million.
 In collectibles, Christie's will offer two examples of one of the rarest United States postage stamps on Sept. 25: the 24 cent Jenny air mail stamps from 1918 with an upside-down airplane. Both are to be sold inblocks of four stamps and are from the same seller, Arthur J. Kobacker, a sho manufacturer of Columbus, Ohio. The presale estimates are at most $700,000 and $800,000 each.
 Sotheby's plans a number of smaller sales of property from prominent collections for October. On Oct. 13 Karl Lagerfeld is selling his 1980's made-in-Italy Memphis designs from his Riviera apartment at a sale in Monte Carlo, estimated to bring $255,000. And Oct. 4 the contents of William S. Paley's Fifth Avenue apartment - $2 million worth of 18th-century French furniture, tribal art, Oriental art and precious objects - are to be auctioned.
 Sotheby's is also auctioning property collected by major figures in the ballet world. The $2 million collection of Ruth Page, the doyenne of ballet in Chicago, is to be sold on Nov. 7 inNew York, and the paintings, letters, books, manuscripts and photographs of Diaghilev's personal secretary and friend, Boris Kochno, are to be auctioned in Monte Carlo on Oct. 11 and 12 in a sale that is estimated to total $2.5 million.
 Such auctions of decorative arts, jewelry, books and colelctibles are expected to fare well next season, as they have for the last year. Both Sotheby's and Christie's chalked up some impressive totals in auctions of everything other than fine arts - furniture, jewelry, books, collectibles and automobiles - although the totals were lower than the year before. At Sotheby's, theybrought $532 million compared with $827 million a year ago. At Christie's the total was $607 million, down from $714 million.
 
The Outlook
 Many questions remain. "We don't know yet to what level Impressionist, modern and contemporary paintings have come down," Mr. Burge said. "The market in its cyclical fashion has a steady run of years that show healthy normal increases. Then it begins an acceleration up to a peak. The sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art sales are around 20 percent of the market in the steady times and then accelerate up to 45 or 50 percent. We are now back to about 20 percent."
 Will the Americans and Europeans who collect for investment, who bought heavily at auction in the last five years and stopped this year, return to buying art?
 "I don't think so," Mr. Nash said. "They have to sell the things they paid too much for. Many of the changes seen over the last year are probably permanent.
 "The Japanese bubble money is gone from the market and I don't expect it to come back. There are however, many serious Japanese collectors, museums and Corporate buyers that werenot part of this phenomenon. They are keeping a low profile at this moment. Inevitably they will return."
 James Roundell, who heads Impressionist and modern art sales at Christie's in London, said: "I think it is a pretty uneven picture. Some high prices have been achieved, including the $9.7 million 'Racehorses.' But the peaks are fewer and farther between. Overall, we are still in a market that has a lot of problems. We are still trying to find a level for certain pictures where instead of bidders going to a certain level, we have no bidding at all."
 Mr. Salomon's view is less bleak. "People have always wanted to be able to demonstrate their success or their presumed successes in business by buying art," he said. "The stock market is close to the record highest level. Presumably there are people who have made enormous sums who may become the next group of art buyers."
 But before that happens, Allan Stone said, "I think the art market is going to be left for the people who really like art again. All the speculators have gone home."
 "Unfortunately," he added, "you hope the cure isn't going to kill the patient."
