HEADLINE: Careers;
When You Can't Get In Front Door

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
WITH graduating seniors still having a tough time searching for jobs, their job-seeking techniques are changing.
It is back to the old days of using contacts for all they are worth, said Lee J. Svete, college placement director of St. Lawrence University, in Canton, N.Y. "About 66 to 70 percent of those who do find jobs have been finding employment this year through contacts with alumni, parents, friends and others, compared to only half the class relying on contacts a year ago," he said. "If you cannot go in the front door you go through a side door." 
 He estimates that about half the class at St. Lawrence have found jobs, in many cases perhaps not what they want, and thinks 30 percent will go to graduate school within a year, based on last year's statistics.
Internships have given a haven to about 15 percent of the 500 seniors, which he calls a "unique statistic" because in previous years only about 2 percent of the graduating class took internships. The theory is that internships sometimes result in permanent jobs and that in any case they offer experience and look good on a resume.
Mr. Svete said the average job search for a graduate was taking much longer, perhaps six months now, compared with three months or so last year.
Another placement director, Vicki B. Lynn of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., reports that in past years she has had good luck in helping graduating seniors find good jobs with good companies. Most are engineers or computer science majors, who are usually in demand. But she has not been as lucky in 1991.
"This has been the worst year in the last 20," she said last week. "I went through the recession of 1982-83 and that was not as bad as this year."
Of R.P.I.'s senior class of 700, she said, 35 percent have jobs, compared with 46 percent a year ago. About 30 percent are still looking, compared with 25 percent last year, she added.
Graduate school is a handy alternative for those who can afford it. About 25 percent are headed there, compared with 14 percent last year, she said.
Of the remaining graduates, 10 percent are taking another semester of courses, hoping the job market will improve in the meantime.
With many companies shrinking, Mrs. Lynn wonders why they do not take in more interns. "You would think companies would be recruiting for interns," she said. "It gives them a short look at an individual at low cost."
She recently asked several companies about this, and the replies basically were, "Our managers are too stressed to hire interns, who need a lot of supervision."
Job cuts have reduced staffs sharply, increasing the responsibilities of managers. And in many cases they must worry about the loss of their own jobs.
Mrs. Lynn has noticed a new corporate approach to the job market -- contract hiring. "A company asked me for resumes of six students who were computer science majors willing to work for six months on a project for a major electronics firm," Mrs. Lynn said. The students are being paid at the rate of $30,000 a year, she added.
She is encouraging students to take such contract jobs because they offer experience. "Students can say, 'Hey, I got a shot at a major electronics firm even though times are tough,' " she said. "It certainly is better than slinging hamburgers while waiting for the job market to improve."
Mrs. Lynn calls contracting a trend because she expects such jobs to be offered more and more by companies that want to save on pensions and other benefits.
Another answer to the insecurity of the current job market, she said, is an approach now used by Northern Telecom, a major Canadian company: It offers three-year contracts to its recruits.
As might be expected, recruiting by Wall Street firms has declined, but she noted that J. P. Morgan hired R.P.I. students this year, as did Goldman, Sachs, the First Boston Corporation, and Chemical Bank.
One strategy that companies are using in these bad times, Mrs. Lynn said, is to decentralize recruiting, letting plant managers do the hiring. She named companies like General Dynamics and Hughes Aircraft as examples.
Campus recruiting is down sharply. She said: "We had 353 companies recruiting on campus for the 1990-1991 year and 34 percent made no offers. That compares with 422 companies that recruited in 1989-1990, of which 27 percent made no offers."

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
More State Curbs On Insurer Rates

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
A SMALL but growing number of states are cracking down on health insurers that aggressively reduce premiums to attract small businesses with young, healthy employees, and raise rates to discourage employers with potentially high medical costs. Critics say that such practices make access to health care unaffordable for those who need it most, adding to more than 34 million Americans already without insurance.
Vermont and Oregon enacted sweeping laws this year that require all insurers to spread risks evenly among small businesses by offering uniform community rates, regardless of the health status of employees. Bob Opel, a vice president with Blue Cross in Vermont, said the new law prohibited setting rates based on medical or demographic criteria. 
 But many insurers contend that even more people would have to give up their coverage if community rating was compulsory. They say that premiums would go up for young workers who are considered good risks, and many would drop out. "It is not unusual to have a spread in rates of 1,000 percent between groups," said Greg Scandlen, publisher of Health Benefits Letter, which is based in Alexandria, Va. "Obviously those at the bottom would pay more."
Similar legislation is also being considered in New York, California, Maine and Minnesota, where the Governor recently vetoed a wide-ranging health-access bill that included community rating.
The debate heated up in New York this summer when the state's largest insurer, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, applied for rate increases and the elimination of longstanding community rating for 350,000 employees of small businesses. Empire argued that it had to tie small-group rates to the employees' health status because it had lost several hundred thousand of its healthiest customers to commercial insurers offering lower rates. And Empire said it was losing money on the remaining small-group customers.
Michael Dowling, a senior health policy adviser to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, said Empire's rate request "underscores the necessity of moving forward with some kind of community rating" law. He added that the Governor's aides were discussing the Empire proposals with the Insurance Superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale, whose approval is required for Blue Cross increases. Commercial insurers strongly opposed a Cuomo community rating bill earlier this year, and it did not reach a vote. But Mr. Dowling said there would be "a major push" to get the bill enacted.
Chris Petersen, a senior counsel with the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group, said that before passing a new law, the New York Legislature should wait to see the results of new Insurance Department regulations, which limit rate increases based on health status for small groups. "A lot of the abuses that the Blues complain about have been addressed," he said.
Eleven states enacted less sweeping laws on small-group insurance this year. They limit the difference betweeen the premiums that may be charged to small businesses considered poor risks and those charged to younger, healthier customers. The new laws -- in Arkansas, Delaware, Florida, Iowa, Nebraska, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, South Carolina, South Dakota and West Virginia -- generally follow recommendations adopted in December, with industry support, by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, a group of state officials.
There are mixed views about community rating among the 73 Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations across the country. Their roots go back to the Great Depression, when hospitals organized Blue Cross associations to help hard-up patients pay their bills. But by the competitive 1980's, most Blue Cross plans had dropped community rating and become more like commercial insurers. They see little merit in going back to the old ways.
"A quick transition back to community rating would cause disruptions," said Gretchen Babcock, executive director of state services with the national Blue Cross association. She said most Blue Cross plans still "tend to have higher-risk enrollees" than commercial insurers, making it harder to compete under community rating.
The community rating concept survives in places where Blue Cross still dominates the market, notably in New York, Pennsylvania and Michigan. In return, Empire Blue Cross, for example, receives a 13 percent discount on hospital bills, and state tax concessions on premiums. But Empire executives said that its edge had been eroded as health care had increasingly shifted out of hospitals, and commercial insurers also got discounts, for prompt payment of hospital bills.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
State of Emergency Committee's Statement: 'A Mortal Danger Has Come'

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement to the Soviet people issued today by the State Committee for the State of Emergency in the U.S.S.R., as provided by Tass:
Compatriots, citizens of the Soviet Union, we are addressing you at the grave, critical hour for the destinies of Motherland and our peoples. A mortal danger has come to loom large over our great Motherland. 
 The policy of reforms, launched at Mikhail S. Gorbachev's initiative and designed as a means to insure the country's dynamic development and the democratization of social life has entered for several reasons a blind alley.
Lack of faith, apathy and despair have replaced the original enthusiasm and hopes.
Authorities at all levels have lost the population's trust. Politicking has replaced in public life concern for the fate of Motherland and the citizen.
 
Now Ungovernable
 Malicious outrage against all state institutes is being imposed. The country has in fact become ungovernable.
Having taken advantage of the granted liberties and encroaching upon the first sprouts of democracy, there have emerged extremist forces that have embarked on the course toward liquidating the Soviet Union, ruining the state and seizing power at any cost.
The results of the nationwide referendum on Motherland's unity have been trampled upon.
Cynical speculations on national feelings are merely a smokescreen to satisfy ambitions.
Neither today's misfortunes of their peoples, nor their tomorrow, worry political adventurists. In creating an atmosphere of moral and political terror and seeking to hide behind the shield of popular trust, they forget that the relations they condemn and disrupt were established on the basis of far broader popular support, which, besides, has passed the centuries-long test of history.
 
Inter-Ethnic Conflicts
 Today, those who are in fact working toward the overthrow of the constitutional system should be brought to account before mothers and fathers for the death of the hundreds of victims of inter-ethnic conflicts.
The fate of more than half a million refugees is on their conscience. They are to blame for the loss of tranquillity and the joy of living of tens of millions of Soviet people who only yesterday lived in a united family but today found themselves living as outcasts in their own home.
People should decide what social system should exist, but attempts are being made to deprive them of this right.
Instead of showing concern for the security and well-being of every citizen and all society, persons that have come to positions of power not infrequently use it for interests alien to the people, as a means for unscrupulous self-assertion.
Torrents of words and piles of declarations and promises only underline the scanty and meager nature of their practical deeds. The inflation of authority is destroying our state and society in a more frightening way than any other.
 
Increasing Uncertainty
 Every citizen is feeling increasing uncertainty about tomorrow and deep concern about the future of his or her children.
The power crisis has had catastrophic effects on the economy. The chaotic, spontaneous slide toward a market provoked an explosion of egoism -- regional, departmental, group and personal.
The war of laws and encouragement of centrifugal tendencies spelled destruction of the integral national economic mechanism that has been shaping for decades. The result includes sharp drops in the living standards of the vast majority of the Soviet people, and the blossoming of profiteering and the shadow economy.
It is high time people were told the truth: If urgent and decisive measures are not adopted to stabilize the economy, hunger and another spiral of impoverishment are imminent in the near future, from which it is just a step from mass manifestations of spontaneous discontent with devastating consequences.
Only irresponsible people can bank on some aid from abroad. No handouts can solve our problems; our rescue is in our own hands.
 
Real Contributions
 The time has come to measure the authority of every person and organization by their real contributions to the rehabilitation and development of the national economy.
For long years, we have heard incantations from all sides about the commitment to the interests of an individual and concern for individual rights and social security. In fact, man has found himself humiliated and desperate, his real rights and possibilities infringed upon.
All democratic institutions created by the popular will are losing weight and effectiveness right in front of our eyes. This is a result of purposeful actions by those who, grossly violating the fundamental law of the U.S.S.R., are effectively in the process of staging an anti-constitutional coup and striving for unbridled personal dictatorial powers. Prefectures, mayoralties and other illegal structures are increasingly replacing, de facto, popularly elected governing councils.
An offensive is under way on the rights of working people. The rights to work, education, health, housing and leisure are in jeopardy.
Even the elementary personal security of people is increasingly under threat. Crime is fast on the increase, getting organized and politicized. The country is sinking into the quagmire of violence and lawlessness.
 
Sex and Violence
 Never before in national history has the propaganda of sex and violence assumed such a scale, threatening the health and lives of future generations. Millions of people are demanding measures against the octopus of crime and glaring immorality.
The increasing destabilization of the political and economic situation in the Soviet Union is undercutting our positions in the world. Revanchist notes are to be heard in some places and demands are being made for a review of our borders. Voices can even be heard speaking of dismembering the Soviet Union and of the possibility of establishing international guardianship over individual facilities and regions of the country.
Such is the bitter reality. Whereas only yesterday a Soviet person finding himself abroad felt himself a worthy citizen of an influential and respected state, now he is often a second-rate foreigner, the attitude to whom is marked by either contempt or sympathy.
The pride and honor of the Soviet people must be restored in full.
The State Committee for the State of Emergency in the U.S.S.R. is fully aware of the depth of the crisis that has afflicted the country, it takes upon itself the responsibility for the fate of the country and is fully determined to take most serious measures to take the state and society out of the crisis as soon as possible.
We promise to hold a nationwide discussion of the draft new union treaty. Each individual will have the right and opportunity to think over this major act and define his attitude toward it because the fate of numerous peoples of our great Motherland will depend on what the Soviet Union will be like.
 
Law and Order
 We intend to restore law and order straight away, end bloodshed, declare a war without mercy to the criminal world, eradicate shameful phenomena discrediting our society and degrading Soviet citizens. We shall clean the streets of our cities from criminal elements and put an end to arbitrariness of the squanderers of the national wealth.
We favor genuine democratic processes, a consistent reform policy leading to the renewal of our Motherland, its economic and social prosperity, which will enable it to take a worthy place in the world community of nations.
The country's development must not be built upon the declining standards of living of the people. A consistent rise in the living standards of all citizens will become the norm in a healthy society, without reducing care for strengthening and protecting the interests of the widest layers of the population, those who are the hardest hit by inflation, production disorganization, corruption and crime.
Developing the many-tier character of the national economy, we shall support private enterprise, granting it necessary opportunities for the development of production and services.
Our prime concern is the solution of the food and housing problems. All available forces will be mobilized to meet these, the most essential needs of the people.
We are calling upon workers, peasants, working intelligentsia, all Soviet people to restore, within the briefest period of time, labor discipline and order, raise the level of production in order to resolutely march ahead. Our life and the future of our children and grandchildren, the fate of the Motherland depend on this.
We are a peace-loving country and shall undeviatingly honor all our commitments. We have no claims to make against anybody. We want to live in peace and friendship with all. But we firmly declare that no one will be ever allowed to encroach upon our sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity. All attempts to talk the language of Diktat to our country, no matter where they may come from, will be resolutely suppressed.
 
Patriotic Feelings
 Our multinational people have lived for centuries, proud of their Motherland. We have never been ashamed of our patriotic feelings and we hold it natural and rightful to raise the present and future generations of citizens of this great power in this spirit.
To remain inactive at this hour of crisis for the fate of the Motherland means to take upon oneself the heavy responsibility for the tragic, truly unpredictable consequences. Each individual who holds our Motherland dear, who wants to live and work in peace and confidence, who does not acquiesce to the continuation of the bloody inter-ethnic conflicts, who sees his Motherland independent and prospering in the future must make the only right choice. We call on all true patriots, people of good will, to put an end to the present time of uncertainty.
We call on all citizens of the Soviet Union to grow aware of their duty before the country and render all possible assistance to the State Committee for the State of Emergency in the U.S.S.R. and efforts to pull the country out of the crisis.
Constructive proposals from socio-political organizations, work collectives and individuals will be appreciated as the show of their patriotic readiness to actively participate in the restoration of the century-old friendship in the single family of fraternal peoples and the revival of the Motherland.
 
The State Committee
for the State of Emergency
in the U.S.S.R.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Yeltsin's Remarks: A 'Reactionary Coup'

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks made in Moscow today by Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian federated republic, as translated by the State Department:
I am reading. 
 Citizens of Russia: On the night of 18-19 August 1991, the legally elected President of the country was removed from power.
Regardless of the reasons given for his removal, we are dealing with a rightist, reactionary, anti-constitutional coup. Despite all the difficulties and severe trials being experienced by the people, the democratic process in the country is acquiring an increasingly broad sweep and an irreversible character.
The peoples of Russia are becoming masters of their destiny. The uncontrolled powers of unconstitutional organs have been considerably limited, and this includes party organs.
The leadership of Russia has adopted a resolute position toward the union treaty striving for the unity of the Soviet Union and unity of Russia. Our position on this issue permitted a considerable acceleration of the preparation of this treaty, to coordinate it with all the republics and to determine the date of signing as Aug 20. Tomorrow's signing has been cancelled.
These developments gave rise to angry reactionary forces, pushed them to irresponsible and adventurist attempts to solve the most complicated political and economic problems by methods of force. Attempts to realize a coup have been tried earlier.
 
Citizens' Rebuff Urged
 We considered and consider that such methods of force are unacceptable. They discredit the union in the eyes of the whole world, undermine our prestige in the world community, and return us to the cold-war era along with the Soviet Union's isolation in the world community. All of this forces us to proclaim that the so-called committee's ascendancy to power is unlawful.
Accordingly we proclaim all decisions and instructions of this committee to be unlawful.
We are confident that the organs of local power will unswervingly adhere to constitutional laws and decrees of the President of Russia.
We appeal to citizens of Russia to give a fitting rebuff to the putschists and demand a return of the country to normal constitutional development.
Undoubtedly it is essential to give the country's President, Gorbachev, an opportunity to address the people. Today he has been blockaded. I have been denied communications with him. We demand an immediate convocation of an extraordinary Congress of People's Deputies of the Union. We are absolutely confident that our countrymen will not permit the sanctioning of the tyranny and lawlessness of the putschists, who have lost all shame and conscience. We address an appeal to servicemen to manifest lofty civic duty and not take part in the reactionary coup.
Until these demands are met, we appeal for a universal unlimited strike.

HEADLINE: At Kemper, No Defaults But Lots of Skepticism

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Among the nation's major insurance companies, the Kemper Corporation would appear to be an exception in this real estate recession: virtually none of its $1.97 billion in commercial real estate mortgages and real estate joint ventures are in default. Or so it seems from its financial filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
But over the last few months, insurance ratings agencies and stock market investors have become increasingly skeptical of Kemper's real estate portfolio. In particular they have questioned whether the insurer is hiding losses in its joint-venture mortgages, in which Kemper lends money to partnerships it is a part of. 
 Their conclusions so far make Kemper's record look very different from what can be learned simply from looking at Kemper's reports to the S.E.C.
What worries analysts and investors is Kemper's joint-venture mortgages and the more than $110 million in "equity loans" that Kemper has put into propping them up. A close examination of some of these projects in Illinois shows that the company suffered paper losses on some of its investments and continued, as late as last year, to tie up hundreds of millions of dollars in property ventures with little or no cash return.
Kemper's real estate joint ventures have prompted the company to spend hundreds of millions of dollars on development deals at a time when the commercial property market in Chicago is still severely depressed and the residential market is weak. Some of these deals have provided tens of millions of dollars in fees to developers but little or no immediate cash return for Kemper.
Despite a series of unprofitable joint ventures, the partners have until recently continued to bring new deals to Kemper in which the insurer paid them fees for everything from structuring the deals to managing the development, doing the construction, leasing the property and later running the project. These partners put in little or no money up front but got substantial chunks of equity in addition to the fees.
Kemper is also saddled with loans covering more than 3,000 acres of raw land in Illinois that it hopes to develop. Strangely, the insurer lent more than $75 million to partners to acquire some of these parcels before they were even zoned for development. Much of this land was zoned for farming when the loans were made, and the value of farmland in Illinois has since fallen.
Richard S. Curto, the senior vice president of real estate investments for Kemper Financial Services Inc., another unit of the Kemper Corporation, emphasized that Kemper had chosen a few good developers with which to do joint ventures and create long-term investment value for Kemper shareholders.
"The joint-venture program is working very well to provide the shareholders with hidden assets," Mr. Curto said, explaining that over the long run the value of the investments would increase and that the company could wait.
The Kemper Corporation is a huge, diversified insurance and financial services company with nearly $14 billion in assets, of which the real estate portfolio represents about 21 percent of the consolidated corporation's invested assets and 23 percent of the combined invested assets of the company's two life insurance units. The life insurance industry as a whole has about 24 percent of its assets in real estate.
As of March 31, Kemper had $1.34 billion in joint-venture mortgages. On most of those mortgages interest accrues, but the partnerships do not make cash interest payments to Kemper.
Kemper also had about $503 million in traditional third-party commercial mortgages, and $110 million in what the company calls "equity loans." In addition, Kemper has at least $600 million in commitments to real estate ventures that it has not yet financed.
 
Potential for Defaults Admitted
 Mr. Curto and Steven Timbers, Kemper's chief investment officer, both emphasized that Kemper was large and liquid enough to take these risks on property developments. Mr. Curto reluctantly acknowledged recently that as time passed, some loans might have to be restructured and there was the potential for defaults.
Several analysts have taken comfort in the fact that Kemper's "equity loans" category did not expand rapidly last year and in the first quarter of this year. But Kemper's real estate executives have turned debt investments in some partners' projects into equity positions in those projects, which can also serve to mask problems. Through depreciation, Kemper has substantially reduced the equity investments that show up on its books.
Kemper told analysts last week that as of June it had accumulated losses of $71.3 million on its $57 million of equity real estate investments.
 
Not 'a Traditional Portfolio'
 "One of the reasons that you do not have delinquencies and problems reported is that you don't have a traditional portfolio," said Michael W. Blumstein, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. "When a joint venture isn't quite making it, they make an equity loan to the joint venture, and that's why there is the question about how much they are propping up these joint ventures."
The ratings agencies have expressed similar concerns and have moved twice in recent weeks to downgrade the rating of Kemper Investors Life Insurance Company, known as Kilico.
In the Chicago area, Kemper has three developers with which it has done most of its recent development deals: Walsh Higgins & Company, the Prime Group Inc. and LaSalle Partners.
 
Downtown Chicago Project
 Take, for example, an unfinished office building in downtown Chicago. The building, designed by Ricardo Bofill is a 1.1-million-square-foot joint venture at 77 West Wacker Drive, on the Chicago River. Kemper's partner in the project is the Prime Group, a 10-year-old company headed by Michael W. Reschke, a fast-rising Chicago lawyer who had never built a downtown office building before the Kemper project.
Mr. Curto said that Kemper decided to go ahead with the project in 1989, although the percentage of vacant commercial office space was about 15 percent, an unhealthy level. The partnership broke ground in 1990, and the downtown Chicago vacancy is now about 20 percent, according to the Chicago office of Julien J. Studley Inc., a national brokerage company.
In financing developments, Kemper and its partners usually approach commercial banks to secure construction money, and Kemper guarantees the long-term mortgage.
In the case of 77 West Wacker Drive, four Japanese lenders, the Suisse Bank Corporation and the Bank of Montreal provided a $230 million, seven-year construction loan last March. Kemper also put in a big chunk of equity money that got the construction started, as much as $70 million, some Chicago executives say. Mr. Curto called the contribution substantial but declined to give the exact number.
Kemper will have to keep paying the monthly interest costs on the $230 million even if office rents from the building do not cover the payments. If payments lapse, Kemper would lose its initial equity investment.
Mr. Curto predicted that the partnership would see a 9 1/2 percent return on the building by 1996, but he expects that over the next five years there would be virtually no return on the millions invested in the building and that Kemper would have to finance any shortfalls.
That 9 1/2 percent forecast may be optimistic. Kemper and its partner signed various leases with tenants for most of the space in the building, which after concessions and other special costs average about $10 or $11 a square foot. The building cost at least $250 a square foot to build and lease.
R. R. Donnelly & Company, the country's largest commercial printing company, signed a 15-year lease for 200,000 square feet of space -- 10 floors -- in the building. But to close the deal, Kemper purchased about $14 million in raw land from Donnelly, agreed to pay about $52 a foot for interior work for Donnelly offices, promised to move the company and granted it almost four years' free rent. It is unclear whether the land purchase was done as a separate deal.
The result: The Kemper partnership gets a net effective rent of about $8 a square foot from the lease.
The $250 to $300 a square foot Kemper spent on the space Donnelly will take will thus yield about 2 to 3 percent. Treasury bills, which do not appreciate but are much safer, yield more than double that. Of course, if the property market rebounds and the building can be sold later for a substantial gain, the yield will be higher.
Other tenants fared about as well. Keck Mahin & Cate, a law firm, was lured away from the Sears Tower with a 20-year lease, a year of free rent for 200,000 square feet, $6 million for buying out the remainder of their old lease and more than $60 a square foot in tenant improvements. The bottom line for Kemper: about $12 a square foot.
In deals like this and in others in the suburbs of Chicago, Kemper's partners put up little or no cash for their equity ownership in the projects. If the projects do poorly, as other Illinois deals have, Kemper's partners are still ahead if their equity interests erode and the insurer has to lend more money to the project, because the partners still collect big fees without facing capital calls.
LaSalle Partners, which sold the raw land to Donnelly for about half the price at which Donnelly then sold it to Kemper, made big fees even though it was not an equity partner in that deal. In that case, LaSalle collected several million dollars in leasing commissions for bringing Donnelly to Kemper, LaSalle's development partner in another deal.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS: WHAT BUSH IS FACING;
Prospects for a 'New World Order' Are Precarious, and Critics Line Up

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The edifice of hope that George Bush has spent much of his Presidency building may not come crashing down as a result of the epochal events in Moscow today. But it will probably be much harder to maintain, because the Soviet Union no longer seems a ready or reliable partner.
To some extent Mikhail S. Gorbachev had cooperated with the United States to create a new world order, on issues ranging from the Gulf War to arms control, because his country was weak and he thought he had no other choice. In that sense, little has changed with his ouster; the Soviet Union is now weaker and more vulnerable to internal disruption than it was two weeks ago, and the United States is therefore proportionately stronger. That reality was reflected in the flight to the dollar around the world. 
 But the new Soviet leadership is likely to play a weak hand differently, a senior Administration official said, "and that means things will be harder to achieve -- in the Middle East, at the United Nations, in central Europe."
 
Suddenly an Observer
 Then there is the politics of the thing, with an election year approaching.
The departure of Mr. Gorbachev has clearly left Mr. Bush and his main allies with little influence over events in the Soviet Union. Charles William Maynes, the editor of Foreign Policy magazine, said "we have been pushed to the sidelines, reduced to the status of observers, because we didn't help Gorbachev and the reformers as vigorously as we should have and could have done."
Early in his administration, the President seemed reluctant to make a commitment to the Soviet leader, and such officials as Defense Secretary Dick Cheney regularly predicted Mr. Gorbachev's downfall. Then came the Persian Gulf War and successful summit conferences, and with them what Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat, called "something approaching a real partnership."
Even so, Washington fought shy of large-scale economic aid and opposed giving Moscow full membership in international financial institutions, as advocated by the major European powers, especially Germany. That prompted behind-the-scenes clashes at the summit conference in London last month, when Mr. Gorbachev pleaded in vain for more help in rebuilding his collapsing economy.
 
Critics on Both Sides
 Mr. Bush will no doubt be criticized by conservative elements in his party for having tied American interests too closely to Mr. Gorbachev's fate; Frank Gaffney, the former Pentagon official who monitored arms proliferation in the Reagan administration, accused Mr. Bush as well as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d of having been "too enthralled" with the Soviet leader to see what was happening. Critics on the left, like Mr. Maynes, will say he missed his big chance to change the strategic balance forever.
But the President moved quickly to minimize any domestic political damage by emphasizing his support for Boris Yeltsin, the most important remaining reformer, and picturing himself as a champion of democracy, regardless of who holds power in the Kremlin. The White House was quick to note that Mr. Bush had received Mr. Yeltsin at the White House and had talked with him in Moscow.
"Our national interests have not been damaged, in a global sense, no matter how sad we may be because brave people in Russia and the Baltics are going to suffer," said Senator Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana. "More clearly today than on some other days, you can see that the locus of world authority remains with the United States, and George Bush remains the key leader."
Among many politicians in Washington, there was a powerful sense that, barring a political miracle, a figure of historic dimensions -- someone who may stand alongside Churchill and Roosevelt in the 20th-century pantheon -- had left the world stage. And there were appeals for measures to deny those who toppled him any means to solve the problems he could not.
Mr. Nunn, for example, said President Bush and other leaders should repeat every day the assertion that the new Government was "illegitimate," should refuse to recognize it, should permit no high-level visits, should discourage American companies from further investments in the Soviet Union and should put all economic-aid programs "on hold," as Mr. Bush said he planned to do.
Neither the trade treaty, which would give preferred status to the Soviet Union, nor the treaty covering conventional forces in Europe is likely to be ratified by the Senate this fall, as had seemed certain only last week. An additional $900 million in grain credits, due in October and in February of next year, are not likely to be forthcoming, said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican minority leader.
Most strategic analysts agreed that the cold war wasn't about to be reborn and argued that Soviet military expansionism was not likely to be revived. Rozanne Ridgway, a former assistant secretary of state for European affairs, said the division of Europe, Germany and Berlin were issues that had been solved once and for all, eliminating one of the main causes of that 40-year struggle. The Cold War was also about a competition of ideologies, and Communism has little appeal left, except for Soviet and Cuban hard-liners.
 
Impact on the Middle East
 But the Soviet leadership may be less cooperative in the Middle East, since some of the major backers of today's coup think Mr. Gorbachev too readily abandoned traditional allies in the region, like Syria and Iraq. And given the new order in Moscow, the United States may be reluctant to have Moscow as co-sponsor of a peace conference.
Any further arms-control negotiations, about which the United States already had substantial doubts, are probably out of the question for now. At the United Nations, the Soviet Union will probably be much more inclined than under Mr. Gorbachev to use its veto, one Western ambassador there predicted.
Most ominously, in the view of Administration officials and the Germans as well, the coup has caught the process of Soviet military withdrawal from central Europe in midstream. Almost 250,000 Soviet troops remain in reunified Germany.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Plunge in Rush to Buy Bills

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev's stunning ouster as president of the Soviet Union sent investors from around the world running for the safe, secure haven of Treasury securities yesterday.
As often occurs at times of crisis, short-term Treasury bills were the investment of choice, and interest rates fell sharply. Three-month bill rates fell well below 5 percent for a while yesterday, the first time they have been below that level since after the stock market crash in October 1987. Meanwhile, bond yields dropped below 8 percent for a time, at one point falling as low as 7.92 percent, their lowest of the year. 
 Traders said that profit taking began to emerge once it became clear that stock prices, which plummeted early in the day, had stabilized and were on the rebound.
 
'Things Have Quieted Down'
 "When the stock market stabilized and started to improve, there was heavy retail selling of everything from bills to bonds," one government bond trader said. "After a chaotic morning, things have quieted down a lot."
The movement into Treasury issues on such a tumultuous day seemed to serve as a counterpoint to the recent misdeeds at Salomon Brothers, acts that prompted some critics to question whether the giant firm's transgressions had compromised the market's integrity.
"If you recognize that the Government market is the highest-quality market, I don't think what happened at Salomon Brothers affects investment decisions that much," said Rao Chalansani, chief investment strategist at the Kemper Securities Group in Chicago. "The government market is much too big to be influenced by one party."
Traders said the sharp downward move in short-term bill rates yesterday made bidding difficult at yesterday's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills. But the auction results were about as anticipated, the traders said, and demand for the new securities was good.
 
Restrictions on Salomon
 As mandated by the Government on Sunday, Salomon Brothers was prevented from placing bids for clients at the bill auctions.
At the auctions, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.17 percent, down sharply from an average rate of 5.30 percent at last week's sale. It is the lowest rate on a three-month bill since the sale on Oct. 26, 1987, when three-month bills were sold at an average rate of 5.12 percent.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.23 percent, down from an average rate of 5.39 percent a week ago. The new rate is the lowest since Oct. 27, 1986, when six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 5.23 percent.
The unsettled situation in the Soviet Union increases the odds that short-term rates will fall further, analysts said.
Some added that the turmoil could be yet another reason why the Federal Reserve Board at its policy-making meeting today might decide to lower its target on the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market as well as its discount rate.
"The Soviet situation clearly creates uncertainty, both among consumers and businesses," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International. "When that happens, people tend to postpone decisions. To me the coup raises the possibility that the Fed might lower both the funds rate and the discount rate."
 
Money Flowing to U.S.
 Aside from being a mild negative for the American economy, a development that would favor lower interest rates, analysts said the Soviet situation would almost certainly induce some money invested in Europe to flow to dollar-denominated assets like fixed-income securities.
"International capital flows into the United States should heighten," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities. "Everything augurs for a firm bid on the bond, as well as the dollar."
After moving to new highs early in the session, bond prices ended lower on the day.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 7/32, down 1/4 point, to yield 8.10 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 10/32, down 2/32, to yield 7.82 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 1/4, up 1/8 point, to yield 6.18 percent.
In the secondary market for short-term Treasury bills, three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 5.08 percent, down 14 basis points, or 14-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 9 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.09 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Florida Power and Light Company, a unit of the FPL Group, offered $150 million worth of 30-year first-mortgage bonds through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 1/8 percent securities were priced at 99, to yield 9.223 percent, 1.12 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are nonrefundable for five years, are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In conjunction with its taxable offering, Florida Power and Light also offered $51.9 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds at various prices through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. These securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices of most issues were little changed in quiet trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: Our Towns

BYLINE: By Wayne King

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J.

 BODY:
Nicole Colon is 40 years old, and a woman of considerable authority, but when it comes to things like going to the park, she knows who is boss: her granddaughter, Migdalia Melendez, who is bright, chubby and 2 1/2.
"I don't bring her, she brings me," said Mrs. Colon. "I got custody of her. Or maybe she got custody of me." 
 Mrs. Colon and Migdalia come to the park every day to gain surcease from the stifling heat of their apartment in the adjoining housing project and to stay off the mean streets of North Camden on hot August days. It's safer, says Mrs. Colon, "and Migdalia, she loves the water."
So do a lot of others here, children and teen-agers mostly, who come to take advantage of the spray pool that is fenced off like an oasis in a gritty urban desert.
Camden has seven spray pools, the city equivalent of the sprinkler on the suburban front lawn. The youngsters, and sometimes their parents, run through the sun-sparkling spray and giggle and cavort the way they always do in that happy, hissing chemistry that results when you turn on the water, add children, and stir.
By that measure and others, Camden's spray pools are an enormous success. They are cheaper to build and maintain than swimming pools, which is the reason Camden has only two public pools for 21,000 school children; small children like the spray pools better; lifeguards are not required; in most cases the water is cleansed and recycled and there is little loss and little cost.
Camden could use a lot more of them. Once, like Chicago a city of broad shoulders with a thriving shipyard and a muscular blue-collar economic base, it is now the state's poorest. Forty percent of its 85,000 residents are under 18; over half drop out of high school; 85 percent are black or Hispanic; a third of the babies are born to teen-agers and 90 percent are unmarried.
"We have 14 city parks and ideally we'd have at least 14 spray pools," said Beth Richmond, the city's recreation superintendent. Indeed, the city could use a lot more. There are no spray pools in East Camden, which has a third of the city's population.
In a city with no more than a hundred households with incomes over $50,000, they don't have a lot of air-conditioning, and Camden in August is an oven.
So they do what they can, and that is very often to go out in the street with a wrench and open a fire hydrant. That, of course, is an invitation to disaster.
The last time there was a rash of "hydrant-popping," as the water burglaries are called, the water pressure dropped so low that they closed City Hall and sent everyone home. "The toilets wouldn't flush," said a city spokesman, Tom Hinkle. Fortunately there were no serious fires.
"We did have a spray nozzle program," said Ms. Richmond of the recreation department, referring to a program in use in many urban areas that provides fixtures to residents to attach to hydrants to create a fine spray and save water.
"But the city is self-insured, and they were afraid if the nozzles came off under pressure and caused injury they might get sued. They discontinued the program last year."
Meanwhile, although the city has just opened a spiffy new park with a spray pool just across the street from the one that little Migdalia frequents, it will be hard-pressed to open others. Federal grants and state aid that financed the creation of Camden's spray pools during the late 1970's and into the 80's have been either cut back or dismantled by the Reagan-Bush Administrations in Washington or economic hard times in New Jersey.
The new park and spray pool were financed by the state's Green Acres fund, but the city has to pay back most of the money, close to a million dollars, which it does not have. The money will be repaid by a nonprofit corporate sponsor called Fair Share Housing Development Inc., which will also pick up maintenance costs.
"There was a time during the mid- to late 70's when the Fed was just throwing money at towns like Camden," said Ms. Richmond.
"Now it doesn't begin to fill the need."
Mrs. Colon says the spray pool is even therapeutic. "You know, she got bitten by something, a mosquito I think," she said, gesturing to Migdalia's button nose, which is cherry red. "The water is good for it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Migdalia Melendez, 2 1/2 years old, playing in one of seven spray pools that offer children in Camden, N.J., relief from the heat of the summer. (Sal DiMarco for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: California Medical Researcher Nominated as New York State Health Chief

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today nominated Dr. Mark R. Chassin, a California medical researcher and businessman who has worked to improve the quality and affordability of health care, as the state's new health commissioner.
In selecting Dr. Chassin, Mr. Cuomo placed the state's evolving policies on AIDS, health insurance, medical malpractice and health care regulation in the hands of a man with little experience in New York's singular health care problems. But aides to Mr. Cuomo and Californians who know Dr. Chassin praised his intelligence and his openness to diverse opinions, and said those qualities would offset his lack of familiarity with New York. 
 The nomination is subject to confirmation by the State Senate. John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said the Senate is not likely to consider the nomination until the Legislature convenes a special session, probably in November or December.
 
Extra Pay
 Mr. McArdle said "some eyebrows have already been raised" by the salary package offered Dr. Chassin, which would total $160,000. The previous health commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, received $98,399, but Cuomo officials said they could not lure Dr. Chassin for that.
Dr. Chassin, 44 years old, will receive the health comissioner's salary, which is set by law, and an additional $61,601 as president of Health Research Inc., a nonprofit corporation operated by the Health Department. The corporation, which Dr. Axelrod directed without pay, solicits and administers grants for Health Department research projects.
Dr. Chassin is senior vice president of Value Health Sciences, a Santa Monica company that markets state-of-the-art computer software that helps hospitals and doctors determine the appropriateness of particular medical treatments. He is a former health care researcher for the RAND Corporation and an emergency room physician.
 
Complicated Search
 His areas of expertise -- health care access and cost containment -- are likely to dominate the state's health agenda in the 1990's, particularly as the Governor and Legislature grapple with the costs imposed by a growing Medicaid caseload and simultaneous epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis and measles.
"Dr. Mark Chassin has distinguished himself as an innovative leader in the health care field, particularly in his work on such key issues as quality of care, cost control and the appropriateness of various health services," Mr. Cuomo said in a statement.
The Governor made it clear, however, that Dr. Chassin would have to fill large shoes in succeeding Dr. Axelrod, who suffered a stroke in February. Dr. Axelrod, who directed the 4,200 workers and $930 million budget of the health department for 11 years, was a nationally recognized expert on health policy and one of the Governor's closest advisers.
Dr. Chassin was en route to Albany today for two days of meetings and could not be reached for comment.
Several leaders of New York's health care community said they found the Governor's choice unusual because Dr. Chassin has had little experience managing a public health bureaucracy and has spent most of his professional life in California, where health care is far less regulated than it is in New York.
The search, which began formally with the announcement of Dr. Axelrod's retirement in April, was complicated by a state law requiring the health commissioner to be a medical doctor. Cuomo aides said many doctors found the statutory salary unacceptably low.
By creating a salary for the corporation job, Mr. Cuomo was able to offer Dr. Chassin the highest salary paid to a state commissioner. By comparison, the Governor receives $130,000. Because the corporation salary will be paid with funds generated by the corporation's activities, and not through the state budget, it will not require legislative approval, said Michael J. Dowling, Mr. Cuomo's director of health, education and human services.
 
Raised in New York
 Dr. Chassin, a doctor's son, was born in Brooklyn and reared in New York City and on Long Island. He received undergraduate, master's and medical degrees at Harvard and spent three years in Washington as deputy director of an agency within the Department of Health and Human Services. He has lived in California for the last 10 years.
Some health care officials in New York expressed concern that Dr. Chassin's positions on major issues are unknown and questioned whether he would take the tough stands that made Dr. Axelrod a larger-than-life figure in the state's health community.
But those who sometimes resented Dr. Axelrod's uncompromising dedication to heavy regulation said they welcomed a change. "From what we understand about him, he is extremely bright but is not going to be an individual who is going to overpower other opinions," said Kenneth Raske, president of the Greater New York Hopsital Association.
Mr. Cuomo has said there will be no backsliding on any of the administration's leading health initiatives, including proposals to impose universal health care and no-fault malpractice insurance. But some health care advocates questioned where Dr. Chassin would place his priorities.
"The concern is, is this a guy who has the commitment to and the expertise in the area of health policy to play the aggressive role necessary to make these things happen?" asked David A. Hansell, deputy executive director of Gay Men's Health Crisis, the New York City-based group that serves people with AIDS.
Mr. Hansell and other AIDS lobbyists said they are particularly concerned about the future direction of Dr. Axelrod's policies protecting the confidentiality of AIDS patients. In light of new Federal guidelines and several high-profile cases, the Health Department currently is reviewing its policy of not requiring infected health care workers to disclose their condition to patients.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Restore Gorbachev, Bush Urges Moscow

 BODY:
In a sharp condemnation of the coup that overthrew President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Bush made a blunt demand for Mr. Gorbachev's restoration to power and said the United States did not accept the legitimacy of the self-proclaimed new Soviet Government. 
 Mr. Bush issued his strongly worded statement after a day of consultations with other leaders of the Western alliance and a concerted effort to squeeze the new Soviet leadership by freezing billions in economic aid. HEADLINE: MOSCOW AND THE MARKETS: Kremlin Shake-Up Jars the Financial World;
Glancing Blow Seen in U.S., with Little Lasting Damage

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The downfall of Mikhail S. Gorbachev is likely to deal the United States economy a mild, glancing blow over the next few weeks. But it is sufficiently insulated from the Soviet Union's economy to avoid much lasting damage.
Many economists said yesterday that short-term problems -- the impact on the stock market, the dollar and perhaps agriculture -- could throw the incipient recovery from recession temporarily off course. "But over the long term, the impact won't be very great, beyond the uncertainty that is likely to prevail for a while," said David M. Kemme, a Russian expert and economist at Wichita State University. 
 The immediate effects can cause some pain. Sharp declines in stock prices beyond yesterday's plunge would reduce the wealth of millions of Americans. A stronger dollar would increase the prices of American exports, curtailing this important source of economic growth. And grain sales to the Soviet Union could be disrupted.
 
Grain Shipments Delayed
 Grain dealers said yesterday that the loading of grain in New Orleans aboard ships bound for the Soviet Union had been delayed because of concern about Soviet payment. Reflecting that uncertainty, the prices of corn, wheat and soybeans dropped sharply on commodity exchanges yesterday.
The Soviet upheaval came just as the Federal Reserve's top policy makers were preparing to travel to Washington for one of their periodic meetings to review recent economic developments and decide whether to change interest rates. The Fed lowered a key short-term rate earlier this month out of concern that the recovery might be fading. Now Mr. Gorbachev's downfall might prompt consideration of another rate cut at today's meeting, economists said.
"The Fed is already biased toward lower rates to stimulate the economy and this could tilt them more in that direction," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
That would be the case particularly if the dollar rises against the German mark and the Japanese yen, as it did yesterday. Lower rates discourage investors from buying the dollars needed to purchase American securities.
For the longer run, economists expressed concern about how the emergence of a hardline Soviet Government might affect military spending in the United States.
Currently, they expect that military spending will be cut by as much as 25 percent over the next few years, with the money saved -- "the peace dividend" -- diverted to reducing the budget deficit and financing public works and social programs. A decision to rebuild the military, in response to some renewed Soviet threat, would most likley increase the deficit and renew the debate over its size.
But economists pointed to another factor that might help reduce the deficit. Many hold that when the deficit rises, so must interest rates, as the Government tries to borrow from a limited worldwide pool of savings. But until the Gorbachev Government fell, a portion of this pool was earmarked for investment in that country. Now, investments there and in Eastern Europe appear less attractive, said Edward S. Hyman, president of ISI Group Inc., an economic consulting firm.
"The capital shortage story has been lessened a fair amount by these latest events," Mr. Hyman said. "If anything, these events are somewhat deflationary."
The Soviet upheaval also raised the possibility that Americans, unnerved by the news, might cut back on consumer spending, further damaging an already weak retail sector. But Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Center, discounted this concern.
"The worst thing that could happen to consumer confidence would be the emergence of a general sense of uncertainty," he said. "And even if this happened, consumers would soon conclude that the Soviet struggle is not going to have much lasting impact on them."

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Text of White House Statement

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement by President Bush, issued today by the White House:
We are deeply disturbed by the events of the last hours in the Soviet Union and condemn the unconstitutional resort to force. While the situation continues to evolve and information remains incomplete, the apparent unconstitutional removal of President Gorbachev, the declaration of a state of emergency, and the deployment of Soviet military forces in Moscow and other cities raise the most serious questions about the future course of the Soviet Union. This misguided and illegitimate effort bypasses both Soviet law and the will of the Soviet peoples. 
 Accordingly, we support President Yeltsin's call for "restoration of the legally elected organs of power and the reaffirmation of the post of U.S.S.R. President M. S. Gorbachev."
Greater democracy and openness in Soviet society, including steps toward implementation of Soviet obligations under the Helsinki Final Act and the Charter of Paris, have made a crucial contribution to the welcome improvement in East-West relations during the past few years.
In these circumstances, U.S. policy will be based on the following guidelines:
*We believe the policies of reform in the Soviet Union must continue, including democratization, the process of peaceful reconciliation between the center and the republics and economic transformation.
*We support all constitutionally elected leaders and oppose the use of force or intimidation of suppress them or restrict their right to free speech.
*We oppose the use of force in the Baltic states or against any republics to suppress or replace democratically elected governments.
*We call upon the U.S.S.R. to abide by its international treaties and commitments, including its commitments to respect basic human rights and democratic practices under the Helsinki Accords, and the Charter of Paris.
*We will avoid in every possible way actions that would lend legitimacy or support to this coup effort.
*We have no interest in a new cold war or in the exacerbation of East-West tensions.
*At the same time, we will not support economic aid programs if adherence to extra-constitutional means continues.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Increases Sharply; Gold Also Moves Upward

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar soared in wild foreign-exchange trading yesterday, reflecting a surge in demand for the safe-haven currency on news that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union had been overthrown.
The dollar's rise came despite heavy intervention by several central banks, which sold dollars to contain the currency's strength. The United States currency's increase was especially sharp against the German mark, because Germany is seen as the Western nation most vulnerable to Soviet political and economic upheaval. 
 The mark "is the first one to benefit in case of any good news and the first one to be suffering in any development of this sort," said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange with Paine Webber International Ltd.
Gold also finished higher. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid of $358.20 a troy ounce, up 50 cents from late Friday. Gold for current delivery rose 60 cents a troy ounce, to a late bid of $358.60 on New York's Commodity Exchange.
Money trading was active and volatile in Europe, though it moderated by afternoon in New York, analysts said.
"Most of it happened in overnight trading, and most of it's been concentrated on the dollar vs. the mark," said Terri Reid, an investment officer with Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
The dollar finished at 1.8245 German marks in New York, up from 1.7645 late Friday. In Europe, the dollar closed at 1.8155 marks, up from 1.7605 Friday.
Other currencies declined less in value against the dollar, but the moves were still significant, underscoring the dollar's historical role as the most secure currency when uncertainty prevails.
In New York, the British pound finished at $1.6255, down from $1.6575 late Friday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.6305, from $1.6610 late Friday.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.50 yen, to a closing 138.40 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 138.20 yen, and in New York, the dollar was quoted at 138.15 yen, up from 137.30 yen Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.5535 Swiss francs, up from 1.5440; 1.1431 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1450; 6.1775 French francs, up from 5.9975; 1,359.59 Italian lire, up from 1,320.25.
Selected late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.5510 Swiss francs, up from 1.5395; 6.1535 French francs, up from 5.9875; 2.0460 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9855; 1,352.25 Italian lire, up from 1,319.25; 1.1442 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1438.
In precious metals trading, silver, as well as gold, rose yesterday, but not so sharply as some analysts had expected.
"The dollar in a way has usurped the safe haven status of gold," said Warren Myers, a vice president with Merrill Lynch & Company. "The dollar is the prime beneficiary of what has happened in the Soviet Union."
Earlier in London, gold rose to a late bid price of $360.50 a troy ounce, from $358.25 bid for an ounce late Friday, and to $360.70 an ounce in Zurich, up from $357.75 late Friday.
In Hong Kong, gold rose $4.95 to close at $363.33 an ounce.
Silver for August delivery rose 0.10 cents an ounce, to $3.986 on New York's Comex. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.05 a troy ounce, up from Friday's $4.01.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
2 Retailers Post Profits For Quarter

 BODY:
The K Mart Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings increased by 10 percent. But profits of another big retailer, Toys "R" Us Inc., slid 11.7 percent. Following are details of the companies' results: 1
 
K Mart
K Mart said profit rose to $162.8 million, from $148 million in last year's period. Earnings per share were 81 cents, compared with 74 cents last year. 
 Second-quarter sales rose 8 percent, to $8.49 billion, compared with $7.88 billion a year ago.
Edward A. Weller, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said K Mart's results, which were at the high end of analysts' expectations, demonstrated the "benefits of selling goods early in the season at full margin."
He said the huge retailer also benefited from better-looking in-store displays and the improved overall appearance of its stores. With some K Mart stores more 20 years old, the company is in the middle of a $2.3 billion, five-year refurbishing program.
In a statement, Joseph E. Antonini, K Mart's chairman and chief executive, said K Mart was "poised to benefit significantly from an acceleration in the pace of sales" because of a cost-cutting program and a recent move to improve its line of merchandise.
In yesterday's bear market, K Mart shares closed at $42.125, down $1.50, in trading on the New York Stock exchange.
 
Toys 'R' Us
By The Associated Press
The nation's largest specialty toy retailer said its earnings in the quarter ended Aug. 3 fell to $23.4 million, or 8 cents a share, from $26.5 million, or 9 cents a share, for the correspoinding period in 1990.
Overall sales increased 9.5 percent, to $1.06 billion, compared with sales of $964 million a year earlier. But sales at the company's established stores -- those open at least a year -- decreased 2.6 percent. Sales from older stores are considered the more accurate barometer of a retailer's business.
Toys "R" Us, once seen as a "recession proof" company, has found that cautious consumers have curtailed spending on toys and other items for their children. The company said, however, that its second-quarter sales improved as the quarter progressed, with July the strongest month.
Toys "R" Us operates 457 toy stores in the United States, 97 international stores and 189 Kids "R" Us children's clothing stores.
In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, Toys "R" Us shares fell 75 cents to close at $31.125.

HEADLINE: MOSCOW AND THE MARKETS;
Oil Up $1.17 on Concern Over Coup

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The price of oil jumped on world markets yesterday as traders worried that the coup in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, would disrupt that nation's exports.
In New York, oil closed up $1.17 a barrel, after trading as high as $1.80 above the Friday close. 
 The countries that would feel a disruption first are in Europe, which is the market for almost all of the 2.2 million barrels that the Soviet Union exports each day. But eventually, all importing countries would feel the disruption, as the Europeans turned to other sources.
The United States, which imports very little oil from the Soviet Union, would nonetheless be affected, because Europeans would probably seek heating oil and diesel fuel on the American market, which would drive up prices in this country.
 
Soviets Need Hard Currency
 Oil is the Soviet export commodity of greatest interest to the West. And no matter who is in charge in that country, experts said, maintaining oil exports will be the leadership's top priority to help insure a supply of hard currency. But a disruption of exports seems possible: 90 percent of the country's oil resources lie in the Russian Republic, and the oil workers have been very supportive of the Russian president, Boris Yeltsin, who is calling for a general strike.
Even before the coup, Soviet oil exports had been declining because of the nation's domestic turmoil.
"Soviet oil has always been a wild card," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "Now," he said, "it's more of a wild card."
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, oil for September delivery closed at $22.47, after peaking at $23.10 a barrel near the opening and sinking briefly in midafternoon to $22.15. Thomas P. Blakeslee, an analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group of Hoboken, N.J., said the market was calmed somewhat by the appearance on television of the new Soviet leader, Gennadi I. Yanayev.
But the market's movement yesterday provided little clue about the direction of oil prices in coming weeks. Mr. Blakeslee noted that when Iran invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 last year, the market jumped immediately but did not peak until Oct. 10, nearly 11 weeks later.
 
The Wrong Time of the Year'
 The coup in the Soviet Union comes as Western companies are beginning to build stocks for winter, a high-demand period, said Larry J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "We're going into the wrong time of year," he said. With uncertainty about oil production, he said, those companies may seek higher inventories, driving up demand and therefore price.
Also vulnerable are supplies of natural gas to Western Europe. On an energy basis, the Soviets' natural gas exports are nearly as large as its oil exports. And while an oil buyer can always purchase a tanker load from a different source, coping with a gas pipeline that stops flowing is often much harder. Some of it could be replaced with oil, which would further increase demand for scarce supplies.
Stated on an oil-equivalent basis, Germany imports 400,000 barrels' worth of natural gas a day from the Soviet Union, and France imports another 200,000 barrels' worth, according to the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington-based consulting firm. Turkey and Italy, combined, take in another 460,000 barrels' worth of gas, the firm said.
Soviet oil exports had been falling sharply in recent years. Mr. Lichtblau said exports this year had been expected to run about 2.2 million barrels a day, down from 3.2 million barrels a day last year.
The coup against Mikhail S. Gorbachev came a day before the scheduled signing of a new "all Union" treaty that, among other provisions, would have given the Russian Republic managerial control over its oil resources, with revenues to be shared with the central Government. Many experts said they thought the timing of the coup was determined by the treaty.

GRAPHIC: Photo: On the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, the price of oil fluctuated through the day, rising as high as $23.10 a barrel, dropping as low as $22.15 and closing at $22.47, up $1.17 from Friday's close. (Ed Quinn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
In a Brooklyn Haven, Fear for the Homeland

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Soviet emigres in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn reacted yesterday with shock, anger and sadness to the news that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, had been deposed in a coup.
"If the K.G.B. takes over, it's like fascism," said Nina Koganovsky, who owns the Cafe Zodiac on Brighton Beach Avenue and who came to the United States from the Ukraine 10 years ago. "Gorbachev brought a better life for people, but he couldn't change the Soviet Union. The Russian people don't understand freedom." 
 Leo Blinder, the manager of Odessa, another popular restaurant and nightclub in the area, said: "It's a total shock. It's like snow on a sunny day."
Throughout Brighton Beach, the home to about 25,000 Soviet-born residents who make up perhaps the largest emigre community in the United States, people gathered at newsstands and in restaurants to discuss the latest news bulletins from Moscow and share their fears about the safety of relatives and friends in the Soviet Union.
"I have cousins and sisters in Russia," said Tsila Polevetsky, who left the Soviet Union for Israel in 1973 and moved to New York in 1982. Like many in Brighton Beach, she had tried to call her family in the Soviet Union yesterday, only to have operators say that there would be no open telephone lines for the indefinite future.
Among emigres there was particular fear that Soviet Jews would be most vulnerable after the coup.
"Jews, entrepreneurs and liberals will be persecuted first," said Felix Andreev, a former critic for Soviet Screen who emigrated last year and now hosts a twice-a-week Russian-language radio show on WKRB-FM in Brooklyn. "But Jews are always the first scapegoat. Any upheaval in Russian history, Jews are persecuted. It's a deeply anti-Semitic country, and the right-wingers now accuse them of everything that's wrong with Russia."
 
Doubts Are Realized
 Yelena Arutinyan, who left the Soviet Union in 1979 and whose father still lives in Odessa, said: "The K.G.B. are like animals. They're worse than Hitler."
"Gorbachev did good things for me," she added. "Before him, I couldn't see my family. But he let people visit relatives in the U.S. and in Israel."
Indeed, many emigres who came to this south Brooklyn waterfront section during the 1970's and 80's praised Mr. Gorbachev's reforms. But they also said they had doubted that democracy could become permanent in their former homeland.
"I was expecting it because of events in the last year," said Samuel Zeritsky, who left the Soviet Union 13 years ago.
Mr. Andreev agreed. "This coup was inevitable, because you can't reconcile fire and ice," he said. "Ice is communism and fire is democracy, and they're incompatible."
"Gorbachev represented a new trend compared with Andropov or Brezhnev," he added. "He was someone with a human face, who could kiss an American child. But all his attempts at reform were futile. He didn't believe he would succeed either."
Vladimir Sukhoi, the chief New York correspondent for the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda, said Mr. Gorbachev's undoing might have been of his own making. "Maybe Gorbachev wasn't decisive enough in making policy. He tried to be between left and right; that's his tragedy as a politician."
Mr. Sukhoi said yesterday morning that he had heard that Pravda was among only a handful of Soviet publications that had not been suspended.
Few emigres held out hope that Mr. Gorbachev would return to power. Most offered grim predictions.
"I think blood will be shed," said Michael Weinstein, the owner of the Soft Line art gallery. "If people follow Yeltsin's call for a general strike, it will further paralyze a weak and unstable economy. And the new government, who are outlaws, will force people back to work. These events will test how six years of perestroika have affected people's minds in Russia."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Gorbachev brought a better life for people, but he couldn't change the Soviet Union," said Nina Koganovsky, owner of a cafe in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. Samuel Zeritsky, who left the Soviet Union 13 years ago, said yesterday that he was not surprised by the coup. "I was expecting it because of events in the last year," he said. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)
