HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS: THE WESTERN ALLIANCE;
Condemnation And a Halt to Aid

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Amid strong condemnations of the overthrow of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Western governments demanded today that the new Soviet leadership maintain the ousted leader's reform program and honor Moscow's international commitments.
The English-speaking allies -- the United States, Britain and Canada -- announced the freezing of economic assistance to the Soviet Union, and European Community foreign ministers scheduled a meeting on Tuesday to discuss a suspension of the Community's $1.5 billion aid program. French and British officials said a summit of Community leaders may also be called to discuss the crisis. 
 Some Western European leaders adopted something of a wait-and-see attitude. "We will know very soon," France's President, Francois Mitterrand, said of the new leadership's direction.
Mr. Mitterrand, who said the first phase of the coup in Moscow had clearly succeeded, was among several Western leaders to receive a personal letter from the new Soviet leader, Gennadi I. Yanayev, in which he pledged that Mr. Gorbachev's program of reforms would continue.
Mr. Mitterrand and Prime Minister John Major of Britain conferred by telephone, and both leaders also spoke during the day with President Bush, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers of the Netherlands, the country that currently holds the rotating presidency of the 12-nation European Community.
After an urgent meeting of NATO ambassadors today, it was disclosed that foreign ministers of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization would probably meet in Brussels later this week to analyze whether the coup in Moscow could signal a resumption of the cold war.
Canada, a NATO member, announced that it was freezing a $131 million program of food aid to the Soviet Union. "We have a Government there that we do not recognize," said Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. "Until that is resolved everything is suspended."
Britain announced suspension of an $80 million technical assistance program with Moscow.
Denouncing the "hard-line and reactionary coup," Mr. Major said the Soviet Union's future depends on continuing reforms. "It is in their interests to have reform and it is in the West's interest to see reforms," he said. "But the omens at the moment are not propitious."
In a television interview, Mr. Mitterrand said the Moscow coup could rapidly become "a cold war act" if the new leadership were to reverse the reform process.
Holding up what he described as "a rather astonishing letter" he had received from Mr. Yanayev, the French leader quoted it as saying: "Reforms will continue. Our choice is made. We will stick to democracy, glasnost. We will strive to build up the economy, including private enterprise. We shall continue the policy to guarantee civil rights and freedoms."
Earlier, Mr. Mitterrand issued a statement demanding that Moscow guarantee the "life and liberty" of both Mr. Gorbachev and of the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin. He noted that Mr. Yanayev had assured him in his letter that Mr. Gorbachev is "in perfect safety and nothing threatens him."
The Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said he was ready to cut short his vacation in Portugal. He expressed hope that Moscow would respect the sovereignty and independence of the countries of Eastern Europe.
Condemnation of the coup also came from Italy, Spain, Belgium, Turkey, Finland, Denmark and Greece.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Excerpts From Soviet News Session: 'What Is He Sick With?'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the news conference held today by Acting President Gennadi I. Yanayev and four other members of the State Committee for the State of Emergency, as translated by Soviet Foreign Ministry interpreters:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
 MODERATOR: Welcome to this press conference by the acting U.S.S.R. President, Mr. Gennadi Yanayev. Also present are Mr. Oleg Baklanov, who is deputy chairman of the Defense Council under the U.S.S.R. president. Next is Mr. Boris Pugo, the Minister of the Interior. Mr. Vasily Starodubtsev, chairman of the U.S.S.R. Peasants Union. And finally, Mr. Aleksandr Tizyakov, president of the Association of Transport and Communications Enterprises of the U.S.S.R. 
 I recognize Mr. Gennadi Yanayev.
 
YANAYEV'S STATEMENT
 Ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, comrades, as I am sure you know from the media reports, due to the inability to continue in office, and under article 127.7 of the U.S.S.R. Constitution, of the U.S.S.R. president, the Vice President has taken office of the U.S.S.R. president.
I'm addressing you, Mister -- you, ladies and gentlemen, at a crucial moment for the Soviet Union and for the entire international community who took a path and have gone a long way toward reform, and now the Soviet Union has faced a deep crisis which can call into question further reform and bring major upheavals in the international scene.
It is no secret to anyone that a drastic drop in production, which is not being compensated by alternative economic structures, posing a real threat to further development and survival of the U.S.S.R. nations. The situation has gone out of control in the U.S.S.R. and we are facing a situation of multi-rule.
This is a cause of popular discontent. We're also facing a threat of disintegration, a breakup of a single economic space, a single space of civil liberties, single defense, and a single foreign policy.
And normal life under these circumstances is impossible. In many regions of the U.S.S.R., due to interethnic rivalry, there is bloodshed, and the breakup of the Soviet Union would entail the gravest internal and international repercussions.
Under the circumstances, we have no other alternative but to take resolute action in order to stop the country from sliding down to a disaster.
As I am sure you know, in order to provide an effective government under the state of emergency, it has been decided to set up a State Committee for the State of Emergency in the U.S.S.R., which will consist of Mr. Baklanov, first deputy chairman of the Defense Council; Mr. Kryuchkov, Chairman of the K.G.B.; Mr. Pavlov, Soviet Prime Minister; Mr. Pugo, who is Minister of the Interior; Mr. Starodubtsev, chairman of the U.S.S.R. Peasants Council; Mr. Tizyakov, president of the Transport and Communications Association; Mr. Yazov, Soviet Defense Minister; and Gennadi Yanayev, Acting President of the U.S.S.R.
Today I would like to say the following. The State Committee on the State of Emergency in the U.S.S.R. is well aware of the gravest crisis which we're going through, and it is determined to take full responsibility and to adopt urgent measures to get the country out of the crisis. We pledge to insure a nationwide discussion of the draft union treaty, and every citizen of the U.S.S.R. will have the opportunity to assess this document at his leisure and make a decision that will shape the future of our multinational homeland.
 
Law and Order
 We are determined without further delay to restore law and order, stop the bloodshed, and to wage relentless war on the criminal underworld and to root out this social scourge. We will rid our cities of crime and will prevent further pilfering.
We stand for genuine democratic reforms, for a consistent reform policy toward a social renewal and economic prosperity which will enable our country to adopt the place it deserves in the world community of nations.
But the development of the country must not be built on falling living standards. Without departing from the human-rights principles, we will emphasize the protection of rights of those individuals who are most at disadvantage and suffer most from inflation, economic disintegration, crime and corruption. We will develop an economic diversification, we will uphold free enterprise and create all the conditions for the development of production and the services sector. Our top priority is food and housing.
We will mobilize all the forces to meet these most urgent needs of the people. We call on the peasants, the workers and the working intelligentsia -- in other words, all Soviet people, to re-establish labor discipline and to uphold production in order to continue forward. On this will depend the future of our children and grandchildren and the future of our homeland.
We are a peaceful nation and we will strictly adhere to the obligations we have assumed. We have no claims on anyone at all. We want to live in peace and harmony with everyone, but we state that nobody, but nobody, can infringe on our sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity, and any attempt to dictate terms to our country, whoever they come from, will be stopped.
Our multinational country has lived for generations in pride for its homeland. We have never been ashamed of our patriotic feelings, and we think it justified that the younger generation be raised in that spirit.
To do nothing at this crucial period means to take a grave responsibility for tragic, really unpredictable circumstances. Anyone who wants live and work in peace, who does not accept the bloodshed, who wants to see his homeland in prosperity must take the only right choice. We call on all genuine patriots, all people of good will to put an end to this turbulent time. We call on all the citizens of U.S.S.R. to fulfill their responsibility and to provide the necessary support to the State Emergency Committee to get the country out of the crisis.
All constructive proposals from individuals and work collectives will be considered with gratitude as their manifestation of patriotism and a desire to re-establish multinational friendship for the revival of our homeland. I thank you.
Yes, please. Ladies first.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Where is Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev? What is he sick with? Specifically, concretely, what disease does he have? And against whom are the tanks that we see on the streets of Moscow today directed? What is the purpose of those tanks today on the streets?
A. Let me say that Mikhail Gorbachev is now on vacation. He's undergoing treatment in the south of our country. He is very tired after these many years and he will need some time to get better, and it is our hope -- it is our hope that Mikhail Gorbachev, as soon as he feels better, will take up again his office.
At any rate the policy that was initiated back in 1985 by Mikhail Gorbachev will be continued by all those present here. So far as the state of emergency is concerned, quite naturally the state of emergency is introduced, as I have already stated, at a very difficult and crucial time in our history and in order to rule out any dangers and menaces we had to take certain steps to insure security.
 
Economic Program
 Q. I have two questions. Perestroika has not brought any tangible results, among other things because there was no clear-cut tactics or strategy of implementation of the policy of perestroika. Do you have a specific program for improving our economy? Will existing laws still remain in effect? Will you still continue the movement toward a market economy?
Now my second question. The Russian Information Agency has transmitted an address by Yeltsin [inaudible] Russian Federation, where what happened last night was described as a right-wing anti-constitutional coup d'etat.
What do you think about this? And secondly, the same address also contained an appeal to a general strike. I think that such an appeal can have tragic consequences.
Do you think that the, your committee will take any specific action against that?
A. Let me start by answering your second question, and I'll ask Comrade Tizyakov to answer your first point.
TIZYAKOV: It is true that perestroika, that what was initiated back in 1985, did not bring the results which we all expected from it.
Our economy today is undergoing a very difficult time. There is a drop in the rate of production, and thus as a result of a convergence of a number of factors, including the fact that, of -- it was for the first time that we were undertaking perestroika at such a scale. We were looking for ways and means of achieving that, and as we search for such ways and means of course there may be errors and mistakes.
Now where do we move on from here? The situation that has developed was the reason why the state of emergency was introduced.
You know that the system of horizontal communications, and ties and relations among various enterprises have collapsed.
Many of those present here know that at the end of December 1990, a meeting of the directors of enterprises was held in Moscow which addressed relations among enterprises in various regions of this country.
We discussed this problem at great length and in January 1991 we had 85 percent of the contracts already concluded, and we thought that this provided a good foundation. However, later on, as a result of the parade of authorities, many borders and frontiers were blocked, including the Ukraine, Byelorussia, the Baltics and other republics, which brought about a very difficult situation for our enterprises. There was a slowdown in the rate of production. There was a lot of uncertainty. And it has brought its results.
Now, what we are going to do is this. We will try to stabilize the economy of this country, and naturally the policy of the reforms toward a market economy will not be reversed. We think this is the right and wise policy, except that we will have to make some more thinking about that and to be more organized.
YANAYEV: And now let me take up your second point. It is true that today, when our people were informed about the establishment of the emergency committee, other members of the committee and myself had a contact with the leaders of the nine republics which had stated their readiness and willingness to become part of the new union. We got in touch with leaders of many regions and districts in this country. And I can say that on the whole the establishment of the committee and the efforts by this committee to lead this country out of the crisis were appreciated and supported.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Acting Leader's Health
 Q. I have two questions for Mr. Yanayev. The first question is this. Could you tell us how you feel today? Do you feel healthy?
And, secondly, under your Constitution the state of emergency can only be introduced by the president of the country or by the presidium of the Supreme Soviet, provided that the republics agree. Who took this decision? And there is no provision in the Constitution for the establishment of a national salvation committee, or a committee for the state of emergency. Are you going to convene a Supreme Soviet meeting any time soon?
A. With regard to the state of my health, I think I feel fit and I'm quite capable of working long hours, up to 16 hours a day. So, as you can see, I am alive and kicking, and I look fit, although we had a sleepless night.
Now, with regard to the state of emergency. We were guided by the principle that sometimes there are critical situations which call for immediate action, and it is our intention to ask the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. to reaffirm the state of emergency, and that will happen on the 27th of August. The meeting of the Supreme Soviet will be convened on the 27th of August.
 
Food Shortage Problem
 Q. I have a question for Mr. Yanayev. The emergency committee in its address to the nation has stated that as a first priority it will take care of the interests of the widest -- of the population of this country. It will try to address the food problem. Do you have any specific measures in mind to do that? And what are your resources?
A. This is a very good question, it's a very interesting question. The first priority step that we will take is do all we can to salvage the crops that have been brought in. I think tomorrow we will adopt a document that will provide for emergency actions and measures to salvage whatever crops have been brought in. Secondly, we will try to use the whole potential of this country to make up an inventory of everything that we have in this country.
In our statement, we said that as soon as we have set up an inventory, we will tell our people what we have, what our resources are, including the material resources that we can put at our disposal to get the housing problem moving.
Over the past three years, we did a bad job in terms of housing construction, and many people who were standing in line for new housing and expected us to fulfill the housing problem that at the very beginning of perestroika we proclaimed back in 1985 -- unfortunately, we could not meet their expectations. And therefore I believe that we are faced with three tasks now: food, housing, and transportation and energy. Because winter is approaching, the energy situation is very, very difficult, and we have to take extraordinary measures to make sure that the country does not face an energy crisis during the wintertime.
 
Fate of the Press
 Q. [inaudible] were closed. For how long is my question, and when will they be reopened?
A. Thank you. I think if we introduce a state of emergency we will have to make a provision for re-registering the mass media. We are not closing down newspapers, we are just thinking in terms of having them re-registered, reincorporated -- because the country is facing a crisis and many mass media have played a certain role in this. . . .
 
U.N. Reaction
 Q. A question to Mr. Yanayev. What is the reaction that you have received to your address to the United Nations Secretary General and the world leaders?
A. They have studied very carefully reactions from the world leaders, and I must say that their reaction has been rather low key because the situation is still unfolding and it is still too early to take a stand. I am familiar with President Bush's latest statement in which he expresses the hope that the foreign policy commitments that the Soviet Union has assumed will be fulfilled. I believe I mentioned that earlier in my statement, and this was confirmed just after the state of emergency committee was set up.
 
Comparison of Coups
 Q. Are you aware that you committed a military coup this past night, and which is a more fair comparison, with 1917 or '64? And a second question, about newspaper registration. How long will it take and what will be the criteria? Who will be in charge? And will a political censorship be reintroduced in the newspapers?
YANAYEV: We will try to expedite the newspaper re-registration process. I do not want to comment on the criteria of registration. As for your statement that tonight there was a -- there was a military coup, I beg to disagree, because we are basing ourselves on the constitutional provisions, and the endorsement of our decision by the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet will enable us to say that all the constitutional norms have been observed. I think any analogy, including a comparison to 1917 or '64 are, are simply dangerous.
 
Consulting Gorbachev
 Q. It's again on Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev. Did you discuss with the President your takeover before doing it? Did he agree? Why is there no medical bulletin on his health?
And the second question is, given the wording of your, of your communique, did you ask for any suggestion or any advice through General Pinochet?
A. I believe that in due course, the medical bulletin on the President's state of health will be issued. As for your statement that we have snatched the power, ousted President Gorbachev from office -- President Gorbachev is temporarily incapacitated, and is unable to continue in office, and given that, the Vice President of the Supreme Soviet takes over.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Reaction in the Republics
 Q. Two questions to Mr. Yanayev. Question one. You said you consulted presidents of the constituent republics. How do you visualize the reaction of those republics who do not belong to the nine-plus-one, and do you have a contingency plan toward putting an end to interethnic rivalry. And what is it?
A. Yes, we do have a plan to bring down the tension in interethnic relations. We have specific provisions to settle the differences between Azerbaijan and Armenia, and we have specific proposals on settling other regional issues and those are the most important challenges facing the country and the country's leadership, and the leaders of the state of emergency committee must get down to business without any further delay.
As for your first question I'm afraid I, I forgot that.
Q. You said you consulted the constituent republics. How do you visualize the further development of the situation there?
A. Yes, we spoke with most of the republican leaders. I met with leaders from the 15 Russian autonomies, and I must say that we have the support from the autonomies and from the overwhelming majority of the constituent republics. They support our intention to save the country and to put our house in order.
 
Producing Gorbachev
 Q. Novosti Television. Mr. Yanayev, could you spell it out for us -- when you say in certain territories, what do you mean? And what is their geographic location? And when can we meet President Gorbachev?
A. As soon as he feels well enough, President Gorbachev is sure to meet journalists.
As for the state of emergency, I assume that there is no need to introduce the state of emergency throughout the country. Everywhere in the country there are regions where the state of emergency must be imposed to resolve the problems. In countries -- republics -- like Uzbekistan or Kazakhstan, there's no need to impose a state of emergency there. I'm afraid I cannot give you the specifics, but Moscow is definitely a state of emergency territory, and as of today the state of emergency will be introduced in Moscow.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Moving Against Yeltsin
 Q. Mr. Yanayev, you used to be a trade-union leader, and a very successful one at that. My question is: Are you prepared to adopt some constitutional legitimate steps against Yeltsin's decree, which is directed not only against the party cells but against the trade-union organization?
And a question to Mr. Pugo. Your ministry is in pretty bad shape, including financially. And all the links with the republics, with the Baltic republics, have been disrupted, and the Ministry of Interior branches have fallen into the hands of separatists. What are the steps you are going to adopt in order to centralize the law-enforcement system?
YANAYEV: I think that all the decrees and all the decisions that will be taken will be considered from the viewpoint of the state of emergency that we are introducing in this country. However, let me avail myself of this opportunity to emphasize that what the leaders of the Russian federation are doing now, setting out barricades, calling for civil disobedience, is a very irresponsible and dangerous policy.
I think this policy is fraught with the potential of an armed provocation in order to lay the blame for whatever catastrophe may happen on the leaders of the emergency committee. We want to issue a stern warning against that. We want to tell all the Soviet people, particularly the Muscovites, so that they know that there is a state of emergency in Moscow, and we hope that law and order will be insured.
PUGO: . . .
Let me simply say that we have regular meetings with Ministers for the Interior of the federal republics, and at all the meetings that we have had we met with all the ministers, including the Baltics, and the Transcaucasian republics and Central Asia -- I mean, all 15 republics were represented.
 
Gorbachev's Fate
 Q. Can you provide a guarantee or can you give us your word of honor in front of members of the mass media that Mikhail Gorbachev will continue feeling better?
YANAYEV: Let me tell you that nothing threatens Mr. Gorbachev. He is in a safe place. He needs some time to feel better.
Ladies and gentlemen, you can imagine the stress that he has had to endure over the past six years. I hope that my friend President Gorbachev will return to his office and we will work together.
 
Union Treaty Vote
 Q. Regarding the Treaty of the Union, does this mean that there will be a referendum on the Treaty of the Union? And secondly, what does the committee think about the Baltic republics, Georgia and Armenia and Moldavia, who do not intend to sign the union treaty? And did Mikhail Gorbachev know that the state of emergency was being introduced and that the committee was being established?
A. With regard to the establishment of the committee, the committee, as some of you have already said, was established last night, and I think that President Gorbachev understands and will understand this. He will appreciate that at a time where the country is undergoing a crisis, we will have to find effective ways and means of leading the country out of the crisis.
So far as our attitude to the Baltic republics, Moldavia, Georgia and Armenia, is concerned, namely, the republics that have made known their intention not to sign the Treaty of the Union, our attitude remains unchanged. President Gorbachev made it known on a number of occasions, we will respect the will of the people of those republics.
I think we will find a way to gauge the feelings of our people with regard to the union treaty. I do not know whether this will be a referendum or whatever, but we will try to make sure that the union treaty, on which the future development of this country will depend, is discussed and adopted by the public at large.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Defining Interim Rule
 Q. Mexican Television. How interim is your government? Just how interim is it? And will there be a presidential election?
A. I have assumed the office of president on an interim basis, on a provisional basis, as I have already said, and I believe that as the situation improves, we will hold direct elections of the president of the U.S.S.R. based on the democratic principles that we have always announced.

HEADLINE: Weather Stalls Hartford Budget Plan

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 19

 BODY:
State lawmakers had set aside today for one more hard push to pass a budget for the fiscal year that began seven weeks ago, but, like so many other budget plans, this one was derailed -- this time because the weather was so threatening that legislators were told to stay home.
But there was renewed hope that a budget compromise was perhaps within reach in the State Senate, which has been the main bulwark of opposition to the income tax and revenue overhaul plan being pushed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. 
 Mr. Weicker, who represents a third party that has no members in the legislature, has vetoed three budgets that lacked the income tax, and the Senate has blocked every option that contains such a tax.
 
An Executive Order
 Mr. Weicker, who said last week that he would veto any further attempts to continue running the state with temporary two-week budgets and who briefly shut down many state agencies last month, also issued an executive order today saying services would be maintained even though the last temporary budget expired this morning just after midnight.
The new executive order contained no expiration date, but Governor Weicker's press secretary, Avice A. Meehan, said the order was issued in the belief that progress was being made on the budget.
Connecticut is one of only 10 states that do not tax wages, and Mr. Weicker has argued that one is now necessary to allow other cuts in business taxes to stimulate the state's floundering economy.
Opponents say opening the door on the long-avoided income tax would release a flood of new revenue and break the restrictions that have restrained state spending.
The chief of staff for the Democratic majority in the State Senate, David J. McQuade, said that a Senate session was scheduled for 1 P.M. on Tuesday and that discussions today -- by telephone and in person among those senators who were actually in the building -- centered on a plan for a flat income tax with a rate set between 4 percent and 5 percent. The sales tax would be reduced from the current 8 percent rate to between 6 percent and 6.5 percent.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Bush Condemns Soviet Coup And Calls For Its Reversal

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 19

 BODY:
In a sharp condemnation of the coup that overthrew President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Bush made a blunt demand today for Mr. Gorbachev's restoration to power and said the United States did not accept the legitimacy of the self-proclaimed new Soviet Government.
Back at the White House after rushing from his vacation home here, Mr. Bush issued a strongly worded statement that followed a day of consultations with other leaders of the Western alliance and a concerted effort to squeeze the new Soviet leadership by freezing economic aid programs. He decried the coup as a "misguided and illegitimate effort" that "bypasses both Soviet law and the will of the Soviet peoples." 
 The Bush statement, drafted after an afternoon of meetings with top aides at the White House, was much more forceful than the President's initial reaction this morning in Maine. It was in keeping with a unified Western effort to apply both diplomatic and economic pressure to the group of Soviet officials seeking to gain control of the Kremlin and the country.
 
Britain Freezes Aid
 In London, the British Government announced that it had frozen $80 million in economic aid to Moscow, and the European Community scheduled an emergency meeting for Tuesday in which it was expected to suspend a $1.5 billion aid program.
President Bush decided to send Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to a meeting in Brussels of the foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to discuss the crisis in the Soviet Union.
News of President Bush's decision was first disclosed tonight by ABC News, which said the meeting would be held on Tuesday. A State Department official said, however, that plans were being made for such a meeting on Thursday.
Holding to a dwindling hope that the coup might still fail, Mr. Bush outlined a series of tough positions that would guide American policy toward the Soviet Union during this latest crisis. It dennounced the use of military force in the Baltics and demanded that the Soviet Union respect all of its international treaties and commitments, including the Helsinki guarantees of free speech and other human rights.
"We believe the policies of reform in the Soviet Union must continue, including democratization, the process of peaceful reconciliation between Moscow and the republics, and economic transformation," Mr. Bush said in a written statement that marked a deliberate escalation in the tone of his comments after an initially restrained response.
"We support all constitutionally elected leaders and oppose the use of force or intimidation to suppress them or restrict their right to free speech," Mr. Bush said.
 
Contact With Leaders
 In addition to telephoning his Western allies to coordinate his response to the coup, the White House said Mr. Bush also spoke today with leaders of Eastern Europe and stressed that the changes that had taken place in their countries -- democratic reform and separation from the Soviet-dominated Warsaw Pact -- were irreversible.
Moving to align the United States with the most visible voice of resistance to the newly imposed leadership -- Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian federation -- Mr. Bush said, "We support President Yeltsin's call for restoration of the legally elected organs of power and the reaffirmation of the post of U.S.S.R. President M. S. Gorbachev."
James Collins, the senior American diplomat in Moscow, met with Mr. Yeltsin today while Mr. Bush pondered whether he should contact the Russian president himself.
"We will avoid in every possible way actions that will lend legimitacy or support to this coup effort," Mr. Bush said.
 
Change in Policy
 With these words, Mr. Bush, who has taken pains to keep out of Soviet internal affairs during the period in which he has tightened his political bonds with Mr. Gorbachev, marked a significant change in American policy toward the Soviet leadership.
Since Washington recognized the Communist Government of the Soviet Union in 1933, the United States has never tried, even through indirect political pressure, to reverse a change of leadership in that country.
The only contact between the United States and the eight-man committee that ousted Mr. Gorbachev, the White House said, came when the Soviet Ambassador in Washington, Viktor Komplektov, met with the Deputy Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, and Robert M. Gates, the deputy national security adviser.
Mr. Komplektov gave Mr. Gates a letter for Mr. Bush from Vice President Gennadi I. Yanayev of the Soviet Union, who has been proclaimed the new president. Administration officials said the letter, like others received by Western leaders today, contained assurances that Mr. Yanayev would continue Mr. Gorbachev's policies. But American officials said the Bush Administration discounted those assurances.
Although the United States's economic ties to the Soviet Union largely involve grain sales and technical assistance programs, other Western countries today moved to freeze billions of dollars in financial assistance.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, which has become the Soviet Union's largest donor of financial aid, having given tens of billions of dollars, said it was too early to decide about halting those programs. But he warned that Western aid to the Soviet Union would end if the new Government abandoned reform or violated human rights.
Because the Kremlin upheaval threatened to stall, if not reverse, the improvement in Soviet-American relations that had evolved under Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush's first response today was restrained.
"I've said over and over again that we did not want to see a coup backed by the K.G.B. and the military, and apparently that is what is under way," Mr. Bush said at his vacation home here three weeks after he met with Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow.
Trying to mitigate the potentially explosive nature of the stunning developments in Moscow, Mr. Bush said: "We're not going to over-excite the American people or the world. And so we will conduct our diplomacy in a prudent fashion, not driven by excess, not driven by extreme."
 
Evident Alarm
 But even before Mr. Bush stepped up the tone of his comments with this evening's written statement, the alarm of the President and his aides was evident. Mr. Bush, who values his vacation time, flew back to Washington from Maine as a hurricane lashed the Atlantic coast and he summoned Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d from their Western vacations.
On Tuesday, Mr. Bush planned to swear in his new Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Robert S. Strauss. But the Administration has yet to face the decision of whether to send him to Moscow in light of Mr. Bush's determination not to legitimize the group that deposed Mr. Gorbachev.
Mr. Bush offered words of praise for Mr. Gorbachev, calling him "an historic figure," and said "the world would be sighing with relief" if he were back in power, but he also said, "We have other democratic forces out there now and we want to give them the kind of support we can without being counterproductive."
Mr. Bush called the change in power "disturbing" and "extra-constitutional" and described the eight-man committee that replaced Mr. Gorbachev as a "very hard-line group."
Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said later that the United States assigned little credence to assurances by Mr. Yanayev that the shift of power "was not a reversal." He added, "It can only be, I think, for the purpose of setting back reform."
Mr. Scowcroft said there was evidence of haste in the way the coup was carried out. "It's interesting to note that in ordinary coups the tanks move about the time an announcement is made," he said. "The tanks didn't move for a number of hours afterwards, which indicates that that they had not completed their preparations before they did that."
 
Question of Treaties
 Mr. Bush and his aides were particularly careful to say that there was no indication of a threat to the Soviet Union's nuclear arsenal or any suggestion of Soviet military activity outside the country's borders. The President also said that he expected Moscow would adhere to the terms of the treaty reducing long-range nuclear arms that he signed with Mr. Gorbachev last month, although American officials have said they believe there was resistance to the treaty within the Soviet military.
"These treaties are in the interest of the United States, clearly, and they have said that all treaties will be abided by," Mr. Bush said. "We don't want to go back to the cold war days, and we're not going to do that."

HEADLINE: Fatal Crash Starts Melee With Police In Brooklyn

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON

 BODY:
A 7-year-old boy was struck and killed and his cousin was injured when a car jumped a sidewalk in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn last night and pinned them against a window grate, the police said.
More than 100 police officers, some in riot helmets, surrounded the accident scene as more than 250 neighborhood residents, mostly black teen-agers shouting "Jews! Jews! Jews!" jeered the driver of the car, a Hasidic man, and then turned their anger on the police. 
 Some youths threw bottles and set a Yeshiva van on fire, the police said. A 17-year-old fired a gun at a police officer, without hitting him, and another youth drove his car at a group of officers but did not injure them, the police said. Both youths were arrrested.
 
Barricades Set Up
 The police set up barricades at several nearby intersections as youths continued to roam the neighborhood. At 11:30 P.M., three blocks from the accident, a group of youths stopped a car and stabbed the driver, another Hasidic man, the police said.
Witnesses said the youths confronted the man at the corner of President Street and Brooklyn Avenue. When he jumped from his car, he was stabbed in the left side and left bleeding on the hood of his car.
The police arrested one of the youths as they fled. The victim, a yeshiva student from Australia, was in stable but critical condition at Kings County Hospital.
The fatal accident occurred at 8:20 P.M. as the car, carrying three Lubavitch Hasidic men, swerved to avoid another car at the intersection of President Street and Utica Avenue, said Sgt. Edward Burns, a police spokesman.
 
Driver Questioned
 The car, a dark blue station wagon, ran up on the sidewalk in front of 1681 President Street and pinned the two children against an iron grate covering the window of a first floor apartment in the four-story brick building.
One child, Gavin Cato, was pronounced dead at the scene. The other, Angela Cato, also 7, was in serious condition at Kings County Hospital.
Mayor David N. Dinkins visited the girl in the hospital shortly after midnight.
"No words and no deeds can bring Gavin back to us," the Mayor said at the hospital. "There has been the loss of one life and the injury of two others. There should be no more hurt."
Sergeant Burns said that the driver and two passengers were treated at the 71st Precinct, where they were questioned about the accident.
 
Rumors Abound
 At the scene, descriptions of the accident swept through the crowd. Some youths in the crowd said they had heard from other youths that the three Hasidic men had received medical treatment before the two youths.
Bob Leonard, a spokesman for the Emergency Medical Service, said that the ambulance unit was on the scene in three minutes and that in a matter of two to three minutes more, the first child was on the way to the hospital.
"I'm not aware of us treating anyone other than the children," he said.
Rabbi Yehudah Krinsky, a spokesman for the Lubavitch community who did not witness the incident, said that he had been told that the driver and a passenger had been dragged from the station wagon and beaten by some of the angry youths.
However, Mr. Leonard said they had no report of anyone in the car being injured.
Sharon Bell, a 28-year-old neighborhood resident, said the trouble began when an ambulance came and the word spread about the three men in the car being attended to before the children.
She said that a police cruiser was escorting the car through the intersection when the light changed.
"The cop went through and the car followed, but another car came along and forced it up on the sidewalk," she said.
Crown Heights has a history of black-Hasidic tension. Some of the earliest anti-crime patrols of the Jewish Defense League started in the area, and in the 1970's a number of incidents of violence between the two groups flared up.
Although relations have been relatively quiet in the past decade, the tension has remained. In the summer of 1986, a Hasidic man was beaten unconsious by a group of black youths on a subway station and eventually died. In April 1987, 400 blacks marched through the area to protest what they said was harassment by a Hasidic surveillance patrol.
In March 1989, a crowd of Hasidic Jews surrounded and beat a black teen-ager who they said had slashed a Hasidic woman and her son.
This history of ill will was much on the minds of black Crown Heights residents last night as they milled about in front of their apartments.
"My husband is afraid to go down the street at night to get baby formula," said one woman. She said Hasidic patrols were "always questioning him about what he is doing on his own block. It's a shame, but it's true," she said.
Another black resident of President Street, Kobie Foster, said he resented the presence of Hasidic patrols on the block.
"We're not living in their neighborhood, they're living in our neighborhood," he said.
"It ain't about us getting together," Mr. Foster said. "It's about us being able to live together without killing each other."
As President Street grew quiet around midnight, a small crowd of about 40 blacks gathered nearby across the street from the Tomchy Yeshiva at 770 Kingston Avenue, the world headquarters of the Lubavitch sect.
About 50 Hasidic men stood in front of the yeshiva, with about 25 police standing in the street street between the two groups.
"I believe this is just a group of young people who for a number of reasons, whether it's the recession or the excitement of the summer heat, got together and turned to a bit of violence," said Joe Kopfer, a yeshiva student.
"I hope it's just a small group that will go away very quickly," he said.
Across the street, Arnold Jacobs, a black man, said, "The reason we're here is we want justice. They don't want to give it to us, so we're going to take it," he said.
As the standoff continued at the Tomchy Yeshiva, flames were suddenly visible a block away at Albany Avenue and Eastern Parkway where a yeshiva van had been set afire.
Witnesses told the police that a group of black youths was seen running from the van as it burst into flames.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Jolt From Moscow
The world's financial markets reacted quickly and sharply to Gorbachev's ouster, with stock markets around the world falling as much as 9 percent. [Page D1.] U.S. stocks plummeted, with the Dow losing 69.99, to 2,898.03, its largest drop since the early days of the Kuwait crisis. Defying the trend were military equipment stocks and oil shares. [D7.] The dollar soared in wild trading, reflecting a surge in demand for a safe currency. The dollar's rise came despite heavy intervention by several central banks. [D16.] 
 The march of foreign private investment into the Soviet Union seemed to freeze mid-stride, as business executives watched the events in Moscow with confusion and concern. [D1.]
The coup is likely to deal the U.S. economy a glancing blow over the next few weeks. But the economy is sufficiently insulated from the Soviet Union's to avoid much lasting damage. [D1.]
The price of oil jumped as traders worried that the coup in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer, would disrupt the nation's exports. [D6.]
The Soviet coup put in question Western investment and many public and private programs for developing the Soviet economy. But any losses in the West would mostly be suffered by governments, particularly in Western Europe. [D6.]
Investors from around the world ran to the safety and security of Treasury securities. As often occurs at times of crisis, short-term Treasury bills were the investment of choice. [D14.]
Grain prices plunged in fast, hectic action as traders feared that the overthrow of Gorbachev might halt exports to one of the world's biggest purchasers of U.S. grain. [D16.]
 
Companies
The Salomon scandal widened, as the S.E.C. began requesting documents from dozens of other firms seeking evidence of possible widespread collusion, fraud and other illegal practices in the $2.2 trillion Treasuries market. [D1.] Salomon took part in the Treasury auction under strict new rules. [D17.]
Among leading insurers, Kemper would appear to be an exception in this real estate recession: But ratings agencies and investors have become increasingly skeptical. [D1.]
Conoco will start selling propane today from pumps next to gasoline pumps at some stations in the Denver area, in a push to capture a big share of a new market. [D2.]
K Mart said its earnings rose 10 percent, but Toys "R" Us profits slid 11.7 percent. [D4.]
Infonet will start beaming its "infomercials" nationwide on Labor Day, executives of Home Shopping Network said. [D19.]
An offer for the Six Flags amusement park company was made by Time Warner and two investment banking concerns. [D4.]
 
Today's Columns
Some states are cracking down on health insurers that aggressively reduce premiums to attract small businesses with young employees. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health. [D2.]
What began the day as a flight to safety was looking more like a crawl by the end, as stocks rose from early lows and rallies in both gold and Treasury bonds faded. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
Gorbachev's ouster could put an end to ad agencies' efforts to capitalize on the good will that glasnost generated in the West. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Species Loss: Crisis or False Alarm?

BYLINE: WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
RATS, weeds, cockroaches and other hardy, ubiquitous "tramp" species may never inherit the earth. But some scientists say they could make a run for global ascendancy if humans, as many biologists fear, precipitate a mass annihilation of less adaptable creatures.
In this scenario, the actions of an exploding human population are sundering the ecological webs that support life by setting off a worldwide wave of extinctions comparable to the one in which the dinosaurs perished some 65 million years ago. 
 But is the scenario accurate? A minority of dissenters says that while wild habitats are indeed disappearing because of human expansion, and species with them, the supposed magnitude and rate of the extinctions are unsubstantiated by hard evidence and have probably been exaggerated. In possibly overstating the risk, some critics say, conservationists may harm their own cause by setting themselves up for the charge of crying wolf.
The perceived threat to species diversity has prompted delegates from around the world to meet under United Nations auspices in Nairobi, Kenya, next month in the second of three negotiating conferences aimed at producing a treaty by next June.
Meanwhile, the argument over the seriousness of the threat has surfaced in the current issue of the journal Science. In one of six articles on biological diversity and extinction of species, two prominent biologists, Dr. Edward O. Wilson of Harvard University and Dr. Paul R. Ehrlich of Stanford University, assert that if tropical rain forests continue to be cut down at the present rate, a quarter or more of all the species on earth could be exterminated within 50 years. For the first time in geological history, they say, plant species are becoming extinct in large numbers.
The tropics, and most of all the rain forests, are the richest repositories of biological diversity on earth, and the two biologists point out that many tropical species exist only locally and are subject to immediate extinction with the clearing of a single tract. They say that while conservation efforts are needed, the only way to head off the crisis in the long run is to reduce the scale of human activities.
Since the Science article was prepared, Dr. Wilson said in an interview, he has further estimated that 50,000 species a year, or about six every hour, are being doomed to eventual extinction. The estimates are based on a mathematical model of the observed relationship between habitat area and number of species and on the observed disappearance of rain forests.
Coral reefs, dry tropical forests and other tropical habitats are also being destroyed. The resulting mass extinction, Dr. Wilson said, is likely to compare with the largest extinctions in geological history and to take place in a much shorter time: decades, perhaps, instead of centuries or millennia. "It is a genuine holocaust," he said.
"That sounds alarmist," Dr. Wilson conceded. "But I invite anyone to check through the figures."
The skeptics have not yet had a chance to examine Dr. Wilson's latest assessments in detail, but they have attacked earlier, similar assessments made by him and other scientists. The critics say there simply is not enough information on which to build a reliable assessment.
While species constitute a "valuable endowment" and should be protected, there is "a total lack of evidence" of a biological holocaust, said Dr. Julian Simon, a University of Maryland economist. He is perhaps better known for arguing that the world's resources, coupled with human ingenuity, can support a surging population. "We're being asked to take the entire scenario on faith" and on the judgment of those who advance it, he said. The warnings of mass extinction, he said, "seem like guesswork and hysteria."
Other dissenters say there is a problem, but that its dimensions simply cannot be known at the moment. No one even knows the true number of species in the world, they say. This is acknowledged by Dr. Wilson and others who share his view.
Only 1.4 million species have been identified worldwide, but estimates of South American species alone range from 5 million to 50 million, and estimates of global species range up to 100 million.
"When you deal with that kind of error, it's hard to say what's happening," said Dr. Michael A. Mares, a zoologist at the University of Oklahoma who is an expert on neotropical habitats.
Likewise, he said, it is difficult to come up with a rate of extinction when the geographical distribution of organisms is not known. "Most of them are invertebrates," he said. "We really don't have a good handle on whether or not they're going extinct and how rapidly. The problem is data right now."
More should be known, he said, before the poor countries of the world are asked to make large sacrifices to preserve tropical forests.
For his part, Dr. Mares said, he believes that the wolf is not yet at the door. "The wolf is coming," he said, "but he's coming later."
It is "understandable that there's disagreement," said Dr. Jared Diamond, an ecologist at the University of California at Los Angeles who has examined the problem. "What people are arguing about is what's going to happen in the future."
Predicting the stock market, with its well-known variables and wealth of data, is a far more certain pursuit than predicting the future of species, he said.
Dr. Diamond has concluded that, even taking into account all the uncertainties, "something like half the species that now exist will go extinct or will be on the verge of going extinct in the next century" if current trends continue.
Geological history is filled with mass extinctions. The most famous is the wave of extinctions in which the dinosaurs vanished 65 million years ago. Three-quarters of the species on earth were wiped out in that event, paleontologists say.
Extinctions of similar scope took place about 208 million, 367 million and 439 million years ago. An estimated 96 percent of all species disappeared in a mass extinction 245 million years ago in the most extensive wipeout of species in the geological record. Most recently, an estimated 35 percent of species disappeared in an extinction 35 million years ago.
 
Dispute Over Causes
 Scientists argue about the causes of such events. Species become extinct in the natural course of evolution, but this "background" rate of extinction is very low, said Dr. David Jablonski, a paleontologist at the University of Chicago. Some scientists have tried to assign a single cause, like an impact of a meteorite or comet, to the mass extinctions. Others say changes in climate, sea level, ocean currents or ocean oxygen content could do it. In any case, some great environmental disruption, or combination of disruptions, is believed to be responsible in each case.
Writing in the current issue of Science, Dr. Jablonski says that according to fossil studies, widespread species are more likely to survive a mass extinction, whereas specialized species adapted to a smaller area are especially vulnerable. This, he wrote, suggests that disruption and fragmentation of habitat caused by humans are likely to result in the increasing appearance of "widespread, weedy species -- rats, ragweed and cockroaches." The weedy species, he said in an interview, "are biologically prepared to cope" with environmental change and are "capable of using a lot of different kinds of resources," like disturbed roadside habitats and human waste.
Coming at it from a different perspective, Dr. Terry L. Erwin, an entomologist at the National Museum of Natural History in Washington, wrote in Science that if the disruption of ecosystems continues, "we can expect the evolutionary process as we know it to become degraded and retarded." If current trends continue and are pushed to their extreme, he wrote, "within a few hundred years this planet will have little more than lineages of domestic weeds, flies, cockroaches and starlings evolving to fill a converted and mostly desertified environment."
The big question is whether the disruptions caused by human activity will be enough to create this bleak landscape and to bring about a mega-extinction like those of the distant past.
"That's the $10,000 question," said Dr. Jablonski. "We have no idea how many species are out there and how many are dying. My own personal feeling is that if the destruction goes unchecked, we will reach an extinction level unmatched since the end of the Cretaceous" period, when the extinction of the dinosaurs took place. "Under any circumstance, we're going to have a big loss," he said.
Dr. Simon has argued since the mid-1980's that there is no evidence of extinction rates of the magnitude advanced by Dr. Wilson and others. In an article in 1986, to which he says he still holds, he wrote that "there is no prima facie case for any expensive policy of safeguarding species without more extensive analysis than has so far been done." He says that the only scientifically observed extinction rate in this century is one species a year.
 
'Massive and Worldwide'
 On the contrary, says Dr. Wilson, "the observed extinctions of species in this century have been massive and worldwide." While "our very incomplete knowledge" makes it difficult to monitor extinctions, he said, "in the small minority of groups of plants and animals that are well known, extinction has been found to be proceeding at a rate hundreds or thousands of times above pre-human levels. That has been spread prominently on the scientific and public record."
While no comprehensive global survey has been taken, he says, there are hundreds of separate examples of serious recent extinctions: for instance, 90 plant species whose only habitat was a single mountain ridge in Ecuador, and half the 280 freshwater fish species in peninsular Malaysia.
Dr. Wilson bases much of his case on calculations employing a mathematical model that describes the effect on the number of species when the geographical area in which they exist is reduced. The model, which he says has been tested for validity against field studies and observations "over and over again," calculates that when species' habitat in a given area, an island or a continent, and the habitat is reduced by 90 percent, the number of species eventually declines by about half.
Worldwide, he said, tropical rain forests are being lost at the rate of nearly 55,000 square miles a year, a loss roughly equivalent to the land area of Florida. This figure, he said, was derived recently from satellite reconnaissance and from surveys by governments and scientific teams.
At that rate, Dr. Wilson calculated, the world's rain forests would be reduced by half in 30 years. Applying the area-species model to this finding, he calculated that 10 percent to 22 percent of the rain forest species would be "doomed" in the next three decades.
As used by ecologists, doomed means that extinction might take some time, but that it is a foregone conclusion. Although they cannot be sure, scientists believe that more than half the world's species, from bacteria to big mammals and trees, live in the rain forests.
 
Criticism on Data
 The mathematical model used by Dr. Wilson "is based on nothing but speculation," said Dr. Simon. "If scientific models are to have any validity, they must be based on some solid data." He said he has been unable to find such data.
Critics also say that deforestation statistics can be misleading, that in the Amazon, for instance, more than a third of the region that is considered tropical forest is not rain forest but savanna and semi-desert. They say also that some of the forest is not virgin forest, which is richest in species, but secondary growth. In reply, Dr. Wilson says that his calculations involve rain forest only, and apply globally, and that secondary forest is included as well.
To observations that not enough is known about the number of species in the world, Dr. Wilson says that this is "completely true," but that it makes no difference: Whatever the number, it is the proportion by which the species total is reduced that is important, and this is calculable.
Dr. Mares notes that there was no widespread extinction of species in the eastern United States after its forests were cleared. "While there were quite a number of changes in distribution patterns of many species," he said, "we haven't had massive die-offs."
Dr. Wilson said that in the temperate zones, species tend to be distributed over a wider area than in the tropics, where it is common for a given species to be confined to one mountainside or one river basin. Temperate-zone species, he said, are consequently better able to survive habitat destruction.
Dr. Mares acknowledged this, but said that "when you look at mammals" in the tropics, in which he specializes, "I don't think this is the case. Many have extensive distributions."
 
Puerto Rico's Experience
 Some dissenters have also said that the experience of Puerto Rico casts doubt on the doomsday scenario. There, they say, there are as many species now, or more, than before the arrival of Columbus. Yet the island was largely deforested at the turn of the century.
"That's probably true," said Dr. Wilson, "but it has been loaded up with tramp species, cockroaches, weeds and so forth. Everywhere you go, you get them, and they're the same ones you get in Caracas and Lagos and Miami." Meanwhile, he said, some of the local species have been lost, and those are "gone from the global roster."
That, he said, is the direction in which the world is going, "as we wipe out very rich assemblages of local, endemic species that have taken millions of years to build up, in many cases wiping them out before we have put scientific names on them."

That has been spread prominently on the scientific and public record." (Associated Press); Dr. Julian Simon: The University of Maryland - "There is no prima facie case for any expensive policy of safeguarding species without more extensive analysis than has so far been done." (pg. C8)
 
Diagrams: "Will the Weedy Inherit Earth?"
 
When humans disrupt natural habitats, scientists say, highly adaptable global species like rats and cockroaches invade the disrupted area and replace richly varied assemblies of local organisms. In mass extinctions of the past, fossils show, large vertebrates were more vulnerable than smaller ones. (pg. C1)
 
"Evolution, Density and Variety"
 
Vast numbers of insect species originate in lush tropical rainforests. Even while living close together, two different races of the same species evolve into two wholly new species. Although they are neighbors, they live and feed on different species of plants and are thereby reproductively and genetically isolate.
 
The tropics contain a much denser concentration and greater diversity of species than temperate zones. One study found 300 species of trees in one hectare (2.47 acres) of Peruvian rainforest, compared with 700 native species of trees in all of North America. A single tree in the same Peruvian area yielded as many ant species as live in Britain. (pg. C8)

HEADLINE: The New Range War Has the Desert as Foe

BYLINE: By MYRA KLOCKENBRINK

 BODY:
AS much as 85 percent of the rangeland in the Western United States -- about 685 million acres -- is being turned into desert by overgrazing and other problems, according to a study prepared for the United Nations Environment Program.
The desertification manifests itself through low groundwater tables, salinization of topsoil and water, reduced surface waters, high soil erosion and acute loss of native vegetation. The result is the general impoverishment of an ecosystem's productivity. 
 The land is principally degraded in two ways: overgrazing by cattle and salinization of the soil due to poor drainage on irrigated farmland. While salinization is more deadly -- plants will not grow in salt-laden soil -- overgrazing, while not necessarily irreversible, is by far the most pervasive cause of desertification.
 
Monitoring Costs Unmet
 At the heart of the rangeland's poor state of repair, according to Government officials, is a lack of adequate funds to monitor the number of cattle on public land or to manage them properly.
At least 265 million acres of Federal lands are made available to livestock grazing. Grazing fees generated by the leasing of these lands are well below those charged for private land, officials say, and don't cover monitoring costs. As a result, range managers don't have the data to enforce reduction in grazing capacity.
A report by the General Accounting Office found that 75 percent of the public lands believed to be overstocked had not been scheduled by either the Bureau of Land Mangement or the Forest Service for a reduction in livestock.
"We're not getting the job done," said Robert Williamson, director of the Range Management Program of the Forest Service. "We don't have the resources to do the monitoring or administering of our allotments."
Dr. Harold Dregne, the Horn Professor of Soil Science at Texas Tech University, measured precipitation and evaporation to determine productive yield on cropland and rangeland west of the 100th meridian. This runs from central North Dakota through central Texas.
Dr. Dregne, the author of the United Nations report, which is soon to be published, classified 430 million acres of this area as suffering a 25 to 50 percent reduction in yield from that of a healthy state. Thirteen million acres showed very severe degradation, largely because of salinization, with more than a 50 percent reduction in their ability to sustain crop yields or natural vegetative production. When land is abandoned, it becomes a source of dust storms and water erosion, eventually becoming sterile sand dunes.
Dr. Dregne says he believes these 13 million acres are "irreversibly degraded and cannot be economically rehabilitated or improved."
Government reports have made similar findings, although they are not usually expressed in terms of desertification.
Chief among the expensive habits that have depleted the land in the West is overgrazing. The cattle industry began with millions of acres of free and unrestricted pasturage. Though much of the damage was done in the great cattle drives of the late 1800's, the number of cattle on the land has reached an all-time high of more than 19 million head in the 11 Western states today.
The number of cattle and the long periods they are kept in one area are what leads to overgrazing, and repeated overgrazing undermines tissue reserves until the plant grows weak and dies.
"The Western range has been kept in a dynamic state of degradation," said Lynn Jacobs, the author of a forthcoming book, "Waste of the Land," about the effects of overgrazing on public lands. "People get the impression that the land has always looked like this. But just as your hair doesn't turn gray overnight, this land has been degraded over a long period of time, and it continues to be degraded."
While pressure from environmental groups and congressmen has led to some changes in land management practices, cattle ranchers have opposed new restrictions on the size of herds and the higher fees for the use of public lands.
"For too long the permittees have had priority," said David Oman, ranger for the Sawtooth National Park in Idaho, said of ranchers whose cattle graze on public land). "They talk about it as their land."
Livestock operators contend that preservationists are interested in limiting the use of the land to wildlife, excluding any human impact. In fact, they contend that management by the livestock industry accounts for increases in wildlife numbers and conservation of land.
"In our part of Montana my father never saw any wildlife," said Joe Etchart, a rancher in Glasgow, Mont., who is president of the Public Lands Council, an organization for the 31,000 Federal permit holders. "Today we have hundreds of hunting parties coming to our area each year to participate in our game harvest."
Cattle typical of the range today are northern European imports, which, unlike their bison counterparts, are fond of wet places and high-protein forage and dislike going far for either. However, wet places and good forage are scarce in the arid West. So while it may take one acre of land to raise a cow in Georgia, it may take 20 in Colorado or as many as 200 in the desert Southwest.
"We have tried to make the West a replica of Georgia by damming our rivers, through irrigation and groundwater mining," said George Wuerthner, an ecologist who studies the effects of overgrazing. "And we have failed. We have achieved desertification instead."
Many of the native grasses, like the grama grasses and bunchgrasses known to live 100 to 150 years, have been eradicated by grazing. Because they are among the most desirable forage, they are the first to be eaten. In addition, they are crowded out by the desert sagebrush, mesquite and introduced exotic grasses that quickly take over the depleted soil.
The delicate layer of topsoil, often held together by no more than a thin mat of algae, fungus or lichens, is easily broken apart by cattle roaming for forage. The soil is then exposed to wind and water erosion and the further infiltration of desert shrubs and non-native plant species.
Dr. Robert Stebbins of the Zoology Department at University of California at Berkeley, an expert on California desert systems, said, "the shift toward weedy species such as the Russian Thistle or tumbleweed tends to create monocultures, a uniform vegetation without the biological diversity" so important to all natural landscapes.
The prolonged presence of too many cattle further degrades the West's dry lands by compacting the fine clay soil and preventing what precipitation there may be from reaching the roots of plants. Rain on heavily grazed land will run off, carrying the topsoil with it and polluting streams and rivers.
In the West, riparian zones, the narrow belts of land along waterways, represent a small proportion of the land, but are critical to the overall ecological health of the rangeland because it here that the greatest diversity of plant and animal life exists. A 1990 report by the Environmental Protection Agency found that "riparian areas throughout the West are in the worst condition in history."
Because cattle need water( 20 gallons a day for each cow, according to the Bureau of Land Management) they congregate along streams and meadows. However, a fragile streambank is easily destroyed by the 1,000-pound animals. Tender grasses and saplings that line the streams provide succulent feasts for cattle, destroying the habitat for other animals. Eventually, the water table falls through the deepening and widening of the stream bed, and if the cattle stay long enough, they will effectively turn a stream into a dry arroyo bed.
Mr. Williamson said that more than half of the 101 million acres under the Forest Service protection were unsuitable for livestock grazing, but nevertheless were still being used.
A bill now in Congress would raise grazing fees from $1.97 per cow per month to $8.70 by 1995. Ranchers say that such an increase would make cattle too expensive to raise.
"We'll go out of business a piece at a time," said Kenneth Spann, a rancher in the Gunnison Valley of Colorado. "Our land will be subdivided and developed, and the water will go to the highest bidder, Denver or California, who knows?"
Before the era of great cattle drives, bison, bear and other wildlife were abundant. Giant trees paved the mountain sides and commanded flood plains and grasses grew as high as a horse's belly.
"Now it's hard to find anything growing that would scratch a horse's ankles," said Norbert Riedy of the Wilderness Society. "The natural grasslands are all but gone."

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR's WORLD;
Unraveling the Mystery Of Bypass Survival

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

 BODY:
To learn why death rates from heart bypass operations varied as much as 400 percent in a New England study, researchers are reviving an old practice: Surgeons are visiting each other's hospitals to watch colleagues operate. But in new twist, they are taking engineers, anesthesiologists, technicians and nurses with them.
The teams are seeking clues to death rates that defied explanation in a study of 3,055 bypass operations by the 18 heart surgeons in the five hospitals that do all the bypass operations performed in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont. 
 The effort is a return to the days when surgeons routinely learned new techniques at first hand from their colleagues. But it is not the only one. In the belief that doctors often learn more from mistakes than successes, surgeons in Europe long ago formed what is known as Pete's Club, in which members report their biggest surgical disaster of the past year.
In the United States, 25 heart surgeons belong to a 12-year-old club that makes informal visits to a member's hospital once a year. They watch the host perform operations and talk with nurses and technicians to pick up tips that they often incorporate into their practices back home, said Dr. Dan J. Ullyot, a heart surgeon at the University of California at San Francisco and club member.
But unlike the members of Pete's Club and the 25 surgeons, the researchers in New England intend to publish results of their efforts to unravel the heart surgery mystery.
The puzzling new findings, along with those of another study from Philadelphia published in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association, challenge the prevailing view that differences in death rates can be explained by simple factors, like differences in patients' conditions. They suggest that more complex factors are involved. So the New England team will consider such factors as drug treatments before and after surgery, the organization of the hospital and the personality of the surgeon.
All teaching hospitals once had amphitheaters or domes where surgeons watched masters perform operations. It was under what became known as the ether dome at Massachusetts General Hospital, for example, that surgical anesthesia was first publicly demonstrated in 1846.
But no such amphitheater was included in the new hospital that Duke University built 10 years ago because "no one uses them anymore," said Dr. David Sabiston, the chief surgeon at the Durham, N. C. medical center.
Instead, many surgeons now learn by watching films or videotapes of key portions of operations at meetings or on closed circuit television.
But such "films are often dressed up, so what you see looks almost perfect, and there's never anything on a film that shows bleeding and other problems," Dr. Sabiston said in an interview. He added: "Films do not tell you about pre-operative and post-operative care, and more important, you do not hear the conversation in the operating room."
Some famous heart surgeons have suffered tarnished images after visitors have seen them err.
One surgeon told about a colleague who was astonished to watch a world-renowned surgeon sew a heart valve in upside down. Junior assistants did not point out the mistake. As was his custom, the surgeon went on to work on another patient in another operating room, leaving his assistants to finish the first operation. Once the master had left, the assistants repositioned the valve.
Economic competition remains another obstacle to the practice of surgeons watching each other. Many surgeons have declined to host visitorsfrom another hospital in the same city out of fear that the visiting surgeon might steal a technique and thus, future patients.
"There's an old saying that 'the friendliness between surgeons is directly proportional to the distance between them,' " said Dr. Ullyot, the San Francisco heart surgeon.
Dr. Gerald T. O'Connor, an epidemiologist at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H. who led the New England team, said his study could not have been done in Boston or another big city. The medical centers in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont are 70 miles distant, separated by mountain ranges, Dr. O'Connor said. In an interview he added: "The doctors do not compete with each other, so there is less ego involvement in being the best, and there is more willingness to learn from each other."
Now, in another study, Dr. O'Connor's team is comparing the records of 350 patients who died after bypass surgery with those of 700 survivors. The aim is to determine whether any of 160 factors, some derived from observations made on team visits might be clues to the different death rates.
For example, the team will determine whether aspirin use is a factor. Aspirin is a standard therapy to prevent a heart attack because it makes it harder for blood to clot. But bleeding can be a serious complication in heart surgery. "We know some hospitals won't operate on someone who has had an aspirin and they do extensive screening for bleeding problems," Dr. O'Connor said. "Yet other places do not think such tests are important at all."
"We don't know which is right, but we will know" after the data is collected, Dr. O'Connor said.
The visiting teams have also found wide variation in the techniques used to deliberately stop the heart while the damaged coronary arteries are repaired. All teams use a heart-lung machine, but they vary the kinds and temperatures of the standard solutions added to the blood that circulates through the machine.
Experts agree that nursing care is a critical factor in the care of patients with heart disease. Although nurses are full partners in the New England study, there are fewer questions about nursing care than many experts might expect.
The fragile hearts of bypass surgery patients are vulnerable to little changes that could cause further heart damage. After bypass surgery, for example, nurses watch cardiac monitors for the earliest sign of a serious heart rhythm abnormality. Some can kill in seconds. Nurses also are alert to drops in blood pressure that could be clues to bleeding around the heart. Such bleeding can hamper blood pumping and lead to shock.
"In some hospitals the nurses say they do not know what is going on, that every doctor wants something different, while other hospitals seem more organized and nurses and doctors there seem to agree more on what they are doing," Dr. O'Connor said.
Another potentially critical factor is the ratio of nurses to patients. In most acute care units the ratio is one to one, but sometimes is stretched to one nurse to two patients, said Dr. Sabiston of Duke. He added, "There's a lot of variation in the ratios."
The ratio can be critical because if a heart stops, nurses are often the first to start resuscitation measures.

GRAPHIC: Table: "Lines of Inquiry"
 
A partial list of variables in bypass surgery:
 
Pre-Bypass Care. Medications, including antiplatelet and anti-clotting agents; anesthesia, including qualifications of anesthetist and oxygen supply to heart.
 
Heart-Lung Machine. Qualifications and number of machine operators; disasters, like equipment failure or loss of air supply; clotting; blood conservation techniques.
 
Surgeon. Number of cases handled per year; type and qualification of assistant; use of magnifying loupe; day of week and time of day.
 
Patient Characteristics. Age; sex; diabetes; tobacco use; blood pressure; cholesterol; lung disease; hardening of brain arteries; heart rhythm abnormalities; clotting ability; kidney function; whether surgery is emergency or elective; history of heart failure; damaged blood vessels in legs; prior angioplasty; extent of coronary artery disease; silent heart attack; angina; damaged heart valves; heart aneurysm; time since prior heart attack; enlargement of heart; previous bypass.
 
Operation. Number of diseased vessels and number bypassed; length of operation and time on bypass machine; use of internal mammary artery instead of leg vein; lowest body temperature while on bypass machine; medications; amount of blood transfused; doctor-induced tears in blood vessels.
 
Post-operative management. Time before removal of breathing tube; time in intensive care unit; post-operative monitoring.
 
Source: Northern New England Cardiovascular Disease Study Group
