HEADLINE: PERIPHERALS;
Chess Game With Big Differences

BYLINE: By L. R. SHANNON

 BODY:
PLAYING chess on a personal computer is nothing new, but here is a program with three important differences. First, it was designed to work with Windows 3.0, so it does not force you into the contortions sometimes required to get a plain DOS program to run in that environment. Second, if you have a modem and a friend with a modem, as well as his own copy of the program, you can play chess over the telephone lines. Finally, if your computer is linked to other computers in a Netbios-compatible network, you can play through that.
ChessNet for Windows, version 2.0, plays a good game, too, much better than this writer's. 
 Installing the program into Windows is a breeze and, when the screen appears, there is the familiar menu bar across the top for the various options. You can change the color of the squares, the background and border and have the moves recorded in either algebraic or coordinate notation. Everything can be done with the keyboard, but a mouse is easier.
The computer can play either the black or the white side at six levels of difficulty, will give hints if asked and can even be made to switch sides in the middle of a game. If you are playing through a modem or on a network, there is a "chat" feature that lets the two human players praise, or vilify, each other on screen.
Playing by telephone could become expensive, but playing by mail -- long favored by some -- certainly tries the patience. Playing over the office network sounds like a good way to win a spot in the unemployment line, but one can imagine the members of a company chess club competing after hours. Games may be saved on a disk.
The manual includes a summary of the official rules of the game prepared by the U.S. Chess Federation in addition to instructions. The package contains both 5.25-inch and 3.5-inch disks and can be played on any computer capable of running Windows 3.0. The suggested retail price is $49.95. ChessNet for Windows, 2.0, is a product of Masque Publishing of Englewood, Colo. If you can't find it in a retail outlet, it can be ordered by calling (800) 765-4223.
 
Playing With Fear
 Arachnophobia is the unnatural fear of spiders. If you don't have it now, you may after playing the computer game of the same name.
Based on the popular movie of last year, the program sends you to seven different towns to try to destroy the offspring of a venomous South American spider. If you succeed (I didn't), you go to the jungle home of the species to try to eradicate it.
If this sounds like fun, Arachnophobia is available for MS-DOS computers for $49.95 or, in a package with the Sound Source, which greatly improves such sounds as spiders frying, for $69.95. There are also versions for the Amiga, coming soon, and Commodore 64/128. The grisly thing is a product of Walt Disney Computer Software, a division of the Walt Disney Company, of Burbank, Calif.
Also from Disney is Mickey's Jigsaw Puzzles, 15 puzzles that can be put together on screen. When completed, the scene becomes an animated sequence. Intended for children 5 years old and older, the program can be tailored for the user; puzzles can have as few as 4 to as many as 64 pieces, and there are three levels of difficulty.
The puzzles can also be printed out for coloring. The suggested retail price is $49.95, or $69.95 with the Sound Source.
 
Wheel of Fortune Revised
 GameTek, of North Miami Beach, Fla., has enhanced its Wheel of Fortune game and renamed it Wheel of Fortune Featuring Vanna White. The game is played pretty much as it is on television, and the bonus round now incorporates changes made in the show: for one, the player starts off with N, S, L, R, T and E already selected.
The DOS version of Wheel should be in the stores next month, at $49.95, and a Nintendo version is due in November. By now, Pat Sajak probably wishes he had taken the letter-turning job.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;
Test-Drive for Software

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS

 BODY:
A PICTURE used to be worth a thousand words. Today, in the age of personal computers, a graphical display is worth a kilobyte of text.
At least that's the premise behind Select Demos, a CD-ROM product that contains more than a thousand graphical demonstrations of popular (and not so popular) MS-DOS and Windows programs. It requires an I.B.M. PC or compatible equipped with a CD-ROM drive. 
 At the introductory price of $99 for the disk, Select Demos can be either an economical alternative to spending afternoons going from computer store to computer store to test-drive software or a cheap way to entice people to spend hundreds of additional dollars on software they never knew they needed.
Many software companies offer their prospective customers a so-called demo disk, a diskette that shows off the features of a program in a way that no printed product review or box blurbs can. The user plugs the diskette into his or her PC, types "demo" or some other command and watches as the software struts its stuff, often with flashy animation and sound.
Computer Library, the New York City company that also produces a CD-ROM product called Computer Select, has persuaded more than 600 software companies to put their demo disks on this single shiny platter. There are more than a 1,000 demo programs in all, from companies including Aldus, Ashton-Tate, Borland, Broderbund, I.B.M., Microsoft, Lotus, Symantec-Norton, and Wordperfect.
There are also lots of demos from companies that are less well known, which is a good thing. This disk might allow a PC user to see products that otherwise might never show up on the radar screen.
In the best demos, the software company simply gives the user a copy of the real software, but cripples it in some way that renders it useless for day-to-day operation. A word processing program demo might not print, or a data base might not accept more than a dozen entries. All the commands work, through, and the user gets a good sense of whether to invest in the full program.
In the worst demos, the company just uses a bit of animation and fancy graphics to make a slide-show sales pitch. Product features are listed and promises are made, but the user does not really get a chance to play with the software or even see how it operates. Slightly more than half the demos on Select Demo fall into this category.
Jonathan Pollard, director of development for Computer Library, a division of the Ziff Communications Company, said companies were encouraged to contribute crippled software rather than the automated slide shows.
A handful of companies also decided to contribute actual working programs, functionally the same as one would find in the stores, but without printed documentation.
Hayes Microcomputer Products contributed Smartcom EZ, a simple, $49 communications program, presumably in the hope that users would like it enough to go out and buy the more powerful Smartcom package.
The Checkfree Corporation, maker of software that allows PC users to pay bills electronically, offers its $29.95 software, but the catch is that there is a monthly fee for use.
And for those who are either a year late in paying their taxes or a few months early in evaluating programs to handle next year's tax returns, there are four 1990 tax preparation programs on the disk: Andrew Tobias TaxCut, Macintax for WIndows, Turbotax Personal and 1040.
The pick of the pack, however, is Geoworks Ensemble, a collection of applications that works essentially like Microsoft's Windows, but without the need for a powerful PC and lots of memory. Ensemble is a so-called multitasking environment, which means that more than one program can be running on screen at once, each in its own window.
Ensemble is more than a "poor man's Windows," though. It comes with programs that handle word processing and simple desktop publishing, file management, communications, drawing, scheduling, and personal secretary stuff. There is also a solitaire game. The choices are much more limited than for Microsoft Windows, which has sold 4 million copies and drawn commitments from hundreds of software companies, but perhaps Geoworks is using Select Demos to spread the word.
Geoworks has contributed version 1.0 of Ensemble to this disk; the current version is 2.0. Still, it is a great idea to test the program on Select Demos to see if it is worth going out to buy the newer version.
Mr. Pollard of Computer Library said no decision had been made on whether to offer regular updates of Select Demos, or how much to charge for them. If this new CD-ROM format is a success, which it deserves to be, it would be nice to see quarterly or semiannual updates, sold either individually or as a subscription.
Select Demo's CD-ROM companion, Computer Select, is a compilation of computer-related reviews taken from the past 12 months of publication of 1,300 magazines, newspapers and industry newsletters. Computer Select is sold on a subscription basis for $995 a year.
Computer Library can be reached at (212) 503-4400 or (800) 848-1472, extension 107.

HEADLINE: Democrats Attack Bush on Economy As Spotlight Shifts to Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Democratic Governors tried to escalate the pressure on President Bush today over his handling of the economy and other domestic issues, but found themselves overshadowed by a foreign policy crisis that threatened to freeze Presidential politics once again.
The Democrats, gathered here for the annual summer meeting of the National Governors' Association, passed a resolution assailing Mr. Bush for his "refusal to recognize that 8.5 million Americans out of work is a tragedy and an emergency." They urged him to reverse his decision last week to block the spending of money needed for extended unemployment benefits authorized by Congress for more than three million people out of work for more than half a year. 
 It was part of the Democratic Party's orchestrated effort to highlight Mr. Bush's domestic record, which it considers his Achilles' heel. But it came as the crisis in the Soviet Union turned the spotlight once again on foreign policy.
Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, chairman of the Republican Governors' Association, offered a preview of the political uses of the Soviet crisis, asserting, "We're lucky to have George Bush in a position to deal with this."
Some Democrats acknowledged that the developments in the Soviet Union, like the war in the Persian Gulf, will play to Mr. Bush's strengths, at least in the short term. "Right now the ball goes back in his court, where his strength is," said Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida.
There is a further danger for the Democrats: the possibility that the Soviet crisis will slow the race for the Democratic nomination, which was already stalled for months by the Gulf war and the President's towering wartime popularity. But this possibility was strenuously dismissed today by Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, who was here to brief the Democratic governors on the 1992 campaign.
"I don't think it has anything to do with freezing partisan politics," Mr. Brown told reporters. "If anything, it raises a lot of questions in an area that is supposed to be George Bush's strength, the foreign policy arena."
The chairman also said that while the Soviet developments were "a matter of grave concern" he was "not sure" the American people felt a "sense of crisis" or "wartime footing."
But the immediate political impact of the crisis was apparent in the caution of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, a potential contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Mr. Clinton, who only yesterday was pressing the case against Mr. Bush, both foreign and domestic, was subdued and careful on the Soviet crisis today.
"We ought to give the President a decent breathing space to find out what the facts are and make a statement on behalf of the United States," Mr. Clinton said. "Then the rest of us can decide what we think about that."
He added, "I think people like me shouldn't say much right now until we find out exactly what's happened and we give the President a chance to asess it and announce a policy."
The four-day meeting of the nation's governors, which concludes Tuesday, has been dominated by the health care issue and bipartisan panels on a number of other policy issues. But it has also featured careful partisan maneuvering. On Sunday, Democratic Governors assailed the Administration's progress on health care, and today they focused on its handling of the unemployment issue.
Mr. Bush announced Friday that he would make the symbolic gesture of signing a bill that would provide extended unemployment benefits, but would block actual spending of the bill's $5.8 billion in benefits. "I won't bust the budget," he told a news conference at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me., saying he would not sign a declaration of budget emergency necessary to spend the money.
In the resolution approved today, the Democratic Governors urged the President to reconsider his decision, declaring, "Just as President Bush had the wisdom to help those in need in Israel, Turkey and Iraq, he should move immediately to help victims of this yearlong recession in America."

HEADLINE: Gambling Raid Angers Mining Town

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALLACE, Idaho

 BODY:
Well before Idaho was a state, there were gambling houses, brothels and boisterous saloons in this storied mining country in the Coeur d'Alene Mountains.
So it wasn't exactly a surprise when, on the morning of June 23, Federal agents from all over the West raided virtually every bar here in Shoshone County and found more than 200 video poker machines. Gambling, local officials say, is one of the few industries that have yet to die in the area. 
 What is so perplexing to residents of the panhandle of north Idaho, and to outsiders as well, is why the Federal Bureau of Investigation used such a show of force. The raiding party on that Sunday comprised 150 agents, and now Federal lawyers are moving in court to take control of the places that were raided, a move that would make the Government owner of every bar in Wallace.
To a community that considers itself on its knees, racked by a series of economic and environmental calamities, the raid has provoked protests and stirred old animosities.
 
Machines Not Target, U.S. Says
 In an age when banking scandals have cost the nation's taxpayers billions of dollars, many residents here say the Government has spent far too much time and money on video poker machines in a crippled mining town.
Federal officials say the focus of the raid was not so much the machines as the local authorities who had allowed them to flourish.
The raid was the biggest single Federal law-enforcement raid ever in the Rocky Mountain region, said James T. Screen, a spokesman for the F.B.I. in Salt Lake City. Not since the late 19th century, when Federal troops were sent here to battle union organizers, have so many Government agents moved so heavily against one community in the region.
Residents of this valley, which once produced more silver than any other place on earth but is now poverty-stricken and polluted, say the raid can be explained more by the area's reputation than by any real criminal enterprise.
 
Panhandle Goes Its Own Way
 "Here you've got a community that's always lived a little bit outside the law," said Chris Stuecker, a local contractor who specializes in renovating historic houses. "And then you get an outside agency, like the F.B.I., that doesn't understand that we're just average folks, and they hear about all these gambling devices and it gets them going."
Mr. Stuecker helped to organize a rally last month to protest the raid, and about 200 people attended.
This town of about 1,000 people is a national historic site, an example of the boom-and-bust mining towns that used to dot mountain valleys throughout the West. Even the newer buildings here look archaic. But, Federal officials say, it is not just architecture that is frozen in time in the Silver Valley: so are attitudes.
Many residents and some public officials of the valley admit that their county is different from most. Idaho is better known for potatoes and Mormons than gambling and prostitution. But the northern part of the state, in the mountainous panhandle, has always gone its own way.
When the silver mines were running rich, the area was full of rough-edged men who spent their earnings on the basic vices of typical mining and timber camps -- gambling and prostitution. Once, more than a dozen brothels operated in Wallace, local residents say.
But the Silver Valley has changed dramatically in the last decade. As the mines have closed and toxic levels of lead have been found in local streams and soil, Shoshone County has lost more than 27 percent of its residents, down to about 14,000 now. Unemployment has been running at more than 20 percent, and last year the last known brothel went out of business. "It died a natural death," said Dick Caron, who owns the Wallace Corner, a general store.
 
'Corruption of Public Officials'
 Federal agents say local authorities have long tolerated the traditional forms of vice here, and the raid was intended to end that. "Corruption of public officials was the focus," said Mr. Screen of the F.B.I.
The case is being handled by the Justice Department's Division of Public Integrity, a unit in Washington, D.C., used primarily to prosecute corrupt elected officials. Department officials would not comment on the investigation.
Grand jury proceedings are under way in Boise, but no one has yet been indicted.
 
Agents Confiscate $500,000
 The 150 F.B.I. agents raided 58 bars, breaking down doors and windows in some cases. So many agents were needed, Mr. Screen said, because there were so many bars.
The agents confiscated more than $500,000 in cash from various bars and seized all the video poker machines. The machines are legal in Idaho but are considered unlawful by the state if they are used for actual gambling -- that is, if the bar pays players for points scored on the machines.
 
'We're Talking Quarter Games'
 Rather than expressing outrage at crimes that the authorities say were going on in their midst, Wallace residents have directed their anger at the F.B.I.
"What we have in these saloons is no more harmful than bowling on Sundays," Mr. Caron said. "It's petty, insignificant, victimless entertainment. We're talking quarter games."
Jack Rose, the Shoshone County Prosecutor, said, "I think the F.B.I. would be better served trying to solve the many killings back in their headquarters city, the murder capital of the nation."
Mr. Rose said that he had done nothing wrong and that he was not aware of any gambling on the video poker machines.
F.B.I. agents, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. Rose was one of the public officials under investigation. Justice Department officials refused to comment.
T-shirts criticizing the F.B.I. quickly sold out at Dickison's Trading Post here. A local newspaper, The Silver Valley Voice, published a satirical front-page picture of a clownish-looking man, posing in fake nose and glasses, wearing an F.B.I. hat and shorts while standing in front of a bar.
Several hundred people have signed a petition calling for a Congressional investigation of the raid; it accuses the agency of selective enforcement of the law.
 
'Colorful Way of Life'
 Video poker machines can be found throughout the state, said Keith Mathews, assistant director of the Idaho Department of Law Enforcement. "I don't think that Shoshone County is any different than any other part of Idaho," he said.
The area's Representative in Congress, Larry LaRocco, a freshman Democrat from Boise, said the raid left him with many questions.
"I wonder if they are using an F-117 when a small rifle would do the job," Mr. LaRocco said, adding that the Silver Valley has long had a "live and let live" attitude and "colorful way of life" that local officials have tolerated.
Mr. Caron, the merchant, said, "We might be hicks in the sticks, but we know what overkill is."

HEADLINE: FLAWS ARE FOUND IN JOBS PROGRAM

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Congressional investigators studying a $4 billion Federal job training program have found that women and blacks are more likely than white men to be channeled into lower-paying jobs.
The investigators said they also found instances of blatant racism and sexism by the private companies that provide classroom and the on-the-job training in the program, which serves economically disadvantaged people, dislocated workers and others who face significant employment barriers. 
 In the study, which is not yet complete, investigators with the General Accounting Office examined programs established in 16 states through the Job Training Partnership Act.
It said the findings did not mean that civil rights violations had occurred, and it cited factors that accounted for disparities in the treatment of blacks and women. In some cases, the study said, the clients felt more comfortable in jobs that happened to pay less, or they shunned the training that would enable them to get higher-paying work.
 
Quayle's Top Achievement
 The jobs program, which Vice President Dan Quayle has said was the most important achievement in his eight years in the Senate, provides Federal money to the states. While state and local governments have ultimate responsibility for the management of the local program, they are run primarily by private industry councils. Ten million people have participated in the programs since they began in 1983.
The General Accounting Office obtained data from the 1989 program year, the most recent information available, on adult participants who had a high school education. The data came from 227 local projects, about a third of the programs nationwide.
The study, to be completed by February, will include information about minorities other than blacks and additional information about disparities in treatment by sex.
In one unidentified project, the study said, 55 percent of the white men in classroom training received electronics instruction, and this led to jobs that paid the highest wages, an average of $7.50 an hour.
But among the black men in classrooms, only 26 percent received electronics training. Forty-two percent of them received training in health or food services, and this led to jobs paying an average of less than $6 an hour.
In 11 percent to 20 percent of the projects, the study found, blacks were more likely than whites to get assistance only in searching for jobs, without any classroom or on-the-job training. When blacks did receive training, it was usually for lower-paying jobs, the study found.
The study said that women were more likely than men to receive classroom training, but that the training was for lower-paying clerical or health jobs.
 
Defense of the Program
 Assistant Secretary of Labor Roberts T. Jones defended the Job Training Partnership Act programs and said the G.A.O. report "at no point recognizes that minorities and women generally have less education and work force experience." He said minority members and women "start further behind, but make greater progress" because of the program.
Mr. Jones said that the disparities in wages cited in the study mirrored those in the work force in general and that the data in the study did not support "any findings of overt or systematic discrimination" against minorities or women.
"There's no question that this program does better for all these groups than they normally experience in the work force," he said. "It doesn't excuse discrimination, but let's be careful about what we're attacking. This program is doing better for these groups than anything we've had."
Mr. Jones said the Secretary of Labor, nevertheless, had asked the department's civil rights division to review all grant recipients to insure that they were in compliance with civil rights requirements.
 
Clients Stuck in Stereotypes
 The General Accounting Office, the investigating arm of Congress, found that participants sometimes requested jobs that were lower-paying than others.
"Some of the clients selected stereotypical jobs," said the head of the study, Franklin Frazier, director for education and employment issues for the G.A.O. "Someone might walk in and say, 'I want to be a truck driver,' even if he knows he would have a brighter future if he received computer training, or someone might say, 'I want a job right away. I don't want training.' "
But the study also found blatant racism and sexism affecting the work of some of the local programs, called service delivery areas, or S.D.A.'s.
"Some employers told the S.D.A.'s that they didn't want them to send out a black or a Hispanic or a woman," Mr. Frazier said. "And in some cases, whenever the S.D.A.'s would send minorities to the employer, none of them would be hired."
Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, who ordered the study as chairman of the Government Operations Committee, said the program should not be striving to simply put people in jobs, but rather should be trying to improve workers' skills and put them into the best possible jobs.
"You can process a lot of short-order cooks and fast-food processors and elevator operators," Mr. Conyers said, "but what that really does is downgrade people and hold them back from realizing their potential."

HEADLINE: Gorbachev's Loss, and Ours;
The Lunge for Legitimacy

 BODY:
The world stopped yesterday in the Soviet Union. The coup against Mikhail Gorbachev may not have been a surprise, exactly, but it's still a shock. The Grand Bargain advocated by some Westerners to aid Soviet reform might never have worked; but now the world is threatened with a grievous loss.
Everybody knew the Soviet President was walking a tightrope. And there were warnings of a coup, like the one last Friday from Mr. Gorbachev's old ally Aleksandr Yakovlev. But even so, after standing at the nuclear brink for decades, Americans were just starting to trust the forces of change that Mr. Gorbachev set free. 
 Now, suddenly, the reckless takeover by members of a discredited Communist old guard imperils the surge of progress. They may yet fail, if the Soviet public sweeps them aside and resumes the march to political and economic freedom. But even if the coup lasts, the plotters lack the legitimacy and the vision needed to succeed.
The likely catalyst for the coup was today's scheduled signing of a new union treaty redefining relations between the central Government and its restive republics. That treaty would have devolved power from the center, diminishing the power of the hard-liners.
And that was just the beginning of the end for the old guard. A companion agreement would empower the republics to collect taxes and share only a portion of revenues with Moscow. That would eventually have starved the military-industrial complex. And local elections this fall in Russia could have pushed most party hacks out of power.
But there is not a word of these realities from the plotters. Instead they lunge for legitimacy, trying in the first instance to justify their rash action with the kind of big lie made famous by past totalitarians: Mr. Gorbachev supposedly was sidelined for "health reasons."
For those who doubt that, the plotters appeal to the desire of some citizens for order over change. And if that's not reason enough, the new State Committee for the State of Emergency recoils in horror from "the chaotic, spontaneous slide toward a market." But the plotters do not stop at large, labored justifications. They rail also against shameless "politicking." They praise political relations that have "passed the centuries-long test of history," which sounds, bizarrely, as though these old Communists claim the blessing of the czars.
Not only that; the plotters justify their action by citing a need to resist the spreading "propaganda of sex and violence." And then, reflecting their own privileged station, they complain that "Only yesterday a Soviet person finding himself abroad felt himself a worthy citizen of an influential and respected state." Now he is "often a second-rate foreigner."
One way or another, they are likely to lose. They may not be able to stay in power long; the Soviet people may already have developed a preference for robust, even raucous politicking over the security of Big Brother. But even if the coup stands, there is no reason to believe that the new State Committee can manage the shrinking economy and the swelling thirst for autonomy. It is hard to see how the plotters can restore the old central command system. Neither can they retrieve the Soviet position in Eastern Europe.
Mr. Gorbachev and his fellow reformers have faced the future, knowing there is no choice but perestroika to build a better life for the Soviet people. The outside world had a monumental opportunity to help him win. There will be intense debate in the West over whether, by forfeiting that chance, the world also has lost. For now, the Soviet people are on their own.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Last Act

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
For six years now, ever since Mikhail Gorbachev came to power, the United States and other Western governments have done their best to avoid facing the one most important truth about the Soviet Union.
Now that reality, which Mr. Gorbachev knew better than any man on earth, has led to the coup against him. It is this: The Soviet Union is not a country but a collection of nationalities forced to live under a system of control that rests on a Communist Party whose own authority and protection are provided by the police organization known as the K.G.B. 
 All through its history, the K.G.B. has correctly described itself as the sword and shield of the Communist Party. The party and its police have been inseparably interwoven, parts of a single instrument of domination.
Mr. Gorbachev came up through this apparatus. He was placed in power by the party-K.G.B. to try to save a collapsing economy -- of course, without destroying the whole system.
He did his best. For most of his rule, he had the support of the party and the police, as they had his.
Mr. Gorbachev did not challenge the K.G.B. But he dreamed an impossible dream -- to bring about reform within the party-K.G.B. system.
The system itself began to fall apart when the move toward sovereignty -- and eventual independence -- of the nationalities became unstoppable. The party-K.G.B. complex, no dreamers, faced the choice of surrendering power and dachas, or fighting.
Mr. Gorbachev's failure to confront the K.G.B. -- or demand an accounting of the murders it carried out for one Kremlin regime after another -- is understandable. Seeing it as the enemy would have been like looking at his own hand and wondering how to cut it off.
But the West had no such excuse. The West's failure to see and state the truth about the Soviet system was based on short-term self-interest and long-term blindness, a congenital political disease in the West. President Bush himself fantasized that if only he became friendly enough with Mr. Gorbachev he could influence Soviet destiny -- quite as if the sword and shield never existed.
The U.S. Government didn't mention it. Last month, after I wrote a column emphasizing the power and danger of the K.G.B., some friends in government said oh, no, the K.G.B. was finished. But they forgot to tell that to Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, its chief, so he went on to lead the coup.
For years, Mr. Bush made Mr. Gorbachev the center of American Soviet policy and tied everything to him, including his Administration's reputation for judgment. The New World Order looks a little strange these days: Saddam Hussein rules in Baghdad, and Stalin calls out the tanks in Moscow.
History gives Mr. Bush another chance. My Soviet friends who have spent their lives fighting Communism believe that although the Soviet tragedy is not over, the last act has begun. They pray that the U.S. will refuse to recognize the coup government, however long it lasts. They believe that parts of the army command will refuse to obey party-K.G.B. orders, that many Soviet soldiers will refuse to kill their countrymen and that neither Boris Yeltsin nor the millions of Soviet democrats will surrender to the coup.
They believe that the coup will eventually fail, perhaps soon, and that a new government will emerge, breaking with the party-K.G.B. -- and the Gorbachev era of trying to bring reform within the system.
They think that unless the U.S. intervenes once more to save it, the Soviet Union will disappear into the annals of failed empires. It will be replaced by an association of 12 to 15 former republics, joined in an economic union with Eastern Europe.
It won't be neat and always stable, but it certainly will be a lot more peaceful than a system that gobbled up Eastern Europe, kept the world on military alert for half a century and slaughtered tens of millions of people trapped within its borders.
To help, the West should not only refuse to recognize the coup government but increase its contacts with Mr. Yeltsin -- and all the democratic groups of the Soviet Union.
But the policy of tying political and economic aid to one Kremlin leader has failed. It should not be tried again -- even if Mr. Gorbachev should somehow be politically resuscitated by his friends, or by the sword and shield.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Plunge in Rush to Buy Bills

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Mikhail S. Gorbachev's stunning ouster as president of the Soviet Union sent investors from around the world running for the safe, secure haven of Treasury securities yesterday.
As often occurs at times of crisis, short-term Treasury bills were the investment of choice, and interest rates fell sharply. Three-month bill rates fell well below 5 percent for a while yesterday, the first time they have been below that level since after the stock market crash in October 1987. Meanwhile, bond yields dropped below 8 percent for a time, at one point falling as low as 7.92 percent, their lowest of the year. 
 Traders said that profit taking began to emerge once it became clear that stock prices, which plummeted early in the day, had stabilized and were on the rebound.
 
'Things Have Quieted Down'
 "When the stock market stabilized and started to improve, there was heavy retail selling of everything from bills to bonds," one government bond trader said. "After a chaotic morning, things have quieted down a lot."
The movement into Treasury issues on such a tumultuous day seemed to serve as a counterpoint to the recent misdeeds at Salomon Brothers, acts that prompted some critics to question whether the giant firm's transgressions had compromised the market's integrity.
"If you recognize that the Government market is the highest-quality market, I don't think what happened at Salomon Brothers affects investment decisions that much," said Rao Chalansani, chief investment strategist at the Kemper Securities Group in Chicago. "The government market is much too big to be influenced by one party."
Traders said the sharp downward move in short-term bill rates yesterday made bidding difficult at yesterday's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills. But the auction results were about as anticipated, the traders said, and demand for the new securities was good.
 
Restrictions on Salomon
 As mandated by the Government on Sunday, Salomon Brothers was prevented from placing bids for clients at the bill auctions.
At the auctions, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.17 percent, down sharply from an average rate of 5.30 percent at last week's sale. It is the lowest rate on a three-month bill since the sale on Oct. 26, 1987, when three-month bills were sold at an average rate of 5.12 percent.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.23 percent, down from an average rate of 5.39 percent a week ago. The new rate is the lowest since Oct. 27, 1986, when six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 5.23 percent.
The unsettled situation in the Soviet Union increases the odds that short-term rates will fall further, analysts said.
Some added that the turmoil could be yet another reason why the Federal Reserve Board at its policy-making meeting today might decide to lower its target on the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market as well as its discount rate.
"The Soviet situation clearly creates uncertainty, both among consumers and businesses," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International. "When that happens, people tend to postpone decisions. To me the coup raises the possibility that the Fed might lower both the funds rate and the discount rate."
 
Money Flowing to U.S.
 Aside from being a mild negative for the American economy, a development that would favor lower interest rates, analysts said the Soviet situation would almost certainly induce some money invested in Europe to flow to dollar-denominated assets like fixed-income securities.
"International capital flows into the United States should heighten," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities. "Everything augurs for a firm bid on the bond, as well as the dollar."
After moving to new highs early in the session, bond prices ended lower on the day.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 7/32, down 1/4 point, to yield 8.10 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 10/32, down 2/32, to yield 7.82 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 1/4, up 1/8 point, to yield 6.18 percent.
In the secondary market for short-term Treasury bills, three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 5.08 percent, down 14 basis points, or 14-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 9 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.09 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Florida Power and Light Company, a unit of the FPL Group, offered $150 million worth of 30-year first-mortgage bonds through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9 1/8 percent securities were priced at 99, to yield 9.223 percent, 1.12 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are nonrefundable for five years, are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In conjunction with its taxable offering, Florida Power and Light also offered $51.9 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds at various prices through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. These securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices of most issues were little changed in quiet trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up 1/8 point.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Excerpts From Bush News Conference on Soviet Coup: Hope and Warnings

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference this morning in Kennebunkport, Me.:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
While we're still watching the situation unfold -- and it still is unfolding -- all is not clear -- it seems clearer all the time that contrary to official statements out of Moscow that this move was extra-constitutional; outside of the constitutional provisions for constitutional change. 
 Clearly, it's a disturbing development, there's not question about that. And it could have serious consequences for the Soviet society, and in Soviet relations with other countries, including the United States.
 President Gorbachev is clearly an historic figure, one who's led the Soviet Union toward reform domestically, and toward a constructive and cooperative role in the international arena. And it's important to keep in mind the enormous changes that have taken place towards openness, towards reform, the changes in Eastern Europe, the new-found cooperation with the United States and others in the Gulf, and many other areas. There's a whole new era of cooperation, and we don't want to see that change, obviously. Now, Gorbachev's contributions have laid a foundation for progress that I am convinced the people in the Soviet Union want to see continue.
 
Calls to World Leaders
 This morning I've been in touch with other world leaders. I just hung up from talking to Chancellor Kohl. I talked to President Mitterrand. I talked to Prime Minister John Major. I'm sure I'll be talking to others today. I've talked to the Secretary of State.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 So what we'll do is follow the events very carefully as they unfold in order to determine the appropriate response that we, in consultation with our allies, should make. And we expect that the Soviet Union will live up fully to its international obligations, and clearly, any commitments that are outstanding on the part of the West will be judged and acted on in accordance with that statement that the Soviet Government must live up to its obligations.
 Obviously, the West is not going to retreat from its principles of reform, openness, commitment to democracy. And there's a lot at stake here. I don't know whether to take heart or not from Yanayev's statement that this does not mean turning back the reforms, but there was such a statement made by him. So the situation is still quite murky inside the Soviet Union.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Assessment of Yanayev
 Q: Mr. President, you know Yanayev. You mentioned his report the last time you were in Moscow. What do you make of him? . . .
 A: Well, my gut instinct was that he has a certain commitment to reform. The book on it so far has been something to the contrary, but I think, if not he -- him that is -- that he that is calling the shots, and you see some of the other individuals involved. They have been real hard-liners. One of the reasons that we have conducted our policy the way we have is to encourage reform and democracy, and I've said over and over again that we did not want to see a coup backed by the K.G.B. and the military, and apparently that is what is under way. I think it's also important to note that coups can fail.
 They can take over at first, and then they run up against the will of the people. So it's too early to say, but let's hope that Yanayev . . . was speaking from conviction . . . that this will not mean . . . setting back reform and commitment to go forward.

 	 	 		.. .	 	 Q: Mr. President, have U.S. forces been placed on any heightened alert because of this?
 A: No. . . .
 Q: Has the United States detected any heightened alert on the part of Soviet forces in Central Europe or in the Soviet Union?
 A: Well, I don't think there have been any changes there, but . . . certainly we've seen heightened use of Soviet force in Moscow and outside . . .
 
Background of Coup
 Q: What do you believe the motivation is, sir, behind the coup? Why did they remove him?
 A: We don't know that. . . . Clearly, some of the hard-liners have been concerned about the rapidity of reform. They've been concerned about the demise of the Communist Party per se. And . . . I think they've also been concerned about the Soviet economy . . . But the people's commitment to reform and democracy and openness is very profound. . . . I'm inclined to believe that, when people understand freedom and taste freedom and see democracy in action, that they're not going to want to change.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 Q: Mr. President, do you actually know who's in charge right now and, more specifically, who's in charge of the Soviet nuclear arsenal? Is that a great concern?
 A: Well, I don't imagine there's been any change in that. And we don't know who's in charge, except that they say Mr. Yanayev is in charge.
 . . .
 Q: Are you going to stop the process of economic cooperation that's been unfolding in recent months?
 A: I think things will be on hold. If we're going to set back democracy, set back reform, obviously not only the United States, but Europe will put things on hold as well.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Call for General Strike
 Q: Mr. Yeltsin seems to have called for a general strike in protest. Do you support that call?
 A: Well, we'll just see what happens on that.
 Q: Mr. Yeltsin has said that the Russian federation will not abide by the new decrees. Do you support that, sir?
 A: Well, I support what I've outlined here as our principles. And certainly I can understand where an elected leader like Mr. Yeltsin is coming from. . . . And I think what he's doing is simply expressing the will of the people there to have these reforms and have democracy, the steps already taken to democracy strengthened. And I hope that people heed his call.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 Q: Mr. President, what do you feel you could do at this point to effect events in the Soviet Union, if anything?
 A: There's very little we can do except to reiterate, in total cooperation with the European allies, our commitment to these principles of reform, and openness and democratic change.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 Q: Mr. President, you said the economic aid was on hold. What about the START treaty? Will you hold back on that as well?
 A: No. These treaties are in the interest of the United States, clearly. And they have said that all treaties will be abided by, and that's good. We don't want to go back to the cold war days, and we're not going to do that. . . . We're not going to go back to seeing Europe as it used to be, with Soviet forces into -- all through Eastern Europe.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 Q: How can you be sure the hard-line government will honor the terms of the treaty?
 A: Well, hard-line governments in the past adhered to certain treaties that were enacted, and so I don't think we need to raise that specter at this point. Obviously, if they weren't adhering to the treaty, . . . that would be a whole different ball game.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
A Militry Threat?
 Q: Mr. President, you say you don't want to go back to the cold war days. But at this point, do you feel that the Soviet Union may again be a threat to the United States?
 A: A threat in what sense?
 Q: Military threat.
 A: Well, I think we've always based our defense posture on the fact that Soviet missiles are aimed against the United States. One of the reasons I rejoiced in getting a strategic arms talk is that there . . . will be fewer missiles aimed against the United States. But nobody in their fondest dreams has suggested that that is not a problem.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 And if you think there's some concerns here about this, try talking to the Germans about it. They don't want to see the clock set back. Nor do the Eastern Europeans. . . . I don't want to . . . act like we're going to go back into a status quo ante; go back and encourage, through reckless statements, something to take place that would set the clock back to where it was before these changes under Gorbachev took place.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Defense Chief Saw Gorbachev Hours Before Coup

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The Soviet Defense Minister, Gen. Dmitri T. Yazov, flew to the Crimea on Sunday and met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hours before Mr. Yazov and other senior officials staged a coup and removed Mr. Gorbachev from power, according to Bush Administration officials.
 The nature of the conversations between the two men is not known, according to these officials, and General Yazov's flight has become a critical indicator only in hindsight as the Administration sought today to reconstruct the events of the weekend to understand the coup, which caught the world by surprise. 
Administration analysts today put two likely interpretations on General Yazov's mission. The first is that he flew to the Crimea simply to inform Mr. Gorbachev that he was being removed from power and placed under house arrest.
 If this was the case, an official said, the general may also have wanted to attend to security arrangements personally to insure the loyalty of forces that were to detain Mr. Gorbachev.
 
An Alternative Hypothesis
 The second interpretation, Administration officials said, was that General Yazov was engaged in last-minute negotiations to bring Mr. Gorbachev into the conservative camp and thus prevent the scheduled signing this week of a new union treaty that would have significantly diminished Moscow's power over the Soviet republics.
 "There are a number of things that indicate he was approached," a State Department official said, referring to Mr. Gorbachev. "But there's no evidence so far that rules out either hypothesis."
 "The other thing is that if they are going to go down and arrest him," the official continued, "Yazov would want to go down and make sure it happens."
 This official also said that today's statement by Acting President Gennadi I. Yanayev expressing the "hope that Mikhail Gorbachev, as soon as he feels better, will take up his office" was another indication that the conservatives may still be engaged in discussions with him.
 
Precipitous Action Seen
 Adding to the sense that the coup plotters acted precipitously, President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said Moscow's belated deployment of military forces to control the capital suggested that the coup plotters "had not completed their preparations before they did it."
 "It's interesting to note that in ordinary coups the tanks move about the time an announcement is made," Mr. Scowcroft said to reporters aboard Air Force One, adding that there was no military activity in Moscow early today when Tass, the Soviet press agency, announced that a State Committee for the State of Emergency had taken power. "The tanks didn't move for number of hours afterward," Mr. Scowcroft added.
 United States intelligence agencies were not able to give the Administration any specific advance warning about the coup, according to officials in a number of agencies that receive intelligence reporting.
 The coup caught both the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency off guard, according to Administration officials, though both agencies have been warning for months that Mr. Gorbachev faced formidable conservatives forces opposed to his reform campaign.
 "Although the intelligence community did not know the date and the time of the coup, there has been reporting on the possibility of a hard-liner crackdown for more than a year," an official said.
 "It was known that the military and security forces were unhappy with their diminishing role under a relatively weak center," the official said, adding that the hard-liners had also sought to help create a crisis atmosphere to justify their actions.
 Some officials inside and outside the Administration said warnings from prominent Soviet figures, such as former Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, who resigned his Kremlin post last week, should have been taken more seriously. Both men in recent weeks have been forecasting a hard-line crackdown.
 In Washington today, a former National Security Council staff member, Vincent Cannistraro, also asserted that raw intelligence available to Administration analysts would have sounded alarm bells earlier.
 Speaking to reporters before he left Kennebunkport, Me., to return to Washington, President Bush said there had "always been a concern" that Mr. Gorbachev would be overthrown.
 
Military Crisis Avoided
 Administration officials sought to play down any prospect that the Soviet Union's internal crisis could become a military crisis affecting its external relations, especially with the United States.
 Although the Soviet Union and its former allies in Eastern Europe have dismantled the Warsaw Pact military alliance, an estimated 250,000 Soviet troops remain in eastern Germany and 50,000 are in Poland.
 Pentagon officials said they had received no formal or informal warning from Soviet military leaders that a coup was under way. There has been no alert or unusual activity among the Soviet Union's strategic nuclear forces, which are the focus of the most intense intelligence monitoring.
 Mr. Bush said United States forces had not gone to any high state of alert, but officials said intelligence monitoring had increased sharply. After Mr. Bush's remarks, Mr. Scowcroft emphasized to reporters that "this is not a military crisis."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Viktor Komplektov, Soviet Ambassador, leaving the State Department after meeting Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Accords Threatened by Soviet Discord"
 
MAJOR PENDING AGREEMENTS AND ARRANGEMENTS
 
Treaty on Conventional Forces in Europe
 Conventional arms reduction treaty, with heaviest cuts in Soviet forces, especially tanks, has already been submitted to Senate. Action was likely this fall, but now is likely to be put off.
 
Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty
 First pact to lower the numbers of nuclear warheads, especially those carried by intercontinental ballistic missiles. Signed at the Moscow summit meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev, the act is being refined to correct textual problems. Was likely to be considered by the Senate early next year; may be delayed further.
 
Trade
 A three-year trade agreement granting most-favored-nation status to the Soviet Union, and establishing various other conditions, such as copyright protection for literary and other cultural works and computer software, to promote trade and U.S. investment. Approval was considered almost certain after the Soviet Union passed a law formalizing free movement into and out of the country. The measure was considered likely to have been approved before Congress adjourned this fall; now it seems sure to be put off.
 
Joint Venture
 In the largest Soviet-American business venture ever, the Chevron Corporation planned to develop huge oilfields in Kazakhstan. It was unclear what effect the ouster of President Gorbachev would have on the deal.
 
Grain Sales
 President Bush has authorized $600 million in loan guarantees for selling grain to the SovietUnion and planned to authorize another $500 million in October and $400 million next February. Delays possible to put pressure on the Soviet Union, although grain-state lawmakers are considered likely to resist.
Lesser Agreements Signed at Summit
 
Airplane Hijacking
 Promises each country will use force and assist the other in criminal proceedings if a plane from one country is hijacked to the other.
 
Disaster Assistance
 Establishes exchanges of information and assistance.
 
Economic Assistance
 Approves U.S. technical assistance to the Soviet Union and its 15 constituent republics.
 
Medical Supplies
 Allows U.S. to fill critical shortages.
 
AREAS OF COOPERATION AND POTENTIAL AGREEMENT
 
Regional Conflicts
 Both superpowers have been trying to resolve conflicts in the Middle East by working together to encourage a peace conference that would bring Israel and Arab nations face to face, and have been urging Vietnam and other parties to the civil war in Cambodia to make peace.
 
Poison Gas
 The two countries have been negotiating bilateral and multilateral agreements to eliminate most chemical weapons.
 
AREAS OF POTENTIAL COOPERATION
 
 Discussions are in the early stages on whether the two nations can work together to limit the spread of nuclear weapons or missile technology, whether they can strengthen international institutions or develop new ones, and whether the can develop other areas of cooperation.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1971 words

HEADLINE: MOSCOW AND THE MARKETS: Kremlin Shake-Up Jars the Financial World;
Stock Prices Drop In Global Selloff; Dollar, Bonds Up

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The world's financial markets reacted quickly and sharply yesterday to the ouster of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, with stock markets around the world falling as much as 9 percent. The American dollar soared 3 percent against some currencies as the uncertainty sent investors looking for a safe harbor.
 The Tokyo market was the first to feel the jolt and ended by losing nearly 6 percent, but as the trading day followed the sun westward and the immediate emotional impact of the coup wore off, some European and American stock markets regained a portion of their lost ground. And in morning trading today in Tokyo, prices were down only slightly at midday. 
The Dow Jones industrial average, after being off 106 points in early trading yesterday, closed down 69.99, or 2.36 percent, at 2,898.03, but military equipment and oil stocks defied the trend, holding steady or rising. The dollar, oil prices and gold came off their highs. [Pages D7 and D16.]
 
Iraqi Effects Cited
 Analysts argued that the impact on world financial markets of Mr. Gorbachev's fall would be less than that from the Iraqi invsion of Kuwait just over a year ago, although major markets fell two, three or even seven times as far yesterday as they did the day after the invasion.
 Oil prices rose, but not nearly as sharply as they did a year ago. The price of crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed up $1.17, at $22.47 a barrel. Many economies, including the American, are on the verge of recoveries after the recession that began last year. And there is a belief that the crisis in the Soviet Union could lead to lower interest rates as governments try to make money more readily available to help limit the impact.
 The flight from stocks also helped ease the pressure in bond markets, another safe harbor for investors in time of trouble. The move to the United States was reflected in the drop of three-month Treasury bills below 5 percent yesterday for the first time since just after the stock market crash in October 1987. Bond markets in Europe and Japan also fared better than their stock markets.
 
New Opportunities Seen
 And some analysts were looking at the sharp falls in many stock markets as new opportunities to buy quality stocks that are much cheaper than they were a week ago.
 Yet, the economies of many countries, including the United States, Britain and much of Continental Europe, are struggling to begin economic recoveries. In addition, before yesterday, many markets, including Germany's, had not even recovered all the ground lost in the Persian Gulf crisis.
 Some analysts said the latest jolt could trip up the economic recoveries. To have this impact, however, analysts say the Soviet upheaval has to dampen consumer and business confidence, a result that many do not expect unless the Soviet situation deteriorates significantly.
 "The worry that stock markets were reflecting today was that the impact of what happened in the Soviet Union would somehow find its way through and slow down the incipient recoveries" around the world, said Martin Paling, the international investment strategist for James Capel in London.
 "But the only way for that to happen is through falling business and consumer confidence and that is very difficult to forecast," he added. "The real problem is that at this time we haven't got enough to go on but there is a new element of risk."
 All financial markets are likely to continue to be volatile while the new hard-line Government moves to consolidate its control. But markets in the United States and in the Far East, are expected to be hurt less. They are farther away and have little trade or other economic relations that can be disrupted.
 The hardest impact is expected in Germany because of the Government's close role as a financial backer of Mr. Gorbachev; the threat of immigration because of the flight from countries bordering the Soviet Union and the presence of 372,000 Soviet troops in what was East Germany. Germany is also a major importer of natual gas from the Soviet Union.
 
Plunge in Tokyo
 In Tokyo, where the stock market was already weakened by a series of stock and banking scandals, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks was already off about 360 points when the news of the coup arrived. In minutes it was down by 1,000 points and closed down 1,357.61, off 5.95 percent, at 21,456.76. It fell 1.92 percent the day after the Iraqi invasion. At midday today it was off 36.48, at 21,420.28.
 In Germany, the drop was more severe. The DAX index of 30 leading shares plunged 155.40 points or 9.40 percent, to 1,497.93, which exceded the first-day drop after the Iraqi invasion, which was 1.24 percent, and was the largest one-day drop since the small market crash of October 1989.
 Other stock markets falling in Europe included Britain, where the FT-SE 100 dropped 80.5 points, to 2,540.5, its largest one-day drop since October 1989; France, where the CAC-40 fell 132.77 points, to 1,687.54, and Italy, where the Milan Bourse index dropped 79 points, or 7.23 percent, to 1014. The markets in Spain, Switzerland, Beligum, Norway and Sweden also fell sharply.
 The dollar rose the most against the German mark because of the impact the Soviet coup could have on Germany. After jumping to over 1.83 marks to the dollar, the dollar ended in New York at 1.8235, up 3.34 percent on the day. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar rose only 0.57 percent, to 138.15, reflecting the expected smaller imact of the crisis in Japan.
 For the impact of the Soviet coup to change the economic foreces that are pushing the world's economy now there would have to be an abrupt slump in both business and consumer confidence. If this happened, like it did during the Persian Gulf crisis, spending by business and consumers would decline and the economy would slow.
 But many analysts do not expect this to happen. "This crisis is localized," said Michael J. Howell, chief strategist for Salomon Brothers in London. "It will have fewer ramifications for the global economy because the economic fundamentals on the near-term baisis are not that bad." He added that its impact should be more like that of the Tiananmen Square massacre in June of 1989 in China when the Government crushed the democracy movement.
 In the United States, Fabian Linden, the executive director of the consumer research center of the Conference Board, a business research group, said he expected no signficant impact on business or consumer confidence because the Soviet coup should not have the fallout of the Persian Gulf crisis. "With the events in Iraq, we were deeply involved; there was talk of body counts and other dreary forecasts," he said. "There was the impact on taxes, on inflation and on oil prices and the cost of driving to work. These were things that really hit home."
 But George Mangus, the chief strategist at S. G. Warburg in London, said confidence had been hurt, which, he added, meant that Europe, outside of Germany, "could bounce along the bottom of this recession for considerably longer" and that doubts about an American recovery could deepen.
 The big risks now, said Paul Feldman, global strategist at Goldman Sachs & Company in London, was that oil prices could rise, there could be "blood on the streets" in the Soviet Union; American investors could pull money out of European stocks and there could just be a long period of volatility.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
HEAVY ASIAN SELLING
 TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 20 (Special to The New York Times) -- Asian financial markets, which were the first to react to the Soviet coup, were hurt on Monday by a heavy wave of selling by nervous investors from Tokyo to Kuala Lumpur.
The huge Tokyo stock market fell almost 6 percent, while the Hong Kong stock market tumbled 8.4 percent. Stock markets in Singapore and Kuala Lumpur also took steep dives.
 Analysts suggested, however, that as the initial shock wears off, Asia may fare better than markets in the West. Asian economies, while vulnerable to any major shocks to the global political and economic system, generally have fewer direct ties with the Soviet Union, analysts said.
 "There are some ominous signs here, but in the longer term I would rather be in Japan than Germany," said Peter Norton, head of research here for Baring Securities.
 The Soviet shock waves hit an already weakening market in Tokyo and jolted it into a near free-fall just after midday. A series of financial scandals and worries that the economy is slowing have sent the market lower here for weeks.
The 225-stock Nikkei index was off about 360 points just before the first reports hit Japan. Minutes later, at 1 P.M. the index had fallen by about 700 points. At 1:04 P.M. the Nikkei average had dropped more than 1,000 points, or about 4 percent.
 The closing price of 21,456.76 on Monday, off nearly 6 percent, is close to what is considered the psychologically important 20,000 level. At midday today it was off 36.48, at 21,420.28.
 Mr. Norton of Baring Securities said much of the Monday selling came not from Japanese, but foreign investors worried about the impact of the developments in the Soviet Union.
 In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index had its sharpest decline since the Chinese Government cracked down on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square two years ago. The index fell 340 points, or 8.4 percent, to 3,722.
 In Singapore, the Straits Times Industrial index tumbled 84.51 points, or 6.1 percent, to 1,309.23. Nearby, in Malaysia, the Kuala Lumpur index skidded 36.19 points, or 6.7 percent, to 505.47.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
SHOCK IN EUROPE
 BONN, Aug. 19 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Soviet coup shocked Europe's financial markets today. Fearing a reprise of the cold war economic climate, investors sent stocks plunging while driving the dollar's value sharply higher in tumultuous trading.
 Economists said Mr. Gorbachev's removal and subsequent replacement by an emergency committee of Communist hard-liners might continue to roil financial markets until the situation in the Soviet Union stabilizes. Big losses on Wall Street would also weaken European share prices, despite the fact that the sudden change in the Soviet leadership was not seen endangering Western Europe's economic health.
 "I don't see any great economic effect on Western European nations since their ties to the Soviet Union simply aren't that big." said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist at Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt. "There could be short-term disruption of Soviet trade, depending on developments. And the markets may suffer because fantasies about the potential for business in the Soviet Union and eastern Europe are really gone right now."
 Should the situation in the Soviet Union deteriorate, the broader consequences of Mr. Gorbachev's fall could include at least a temporary freeze in Western economic aid to the Soviet Union. "There can be no money and know-how from the West for a return to totalitarian thinking," Germany's Economics Minister, Jurgen Mollemann, said.
 Many Western banks and businesses may share that view. They will immediately begin reassessing their strategies in the Soviet Union, said Jonathan Hoffmann, an economist with Credit Suisse-First Boston in London.
 Those factors helped drive prices sharply lower on Western Europe's major stock exchanges. The Frankfurt stock market was hardest hit, with the DAX index of 30 leading German stocks falling 155.40 points, to close down 9.4 percent at 1,497.93. It was the DAX's biggest one-day drop since October 1989 and prompted some comparisons with the global stock crash of October 1987.

HEADLINE: Under the Heel -- for Now

BYLINE: By Richard Pipes; Richard Pipes, professor of history at Harvard and author of "The Russian Revolution," was director of Soviet affairs in the National Security Council in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: MARLBOROUGH, N.H.

 BODY:
Today, Mikhail Gorbachev was to sign a new union treaty with the presidents of major republics. Its text has not been released yet but it was known to transfer much authority from the central organs of the Communist Party and Soviet state to institutions in those republics.
But the most reactionary elements in the Communist leadership -- die-hards of the party nomenklatura, army and K.G.B. -- pre-empted the event with a coup.
These elements had at first approved of Mr. Gorbachev's reforms because they promised to revitalize the country's economy and, by so doing, renovate the armed forces, the mainstay of the regime. But perestroika turned out to be more than they had bargained for. To energize the economy Mr. Gorbachev had to restore freedom of speech; freedom of speech led to the emergence of public opinion and the formation of political parties. 
 In the end, perestroika cost the party its monopoly on political life. At the same time, securing financial and technical aid from the industrial democracies required a less aggressive foreign policy, cutbacks in military spending and, in the end, the restoration of freedom in Eastern Europe.
The conservatives watched these developments with disbelief, then with dismay and finally with uncontrollable fury. For them, Mr. Gorbachev's support of the U.S.-led coalition in the gulf war seemed to have been the last straw: the allied victory, won with Moscow's diplomatic help, drove the final nail in the Soviet claim to superpower status. To exact punishment, they made the life of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze intolerable, forcing his resignation in December 1990. More than anyone, he had been responsible for ending the cold war.
Preparations for a coup were already under way last fall. The signal was to be a crackdown on Lithuania, following which fraudulent "committees of national salvation" were to assume power throughout the U.S.S.R. In mid-January the plotters stood in readiness. Special forces massacred unarmed Lithuanian youths. But after an outcry, Mr. Gorbachev lost his nerve and called off the operation. Col. Viktor Alksnis, the reactionaries' spokesman, accused him of betrayal.
Two factors assured the inevitability of a military coup. One was the unprecedented degree to which Soviet generals presumed to criticize the Gorbachev Government openly for its laxness at home and concessions abroad. Such criticism ran contrary to the Russian Army's tradition and indicated that the disaffected armed forces had slipped from party control. The other was the conservatives' hostility to plans to decentralize the Soviet Union. Transferring authority to the republics threatened to emasculate the power of the party, army and K.G.B.
It was on such grounds that in November 1990 I thought it warranted on these pages to call attention to the possibility of a military coup.
The putsch this week is still too veiled to permit authoritative analyses. Some things, though, seem reasonably clear. One should not assume that the coup will succeed: most military bids for power fail, and this one may be no exception. Whether the generals establish effective authority or turn out to be paper rulers depends on several unpredictable factors: the resistance of the crowds, especially in Moscow and Leningrad; loyalty of the military and its willingness to fire on civilians; readiness of the bureaucracy, notably in the Russian republic, to take orders from the usurpers.
And perhaps, most important, it hinges on the courage and skill with which the president of the Russian republic, Boris Yeltsin, the generals' only credible rival, takes charge of the scattered democratic forces.
If the coup does succeed, its prospects for instituting a viable regime appear slim. The State Committee for the State of Emergency is made up of primitive personalities. One member, Vladimir Kryuchkov, the K.G.B. head, not long ago accused the West of using economic aid to subvert the Soviet Union. These people evidently have learned nothing from the crisis that has afflicted their country in the past decade. Notwithstanding Gennadi Yanayev's claims yesterday that he supports perestroika, he and the others believe in the golden age of Stalinism.
They want the union -- that is, the empire -- to be reconstituted in all its glory. This objective is certain to clash with the wishes of the non-Russian citizenry and virtually to eliminate the possibility of the Soviet Union being preserved. They have no idea of the complexities of modern industry, of the need for incentives and international collaboration. They are anti-Semitic and anti-Western. It is unlikely that such people, or those who stand behind them, will be capable of running the country for any length of time.
Nevertheless, the coup most likely has ended Mr. Gorbachev's political career. The Soviet leader managed to stay afloat by skillfully maneuvering between left and right. In following such a course, he left himself without a loyal constituency.
The new leaders, if they hang on to power, will likely make friendly overtures to the West. They know that to qualify for foreign assistance, they have to calm the anxieties of Europe and the U.S. But in the long run their presence in the Kremlin threatens world stability. The hard-liners are likely to rely on force to maintain power at home and to reclaim their status as a superpower abroad. We may assume that they will further delay the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Poland and Germany, resume large-scale aid to Cuba, Vietnam and other client states and sabotage the promised reductions in weaponry.
Unhappy Russians! The British writer Maurice Baring described them 85 years ago as a "people who have been longing for the dawn and condemned to the twilight." If any hope exists that this time, perhaps, the darkness will lift, it is that the past 70 years may have cured them of utopian fantasies and the past five years have rid them of fear.

HEADLINE: Deere Net Off 72% in Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOLINE, Ill., Aug. 20

 BODY:
Deere & Company today reported a 72 percent drop in its third-quarter net income. The maker of farm and industrial machines said a worldwide recession had dampened demand for its products.
The company's third-quarter net income totaled $31.3 million, or 41 cents a share, down from $114 million, or $1.50 a share, for the quarter a year earlier. 
 Revenue amounted to $1.79 billion, down 13 percent from $2.05 billion in the 1990 quarter.
Deere's stock closed today at $46.875, down $2.625, in New York Stock Exchange trading.
The Moline-based company predicted that conditions would not improve in the near future. Last week, Deere began labor negotiations with the United Automobile Workers union to replace a contract that expires Sept. 30.
In the first nine months of the fiscal year, Deere laid off more than 1,400 workers, cut production by 12 percent and reduced inventories. Deere's work force stood at 37,000 at the end of the quarter.
Deere's chairman, Hans W. Becherer, said the company expects a 17 percent reduction in production this year. "We expect farmers to remain cautious in making new product purchase decisions," he added.
