HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
German Unity: Paying the Bill

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WHAT a difference a year can make.
When the eastern and western German economies merged in anticipation of political union last July, most analysts assumed that the east's financial troubles would be washed away in a torrent of Deutsche marks. Today eastern Germany is straining to produce two-thirds as much as it did in 1989, and T-shirts bearing the legend "Bring Back The Wall" are all the rage in Berlin. 
 Germany is not Romania: Bonn has committed to doing whatever is necessary -- including raising taxes and interest rates -- to sustain eastern Germans at a living standard other eastern Europeans can only dream about. But Janet Yellen, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, argues that the means to economic integration may matter almost as much as the end. By subsidizing unemployment rather than employment, she says, Germany is wasting productive resources and condemning millions to life on the dole.
Everyone knew that East Germany produced little the world coveted, save Dresden china and Olympic athletes. Somehow, though, hardly anyone inferred what now seems obvious: Once eastern Germans (and East Germany's former trade partners) were free to buy western goods, they would not settle for the shoddy old stuff, unless it was much cheaper. But by the same token, eastern Germany's factories would be in no position to cut prices to competitive levels unless they could cut wages to a small fraction of western German rates.
The Deutsche Bank, the largest private bank in Germany, estimates that the productivity of eastern Germans now averages just one-third of their western counterparts. But the difference is not reflected in wages. In fact, Ms. Yellen and three Berkeley colleagues, George Ackerlof, Andrew Rose and Helga Hessenius, estimate that at current compensation rates eastern industry can afford to employ only 8 percent of its pre-unification labor force. Their analysis was published in the first 1991 issue of the Brookings Institution's "Papers on Economic Activity."
The gulf between productivity and wages might be expected to hold down compensation. But eastern Germans, trapped for 45 years in a socialist backwater, are in no mood to wait for a better life. And German unions, fearful that easterners will compete for jobs in western German factories, are cheering them on.
This explains why industrial production in the east has already fallen by two-thirds, and why the Deutsche Bank predicts that total eastern employment will dip to five million by 1992, half the number employed in 1989. It also explains the Government's failure to find buyers for the great majority of eastern Germany's public enterprises. The Berkeley economists argue that the fairest and least disruptive way out of the bind is to subsidize eastern German wages. They estimate that Bonn could make it profitable to employ three-quarters of the eastern German industrial labor force at current wage rates by temporarily underwriting three-quarters of the labor bills of eastern factories.
The fairest way, they predict, would also prove the cheapest: Every 100 marks spent on wage subsidies would save 79 marks in unemployment benefits. And much of the rest would be recaptured in the sale of eastern German enterprises, many of which would become financially viable overnight.
German Government officials, however, are not buying. In public, they denounce the idea of paying eastern Germans to work. In private, they worry that wage subsidies would encourage labor to become more militant. And they fear that once in place subsidies would be impossible to remove.
Ms. Yellen concedes that the subsidy approach could prove an expensive mistake unless it was linked to a tough social contract that limited wage increases and set a timetable for phasing out benefits. But she thinks the practical alternatives are equally problematic.
Millions of eastern Germans do not have a prayer of finding work at home today, she argues, and will not for many years. The most ambitious will probably move west, draining the east of skilled workers needed for development and straining the resources of western German cities already bracing for a flood of refugees from the collapsing Soviet Union. Others will scramble from one temporary job to another, playing the social insurance system for maximum benefits. Still others will join the army of the chronically unemployable.
In the long run, western investment will no doubt eliminate east-west productivity differences. But in the long run, Germany could become a very different place to live and work -- one far less to the liking of its deeply conservative citizens.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Earnings Off For Dayton

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the department store operator, said yesterday that second-quarter earnings skidded more than 32 percent amid the continuing slump in consumer spending.
The company said it earned $40 million, or 47 cents a share, in the quarter ended Aug. 3, down from $59 million, or 75 cents a share, in the comparable 1990 period. Revenue totaled $3.56 billion, up 10 percent from $3.24 billion a year earlier. 
 "We expected a tough first half," said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive officer of the Minneapolis-based retailer. "We have just started to see a modest improvement in sales in several difficult markets. However, we do not know what effect the events of the last two days will have on consumer confidence in the next few months," Mr. Macke said, referring to the ouster of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
Operating income for the department store division, which includes the Dayton Hudson and Marshall Field stores, rose slightly because of the contribution of the Field stores, the company said.
Dayton Hudson operates 733 stores in 33 states, including the Mervyn's clothing stores and Target discount stores. The company was particularly hard-hit by the weak economy in California, where one-third of its stores are situated.
Dayton Hudson's stock fell 62.5 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $71.75.

HEADLINE: Bangkok Journal;
Where Beauty Queens Preen, No Eyesores, Please

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand

 BODY:
The World Bank and Miss Universe are coming to town, and for that reason some of Bangkok's struggling poor have been told to move out.
Thousands of Bangkok slum dwellers have been ordered to leave their homes as quickly as they can. The first 2,000 must be out by October, when the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund open their annual conference in the new National Conference Center. As many as 5,000 others will be evicted before May, when the glistening conference center is the site of the 1992 Miss Universe Pageant. 
 Apparently embarrassed that the nation's spectacular economic boom has not provided for all of its citizens, the Thai Government has hastily put forward a "beautification" plan that calls for poor neighborhoods to be removed from the view of well-heeled visitors. It is the sort of story as likely these days in the developing world as it has long been in richer lands.
 
Put in Awkward Position
 Despite the protests of slum residents, most of whom do not want to go, the first were evicted from the jumble of tin-roof shantytowns in early August.
Bangkok newspapers have rallied to the slum dwellers' cause, and the publicity has put the Washington-based World Bank and International Monetary Fund, the first big guests in the conference center, in the awkward position of distancing themselves both from their Thai hosts and from the appearance, if not the reality, that thousands of poor people are being uprooted so as not to offend a group of Western bankers.
"We have never asked or suggested that this should be done," said Philippe Annez, the chief of the regional mission of the World Bank. "The Thai Government knows very clearly that we are concerned."
Boonnoeng Phanyong, a 42-year-old widow whose husband died of cancer in June, has been told she must leave her dilapidated one-room home and move her tiny papaya-salad stand out of the neighborhood.
 
'Government Is Ashamed of Us'
 "The Government is ashamed of us," she said, putting down the bamboo-handled knife that she used to chop greens and pointed to the sprawling glass-and-steel conference center across the street. "They do not want the bankers and the businessmen to see how we live."
The Thai Government insists that it has been planning since 1986 to demolish some of the slums. One of the shantytowns is on a draining ditch that the city says must be dredged to control street flooding; another is being torn down to build a road to ease traffic jams.
Thai officials acknowledge, however, that it took the October conference of the World Bank and I.M.F., which is expected to attract bankers, financiers and government officials from 150 nations, to make them act.
The two development organizations meet outside Washington every three years. In 1976, when they gathered in Manila, more than 400 families were evicted from slums there as part of what was described as a "beautification" campaign by Imelda Marcos.
 
What Might People Think
 Thai officials, stung by publicity over the evictions in Bangkok, now refuse to be quoted by name about the move.
But when the plan was made public in June, a spokesman for Thailand's National Housing Authority said the slums were "an eyesore in the heart of Bangkok" and might cause foreign visitors to think less of Thailand.
Thai officials also said they were concerned that terrorists might try to hide among slum dwellers -- a suggestion slum residents find laughable, if only because the overcrowded slums offer no privacy to anyone, terrorists included.
Under the plan, many will be moved to apartment developments going up only a few hundred feet away from their current homes.
Luan See Loh, a shopkeeper who has lived in the Theppatharn slum for 40 of her 60 years, said she would prefer to stay. "But the Government says I will not move very far and if the Government says we must go, we must," she said. "They say the new apartments will be nice."
 
Being Moved 10 Miles Away
 Others are being moved to developments more than 10 miles from the heart of the city -- a potential calamity for the many slum residents who sell candy or fruit along city streets, earning the equivalent of $3 or $4 a day.
Because of Bangkok's appalling traffic and its lack of reliable public transport, it will be hard for them to return downtown to work. There is hope, but no guarantee, that jobs may become available at factories near their new homes.
"If we leave here, we will be leaving our customers and our livelihoods," said Akaraj Chanpuang, the elected leader of the 40-year-old Klong Pai Sington slum. "I am a taxi driver. How will I find work so far from Bangkok?"
The hurried evictions are part of a larger problem in Bangkok, a city of more than six million people that is growing so rapidly and with so little planning that the whims of real-estate developers often force the poor from their homes.
 
1.3 Million Live in Slums
 As Thailand has emerged in the 1990's as one of the economic tigers of Southeast Asia, the capital, Bangkok, has turned into a congested boom town, with an estimated 1.3 million people living in the city's 1,500 slums.
Mr. Annez of the World Bank said he hoped and believed the slum residents who face eviction would be well compensated for their move.
As for the Thai officials overseeing the evictions, Mr. Annez has urged them to keep in mind that Bangkok has no monopoly on poverty -- that New York and London and Hong Kong and most of the world's other financial centers have their slums, too.
"The delegates to our conference have plenty of slums at home," he said. "They have all seen slums before."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thailand wants to evict thousands of slum dwellers from Bangkok in a "beautification" plan for its new National Conference Center. A boy played atop the tin roof of a shanty near a sign, rear, announcing the center. (Kraipit Phanvut for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Potent Office Weaves Web In China Arms

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 20

 BODY:
If Western leaders want to know what they face in trying to get China to restrain its weapons sales, they might drop by the secretive office of Poly Technologies on the 17th floor of the Citic Building in downtown Beijing.
The efficient, well-equipped office is at the core of a remarkable Chinese military-industrial complex. Western complaints to China's Foreign Ministry about arms deals are unlikely to impress this company, which in some respects is more powerful than the Foreign Ministry itself. 
 Among those who have been active in Poly Technologies in recent years are relatives of President Yang Shangkun, Vice President Wang Zhen and Deng Xiaoping, the nation's senior leader.
The family links between Beijing's arms dealers and its top rulers appear to be one reason why China's weapons industry has rapidly become a major exporter in recent years, and why it will be difficult to curb. The West's arms control debate with China, far more than with other countries, involves links of family and friendship that are the veins of power in China.
 
A Holdout on Pacts
 While most major military powers seem to be moving toward agreement on curbs on the proliferation of arms, China stands out for its refusal so far to join the Missile Technology Control Regime, an agreement to curb the spread of missiles, although it says it is considering joining. China also has not joined the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, but said this month that it would do so.
In recent months, China is believed to have sent Pakistan M-11 missiles, which can carry nuclear warheads and could be used against India. Beijing may also be sending Syria its new M-9 missiles, which would be able to strike targets throughout Israel. The Far Eastern Economic Review of Hong Kong reports in its current issue that up to 24 of the M-9 launchers already have been spotted in Syria.
Such sales may have been arranged through companies other than Poly Technologies. The common denominator is that the aim of such deals is not to cultivate friends or spread Communism, but a more capitalist motive.
"In the United States, arms sales are an expression of your foreign policy," a Chinese official said. "But in China, the reason for arms sales is to earn money."
Xie Datong, the president of Poly Technologies, did not respond to requests for an interview. Citic, the Chinese investment company that on paper is the parent of Poly Technologies, also declined interviews.
 
Like a Military Outfit
Other Chinese with knowledge of Poly Technologies' operations were more forthcoming. In interviews recently, they portrayed a sophisticated company run like the military organization it is, where employees address one another other by army rank and where Hong Kong chefs provide catered lunches.
"It started because the army general staff department wanted to have its own arms trading company, but it thought that it wouldn't be appropriate to do this openly," said a Chinese familiar with the company. "So it approached Citic, and Poly Technologies was set up on paper as a subsidiary of Citic."
Poly Technologies was formally founded in January 1984 with the approval of the State Council, China's Cabinet. It is registered as a subsidiary of Citic. In fact, Chinese say, it reports to the armament department of the general staff of the army.
Poly Technologies seems to be authorized to sell virtually everything in the Chinese arsenal, although the Central Military Commission must approve politically sensitive deals.
The most important deal arranged through Poly Technologies was the sale to Saudi Arabia of about $2 billion worth of Chinese ballistic missiles with a range of about 1,600 miles. That transaction, arranged in 1985, came to light in 1988 and caused a wave of indignation in the United States.
 
Car Stoned in Myanmar
 Among recent deals arranged by Poly Technologies was the sale of guns and ammunition to Myanmar, formerly Burma.
"Poly Technologies has an office in Myanmar, and when its car goes out on the street, it's sometimes stoned by the Burmese," said a Chinese who has worked for the company. "They think we're helping the Burmese Government suppress the people."
The first head of Poly Technologies was He Pengfei, son of a famous Chinese marshal. The son also rose in the army, and after heading Poly Technologies, he returned there, attaining the rank of major general and becoming director of the armament department, a vantage point from which he continued to oversee the company.
The next president of Poly Technologies was He Ping, who is married to Deng Rong, a daughter of Mr. Deng and now his personal assistant.
An article this spring in International Security, a scholarly journal, asserted that the Foreign Ministry had tried to restrain Poly Technologies but had had little success.
In one indication of where business is headed, Poly Technologies has recently expanded, taking up an entire floor in the Citic Building. Most of the employees are on loan from the army.
Morale is said to be high and job benefits substantial. The staff need not lunch in the regular Citic cafeteria, because the chefs of the Hong Kong-managed Windows on the World restaurant on the top of the Citic building send them lunches every noon. The price charged each employee is just nine cents a meal.

HEADLINE: Cuba Seeks U.N. Debate on U.S. Trade Embargo

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Calling the nearly 30-year-old United States economic embargo against Cuba illegal, unjust and a violation of the United Nations Charter, Cuba's mission to the United Nations said today that it had asked for a General Assembly debate on the issue.
Taking the matter before the General Assembly is seen as an attempt by Havana to help kill legislation pending in the United States Congress that would close one of the last and most lucrative loopholes allowing trade with Cuba. 
 "The issue is not if the U.S. will trade with a particular country," said the head of Cuba's United Nations delegation, Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada. "but the U.S. has no right whatsoever to attempt to impose its own legislation over other sovereign states, as they are doing throughout the world."
A senior member of the United States mission said today that Washington was likely to oppose such a debate. "There is nothing in international law or politics that says all countries have to trade with other countries," said the American diplomat, who spoke on condition that he not be identified by name.
Before the embargo, the United States was Cuba's largest trading partner.
Mr. Alarcon de Quesada said at a news conference today that Cuba did not expect Washington to relent on direct trade with Cuba but that it hoped to put pressure on other countries that were host to foreign subsidiaries of United States companies to demand that those companies be allowed to do business with Cuba.
Originally, the embargo applied to United States citizens, companies and their foreign subsidiaries. But under pressure from allies, Washington in the mid-1970's eased some restrictions.
The relaxed guidelines applied the ban only on those foreign subsidiaries of United States companies headed by United States citizens and allowed trade with Cuba so long as United States currency or manufactured goods were not involved.
Last year, United States foreign subsidiary trade with Cuba amounted to $700 million and involved hundreds of companies, most of them in Switzerland, Canada and Britain, a Treasury Department official said.
An amendment sponsored by Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, would close that loophole and increase the embargo against Cuba to the level now imposed against North Korea, Vietnam and Cambodia. The Bush Administration, while eager to keep the economic pressure on Cuba, is opposed to the legislation because of pressure from allies.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down sharply for the week ended yesterday.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., the rapid decline of C.D. yields has sent depositors reeling, since many of the traditional havens for depositor money are just as low, or even lower than current yields. 
 "The main competition for C.D. money is in the form of U.S. Treasury securities and money market funds, and they have tumbled just as fast," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of the weekly bank rate publication.
The unsettling international news from the Soviet Union has sent money flooding into the United States markets and into Treasury securities, pushing up the price of Treasuries and sending interest rates down. Mr. Heady advised depositors to stay short through this down cycle, staying with certificates of deposit with short maturities, so to be in a position to shift into a higher-paying certificate later as the economy recovers.
At the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday average discount rates, which have been down for four consecutive weeks including yesterday, showed a steepening decline for the second straight week. The three-month bill fell 13 basis points, to 5.17 percent, while the six-month bill fell 16 basis points, to 5.23 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Analysts note that the average three-month bill rate was the lowest yield since Oct. 26, 1987, when it was 5.12 percent, and the six-month was the lowest since Oct. 27, 1986, when it was 5.21 percent.
The largest yield changes in New York area banks this week were at Emigrant Savings Bank, which cut the yield of its money market account by 20 basis points, to 5.30 percent, and at Chase Manhattan, which lowered the yields on its three-month certificate by 27 basis points, to 5.07 percent, and its six-month certificate by 26 basis points, to 5.13 percent.
Among the commercial banks, an average money market account fell by 3 basis points, to 4.95 percent, with three-month certificates off 8 basis points, to 5.15 percent, and the six-month certificate down by 10 basis points, to 5.32 percent.
Depositors at savings institutions saw the average yield on a money market account fall 4 basis points, to 5.46 percent, and a three-month certificate fall 2 basis points, to 5.64 percent. The yield on a six-month certificate down 4 basis points, to 5.90 percent.
By comparison, 20 large banks around the country, all of which are outside the New York market, showed the average money market yield down one basis point, to 5.15 percent, and average yield of a six-month certificate down 7 basis points, to 5.47 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Declines Slightly While Gold Is Also Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most major currencies in choppy dealings yesterday, as traders nervously tracked the rapidly changing developments in the Soviet Union.
Gold also fell, with gold for current delivery dropping $2.70 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, to a late bid of $355.90. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid of $356 an ounce, down $2.20 from late Monday. 
 "Everyone has had an eye on the news," said Harlan Matusow, a trader with Bank Julius Baer & Company. "It's strictly a news follower's market."
The dollar traded most actively against the German mark, since Germany is seen as the Western nation most vulnerable to Soviet political and economic upheaval. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7985 German marks, from 1.8245 late Monday.
The dollar, as a safe-haven investment, soared with early-morning reports that tanks were rolling toward the Russian Parliament building, then fell when the Soviet Vice President, Gennadi I. Yanayev, said he would not storm the building, said Gabriele Schmitt, a vice president with the Bank of New York. Mr. Yanayev heads the committee that ousted Mikhail Gorbachev Monday.
Although analysts said the market remained jittery yesterday, Mr. Matusow said that "everything seems to be certainly a lot calmer and a lot more diplomatic than it was" on Monday.
But the dollar eased even lower after afternoon reports of a shake-up among members of the coup committee. "It seems the chance that Gorbachev is going to come back into power is greater today than it was yesterday," Mr. Matusow said.
In New York, the British pound finished at $1.6440, up from $1.6255 late Monday. In London, the pound rose to $1.6380, from $1.6305 late Monday.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.62 yen, to 137.78 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 137.41 yen, and in New York, the dollar was quoted at 137.20 yen, down from 138.15.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.5432 Swiss francs, down from 1.5535; 6.1140 French francs, down from 6.1775; 1,340.50 Italian lire, down from 1,359.50, and 1.1417 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1431.
Commenting on precious-metals trading, an analyst with Barclays Bank said the metals came under selling pressure on rumors that Far Eastern traders were secretly acting as brokers for Soviet selling.
Earlier in London, gold fell to a late bid price of $355.50 a troy ounce, from $360.50 bid late Monday, and to $354.50 an ounce in Zurich, down from $360.70 late Monday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Short-Term Rates Drop Further

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Interest rates on short-term issues moved lower again yesterday and bond prices rose as the continuing crisis in the Soviet Union gave investors ample excuse to redirect funds into high-quality, safe securities.
In addition to the Soviet crisis, traders said prices had also risen in anticipation that the Federal Reserve Board is about to lower short-term interest rates again soon and the idea that the economy may be falling back into recession. 
 "Given those three factors, how can you bet against the market?" one government bond trader said.
Compared with Monday, when trading activity bordered on the chaotic after news of the ouster of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, dealers said yesterday's session was much quieter.
"People are just waiting, but right now the fundamentals for the market are in pretty good shape," another bond trader said.
Traders hoping to see a sign from the Fed that it had eased policy yesterday were disappointed. The central bank refrained from conducting open market operations when the funds rate was trading at 5.50 percent, the rate widely seen as the Fed's current target.
 
Fed Panel's Meeting
 Market participants were watching the Fed's activities more closely than usual yesterday because members of its policy-making Open Market Committee were meeting in Washington.
Recurrent weakness in the economy and the positive inflation outlook have led some analysts to forecast that the Fed would move almost immediately after yesterday's meeting.
Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers, is not among that group. But he added that he expected the Fed would not delay too much longer. Moreover, to restimulate the economy the funds rate, which the Fed trimmed just two weeks ago, may have to fall much, much farther, he said.
"I think they will wait for the employment report," on Sept. 6, Mr. Slifer said. "But we have a long ways to go on the funds rate," he added.
"In almost every other business cycle, the funds rate has had to fall below the inflation rate in order to promote a vigorous recovery. Given where inflation is now, and where I think it will be by the end of the year, I think that means the funds rate will have to get down to 4 percent."
 
Bill Rates Down
 The Soviet crisis and anticipation of a Fed easing move helped to push down Treasury bill rates again yesterday.
By late in the session, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.10 percent, down 5 basis points, or five one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped 8 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.13 percent. And one-year bill rates fell 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.16 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 14/32, up 1/4 of a point, to yield 8.08 percent, down from 8.10 percent late Monday.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 17/ 32, up 7/32, to yield 7.79 percent. And the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 11/32, up 3/32, to yield 6.12 percent.
Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by an offering of $993 million issue of securities backed by auto loan receivables from a financing subsidiary of the Security Pacific Corporation.
The 6.70 percent securities, which have an average life of 1.34 years, were priced at $99.30 to yield 6.844 percent, 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 7/8 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the transaction. The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, market participants said the prices of most issues were unchanged to up 1/8 of a point in quiet trading.
Meanwhile, municipal bond traders said the prices of most widely quoted tax-exempt issues fell by about 1/8 of a point. CS First Boston

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Coup Seen Aiding Stocks in U.S.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
WITH stock prices down on news of the Soviet coup, many American stock market strategists are arguing that the coup, and the resulting economic and financial impacts, made American stocks a much better buy.
"My experience is that these political events do turn out to be pretty transitory" in terms of market impact, Greg Smith, the chief strategist at Prudential Securities, said yesterday. But he added that the turmoil in the Soviet Union was likely to make investing in Europe less attractive, while improving the relative standing of markets in this hemisphere. 
 Mr. Smith recalled that the negative market reaction to the killing of Chinese students in Tiananmen Square had been brief, and that even the Hong Kong stock market later recovered from the shock.
Another widely followed market guru, Elaine Garzarelli of Shearson Lehman Brothers, said she was convinced there would be little if any harm to the American economy. "This makes us the strongest nation in the world," she said. "Our dollar will be stronger. It is good for us."
Mr. Smith said yesterday that he had recommended that institutions with portfolios split between stocks and bonds invest an additional 10 percent in stocks, raising that portion to 70 percent. The portion in cash was cut to 10 percent, while bonds stayed at 20 percent.
At Goldman, Sachs, Steve Einhorn recommended that equity portfolios go to 95 percent stocks, leaving only 5 percent for cash. That was a move of five percentage points, and the highest he had recommended in at least five years, he said.
"The Soviet event, in my opinion, should not disturb one's bullishness," Mr. Einhorn said. "It is bankrupt, and in no position to be belligerent to the West."
The bullishness was based in significant part on the reaction of markets on Monday, the first day after the coup. Short-term interest rates fell sharply, continuing a trend that has been under way for months. At the same time, stock prices tumbled around the world. Yesterday, rates moved a little lower, and stock prices staged a mild recovery.
Many measures of stock valuation are based in part on interest rates. Lower rates justify a higher level of share prices, all other things being equal. Mr. Einhorn said that before the Soviet coup, American stocks were mildly overvalued, based on averages, but now they were undervalued.
He said he expected share prices to rise well above fair valuations, in part because other factors were in line. "The economic fundamentals are still quite good," he said. "Inflation is mild and there is a mild recovery developing in the economy and in earnings."
One indicator Mr. Einhorn pointed to was the relationship of the dividend yield on stocks to the rate on Treasury bills. Dividend yields are near the low end of their historic range, at 3.2 percent, but with the rate on three-month Treasury bills falling yesterday to 5.12 percent, the ratio of the two is relatively high, and by itself would indicate that the stock market is 20 percent undervalued, Mr. Einhorn said.
Ms. Garzarelli said that largely because of the fall in rates, her indicators were now 90 percent bullish, an unusually high level and far above the 65 percent needed for a buy signal. She said she thought the Dow Jones industrial average, which rose 15.66, to 2,913.69, yesterday, could rise to 3,500 or more.
The low level of short-term interest rates has been a big bullish argument for several months, and the reaction to the Soviet coup simply stimulated those arguments. "The issue here, amidst all the fog, is that the Federal Reserve has every reason to keep interest rates on a downward path," Mr. Smith said. He said that was needed to keep the economic recovery from faltering.
Mr. Smith said he believed that the low level of interest rates would force many savers to take money out of certificates of deposit and put the cash into other securities, with some going into stocks and some into longer-term bonds.
Ms. Garzarelli said she discounted the possibility that the Soviet coup might damage the American economy, largely because she did not think it would force up oil prices and lower consumer sentiment, as happened a year ago following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. If she thought that was likely to happen, she said, she would be less bullish. Oil prices rose modestly on Monday, but slipped back yesterday.
Not all Wall Streeters are bullish, although the ones who are were the most vocal yesterday. David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, noted that while getting 5 percent on Treasury billls might seem low by recent standards, other markets could produce large losses.
"This uncertainty will take a long time to resolve," he said. "The moral of this story is to preserve what you've got from the 1980's. Safe, short-term investments are where you should be."

HEADLINE: Development Not Even a Contender on Brooklyn's Waterfront

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Three burned-out steel piers stand like eerily twisted skeletons in Upper New York Bay as teen-agers swim past the rusted shell of a half-submerged Chevy Cutlass off the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn. Just to the north, beyond the stench of the Gowanus Canal and a huge, unused grain terminal, a short-lived Port Authority project called Fishport stands empty, and row upon row of scofflaws' cars fill an impoundment lot.
Further north are the little-used piers beneath the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, the subject of long, bitter debate, and the industrial waterfront in Williamsburg and Greenpoint, where a few factories and waste-processing plants operate, but much of the land remains a foreboding, fenced-off no-man's land. 
 This is the north Brooklyn waterfront.
 
'Neglect and Decay,' and Studies
 Despite years of voluminous studies -- including a comprehensive waterfront plan being prepared by the City Planning Department -- much of this waterfront continues to suffer from "neglect and decay," said Marcia Reiss, the policy director for the Parks Council, a private group, and author of a 1990 report, "Creating Public Access to the Brooklyn Waterfront."
"No real changes, no development or creation of public access has moved forward substantially," she added. "The city has no comprehensive thinking, because they don't have the confidence that they will derive sufficient revenues from the waterfront."
There have been some commercial success stories, like the Red Hook Marine Terminal, the only active container port in New York City; the Cocoaport at the still mostly empty South Brooklyn Marine Terminal in Sunset Park, and the industrial revitalization of the old Brooklyn Navy Yard along the East River and the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park. But this winding, 10-mile stretch of waterfront is largely an economic, esthetic and recreational disaster.
 
Few Stevedores and Fewer Parks
 Commercially, it is a pale shadow of a waterfront once teeming with stevedores unloading cargo ships and bustling shipbuilding and repair yards. And, in the borough with the city's lowest percentage of parkland, virtually none of this coastline, with its views of Manhattan and New York's harbor -- is accessible to the public.
"New York City was built around the water," said Richard J. Aneiro, the president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation. "But it turned its back on the water because the city wanted to be white-collar."
Consequently, he added, as traditionally waterfront-based industry fled the city during the last 40 years, "nothing was done to develop industry -- only white-collar business and luxury housing."
Officials of the city's Planning Department, Economic Development Corporation and Department of Business Services -- which last month superseded the Department of Ports and Trade -- as well as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, all express cautious optimism about the waterfront's future, and point to a net gain in industrial tenants near the waterfront during the mid-1980's.
Yet, many Brooklynites feel frustrated and bitter about the waterfront, saying that New York City has done pitifully little to attract commerce or visitors to its waterfront, compared with cities like Boston, Baltimore, Miami and San Francisco.
"With the development on the Manhattan side of the river, the neglect on this side makes one angry," said Marilyn Gelber, the executive assistant to the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden.
 
Prostitutes Sleeping on Benches
 And Pompilio Rosario, who often rides his bicycle to the tiny, debris-strewn waterside park between the Amstar sugar factory and the Pfizer pharmaceuticals plant at the end of Grand Street in Williamsburg, said: "During the day, you see prostitutes sleeping on the benches. People leave garbage here and the city doesn't even put in garbage cans. It could be a lot better."
After World War II, waterfront businesses gradually left Brooklyn, as traditional cargo shipping gave way to giant container ships. Because Brooklyn lacked enough inexpensive land for container storage, much of the region's shipping industry moved to New Jersey, where the Port Authority developed container ports in Elizabeth and Newark. Many Brooklyn piers and warehouse sheds were abandoned and allowed to deteriorate. And the Brooklyn Navy Yard -- which employed 70,000 people at its peak during World War II -- closed in 1966.
The waterfront's problems are further aggravated by its divided ownership by a patchwork of city agencies, the Port Authority, New York State, private developers hungering to build and other individuals. Some disputed claims date to titles issued three centuries ago by English monarchs, said Ann Buttenwieser, vice president for waterfront planning with the Economic Development Corporation.
The number of groups involved makes comprehensive planning and concrete action difficult, said Alfred Ng, the director of Port and Aviation development for the Department of Business Services.
The north Brooklyn waterfront is in fact a series of somewhat discrete areas -- including, from south to north, Sunset Park, the Gowanus Canal area, the Erie Basin, Red Hook, Brooklyn Heights, the Fulton Ferry area, the Navy Yard, Williamsburg and Greenpoint. Each has its own problems, controversies and promise.
The Sunset Park waterfront, from about 69th Street north to the Gowanus Canal, illustrates both the legacy of neglect and successful attempts at economic redevelopment.
The 42d Street pier, known as the Camelot pier locally after a nearby restaurant, is one of several adjacent burned-out, garbage-filled piers whose contorted steel frames are gradually sinking into New York Bay. Nonetheless, fishermen come in search of porgies and bluefish, and teen-agers use a makeshift diving board to jump into water filled with abandoned cars and other debris.
"I don't care if it's polluted," said David Gomez, 18, one of a dozen Sunset Park youths swimming near the pier on a recent hot afternoon. "If they fix it up, we can't swim anymore. At least now we can have fun."
To the south are city-operated garbage-transfer terminals and a sewage plant.
Although the 110-acre South Brooklyn Marine Terminal in Sunset Park is only 10 percent occupied, more than 20,000 people work in the area between Owl's Head Park in Bay Ridge and the Gowanus Canal, according to Karen Burkhardt, the director of the Brooklyn office of the City Planning Department.
On the 39th Street pier, near several topless bars and the mile-long phalanx of mostly empty eight-story yellow-and-white warehouses known as the Bush Terminal, a pungent smell of cocoa fills the air. Brown 150-pound bags are packed 15 feet high in a warehouse nearly half a mile long. Some 200,000 bags have been unloaded from ships coming from West Africa and Southeast Asia in the last three months alone, said Dean Milone, a manager of the two-year-old Cocoaport.
North of 23d Street, where Continental Terminals unloads coffee, more desolation looms. The Gowanus Bay and Canal -- lined with more garbage-transfer stations, Hess Oil tanks and Con Edison generators -- remains a foul industrial inlet that has long been the butt of Brooklyn jokes. Further north, an arm of land forms the Erie Basin, where Navy and commercial ships are still repaired and garbage barges, with nets covering their mountains of debris, float past relentlessly.
 
Port Authority's Fishport Fiasco
 Amid this seascape of rusting piers and giant cranes is a recent Port Authority fiasco -- Fishport. In the late 1980's, the agency spruced up the southern flank of the Erie Basin to develop a commercial fishing center. About one year after opening, Fishport closed, and the pier is now incongruously used by a lobsterman to store his traps and by the city to store police cars and other public vehicles.
Along Van Brunt and Imlay Streets, Red Hook's main waterfront thoroughfares, homeless men sit on sidewalk sofas, prostitutes ply their trade, cars are stripped and drugs are openly sold near deserted red-brick warehouses. However, many small and medium-sized businesses like Mercedes Distribution, a data-processing storage firm with 150 employees, have moved into many of the area's old warehouses.
Beneath the Brooklyn Heights Promenade are a string of barely used Port Authority piers. In the early 1980's, the agency decided that it wanted to dispose of Piers 1 through 6, to let either the city or private developers transform the 60-acre parcel into housing, and for commercial and recreational uses. What ensued were several development plans, now defunct, and years of squabbling.
While the most recent proposal languishes, Mr. Golden and the Brooklyn Bridge Park Coalition -- a Brooklyn Heights community group that has developed an alternative plan including a park, marina and conference center -- are now calling for the creation of a new public authority like the one that developed Battery Park City in Manhattan to gain control of the site.
 
Navy Yard's Success Story
 Northeast of the Manhattan Bridge, beyond the industrial loft area known as Vinegar Hill, colonized during the 1980's by hundreds of artists, is the waterfront's other recent success story -- the Brooklyn Navy Yard. A decade or so after the Navy closed the shipyard, a publicly chartered industrial park began to emerge. Today, about 3,500 people are employed by 180 businesses -- from furniture and jewelry makers to ship repair companies and theatrical set designers -- which occupy the complex of century-old brick and steel buildings.
The northern end of the Navy Yard is also the city's designated site for a giant garbage-burning plant. The futures of an adjacent 40-acre Naval Reserve Station, recently declared surplus property by the Federal Government, and two privately owned sites in Williamsburg and Greenpoint, are also undecided.
Indeed, the waterfront's future remains very much in question. City officials concede that it is unlikely that major commercial, residential or recreational development will happen any time soon.
Instead, they see waterfront redevelopment as a delicate balancing act, in which fragile, existing industries are not driven away; new, light industry is attracted to areas like the Navy Yard and the Army Terminal; new housing is built in such areas as Red Hook and in severely overcrowded neighborhoods like Williamsburg, and recreation areas are created in Brooklyn Heights, on refurbished piers and at mall street-end parks.
"The future is not rosy and glory," said Mr. Ng, of the Department of Business Services, "but we're working with what we have the best we can."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
From a Pollutant, a Cleaner Fuel

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Despite recurring energy crises, the world has plenty of fuel. The problem is, it is in the wrong place or the wrong form. Coal does not run cars and trucks, and natural gas, because it is hard to ship, often runs nothing at all.
From time to time, desperate governments and venturesome capitalists try to produce diesel fuel and gasoline, the cream of the hydrocarbons, from natural gas or surplus coal. But usually these efforts are uneconomical. 
 Next month, a group will try a new method. A new refinery in Pueblo, Colo., will turn methane gas, a pollutant given off by decaying garbage, into diesel fuel. The fuel will be far cleaner, but no more expensive, than what is now available at filling stations. More important, the plant's builder, Rentech Inc., expects to make money.
 
Broad Expansion Sought
 Other landfills have burned methane to produce steam for powering factories or generating electricity, neither of which is needed in Pueblo. For the new plant -- called Synhytech, for synthetic hydrogen technology -- Rentech developed a patented catalyst that performs a key step of the operation. The new method could also be used to convert natural gas into diesel fuel in locations like Alaska that are too remote to justify building a natural gas pipeline.
At 240 barrels of products a day -- enough to fill one tanker truck -- the Pueblo plant is "a boutique refinery," said Rentech's president, Dennis L. Yakobson. But Rentech, based in Denver, believes that 100 landfills around the country could use the process. Rentech, which went public earlier this year and trades over the counter, hopes to license its technology to companies around the world. The stock, which is lightly traded, closed yesterday at $2.50.
The new plant's construction cost, $16 million, was put up by Fuelco, an unregulated subsidiary of the Public Service Company of Colorado.
Along with the diesel fuel, the Pueblo plant will produce naphtha and wax. Naphtha is used to make other chemicals; the wax, of a type mostly imported from South Africa, is used in everything from adhesives to lipsticks. The total value is about $60 a barrel, providing a satisfactory rate of return, Mr. Yakobson said.
 
52 Percent Methane
 Situated above Pueblo's 110-acre municipal landfill, the Rentech plant collects a gas that is 52 percent methane -- the main component of natural gas -- plus carbon dioxide, nitrogen and water vapor.
The technology disposes of a hazardous pollutant; the methane is flammable and adds to global warming. The United States Environmental Protection Agency in May proposed regulations that would force controls on methane emissions at more than 10 percent of the 6,000 landfills now operating.
Mr. Yakobson said the technology would prove valuable in converting natural gas to liquid fuels in remote areas, where there is gas but no market for it.
In these cases, the gas has to be cheap to make conversion economical. If a pipeline is available to ship gas to a conventional customer, the gas price becomes too high for the Rentech process to be competitive. The Pueblo plant will pay $50,000 a year for its gas, which is found money for the local government but only about 60 cents a barrel of product.
Another group interested in the new method includes companies that drill offshore, where gas can be a nuisance or even an impediment. Some have found gas associated with oil, but the gas cannot be economically shipped by tankers, and pipelines would be too costly.
Normally, in such circumstances, the gas is reinjected underground, but in some formations this is difficult because pressures are too high. Marathon Oil, a subsidiary of USX, initially rejected the Rentech process but is reconsidering it because of recent improvements.
 
From Decay of Trash
 The Rentech process involves taking the carbon and hydrogen atoms that emerge in small molecules from the decay of trash, in this case as methane gas, and stringing them together into the giant hydrocarbon molecules found in diesel fuel.
Rentech mixes the methane, or CH<4>, and water, or H<2>0, at high temperature and low pressure, producing two gases, carbon monoxide, or CO, and hydrogen, or H<2>. These are fuels also, because they burn readily.
Some carbon dioxide that is also produced in the process, and some that is naturally present in the landfill gas, is removed using standard industrial methods.
Then the remaining gases are sent to a synthesis reactor, where an iron-based catalyst a little coarser than talcum powder absorbs the carbon monoxide and the hydrogen and strings them together in straight-line hydrocarbon fuel molecules. The company says the catalyst, embedded in molten wax, represents an improvement on the Fischer-Tropsch process developed in the mid-1920's and used by the Nazis.
The diesel fuel that results has several advantages over what is made from crude oil, according to Mr. Yakobson. It has no sulfur, a component that the Environmental Protection Agency is struggling to remove from conventional diesel fuel with progressively stricter limits. It also has no aromatics, which are harder to burn and thus are a source of pollutants, some of them cancer-causing.
The fuel is pale champagne-colored, with very little smell. Commercial diesel fuel is amber and has a smell well known to anyone who has visited a truck stop.
 
More Nitrogen Oxide
 The Detroit Diesel Corporation tested the fuel recently in a transit bus engine and compared it to No. 1 diesel fuel, an off-the-shelf formulation cleaner than the No. 2 diesel now sold in truckstops. It found substantial decreases in particulate matter, hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide, but an increase in nitrogen oxide, an ingredient of smog. Nitrogen oxide rises with combustion temperature, and the Rentech diesel burns hotter.
If the plant turns a profit, it will be standing on the shoulders of giants that collapsed before it. The biggest coal-to-liquids project to date was run by the Nazis, to provide fuel for the Luftwaffe and the Wehrmacht during World War II. South Africa, in response to international sanctions, also makes gasoline from coal, at costs that are secret but believed to be high.
Other efforts to make diesel from coal or gas are under way or planned. The Department of Energy announced on July 30 that it would put $5 million over the next two years into research on making liquid fuel from coal. The goal is to reduce the cost to $30 a barrel over five to ten years.
New Zealand, to reduce its vulnerability to international crises, heavily subsidized a plant that turns natural gas into methanol and the methanol into 900,000 barrels of high-octane gasoline a year. Opened in 1985, the plant has operated smoothly, "like a Rolls-Royce," said Bruce Wallace, a spokesman for Fletcher Challenge, a company that owns 75 percent of it.
 
Not a Commercial Success
 The rest is held by Mobil, which runs the plant. But the project is hardly a commercial success; it cost $1.2 billion to build. The New Zealand Government paid Fletcher Challenge to take the 75 percent stake.
Mr. Wallace said that given the amount the Government had invested, it would not have turned a profit for New Zealand until oil prices rose to $50 or $60 a barrel, more than triple current levels. If prices do go that high, someone might build another plant as a profit-making venture, he said. But as to when that would be, he said, "we probably wouldn't even ask ourselves."

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "Using Landfill Gas to Produce a Clean Diesel Fuel"
 
A plant designed by Rentech uses landfill gas, currently a waste product and pollutant, to produce a very clean diesel fuel as well as naphtha, a chemical feedstock, and a wax, used in products from textiles to lipsticks.
 
1. Gas from landfill: Landfill gas, mostly methane, but also carbon dioxide, nitrogen and water vapor, is collected through pipes.
 
2. Gas compression and sulfur removal: The gas is compressed and strippe of sulfur, a mjor pollutant.
 
3. Steam reformer: Steam breaks down the landfill gas at high temperature into two gases, carbon monoxide and hydrogen, that can be burned as fuels, along with carbon dioxide.
 
4. Carbon dioxide absorber: The carbon dioxide is absorbed using conventional technology.
 
5. Carbon dioxide stripper: The carbon dioxide is purified and recycled into the steam reformer to improve the efficiency of the reaction.
 
6. Synthesis reactor: A catalyst stings the fueld gases into hydrocarbons and returns steam to the steam reformer.
 
7. Distillation column: The liquid hydrocarbons are cooled, producing diesel, naphtha and wax. (Source: Rentech)

HEADLINE: Dow Ends With 15.66 Rise; Early Rally Cut

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Stock prices yesterday regained part of the ground lost in Monday's slide, with many traders apparently believing that the Soviet crisis would have a limited impact on the American economy. Still, reports of tension in Moscow took some steam out of a strong early rally.
The Dow Jones industrial average took back nearly a quarter of Monday's 70-point loss, rising 15.66, to 2,913.69, after soaring 25 points at the opening. 
 Volume fell to 184.3 million shares, from 230.4 million on Monday.
"The market did not react as badly as many had feared," said Greg A. Smith, chief investment officer for Prudential Securities. "People realized that perhaps this thing isn't so bad for the economy."
Steven G. Einhorn, portfolio strategist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said that most investors saw the Soviet Union as "a bankrupt country that is economically distressed and doesn't have the option to be noncooperative with respect to the West."
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.96 points, to 379.43, a rise of 0.79 percent. The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks was up 4.41 points, to 502.05, an increase of 0.89 percent. The American Stock Exchange's composite index rose 1.39 points, to 360.30, a rise of 0.39 percent. And the New York Stock Exchange's index closed at 208.27, up 1.43 points, a rise of 0.69 percent. Advancing issues outpaced declining ones by 1,088 to 566.
As in the previous session, military equipment stocks continued to perform well yesterday. McDonnell Douglas rose 4 1/4, to 55 1/2; Lockheed was up 1 5/8, to 45 3/4, and General Dynamics rose 2 1/2, to 46 3/4.
Oil stocks also performed well generally. Triton Energy, an oil and gas exploration and development company, rose 4 3/4, to 43 1/4; Mobil was up 1 5/8, to 67, and Occidental Petroleum was up 1 1/8, to 24 1/8.
Westinghouse Electric was the most active issue on the Big Board, rising 1/8, to 22 5/8. H. J. Heinz, No. 2 on the active list, rose 1/4, to 45, following speculation that it might be a takeover target.
Shares of UAL, the parent of United Airlines, were down 5, to 128 1/4. The stock fell after more airlines joined in another round of fare discounting.
Deere was down 2 5/8, to 46 7/8, after the company reported a 72 percent slide in third-quarter profits.

HEADLINE: Airlines Speed Up Fare Cuts

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The airline industry is cutting its lowest discount fares more widely, deeply and earlier than it normally does at the end of the summer, a time when travel usually falls off and the industry puts in some lower fares to attract passengers.
Yesterday American Airlines capped a series of cuts in domestic fares begun by USAir on Sunday and matched by other major carriers. American reduced its lowest discount fares by as much as 28 percent on all domestic routes. 
 Typical savings for travelers will range from $60 to $100, but on some routes the reductions are more substantial. The round-trip off-peak super-saver fare between New York and Los Angeles will drop 28 percent, to $338 from $468; in peak periods the fare will be cut 24 percent, to $398 from $518.
The off-peak round-trip super-saver fares between New York and Miami will be reduced 24 percent, to $258 from $338, while the peak fares will fall 16 percent, to $318 from $378.
 
On Sale Until Oct. 31
 "The cuts are deeper than usual for the fall," said Ray Neidl, an airline analyst for Dillon, Read, "but they are not totally a surprise, taking into account the weak economy."
The fares, which were being put into computers yesterday, will be good for travel from Sept. 4 through Dec. 15, and will be on sale until Oct. 31.
The reductions affect only the super-saver fares, which are typically used by about 30 percent of those traveling. The figure is higher in the busy summer season because vacation travelers like to take advantage of the restricted fares. Tickets must be purchased seven days in advance, are nonrefundable and are valid only when fliers stay over a Saturday night.
Although some business travelers, particularly independent-business owners, are able to take advantage of super-saver fares, restrictions barring refunds and requiring a Saturday stay-over make them impractical for most corporate travelers, who require some flexibility in scheduling.
Moreover, airlines place limits on the discount fares for each flight, generally allotting more discount seats per flight on off-peak days like Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday.
Earlier this year the industry substantially increased some fares, particularly those used mostly by business travelers, and imposed restrictions that have made it more difficult for them to use discount fares.
Most other carriers, like United Airlines and Delta Air Lines, which have already followed USAir's move by cutting fares on competitive routes, are expected to match American's across-the-board cuts.
American initially said it had tried to match USAir's cuts only on routes where it competed with the carrier, which has its hub in Pittsburgh. But as United and Delta joined in trimming fares, it made sense to extend the cuts to all its routes, said Tim Smith, a spokesman for American.
"The point came where it was easier to match it everywhere," Mr. Smith said.
Fares on some international routes were cut 15 percent last week by British Airways P.L.C., a step that was matched by American and United. Then Pan American World Airways and Virgin Atlantic Airways lowered their ticket prices on some international routes.
Pan Am has distributed coupons through newspapers and travel agents for 25 percent off on flights to Europe, the Caribbean, Mexico and South America.
Northwest Airlines announced last weekend that it would cut fares by as much as 50 percent for fall and winter travel between the United States and London, Paris, Frankfurt, Amsterdam and Glasgow, Scotland. The lower fares are available through Sept. 18.
Mr. Neidl of Dillon, Read said that once a major carrier like USAir made a fare cut, the other large carriers were virtually forced to match it to prevent losing their customers.
In addition to matching the USAir move, some carriers, including Delta and Trans World Airlines, said they were reducing fares on some international routes by as much as 50 percent.
American Airlines also said it would expand its Latin American Service from 142 to 181 flights a week, for an increases of 27 percent. American acquired the routes from Eastern Airlines.
The anouncement comes a little more than a week after Pan Am, which has a major presence in Latin America, received approval from bankruptcy court to sell most of its assets to Delta. The deal will make Pan Am a smaller carrier concentrating on Latin America.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Changed Agenda for Moscow Envoy

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
For Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic elder and millionaire lawyer, the political chaos in the Soviet Union makes his mission as Ambassador to Moscow far different from what he envisioned when he accepted the appointment two months ago.
When President Bush selected him, he was expected to work with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and help him pioneer a way to a free-market economy. But now the coup by hard-liners has inspired questions of whether Mr. Strauss, who knows little about the Soviet Union and has only a smattering of Russian, is equipped to handle the very different challenges posed by the current turn of events. 
 At a news conference in the Rose Garden, Mr. Bush pointedly said that Mr. Strauss would not present his credentials to the current leadership, which the United States considers illegitimate.
Senior Administration officials said that unless Soviet authorities made it impossible, it was probable Mr. Strauss would attempt to meet with Boris Yeltsin, the President of the Russian federated Republic, to offer Mr. Bush's support to the democratic opposition forces. Mr. Strauss is also expected to ask to see Mr. Gorbachev.
"You go in there and use your own judgment," a senior official quoted Mr. Bush as telling Mr. Strauss at the White House today.
Mr. Strauss conceded to reporters after he was sworn in at the White House this morning that "circumstances have changed rather dramatically since I accepted this assignment. It's a different world." But in an apparent effort to point out that his strengths were still suitable to his task, Mr. Strauss added, "although the circumstances have changed, it seems to me that my mission remains basically the same, and that is to go to Moscow, speak very clearly, speak very plainly and, if necessary, with undiplomatic candor from time to time."
The Administration's original plan was to have Mr. Strauss, who is 72 years old, make his way to Moscow by the end of September after spending the summer studying Russian and being sworn-in just after Labor Day. But in the aftermath of the coup, Mr. Bush decided to have him dispatched to Moscow this week with instructions to demonstrate support for the anti-coup forces and assess the political crisis. Mr. Strauss left for Moscow tonight.
 
No Expert on Soviet Affairs
 "He was an interesting and creative appointment," said Dimitri Sims, an analyst of Soviet affairs at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "But this is the time for sophisticated reporting. Mr. Strauss is not a Soviet affairs analyst, he has no network of connections in Moscow, and his arrival may create an impression that the United States is prepared to maintain normal relations."
"It is unfortunate timing," said Herbert J. Ellison, a professor of Russian history at the University of Washington. "What one needs now is someone with the kind of savvy about Soviet politics as well as skills in Russian language and knowledge of Russian culture possessed by the former ambassador."
A senior State Department official disagreed, however, saying that Mr. Strauss had the political expertise to be effective in Moscow. "He's a man of great energy and dynamism," he added.
 
Something of a Surprise
 Mr. Strauss's appointment to replace Jack F. Matlock, who retired, came as something of a surprise given that he would be only the second envoy to Moscow since World War II who was not a career diplomat or a high-ranking military officer. Mr. Bush passed over Edward P. Djerejian, a professional diplomat initially favored by the State Department, who is now Ambassador to Syria.
Senior Administration officials said Mr. Strauss's functions would remain fluid until the situation in Moscow became clearer. Mr. Strauss will return to brief Mr. Bush some time next week. A senior State Department official said it is doubtful Mr. Strauss would then return full-time to Moscow any time soon unless the coup against Mr. Gorbachev failed.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
BUSH SNUBS CHIEFS OF 'ILLEGAL COUP'

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
President Bush today told the leaders of Monday's coup in the Soviet Union that the United States would refuse to establish normal relations with them, and he telephoned Boris N. Yeltsin to offer support.
"We are not giving up on the restoration of constitutional government in the Soviet Union," the President declared as tanks maneuvered in the streets of Moscow, well before the first signs that the coup might have stalled. 
 Moving to coordinate his strategy with European leaders, who voted today to hold up most of the European Community's planned economic aid to Moscow, Mr. Bush dispatched Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Brussels on Wednesday. [Page A11.]
 
Envoy to Shun Coup Leaders
 After Robert S. Strauss was sworn in as the new United States Ambassador to Moscow, Mr. Bush appeared with him on the White House lawn. The President said Mr. Strauss would travel to the Soviet Union immediately as a special envoy.
But to symbolize Mr. Bush's determination to help Mikhail S. Gorbachev regain office, Mr. Strauss was instructed not to present his credentials to the coup leaders, indeed not to meet with them at all except in a dire emergency.
"We're making very clear to the coup plotters that there will not be normal relations with the United States as long as this illegal coup remains in effect," the President said, in a noticeable toughening of his language.
But Mr. Bush was careful to avoid threats and to sound cautious and measured. He said he had no desire "to see this turn into an East-West confrontation" and declined to say which United States-Soviet agreements would take effect and which would not.
"We're just sitting here for a while, leaving everything on hold," the President told reporters at the White House before returning to his vacation home in Maine. "We've just got to take our time, we've got to be prudent -- a word I think is applicable here -- and I think we've got to be strong."
But American officials conceded that there was relatively little anyone outside the Soviet Union could do to defeat the coup, and specialists in Soviet affairs raised doubts about the effectiveness of the attempt to freeze out the new regime in Moscow by political means and of the Western allies' moves to cut off economic aid.
Asked what specific help the United States could give the forces headed by Mr. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, Mr. Bush replied only, "We're certainly going to offer encouragement in every way we can."
"You don't take freedom away from people very easily," he added. "You don't set back democracy very easily. Some coups fail. The likelihood of this, it's hard to evaluate in this circumstance. However, there appears to be very strong support from the people in the Soviet Union for constitutional government, for democratic reform."
The President appeared eager to identify American policy with Mr. Yeltsin, whom he had shunned for a time as a threat to Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Bush said of the Russian leader, who was elected in a landslide this year, "He's a very courageous man, and he said he's convinced the people will stand with him, and well they should."
 
Strauss's 'Undiplomatic Candor'
 Mr. Strauss said, in an uncharacteristic understatement, that "circumstances have changed rather dramatically since I accepted this assignment." But in an apparent effort to deflect suggestions that a Soviet expert rather than a corporate lawyer like himself is now needed in the Moscow embassy, he added, "It seems to me that my mission remains basically the same, and that is to go to Moscow, to speak very clearly, to speak very plainly and if necessary with undiplomatic candor from time to time."
Mr. Strauss left for Moscow tonight. White House officials said one of his first tasks would be to talk with Mr. Yeltsin, if the opposition leader remained at liberty when he arrived.
Mr. Bush also said he had sought several times to call Mr. Gorbachev, including one attempt this morning, but could not get through. The President did not say where he believed Mr. Gorbachev to be, though he is widely believed to be in a villa in the Crimea. The coup leaders have said Mr. Gorbachev stepped down for health reasons, but Mr. Bush, echoing other world leaders, said, "I must tell you I don't believe it."
Among the issues that the Administration is still reviewing are whether agricultural credits for the Soviet Union will be halted permanently, the status of treaties still awaiting approval by the Senate and the planned sponsorship with the Soviet Union of a Mideast peace conference in October.
 
Trade Status and Arms Treaties
 Senior officials on Capitol Hill said Congress almost certain not to grant the Soviet Union favored trade status and was unlikely to act on pending arms treaties when it returned from its summer recess next month.
Most Senators and Representatives who commented on the situation concentrated on attacking those who seized power. But as Mr. Bush himself noted in defending what he has done, there were criticisms of his policies from the right and the left.
Representative Bob Toricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, said the Administration had squandered "a chance to virtually remake history" by providing too little help for Mr. Gorbachev when he needed it worst.
Senators Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, faulted the Administration from another perspective, arguing that it had focused too heavily on Mr. Gorbachev at the expense of support for Mr. Yeltsin and other reformers. Mr. Moynihan commented, "There are a thousand ways to tell those people that if they lay one hand on Yeltsin they will be left to live off rotten cabbage for the next century."
But most political analysts said Mr. Bush found himself in a commanding position, with the emphasis once again back on foreign policy, his strength, rather than on what opponents say are his domestic-policy failures, which the Democrats have spent the summer attempting to exploit. One Democratic strategist commented, "He looks like the President of the world again, just like during the gulf, and that's very bad for us -- I have to admit it."
The President showed his confidence by deciding to continue his vacation, although he said that he would have "a more formal work schedule" than expected in the period before he returns to the White House on Sept. 3.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We are not giving up on the restoration of constitutional government in the Soviet Union," President Bush told reporters yesterday after swearing in Robert S. Strauss, right, as the new American Ambassador to Moscow. With them outside the White House was Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A13)

HEADLINE: Free-Trade Zone Progress

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Trade officials from the United States, Canada and Mexico said today that they had made progress toward setting up a North American free-trade zone, but that negotiations remained at an early stage.
"Fight as you may, you're not going to find that much controversy today," the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, told reporters at the close of a second round of talks. 
 The three countries want goods and services to move freely within a free-trade bloc of the continent's 360 million consumers, which would rival the European Community in size.
But labor leaders, environmentalists and other critics say the agreement would lead to an exodus of American and Canadian companies to Mexico to escape stricter environmental laws and exploit a low-cost labor force.
The trade officials said that they had no timetable for reaching an agreement, but that one was still possible before the end of the year.
The next round of talks would take place at Zacatecas, Mexico, on Oct. 26, when each country's proposals for reducing tariff barriers would be ready for discussion.
None of the trade officials would say how some of the social and environmental issues in the proposed trade agreement might be settled.
Labor leaders and environmental groups have complained that discussion of those issues have been secret.
Mrs. Hills said the agreement would raise labor standards. "It is a fact that as our economies grow, that there will be greater wealth for all."
