LENGTH: 2201 words

HEADLINE: Papp Names Akalaitis to Step In As Shakespeare Festival Head

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL

 BODY:
Joseph Papp, the founder of the New York Shakespeare Festival and its sole artistic leader for 37 years, has appointed JoAnne Akalaitis to succeed him, effective immediately.
The appointment ends a year of speculation on who would take over for the legendary director and showman who introduced New York City to free Shakespeare in the Park in 1956, and who turned 70 in June. The choice of Ms. Akalaitis, 54 years old, who has been Mr. Papp's artistic associate for the last year, signals a major change in the programming direction of the festival, long considered the premier nonprofit theater in the United States. 
 A figure synonymous with the New York avant-garde, Ms. Akalaitis is better known for reinterpreting the classics than for collaborating with playwrights in the development of new plays and musicals, as Mr. Papp has done. He has provided Broadway with some of its biggest hits, including "A Chorus Line," "Hair" and "That Championship Season," and nurtured some of the theater's greatest contemporary writers, including Vaclav Havel, David Mamet, David Rabe, Caryl Churchill, David Henry Hwang, John Guare, David Hare, Wallace Shawn and Tina Howe.
 
Other Staff Changes
 In addition to the appointment of Ms. Akalaitis, other staff changes include the promotions of Jason Steven Cohen, from associate producer to managing director, and Rosemarie Tischler, from casting director to artistic associate. Mr. Papp will retain the title of producer.
Mr. Papp has been absent from the theater since last spring because he is being treated for cancer and recovering from the death of his 28-year-old son, Tony, a sculptor and jewelry designer, of AIDS in June. During his leave, the festival has slipped into a financial crisis that has resulted in an almost 50 percent cutback in the number of new productions this season.
Last week, Mr. Papp agreed to give his first interview since the spring. He has lost a great deal of weight, and when he crossed the room of his Greenwich Village apartment, his walk was slow and uncertain. But when he sat down to talk, his manner was as vigorous as ever. His determination to fight for the survival of his own theater, and of the theater in general, has not abated. And although his reputation in the industry has been as a maverick -- if not an egomaniac -- recent events seem to have mellowed him somewhat.
 
Didn't Know What 'No' Was
 "My life has been the theater," he said. "The idea of free Shakespeare happened because I believed it was good for the whole city. I was always a good organizer and I didn't know what 'no' was. When people told me something couldn't be done, I knew they were wrong. And I would just plow my way through. I never saw myself as a hero or as doing anything unusual. I never went to college. I have a real working-class background. But I knew the city and the people in it."
As Mr. Papp steps down as artistic director, his theater's operating budget has been cut to $10.5 million from last season's $13.5 million. Besides the cuts in production, the theater plans, for the first time in its history, to co-produce up to four shows with other nonprofit theaters in order to share expenses.
Forty-three staff members have lost their jobs, including 37 stagehands from in-house production shops -- scenic, costume, electric and props -- that have been closed.
Festival Latino, a program of Hispanic theater and film that has been produced annually for the last 15 years, may also be in jeopardy.
Compounding the institution's financial troubles is Mr. Papp's refusal to accept money from the National Endowment for the Arts. Two seasons ago, he disagreed with the agency when it withdrew its support from an exhibition by the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. The festival lost Federal grants worth $373,000 that year, and Mr. Papp refused to apply for funds last year.
Also in the last year, the festival's funds from New York City have been cut 33 percent, and from New York State 60 percent. Foundation support has shifted away generally from the arts toward health and social concerns, and corporate support is down because of the recession. Perhaps most important, the festival no longer has the profits of "A Chorus Line" to pay its bills. The show earned $38.8 million before it closed on April 28, 1990, after a 15-year run.
 
'You Can't Pigeonhole Her'
 But the tough economic times, Mr. Papp said, are an opportunity for the festival's rejuvenation, and he calls Ms. Akalaitis, who has directed at the Public intermittently for the last 15 years, the perfect person to guide it. "JoAnne has the most original mind in the theater today," he said. "As a leader, she is independent. She doesn't recognize boundaries and you can't pigeonhole her. She has great drive. And she is very astute about how the theater is run."
As might be expected, Ms. Akalaitis's new season will consist mostly of classics, albeit those that are infrequently produced. Bertolt Brecht's "Jungle of the Cities," a co-production with Mabou Mines, directed by Anne Bogart, will open the season, followed by "Pericles," the only Shakespeare on the schedule, starring Campbell Scott and directed by Michael Greif. Mr. Greif was chosen by Mr. Papp last season to be one of three resident directors at the festival, along with George C. Wolfe and David Greenspan. "Pericles" is his only production this season.
Mr. Greenspan, too, will have one production instead of three, directing a pair of new plays he has written, as yet untitled. Because Mr. Wolfe is directing a Broadway-bound musical this season, "Jelly's Last Jam," he will not direct at the festival at all. Instead, Ms. Akalaitis says, he will be a "curator producer" of a bill of solo performance artists who will appear at the theater.
The season will also include a double bill of Jean Genet's "Four Hours in Shatila," about the 1982 massacre of Palestinians in a refugee camp by Lebanese Christians allied with Israel, which Ms. Akalaitis will direct ("it is not an anti-Israeli piece," she said) and Dario Fo's "Story of the Tiger," directed by Chris Ashley, an artistic associate at New York Theater Workshop and an "up-and-coming talent," according to Ms. Akalaitis. She described the piece as "anti-Maoist."
 
Gloria Foster in Lorca Play
 In a co-production arrangement with the Second Stage, "Before It Hits Home," a play by Cheryl West about AIDS and a black family, will be presented at the Public, directed by Tazwell Thompson, who did the play last season at Arena Stage in Washington. Ms. Akalaitis will direct John Ford's " 'Tis Pity She's a Whore," and Melia Bensussen, a young director who ran a free play-reading series at the Public last season, will direct Federico Garcia Lorca's "Blood Wedding," starring Gloria Foster.
Three more Shakespeare productions are tentatively planned for next summer, which would make four for the season. When questioned on the progress of the Shakespeare Marathon, Mr. Papp's plan to give American actors a chance to work on the classics by presenting all 36 of Shakespeare's plays, Ms. Akalaitis said, "I haven't even thought about that, frankly."
She did allow that the season she has chosen was "too serious."
"It sort of shook down that way," she said. "But you can't measure a season on how many times people laugh. If they need a giggle, they can find it in a John Candy movie. We will have funny plays and musicals, eventually, but this is a tough world."
Has she thought about how this season might appeal to a Public Theater audience accustomed to having its esoteric fare balanced by "The Mystery of Edwin Drood" or "Much Ado About Nothing?"
 
Wants a Wider Audience
 "I think it is hard to characterize the Public Theater audience," she responded. "It is wide and it should be wider. There should be more people of color."
Ms. Akalaitis said one of the ways she wanted to reach out to different audiences was to present the work of smaller theater companies that have lost their homes because of the recession. These would include Cucaracha, Baca and Home for Contemporary Theater.
Although Ms. Akalaitis has directed only one full production of a play by an American playwright (Len Jenkin's "American Notes," at the Public Theater in 1988), she said, "We have to be very aggressive in establishing connections." Among the playwrights she says she will pursue are Marlane Meyer, Suzan-Lori Parks, Tony Kushner, Elizabeth Egloff, Eric Overmyer and Charles Mee Jr.
These playwrights are mostly unknown to a large theatergoing audience, and their work will need financial subsidy. Mr. Papp realized early on that he could present plays by lesser-known talents by also producing plays and musicals likely to have a commercial future, often through transferring them to Broadway. Among Mr. Papp's hits were "For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf," by Ntozake Shange; "Sticks and Bones" and "Streamers," by David Rabe, and the highly lucrative musicals "Drood," "The Pirates of Penzance" and "Two Gentlemen of Verona."
Ms. Akalaitis said she, too, was committed to the development of new musicals at the Public, though she admitted no knowledge of -- or interest in -- Broadway. "Believe me, I have nothing against money," she said. "But Broadway is not my scene. I think there should be people in this institution who can keep us involved there; it just doesn't have to originate with me. Theater should be pluralistic. We are talking about hiring a consultant to work as a scout for any musicals that are out there."
What would the motivation be for a musical team to go to the Public, instead of Playwrights Horizons or Lincoln Center, whose artistic directors have recently produced such hits as "Anything Goes," "Sarafina!" and "Once on This Island"?
"History, for one thing," she said. "The cachet of the Public and the promise of a first-rate production with a really great audience. But cultural institutions are not business institutions. We are about making art accessible and important. We are communicating."
One person who might prove helpful to Ms. Akalaitis is the actor Kevin Kline, who recently joined the festival's board and who will be in charge of an advisory board whose purpose, Mr. Kline said, is "pretty vague at the moment."
"It will be comprised," he said, "of the old guard who have worked at the festival and have a grasp of its ongoing philosophy, who will be part of the continuum."
What may not continue is the institution's refusal to apply for National Endowment funds. It is an issue that seems to find Ms. Akalaitis and her predecessor on different sides, and she declined to discuss it. "I want to talk to the board about it," she said. "I'm not sure how I feel, frankly."
 
Health a Priority
 Even so, Mr. Papp's commitment to Ms. Akalaitis seems solid. "I will not censor JoAnne in any way," he said. "She is the artistic director now. I'm the producer and can provide the overall view. It remains to be seen what will happen, but isn't that exciting?"
Perhaps, though many in the industry still cannot envision the theater without Mr. Papp.
His health, however, must remain a priority. "I've been going through treatment at Sloan-Kettering," he said, "as part of some kind of experiment that has to do with a new drug." And he added firmly, "It looks like I'm improving."
He said the death of his son, the youngest of five children, had hit him especially hard. "Tony knew all the songs, all the lyrics of all the shows we did," he remembered. "His artistic ability as a sculptor. . . ." He was unable to finish the sentence, looking suddenly like an old man.
"I still haven't been able to deal with that grief," he continued in a steadier tone. "It is the most grievous experience to lose this young man, at the peak of his artistic life and his youth. I found notes he had written saying his dad was a great guy, which made me feel good, because when you work so hard in your career you always feel that you are neglecting your children. But I taught him how to hit a ball, ride a bike. I spent a long time with him. He learned from me. And I learned from him." He shook his head. "Twenty-eight years old," he said.
He was told about an incident that happened at the festival last March, after he stopped going to the office. A maintenance man, a self-professed spiritualist, went into Mr. Papp's locked office to clean it. When he came out, he told a co-worker that he had felt "a cold wind in there" and didn't want to go back.
"I don't want to make fun of spirituality," Mr. Papp said, "but maybe a window was open. Look, why make it all so ominous? What's bad? People get sick, people die. It's the law of nature. The important thing is to maintain a positive attitude toward life. That's what gives me courage. I don't see life as something to dread."
He mentioned that he had been reading a new translation of the French classic novel "Les Liaisons Dangereuses," and he talked about the complexity of the language and how the adaptor had mastered it. "You know," he said with admiration in his voice, "there are still so many ways to say something new."

HEADLINE: Patients Refusing to Be Well: A Disease of Many Symptoms

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
THE young man said his head felt as if it were filled with cotton, his heart felt "weak," his arm was numb and tingled, his veins ached.
By the time he was referred to Dr. Arthur Barsky, a psychiatrist at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, he had been examined by specialists in infectious disease, endocrinology, allergy, kidney disease and neurology and was scheduled for tests at three different Boston hospitals. 
 But none of the tests showed any medical problems. "He just had the conviction he was sick, and so interpreted all his vague aches and pains as proof," Dr. Barsky said.
 
Many Unexplained Symptoms
 The young man is not alone. "Up to 50 percent of patients in physicians' offices are there for at least one symptom with no medical explanation," said Dr. Charles Ford, a psychiatrist at the University of Alabama who is a leading expert on hypochondria. "And 10 percent of patients have no evidence of any medical disease whatever."
Doctors, out of frustration, often dismiss such patients as hypochondriacs or "crocks." Sometimes the problems are with the doctors: the patients have real problems but the doctors cannot identify them. But often the patients are "somatizing," expressing emotional conflicts or the need for attention as physical maladies.
While in the past such patients shuttled from emergency rooms to specialists to medical labs, doctors are finding new methods to identify these patients and help them.
One motive for the recent interest in treating somatizers is economic. "Somatizers have medical costs 10 to 14 times higher than the national average," said Dr. Michael Kashner, a medical economist at the University of Arkansas medical school in Little Rock. Dr. Ford, who earlier this year prepared advice for the American Academy of Family Physicians on how to treat somatizers, said somewhere between $20 and $30 billionwas spent each year on unneeded health care for such patients. The cost is borne, not only by the individual, but by all those people whose insurance premiums rise because of these bills.
Of course, it is prudent to consult a doctor when there is a symptom of illness. And the symptoms that most commonly bring people to a doctor's office usually have no medical cause.
A 1989 study of 1,000 patients seeking help from internists found that the most common symptom, chest pain, signified a medical problem in just 11 percent of cases. For fatigue, the next most common, there was a medical cause in only 13 percent of cases. For dizziness, the figure was 18 percent.
 
A Step Further
 "Hypochondriacs carry it a step further," Dr. Barsky said. "Unlike most of us, they don't feel better when a doctor reassures them that there's nothing wrong."
He added, "Somatizers have the firm belief that they are sick and so reinterpret ambiguous sensations like dizziness or being out of breath as proof." The more symptoms they notice, the more anxious they get and this, in turn, makes them physically upset, thus providing them with still more symptoms.
One man Dr. Barsky treated feared he had tuberculosis and had a skin test for it. "For the test, they prick your arm," Dr. Barsky said. "Everyone gets a red flare for a while, but all that matters is what's there after 48 hours. His test was normal, but he remained convinced his initial skin flare meant he had TB."
Dr. Barsky's research suggests that hypochondriacs are prone to complaining about their symptoms in part because they are more sensitive than others to physical sensations in general.
In an article published this year in the Journal of Psychiatric Research, Dr. Barsky said a study of 41 hypochondriacs showed that compared with other people, the hypochondriacs tended to feel bodily sensations of all sorts more intensely and tended to interpret them as disturbing. While other people would see sensations, like cold hands or a twitching eyelid, as perfectly normal, the hypochondriacs seized on them as a sign of disease.
"If most people start to pay close attention to their throat, they'll begin to notice it's dry, scratchy and itchy, and try to clear it or start coughing," Dr. Barsky said. "That's a normal response, which comes from paying close attention to a bodily sensation. It's the hyponchondriacs who will then interpret that as a medical symptom of some sort rather than normal discomfort."
 
Counseling Distraction
 Because part of the problem for hypochondriacs is that they focus so intently on scanning their bodies for signs of disease, Dr. Barsky's treatment includes teaching them to distract themselves when they find they are worrying about some sensation.
Another facet of his suggested therapy for hypochondriacs is teaching them to relax. "When they're anxious, they get hypervigilant and start scanning their body for something worrisome," Dr. Barsky said. "If they calm down, they won't do that so much."
A third approach is to explain to those prone to hypochondria "what are normal aches and pains," Dr. Barsky said. "They have completely unrealistic views of good health, so they see any bodily discomfort, from a bloody nose or cramp to feeling dizzy, as a symptom" he said.
For many somatizers, the real problem is depression or anxiety. A study published in the Archives of General Psychiatry last March found that in 68 women who were somatizers, two-thirds suffered from depression and three-quarters had an anxiety disorder, like panic attacks. The study was published by Jacqueline Golding, a psychologist at the Institute for Health and Aging at the University of California at San Francsisco, and colleagues.
Psychiatrists say that when the underlying depression and anxiety are treated, the hypochondria often disappears. But because hypochondriacs are convinced that they have medical problems, it can be hard to get them to consider psychotherapy.
"Psychotherapy often is just not appropriate," said Dr. Ford said. "Somatizers get angry if you refer them to a psychiatrist, since they don't believe there could be a psychological cause."

HEADLINE: A Nation Hungers for Farm Stands And a Harvest Without Cellophane

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
LIKE steepled white clapboard churches, dusty Little League parks and weathered rail fences that cinch acres of corn, the roadside farm stand is part of the American landscape, a fixture in the national psyche. The sight of a wood plank set between sawhorses at the side of the road, buckling under the weight of tomatoes and corn, is enough to set most drivers' brake feet atingle and triggers involuntary rubbernecking.
It's hard to resist vestiges of a shared past. 
 The farm stand has entered the 90's: The wooden plank may have grown into a rambling food emporium; the local raspberry stand may have gone whole hog into mail-order jam; the local herbgrower might have moved his stand from the roadside to an urban farmers' market. But the farm stand essence remains: a link between farmers and those who left the farm, a world dependent on memory and the senses -- things that frenetic, modern life tends to blunt.
After decades of eating food encased in cellophane protection, more and more shoppers are reaching for naked, sun-warmed tomatoes, unwrapped lettuce, cucumbers with tender, unwaxed skin. The urge hasn't abated since John McPhee described the arrival of fresh corn at a New York City Greenmarket in 1976:
" 'The people fell on it, stripped it, threw the husks around,' " he writes, quoting Rich Hodgson of Hodgson Farms in Plattekill, N.Y. " 'They were fighting, grabbing, snatching at anything they could get their hands on,' said the farmer. 'It was as if there was a famine going on.' "
The famine was for personal contact as much as for fine produce, a hunger that hasn't been sated.
"It seems like the bigger and more sophisticated conventional supermarkets get, the more people want a connection with the people who grow their food," said Hilary Baum, a co-founder of Public Market Partners, a nonprofit group in New York City that has assisted 20 urban farmers' markets around the country.
Ms. Baum estimates that nearly 2,000 urban farmers' markets and thousands more farm stands have sprouted up in the past 15 years. Some urban markets allow farmers to sell only what they grow, while others are more lenient; most farm stands sell their own crops as well as produce that they have bought. Agriculture experts say that the amount of money that Americans pay directly to farmers has doubled in those 15 years and is now close to $2 billion a year, or 2 percent of the total that people spent on produce.
Changes in the nation's diet over the past two decades sent produce sales soaring, stoked an appetite for arcane greens and fueled a preference for organic fruits and vegetables. A bumper crop of farm cookbooks in 1991 -- "The Modern Country Cook," (Viking), "Food from an American Farm" (Simon & Schuster), "The Farm Market Cookbook," (Doubleday) and "Farm House Cookbook" which will be released by Workman in the fall -- say that the farm fixation is more than dietary. A steadfast piece of the American heart has sent customers to small, family-owned stands where the deals are person to person.
"Naturally," is how farmers and market organizers explain the success and the continuing evolution of local markets.
"Customers have a natural sympathy for the small farmer," said Robert A. Lewis, the chief marketing representative of New York State's Department of Agriculture, who helped found the Greenmarket in New York City in 1976. Direct marketing, he said, has been a "natural antidote" to the escalating operating costs and land values of family farms.
By becoming retailers, farmers weed out wholesale brokers, "natural predators," said Perry Kozlowski, a berry grower in Forestville, Calif., in Sonoma County. A small farmer who sells directly to customers can make up to three times the amount that one who sells to a wholesale broker can make, he said, adding that brokers also impeded a farm's "natural diversity."
"When my parents started this ranch in the 50's, wholesalers basically bought one kind of raspberry and one kind of apple," he said. After moving into direct marketing, the Kozlowskis began growing "golden raspberries, blackberries, boysenberries, strawberries," he said. "We grow what people want now, not just what wholesalers can ship."
Alexander Van Rensselaer, owner of the Hay Day farm stores in Westport and Greenwich, Conn., encountered a similar barrier between customers and the vine-ripened tomatoes that he began growing in 1970. "Brokers gave me these blank looks," he said. "They bought green tomatoes, and they had no idea what to do with a red tomato." He set up shop to sell his tomatoes.
For these growers, going retail with produce was the first step. Mr. Kozlowski's family now sells as much private-label jam as berries; Mr. Van Rensselaer doesn't grow tomatoes anymore. His orginal store has doubled in size; he opened a second location in Greenwich and this week he is opening Hay Day Cafe in Ridgefield, Conn.
But for other family farmers, growing new varieties of vegetables and fruits was enough. Inspired by chefs like Alice Waters, who opened Chez Panisse 20 years ago in Berkeley, Calif., and who says she spends "as much time shopping for diverse, high-quality ingredients as cooking," farmers across the country have planted new vegetable varieties that fetch premium prices. "When we started Greenmarket, it was basic corn and tomatoes, cucumbers and peppers," Mr. Lewis said. Today one Greenmarket farmer has 40 varieties of peppers.
Old-time farmers are amused at how urban farmers' markets have affected planting. They offer their own theory on the rise of baby vegetables. "You have to plant little things and herbs, stuff that has more value to it so you can pack a truck with a thousand bucks worth and make the drive worthwhile," said Edward Latham, whose 400-acre family farm at Orient, L.I., dates to 1805. "If you just grow corn or potatoes, you're going to need a semitrailer to make a day's pay."
But customer demand doesn't stop at the city limits. Ten years ago, Mr. Latham grew strawberries and his daughter sold them at a stand outside his farm. Today, six employees help sell the strawberries, plus the panopoly of produce, herbs and flowers at his stand. "It helps," he said. "A lot of neighbors who didn't go retail ended up selling out to developers."
There is an undeniable similarity between those who would buy the vacation homes built near Mr. Latham's farm and those who request bunches of hand-plucked baby lettuce or pricey little boxes of wild berries at the urban farmers' market 90 miles west. The yuppification of American farming is part of the current direct-market ecosystem.
But like most natural phenomena, the market for midget vegetables and arcane fruit is balanced by the enduring need for affordable healthy produce. American Demographics magazine found that direct-market customers were concentrated at opposite ends of the economic scale. "Consumers who buy food from farms tend to be older and relatively well-to-do or low-income and looking for bargains," the article said.
Public Market Partners concurs. "The rise in direct marketing is not simply about people who want to pay dearly for a perfectly dear tomato," Ms. Baum said. Markets in high-rent neighborhoods stock high-rent produce, but, she said, "Markets continue to thrive in inner-city areas by offering bargains for bulk buying of in-season produce."
City planners recognize the wide-ranging appeal of centrally located farmers' markets. "The market in Syracuse was originally sponsored by a civic association; so was the one in Buffalo," Mr. Lewis said. Tucson, Ariz., Lynchburg, Va., and Little Rock, Ark., have also created central farmers' markets to revitalize downtown shopping areas, Ms. Baum said. "It's gotten to the point that cities are fighting each other for farmers," Mr. Lewis said.
Everytown, U.S.A., wants Mr. Greenjeans. He is an antidote to the plastic-wrapped world of suburban shopping malls. He brings a timeless pageant that is as much about people as it is about produce.
Every Saturday morning a patch of asphalt in Carrboro, N.C., outside Chapel Hill, begins blooming before dawn. When the sky is still a tug-of-war between gray and blue, a battered Ford pickup rattles into the lot. It has a bumper sticker that says "I Own a Gun and I Vote" and it is loaded with tomatoes. A shiny Volvo station wagon with a Greenpeace decal pulls in. A rusty brown Buick whose front license plate says "Prayer Changes Things" arrives next, full of homemade pies.
"It's mountain mint week," says one shopper, divining the herbaceous perfume between the layers of sausage and biscuit smell, the coffee, cinnamony apple turnovers, basil and damp earth in the city's morning air.
"That's right, lady, and I got organic corn, yep," said Chester Copeland, a 68-year-old, fourth-generation farmer who is also the Carrboro market's manager. "Organic tomatoes. Touch 'em lightly, darlin'. Careful!"
"They can't keep their hands off," he whispered and then, hooking a thumb to the suspender of his denim overalls, he told how going retail had saved his 15-acre farm: "I was losing my shirt and then, see that guy over there? That hippie-looking type? He started this market. That was over 10 years ago and I'm doing real good. We get the society type and the college type and the family people, young, old, you name it. This is where the elite meet to greet."
He waved to a sprout-grower in the neighboring stand, raised his eyebrows and grinned. "I never thought I'd live to see the day," he said. "But they show me things and I show them a few things. It takes all types and it's fine with me. I see my friends. I sell my stuff. I'm staying alive."

HEADLINE: Louisiana Baffled by Vast Fish Kills

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 17

 BODY:
All across South Louisiana in this wettest of summers, the fish stories are depressingly the same: dead fish.
At last count, 750,000 fish had died: striped mullet, largemouth bass, yellow bass, freshwater drum, spotted gar, ladyfish, shad, buffalo, mosquito fish, carp, southern flounder, blue catfish and more. 
 What is killing them is not clear.
State environmental officials suspect a pesticide used in the vast fields of sugar cane that stretch along the waterways of south-central Louisiana.
State agriculture officials say they cannot blame the pesticide without more information, although they have imposed a temporary ban on its use.
Many people say the fish are dying for a combination of reasons: the heat, the pesticide and a runoff of various farm chemicals from some of the heaviest rain on record.
 
Unusually Massive
 The Federal Environmental Protection Agency says the kills dwarf the summer's other much-publicized environmental disaster, the pesticide spill that destroyed tens of thousands of fish in the Sacramento River in California. There have been 19 fish kills since early July, about half of them in Vermilion and Iberia Parishes, the rest in the parishes south and west of Baton Rouge. Two kills, in Bayou Lafourche and the Blind River, extended for 10 miles.
While it is not unusual to find dead fish floating on waterways in the steamy Louisiana summers, when oxygen in the waterways is depleted by the heat, this summer's kills are unusually extensive, and they have captured the attention of the region like the steamiest political scandal.
Sister Helen Vinton, a Roman Catholic nun who has become the state's most active lobbyist seeking safer use of farm chemicals, said the fish kills had brought attention to a serious problem in which Louisiana's farmers had grown much too dependent on chemicals. "We've used so many pesticides for so long," she said.
Sister Helen, a grass-roots advocate for displaced sugar cane workers, slipped almost unnoticed into the state bureaucracy in 1989 as a member of the Pesticide Advisory Commission, an arm of the Department of Agriculture and Forestry.
This week, the Agriculture Department, long regarded as more a friend of farming and industry than of the environment, banned the use, pending a review, of the pesticide azinphos-methyl, used liberally this summer to attack the sugar cane borer.
The department acted three days after a crop-dusting plane sprayed the chemical over the town of Grosse Tete, which lies alongside sugar cane fields just west of Baton Rouge. Six people were treated in hospital emergency rooms for complaints of burning eyes, throats, noses and nausea from the spraying on Aug. 9.
The pilot was arrested on charges of negligent injury and his license and those of two other pilots involved in spraying incidents were suspended.
The Agriculture and Forestry Commissioner, Bob Odum, assembled a panel of experts in an attempt to learn what has killed so many fish this summer and whether azinphos-methyl is to blame.
The panel, which is still investigating, said it was too early to know exactly what had caused the kills.
But one panel member, Paul Conzelmann, a biologist with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, said that 10 of the 12 kills he had studied showed classic signs of poisoning by the family of chemicals that includes azinphos-methyl.
According to the State Department of Environmental Quality, fishermen and others have observed crop-dusters spraying near or over bayous and canals before some of the fish kills. But some insist that the chemical is not the only culprit.
 
Pointing to Natural Process
 Norris Grabert Jr., a parish agricultural agent in New Iberia, said much of the problem was a result of oxygen depletion caused by the heat and by the runoff of organic matter from woodlands into streams in the frequent rains.
In New Iberia, where sugar cane propels the economy, the borer is a major villain. The farm economy is already vulnerable because of a killing freeze the winter before last. And last year's mild winter encouraged the borer.
Mr. Grabert said nearly 85 percent of the sugar cane crop had been attacked by the borer.
Still, thanks in part to use of the chemical, the crop is expected to be good this year.
The American Sugar Cane League, a farmers' lobbying organization, said that it was concerned about the fish kills and that if waterways were sprayed with pesticide it was accidental. But the group said that naturally occurring processes could be involved.
In most cases the fish have died by the thousands or tens of thousands, left floating in the waterways that help make Louisiana a fisherman's paradise and seafood an important business.
 
'Everything Was Dead'
 Describing several of the kills, Maureen O'Neill, a state water quality official, said: "Everything was dead. Fish, turtles, snakes, everything in the immediate vicinity."
The Federal Environmental Protection Agency said that if the pesticide was behind the deaths, the Louisiana kills would be among the largest pesticide-related kills of the past decade.
"More than 10,000 is an unusual occurrence," said Susan H. Wayland, the deputy director of the agency's Office of Pesticide Programs. The agency said at least 100,000 fish were killed in the Sacramento River. In one Louisiana kill, in Assumption Parish, there were more than 200,000 dead fish.
From her base in an old Cajun cottage near New Iberia, Sister Helen is riveting public attention on what has long been regarded as a nuisance to be endured like the humidity: careless crop-dusters.
She says the planes periodically dust people along with sugar cane, which stretches in long green rows across much of Southern Louisiana, nudging highways, homes and waterways.
Since her appointment to the nine-member commission, Sister Helen has been the sole commissioner calling for stricter control of crop-dusters and a public hearing into their practices.
The banned chemical is toxic to insects, fish and people, attacking the nervous system like a nerve gas used in warfare.
In Grosse Tete, which has 727 residents, the crop-duster exposed "the whole town" to the chemical, said Mayor Pro Tem Dolores Nall.
 
'An Ongoing Problem'
 "The plane got caught in the wind as the pilot was spraying," Mayor Nall said. "It was 6:30 P.M. and people were mowing their yards or relaxing in patios. People were overcome by fumes. This is an ongoing problem."
After a crop-duster flew low over Cesar and Ruby Romero's house near New Iberia on a breezy day last month, 400 catfish, 80 gamefish and 7 bass died in the spring-fed pond behind the house near the cow pasture. The plane flew close enough for Mrs. Romero to read its identification number.
A neighbor who wrote down the plane's number was sprayed, Mr. Romero said. "The pilot was so close, our neighbor could tell he was blond," he said.

HEADLINE: Rep. Harley O. Staggers Sr., 84, Democrat Who Aided Railroads

BYLINE: By NOAM S. COHEN

 BODY:
Harley O. Staggers Sr., a West Virginia Congressman for 32 years who is credited with helping to revive the nation's rail system, died yesterday at Sacred Heart Hospital in Cumberland, Md. He was 84 years old and lived in Keyser, W.Va.
Mr. Staggers died of congestive heart failure and respiratory failure, a family spokesman said. 
 From 1949 to 1981 he represented West Virginia's Second District, a sweeping mountainous region that covered the state's least populated areas. His son Harley Jr. has represented the district since 1983.
An old-style liberal Democrat, Mr. Staggers in the mid-1950's proposed the creation of a domestic Marshall Plan to curb unemployment and proposed the creation of a new Cabinet-level post, Secretary of Peace.
 
Daylight Time an Issue
 In 1966, Mr. Staggers won passage of a law requiring uniform observance of daylight-saving time. Referring to the confusion that the law was meant to correct, he said at the time, "It's a small thing, but it irritates thousands of people in this land."
During one hearing, he cited a Moundsville, W.Va., bus driver who encountered seven time changes while making runs to St. Clairsville, Ohio, a distance of about 20 miles.
That same year, Mr. Staggers became chairman of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee. He used his platform to influence laws on energy, broadcasting, health and transportation.
He used his position in the House to insure that train lines through West Virginia continued to operate. He also helped convince the Department of Transportation to spend $120 million for the experimental Personal Rapid Transit system, which used computer-controlled passenger cars at West Virginia University in Morgantown.
But he also suffered setbacks that were unusual for a powerful committee chairman.
In 1971, he tried to force CBS to turn over to his committee the outtakes from a documentary on the Pentagon, but he was rebuked when the full House voted against his proposal for citing the network for contempt for refusing to comply.
In 1975, Mr. Staggers was ousted from the chairmanship of his committee's Investigations Subcommittee by those who thought the panel was inactive under his leadership.
In one of his last acts in the House, he successfully pushed for passage of the Staggers Rail Act of 1980. The law brought about partial deregulation of the national railway system.
The act created competition within the railway system and with the trucking industry, and is credited by economists with making the nation's railroads more efficient. Economists who studied the issue have said the act saved at least $20 billion by eliminating wasteful train routes and encouraging competition.
"There's a consensus among economists that regulation was doing more harm than good," said Theodore E. Keeler, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, who studies transportation. "That view certainly was vindicated."
Harley Orrin Staggers was born in a two-room log cabin in Mineral County, W.Va., on Aug. 3, 1907. He would have gone to work as a railroad hand, his son Harley said, had he not been a high school football star.
"He used to say that he wouldn't have gotten a college education without the sports," his son said in an interview yesterday. "Without that help he would have been in railroads."
Mr. Staggers graduated from Emory and Henry College in Emory, Va., in 1931. He was a college football and basketball coach, until he became a sheriff of Mineral County in 1937.
Mr. Staggers served in naval aviation during World War II and was elected to Congress in 1948.
In addition to his son Harley, Mr. Staggers is survived by his wife, Mary; another son, Daniel Casey Staggers of Keyser, and four daughters, Margaret Ann Staggers of Beckley, W.Va., Mary Katherine Staggers of Burlington, W.Va.; Frances Susan Tasker of Keyser, and Elizabeth Ellen Shank of Morgantown, and 10 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Governors Urge Overhaul of Health Care in U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The nation's governors approved a policy statement today urging sweeping reform of the American health care system to make "health care affordable and available for all," but only after sharp partisan debate over whether to call for the Bush Administration and Congress to act by 1994.
The policy statement passed unanimously, reflecting broad agreement that there was a growing crisis in both the cost and the availability of health care, which the governors said was straining state budgets already pressed by the recession. 
 But the governors, here for the annual summer meeting of the National Governors' Association, divided along partisan lines when Democrats unsuccessfully sought an amendment to demand that the Federal Government overhaul the system by 1994.
While several Democratic governors said they had sought to prod both Congress and the White House, there was a clear focus on President Bush, frequently accused by Democrats of neglecting the domestic agenda.
"When the President of the United States places the full force of his executive leadership and the power of his office behind any issue, things happen," said Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, a Democrat. "We mobilized an entire country behind Desert Storm."
 
A Prediction for 1992
 Several governors did not attend the Seattle meeting. Democrats failed to get the two-thirds vote needed for the amendment to set a 1994 deadline (the vote was 19 to 17), but Gov. Booth Gardner of Washington, a Democrat who is retiring as chairman of the governors' association, predicted later that the health care issue would be at the center of the 1992 Presidential campaign.
Mr. Gardner said there would be a "chain reaction" push for change in the system, saying, "In my seven years in this association, I have never seen this intensity on an issue before."
The policy statement passed today asserts that Medicaid, the state and Federal program to provide health care to the poor, is "broken," has become "rigid and overly complex" and should be replaced. It calls for a new program to provide care to people with low incomes, including those who are working but lack health insurance. It also suggests that the Federal Government, through the Medicare program, pick up the responsiblity of providing long-term care for the elderly and disabled.
The statement also calls for new flexiblity from the Federal Government to allow states to experiment with ways of providing health care; many of the Governors here envision states' leading the way to a new health care system.
The bipartisan consensus behind this proposal, however, was overshadowed today by the intense partisan skirmishing around whether to set a deadline. "I hear Democratic governors ready to put the heat on Congress, which is controlled by the Democrats," said Gov. Lawton Chiles of Florida, a Democrat who led the fight for the deadline. "I don't hear the other side ready to put the heat on the White House."
 
'It's All Over; We Won'
 But Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, a Republican, dismissed the effort as simple politics. "That's all right," he said, "It's all over; we won. We got a good policy that was bipartisan to begin with."
Republicans opposed the deadline as unnecessary, unlikely to move Congress and unlikely to produce a good program if it did. The policy statement, as passed, calls for the White House and Congress to begin working with governors immediately to achieve reform.
The skirmishing was yet another example of Democrats' seeking to ratchet up the pressure on Mr. Bush over domestic issues, an effort that seems all the more difficult when overshadowed by the crisis in the Soviet Union.
This four-day meeting, which ended today, was consumed with the health care issue. The governors also passed a resolution deploring an effort expected from the Federal Government to curtail a widespread fund-raising technique used by states to pay for the care of poor people under Medicaid.
Under the new rules expected from the Federal Government, Washington would no longer match state spending for Medicaid when the state share comes from funds donated by hospitals or by taxes imposed on hospitals, nursing homes or institutions for the mentally retarded. Governors here said such a ruling would be devastating.
"This proposed rule will not play well in Peoria," said Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois, a Republican.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Governors Bill Clinton of Arkansas, left, Warren Chiles of Florida, center, and Pete Wilson of California voting unsuccessfully to demand that the Federal government overhaul the health-care system by 1994. The vote took place at the National Governors Association meeting in Seattle. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: When Parents and Children Go to School Together

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
In two portable classrooms, hardly more than construction trailers with desks and blackboards, two generations of students venture into often perplexing streams of printed words.
Set on a grassy elementary school playground in Louisville, Ky., one classroom contains preschool-age children, while a neighboring one contains their mothers. Three days a week they come to the same school -- traveling in the same yellow buses, eating meals in the same cafeteria, pursuing the same certificate -- as part of an innovative program to break the cycle of illiteracy and poverty in America and establish a foundation for learning and critical thinking among families at risk. 
 Two years into its mission the National Center for Family Literacy, a private, nonprofit corporation based in Louisville, has become the progenitor of literacy programs that serve parents and children as students in the same classroom. It supports programs in 32 states.
And the Toyota Motor Corporation recently gave the center $2 million to expand its work. The money is financing 15 new literacy programs, scheduled to begin next month as demonstration projects in five cities: Atlanta, Rochester, Tucson, Ariz., Pittsburgh and Richmond.
 
Higher Literacy Skills
 "We are trying to get parents to raise their literacy skills so that they can, in fact, support education in the home," said Sharon Darling, the center's founder and president. "We want them to also have skills that will help them be employable and skills that will help them be better parents."
The children, most of them 3 or 4 years old, are taught what early-education teachers call preliteracy skills -- how to express themselves orally, for example, and how to get along with others.
In a nation in which an estimated 87 million people are marginally illiterate, one in five cannot read at all and succeeding generations slip further into the haze of the chronically undereducated, the center's adult-child approach has an obvious appeal.
"I am convinced that 'at-risk' families can change their lives if provided the opportunity to learn together in an environment that constantly demonstrates and reinforces positive values," Don Seaman, director of the Texas Center for Adult Literacy and Learning at Texas A&M University, said of the program.
The program is sometimes called the "Kenan model," after the William R. Kenan Jr. Charitable Trust of Chapel Hill, N.C., which helped establish the Louisville center.
 
Study Finds Gains
 A recent study by the literacy center has found that once in elementary school, children who participate in Kenan-style programs outperform children with similar needs who do not receive such help.
Only 10 percent of the program's participants are considered "at risk for school failure" by their elementary schoolteachers, Mr. Seaman said; at least 75 percent rank in the upper half of their classes, and more than a third are in the top quarter. Without the literacy program's intervention, he said, 50 percent would be at the bottom of their classes and 25 percent would probably be held back a year before fourth grade.
None of the children in 100 participating families in Indiana, Kentucky and West Virginia who were approached for the study had been kept back.
The study also examined how participating parents were affected. While the literacy program helps adults become more employable, the study focused on results not related to employment. Parents reported that the program helped them feel better about themselves and about participating in their children's school activities, including talking to teachers and administrators.
 
'I Read to My Child'
 One parent, Chloe Gentry, told researchers: "Now I read to my child almost every day. I sure didn't do that before."
All of the parents in the study were high school dropouts, yet half of them work as volunteers in their children's schools, the report said. Many parents said they now read newspapers, books and magazines for pleasure and visited the public library.
The typical adult participant is a 27-year-old woman who may be married and have two or three children. She is unemployed and has an annual income of less than $5,000; she dropped out of school in the 11th or 12th grade.
About 1 percent of participants are fathers, said Robert E. Spillman, vice president of the national center, and a small number are grandparents, aunts or uncles. In most cases, Mr. Spillman said, the fathers are either not available or are working and cannot attend the daytime classes.
Thousands of adults are participating in Kenan-model programs nationwide, Mr. Spillman said, including 1,300 in Kentucky alone. The center provides staff training and technical support for all the literacy programs. The center also helps finance programs involving research and development, such as the 15 model programs and a $100,000 center scheduled to open in Louisville in September, complete with a day-care program for children too young for existing programs.
The center, which will serve 30 families, will be operated by the Jefferson County public school system, which includes Louisville.
 
Joint Literacy Effort
 By contrast, the model programs are intended to demonstrate how various community agencies and organizations can create and sustain local literacy projects, Ms. Darling said. The three project sites in Richmond, for example, have brought together the public library, the Junior League, the United Way and the Virginia Family Literacy Task Force, among other groups.
Donald W. Ingwerson, the Superintendent of Schools in Jefferson County, said one reason for adopting a literacy program for parents and children was to reinforce the importance of education, but especially in adults.
"Many times parents have not had a good experience in our schools; consequently, when they are ready to send youngsters to us they are ambivalent," Mr. Ingwerson said. "They are not able to communicate good, positive feelings children need to have about school."
All that changed for Janie Smith, a 33-year-old mother of two who came to the program as a high school dropout wanting a better life for her children.
Last fall, Mrs. Smith enrolled in the program with her 3-year-old daughter, Charlie. By March, Mrs. Smith had earned her general equivalency certificate. By the summer, she and her daughter had received their literacy program certificates in a joint graduation ceremony.
 
Learning Is 'My Job'
 Eventually, she said, she came to think of the program as "my job." Now she is applying for jobs as either a teacher's assistant or a data entry clerk at a local bank.
Three days a week, from September through June, classrooms like those attended by Charlie and Mrs. Smith are alive with the commotion of learning.
Adult education teachers press the grownups to think critically while helping them master basic reading, writing and math skills. Parents are also taught practical skills like resume writing and job interviewing.
The children are taught preliteracy skills while being routinely treated to special guests: their mothers and sometimes their fathers.
Just before lunch, the parents come to their children's classroom for joint projects: some parents read aloud from books their children have selected, while others help their children write their own books, dutifully recording the tales the youngsters spin; still others just play.
 
Some Frank Discussions
 Later in the day, as the children take naps, parents perform volunteer duties in the school, working in the office or library or tutoring elementary school pupils. The last 45 minutes of the parents' more than five-hour day are devoted to parenting skills and an open -- and sometimes frank -- discussion about things like discipline and problems at home.
Karen Palmer, who is 30 and the mother of four, says she dropped out of high school because her mother gave her the impression that education was not important.
"If I said I was sick and just laid in the bed, my mother would knock on the door and ask me if I was going to school," Ms. Palmer recalled. "If I said no, she would never say anything. If she didn't care, I didn't care."
Her haphazard schooling, Ms. Palmer said, left her feeling "like something was missing."
She enrolled in the Kenan literacy program in part, she said, because she wanted to feel good about herself.She said she discovered instead that she must also make her children feel good about themselves -- that self-esteem is a cornerstone of educational achievement.
If, for example, her son, Reginald, acts up, "we choose a book to read, or lie down and watch TV," Ms. Palmer said. "I see now that I have to make him feel important."
Ms. Darling said she had heard similar testimonials from other students, and added: "You just can't teach a mother to read and expect that is going to make a difference in their lives. You can't pretend that it is an isolated literacy problem."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Janie Smith, a 33-year-old mother who was a high school dropout, receiving a literacy program certificate together with her daughter, Charlie, at a joint graduation ceremony last May in Louisville, Ky. (Keith Williams for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
People Like Us

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
I went to the Soviet Union in 1987 with a group of American women. A delegation from the Soviet Women's Committee waited to greet us at the airport, just beyond the security kiosks. A guard noticed what I had not: that the dates of birth on my passport and my visa were different. He looked from one to another and I, an American child raised on Godless Communism nightmares and Red Menace movies, wondered whether I was in deep trouble.
Suddenly one of the Soviet women, the one we would come to love for her sly cynicism about the system, stepped forward with her clutch of ceremonial red carnations and barked out several sentences. The guard looked at my flawed papers one last time and then slowly handed them back. I had officially arrived in Moscow. 
 I felt as if I'd landed on Mars.
I felt that way often as I stood in line for old cranberries and carrots one day and carrots and older cranberries the next, as I heard stories of exchanging vodka and cosmetics for clean sheets in the hospital, as I visited college professors in a crumbling barracks of an apartment building, their perishables chilling on the window sills as mine had in my dorm days.
The everyday tales of the women I met in Moscow stunned me: the ubiquitous only children because the authorities would never assign an apartment large enough for more; the hours of grocery shopping because the stores were poorly stocked and reliable refrigerators scarce; the repeat abortions because the supplies of decent contraceptives constantly ran out. A poet poured tea in her apartment, the walls lined with books. The bathroom ceiling was falling in. "The apparatus does not work," she said, with an air of meaning more.
They were hoping for something better then; "glasnost" and "perestroika" were just beginning to be catchwords, and letters critical of the Government had started to pop up in newspapers, which made people scent possibility. We visitors already had something better; once we got past the paucity of comforts, the acceptance of economic failure, we discovered that our hosts were people like us.
We talked of our children, of women's liberation, of whether the Soviet Union was ready for democracy and whether America was as democratic as it thought itself. We complained of husbands who watched sports events and left wives all the work. The Soviet Union still seemed like Mars, but after eating dinner in their combination living-dining (sometimes bed) rooms, its people no longer seemed like Martians.
Over the last three decades, a succession of square gray faceless nonocrats have come and gone in the Soviet Union, and we hardly noticed, in part because we believed they led square gray faceless people, whose most signal attribute was that they were essentially different from us.
But in the last few years, with glasnost, openness, Gorbachev, we learned something new, about essential similarities. We have seen the people of the Soviet Union hold beauty contests and fashion shows, jam into churches, listen to rock-and-roll bands, battle for independence, even go to the polls.
This week we watched Boris Yeltsin climb atop a tank to exhort an uprising, looking like a Chicago pol on the hustings. A wall of Muscovites linked arms, a human wall like the ones we have seen around the Washington Monument in other freedom fights. And the occasional comrade walked by and said it was about time they threw the guy out.
Never are the differences between the Soviet Union and the United States clearer to an American child than when she wakes to find that one of the world's great leaders has been called in permanently sick by his opponents, with the help of tanks. Contraceptives, vegetables, apartments, economic hope -- all are still in short supply. A McDonald's does not a revolution make.
But the Soviet Union changed, and so did we. Its citizens began to become people to us, with their struggles and their seemingly hopeless hopes, instead of ideology in a boxy topcoat, and that is one of many reasons we are riveted today by their continuing drama. History is happening at this moment there. Because of the Gorbachev years, for many of us it is history with humanity. That alone is no small change.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: New York State Errs on Vocational Education

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Oregon attempt to educate technically minded students should be looked at carefully by the New York State Board of Regents (front page, July 24). The Regents action plan has so far been a dismal failure when it comes to the needs of vocationally oriented students. There is a greater incentive to drop out of school now that a foreign-language requirement has replaced industrial arts as a New York State requirement. 
 My experience as a high school English teacher has been that students from modest-income families prefer technical studies for social and economic satisfaction. American students, unlike their European counterparts, cannot take a ferry or train to end up in another culture with a different language. The reality here is that the standards of a modern European culture are being applied to a civilization 3,000 miles away. Language teachers who themselves travel over summer vacations often encourage their students to do so.
The children of the successful go. The children of the struggling middle class usually stay home. Many students feel that since firsthand experience is impossible, the study of a language is fruitless.
Industrial arts programs have been gutted in New York State. True, students may travel to a designated school for vocational subjects, but are then no longer able to engage in extracurricular programs. They are singled out as students of lower expectations. There is little doubt that the foreign-language requirement has acquired a high degree of social status. Whatever flaws were contained in the old program, at least it meant that there was an inherent dignity to a technical education. Building engines in metal shop was not a lower form of education. A Regents diploma was possible.
The new emphasis on a foreign-language requirement has left a great number of students alienated. The one choice for genuine achievement and satisfaction is now denied to them. Oregon, I believe, is making the necessary adjustment to America's student needs. Its flexible system is insuring less student frustration and, it is hoped, far fewer dropouts.
 
DENIS T. THOMPSON
West Islip, L.I., Aug. 5, 1991

HEADLINE: What Banks Can Do That Nothing Else Can;
Think of Workers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Jay G. Baris may make some novel points in "Abolish Banks (Seriously)" (Op-Ed, Aug. 6), but he curiously overlooks one major problem. By abolishing the roughly 16,000 banks within the United States, including the American-based branches and offices of foreign banks, Mr. Baris will cheerfully send hundreds of thousands of people to the unemployment office, ranging from janitor to chief executive officer. 
 Furthermore, many companies that provide products and services specifically for banks will also begin to hand out pink slips, and the dozens of national and regional banking trade associations would also be forced to send their staffs to the want ads. And in a classic case of guilt by association, there could be layoffs in the media and the Postal Service because of the lost revenue from bank advertising and the voluminous bank mailings.
Of course, the money that's saved in deposit insurance can be used to pay the unemployment insurance benefits of these newly out-of-work individuals, but that's like trading in a bout with malaria for a bout with dysentery.
 
PHIL HALL
Bronx, Aug. 6, 1991
 
The writer is the former editor of Financial Technology News, a banking trade newspaper.

HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Voices of U.S. Scholars: 'These Forces Go Way Back in Russian History';
Scholars See a 'Putsch,' a Gang of Rivals, and Analyze the Plotters' Chances

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:

Stephen F. Cohen
Professor of politics and director of the Russian studies program at Princeton University
For almost seven years, Gorba chev led a reformation which sought to reverse the Russian des potic tradition which existed long before the revolution. He sought to do this through political and eco nomic democratization and open ing the country to the West. 
 At the same time there have al ways been powerful forces that have opposed this for political, cul tural and economic reasons. These forces are not just Communist -- they go way back in Russian history. This has been an epic struggle. While this coup d'etat is a shock, it is not a surprise.
These people and the institutions they represent -- the military-industrial complex, the K.G.B., the party apparatus, the Ministry of the Interior and the state collective farm structure -- were the primary targets of Gorbachev's reforms.
In terms of our own foreign policy before this, I am of the view that we should have done much, much more for the Soviet Union and much more quickly.
But I don't know if that would have helped, if that would have stopped this. Let's say we'd committed $10 billion a year last summer. At least when these people were going to do this, they would have had to calculate, "It'll cost us $50 billion."
 
Gail Lapidus
Professor of political science at the University of California at Berkeley
The key issues are the extent to which Yeltsin and the reformers are able to mobilize large masses of the population in defense of reform and democratization, then to what extent can they exploit the cleavages within the military and security apparatus.
The longer they wait, the greater the size of the crowd, the higher the stakes and the higher price they have to pay if they open fire. One serious option for them is trying to work away at the opposition slowly, to have creeping totalitarianism: shut down the media, isolate cities from one another, and then pick up an opposition leader here or there.
This conservative coalition is united on what it is against. It is opposed to reform, democratization, the opening to the West and the significant devolution of power to the republics and the secession of some. It does not have a coherent program of its own. Significant cleavages will come to the forefront as soon as it has to formulate its own political and economic agenda.
Some elements of the situation resemble events in Eastern Europe in 1989. But a much larger circle of people have a stake in preserving the existing system than in Eastern Europe.
 
Roald Z. Sagdeyev
Professor of physics at the University of Maryland at College Park, former director of the Soviet space program and a recent adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev
There are two things to watch. One is the potential political resist ance. We are already witnessing how the demonstrations are build ing up momentum. The second issue is whether the government will be successful economically.
I think it is absolutely excluded that they could change the eco nomic situation to the better. The very composition of the people in this committee makes it clear. Starodubtsev is an ardent enemy of private farming and Tizyakov launched the movement against privatization of state-run enterprises.
They try to avoid mentioning the analogy with Poland, but for the past year some of the top party leaders were talking about the model of Pinochet in Chile, to create order via military administration and allow development of an economy in an unpoliticized way. But the economy is in a shambles and you know you cannot put people back to work on the old premises.
My friends point out that in their rhetoric, the new people are not using Communist jargon. They are trying to paint themselves as apolitical, on the side of order and legality and against chaos and civil war. They're looking for the support of the working class and the privileged groups inside the military industrial complex.
 
Alexander Dallin
Professor of history and political science at Stanford University
It's curious that there's been no mention of Communism so far. I think it's probable there's some difference of opinion on that. Some think it's so unpopular that they can't use it. For some others it's still a rallying cry.
The thing that unites the new leadership is the effort to stop the reforms. What divides them is, first of all, different institutional loyalties.
The army is largely made up of enlisted men from different nationalities. They are much closer to the rank and file of the population and would be much more hesitant to engage the civilian population. I think there was some feeling in the army that it should not be used internally in the country. That's obviously not true of the Interior Ministry. The K.G.B. is less subject to that kind of pressure, though there are fissures there, too.
There are also rival personalities. There's no reason to think these eight people like each other.
 
Zbigniew Brzezinski
National security adviser to President Carter
This is a struggle between the future and the past, not two differ ent views of the future. In the long run, the coup will most certainly fail. There is no way of putting the old system back together with a military putsch. The Soviet Union is an anachronism and Commu nism is disgraced. The putschists represent a bankrupt past, in many respects a criminal past.
In the short run, this is a close call. I lean to the proposition that it won't work. In the next weeks and months it will become clear that this gang has no conception of what needs to be done. Social opposition will become more intense.
It's extremely important that the West give unambiguous, energetic political and moral support to the forces struggling for democracy. We ought to do what we can within reason to help the men in the trenches -- Yeltsin in Russia, Landsbergis in Lithuania, Gamasakhurdia in Georgia.
We could find the Soviet Union becoming less cooperative in the Middle East, stalling with the implementation of arms control agreements. They need not repudiate them. There could be the rapprochement of the international outlaws, like the butchers of Tiananmen Square. That is why we can't afford, from the standpoint of the immediate future and longer-range history, to take a stance that is passive.
 
Condoleezza Rice
Associate professor of political science at Stanford and former chief Soviet specialist on President Bush's National Security Council
The reason this caught me and other people by surprise -- there have been calls for things like this quite a bit. People here were inured to it. There was no reason to believe things were any differ ent, until now.
Success for the plotters would be if they were able, without mas sive bloodshed, to silence the democratic forces, to really go after the breakaway republics. It's possible that the leaders will huff and puff but when people go into the streets they turn the turrets of the tanks the other way. When Gorbachev was President, he didn't have the stomach for major bloodshed. But it's anybody's bet whether Pugo and Kryuchkov and Yazov do.
There's a lot of calling this a military coup. The military's involved. But this is a right-wing putsch. This is all the right wing. That makes it more dangerous. The K.G.B. has its troops, the Interior Ministry has its troops.
There are two possible futures. One is the coup fails, because they don't have the stomach to go through with it or it fails because people resist and that could be bloody. The other scenario is dark: that these people win and succeed through brute force to put people in their place.
 
Henry Trofimenko
Visiting scholar at the University of Maryland and former head of the foreign policy department of the Institute of the United States and Canada in Moscow
The people who were making the coup, they bank on the total dissatisfaction of the people with the economic situation in the country. A lot of people are clamoring for some sort of stability. If it's promised from different quarters they might be willing to go along for a while. These people can deliver some goods for a short period. But the crunch will come very shortly.
In the long run, without big structural economic reforms in the Soviet Union, the system is doomed and you cannot restore it by reverting to the old setup. It is not that the money from the West will or will not be forthcoming. That's irrelevant. The people who made the coup did it to refurbish the Communist system. They are trying to do what Gorbachev failed to do in 1985 and 1986.
Somebody also should have warned Gorbachev that the gimmick of national salvation committees that was tried by him in the Baltics could be later used against him. Also, by deliberately emasculating the power of the Supreme Soviet not long ago, Gorbachev foreclosed the option of an appeal to the Supreme Soviet, or the option of using the Supreme Soviet to override the coup.
 
Jeane J. Kirkpatrick
Senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and former United States representative at the United Nations
I think it has already succeeded in the short run. It has succeeded in disrupting and presumably deposing the Government and tak ing control of the streets in the capital city.
But it's wholly impossible to predict the long-run consequences. It's not probable that the same group that undertook this effort will remain together in power for very long. It's an ad hoc group cooperating for this particular end.
We don't know enough yet about the character of this new group but they are bad news for U.S.-Soviet relations, bad news for Soviet-world relations, bad news for arms control, bad news for global and regional cooperative arrangements. We don't know if this is the kind of group with whom we could be partners in anything.
We know that there have been plenty in the Soviet military concerned about the fate of unsavory allies in the Middle East and elsewhere. The same groups who conducted this coup are concerned about maintaining Saddam's strength and Fidel Casto's arms flow and Assad's high-performance aircraft. It was Gorbachev slowing down the sale of arms to unsavory dictators around the world. Gorbachev's opponents are now in power.

The Struggle for Leadership
 Resolve Stiffens on Both Sides: The coup leaders met rising opposition with a curfew and armored movements in Moscow that provoked clashes. Three civilians were killed near the parliament of the Russian republic, where the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, was holding out. Throngs of his supporters shielded the building from troops. Page A1. 
 Mutinies in the Military: Some entire units and individual servicemen defected to defend anti-coup forces. Page A1.
 
Bush Takes a Risk
 A Snub from the U.S.: The President rejected normal relations with the coup leaders, and phoned Mr. Yeltsin offering his support. Page A1.

 Outraged in Europe: The European Community suspended all but humanitarian aid. Page A11.
 Adrift in the U.S.: Several Soviet citizens on a good-will boat tour in the Pacific Northwest defected; others aboard pondered their future. Page A19.

HEADLINE: Newport After the Storm: Peevish but Still Standing

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20

 BODY:
Like a dowager who has taken a fall into the pool, this stately resort town calmly but somewhat peevishly began to wring itself out today from the hurricane that crashed through on Monday.
 Newport was the first significant city to be hit by the storm as it moved ashore, and it greeted Hurricane Bob with a kind of sturdy disapproval befitting a city that was once a summer home to the Vanderbilts and the Astors, boarding up its windows and firmly securing its yachts. 
The city seems to have been spared real tragedy; few serious injuries were reported and fewer houses were damaged more than superficially. But the hurricane, which hit at the height of the summer season, did not spare this city's elite as it raged up the coast.
 The hurricane damaged some of Newport's most fashionable beach clubs, deposited a few 45-foot yachts on the shore and felled trees across the lawns of the city's great mansions. And it left much of the city, rich and poor alike, without electricity.
 
Assessing the Damage
 Today, under steel-gray skies and an occasional squall, Newport stepped out to assess the damage, some of it physical and much of it psychological.
 Paul Pedro, who came to the Newport Yacht Club this morning to check on his 31-foot sailboat, Irie, found that he had become one of the thousands of Rhode Islanders to be inconvenienced by the storm. His boat had rubbed up against another one during the hurricane and was looking somewhat the worse for the experience.
 "Believe it or not," he said, pointing to the boat's name on the stern, "that's Jamaican for 'no problem.' "
 For visitors drawn to Newport for its beaches and waterfront estates, there was much to be disappointed about today. The estates, usually open to the public, were closed while crews worked to cart away the storm's debris. The beaches, some of them also open to the public, simply were no longer there.
 
A Shattered Holiday
 Clive and Anne Spicer, tourists from Wallheath, England, stared disconsolately into their sodas this afternoon as they considered what was left of their American holiday. They had hoped to go to Cape Cod but, because of the storm, had washed up on Newport instead. Now, with half the roads in town closed and the beaches washed away, there was not much for a tourist to do.
 "We had planned to take a nice seaside break," Mr. Spicer said. "Wham, that's gone."
 This afternoon it seemed that much of Easton's Beach, one of the city's largest public beaches, had migrated onto the nearby highway and then across the divider. The dunes were torn up, the blue and white cabanas shredded.
 The more exclusive Bailey's Beach was similarly damaged, its cabanas left in tatters and their contents cast out to sea. Among those who came to sift through the fashionable wreckage check at Bailey's, according to the local newspaper, The Newport Daily News, were Annie-Laurie and Alexander von Auersperg, the children of Martha von Bulow.
 
Power Failure Persists
 With the beach clubs torn up and the National Guard called in to direct traffic, many store owners said they feared that the wealthy who summer in Newport would leave, taking their wallets with them.
 "The economy has not been good, and this does not help," said Cathy Loughlin, who was trying to sell an expensive array of model ships and leather luggage.
 To many Newport residents the most annoying legacy of the hurricane was the persistent power failure. Electricity in the city was still spotty today, and many stores and restaurants remained closed. Residents were warned that it might take several days before all the power was restored, and radio talk shows were flooded with calls blaming everything from unions to corporate greed for the continuing problem.
 "I haven't seen any utility trucks out here," said Ron Lurgio, who was clearing fallen branches from his yard. "We'd like to take showers again. We'd like to be able to flush the john."
 
1938 Hurricane Recalled
 Despite the complaints, though, many people were ready to declare that the storm, while a pain, was really rather tame compared with some of its predecessors.
 Newport, which sits on an island that juts out into the Atlantic, has been hit by several memorable storms this century, including Hurricane Carol in 1954 and an unnamed hurricane in 1938 that killed more than 250 Rhode Islanders.
 Madelyne Gillespie, who was working at Woolworth's in Providence when the 1938 hurricane struck, recalled that the flood waters reached up to the second floor in that storm. The memory of Hurricane Bob, she said, would probably soon fade.
 "This one," she added, "wasn't really very bad, was it?"
