HEADLINE: THE SOVIET CRISIS;
Excerpts From Bush's Talk: 'You Don't Set Back Democracy Very Easily'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference this morning:
 
BUSH'S STATEMENT
Well, events in the Soviet Union continue to deeply concern the whole world. The unconstitutional seizure of power is an affront to the goals and aspirations that the Soviet peoples have been nurturing over the past years. This action also puts the Soviet Union at odds with the world community and undermines the positive steps that had been undertaken to make the Soviet Union an integral and positive force in world affairs. 
 I have this morning spoken with Boris Yeltsin, the freely elected leader of the Russian republic, and I assured Mr. Yeltsin of continued U.S. support for his goal of the restoration of Mr. Gorbachev as the constitutionally chosen leader. And I also shared with him the support that other world leaders voiced in my several conversations yesterday, conversations I had with those leaders in Eastern Europe and leaders in Western Europe as well, and Prime Minister Kaifu. And I gave him that reassurance.
 Mr. Yeltsin is encouraged by the support of the Soviet people and their determination in the face of these trying circumstances. He expressed our gratitude -- his gratitude for our support of him and President Gorbachev. The situation concerning President Gorbachev's status is still unclear, and I have twice tried to reach him by phone, including within the last hour, but have so far been unsuccessful.
 We continue to closely monitor this situation. Our new, and I might add very able Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Robert Strauss, just sworn in, will be departing immediately for Moscow to take charge of our embassy and to report to me on the situation that he finds in the Soviet Union.
 So I'm asking him to go over there, get the lay of the land, establish what will be strong leadership at the embassy -- we've got a good team in place, but this man is in charge of this important mission -- and then to return within the next several days to give me a full personal report on what he sees there. He will not be presenting his credentials on this trip. It's going to be a short trip. And I have said that this group assumed power extraconstitutionally.
 
Kennebunkport Work Schedule
 In conclusion, I want to emphasize that we are going to monitor the situation closely and consider its ramifications throughout the entire world. And I've emphasized in my conversation with the Eastern European leaders that the democratic processes in their country cannot be reversed. Eastern Europe is important. And I've called three of the leaders.
 And I want to take this opportunity to assure them of our continued interest and the need to retain calm in those countries. And, indeed, they were very grateful for the contact by the United States. The United States will continue to support the economic and political reforms in their countries. And I will continue to seek the advice and counsel of Eastern European leaders in the days ahead. And, of course, the Secretary and I will be in close touch with the Western European leaders and others around the globe.
 Because this is an ongoing process of consultations, we intend to maintain a more formal work schedule during the remainder of my stay in Maine. There will be a number of meetings with government officials and private-sector experts related to the events in the Soviet Union. There will be daily briefings on a formalized basis by my national security advisers, and I will be keeping in touch with Secretary Baker. As you know, I'll be receiving Prime Minister Mulroney and also Prime Minister Major and, of course, receiving Ambassador Strauss when he returns. Secretary Baker will be leaving today for the NATO ministerial that's being held -- will be held in Brussels.
 These difficult events in the Soviet Union, I believe, demonstrate the wisdom of our strong and continuous support for the process of reform and restructuring. We'll continue to support the democratic processes that have been set in motion in the Soviet Union. And most importantly, I know that the American people stand behind the people of the Soviet Union who are seeking more freedom and more opportunity in their society.
 So, I'd like now to turn this podium over to Ambassador Strauss for a comment, and then Secretary Baker and I will be glad to take questions, or the Ambassador, and I have here, of course, our top national security team, and I -- Secretary Cheney and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs is here, the Vice President, and if you want to direct questions to any of them, why, that would be fine, too. We're following the situations on all fronts there, economic, military, whatever it is, very, very closely.
 
STRAUSS'S STATEMENT
 Thank you, Mr. President. Let me just very briefly say that the circumstances have changed rather dramatically since I accepted this assignment. It's a different world. Nevertheless, although the circumstances have changed, as I've said, it seems to me that my mission remains basically the same, and that is to go to Moscow, speak very clearly, speak very plainly and, if necessary, with undiplomatic candor from time to time, to speak for you, Mr. President, you, Mr. Secretary, and for the American people, and to speak for the principles of freedom and democracy and rule of law, and that, I intend to do. I thank you for this -- express my appreciation to you for the confidence you've shown in me, and I'll do my best to fulfill the job.
Thank you, sir.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Has there been any evidence -- do you have any evidence that the -- that this coup might be on shaky ground, in line with what you mentioned yesterday about sometimes coups fail and that possibly the opposition that's rallying around Yeltsin has any possibilities to turn it around and what kind of support are you able -- or will you give them other than verbal?
 A. Well, I am -- I said yesterday that some coups fail. The likelihood of this, it's hard to evaluate, in this circumstance. However, there appears to be very strong support from the people in the Soviet Union for constitutional government, for democratic reform. And when you see the numbers turn out, President Yeltsin told me that he anticipated there were -- he thought there were 100,000 people near his building when I talked to him a few minutes ago. He thinks that there will be strong support from labor to his request that labor go out and do not -- don't produce until this matter is resolved.
 So, you don't take freedom away from people very easily, you don't set back democracy very easily, and I'd say that it is in the best interests of the Soviet Union and its relations with other countries if a constitutional government is promptly put back into operation there.
 
U.S. Aid to Yeltsin
 Q. Mr. President, what kind of support, though, are you going to give Yeltsin, or you just have to stay on the sidelines and offer verbal encouragement?
 A. Well, we're certainly going to offer encouragement in every way we can. And we're making very clear to the coup plotters and the coup people that there will not be normal relations with the United States as long as this illegal coup remains in effect. The Eastern -- the Western Europeans have met and they have come out with a statement along those lines. And I think, with the exception ofa few renegade regimes around the world, we're seeing universal condemnation. So, let's hope that that will bring these people to their senses.
 I was just looking here at the statement from the -- the E.C. decisions. And they have concluded that this C.S.C.E. human-rights conference in Moscow should not go forward, and we will certainly back them in that. Technical assistance, they're following what I mentioned yesterday in holding back all of that. And they have some serious economic problems, and they need the help of the West and they need the cooperation of Eastern Europe. And they're not going to get it under existing conditions.
 
Mideast Talks
 Q. What happens now to the co-sponsorship of the Middle East conference? Will we do it alone? And other front-burner issues with the Soviet Union? And what was the gist of the letter from Yanayev?
 A. It's far too early to say what will happen to the Middle East conference. The whole world wants to see that succeed. The hopes for peace in the Middle East -- and again I credit Secretary Baker for his indefatigable efforts in putting together this peace process. The whole world wants to see it succeed. And I hope that there will be no frustration of that on the part of the Soviet Union, who have heretofore played a very constructive role in all of that. But, again, we are not in contact with Foreign Minister Bessmertnykh. We simply don't know what is going to happen. What was the other part of your question?
 Q. Will we go it alone?
 A. Well, I mean, we will continue to fight for -- we will continue to use our best efforts to bring peace to the Middle East no matter what happens. Of course, we will. But let's face it, the Soviet Union heretofore has been constructive, and they're important in the United Nations concept and they're important on their own with the relations they have with some other countries.
 It is ironic that only a handful of countries, predictably extreme countries, have supported what's happening in Moscow. I think of Libya, I think of Iraq, and I think of Cuba. These are renegades. These are people that have been swimming against the tide of democracy. And the rest of the world appears to be very upset with this usurpation of power.
 
German Aid to Kremlin
 Q. Mr. President, in the past you've had differences with Chancellor Kohl over monetary aid to the Soviet Union. In your telephone conversation with him yesterday, did you say it was imperative that they not give any money to the new regime?
 A. No. We worked out, at the G-7 meeting, an agreement with Chancellor Kohl that he fully supported. Germany has some special problems. Germany wants those troops, Russian troops out of a unified Germany. We want the troops out of a unified Germany. But that was not discussed.
 
Talks With Europe
 Q. Aside from Secretary Baker's trip to Brussels, is it -- is this situation such that you might want to see the European leaders meet together in a summit?
 A. Well, I'm not sure that that's -- that's the next step. We're in close contact with them. I talked to the G-7 leaders yesterday, including Ruud Lubbers, the Prime Minister of the Netherlands who is head of the E.C. now. And I'm not sure that a face-to-face meeting of the -- of the European leaders is -- and United States and Japan would be productive at this point. But I think the process of Jim Baker going to NATO, his doing that, is a very important step.
 
Relations in Limbo
 Q. Mr. President, when you say that our economic relations with the Soviet Union are now on hold, does that mean you're actively going after suspending grain credits for example, or delaying Most Favored Nation status?
 A. Well, we're just sitting here for awhile leaving everything on hold, as I have said. We're reviewing all these matters, and it's way too early to say what -- how each individual category is going to work out. It's simply we -- we've got to just take our time. We've got to be prudent -- a word I think is applicable here. And I think we've got to be strong. I think the world is turning to the United States for leadership here -- many countries. And I think the best thing to do now is to put these matters on hold. We did this yesterday. As you've seen, the Europeans, Western Europeans have followed suit.
 
Gorbachev's Fate
 Q. Mr. President, have you heard from Mr. Yeltsin as of the whereabouts or the well-being of Mr. Gorbachev, or from anyone else, for that matter?
 A. Mr. Yeltsin told me that he tried to send emissaries to see Mr. Gorbachev, that those emissaries were unsuccessful because Mr. Gorbachev is being prevented from seeing people. As I say, I've tried to call him, yesterday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Listening to President Bush yesterday were, from left, Ed Hewett, special assistant for European and Soviet affairs; Robert M. Gates, deputy director of the National Security Council; Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser; Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Downtown Retailing;
Cincinnati Puts a Mall In a Tower

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KENT
<, Special to The New York Times
DTL>CINCINNATI, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Tower Place at Carew Tower, a shopping center in the heart of this city, opens Wednesday as the $100 million bait that city leaders hope will lure shoppers downtown again.
The 250,000-square-foot center eoncompasses the renovated Art Deco arcade of the 61-year-old Carew Tower, Cincinnati's tallest building, and the adjacent atrium-style Tower Place, which was completed this month on the site of the former L. S. Ayres department store. 
 The downtown area has seen a net loss of 640,000 square feet of retail space in the last decade. At the same time, two shopping malls, each with more than a million square feet, have opened in the suburbs.
A third suburban mall underwent an $85 million renovation and also has more than a million square feet of space.
The $15 million Tower Place was developed by Faison Associates of North Carolina, while the Carew Tower arcade and Omni Netherland Hotel were renovated by the Belvedere Corporation of Cincinnati.
Belvedere became the tower's lead investor early last year when Emery Realty defaulted on a $50 million loan.
The project, which includes Ray Combs's Comedy Club, a fitness center and Morton's of Chicago steak house, is more than 90 percent leased, albeit without the prominent names that developers had initially sought. About 145,000 square feet are leasable in the 250,000-square-foot center.
The 1.7 million people who live in the Cincinnati area could find outlets of many of Tower Place's 65 stores and restaurants -- the Limited, the Gap, Footlocker, Chick-Fil-A -- at suburban shopping centers where the parking is free. At Tower Place, parking costs $1.50 an hour up to a maximum of $8 for 24 hours.
But Belvedere's president, Steven Stein, said the tenant mix was demographically correct.
"Perhaps some people will ask why we didn't go out and spend a million dollars to bring Gucci to the Carew Tower," he remarked. "The reason we didn't is that I don't think that's our customer base."
Also among the shops are the area's first Banana Republic and the third American shop of Goodebodies, a British retailer of bath products made from natural ingredients.
Mr. Stein acknowledged when Belvedere started the Carew Tower renovation that visions of Gucci, Fendi and Louis Vuitton danced in his head. But with today's retail environment battering many high-fashion retailers, he said he was glad they were only visions.
"We've got stores that are right for the 90's," he said.
He pointed out that designer apparel was readily available downtown at Saks Fifth Avenue and Gidding-Jenny, a stylish boutique, that just reopened under a new owner after a six-month, $2 million renovation. Saks is in the midst of a million-dollar renovation. The city's 18-block skywalk system connects Saks, Gidding-Jenny and McAlpin's department store to Tower Place.
Even if suburban shoppers do not flock downtown to buy lingerie at Victoria's Secret or books at Brentano's, there is a base of 82,000 downtown workers and 65 percent of them are women, Mr. Stein said.
Tower Place at Carew Tower brings a retail focal point to downtown, retail experts say. Though plenty of shopping has always been available, there is a perception that it is difficult to park and move from store to store downtown.
"It was until only three years ago that the largest concentration of retail was downtown," Mr. Stein said. "Ayres's closing caused the hub of the hub-and-spokes system to go dark."
City leaders' next priority is to move Lazarus, a locally based department store, several blocks away, to a site across the street from the Carew Tower known as Fountain Square West, said Mark McKillip, the downtown economic development officer.
Although the opening of Tower Place came a year and a half past schedule, its development was speedy compared with Fountain Square West, which has been idle since a department store, Elder-Beerman, pulled out in 1985.
Demolition of the store is almost complete, but the potential developer of a new mixed-use project at the site was deterred by financing difficulties, and the city now plans to turn the prime parcel into a parking lot until the economic picture changes.
City leaders, who have already invested $10 million in the Fourth Street retail district, do not want to lose momentum.
Mr. McKillip said that after Lazarus is moved, the city would seek out another department store of 60,000 to 100,000 square feet for its old Parkade Garage site two blocks north of Tower Place.

HEADLINE: Couples Who Tread 225-Mile Tightrope

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
WHEN Sally Shelton-Colby was a weekend commuter aboard the New York-Washington shuttle, she was not surprised by the sight of another passenger boarding a jet one Monday morning at National Airport carrying a vacuum cleaner instead of a briefcase.
Like Ms. Shelton-Colby, a former United States Ambassador to Barbados, the man was a member of a hardy band that struggles to maintain weekend marriages in one of the two cities and weekday jobs in the other. The vacuum cleaner, she concluded, was being transferred for duty in the man's New York apartment from his home in the capital. 
 "On some Mondays, I was schlepping orange juice and milk aboard the shuttle because I had none in my New York apartment," said Ms. Shelton-Colby, 47, whose husband, William Colby, the former director of the Central Intelligence, is a lawyer in Washington. "It was a crazy life style."
Couples who juggle homes and jobs in different cities can be found across the nation, but the Washington-New York connection appears to be a particularly strong one, and the commuting couples often come from the higher echelons of government and corporations. For them, it is a way of life, not just a hasty arrangement forced by a job transfer.
Marriages that span the two cities seem to be particularly common for a number of reasons, including these:
* The distance between the two cities -- 225 miles -- is covered, weather and air-traffic controllers permitting, in a one-hour shuttle flight (departing half-hourly from both cities most of the day) or a train ride of two and a half to three hours (hourly most of the day). By car, it is 5 to 6 hours.
* Professional men and women in New York and Washington who are employed in government service, law, communications, finance, publishing and the arts often meet through work and marry but wish to maintain careers in separate cities.
* Those who build a reputation in the Federal Government often go on to higher-paying corporate jobs in New York but are reluctant to uproot their families. And well-placed New Yorkers represent a talent pool for Government.
* Salaries in New York, often in the six figures, or prestigious appointments in Washington, can make the commute worthwhile as well as allow couples to cover commuting expenses, about $10,000 a year, and the costs of two households.
But for many of those who do the commute, the toughest part is the stress of frequent travel delays, airport shutdowns, weekend fatigue meltdowns and loneliness.
"It's the pits," said Ms. Shelton-Colby, who gave up an international banking position in New York after two years of commuting to teach at Georgetown University and work as a consultant. "Those of us who did it grew to hate the shuttle. The stress factor was horrendous. I think my gray hairs were caused less by working on the Latin American debt than by trying to find a taxi in midtown Manhattan for a Friday afternoon dash through traffic to the airport."
The shuttles operated by Trump and Pan Am fly between La Guardia Airport in New York and National Airport, two of the smallest yet busiest airports in the nation, and are subject to frequent weather and traffic delays. The shuttle flights cost $142 each way. One-way Amtrak Metroliner coach fare is $79.
Some professional couples do quite well despite the rigors of long-distance commuting, said Margaret Hall, a sociology professor at Georgetown who is writing a book on modern pressures on families. "When separated during the week they can better concentrate on their work and by the weekend let go of it and enjoy their time together," she said.
But, she added, when there are young children at home the major burden of the arrangement shifts from the spouse who is commuting to the one who stays with them and also works, usually the wife.
Charles Meissner, 50, a Chemical Bank vice president in New York and former ambassador at large for economic negotiations in the Carter and Reagan Administrations, has been a Washington-New York commuter since 1982. His wife, Doris, a former acting United States Commissioner of Immigration, is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington.
"I won't minimize the difficulties this arrangement poses to holding a relationship together," Mrs. Meissner said. "At least we live, unlike some couples we know, in the same time zone."
The Meissners had two school-age children in the early years of his commuting to New York, and they agree that children represent the biggest challenge. "We didn't understand in the beginning what a jarring change it meant," she said.
Like others doing the two-city dance, the Meissners set rules, including these, to lessen the burdens:
* Financial and household decisions made by one spouse are not challenged.
* The commuting spouse needs attractive accommodations in the city of employment, fully equipped to eliminate carting goods and clothing back and forth.
* Nightly telephone calls are necessary to maintain an emotional life and morale.
* Weekends are spent doing things that the whole family can enjoy.
* The commuter gets himself home.
Pedro Kuczynski, chairman of First Boston International and former Minister of Energy and Mines in Peru, his native land, and his wife have broken that last rule in the nine years he has been commuting to his New York office from Washington.
"My friends think Pedro is a Latin American male chauvinist because I always pick him up at the airport," said Jane Kuczynski, a Voice of America broadcaster. "But he actually pays me money for doing it. On my last birthday he gave me a phone for my car because I had so much trouble finding him at National Airport."
When she flies to New York it is usually for social functions connected with her husband's business. "The New York women simply can't understand why I prefer living in Washington," she said. "They imply you're not strong enough or competitive enough to live in New York. They haven't seen my swimming pool and sauna."
William Dunlap is an artist in McLean, Va., across the Potomac from Washington. His wife, Linda Burgess, is a New York painter and writer. They live apart by choice because he likes to paint in the Shenandoah Valley and she prefers the couple's SoHo loft to write.
When Mr. Dunlap, 47, thirsts for the art scene he hops up to Manhattan. When she hungers for fresh air she slips down to Washington.
David C. Levy, 52, executive director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington since January, prefers to spend summer weekends on Fire Island with his fiancee, Carole Feld. The rest of the year Ms. Feld, 35, who is director of promotions for Home Box Office and has an apartment in New York, goes to Washington on weekends. She said the couple planned to maintain the two-city arrangement after their marriage.
"I spend a lot of time on the road," she said, "so I seize opportunities to fly into Washington to see David for a night any time I can. If he still lived in New York I don't think we would get to see each other more than we do now."
Ed Rollins, 48, the Republican political strategist who managed President Reagan's 1984 campaign, is married to Sherrie Rollins, 33, director of information for ABC News in New York. She has commuted from the couple's Arlington, Va., home for 13 months.
"It's a modern marriage, with a young bright woman who has to travel to do her job while I stay home and look after her dogs," said Mr. Rollins, now a managing partner in a Washington consulting firm. "It's something that women have had to put up with over the years."
When major news stories break, Mrs. Rollins may not get to Washington at all. During the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Rollins commuted to New York on weekends to be with his wife in their one-bedroom Upper West Side apartment.
"There's something healthy about missing your husband each week and then getting to spend a weekend together," Mrs. Rollins said.
"Don't believe her," her husband said. "It's her dogs she misses."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ed Rollins and dogs waiting at Washington National Airport for his wife, Sherrie. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times) (pg. C10)

HEADLINE: Mubarak Urges the Lifting of Sanctions Against Iraq

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 21

 BODY:
President Hosni Mubarak, chief among Arab leaders aligned against Saddam Hussein in the Persian Gulf crisis, said in remarks pulbished today that he wants economic sanctions against Iraq lifted for the good of the Iraqi people.
The interview with the state-owned magazine Al Mussawar reflected a turnabout in Mr. Mubarak's support for sanctions imposed by the United Nations Security Council after Iraq invaded Kuwait a year ago. But he said the move should come only after world leaders devise checks on Mr. Hussein's ambitions. 
 "We strongly sympathize with the Iraqi people in their present ordeal resulting from the miscalculations of their leadership," he said. "We are for the lifting of these sanctions."
"It would not be difficult for the world community to agree on adequate guarantees that would prevent the squandering of Iraq's resources on projects which serve only the ambitions of its leader," he said.
His comments were published a day after Nabil Najim, Iraq's delegate to the Arab League, told reporters in Cairo that he had asked the Secretary General of the 21-member organization to try to persude the United Nations to ease the sanctions.
League officials initially saw little prospect that any effort by Secretary General Esmat Abdel-Meguid, a former Egyptian Foreign Minister, would succeed. But Mr. Mubarak's comment could improve Iraq's chances.
Sanctions were maintained even after a American-led international military coalition drove Iraqi forces from Kuwait in February. Iraqi officials say shortages caused by sanctions have killed thousands of Iraqi civilians since the war ended.
The United Nations voted on Thursday temporarily to lift the sanctions by allowing Iraq to sell $1.6 billion in oil to raise money for food and medicine for Iraqi citizens.
Mr. Mubarak said his concern for the welfare of the Iraqi people also was behind his opposition to suggestions that the United States and other Western allies mount air strikes to destroy Iraq's nuclear installations.
He said he had conveyed this position to President Bush through Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on the Secretary's visit to Egypt last month.
Mr. Mubarak also said all Egyptian troops in Kuwait would be back home by the end of this month. About 36,000 Egyptian soldiers joined the battle to rid Kuwait of Iraqi occupation.
Egypt began withdrawing them in May after Kuwait appeared to have second thoughts about a Persian Gulf security agreement that would have kept them there with Syrian troops as the core of a security force.

U.N. Team Ends Iraq Visit
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- A team of United Nations experts wrapped up an inspection tour of Iraqi chemical weapon sites today, saying Iraq had cooperated fully and was working out ways to destroy its bombs and warheads.
The leader of the inspection team, Jean-Paul Peroz of France, attributed Iraqi helpfulness to an urgent need for permission to resume production of chemicals such as chlorine, which is used for water purification as well as weapons-making.
"They gave us many plans, much information, and they have very good cooperation with the inspection team," he told reporters.
The Security Council has linked a full lifting of trade sanctions to Iraqi compliance with its cease-fire terms, which include declaring and scrapping all weapons of mass destruction.
Mr. Peroz said his 21-member team, which leaves Thursday, had seen 6,420 small rockets with chemical warheads and 200 mustard gas bombs during their six-day visit.
He said they had found no inconsistencies between Iraq's declarations and what they had seen.
He said Iraq had asked for permission to turn chemical weapons production plants into arms destruction plants.
Mr. Peroz, whose inspections included production and storage sites, said Iraq was eager to put the issue of its chemical weapons program behind it because it urgently needed to reopen chemical plants for civilian needs.

HEADLINE: Is a Fifth Avenue Rose Wilting?

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Like a haughty Park Avenue matron whose credit has been challenged at the local supermarket, Saks Fifth Avenue is defending its blue-blooded reputation these days amid rumors of big losses and late payments to suppliers.
Saks denies it has any financial troubles, and industry analysts note that it has been one of the most profitable companies in the business. Competitors have long envied Saks's knack for finding and selling some of the most innovative, and priciest, lines of high-fashion merchandise. 
 But even Saks acknowledges that it has to seek new ways to stay profitable. Among other changes, its 48 stores are stocking more lines of less expensively priced clothing, like women's blazers for $400 to $600, compared with $1,000 or more for designer labels. It is also dropping some slow-selling high-priced lines and adding more of its own private brands and larger-sized clothing.
While these moves seem to be edging the store ever so slightly toward the retail mainstream of Bloomingdale's and Macy's, Saks executives insist they have no intention of abandoning their affluent customers.
"Reaching for a broader audience does not mean reaching down," said Arthur C. Martinez, 51 years old, one of Saks's two vice chairmen.
Saks is privately held and, befitting its status as one of retailing's crown jewels, it jealously guards its financial position and its merchandising plans. But recent interviews with top Saks executives, rivals, suppliers and others show a company pressed to reach out to new customers while trying to keep its singularity.
Much of the speculation about the company's health began in late July, when a major financial company stopped guaranteeing credit for shipments to Saks. Many people in the industry began to wonder whether the store that gave Fifth Avenue its cachet had contracted a touch of the malady afflicting so many of its retail cousins.
Saks certainly is not immune to the combined forces of a frigid sales climate and the huge debt the company assumed last year when Investcorp International Inc. bought it for $1.5 billion. Further, experts say, economic conditions in general and Saks's financial obligations in particular may change forever the character of its business.
Some evidence of that change can be seen in the strategies the company has adopted to see it through the recession. To be sure, Saks is still busy drawing up three-year business plans with Escada and Chanel and its other top design firms. But it has now joined other retailers in aggressively encouraging many of its suppliers to add new, less costly collections, called "bridge lines."
A woman's jacket in these lines, like Malisy from Genny and Company from Ellen Tracy, costs about half as much as those sewn with the designers' regular labels.
Saks is also re-establishing ties with some manufacturers it abandoned in the 1980's when it turned its attention to pricey sequined, beaded or beribboned $10,000 designer dresses and elegantly tailored $2,000 designer suits.
"For a while Saks went away from more middle resources and concentrated on the high end," said Shep Porter, owner of Regina Porter, which makes moderately priced women's wear. "Now they're starting with us again."
 
'A Little Pause'
 Melvin Jacobs, 64, Saks's chairman, acknowledged that sales of the costliest garments were slowing. "We're seeing a little pause in $9,000 ball gowns, but they haven't gone away," he said. "It's sort of slowed at a very high level, but it's still an important business and one we will continue to give a great deal of emphasis."
On the other hand, based on strong sales for DKNY, the designer Donna Karan's bridge line, Saks has added Anne Klein's new, less expensive label, A-Line, and similar labels to entice younger women.
"We tend to have a very mature, traditionally oriented customer from a fashion point of view," said Philip B. Miller, 54, who is Saks's other vice chairman, and who is responsible for merchandising strategy. "Now we'd like to be the store of choice for her daughter as well."
What that means, said Patrick M. Dunne, who teaches retailing at the College of Business Administration at Texas Tech University, is this: "The traditional Saks consumer has probably cut down on her spending. She may just not be interested in high fashion any more. But the younger consumer is still fashion-oriented, so it makes sense for the fashion-oriented retailer like Saks to focus there."
In other moves to raise more revenue, Saks is revamping its credit card business to squeeze more cash from interest payments and provide a more accessible source of capital. And it is investing in computer systems that will enable it to track its inventory more closely.
 
Progress Expected
 Retail analysts and consultants say Saks's new strategies are likely to have some success. But they have also left the company open to speculation that it is reaching out to new customers out of near desperation.
Adding to the unease about Saks is the remarkably low profile of its owner, Investcorp, a partnership of Arab investors that bought Saks from B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. Investcorp plowed about $600 million of equity into the company. Investcorp installed its own management team at Saks, including Mr. Martinez, who had been with the American subsidiary of B.A.T., and Mr. Miller, to back up Mr. Jacobs, whose contract runs through 1993.
Seventh Avenue seems to regard Mr. Martinez, who is responsible for financial operations, as something of a financial wizard and a well-rounded businessman. But some retailing experts say he lacks the training in merchandising so prized among merchants.
And while Mr. Miller mastered his trade in such vaunted retail laboratories as Lord & Taylor, Marshall Field and Neiman-Marcus, Saks's foremost competitor, many people interviewed felt that having two vice chairmen created the potential for divisiveness.
"Any time you change as many merchants as they have, you've got a different culture and everybody has to get used to it," said Nicholas A. Gallopo, a partner at Arthur Andersen. "So far they've done everything right except they got caught in this down retail climate and they're the new guys on the block."
 
Rumors on Late Payments
 Saks's luster was dulled a bit in late July, when, just before manufacturers began shipping fall merchandise, rumors swept through the garment district that the company was telling suppliers that its payments would be late -- rumors Saks vehemently denies.
Credit agencies, which have relied on scanty glimpses of Saks's financial statements for more than a decade, scrambled to rescind their favorable recommendations. Credit rating agencies, like Credit Clearing House and Sands Credit Consultants Inc., play a special role in retailing, where they act as independent auditors for thousands of small suppliers.
And Heller Financial Inc., a factor, or financial go-between for retailers and suppliers, said it would no longer guarantee shipments to Saks.
Heller's actions reminded many suppliers of a report in Women's Wear Daily that asserted Saks had lost $100 million during the first seven months of the year. Saks executives strongly denied any such loss, but would not be more specific. Still, analysts said they would be surprised if Saks had suffered no losses, given the lagging retail economy, particularly in New York, where Saks's flagship generates about 22 percent of sales.
In 1989, the last year for which figures are available, Saks had sales of $1.3 billion and earned $111 million before interest and taxes. according to an offering memorandum circulated to potential investors.
Despite Heller's statement, and their own doubts, manufacturers shipped to Saks anyway. All credit agencies have restored Saks's ratings and the furor has ended, although Heller has continued its embargo.
"It is my feeling that the firm will be here for long enough to satisfy its current obligations," said Richard Posner, executive vice president of Credit Exchange, a credit rating agency, adding that "long enough" was at the very least six months.
 
Private Labels Added
 The July jitters came on the heels of Saks's decision to increase sales of merchandise under its own labels, like the Works, A.S.A.P. and Fenton Last, a line of women's shoes. Many stores have added such private labels because they are more profitable.
Saks executives made the announcement at a Fashion Institute of Technology seminar on the issues the rag trade will confront in the 1990's. That they did so before an assemblage of Seventh Avenue notables whose goods will now face increased competition from Saks's own brands was taken as an affront by some.
Many people attending the meeting believed Mr. Martinez said 30 percent, or more than $300 million, of Saks's sales would ultimately come from private-label apparel. But in an interview, Mr. Miller said Saks labels accounted for about 12 percent of sales and would probably never amount to more than 15 percent.
Moreover, he said, Saks was working harder than ever to cultivate its relationship with suppliers, signing exclusive deals with manufacturers and inviting them to display special collections in its stores.
Some retailing executives say these new decisions put Saks's reputation for being on the cutting edge of fashion on the line. In the 1970's, Saks was the leading national source for the freshest designer fashions, fragrances and accessories. Its only rivals were regional specialty stores like Neiman-Marcus in Dallas or Bergdorf Goodman in New York.
 
Broad Expansion in 80's
 In the mid-1980's, veteran retailing experts say, Saks became preoccupied, maybe even obsessed, with a national rollout. Stores went up in every major metropolitan area and in many secondary cities, so that Saks's 48 stores extend from Portland, Ore., to Atlanta and from Minneapolis to New Orleans.
Its competitors have also expanded nationally, but mostly in the largest cities. Neiman-Marcus, which recently opened its 25th store, in Minneapolis, goes head to head with Saks in Chicago but not in Portland.
Saks executives say having a national presence is critical these days. "Each major market is an opportunity, but the secondary markets are also opportunities," Mr. Jacobs said. "They are very often underserved, and we have created, really, the only national specialty store."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Saks Fifth Avenue's flagship store, right, in Manhattan accounts for about 22 percent of the company's sales, Melvin Jacobs, the chairman of Saks, likes to think of the chain as "the only national specialty store." (Photographs by John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cuomo's Health Nominee Is Advised to Kepp Silent

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Dr. Mark R. Chassin, the California physician nominated to be New York State's next health commissioner, has emerged as the David Souter of gubernatorial appointees, a man with little public record on major health issues and little freedom to stake out his positions.
In a reflection of the growing political sensitivity of health policy, Dr. Chassin has followed the instructions of the Cuomo administration to divulge little about his positions or agenda until his Senate confirmation hearings. Dr. Chassin was nominated by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on Monday, and his confirmation hearings may not be held before November. 
 Doctors, hospital administrators and health-care lobbyists who participated in get-to-know-you meetings with Dr. Chassin in Albany and New York City this week said he was cordial but provided few details about his plans. In an interview today, he said he would have to "draw the line" at answering specific questions about AIDS, universal health care and no-fault malpractice insurance.
 
Clamp on News Questioned
 Dr. Chassin and aides to Mr. Cuomo said they did not want to subvert the confirmation process.
"We have a confirmation process to undergo with the Senate, at which time the policy issues will be fully discussed," said Michael J. Dowling, Mr. Cuomo's director of health, education and human services. "That's the prerogative of the Senate."
But a spokesman for the Republican majority in the Senate said Senate leaders were eager to learn more about Dr. Chassin and would not object to him speaking publicly.
"The more we know about Dr. Chassin at this point, the better, since we know very little about him," said John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino. "We never have objections to the media being the conduit."
The recent nominations of public-health officials provide ample evidence of the political dangers of speaking too freely.
 
Early Dissent Feared
 Mayor David N. Dinkins's 1990 appointment of Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. as New York City's health commissioner was delayed for several weeks as homosexual-rights groups objected to his previous positions on AIDS.
Similarly, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan's nomination as Secretary of Health and Human Services was nearly derailed in 1988 when he said in a newspaper interview that women should have a right to abortion, a position not shared by President-elect George Bush.
Several Cuomo aides said they hoped to avoid a repeat of such incidents. "We think this guy is going to be very, very good, and the fact that he can't be pinned down on a lot of things is actually good," said one administration official. "He can't be attacked. If positions get out there early, it can create a furor."
Adding to the sensitivity of Dr. Chassin's nomination is his $160,000 salary, a 60 percent increase over the salary received by his predecessor, Dr. David Axelrod. Senate officials said the salary offer had "raised eyebrows," and union officials have complained about such a large increase in a year when there were no raises for state workers.
Dr. Chassin said today that he was taking a pay cut to move to Albany because the health commissioner's job "verges on a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to really have an impact on the delivery of real health care to real people." He declined to disclose his previous salary.
What is known about the 44-year-old physician is that his work for the last 12 years as a bureaucrat, researcher and businessman has been singularly dedicated to reducing health-care costs and eliminating unnecessary medical procedures.
From 1979 to 1981, Dr. Chassin served as deputy director of the Office of Professional Standards Review Organizations of the United States Health Care Financing Administration. In that job, he oversaw the development and application of Federal guidelines for determining which medical procedures might be inappropriate for the treatment of Medicare patients.
He then worked for the Rand Corporation directing research projects that revealed high levels of inappropriate use of various medical and surgical procedures. His most acclaimed study, which was reported in numerous medical journals in 1987, disclosed that a third of all carotid endarterectomies performed on Medicare patients in 1981 were unnecessary.
Nearly 11 percent of the patients who unnecessarily underwent the surgery, which clears blockages in an artery to the brain, either died within 30 days or suffered a stroke, he reported. At an average cost of $13,000, the unneeded procedures were both expensive and dangerous, the study concluded.
Dr. Chassin left Rand in 1988 to help found Value Health Sciences Inc., a Santa Monica, Calif., company that produces computer software to help insurers review the quality and cost of medical care.
Those familiar with Dr. Chassin's work in California said he represented a new type of policymaker who searched for solutions to health-care problems with computer models and financing plans.
"This is a very large business, and it's running amok," said Dr. Mark Blumberg, a health economist with Kaiser Permanente in Oakland. "Data is very helpful in shaping it. Dr. Chassin could contribute to that."
Dr. Chassin is described by friends and colleagues as intelligent, intense, reserved, demanding of those he works with and protective of his privacy.
He holds four degrees, including a medical degree and a master's in public policy from Harvard and a master's in public health from the University of California at Los Angeles. Certified as an internist, he spent 12 years practicing emergency medicine.
"He's a good listener, and yet he's not a patsy," said Dr. Steven A. Schroeder, president of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, the country's largest health-care philanthropy.
Dr. Kathleen N. Lohr, a former colleague of Dr. Chassin's at Rand and now an official with the National Academy of Sciences, said Dr. Chassin "won't waffle and be obtuse about the direction he wants to go."
But until Dr. Chassin sits before a panel of state senators, that direction may remain unclear.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Griffin Bacal Is Diversifying With New Marketing Unit

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
SEEKING to broaden its client base beyond consumer advertising, Griffin Bacal Inc. is creating an agency within the agency, headed by two executives experienced in business-to-business and high-technology accounts.
In keeping with the industry's increasingly popular practice of providing clients a full range of services, known as integrated marketing communications, the new group offers everything from print and broadcast ads to in-store displays to sales brochures. Called the Business Marketing Communications Group, the new unit operates as a separate subsidiary of Griffin Bacal, a New York shop with $180 million in billings from clients in markets like consumer electronics and toys. 
 Griffin Bacal's decision to diversify stems from a belief that "carving out niches in the market makes sense, instead of just banging on client doors," Paul Kurnit, president and chief operating officer, said in an interview yesterday at the agency's office in lower Manhattan. "What we saw was an ability to add a dimension to the company."
Sitting in on the discussion, the first Mr. Kurnit has had about the group since its formation, were its co-directors: Richard Conti, who previously ran his own agency, Conti Advertising, in Upper Saddle River, N.J., which specialized in business-to-business accounts, and Ned Clausen, a longtime advertising executive with high-tech expertise who most recently was executive vice president of Kameny Spitzer Felix, New York. Both are also becoming senior vice presidents and group directors of Griffin Bacal.
The creation of the group reflects two important trends reshaping the advertising industry as it copes with a three-year-old recession. One is the need for agencies like Griffin Bacal, known for creating campaigns for such clients as Sharp Electronics, Hasbro and Playskool, to be able to offer them -- as well as potential new clients -- more than television commercials or print advertisements.
"Whereas before, agencies sold creativity," said Mr. Conti, 48 years old, "today a viable agency must be able to offer a whole plethora of marketing services."
The other trend is the consolidation of small agencies, like Mr. Conti's, into larger ones, as also typified by the recent absorption of Buckley DeCerchio Cavalier into Frankfurt Gips Balkind.
"It's a no-win situation for the smaller agency," Mr. Conti said. "Long term, you must be able to have the strength of a Griffin Bacal to be effective." A key problem for "the small guys who go after $250,000 accounts," he added, is that "we found Jerry Della Femina and friends going after those accounts."
It was particularly appealing to Griffin Bacal to obtain expertise in these fields by bringing in executives, Mr. Kurnit said, because "I don't know, in this economy, whether I would have had the stomach to start something like this from scratch."
Mr. Conti and Mr. Clausen, 52, are bringing dowries with them as they join Griffin Bacal. The three employees and dozen-plus accounts that were at Conti Advertising are being absorbed by the new group. Those accounts, with stimated billings of $9 million, include Chipwich Inc.; Dial America Marketing, a telemarketing service; the Maxell Corporation of America, for its battery products, and Moxy Trucks of America, for heavy-duty trucks.
And Lambda Electronics, a $1 million to $1.5 million account that Mr. Clausen worked on at Kameny Spitzer, is coming with him.
The group is already at work on projects for Sharp, Mr. Conti said, including the creation of sales literature and direct-mail pieces. Mr. Kurnit said he hoped other current Griffin Bacal clients would consider the group for work "that they would have gone elsewhere for."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls as Coup Fizzles; Gold Prices Up in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar plunged against most major currencies yesterday as the currency returned to more normal levels after the failed three-day coup attempt in the Soviet Union.
Gold prices finished higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose $1 an ounce, to a late bid of $356.90. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted an after-hours bid of $356.85, up 85 cents from late Tuesday. 
 The dollar dipped even lower yesterday than its level last week, before a committee of Soviet hard-liners ousted President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The turmoil had pushed up the dollar, which is generally considered a safe currency in times of international distress.
But the coup, which faced resistance led by the Russian republic's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, fell apart and Mr. Gorbachev was returning to Moscow yesterday.
"I think a lot of people were surprised to see how Yeltsin and the military and the Russian people really stuck together," said James Maccario, vice president of foreign exchange at Shawmut Bank of Boston.
Mike Ballow, a market analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago, said the perception in the market is that the democratic movement in the Soviet Union is even more entrenched than people thought before the coup.
 
Mark Gathers Strength
 That perception has strengthened the German mark, he said. It revived considerably in New York trading, as the dollar dropped to 1.7408 marks, from 1.7985 late Tuesday.
For the dollar, Mr. Maccario said, "fundamentally nothing has changed."
"The dollar was going down before Sunday," he said. "There's no reason to hold on to the dollar right now. Interest rates still look like they're going lower."
Expectations of lower United States interest rates generally depress the dollar.
In New York, the British pound finished at $1.6885, up from $1.6440 late Tuesday. Earlier in London, the pound rose to $1.6735, from $1.6380 late Tuesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 137.18 yen, down 0.60 yen from Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 136.85 yen, and in New York, the dollar was quoted at 136.55, down from 137.20 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.5150 Swiss francs, down from 1.5432; 1.1442 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1417; 5.9190 French francs, down from 6.1140, and 1,302.75 Italian lire, down from 1,340.50.

HEADLINE: Vietnam, the Way It Might Have Been

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTMINSTER, Calif.

 BODY:
Before the start of a recent concert of Vietnamese pop music here in the community known as Little Saigon, schoolchildren in smart blue uniforms marched onto the stage of a school auditorium carrying the yellow and red flag of South Vietnam, a country that ceased to exist 16 years ago. The audience, like a roomful of ghosts, rose and joined the singing of that country's national anthem.
Then the performers in their extravagant outfits, mostly aging refugees themselves, sang the familiar ballads of two decades past, of love and loneliness and of weariness with a war that is long since over. 
 Here in Little Saigon, as in other Vietnamese refugee communities throughout the country, people are still struggling to come to terms with history. Many are adapting only halfway to their new country, taking on the ways and pace of American life but with their hearts still in Vietnam.
On weekdays, those who have jobs work in the weapons and computer industries that are prime employers here in Orange County, an hour's drive south of Los Angeles. On weekends they hold anti-Communist political meetings, sit through long afternoons of traditional Vietnamese opera, or stroll through the air-conditioned malls of Little Saigon.
These shopping centers, like the two-story Asian Garden Mall, are what much of Saigon might look like today if the North Vietnamese had not won the war in 1975 and imposed on it the stagnation of their economic system.
 
California Version of Saigon
 Up and down Bolsa Avenue, and for several blocks around, clusters of shops, offices, restaurants and cafes with their Vietnamese signs glitter in chrome and neon, a Southern California dream of Saigon. The centerpiece of this cluster is a pair of bustling indoor shopping malls where the usual staples of shops selling hamburgers and athletic shoes have been supplanted by Amerasia My-A Import Wholesale Retail, Van Hoi Xuan Chinese Herbs and Sai-Gon Color Lab.
While much of Southeast Asia has enjoyed some of the world's most rapid economic growth since the end of the Vietnam war, the Communist nations of Indochina have stagnated, and Saigon, renamed Ho Chi Minh City, has been left behind.
"If America had won the war over there, it would look like Singapore today," said Yen Nguyen, 34 years old, who fled Vietnam by boat after the fall of Saigon in 1975.
"Maybe the style would be a little bit different from here in the mall," he said. "Maybe over there they would put a little pond inside. Maybe it would be a little more romantic than here."
 
Economic Slump Hurts Buying
 Mr. Nguyen owns Kim Son Fabrics, where a refugee can buy a bolt of silk for direct delivery to relatives in Vietnam. But now, he said, along with the rest of the American economy, the Vietnamese community here is in a slump. Many of the weekend strollers in the mall buy little more than a plastic cup of French coffee sweetened with condensed milk.
Since the end of the war, half a million Vietnamese refugees have come to the United States. Those here inspire others; new arrivals soon send for family members, who either make a dangerous escape from Vietnam by boat or join the long list of people petitioning the State Department to come this country.
Mai Cong, a community leader who was one of the first Vietnamese refugees to settle here, in 1975, said: "When I first came here there were very few Vietnamese, and very few Asians. Many of us had to go to Los Angeles Chinatown for our groceries."
Now, Ms. Cong said, more than 20,000 Vietnamese live in Westminster, primarily in an area that has acquired its own freeway exit, "Little Saigon." The Vietnamese now make up a quarter of the residents of Westminster, and the Vietnamese population in surrounding Orange County could be as high as 150,000, she said.
Many Vietnamese here describe Little Saigon as a cauldron of political intrigue, much like the Saigon of the past, with as many as 30 daily and weekly newspapers and an array of political antagonisms that sometime flare into violence. The major issue among Vietnamese in the United States is whether Washington should open diplomatic relations with Hanoi in the hope that the Communist government there will become more liberal or whether to continue to work for its collapse.
Some Vietnamese here called the town "the scam capital of the world," where lawyers fake traffic accidents to collect damages or charge refugees high fees for unnecessary official documents. He said some veterans' groups prey on arrivals, charging large sums for needless dealings with government agencies.
 
Crime Troubles Community
 The community is also the scene of a crime wave in which Vietnamese gangs extort payoffs from local businesses or terrorize refugees in their homes and steal their valuables.
As the years have passed, generational divisions have changed the character of Little Saigon, and a place like the Asian Garden Mall has become the scene of a culture clash that is purely Vietnamese.
Le Thi Thach, who is 81 and lives in San Diego, wore a silk blouse and a formal black hair band for a recent visit to the mall, where she was shopping for a gold wedding ring for a niece. "I come here to remember Saigon," she said. "Everything is Vietnamese here and everyone speaks Vietnamese."
But for 15-year-old Thai Pham, stylish in a black Oakland Raiders jacket who arrived in the United States as an infant, impressions of Vietnam come from photographs and from the mall itself. "No, it's too dirty over there," he said, when asked if he wanted to visit the land of his birth. "I've seen pictures. This is Vietnam for me here. Every Vietnamese comes here."
And for Sean To, just 18 months old, the perspective on the past will be still more distant, helped by the Irish name his father said he gave him to speed his Americanization. "To me, all this looks pretty much like Vietnam," said the father, Ken To. "But for Sean, Saigon will look pretty much like Westminster."
The shifting perspective of the generations is painful for Tran Van Ngoc, 45, a former helicopter pilot who now heads a Vietnamese veterans association and works as a computer technician.
"It hurts my feelings when my daughter asks me about my country," he said, explaining that her questions reflected the ignorance and the biases of her American schoolmates. "It's very hard to explain to the American generation."
Now 15, his daughter has begun to ask him about his role in the war and about the disdain that many Americans feel for the South Vietnamese soldiers who were their allies.
With the defensive tone that some American veterans also found themselves adopting over the years, he said. "I tell her I am proud that I fought that war," he said. "I fought with my heart and I did what I could."
 
Realization of Change
 Most difficult to accept, said Mr. Ngoc, is the realization that he himself has changed over the past 16 years and that the Vietnam of the past cannot be reclaimed.
"When people come here to find Vietnam like Saigon before 1975 they are making a mistake, because we are not the same," he said. "We are Vietnamese but we are not Vietnamese.
"Living in a new country, we change and we don't even know it. Our thoughts are different and we don't even know it. Sometimes I try to deny that I am Americanized, but I have changed."
All around him, people were speaking Vietnamese, eating Vietnamese food, listening to the Vietnamese music that filled the mall. Some shops displayed the yellow South Vietnamese flag with its three red stripes.
"The people walking around here," Mr. Ngoc said, "sometimes they don't realize that this is Little Saigon, but it is not Saigon."

HEADLINE: Inwood Journal;
Of Changing Enclaves And Unchanging Ways

BYLINE: By JOSH KURTZ

 BODY:
Like a lot of taverns in the Inwood section of Manhattan, Bakersfield has Irish flags draped on the wall and Irish beer on tap. When Representative Joseph P. Kennedy, son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy, spoke at a conference on Irish-American affairs in the neighborhood earlier this year, he had breakfast at Bakersfield.
It is a neighborhood that clings proudly to its turf and its Irish roots. But as a swiftly growing Dominican population squeezes Inwood's Irish residents into tighter quarters, mostly north of 207th Street and west of Broadway, some Irish-American merchants have decided, in small measure at least, to adapt. 
 "I'm sure that the business leadership in Inwood understands the economics involved," said James Carney, president of the Washington Heights-Inwood Chamber of Commerce.
For a while, Bakersfield was at the forefront of that movement. But just as quickly in recent weeks the bar's owners have stepped back. Sociologists, take note.
Last winter the bar hired a disk jockey, Tom Moto, to play what he called "white rock" records on Thursday and Saturday nights. The crowds were dismal: usually, 20 or 30 people showed up. Mr. Moto, who lives in Yonkers and works as a D.J. in Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester, had another idea.
"We'd have a lot of Hispanic people coming in, checking it out, then taking off," he said. "I knew what they were looking for. So I told the owners we'd have to go with the neighborhood."
Mr. Moto started playing house music, reggae, freestyle and other dance tunes that appeal to a younger, and often darker crowd, than the bar's owners were first hoping to reach. But it paid off: within weeks, 400 people were going to Bakersfield on Thursday and Saturday nights.
"When I heard they were playing that kind of music there, I couldn't believe it," said Marilyn Rosario, 21 years old, an administrative assistant from the Bronx. "I went there because of the music. I wouldn't go there otherwise. The music first attracted me."
Everyone seemed happy. "The owners were making money, and people didn't have to go downtown on Thursday nights to go dancing," Mr. Moto said.
The 26-year-old D.J., a chunky, unassuming man who often wears baseball caps and T-shirts to work, became a hero to his Dominican customers. Every evening a parade of beautiful young women would run up to kiss him, and the men would pledge their loyalty.
"No one can match the quality of the music," said Pedro Sosa, a professional dancer who, inspired by Mr. Moto's beat, would practice his moves in the wee hours of Friday mornings.
Mr. Moto admitted there was a cultural gulf between himself and the young dancers at first. But because they shared a love for the same type of music, they soon became friends.
"It just goes to show the music is overcoming the difference," he said.
But it wasn't enough to overcome the bar owners' jitters about unknown cultures. One Thursday night in mid-July, a brawl broke out at Bakersfield. Bottles were broken. The police were called. The owners told Mr. Moto to forget about coming by. Perhaps, they said, the dancing could rfesume after Labor Day when things were cooler.
One of the bar's owners, Pat McCormick, was hesitant to talk about the situation.
Mr. Moto took his business elsewhere. He got a Thursday night gig at Tu Casa, a restaurant on 189th Street with a sizable dance floor. Without a single announcement, his customers followed, 80 of them the first week, twice as many the second, and even more the week after.
"Wherever he goes, I'm in there," Miss Rosario said.
Bakersfield, on a recent Thursday night, was almost empty. There were no Dominicans. Regulars slid into their barstools and were served drinks without having to order.
"This," said one patron who refused to give his name, "is what this place is all about."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Funds Are Mixed; Tax-Exempt Yields Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday. Tax-exempt funds struggled with supply, and taxable funds still showed the effects of the interest rate easing by the Federal Reserve in early August.
Tax-exempt money fund yields rose as supplies of new issues increased. The seven-day compounded average yield rose 7 basis points, to 4.10 percent, with the simple yield up a similar amount, to 4.02 percent. During the same period, the 30-day compounded yield rose 10 basis points, to 4.07 percent, and the simple yield was up similarly, to 3.99 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios rose one day, to 58.
Opposite Directions
Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, said "there is a fair amount of supply of new issues, pushing yields in the opposite direction of Treasury securities and the general taxable money fund market, where the Fed has more of a direct impact on rates."
Analysts said total assets of tax-exempt funds fell $401 million, to $87.9 billion.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compunded yield is 5.69 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket is 5.94 percrent.
Of the funds monitored by IBC/ Donoghue's with assets greater than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund, which buys securities that for some investors is subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax, continued as the best performer. The fund, distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee, had a return of 5.09 percent, up 6 basis points from the previous week.
 
Flight to Safety
 Assets of taxable funds rose by $6.2 billion, to $460.2 billion. The sharp rise was attributed to a flight to safety that caused interest rates to drop sharply after the coup attempt early this week in Moscow.
Mr. Frank sees rates in the taxable funds moving up next week as confidence increases and money flow back toward settling market and currencies.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 4 basis points, to 5.50 percent, while the simple yield fell 5 basis points, to 5.35 percent. The 30-day compounded yield was 5.57 percent and the simple yield down 2 basis points, to 5.42 percent.
The taxable fund with the best return was Riverside Capital Money Mark fund, distributed by the Winsbury Company of Columbus, Ohio. The yield was 6.37 percent.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with money market funds, were down 2 basis points to 5.16 percent, according to the Bank Rate Monitor's national index. The yield spread between bank money market accounts and money market funds has narrowed to 34 basis points, compared with more than a full percentage point at the start of the year.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Coup's End Lifts Short-Term Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The abrupt end to the Soviet coup yesterday pushed short-term interest rates back up as quickly as they had fallen earlier in the week. Treasury bond prices also rose on the news.
The steep climb in short-term rates left traders scrambling to get out of positions established earlier in the week, when the Soviet crisis made it seem clear that foreign capital, particularly from Europe, would pour into safe dollar-denominated assets, and that short-term interest rates would therefore continue to fall. 
 "It's been a bad day on the Street," one Government securities trader said. "Since Monday, the approach has been to buy the short end of the yield curve, because everybody was convinced that if the Soviet Union totally broke down it would make Germany such a basket case that capital was going to flow like water into bills and short-term notes. People have gotten hurt."
Given the speed with which events unfolded yesterday, and the fact that dealers were unable to fully hedge short-term positions in the futures market until the opening of the Chicago Board of Trade, "most of the people with London offices" probably got clobbered, said James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management, a New York money management firm.
 
Yield Curve's Blip
 The rise in short-term interest rates left the yield curve, the difference between rates on two-year notes and 30-year bonds, in almost exactly the same shape it was late Friday.
"When we look back at this blip in the yield curve in a couple of years, we are going to scratch our heads and try to remember what caused it," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
The apparent end of the Soviet coup allowed credit market participants to refocus on the Federal Reserve Board. The Fed, which is widely expected to lower key short-term interest rates soon, gave market participants no such signal yesterday.
"As of right now, things are on hold," Mr. Liro said. "We'll just have to wait and see how long it stays that way."
Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Economics, said the quick end to the Soviet crisis left the "present predicament for the U.S. economy pretty much unchanged."
"Therefore," he said, "the presumed bias toward easier monetary policy remains. Now that equity markets around the world have recovered and are rallying, there is still the need for the Fed to ease, and probably more than once."
 
Bonds Climb
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 3/4, up 10/32, to yield 8.05 percent, down from 8.08 percent late Tuesday.
Mr. Capra, Mr. Fabbri and others said bond traders may view the apparent end of the Soviet crisis as reducing the risk of holding long-term securities.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 100 21/32, up 3/32, to yield 7.77 percent. But the 6 7/8 percent two-year notes fell by 6/32, to a price of 101 6/32, to yield 6.21 percent.
"A drop of that size in the price of a two-year note is the equivalent of a full point decline in bond prices," Mr. Capra said.
Late yesterday the Treasury announced it will sell $12.5 billion worth of two-year notes on Tuesday, and $9.25 billion worth of five-year notes on Wednesday.
In when-issued trading after the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.26 percent. The five-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.26 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved sharply higher. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.27 percent, up 17 basis points, or 17 one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose 13 basis points, to 5.26 percent. And one-year bill rates rose 12 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.27 percent.
Elsewhere, the State of California for the first time yesterday issued taxable securities. It offered $602 million worth of taxable general obligation bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers won the issue, which consists of serial bonds maturing from 1992 to 2001.
Coupons on the securities range from 7.70 percent on bonds maturing in 1992 to 8.15 percent on bonds that mature in 2001.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues rose by 1/8 of a point in fairly active trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities, prices of most widely quoted issues increased by 1/8 point, market participants said.

HEADLINE: For China, a Summer of Diplomatic Triumphs

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 21

 BODY:
During a visit to Beijing two months ago, a senior American official warned that any transfer of Chinese M-9 or M-11 missiles to other nations "would have the most profound consequences for our bilateral relations."
China appears to have ignored that warning and transferred the missiles to Pakistan and possibly to Syria as well. Yet there have been no consequences either profound or minor since Reginald Bartholomew, Undersecretary of State for International Security Affairs, issued his warning in June. 
 Beijing's success, at least so far, in evading punishment for its missile sales is characteristic of the success of Chinese diplomacy this summer. For the last two months or so, almost everything has seemed to go right for Prime Minister Li Peng and other top officials in charge of burnishing the nation's external image.
China's latest string of foreign policy triumphs began in early July with its landmark agreement with Britain over a new airport in Hong Kong. Then the United States Senate failed to muster a two-thirds vote to add conditions to China's most-favored-nation trade status, virtually ensuring that China will continue to enjoy its present trade benefits.
This month Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan became the first leader of an industrial country to visit China since the army crackdown on the pro-democracy movement two years ago. Prime Minister John Major of Britain is expected to visit on Sept. 2, also signifying that the Tiananmen crackdown is no longer a serious impediment to Chinese diplomacy.
The Chinese leadership has won praise for its announcement this month that it will sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, and it has not been much criticized for the apparent missile sales to Pakistan, and perhaps to Syria as well.
Launchers for the M-11 have been seen in Pakistan, and after Mr. Bartholomew's visit China confirmed that it has sold "short-range" missiles to Islamabad. It refuses to say whether these are the M-11's.
There is less of a consensus among experts on whether the M-9's have been already transferred to Syria. But the Far Eastern Economic Review, a highly regarded Hong Kong magazine, reports in its Aug. 22 issue that up to 24 of the M-9 launchers have been seen in Syria. Asked for a comment, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said reports of the sale were groundless.
Mr. Bartholemew returned to Beijing early this month and was asked at a news conference why there had been no "profound consequences" after all.
"We are going to be pursuing, continuing to pursue, the questions that I raised the last time I was here," he said. "I don't think that we are at the point where there's anything more to be said, at least not during this visit, and I would leave the matter right there."
There are several reasons why the United States may not have followed up on its threats. Washington may want indisputable evidence that the missile transfers have taken place or it may suspect that any transfers involved only a small number of missiles.
In addition, Washington may believe that the M-9 and M-11 missiles are not as threatening as they originally appeared. They are thought to be more accurate than the Scud missiles used by Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, and to be launched more quickly and fly faster, making them less vulnerable to destruction on the ground or in the air. But it is conceivable that they do not exceed the 180-mile international definition for a short-range missile. That would make the M-11 useful for Pakistan primarily as a tactical weapon in the Kashmir region, although the M-9 could be used by Syria to threaten most or all of Israel. The Chinese missiles could carry nuclear warheads, but experts say that it would be technically very complex to build and attach a suitable nuclear warhead.
"They're proliferating more than we would like," said a Western military specialist. "But I don't think that this is having a strategic impact on the world."
