HEADLINE: Market Place;
Will MCI Always Play David?

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
THE Federal Government gave the MCI Communications Corporation a valuable breathing spell earlier this month. It delayed action on a potentially expensive increase in the costliest item in a long-distance call for MCI and other long-distance carriers. The item, known as "access fees," makes up nearly half the cost of a long-distance call.
The Federal Communications Commission said on Aug. 1 that it would study the situation further instead of allowing current fees to lapse, as scheduled, on Sept. 1. But the Government's lack of action did little to answer the question still bedeviling Wall Street analysts: Has MCI, about one-fourth the size of A.T.& T., gotten as big as it can get? 
 Whether MCI, one of Wall Street's most volatile stocks, will continue to be considered an attractive growth stock turns on whether investors view the American Telephone and Telegraph Company as a permanent Goliath to MCI's David, with United Telecommunications' Sprint and others bringing up the rear, or whether there is still large potential for gaining market share at A.T.& T.'s expense.
Investors are wary. MCI's stock price has limped along since it stumbled to about $18 a share when the recession and a big restructuring charge cut 1990 operating earnings by a third, to $620 million, despite a 19 percent rise in revenue, to $7.7 billion. Most analysts find the stock moderately attractive, yet seem to be constantly shaving their earnings projections by a penny or two. Yesterday, MCI closed at $29.625 a share, far from its 52-week high of $37. At about 13 times projected 1991 earnings, MCI's stock is seemingly undervalued compared with the Standard & Poor's 500, which is trading at around 16.
The shadow of higher access fees, or at least the uncertainty over them, has clouded MCI's luster. The recession, which has hurt the talkative white-collar class that makes many long-distance calls, and a surprisingly competitive A.T.& T., willing to match MCI discount for discount, have added to the doubts.
MCI argues that some securities analysts have misinterpreted the access-fees issue to its disadvantage. They acknowledge the potential for a run-up in MCI's operating costs, but contend that to a greater extent than Wall Street is willing to concede, A.T.& T. will also share the cost of new fees.
The fees themselves are simple. A customer who wants to make a long-distance call from New York to Atlanta, for example, needs a long-distance carrier and two local-telephone companies. New York Telephone and Southern Bell charge fees to the long-distance carrier for access to local lines. These fees cost MCI, on average, 43 cents or more of every dollar of revenue from a long-distance call, according to Charles W. Schelke, a telecommunications analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
A.T.& T., with an advanced network built over decades, qualified for so-called dedicated transport and cheaper fees. MCI and others with different equipment have been rushing to convert from "common transport" and potentially higher fees.
But United States District Judge Harold H. Greene, who oversaw the breakup of A.T.& T., wanted the smaller companies to be able to compete with A.T.& T. He required local phone companies to charge all carriers equal fees, at least for a grace period.
The grace period was to have expired on Sept. 1. But the F.C.C. said it would indefinitely freeze the current access fees, while studying the impact of moving to "cost based," i.e. more expensive, fees for MCI and others. It would also consider another plan that involved "interconnect" fees that tended to equalize fees for everyone.
The upshot, analysts say, is probably a year of F.C.C. study and then several years of gradual price increases or possibly no increase at all.
"But one could argue that MCI should have been getting ready for Sept. 1, but didn't," said Joel D. Gross, a telecommunications analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.
MCI, however, is nearly ready now, according to James L. Lewis, vice president of regulatory affairs. A "substantial majority" of its network qualifies for cheaper access fees. Moreover, Mr. Lewis contends, any rise in access fees would affect only a third of total access fees -- in other words, just 14 cents or so out of $1 of revenue, rather than the full 43 cents.
MCI is still far smaller than A.T.& T. In the quarter ended June 30, MCI had a 16.8 percent share of nearly $12.5 billion worth of long-distance calls, according to Mr. Schelke of Smith Barney, compared with 69.1 percent for A.T.& T.
But even relatively strong growth for MCI, some analysts say, translates to only a modest addition of 2.5 or more market-share points over the next five years, to about 20 percent or so. And that may not be anything to call home about.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
British Air Chooses Boeing And Orders G.E. Engines (Boeing)

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21

 BODY:
British Airways chose the Boeing Company today as its supplier for aircraft worth $6.85 billion. The decision was a strong confirmation of Boeing's new mid-size jet, the 777, and was a victory for the American company over the competing European Airbus Industrie consortium.
Airline industry analysts were not surprised, however, because British Airways has usually bought from Boeing. The surprising aspect of the decision was that British Airways, which has consistently flown its Boeing aircraft with Rolls-Royce engines, said it would power its 777's with a new engine from the General Electric Company. 
 The order, which General Electric valued at $1.4 billion, is the first for the GE90 engine. British Airways also said it was selling British Airways Engine Overhaul Ltd. to General Electric for 272 million, or $447.14 million at current rates.
 
15 Ordered Plus 15 Options
 British Airways ordered 15 of the 777 twin-engine jets and took options to buy 15 more for a total of $3.6 billion. The airline also said it intended to order 24 additional 747-400 jumbo jets, bringing the total value of its order, including service and support, to $6.85 billion.
The share prices of all three companies rose on the New York Stock Exchange today. Boeing closed up $2.375 at $48.25, British Airways up $1 at $28.75 and General Electric up $2.375 at $72.875.
The 777 has two large wing-mounted engines, providing greater fuel efficiency and simpler operation than comparably sized four-engine jets, and can carry a maximum of 360 passengers. The 777 also offers far greater flexibility of design for customers than had its predecessors. And as configured for British Airways, the first 777's will seat 313 passengers in three classes and have a range of 5,220 miles. The airline will later receive models that have a range of 6,800 miles.
Today's order "shows that Boeing has the marketing clout to launch a new airplane in a difficult economic environment," said Howard A. Rubel, a securities analyst with the brokerage C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell in New York. With three leading carriers in the three large markets -- British Airways, United Airlines and All Nippon Airways -- committed to the 777, "there will be follow-on orders from others," he said.
 
Collaborating With Airlines
 Boeing officials said the orders reflected the benefits of designing the 777 in partnerships with eight airlines, including British Airways, United and All Nippon. Consulting the airlines has been crucial to maintaining a competitive edge against increasingly strong competition from both Airbus Industrie consortium and McDonnell Douglas, the officials said.
"I don't think there's any question that every ounce of airline input is gold," Phil Condit, executive vice president and general manager of the 777 program, said in telephone interview. "It makes the airplane better."
Lord King, chairman of British Airways, said, "We looked very hard indeed at all the aircraft and engine combinations in this highly competitive market, and the outcome represents, by a clear margin, the best decision."
The British Airways order brings the total number of orders for the 777 to 72, with options taken on 65. Boeing said that for 1991 it had 163 firm orders for all commercial jetliners at a value of $14.3 billion.
Mr. Rubel, the securities analyst, noted that General Electric was paying a large premium for British Airways Engine Overhaul Ltd., more than 24 times the 11 million ($18.08 million) in earnings that the maintenance business received last year. "It was a strategic investment that opens the door for them to win the All Nippon order," he said. All Nippon will announce in September which engine it will use for its 777's.
"Bravo G. E.," said Terry Moulton, a principal with Airline Capital Associates in New York, an airline industry consulting firm, calling the selection of the plane's engines a coup for General Electric and a blow to Rolls-Royce. "How much better a launch customer could you get than British Airways?"

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP: OLD GUARD'S LAST GASP;
Communism as a Political Force Is Dead, And the Reformers Gain Strong Legitimacy

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The bungled takeover of the Soviet Government left the incumbents of the Communist past discredited, and hastened the demise of the old guard that had long been whispering caution in the ear of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Communism as an ideology was already so moribund that even the conspirators did not wave the Marxist-Leninist flag, claiming instead stability as their cause. 
 Communism as a political force was today's casualty, since the coup debunked Mr. Gorbachev's rationale for clinging to the Communist Party as his power base, in the hope that by doing so he could keep its diehard partisans in check.
The failed coup legitimized the claim of post-Communist reformers that they are the rightful heirs to power, and invigorated them for the mammoth task of civilizing their country. It also raised the possibility that those who have prevailed may now move against those pillars of the K.G.B. and the military who had conspired against them.
When the euphoria recedes, however, both Mr. Gorbachev and the radicals will still face a fundamental problem that the conspirators were banking on to carry their coup: the public's fear of anarchy, ethnic conflict and economic insecurity, which has eroded trust in all politicians.
"There was fertile soil for this action," said Arkady I. Volsky, a Gorbachev confidant who now heads an association of industrial enterprises. "People are demanding order. But that order should be established by forces elected by the people, by constitutional methods."
Along with their endangered democracy, Soviet citizens today recovered their sense of humor, and across the capital Muscovites shared the same relieved joke: "We knew the Communists couldn't do anything right."
The gibe seemed the perfect epitaph for that Communist machine that once knew how to impose its will on neighboring countries with ruthless efficiency, but now could not manage the hijacking of its own Government.
 
From Boor to Statesman
 The obvious winner, of course, is Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic, who rallied the public and kept his elected Government functioning by displaying strength and grace under pressure.
Besides enhancing his authority at home, Mr. Yeltsin at last won the international recognition long denied him.
Mr. Yeltsin, not long ago regarded as a troublesome boor in Washington and European capitals, fielded phone calls from President Bush, Prime Minister John Major of Britain, President Francois Mitterrand of France and other world leaders -- and made the most of this new stature in backing down the coup-masters.
His enhanced stature also strengthens the democrats in other republics, including the beleaguered Baltic states, whose sovereignty Mr. Yeltsin has unflaggingly supported along with Russia's.
Mr. Gorbachev emerges from his three-day captivity in a more ambiguous and shaky position.
The overt show of disloyalty has given him his best chance to purge the nettlesome reactionaries from his Government and extend reforms more forcefully into the military, the K.G.B. and the Interior Ministry, whose leaders all joined the conspiracy.
But his ability to govern is now more than ever dependent on the support of Mr. Yeltsin.
 
Wariness Toward Gorbachev
 In the West, the dramatic demonstration of Mr. Gorbachev's vulnerability, and the sense that the coup was a product of the Soviet leader's own indecisiveness, is likely to create a new wariness toward the hero of perestroika.
At home, the Soviet President will not be welcomed back as a martyr, but interrogated as a man with a lot of questions to answer. After all, he picked the men who tried to overthrow him, and disregarded repeated warnings of danger from close allies. Some liberals continued to speculate that he acquiesced in the coup -- a charge his spokesman, Vitaly Ignatenko, today fiercely denied -- or at very least was a fool for keeping his trust in the Communists.
At the Russian Parliament building today, a policeman standing guard summed up a common sentiment: "Gorbachev's problem all along was that he trusted the wrong people. He never had any trust in us."
Perhaps the first fundamental misjudgment of the men who led the feckless putsch was to think they could win over the public by disguising themselves as guardians of constitutional order.
The plotters' strategy has not been disclosed, but it appears that they hoped to keep the coup comparatively bloodless, and to give their declared state of emergency a legal gloss by winning approval of the Soviet Parliament next week.
They apparently devoted much effort to winning over centrists, such as the wily chairman of Parliament, Anatoly I. Lukyanov, a Gorbachev law school classmate who at first seemed inclined to go along with the conspirators.
The day after placing Mr. Gorbachev under house arrest, the self-proclaimed new leadership summoned the world press to a news conference as if convinced that their new order would meet with acceptance.
It is an open but intriguing question whether the takeover would have succeeded had it been accompanied by an act of brute force -- like the Chinese massacre of students in Tiananmen Square -- that might have terrorized the public into submission.
 
Why Wasn't Yeltsin Arrested?
 Indeed, the removal of Mr. Gorbachev, the shutdown of the independent news media and the initial parade of tanks into Moscow did inspire a wave of fear and confusion that held the city for the first day.
Why, for example, did the military and K.G.B. not move quickly to arrest Mr. Yeltsin and other potential resisters, before Muscovites had rallied to their defense?
"You have to consider that this circle of people came to the leadership in Gorbachev's time," replied Nikolai N. Vorontsov, the Soviet Minister of Environment and the only non-Communist in the Gorbachev Cabinet. "Maybe they understand that in 1991 you cannot behave the way you could in 1964, when the coup was conducted against Khrushchev."
One sign that a more brutal coup might have worked was the cautious reaction of centrist politicians, including Mr. Lukyanov, who played along, and the leaders of two key republics, the Ukraine and Kazakhstan, who withheld their public condemnation.
 
Conspirators Dawdled
 John Hewko, a Ukrainian-American who watched President Leonid I. Kravchuk of the Ukraine waffle for two days over how to respond to the putsch, said he was convinced that if the junta had moved more decisively, "Kravchuk would probably have gone along with the state of emergency."
Instead the conspirators dawdled, sending their tanks in aimless circles around Moscow. By Tuesday night Mr. Kravchuk worked up the courage to announce that he would not recognize the legality of the self-styled emergency committee, and this morning he warned Moscow that any show of force against his republic would be met in kind.
The coup was hampered, according to both liberals and hard-liners, by the personalities of the men who led it, uncharismatic apparatchiks closely identified with the legacy of Communist centralism.
"They couldn't even find a few quasi-democrats to dress up the list," Mr. Yeltsin said.
Even the devout law-and-order faction in the Soviet Communist Party -- called Soyuz, meaning Union -- could not bring itself to endorse the state of emergency in a meeting Tuesday night.
 
Even a Hard-liner Had Doubts
 Col. Viktor I. Alksnis, a Latvian hard-liner who has long advocated a state of emergency, said the group was divided over the blatant illegality of the conspiracy and the lackluster caliber of its leaders.
"We have argued that such an emergency committee should be created, but by constitutional methods, with the approval of the highest constitutional authority, the Congress of People's Deputies," he said, adding that the hard-line legislators were put off by "the group's complete lack of public credibility."
"When I first heard of it Monday, my personal reaction was positive," Colonel Alksnis conceded. "But as soon as I saw that it was constructed of decrees, all on paper, I quickly became disappointed. They displayed military incompetence, inconsistency, a lack of concrete actions."
The conspirators also gravely underrated the strength of the democratically elected officials, especially Mr. Yeltsin. From the moment on Monday morning when he strode confidently from his office into the crowd and delivered his denunciation of the coup atop a tank, Mr. Yeltsin never flinched. He heaped withering scorn on the eight men he referred to as "the junta."
 
Even the Name Was Ridiculed
 In the speeches of Mr. Yeltsin and his deputies, even the name of the State Committee for the State of Emergency was transformed into an object of public ridicule, since the Russian initials -- G.K.Ch.P. -- resemble the sound of a cat choking on a hairball.
"They underestimated the resolution of the Soviet people not to live the way they had lived for 70 years," said Oleg Kalugin, a renegade K.G.B. agent and liberal deputy in the Russian Parliament. "They simply did not know the mood of the people. That was their major miscalculation."
The public response to the coup was far less impressive than earlier anti-Communist uprisings in Eastern Europe, or even in tiny Lithuania, where at moments of danger it has sometimes seemed the entire population was in the streets.
Much of the public seemed intimidated, resigned, or even indifferent.
But by Tuesday Mr. Yeltsin's headquarters was surrounded by a protective crowd numbering in the tens of thousands. Almost by force of his own determination, Mr. Yeltsin amplified this group into a valiant defense, until it may have seemed just that to the plotters.
By Tuesday the coup showed signs of unraveling. State television and the official Tass news agency, which at first served as the mouthpieces of the emergency committee, began airing Mr. Yeltsin's side. Army units and officers began deserting the junta to defend Mr. Yeltsin.
And tonight, Mr. Yeltsin and his deputies were back on television, describing the week's events as the last gasp of the Communist beast.
Perhaps by then the conspirators were wondering if they had deposed the wrong president.

Markets
World financial markets did an about-face, rallying strongly as word spread from the Soviet Union that the coup had collapsed. In Europe, stock and bond markets rallied, but did not regain all the lost ground, in part because they closed too early. [D1.] 
 In the U.S., stocks more than recovered the ground lost Monday, as the Dow skyrocketed 88.10, to 3,001.79. It was the biggest rise since Jan. 17 and the sixth-largest point gain ever. [D8.]
Short-term interest rates went back up as quickly as they had fallen earlier in the week. [D16.]
The dollar plunged against most currencies as it returned to more normal levels after the failed Soviet coup. [D17.] Grain and soybean futures prices soared. [D17.]
The volume of open short sales rose on the New York Stock Exchange to the highest level since March. [D6.]
 
Companies
Salomon Brothers suffered several new blows as more clients suspended business with the firm, and a state treasury said it would stop buying short-term debt the firm issues to finance itself. [D1.] Salomon has become even more prominent in the corporate bond market. [D4.]
Continental Airlines ousted its chairman, Hollis L. Harris, and another executive in a management shake-up that the company said it hoped would speed its recovery. [D1.]

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP: MAN IN THE NEWS;
Enigmatic Commander: Mikhail Alekseyevich Moiseyev

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev, identified by Soviet television today as the acting head of the armed forces, has supported arms control agreements with the United States but in many ways remains an enigma to American officials.
General Moiseyev, the Soviet Chief of Staff, may have been lucky to be on vacation far from Moscow when hard-liners staged their ill-fated coup three days ago, according to American officials. They also suggested that he might have planned to be away to avoid being blamed if the coup failed. 
 As Chief of Staff, he was in a position to order troops into the fray or to refuse to take part in the attempt to overthrow President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. American analysts are not sure which side he took, if any, although some surmise that had he been in Moscow, he would have had to support his political patron, Gen. Dmitri T. Yazov, who was Defense Minister as the coup began and one of eight members of the junta.
It was not clear today whether Mr. Gorbachev, in the hours after regaining power, approved the elevation of General Moiseyev, who appears to have assumed control of the armed forces at some point during the coup.
 
Exchanges With Americans
 General Moiseyev has taken part in various exchanges with top American military officers and Administration officials in Washington and Moscow in the last two years. Western analysts believe that his strong support for the recently signed conventional forces treaty, providing for deep reductions in non-nuclear forces in Europe, helped Mr. Gorbachev overcome the potential hurdle of army opposition. But they also say that when Mr. Gorbachev was trying to cut military spending, he made speeches criticizing the Government for providing insufficient services and housing to officers and enlisted soldiers.
"I don't think he's apolitical, but he is not a far right-wing conservative either," said Stephen Meyer, a political scientist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology who studies the Soviet military.
A Pentagon analyst said General Moiseyev and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, had developed "a friendly, pleasant relationship" during several meetings in the United States and the Soviet Union that included a casual evening at the Moscow Circus last month. But he added: "I don't know how they would relate now. We don't know how he was involved in this mess."
In an article General Moiseyev wrote for Izvestia, the Government newspaper, on April 6, he bemoaned the fall of the Warsaw Pact and warned starkly that the Soviet Union now "remains alone against NATO without allies." Still, he argued that Moscow was justified in reducing military spending to "raise the Soviet people's living and everyday conditions."
 
Joined Party in 1962
 Born in 1939 into a working class family in the rural district of Amur in southeast Siberia and a graduate of a tank school in Soviet Asia, Mikhail Alekseyevich Moiseyev (pronounced moy-SAY-yeff) became a member of the Communist Party in 1962 and rose through the army ranks by attaching his star to successful senior officers. He married a Russian literature teacher, Galina, and they have one daughter.
His career progressed quickly when he served as General Yazov's deputy commander in the Far East Military District. When General Yazov was named Defense Minister in May 1987, General Moiseyev became the commander of the district. General Yazov eventually eased out Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev as Chief of Staff and replaced him with his loyal deputy in December 1988.
According to a United States Government biographical sketch of General Moiseyev, he is intelligent and cordial and relies heavily on his staff.
He is reportedly shy among foreigners, although he attended Fourth of July festivities at the American Embassy in Moscow last year.
 
His Stand on Gulf War
 But he publicly took a position at variance with Washington regarding the circumstances under which military force could be used against Iraq in the months leading up to the American-led assault in the Persian Gulf. He argued that economic sanctions against Iraq would have succeeded, a position he continued to promote even after the war.
Administration analysts are reviewing their intelligence reporting to evaluate what role General Moiseyev might have played in the planning of the coup. One official said that Soviet military communications were sometimes unsophisticated and that it was possible he remained uninformed during the initial stages of the coup.
"We don't know what he has been doing the last few days," a Pentagon official said. "He has been notably absent from public view. He hasn't made any statements."
The official said it was not even known who put General Moiseyev in charge of the military, assuming Soviet television reports are correct.

AFTER THE COUP A10-18
The Soviet coup abruptly collapsed, and President Gorbachev returned to Moscow to reassert control. The coup seemed simply to fizzle under the disdain of the masses who rallied to the summons of Boris Yeltsin, and the irresolution of the plotters, who failed to garner support. Page A1

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP: GERMANY;
Holding Back Aid Is 'Foolish Policy

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Germany responded to the return of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev with renewed appeals for Western nations to increase their aid to the Soviet Union.
"The most foolish possible policy now," Chancellor Helmut Kohl told a television audience, "would be for us simply to sit back as interested onlookers and say, 'So, what are they up to in Moscow?' " 
 For the last two years, German officials have warned that without large-scale Western aid, the Soviet Union would remain unstable and perhaps slide toward chaos.
Up to now, most recently at last month's economic summit in London, most Western governments, led by the United States, have been markedly less enthusiastic about extending asssitance on the scale that Germany said was necessary. In the wake of this week's events, however, officials in Bonn say their warnings have even more credence.
The Economics Minister, Jurgen Mollemann, said today that it was now urgent for the West "to give the Soviet Union more and faster help."
Another of Mr. Kohl's senior advisers, Rudolf Seiters, said that the courage with which Soviet citizens stood up against the attempted coup "gives them a right to a major aid program."
Such comments suggest that Germany is preparing to renew its campaign for large-scale Western aid to Mr. Gorbachev's Government. Chancellor Kohl had effectively given it up as hopeless, at least for the time being.
Mr. Kohl and his aides have argued that with a large infusion of Western help over the next few years, the Soviet Union can make the transition to a market economy and become a productive member of the world economic community.
Political leaders in the United States and some other Western countries have rejected that view as naive. They say that the Soviet Union is not ready to absorb large amounts of aid, and that Mr. Gorbachev has not shown true commitment to the idea of free markets.
It has been the first major difference of opinion between Bonn and Washington since German unification last year.
As soon as news of the coup was received on Monday, senior German officials began blaming it partly on the West's refusal to send more aid to Moscow.
The Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, while not mentioning the United States specifically, lamented that more countries had not supported Mr. Gorbachev "with deeds as well as with words, the way Germany did within the limits of its possibilities."
News of the coup's failure was greeted with special relief here. Germans fear that further upheaval in the Soviet Union could have dire consequences for them. Under some worst-case scenarios, large numbers of Soviet refugees could flood toward Germany, and Soviet troops stationed here could defect by the thousand.
Prominent politicians hailed today's turn of events as a victory for freedom over oppression. Many praised Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian federated republic, and officials said that Mr. Yeltsin may visit Germany soon.
German markets were closing as the news of Mr. Gorbachev's likely return flashed across news wires. There was a late rally.
The German government has been encouraging private businesses to invest in the Soviet Union, and has guaranteed billions of dollars worth of investments there.
On Monday, the day of the coup, fears for the value of those investments surged, and the German stock market suffered its largest one-day loss since 1989.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP: THE NEXT CHAPTER;
Bush Must Reassess U.S.-Soviet Relations

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The collapse of the Soviet coup, a breathtakingly rapid realization of what had seemed but a frail hope to the Bush Administration only 48 hours earlier, will require a comprehensive recalibration of American policy toward Moscow. It will confront President Bush with major challenges, even as he savors a personal victory and a triumph for democracy.
It also constitutes one of the most vivid demonstrations to date of the power of global communications to help shape contemporary history. 
 If the anti-totalitarian forces prevailed in part because of ineptitude on the part of the coup plotters, they were also aided by a vast constituency, assembled electronically inside the Soviet Union and outside it, that reached quick agreement that the coup should be resisted. Mr. Bush, Prime Minister John Major of Britain and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, whose position was ticklish because of the Soviet troops that remain on German soil, made the weight of their wealthy nations felt inside the Kremlin within hours.
That was reinforced by the image of Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian republic's president, spouting defiance from the top of a Soviet tank, like Lenin brandishing a fist at the barricades in a Soviet realist painting -- one of those emblematic moments that television can burn into the world's consciousness.
In addition, modern communications obviously played a major part over the last six years in planting the seeds of democracy, much more deeply than many had thought possible before this week, in the hitherto stony soil of Russia, with its thousand-year history of tyranny. When the test came, Soviet citizens in the hundreds of thousands willingly exposed themselves to danger to defend abstract ideals that many had learned of by radio and television.
The political panorama of Moscow was changed beyond recognition from the one Mikhail S. Gorbachev left earlier this month to go on vacation, and what the United States and its allies do now will have to reflect the new realities.
Will Washington cling to its policy of betting on Mr. Gorbachev as the best hope for democracy, or put its money on the triumphant leader of the counter-coup? Will it keep working to keep the Soviet Union united, or will it back the Baltic republics in their drives for independence? Will it see this as the moment when large-scale foreign aid can help entrench democracy, or will it continue to hold back pending comprehensive reform?
One thing is clear: President Bush will have a relatively free hand to do what he thinks best; in domestic political terms he has scored yet another foreign-policy triumph, having insisted upon and worked toward a turnaround in Moscow when skeptics thought him foolish. He looks more invulnerable than ever as the 1992 campaign approaches, and there was a certain symmetry in the fact that a potential Democratic challenger, Sen. Al Gore of Tennessee, chose today for his announcement that he would not be running for President.
 
Yeltsin Seen as Dominant Figure
 Although Mr. Bush, with his characteristic caution, spoke of Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin almost as partners for the months to come, politicians and experts here believe Mr. Yeltsin is now the dominant figure as the result of his dramatic stand against the tanks of the now-dissolved junta.
"It is clear that the Gorbachev era is over and the Yeltsin era has begun," said Representative Dave McCurdy, the Oklahoma Democrat who serves as chairman of the House Select Committee on Intelligence. Others, including Madeleine Albright and Robert Legvold, two leading experts in Soviet affairs, suggested that Mr. Gorbachev might have an important if diminished role as a transitional figure until national elections next year, or as a federal leader responsible for foreign affairs, or as a symbol of national unity.
Much depends on the shape of the new Soviet Union, and it seems evident that the failed coup -- "the last hurrah of the apparatchiks," as Jack Matlock, former American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, called it -- has accelerated rather than slowed one of the trends the hard-liners hoped to halt, that of ever-shrinking central power and ever-increasing autonomy for the republics. Mr. Yeltsin will presumably be strengthened by that, as the leader of the most important republic, a senior State Department official said.
Mr. Bush at first shrank from Mr. Yeltsin, believing that to embrace him would hurt Mr. Gorbachev. Although he moved closer after the burly Russian was elected President of the republic this spring, the White House still dragged its feet in arranging Mr. Yeltsin's visit to Washington, which was sponsored by Congressional leaders headed by Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas. Congressional officials who coordinated the trip said Mr. Bush adamantly refused to send any ranking official to the airport to greet the visitor.
 
Russian Earns Devoted Following
 In his comments today, Mr. Bush lavishly praised Mr. Yeltsin for his courage, saying he now had "a well-earned stature around the world that he might not have had," and the Russian leader has also earned himself a devoted following in other corners of Washington. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, urged much stronger United States support for the Russian president, with the comment, "If we can't help a man like that, what did we fight the cold war for?"
President Bush is likely to face renewed pressure from the supporters of Baltic independence in the wake of the coup's collapse. He and his advisers have argued in the past that backing the Baltic republics would endanger the relationship of the United States and Mr. Gorbachev; that contention will carry much less weight now that Mr. Gorbachev's right-wing foes are in flight and he has been rescued, in effect, by those who back self-determination.
Mr. Bush may yield some ground on that front. But he is highly likely to resist the suggestion, advanced today by many in Washington, that now is the time to increase exponentially Western aid to the Soviet Union. He insisted at the economic conference in London this summer that reform must go much further before aid would really help, and he is likely, despite the euphoria of the moment, to adhere to that position as the Soviets renew their struggle to reshape their national economy.
 
Baker Urges Reforms
 In Brussels today, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d pooh-poohed the idea of a major policy re-evaluation. He urged "fundamental free-market reforms" and added, "You're not going to see the Soviet Union succeed economically through the mechanism of free check-writing on the part of others."
Robert Blackwill, a former White House aide, now at Harvard University, said the first step should be to ascertain "whether Gorbachev's three-day sojourn in captivity has made him a free marketeer." If it has and reform flows quickly, Mr. Blackwill said, "then the West ought to engage big-time, but not before then, and not simply on the basis of this stupendous, thrilling moment."
The Europeans opposed Mr. Bush's stand in London, where Mr. Gorbachev appeared to appeal for more direct aid, and they may be ready to renew the battle now. The French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, suggested that the West may have missed a chance to avoid a coup by inaction at London and must now "examine its conscience."

HEADLINE: Dow Soars In Rebound Of Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
World financial markets did an about-face yesterday, rallying strongly as word spread from the Soviet Union that Monday's coup had collapsed and that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would be restored to power.
In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 88.10 points, up 3 percent, to close at 3,001.79, the largest one-day rise since the beginning of the allied bombing of Iraq in January. Together with Tuesday's 15-point rise, this surge more than wiped out Monday's 69-point plunge. [Page D8.] 
 In Europe, stock and bond markets also rallied, although leading markets did not regain all that was lost in the sometimes panicky reaction on Monday. But that was in part because these markets closed before the full extent of the Soviet turnabout was known.
Several analysts said the rallies should continue today. Indeed, in Tokyo early today, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks gained 464.17 points, or 2.1 percent, to close at 22,515.77.
 
A Sigh of Relief
 The dollar fell sharply yesterday as the threat of chaos in the Soviet Union eased and investors who had fled to the haven of the American currency took their money back home. Against the German mark, the dollar ended down 3.2 percent and below where it was before the coup. The yields on Treasury bills rose sharply for the same reason. [Pages D17 and D16.]
There was an almost audible sigh of relief in the markets at the sudden turn of events, which many called the Yeltsin Rally, after Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, who stood up to the coup leaders.
On Monday, analysts were wondering how far-reaching the impact of the coup would be and whether it could trip up economic recoveries in the United States and elsewhere.
But yesterday, John Lipsky of Salomon Brothers in London, said "never mind," echoing the famous refrain of Gilda Radner as Emily Litella on "Saturday Night Live." David Roche of Morgan Stanley, who had interrupted his vacation Monday to return to work, said he now would resume his holiday.
Mr. Lipsky and Mr. Roche said that the reversal of the coup would not just mean a return to the status quo, but that the outlook for the Soviet Union should be a little more optimistc because economic reform should move more quickly now.
In addition, they said, the lessening of further threats of political trouble in the Soviet Union makes the outlook brighter for the German stock market.
Analysts also reversed their feelings that the coup and its financial fallout would lead to a lowering of worldwide interest rates as part of an effort to contain any economic crisis. "The bias toward interest rates is more or less gone," said Kit Juckes, international economist for S. G. Warburg in London.
The rally actually began to take shape late Tuesday as markets stabilized and there were signs that the coup leaders were having problems.
When stock trading began yesterday in Tokyo, there was both positive and negative news: Three opponents to the coup had been reported killed in a clash with the military while unconfirmed reports said several leaders of the coup had been replaced or fallen ill. The Nikkei index gained 364.54 points yesterday, to 22,051.60, after rising 230.30 on Tuesday. With today's gain, the Nikkei has recovered 78 percent of the 1,357.61 loss that it suffered on Monday.
In Germany, where the impact of the coup was the strongest because of the huge numbers of Soviet troops stationed in the country's east, the DAX index of 30 leading shares rose 43.89 points, or 2.9 percent, to 1,570.82, after climbing 29 points on Tuesday. But the market is still 82.55 points, or 5.3 percent, below where it was last Friday. Mr. Roche said the rally should continue today as long as the positive news does not change.
The markets in Britain, France, Norway and Sweden, however, came closer to making up the losses caused by the coup. In Britain, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 shares rose 47.4 points, to 2,601.9, 19.1 points short of the pre-coup level. In Norway, the All Share index rose 17.23, to 510.44, just 10.18 points short. And in Sweden, the Affarsvarlden index rose 31.70 points, to 1,084.70, just 19.1 points below last Friday's close.
In the foreign exchange market, trading since Monday has been a rough up-and-down ride. Traders like volatility because it is an opportunity to make money. But the dollar's 3.4 percent move up on Monday, followed by the 3.2 percent drop yesterday, are also opportunties for traders to get caught in the wrong -- and losing -- position.
By the end of trading in New York yesterday, the dollar was at 1.7408 German marks, down from 1.7985 Tuesday and 1.8245 Monday. At that level, the dollar was lower against the mark than before the coup. But that is not unusual, since moves in the currrency market tend to be exaggerated.

HEADLINE: New Troubles for Salomon: Suits Grow, Clients Defect

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Salomon Brothers Inc. suffered several new blows yesterday in the growing Treasury markets scandal, as more clients suspended doing business with the firm, a state treasury announced it would stop buying the short-term debt the firm issues to finance itself, and more investors queued up to sue the firm.
The World Bank, one of the most valuable and blue-chip customers in the securities industry, also announced yesterday that it was suspending all business activities with Salomon through Sept. 30. 
 The action by the World Bank appeared to be a signal to Wall Street that the international lending agency would only deal with firms whose ethical standards were beyond question. In a communication to Salomon, released by the firm, the World Bank said that "if our Sept. 30 review indicates that you once again meet the high standards we set for our financial partners, we would expect to resume our normal business relationship."
The loss of business with the World Bank, whose global bond issues Salomon helped manage for the last several years, was the most stinging rebuke from a client of the firm since the Treasury markets scandal unfolded. The change in Salomon, which had a reputation for arrogance before the scandal, was visible in the firm's unusual apology to the bank.
"Salomon Brothers would like to apologize to the World Bank and its member governments for any embarrassment caused by our actions," the firm said in a statement.
Other customers also stopped important business. California officials, who the day before suspended trading with the firm's Government bond desk, said they would discontinue buying the firm's short-term commercial paper. The California treasury owns $230 million in Salomon commercial paper and will not renew those investments when they mature. Despite that decision, California said it would go ahead with a $602 million issue of taxable bonds that Salomon will co-manage with Goldman, Sachs.
The market's confidence has been shaken, Kathleen Brown, the California State Treasurer, said. "California must take every step to insure the safety of the fund," she added. But state officials said the decision to stop making short-term investments in Salomon's commercial paper did not have any bearing on the bond issue that Salomon helped underwrite because the firm was part of the group that submitted the best bid.
The move by California was the only public indication that any of the firm's sources of funds were being affected. Brokerage firms like Salomon are heavily dependent on being able to borrow huge sums of money cheaply to finance their inventories of securities, and they borrow from banks and other institutions and by selling their own securities, including commercial paper.
Salomon had previously said it had other financial options, including backup lines of credit from banks, to continue financing its operations.
In addition, two Massachusetts state pension funds also suspended their relationships with Salomon. The Massachusetts State Teachers and Employee Retirement Fund, and the Pension Reserve Investment Trust will halt doing business with the firm, the State Treasurer, Joseph Mallone, said, until he was assured that the firm had put controls in place to prevent more violations of the law.
As current clients suspended their business, some former customers brought new actions against the firm. In one of the suits filed against Salomon yesterday, the buyers of preferred securities that Salomon issued for itself in June said they had been defrauded.
That lawsuit, filed by Fred and Rita Schwartz in Federal District Court in Manhattan, charges that the June prospectus for the $100 million worth of preferred securities failed to disclose that the senior management of Salomon, including John H. Gutfreund, who resigned Sunday as chairman and chief executive, had been told two months earlier about illegal bidding on the investment house's Government securities desk. The suit said the misleading information kept the price of the securities above where it would have otherwise been.
The Schwartzes bought 400 of the 4.25 million depository preferred shares issued in that offering at $25 each. The complaint asks that it be granted class-action status.
 
Preferred Shares Fall
 The preferred shares fell $1.25 yesterday, to $22.75, in New York Stock Exchange trading. Since they were sold, they have traded as high as $25.875, and as low as $22.625 -- a low that was reached during yesterday's trading.
In the second suit filed in Federal court in Manhattan yesterday, a purchaser of $200,000 of two-year Treasury notes on May 22, said the price he had paid for the notes was inflated because of Salomon's misconduct.
The troubles for Salomon from civil litigation are not over, lawyers said. Robert N. Kaplan, a lawyer for the Schwartzes, said the complaint filed yesterday was going to become part of a broader complaint that he is working on with other lawyers.
In a sign of the significance the investigation has gained in Washington, William McLucas, the director of the enforcement division for the Securities and Exchange Commission, has decided to conduct the inquiry of Salomon personally, people involved in the case said. Mr. McLucas is said to have made a point of telling others in the case that he is handling the details of the Salomon inquiry himself, these sources said.
The widening investigation has brought a mini-boom to securities lawyers, who have been hired by the dozens of securities firms and Wall Street executives who have been contacted in the Government inquiry. "This is the full employment act for Wall Street lawyers," one securities lawyer involved in the case said yesterday.
 
Names Begin to Come Out
 New information about the illegal bidding scandal also emerged yesterday, as one of the firm's clients whose name was improperly used by former Salomon traders in its illegal bidding in several Treasury auctions stepped forward.
Mercury Asset Management, the largest pension fund manager in Britain, said yesterday that its name had been submitted on bids at two Treasury auctions, the four-year note auction in December and the five-year note auction in February, by former Salomon employees without authorization. Mercury said it was providing information to the American authorities.
In a statement, Salomon confirmed that Mercury's name had been used in the bidding. "We deeply regret this clear violation of a valued customer relationship and the new management of Salomon Brothers has already take steps to insure that it will not happen again," the firm said.
Salomon executives, meanwhile, are scrambling to reassure clients of the firm's integrity and to try to hold business. Among the clients they were visiting was British Telecom. The company had chosen Salomon earlier this month to underwrite its $8.5 billion offering.

HEADLINE: Now, Finish the Revolution;
What Mr. Gorbachev Owes His Defenders

 BODY:
The global village sighed with relief yesterday morning just as suddenly as it had gasped with shock Sunday night. People around the world who still find it hard to believe that the Persian Gulf war ended in 100 hours are gratefully incredulous that a power grab in the Soviet Union could be undone at all, let alone in 60 hours.
How could it happen? President Bush gave one explanation at his morning news conference yesterday when Peter Maer of Mutual-NBC Radio asked what message he had for Mikhail Gorbachev. "Stay with your principles, stay with your reforms," the President said -- and "stand shoulder to shoulder" with Boris Yeltsin, the president of Russia. 
 The Soviet people did all that this week, standing shoulder to shoulder against this last ominous outburst from old gray neoconservatives. If there was any doubt that new winds are sweeping across the Soviet Union, they are erased by this thrilling triumph for freedom.
Americans know that Mr. Gorbachev stirred those winds. The New York Times/CBS News Poll shows that his standing in this country has leaped to 66 percent popularity, almost up to Mr. Bush's 73 percent.
Americans also know how bravely Mr. Yeltsin stood for reform. With his neck at risk, he faced down tanks and kept open lines of communication to the world. "Clouds of terror and dictatorship are gathering over Russia, but this night will not be eternal," he said to wavering troops. His example emboldened leaders and citizens alike.
But with full respect for Mikhail Gorbachev's vision and Boris Yeltsin's courage, the larger lesson of the coup is not heroism. This triumph, if it is to last, cannot turn merely on electric personalities. It will have to become a triumph of dull -- dependable -- democratic process.
The coup plotters contended they were saving the system from chaos. Instead, in their desperation, they ended up destroying the old Soviet order. By the end, even the Communist Party renounced any connection to these old party stalwarts.
The plotters' rout shows how thoroughly the Gorbachev revolution has transformed the Soviet Union. Republic leaders like Kazakhstan's Nursultan Nazarbayev and the Ukraine's Leonid Kravchuk hesitated, then rallied to Mr. Yeltsin's side. And ordinary citizens overcame fear and fatalism to stand up for the rule of law and radical reform.
The early mottoes of the Gorbachev era were glasnost, openness; perestroika, reform; and a third, soon sunk by ridicule, uskoreniye, acceleration. Now the time for uskoreniye has truly arrived. The return of Mr. Gorbachev to the Soviet presidency will not in itself be sufficient.
The collapse of the coup betokens a transforming change in political power. The Soviet President will now be freed from dead hands of the past that have pulled him right, at times hard right. Now he is not only freer to pursue reform; he owes it to his brave reformist defenders to do so.
Accelerating radical reform is the best protection against further upheavals. The obvious starting point is the new Union treaty whose scheduled signing Tuesday probably incited the plotters.
The treaty does much more than regularize relations between Moscow and the various Soviet republics. It provides, among other things, for the early popular election of the next Soviet president. And by breaking the stranglehold of the central apparatus, it would open the way for economic reforms needed to justify important Western aid.
Other countries so far shrink from pouring billions into a black hole in which the word "market," let alone the fact, is barely understood. But they might gladly encourage investment and assistance if there were a credible Soviet economic program. So far, when presented with plausible programs, Mr. Gorbachev has repeatedly shied away at the last minute.
If he will now embrace such a program, this misbegotten mess of a coup can yet have a highly constructive legacy. The old guard's self-destruction can make it possible for him -- and future Soviet presidents -- to give the Soviet people the standard of living and of life that they stood up for this week. That process can start today.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Our Unemployment System Needs Reworking

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To a Florida Congressman, the recession might be about to end, but an out-of-work New Yorker pounding the pavement in search of a job has a very different perception ("Let Unemployment Benefits Run Out," Op-Ed, Aug. 6). E. Clay Shaw Jr.'s Pollyanna view of a rebounding economy underscores a fundamental flaw in the unemployment insurance system, and he even points out -- unintentionally -- why it needs to be reformed: all recessions are not equal, especially region by region. 
 Business may be on the upswing in Florida, but New York City's recession is deeply entrenched, and prospects for a turnaround are bleak. Unofficially, about 28 percent of the city's 4.2 million potential work force is out of work. Mr. Shaw suggests these job seekers turn to "productive industries," but the metropolitan area lost more than 100,000 private-sector jobs last year and is expected to lose about 180,000 more public- and private-sector jobs through 1992. With recovery lagging behind the rest of the country, there are almost no growth industries and few jobs for laid-off workers.
Meanwhile, 42,463 city residents exhausted their 26 weeks of unemployment insurance in the first four months of 1991 alone. By year's end their numbers will tally 150,000. For many, welfare and even homelessness are just around the corner.
There are deeper concerns about the viability of the country's unemployment insurance system, which has been deteriorating steadily since 1975, when benefits were available for up to 65 weeks. Then, 70 percent of all workers were covered by the system, compared with 37 percent now, largely because of the trend toward part-time and temporary jobs.
Since extended benefits are triggered by a figure based on the number of jobs in the unemployment insurance system, the official unemployment rate has to be extremely high before additional benefits are given. Official unemployment would have to reach 11 percent in New York State to get additional help for beleaguered New York City, where rates are edging close to 9 percent.
The method for triggering additional benefits has to be revamped to reflect real unemployment levels, and there should be a method to allow extended benefits to regions that are especially hard hit by unemployment.
But an emergency extension is not enough: the entire unemployment system needs reworking, and New Yorkers should hold Congress to its promise to scrutinize and fix the system this fall.
 
JOSEPHINE NIEVES
Commissioner of Employment
New York, Aug. 8, 1991

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
Bush Looks Ahead to Accelerated Soviet Reforms and Greater Stature for Yeltsin

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 21

 BODY:
Declaring today a "very fine day" for democracy, President Bush began looking ahead to a changed Soviet Union in which he expects democratic reform to leap forward and President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic to enjoy an "enormous" new stature in his own country and around the world.
Recounting his 12-minute conversation with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, which he said had begun at 12:19 P.M. Eastern time, Mr. Bush said, "In his view the constitutional authorities are back in power and democracy and freedom have prevailed." 
 The President, who looked tired after monitoring the unsuccessful coup in the Soviet Union, which had interrupted his vacation, added: "He stated his sincere appreciation to the people of the United States and others around the world for their support for democracy and freedom. He sounded in good physical condition. Indeed, his voice was buoyant."
 
Delighted at the Outcome
 Mr. Bush, who has always been careful to observe diplomatic protocol with the other members of the club of world leaders he has assembled while in office, emphasized that his official dealings would continue to be with Mr. Gorbachev. He said the Soviet President "has certainly not been diminished by this at all."
"He will still be a force to be reckoned with," Mr. Bush told a group of reporters whom he called to his Walkers Point vacation home for his second news conference in less than two and a half hours. It capped a tumultuous day that began with restrained optimism after a phone call to Mr. Yeltsin and later included expressions of the President's "delight."
Before heading off for an afternoon round of golf in a chill drizzle, Mr. Bush reminded reporters of his "respect for Gorbachev."
Looking ahead, Mr. Bush said the vanquishing of the coup should change attitudes in the Soviet Union and abroad about the longevity of the reforms Mr. Gorbachev has undertaken. "What will be filtered out will be the fear of a right-wing military takeover, because the people will see that the power of the people to stand up against this illegality is pretty good, pretty strong," Mr. Bush said.
He also signaled that he might be more inclined to consider greater financial aid to Moscow in light of the events of the last few days. And his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said he believed that the vanquishing of the coup might also bolster public support for economic assistance to the Soviet Union and make American companies more willing to invest in that country.
 
Yeltsin's Gain in Stature
 But as Mr. Gorbachev prepared to return to the Kremlin, Mr. Bush said that Mr. Yeltsin "will have a well-earned stature around the world that he might not have had -- that he was on his way to having but might not have fully achieved before all this happened."
With Soviet power back in the hands of a constitutional authority and the risks that Mr. Bush took in backing Mr. Yeltsin seeming to be paying off, the President and his aides were free to begin pondering what one senior official said would be "inevitable changes" in the relations between Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin and between Moscow and Washington in general.
Mr. Bush seemed to be addressing this in his conversations today with the two Soviet officials. Mr. Bush said he had told Mr. Gorbachev, "as I've told Yeltsin, that we're ready to talk to the leaders of the republics and certainly we'll be ready to talk and deal with the President of the Soviet Union itself."
While American officials said it was too early to draw sweeping conclusions, they suggested that the end of the coup could accelerate progress toward free-market policies, cement the Soviet Union's democratic reforms and radically alter the equation in the negotiations between Moscow and its constituent republics.
An Administration official said the United States would have to walk a delicate line while Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Gorbachev sort out their own relationship.
 
'A Very Courageous Individual'
 But Mr. Bush's admiration of Mr. Yeltsin was vividly apparent today. He referred to "President Yeltsin" repeatedly, and White House aides said Mr. Bush had been deeply affected by the televised scenes of Mr. Yeltsin's mounting a tank in Moscow to hurl his defiance at the Kremlin junta that seized power for three days.
"It leaves the world looking at him as a very courageous individual, duly elected by the people, standing firmly and courageously for democracy and freedom with enormous stature as a result of that," he said.
Even Mr. Bush's response to a reporter who asked -- before Mr. Bush was able to speak to Mr. Gorbachev -- what message he would send to the Soviet President offered a subtle indication of the way the image of Mr. Yeltsin has changed in Mr. Bush's mind.
Mr. Bush said: "I would say: 'Stay with your principles. Stay with your reforms. Stay with your commitment to democratic process and constitutional law. Stand shoulder to shoulder with Yeltsin, as you have been, in seeing the evolution of democracy and perestroika and glasnost in the Soviet Union.' "
Mr. Bush said he was confident that there would not be a "Gorbachev-versus-Yeltsin battle" for power in the aftermath of the failed coup. "I think he is properly and with feeling expressing himself in total support of Mr. Gorbachev," Mr. Bush said.
A senior Administration official said Mr. Bush's attitude toward Mr. Yeltsin had undergone "a fairly steady evolution ever since his first, ill-fated visit" to the United States in 1989, when Mr. Bush refused to receive Mr. Yeltsin formally. White House aides recounted with some disdain the way Mr. Yeltsin simply turned up at the White House, refused to enter at first unless he saw Mr. Bush and then had to be cajoled into meeting with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser.
At the time, Mr. Yeltsin was an unelected politician and a prime irritant to Mr. Gorbachev, with whom Mr. Bush was doing important business. On Mr. Yeltsin's second visit, as President of the Russian republic, he was received in the Oval Office.
"His election impressed people here," the official said.
He went on: "Yeltsin was the first popularly elected leader of Russia in history and got an enormous mandate. People who are engaged in electoral politics themselves take that kind of thing very seriously. His modus vivendi with Gorbachev and his turning into a partner, however fractious, in trying to reach a negotiated outcome to the country's problems impressed people that he had taken a very realistic turn.
"Then his last visit here was important. People saw a different kind of guy, somebody who was much more sophisticated, much more aware of himself and just a much more savvy player on the domestic and international scene. The President quoting him and the phone calls over the past few days were all the logical outcome of this process."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush taking a telephone call from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev yesterday in the bedroom of Mr. Bush's vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me., while his wife, Barbara, stood at left. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Our Unemployment System Needs Reworking;
Illegal 'Subcontracting'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New Rows to Hoe in the 'Harvest of Shame' " (Week in Review, July 28) attributes many of the problems afflicting migrant farm workers to "the growing practice of defining migrant laborers as independent subcontractors, rather than employees." 
 Unfortunately, farmers aren't the only employers who misclassify employees as "independent" subcontractors. More and more contractors in the construction industry are employing workers as independent subcontractors to avoid paying legally mandated benefits -- workers' compensation, unemployment insurance and Social Security -- to gain a competitive bidding advantage, according to industry witnesses who testified before Congress last April.
The General Accounting Office estimated that in 1984 alone the Federal Government lost $1.6 billion in tax revenues because of employee misclassification. The lost revenues represent nearly 10 percent of the entire Department of Housing and Urban Development budget for that year. This scheme not only cheats taxpayers, but also hurts employees who do not receive their benefits, and contractors, both union and nonunion, who lose jobs to unscrupulous employers who knowingly break the law.
Misclassifying employees is a national epidemic in the construction industry that involves an alarming number of large contractors who do business with major corporations and the Federal Government. Recently, for example, a large Massachusetts contractor, Total Property Services of New England, was convicted in Connecticut for labor violations related to employee misclassification while remodeling a General Mills Red Lobster restaurant. The contractor, which also does millions of dollars of business with the Federal Government, is under investigation by the General Services Administration.
Fortunately, in the last year several states have passed legislation allowing contractors to sue competitors who win bids by misclassifying employees as independent subcontractors. Congress has also held hearings on employee misclassification that are likely to generate legislative proposals.
If the practice of misclassifying employees as independent subcontractors continues to grow, more employees will lose their benefits and be exempted from Federal and state labor law protection; more employers who properly classify their employees will lose work to competitors who do not, and the taxpayers' burden will grow.
 
JOHN CUNNINGHAM
MICHAEL D. HOBBS
Norwalk, Conn., Aug. 1, 1991
 
The writers are, respectively, labor and management co-chairmen, Carpentry Industry Partnership.

HEADLINE: Our Unemployment System Needs Reworking;
Extend Benefits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
E. Clay Shaw Jr.'s argument that unemployment benefits should not be extended because of the imminent demise of a mild recession (Op-Ed, Aug. 6) belies the situation in Massachusetts and probably much of the Northeast. The last published unemployment rate for this state was 9.1 percent, down from 9.7 percent. This does not include those who no longer qualify for benefits, those who have given up or who have taken part-time or marginal jobs just to keep afloat. 
 Mr. Shaw's denigrating depiction of the Democratic view of unemployment ("a worker laid off by declines in his industry, spending every day looking for a job, running out of money") is accurate here. Thousands of workers from every sector of society are at the point where they have run through their savings, severance and unemployment, and are losing their homes.
According to published reports, bankruptcies and foreclosures are at their greatest level since the Great Depression. As a psychotherapist, I can report firsthand that the numbers of unemployed people seeking help for severe emotional problems and stress-related medical illnesses, and the rate of suicide attempts among such people, have increased precipitously. This hardly sounds like the end of a mild recession.
For this reason, we should support unemployed workers for 20 more weeks. Economists disagree on whether or not the recession has bottomed out, but believe recovery will be slow. With eclonomic improvement will come more jobs and a chance for these normally productive members of society to recover. To deny them that chance would be unconscionable.
 
ARLENE B. EPSTEIN
Sudbury, Mass., Aug. 8, 1991

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
Bush Quotes Gorbachev: Leader 'Tells Me That Things Are Under Control'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 21

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conferences here today at 10:36 A.M. and 1:20 P.M.:

 	 	 		10:36 A.M.	 		OPENING STATEMENT	 	 Well, I wanted to report to the American people on some of the latest developments related to the situation in the Soviet Union.
 I spoke at length this morning to President Boris Yeltsin. The call began at about 8:30, and I also talked to Ambassador Strauss, who is now in our embassy in Moscow, in position, and I also talked in the last, oh, 20 hours, to President Menem in Argentina, Prime Minister Mulroney, Prime Minister Major, and I will continue these kinds of consultative calls.
 President Yeltsin was clearly encouraged by the fact that he had survived another night in the Russian Parliament building without a major assault by the forces supporting his coup. He told me that tens of thousands of Muscovites had turned out to help guard the building from attack.
 Yeltsin said he was encouraged by indications that more and more military units and their commanders were abandoning support of the coup.

 	 	 		. . .	 		QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS	 	 Q. Mr. President, with Boris Yeltsin anchoring democratic opposition to this coup, where does that leave him if things do in fact resolve themselves satisfactorily?
 A. It leaves the world looking at him as a very courageous individual, duly elected by the people, standing firmly and courageously for democracy and freedom, with enormous stature as a result of that.
 
U.S.-Yeltsin Ties
 Q. Would that change the U.S. approach towards Mr. Yeltsin in any way?
 A. The U.S. approach towards Mr. Yeltsin, as you know, is to be supportive of those who were elected. Ever since he has been elected he has received total support and before he was elected he was received properly. But I must say, in terms of the respect level, I will join others all around the world, not just politicians or elected leaders of countries, in saying that he has shown tremendous courage and the people appear to be rallying behind him. And as I said earlier on, to some skepticism, 48 hours ago or more, that look, all these coups don't succeed and democracy, once unleashed, is a pretty powerful force.
 So I think he will have a well-earned stature around the world that he might not have had -- he was on his way to having but might not have fully achieved before all this happened, provided it works out the way certainly the United States wants it to work out.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Gorbachev's Future
 Q. Assuming that President Gorbachev does recover his authority, how will this affect his ability to keep the Soviet Union on a stable path? Will he be strengthened by it or weakened?
 A. I would say, a little hypothetical for me to get into, but given Yeltsin's support for him and given the respect with which he's held by leaders all around the world, and that has certainly not been diminished by this at all, he will still be a force to be reckoned with. And again, they can sort out inside their own matters. But what will be filtered away, should Gorbachev be reinstated, as we hope he will be, what will be filtered out will be the fear of a right-wing military takeover because the people will see that the power of the people to stand up against this illegality is pretty good, pretty strong.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Coup's Unraveling
 Q. Mr. President, given the, quote, unquote, leader of the coup leaders, are you surprised they sort of went halfway with their coup and were -- the incredible, apparently disorganization of it?
 A. I think it's too early to decree how disorganized it is, but I think they underestimated the power of the people, they underestimated what a taste of democracy and freedom brings, and everyone recognizes that there were serious economic problems, and I think they felt we'll come in there, promise food on the shelves, and to solve these problems, and then they saw that overriding all of that was a commitment by many, many people in Russia and in the Soviet Union, entirely to democracy, for democracy. So I think there, if this coup fails, that will be the serious miscalculation.

 	 	 		1:20 P.M.	 		OPENING STATEMENT	 	 Well, I just wanted to report that at 12:19 I had a phone conversation with Mikhail Gorbachev, and lasted about -- what, 20 minutes, I think. It was a good call. Gorbachev is still in the Crimea. He will return either tonight or tomorrow to Moscow. He tells me that things are under control.
 His first call, I believe, was with Boris Yeltsin. He stated his sincere appreciation to the people of the United States and others around the world for their support for democracy and reform, and he sounded in good physical condition -- indeed, his voice was buoyant. And Barbara was with me, and we both asked him to convey our respects to Raisa, which he -- and he, very kindly, made references to his friendship with Barbara and me on a personal basis.
 But it was good, it was a good talk. It's a good development. And now he will be going back to Moscow, and hopefully working with the Presidents of the republic -- Nazarbayev and Kraychuk, the Ukraine leader, staying with him, there's a good basis now for all of this.
 So we'll see what happens, but in his view, the constitutional authorities are back in power, and democracy and freedom and reform have prevailed. And that's his assessment. I hope it's not ahead of where things stand in Moscow. I've not talked again to President Yeltsin, but he believes that Moiseyev has ordered the forces back from -- to their bases, and all in all it's a very, very positive development.

 	 	 		QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS	 	 Q. Did he discuss the circumstances surrounding his confinement?
 A. No, he didn't, except that his guards, he did say, stayed very loyal to him.
 Q. Does that mean he was never under actual physical ----
 A. I have no idea. I didn't go into all of that.
 Q. Did you get any detail on the 10-plus-1 agreement today? What's the status of that?
 A. No, no. We just got a detail on the fact that freedom and democracy have prevailed, and he's expressing his sincere appreciation to us.
 
Fate of Coup
 Q. Had he talked to people from the coup that assured him that the coup was over? Have they given him ----
 A. I don't know, I don't know. There are all kinds of wild rumors about what's happened to people involved in the coup, but I don't want to go into that. Some of them may be accurate and some may not. But he was anticipating some of them coming to see him. He said that to me, but whether that proves to be the case or not, I don't know.
 
Gorbachev's Status
 Q. Will he be the President again? What's his status?
 A. He feels that way.
 Q. And did he say what happened in the last couple of hours?
 A. No. Just the fact that he was elated, and it sounded like for the last hour he was back fulfilling his duties and calling the shots.
 
Why Takeover Failed
 Q. What do you consider the main factor in the failure of the coup?
 A. The fact that they underestimated democracy and freedom and that you can't put it back in a box. These totalitarian systems, you can't have them come out and take over. You can't put freedom and democracy back into a box and keep it contained. And that's what happened, and as a matter of fact, that's one of the things Gorbachev said. And certainly Yeltsin feels that way.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Gorbachev-Yeltsin Ties
 Q. Does he intend to work with Mr. Yeltsin?
 A. Well, I think he is working with Mr. Yeltsin.
 
U.S.-Soviet Ties
 Q. Does this significantly change the U.S.-Soviet relationship?
 A. I think it's a good day for U.S.-Soviet relationship because I don't think that the fears that some of us have had about -- many people have had, actually, about right-wing takeovers will no longer be as extant.
 They tried and they failed. And democracy prevailed and reform prevailed. And that's what this is all about. So I think that -- I expect the relationship to be, if anything, even better. And we -- you know, you got to wait, you got to sort out some internal problems, but I explained to him, as I've told Yeltsin, that we're ready to talk to the leaders of the republic, and certainly we'll be ready to deal with the President of the Soviet Union itself.
 
Georgian's Comment
 Q. Mr. President, just now on CNN's air, the President of Georgia said that this was all a plot by Gorbachev himself. Now, whether that's true or not, what does that say to the state of the ----
 A. It says he needs to get a little work done on the kind of statements he's making. I mean, that's ridiculous. Here's a man who has been also swimming against the tide, it seems to me, a little bit. And I don't want to go overboard on this, but he ought to get with it and understand what's happening around the world.
 To suggest that this -- President Gorbachev would plot to put the people of the Soviet Union through this kind of trauma and the rest of the world through it just makes absolutely no sense at all. Now, I haven't heard him say that, so I want to hedge it. You've told me he said it, I haven't heard it -- so I've got to be very careful that I don't react to something that may not be true. I learned that one a long time ago.
 But if that's what the man said, I would just discount it one hundred percent. So, anyway, I got to go to work.
 Q. It's definitely over then, you're confident that the coup leaders ----
 A. I'm just telling you what I know here. I've not talked with people in Moscow -- I did talk to Jim Baker, and he's very upbeat from the contacts he's had. He had a long talk with Yakovlev a few minutes ago, who is confident that it's over. But it's not up to us to decree whether it's over or not. I'm telling you what these various leaders are saying about it, and it's a good day -- it's a very good day.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
