HEADLINE: Oregon's New Governor Is Tested by State's Split Personality

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SALEM, Ore.

 BODY:
When Oregon voters went to the polls last fall, they sent a curious mixed message in this state known for its maverick politicians and pioneering laws.
 On one hand, they elected Barbara Roberts, a Democrat, as the state's first female governor, who promised change and new social programs. On the other hand, voters zippered the state pocketbook by passing an initiative that slashed property taxes and forced the state to cut its budget by nearly 15 percent. 
The question in Oregon was whether new ideas could exist on a severe financial diet. David Frohnmayer, the Republican defeated by Ms. Roberts, predicted that the tax-cutting measure would be "a nightmare" for the new Governor.
 
Praise for Approaches
 But with the close of the legislative session this summer, Oregon is basking in national attention for its novel approaches to education and health care, both of which survived the budget ax. Whether Governor Roberts had much to do with the new programs is an open question, but their success or failure is now largely on her shoulders.
 Ms. Roberts, 54 years old, once aspired to a seat in Congress. No more. She sees Washington as a quagmire of inaction and tired ideas -- and she has not been afraid of telling Federal dignitaries as much.
 "The states are where the action is," she said in a recent interview. "There is not a lot of movement at the Federal level. The governors are the innovators."
 A machinist's daughter, and fourth-generation Oregonian, Ms. Roberts campaigned as an underdog last fall and overcame a series of personal blows that included the death of her father, the prolonged illness of her husband and the problems of her son, who is autistic.
 
Defying Timber Industry
 She bucked the timber industry in this most-timber-dependent state and vowed to overhaul traditional education. In a state well-stocked with natural resources, but criticized for its primitive exploitation of forests and farm products, Ms. Roberts was fond of saying, "We don't grow onions anymore; we grow onion rings. We don't grow potatoes; we grow french fries."
 With help from Republican women who crossed party to lines to vote for her, and a conservative independent candidate who took votes away from Mr. Frohnmayer, the Attorney General, Ms. Roberts won the election by three percentage points. The independent candidate, Al Mobley, drew 13 percent of the vote.
 "We in the West have a unique problem," Ms. Roberts said. "This is the fast-growing area of the country. This is where new ideas and leadership are coming from. Yet, there is no Federal investment, as there was when the East was coming of age. So we have to fend for ourselves."
 Oregon, certainly, has followed its own path. It is now instituting a health plan that, by 1995, will make it the second state in the nation to have universal health coverage. Hawaii is the first. Oregon's educational system will be radically redesigned, after legislative action this year. The new system will force students to chose, by 10th grade, whether they want to pursue a course to college, or start learning about a particular trade.
 "The current education system has ceased to be relevant for so many students," Ms. Roberts said. "You have 12th graders working at McDonalds and maybe taking one class. We've got to give them something in the school system to keep their interest. Our goal is to have the best prepared work force in the country by the year 2000."
 Another new law, signed this month by the Governor, entitles all employees who work more than 25 hours a week to be given an unpaid family leave of up to 12 weeks every two years. The leave is to care for children, or ill spouses and relatives. Returning employees are guaranteed, by law, the same job when they return.
 Governor Roberts has benefited from an improving Oregon economy. The tax-cutting measure was expected to force the state to cut about $600 million from its two-year $5 billion budget. But it was able to restore much of that money because of taxes from the growing economy.
 Critics note that Ms. Roberts, while salvaging the budget for the major initiatives in health and education, had very little to do with the conception of either program, or with the family-leave bill. "She was not an active participant," said State Representative Greg Walden, a Republican who is majority leader of the State House. "Now she's wrapping herself around all the good press and good feelings about these programs."
 While many fresh ideas are coming out of the Oregon statehouse, Mr. Walden said very few of them are actually coming from the Governor.
 "She is your basic liberal, spend-and-spend social program Democrat," Mr. Walden said.
 But he gives her high marks for her personal style. "She has great charisma," he said. "She's very likeable, a very good speaker. They don't come much better in campaign style."
 Ms. Roberts got into politics as a citizen activist seeking help from the state for her autistic son. She was elected to the Oregon House in 1981, then went on to be elected Secretary of State in 1985, a job she held at the time of her election as Governor.
 
Taking Environmental Side
 On the environment, Governor Roberts has taken the opposite tack of the state's two Senators, Mark Hatfield and Robert Packwood, both Republicans who favor timber-industry-sponsored bills to allow high levels of tree-cutting in national forests.
 Court action initiated by environmentalists over the endangered northern spotted owl, which nests in forests that the timber industry wants to log, has brought most of the logging in Oregon national forests to a virtual standstill.
 The Governor, pointing to major environmental decisions of an earlier maverick Governor, Tom McCall, says Oregon has to build a future on more diversified industries rather than relying so heavily on logging. Rather than push for reopening huge sections of public land for logging, Ms. Roberts signed a bill giving money to depressed timber towns for job retraining and new industry.
 "I don't see this as a crisis, but as an opportunity," she said. "Oregonians have always been willing to take a long-term view to save their environment.
 Indeed, neighboring Washington State is glutted with new housing projects as the cities push into farm and forest land, while Oregon, restrained by a law limiting urban sprawl passed in the 1970's, has been able to preserve many of its rural areas.
 Ms. Roberts is now preparing to take on what may be her biggest headache -- overhauling the tax system. Oregon has an income tax but no sales tax. The Governor plans to travel around the state, sampling opinion, then propose an amendment to the state Constitution that will allow the change. She is withholding her plan until she believes she has a consensus of the people.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Governors are the innovators," said Barbara Roberts, first woman to be Governor of Oregon. (Don Ryan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
From Baltics to Beijing

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The world rejoices about what happened in Moscow, and nobody more than Li Lu, who lies starving on a street in Washington, outside the Embassy of China.
Mr. Li was one of the thousands of young people at Tiananmen Square who went without food day after day, trying to shake the Communist rulers into surrendering a morsel of freedom. 
 Now, in America, he is on a hunger strike again, praying that this will make the world remember some of his comrades, lying in dark isolation in Communist cells. Although his heartbeat is dangerously low he is filled with zest. He feels that the triumph in the streets of Moscow will bring freedom closer for China.
That hope is not political emotionalism. Mr. Li and his friends have too much at stake -- liberty and life -- to waste time and energies with that.
The essence of political realism now is to understand that from the Baltics to Beijing new opportunities to advance freedom arise from the defeat of the coup. And it is just as important to understand that they will be attained more slowly and painfully unless two things happen.
One is that new leadership takes over in the Soviet Union. The other is that new thoughts take over in Washington.
Suddenly the whole world knows how important the opportunities are to so many Soviet people. That was made brilliantly clear by the swift fury with which the coup against change was smashed.
The dissolution of the Soviet Union, basically a jail for captured nationalities, is one of the opportunities. It is shamefully past time for the U.S. to become part of history, instead of an embarrassed bystander, by recognizing the independence of the three Baltic States. Just about the only important resistance anymore comes from Soviet black berets and American diplomacy.
In a new confederation of former Soviet republics, another goal can come rapidly: the disappearance of Communism, gone but never forgotten. Seventy-four years of Communism guarantee that the economic turnaround will need help and time.
The end of the centralized Soviet system will be the gift of the Soviet people to themselves. But it will also be pleasant news for those who happen to worry about nuclear war.
The huge Russian republic will eventually control the Soviet stockpile. That is an edgy thought. But it is not quite as nerve-racking as having them all these years under a centralized Soviet empire. The coup terrified us all, or should have. Nobody says life after the Kremlin will be perfect and safe -- just better, and safer.
Mr. Gorbachev seems to be telling the world himself that this cannot happen under his leadership. He emerged from his captivity to say he still believes that reform could come within the framework of the Communist Party, that he would not abandon it, that those who had left it were wrong, and that Socialism, as he put it, was his goal.
That, to a people sick of the stench of the Communist Party and of the Socialist economy, and to foreigners who will invest only when they see the death certificates of both. He did what the coup-makers could not -- make the President of the Soviet Union look just plain silly.
Important as he has been as a window opener for the Soviet Union, he returned to find his own credentials in question. He is on political trial by his countrymen to explain why he came to appoint those nasty coup-makers in the first place, and why he is appointing more like them.
So Boris Yeltsin will be the leader of the post-Gorbachev, post-Soviet era. Luckily for us all, he was around. Maybe Washington will even remember the lesson -- not to pin American foreign policy on any one person, not Mr. Gorbachev, not even Mr. Yeltsin.
But what Mr. Bush has learned from the coup we do not really know. He stood strong against it but now is annoyed at any criticism of Mr. Gorbachev: peculiar politesse certainly not shared by the Soviet people.
Meanwhile Li Lu is still out there on a sidewalk in Washington, starving -- and smiling. He smiles because he knows that the men who sent out the tanks in Moscow are in jail while their brothers in Beijing are not only in power but courted and fawned over by the U.S. He thinks that now Americans will find that strange. He thinks maybe Americans will not again turn away if Chinese have to face the tanks again. Maybe Li Lu is right.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Palestinians Again Supported The Wrong Side, Israelis Say

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 22

 BODY:
The Israeli authorities, pursuing their campaign to discredit the Palestine Liberation Organization, poured scorn on Palestinian attitudes toward the failed Soviet coup today and summoned two leading Palestinians for questioning about contacts with P.L.O. officials.
In the occupied territories, a mood of hope kindled by Mikhail S. Gorbachev's brief ouster returned to despondency. 
 "I am very sad and frustrated," said Fraih Abu Middain, a prominent lawyer in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip, echoing a common sentiment about the collapse of the hard-line coup in Moscow. "This incident will concentrate the U.S. domination. The Soviet people must revolt again in order to be a superpower to compete with the United States."
Many Palestinians and radical Arabs, notably in Iraq and Libya, resent Mr. Gorbachev for reducing the Soviet Union's long support for them while the United States has continued to back Israel. Moreover, they oppose Mr. Gorbachev's agreement to the free emigration a Soviet Jews to Israel, fearing that the influx will lead to increased Israeli settlement in the occupied West Bank.
 
Support for the Coup
 When the Soviet leader was overthrown on Monday, thus, many ordinary Palestinians and some P.L.O. officials came out in support of the coup leaders in the hope that their cause had won a new champion.
Israeli officials seized on Palestinian utterances today and presented them as further evidence that the P.L.O.'s misjudgments and attitudes disqualify the organization as an interlocutor.
"In times of international crisis, the P.L.O. has time and again hurried to align itself against the free-world democracy and to reveal its true nature," the Israeli Foreign Ministry said in a statement. "This is one of those times."
In comments to reporters, Foreign Minister David Levy also took issue with Palestinian arguments that the Soviet coup would restore the superpower balance.
"Does a balance of power mean a return of the world to a state of tension and fear of war, and to a race between the two blocs?" he asked. "Only those whose eyes are blinded and who are unable to see the future can talk about this sort of balance of power. Only those who are themselves unbalanced can call this balance."
 
Defense by Palestinian
 Hanan Ashrawi, a prominent Palestinian in East Jerusalem, sought today to rebut the latest Israeli assault. "What really alarms me is that people are interpreing popular reaction as meaning that there was a consensus," she said, referring to the attidtude in the Palestinian leadership to the coup.
"Many Palestinians made very responsible statements," she said. "But I suppose Israeli memory and propaganda is very selective about that."
Both she and Faisal al-Husseini, another leading East Jerusalem Palestinian, were ordered today to appear before the police on Monday for questioning about talks they held last weekend in London with P.L.O. officials, Palestinian officials said. Israel outlaws all contact with the P.L.O., which it calls a terrorist organization.

HEADLINE: Weekly Jobless Claims Are Highest Since June

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
The number of Americans seeking unemployment benefits jumped in early August to its highest level in almost two months, the Labor Department said today, underlining the tentative nature of the economic recovery.
The surge prompted some analysts to suggest that the Federal Reserve must cut interest rates further to invigorate the economy. 
 First-time claims for jobless benefits rose to 430,000 in the week that ended Aug. 10, up 22,000 from 408,000 in the previous week, the department said. It was the second consecutive week that the claims had risen, and the new increase was larger than the 412,000 anticipated.
"It says the economy is moving at a snail's pace," said Don Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University. "It doesn't yet throw the recovery into question. But this is a borderline number."
 
Recovery 'on the Edge'
 Robert McGee, chief economist at the Tokai Bank in New York, said the figure backs the notion that the recovery "is on the edge between growth and stumbling back into recession."
The number of claims, the highest since June 22, when the figure reached 431,000, suggests that the jobless rate is likely to edge up to 6.9 percent in August from 6.8 percent in July, economists said.
Unemployment usually rises for about six months after a recovery has begun because employers delay rehiring until they are convinced that the upturn is firmly in place.
Since March, when initial claims totaled more than 500,000, there have been gradual signs that the labor market was improving, albeit in fits and starts.
But Jean Sundrla at Evans Economics Inc. said the trend might have halted. She pointed to the four-week average of first-time unemployment claims, which economists consider a more reliable indicator of the job market's health. It rose to 410,500 in the week ending Aug. 10, its fourth straight rise after reaching a low of 403,000 in the week ending July 20.
 
'Does Not Bode Well'
 Ms. Sundrla said these figures added fuel to the argument that the economy needed another lift from lower interest rates. "For the outlook on the economy, this does not bode well," she said of the jobless claims.
She said she expected the Federal Reserve, after moving to cut the Federal funds rate earlier this month, to take a firmer stance in the next few weeks and cut its high-profile discount rate.
The discount rate is the interest charged on the Fed's short-term loans to banks and underpins all other rates. The Federal funds rate is the overnight rate at which banks lend each other short-term money.
Other economists said they expected that before the Fed made a decision on interest rates it would seek new data on durable goods orders, a clearer trend on money supply figures, and the August unemployment data, to be released on Sept. 6.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders React to Events in U.S.S.R.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against major currencies yesterday as traders continued moving away from the American currency after the failure of the Soviet coup.
"The rapid disintegration of the coup led directly to a rapid deterioration of the dollar," said Frank Pusateri, a vice president with the Bank of Boston. The dollar is generally considered a safe currency in times of international turmoil. 
 But the German mark has continued to make gains since the coup crumbled. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7295 German marks, from 1.7408 marks on Wednesday; in London, it was quoted at 1.7320 marks, down from 1.7535.
"There was some feeling in the market that with the coup failing, the pace of economic reform in the Soviet Union could possibly accelerate, which could be good for the German economy," said Carl Forcheski, a Chemical Bank trader.
In New York, the British pound finished at $1.6935, up from 1.6885 late Wednesday. Earlier in London, the pound rose to $1.6975, from $1.6735 late Wednesday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 136.75 yen, down 0.43 yen from Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 136.70 yen, and in New York, the dollar was quoted at 136.60, up from 136.55 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.5090 Swiss francs, down from 1.5150; 5.8795 French francs, down from 5.9190; 1,293.75 Italian lire, down from 1,302.75, and 1.1433 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1442.
Selected late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.5035 Swiss francs, down from 1.5285; 5.8680 French francs, down from 5.9675; 1.9445 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9805; 1,295.85 Italian lire, down from 1,311.25, and 1.1432 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1437.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Platinum Prices Plummet On Fear of Soviet Dumping

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as Japanese selling and fears of Soviet dumping pressed the market to 5 1/2-year lows.
Gold and silver futures also fell, but many other commodity prices rose, including grains and soybeans and oil. 
 Platinum for delivery in October fell $9.20 a troy ounce, to $336.20, the lowest settlement of a near-term platinum contract since Dec. 26, 1985.
On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for August delivery fell $2.60 an ounce, to $354.30; September silver dropped 2.8 cents, to $3.91 an ounce.
 
Selling by Japanese
 Signs of new platinum sales by the Japanese, the world's largest platinum investors and jewelry makers, started the sell-off, said James Steel, metals analyst in New York with the commodities trading company Refco Inc.
He said some traders believed the Japanese were selling platinum on behalf of the Soviet Union, which has few other ways to raise hard currency.
"No matter which way the coup turned out, the Soviets are still in a weak economic state and have to step up precious metal sales," Mr. Steel said.
Jacques Luben, executive director of investments for the trade group Platinum Guild International, said the decline reflected selling by individual speculators in a thin market. He called the metal a good buy for long-term investors but said the market was unlikely to rally until the fears of large-scale Soviet selling subside.
Corn, wheat and soybean futures ended sharply higher on the Chicago Board of Trade following a surge late in the session after President Bush lifted a freeze on economic aid to the Soviet Union.
The move frees Moscow to pursue new American grain purchases with $900 million in export credit-guarantees granted earlier this year by the Bush Adminstration.
Wheat for delivery in September settled 3 cents higher, at $2.99 1/4 a bushel; September corn rose 7 cents, to $2.50 1/2 a bushel; September oats fell 1 cent, to $1.26 a bushel, and September soybeans rose 9 cents, to $5.71 1/4 a bushel.
Petroleum futures rose moderately on the New York Merc as traders consolidated their positions after three days of volatile trading. Oil prices were roiled this week by fears the failed Soviet coup would disrupt crude oil supplies from the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer.
Crude oil for October delivery rose 17 cents, to $21.72 a barrel; September home heating oil rose .42 cent, to 62.22 cents a gallon; September unleaded gasoline rose .70 cent, to 68.63 cents a gallon; September natural gas rose 10.8 cents, to $1.42 per 1,000 cubic feet.
The unusually sharp gain in natural gas was prompted by position-squaring ahead of the contract's expiration yesterday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Discount Corp. of New York Appoints a Vice Chairman

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Discount Corporation of New York, an old-line government securities firm and the only primary dealer in the Treasury market not affiliated with a larger parent company, yesterday named Denis P. Coleman Jr. as vice chairman.
The announcement comes as the Treasury securities business is being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the wake of the Salomon Brothers scandal. There are calls in Washington for tighter oversight of Treasury securities firms than is now provided by the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. 
 Mr. Coleman said Salomon's acknowledgment of bidding abuses at Treasury auctions should not lead to quick conclusions that the market is rife with similar activities.
"As far as distributing securities at a good price for the Government, this market has been pretty efficient and done a credible job," he said. "Before you act to improve deficiencies, I think you first have to make sure the problems are there and then be thoughtful in making changes."
"If new regulation creates inefficiencies," he added, "the Treasury will pay for it" in terms of higher interest rates when it auctions new securities.
Mr. Coleman, who had spent the last two years managing his private investments and working with local charities, was previously a senior executive at Bear, Stearns & Company, where he had broad exposure to the fixed-income markets.
After graduating from Georgetown University in 1967, he started at Bear, Stearns as a clerk and rose to manager of the municipal bond department. During the 1980's, he was in charge of the firm's expansion into the Treasury and mortgage securities departments.
Mr. Coleman, 45, said he was re-entering the securities business because Rafe de la Gueronniere, the Discount Corporation's chairman since July 1, "was an old friend and asked me." He and Mr. de la Gueronniere have been friends for nearly 20 years ago.
At the Discount Corporation, Mr. Coleman said, the scope of his duties is not yet clear. But he expects to be more involved in the administrative side of the business than the minute-to-minute trading activities.
Mr. Coleman lives in New York City and will remain active with such local charities as Covenant House, where he is vice chairman.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Brady's Message On the Scandals

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE Salomon Brothers' misconduct in the Treasuries market -- coming after such scandals as the fall and bailout of hundreds of savings and loans, the drug and money-laundering and bribing activities of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, the junk bond debacle of Drexel Burnham Lambert and the assorted frauds in the Japanese stock market -- has further stirred anxieties about the integrity of financial markets. Unless they are quelled, such anxieties could hurt saving and investment all around the world.
In cracking down hard on Salomon Brothers for exceeding the 35 percent quota for primary dealers in the auction markets for Government securities, the Treasury was sending a message to the other 39 primary dealers in that market that conduct like Salomon's would be dealt with harshly. With $2.3 trillion in Federal debt to be marketed and rolled over ad infinitum -- a debt total that is expected to increase by $279 billion in the fiscal year 1991 and by $362 billion in 1992 -- any loss of faith in the integrity of the Government securities market might be extremely costly. 
 Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, in an interview on Tuesday, said he did not know how "deep" the problems in the Government securities market went. The Treasury, he said, was not an investigative agency; the S.E.C. and the Federal Reserve, on which the Treasury depends, are now "collecting information." But Mr. Brady is clearly warning every house that might be acting as Salomon was to clean up its act fast.
He was asked why the Treasury, having first announced, at 10:30 Sunday morning, that Salomon had been barred from bidding in the primary Treasury auction market, said five hours later, following a telephone conversation between Mr. Brady and Warren E. Buffett, the firm's new chairman, that Salomon could bid for its own account but not for its customers. Mr. Brady replied, "In substance, that changed the situation only marginally."
At the time of the first announcement Sunday morning, he said, there had been only "a lot of talk about what might happen," but no concrete action. By the time of the second announcement, said a Treasury official, who requested anonymity, the Salomon board had taken four actions: (1) Dismissed the top three executives -- John H. Gutfreund, the chairman; Thomas W. Strauss, president, and John W. Meriwether, vice chairman; (2) discharged the head of the Government trading desk, Paul Mozer, and his No. 2, Thomas Murphy; (3) announced other administrative and management changes, and (4) pledged, through Mr. Buffett, to cooperate fully with the Treasury, S.E.C. and Fed, to "right the wrongs." Mr. Buffett gave Mr. Brady his personal assurance that the situation at Salomon would be cleared up.
Mr. Brady denies that confidence in United States securities has been shaken. He said that the Federal deficit was "too big" but that the United States was able to sell its obligations to the world. "The enormous amount of our bonds people buy," he said, "imply confidence not only in United States securities but in the method by which we distribute them, directly and with dispatch."
Instead of damage to the United States resulting from the Salomon scandal, he said, the way it was being handled would "enhance everybody's confidence." The United States financial market, he said, is "deep and liquid -- I'm not sure whose exceeds it."
But with financial markets having gone global on a 24-hour-a-day basis, don't investors need better international regulation? "Good question," Mr. Brady said. But he added, "We have to rely on the individual countries." Every country, he noted, has its own rules and codes. He conceded that it might be desirable to negotiate standard regulations at least for the principal financial markets.
He cautioned against overregulating financial markets, contending that "the cure can be worse than the disease being cured." The United States, he said, now has the opportunity to "do it right" and show that "our market is the safest in the world."
Did he have any new thoughts on how to bring the climbing budget deficit down? He said the worsening of the projected deficit for 1992 was the result of to the "vagaries of the S.& L. bailout and Desert Storm," but he had "confidence that in the long run -- that is, the next five years -- the outlook was for the deficit to slope downward."
Official projections support that view. The Congressional Budget Office projects the deficit will peak at $362 billion in the fiscal year 1992 and fall to $156 billion by 1996.
The Administration's Office of Management and Budget sees a peak deficit of $348 billion in 1992 and expects a surplus of $20 billion in 1996.
Herbert Simon, Carnegie-Mellon's Nobel laureate in economics, says, "If you can't forecast, stay flexible." And Treasury Secretary Brady, the nation's premier bond salesman, seems to be saying, in the wake of the Salomon scandal: If you can't forecast the public debt, just be sure you can sell it to the world.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Star Vehicle For Taylor: A Scent Spot

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
IF you plan to catch Elizabeth Taylor's new film, don't buy a very big bag of popcorn; it runs only two minutes and 45 seconds.
The film is a commercial for White Diamonds, the second fragrance that the Elizabeth Arden division of Parfums International is introducing with the collaboration of the actress. The spot, shot in Acapulco in black and white and styled to resemble a theatrical movie, will be shown at department stores' fragrance counters; a 60-second version will be broadcast on television. 
 The commercial is the centerpiece of an estimated $20 million campaign for the new fragrance, which joins Elizabeth Taylor's Passion, a four-year-old brand that ranks in the top 10 fragrances sold through department stores.
White Diamonds is only one of several significant product introductions in what looks like the $5 billion fragrance industry's most frantic round of marketing activity ever. To prepare consumers for the Christmas scent-shopping season, there are elaborately produced commercials, promotional videotapes and enough magazine scent strips that a newsstand might be taken for a perfume counter.
Among the other new brands, joining the more than 500 already on store shelves, are Escape, from Calvin Klein; Spellbound, from Estee Lauder Inc., and Tresor from Lancome.
A key factor in fueling the intense competition for market share is the recession. Fragrance sales tend to hold up during an economic downturn, because shoppers who deny themselves big-ticket items will splurge on a new scent. Another is the increasing concentration of industry ownership by giant consumer-product marketers that spend lavishly on product introductions and advertising; Parfums International and Calvin Klein are owned by the Unilever Group, while Lancome is owned by L'Oreal S.A.
"It's a busy time," said Paulette Dufault, vice president of advertising for Elizabeth Arden in New York, "but we hope all the excitement of all the fragrance launches will pique the interest of consumers to get into stores and see what's going on."
To help stir excitement for White Diamonds, said Tom Moloney, vice president of marketing for Parfums International, Ms. Taylor will begin a national promotional tour on Sept. 12. By that time, consumers in major metropolitan markets will have had the chance to visit local department stores and watch the commercial, which is called "White Diamonds Starring Elizabeth Taylor."
"We're going to set it up as a 'theater' event, as her latest movie," Mr. Moloney said. "We're going to hand out tickets and serve little bags of popcorn." The shorter version of the commercial will appear on television stations in major markets, including New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.
The commercial is styled like a film "because Elizabeth Taylor is a great movie star," said Mindy Goldberg, executive producer and co-owner of Epoch Films, New York, the production company that created it for Elizabeth Arden. "Rather than just see her posing, we wanted to give her a scene and see her acting."
In the spot, directed by Epoch's Terry Bedford, Ms. Taylor, who is drenched in diamonds -- some really hers, some borrowed -- watches a high-stakes poker game being played by a mysterious group of men. The youngest and handsomest is about to fold his hand when she takes off her earrings and drops them in the pot on his behalf. "These have always brought me luck," she says.
Lest Ms. Taylor's first celebrity scent be forgotten amid the hoopla for White Diamonds, Ms. Dufault said that new spots for Elizabeth Taylor's Passion are due soon. Those spots intersperse color shots of the Passion bottle with black-and-white clips from Ms. Taylor's films, including "Butterfield 8" and "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
Bush Restores Some Aid to Soviets but Holds Back on Big Projects

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 22

 BODY:
In a day of deliberately mixed signals, President Bush today reinstated the limited assistance to the Soviet Union that he suspended during the Kremlin coup but said he was still not prepared to support major financial aid until President Mikhail S. Gorbachev enacts significant economic reforms.
The White House's somewhat tentative approach seemed intended to buy time for Mr. Bush and his aides to assess developments in the Soviet Union, particularly whether the failed coup has signficantly shifted the balance of power between Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin. 
While the Administration is clearly putting some pressure on Mr. Gorbachev, it is also waiting to see whether he will move decisively toward reform now that the constraints that the United States assumed were imposed by Communist hard-liners seem to have been removed.
As a senior official put it today, the White House wants a look at the "true Gorbachev." It was surprised, he said, by some of the Soviet leader's initial personnel decisions and by his defense today at a news conference of the Soviet Communist Party.
 
Allies See It Differently
 The cautious policy puts the Administration somewhat at odds with its allies. Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, said an increase in economic aid might be in order now. Germany, which has long pressed for greater Western generosity for Moscow, said it was preparing to recognize the three Baltic republics as independent states, as soon as they reached a secession agreement with Moscow.
Mr. Bush said he would not interfere in Soviet politics and made it clear that he was not ready to do what Germany suggested. But he called on Mr. Gorbachev to speed negotiations on independence for the three Baltic states. "In my view, that would do more to enhance good will in the United States than almost any other single thing that could be done," Mr. Bush said.
In public, Mr. Bush praised Mr. Gorbachev, refused to speculate about whether the failed coup had damaged him politically and avoided taking sides between Mr. Gorbachev, still a commited Communist, and Mr. Yeltsin, who has rejected Communism and resigned from the Party. Mr. Bush also said it was not up to the United States to pass judgment on Mr. Gorbachev's new Cabinet.
But at the same time, the White House sent a senior Administration official to brief reporters in the press room, where he offered a significantly more reserved, even skeptical view.
 
Criticism of Defense Choice
 Speaking on the condition that he not be identified by name, the official called on Mr. Gorbachev to rein in the K.G.B. and the other internal Soviet security organs.
He spoke with some disdain about Soviet officials who "weren't heard from for a couple of days" -- an apparent reference to Foreign Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh -- and criticized Mr. Gorbachev's decision to retain Gen. Mikhail A. Moiseyev as Minister of Defense.
"I wouldn't want that guy behind me in a dark hall now," the official said. "Moiseyev, to put it generously, was ambivalent" during the coup, he added.
Another senior official, also speaking on condition of anonymity, said that Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, Mr. Gorbachev's former right-hand man, had called Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday while Mr. Baker was in Brussels and told him that General Moiseyev was involved in deploying troops during the coup.
By the time Mr. Bush spoke to Mr. Gorbachev on Wednesday, the Soviet leader said the general was obeying his orders to pull the troops back.
 
'Let Them Sort That Out'
 During a brief news conference at his vacation home after meeting with Mr. Baker, Mr. Bush took a more circumspect approach than the senior official, saying that General Moiseyev had helped negotiate the recent treaty on reducing long-range nuclear weapons and that the United States should not comment on personnel choices by Mr. Gorbachev.
"Let them sort that out," Mr. Bush said, though he added, "We will hold back a little on military-to-military contacts until we see this sort out."
White House aides said Mr. Bush had been annoyed by news articles reporting the senior official's comments and pointing out the differences between the Administration's public and private positions. The White House said the senior official was expressing "personal views" and that Mr. Bush was articulating public policy.
But the remarks today at the summer White House reflect a practice commonly used by the Administration when it wants to express views publicly but is not willing to put them on the record. By offering the remarks on "background," the White House is in a position to say later that the remarks of a particular official, no matter how senior, do not represent official policy.
 
Groping for a New Policy
 The strategy is clearly intended to permit Mr. Bush himself to observe the diplomatic niceties and bolster Mr. Gorbachev as the Administration gropes for a new policy toward the Soviet Union.
At the same time, the private statements signaled that the United States is resisting pressure to make sharp changes in American policy toward the Soviet Union as a result of the coup's failure. The senior official's remarks also made it clear to Mr. Gorbachev that he must repay his country and the outside world for their support by making real strides toward political and economic reform.
The official emphasized that the United States would not "try to rush into final decisions on policy in every case in a situation which is as rapidly moving as this." He added, "It is not the right time to nail oneself to the mast."
The White House seemed especially anxious to respond to mounting pressure from Mr. Major and others for Washington to increase its economic aid to Moscow. "I don't see anything new right now on that," Mr. Bush said.
The senior official said that if Mr. Gorbachev rapidly accelerated economic reforms, the United States could respond with greater aid. But he said that as far as the Bush Administration was concerned, nothing has changed substantively since Mr. Gorbachev met with the leaders of the seven leading industrial democracies in London last month.
"I think we're back to where we were at the time really of the economic summit," the official said, "and that is a program in place that is demonstrably able to absorb and use aid in order to further reform, not simply that it will be swallowed up in an economic morass."
Administration officials said they would be willing to consider humanitarian relief assistance, especially in food, if the Soviet harvests are as bad as currently predicted and the country experiences shortages this winter. But they said no such request had been received from Moscow.
As the coup unfolded, Mr. Bush announced that he was "putting on hold" all Soviet-American economic programs. Those projects, primarily technical assistance programs, are extremely limited but included $900 million in agricultural loan guarantees.
But Mr. Bush's order presumably would also have blocked enactment of favorable tariff treatment for the Soviet Union, along with a new trade treaty and associate membership in the Western world's financial institutions. The decision today to lift the suspension was a sign that the United States considers the coup to have finally been put down.
 
Watching Gorbachev and Yeltsin
 The senior official said the United States was waiting to see how Mr. Gorbachev proceeded in his new relationship with Mr. Yeltsin and in other areas.
"Gorbachev has by and large operated in the middle between the more radical reformers and the conservatives," he said. "And as you recall, last winter when the reformers were in considerable disarray, the pressure was all from the conservatives. Then when he and Yeltsin got together and they started working on the union treaty and so on, he got his maneuvering room back.
"Now he's in a sense lost it, because he can't point to the conservatives and say, 'Hey, we can't do any more than we are.' So, I think, you know, we may in a sense see the true Gorbachev coming out more."
Asked what the American assessment is of the true Mr. Gorbachev, the official replied, "We'll wait and see."

Sununu, White House chief of staff; Andrew Card, an assistant to Mr. Bush; and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
Regrouping After a Trauma

 BODY:

Gorbachev and Yeltsin at Work
 
BOON FOR DEMOCRACY Mikhail S. Gorbachev said his rescue from the failed coup has taught him that he must join more closely with "democratic forces" and speed the pace of reform. Page A1. 

A NEW RELATIONSHIP It was perhaps the greatest irony of the coup's failure that Mr. Gorbachev's presidency was saved by the one man he had done his most to destroy, Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian federation president. News Analysis, page A1.
JOY IN THE STREETS Thousands of jubilant Muscovites took to the streets in triumph, removing a statue of Feliks Dzerzhinksy, founder of the Soviet secret police, in front of K.G.B. headquarters. And 50,000 people cheered Mr. Yeltsin in front of the Russian government building. Page A9.
 
New Team and Perhaps New Borders
 
TAKING OVER AT THE K.G.B. Leonid V. Shebarshin, 56 years old, is taking over as the head of the K.G.B. international espionage operations and Lieut. Gen. Vasily P. Truskin replaces Boris Pugo, who committed suicide, as head of the Interior Ministry. Page A8.
BUSH AND THE BALTICS The Bush Administration and a number of other Western governments renewed calls for the Soviet Union to permit the full independence of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. Page A9.
A BLOW FOR COMMUNISM The Parliament in Latvia outlawed the Communist Party, and the republic's government said it was seeking the arrest of the republic's hard-line party leader, Alfred Rubiks. Page A9.
 
Reactions at Home and Abroad
 
EUROPEAN AID IS BACK Relieved and delighted, European Community governments resumed economic aid to the Soviet Union and expressed hope that Mr. Gorbachev woiuld speed efforts to introduce a full market economy. Page A15.

HEADLINE: Giant Banks: Will Little Guy Pay?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The proposed merger of BankAmerica and Security Pacific, the two largest banking companies in California, is the latest in a series of big-bank betrothals that promise cost savings, great riches for shareholders and power for the executives.
Consolidation in the banking industry is all the rage because everyone seems to win -- except, perhaps, the consumer and small-business borrowers. 
 As mergers cause banking power to be concentrated in fewer hands, particularly in states like California where the market is already more concentrated than elsewhere, depositors tend to get lower interest rates, according to recent Federal Reserve Board studies. And borrowers, particularly small businesses, are charged higher rates, the studies indicate.
Timothy H. Hannan, a Federal Reserve economist, concluded in an article earlier this year in the Journal of Banking and Finance that borrowers in markets with a highly concentrated banking system pay interest rates that range from half a percentage point to 2.2 percentage points higher than borrowers in the least concentrated markets, depending on the type of loan. The presence of nonbank competitors -- such as commercial lending companies, loan offices of out-of-state banks, and so-called "800"-number loan services from financial service companies -- are not enough, Mr. Hannan said, to prevent banks in concentrated markets from charging stiff interest rates.
Another study, by Donald T. Savage, a senior economist at the Fed, contends that bankers may be exaggerating the cost savings of mergers. What does cut costs, the study said, is the loss of some customers when a branch closes.
A merger can result in the type of routine cost cutting that a bank can do whether or not it is trying to complete a merger. Citicorp, for example, is halfway through a $1.5 billion cost-cutting program that involves no merger.
Although the Justice Department and Federal Reserve Board have been increasingly tolerant of large bank mergers during the 1980's, the proposed combination of the two big California banks, which would form the nation's second largest, is large enough to raise questions about whether it would concentrate power to the detriment of consumers.
 
Creating a Behemoth
 In California and Washington state, where Bank of America and Security Pacific rank first and second, respectively in terms of deposits, their merger would not simply eliminate competition between the two largest banking companies, it would create a behemoth with even more power to set prices.
"There is no doubt this merger would restucture the competitive environment in many markets," said Kenneth H. Thomas, a bank consultant in Miami and a lecturer at the Wharton Business School. "What bankers call excess capacity, the public sees as competition.
"If regulators have decided that we have too many banks and consolidation would be good for the health of the industry," Mr. Thomas said, "wouldn't it be better if the consolidation occurred by California banks' expanding into New England or Florida instead of combining with each other?"
 
California Interest Rates
 Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla., noted that recent surveys show that California banks already pay lower interest rates on deposits and charge higher interest rates on loans than do banks in other parts of the country.
In Los Angeles, for example, the average interest rate for unsecured two-year personal loans, excluding credit cards, is 20.25 percent -- about 1.9 percentage points more than in New York, 3.11 percentage points above the national average and 5.6 percentage points higher than the average rate in Philadelphia. Interest-bearing checking accounts in Los Angeles, meanwhile, pay an average yield of 4.11 percent, well below the national average of 4.65 percent.
"You can't prove that the cause of high prices in California is the power of the four biggest banks in the state," Mr. Heady said. "But the end result is clear."
 
Antitrust Concerns Cited
 Lawrence J. White, a professor of economics at New York University and formerly a member of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said the condition of the California market and the size of the two banking companies indicates that "this merger will not be approved so easily as some expect." He predicted that "the antitrust division of the Justice Department will weigh in and require the sale of some branches in markets where the concentration is too high."
Peter Magnani, a BankAmerica spokesman, said that higher prices "might be explained by the fact that costs of doing business in California are higher than other parts of the country." He said the company would not comment on any aspect of its merger related to antitrust questions until after Federal regulators had looked at the issue.
 
A Defense of the Merger
 H. Rodgin Cohen, a lawyer at Sullivan & Cromwell in New York who has represented BankAmerica in recent merger attempts, said the one justification of the merger is that "it makes for a stronger bank, and stronger banks are in a better position to make more loans and provide better service."
Banking analysts agree that financially strong banks are best positioned to make more loans, because they have less reason to worry about falling below the minimum capital standards set by regulators. But in the case of Bank of America, its capital strength and profitability are already high enough that it has been increasing its lending more rapidly than the national average.
Over the last 10 years, Security Pacific has also been one of the country's fastest-growing large banks and profitable enough to earn high marks from Wall Street. Despite its losses in the last year from foreign lending and commercial real estate loans outside California, Security Pacific has been strong enough to continue expanding its consumer lending businesses.
 
The Impact of Market Share
 A study published in the spring 1990 issue of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank's Economic Review found that the tendency of California banks to pay lower interest rates on deposits, particularly interest-bearing checking accounts, could not be fully explained by high operating costs in California and the sluggish growth rate of deposits during the mid-1980's.
The study said that market clout produced lower interest rates on interest-bearing checking accounts. It estimated that a 10 percentage point increase in the combined market share of the top three banks in a local market could reduce deposit interest rates by roughly 1.5 perentage points.
Big bank mergers are raising other concerns as well. Some economists have questioned bankers' claims that mergers will yield huge cost savings and better profits and make the new bank more profitable and financially stronger. Such claims by bankers are are not supported by studies, which tend to show that big bank expansions have not resulted in any efficiencies that resulted in greater profits.
Mr. Savage, the Fed senior economist, concluded that the greatest opportunities for cost savings came from other efficiency gains, not the closing of duplicated branches after a merger.
In a hypothetical example involving the merger of a bank with $20 billion in assets and a bank with $10 billion in assets and the closing of 100 branches, Mr. Savage found that operating costs at the new bank rose 4.3 percent if there was no loss of customers. If the acquired bank lost 20 percent of its assets, and closed 100 branches, however, the cost savings amounted to only 2.2 percent of the combined costs of the two banks before their merger.
In one of the two largest mergers proposed recently, BankAmerica and Security Pacific forecast cost savings of $1 billion annually, or 29 percent of Security Pacific's costs. In the other, between the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Corporation, the partners forecast savings of $650 million annually, or 32 percent of Manufacturers Hanover's expenses.
At the Minneapolis Federal Reserve bank, an article in the spring issue of the Quarterly Review by two economists, John H. Boyd and Stanley L. Graham, noted there are several studies showing that banks do not become more efficient as they grow.
Mr. Boyd and Mr. Graham said mergers of large banks in the same market might improve profits for reasons unrelated to closing of branches.
The merger "will necessarily reduce competiton and may render the survivor more profitable," they said, "simply beause of its enhanced ability to earn monopoly rents."

HEADLINE: Coup's Failure May Bring More Investment

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The failed coup in the Soviet Union caused a few hiccups in Moscow's business ties to the United States, but it may well lead to a more rapid expansion of Western investment in the long run.
The hazy consensus among many Western business executives is that the coup attempt was too short-lived to increase concerns about Soviet instability that much. At the same time, many executives said, the coup's collapse left Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian Republic's President, and other advocates of radical economic change in a better position to clear away some hurdles to Western investment and trade. 
 "We think it will speed up change and may allow us to accelerate some of our projects," said Thomas Polski, a spokesman for the Carlson Hospitality Group, the Minneapolis-based parent of Radisson Hotels, which owns what it says is the only American-managed hotel in the Soviet Union. Radisson has been pushing Intourist, its Soviet partner, to build hotels in other Soviet cities to go along with the 430-room Radisson Slavyanskaya Hotel Moscow.
For many companies, the most heartening aspect of the week was how painlessly the coup attempt ended for them. "Operations are back to normal and were never disturbed in a major way," said Karl Nigl, the Vienna-based manager of Pepsico Inc.'s soft-drink and Pizza Hut operations in the Soviet Union.
Mr. Nigl left no doubt about how delighted he was with the outcome. He said Pepsico had sent soft drinks and pizza to Russians who spent the night in front of the Russian Parliament building to repel a possible Army attack. He recounted with relish yesterday that a can of Diet Pepsi had been clearly visible in front of Mr. Yeltsin during the broadcast of his press conference Wednesday.
But emphasizing how little had changed so far, Mr. Nigl added, "The economic difficulties remain and that's what impacts us."
Some Soviet scholars say the reshuffling of authority is likely to open new avenues for business. "The instability of the past three days is far from over, but there is more green light," said John E. Mroz, president of the Institute for East-West Security Studies in New York. "The republics will certainly end up with more economic autonomy and there will be some very positive investment opportunities in regions like Russia, the Ukraine and Kazahkstan."
Some experts, including Peter Pettibone, the chairman of the New York Bar Committee on Soviet Affairs and legal adviser to companies with Soviet operations or technology-transfer agreements, said the coup attempt could lead to a short lull in American business activity.
But that will not last, he added. The conservatives' failure will speed efforts to determine who has authority over what decisions at various levels of the Government, clearing away the uncertainty that has long discouraged investment.
 
'It's Much Too Early to Tell'
 The Commerce Department said yesterday that it was taking a wait-and-see position on questions about the Soviet business climate. But the department has no plans to cancel trips in the fall to improve trade relations, a spokeswoman, Patricia Woodward, said.
Many companies are also noncommittal. "It's much too early to tell whether things will change for the better," said Jack Batty, a spokesman for the General Electric Company. The Fairfield, Conn.-based conglomerate, which sells medical equipment, plastics and some electrical equipment to the Soviet Union, said the coup began and ended too quickly to affect any of its operations.
"We are basically where we were," agreed Ron Roberts, a spokesman for the Eastman Kodak Company. "We didn't rush out and do anything during the coup and we aren't rushing out and doing anything now." Kodak sells some film to the Soviet Union but is nowhere near completing any joint venture to make products there, Mr. Roberts said.
Some disruptions occurred, but they typically were minor. Rama Rao, president of Excel Technology Inc., a start-up laser company in Holbrook, L.I., put off plans to travel to Minsk tomorrow to meet with his joint-venture partners at the Byelorussian Polytechnic Institute. But the visit has already been rescheduled to Sept. 21.
 
Emotional Turmoil
 Businesses in Moscow went through more emotional turmoil but remained unscathed. Radisson offered to remove its 18 managers at the Moscow hotel, including 14 Americans, but all of them chose to stay, Mr. Polski said. The hotel received only a handful of cancellations.
In fact, some companies may have emerged from the crisis with their reputations enhanced among Soviet business partners. Mr. Polski said Radisson demonstrated to Intourist that it would be a good partner "through thick and thin."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
A former top Air Force official admitted he accepted bribes from military contractors in return for his help in steering contracts and confidential bidding information to them. [D1.] 
 The number of Americans seeking unemployment benefits jumped in early August to its highest level in almost two months, the Labor Department said. [D2.]
 
COMPANIES
The proposed merger of BankAmerica and Security Pacific is the latest in a series of big-bank betrothals that promise cost savings, riches for shareholders and power for executives. [D1.]
Salomon has begun using a contingency financing plan the firm had developed to deal with periods of crisis, senior Salomon executives said. [D1.]
A sweetened offer for Harcourt by General Cinema appears to have a good chance of success, analysts said, and should give the troubled publisher a new lease on life by freeing its basically sound businesses from the burden of overwhelming debt. [D1.]
Tandy reported a sharp drop in earnings, as expected, but another maker of personal computers, Dell Computer, said its profits nearly doubled. [D3.]
TRW is considering selling its credit reporting business, in part because of the growing public outcry and regulatory scrutiny of the business of tracking and selling sensitive consumer financial data, its chairman said. [D3.]
The Time Inc. Magazine Company announced that it had purchased certain assets of Health magazine, one of seven titles closed by Family Media. [D5.]
Midlantic said it would sell the United Penn Bank to Mellon Bank for $90.2 million. [D3.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
The failed Soviet coup caused a few hiccups in Moscow's business ties to the U.S. but may well lead to a more rapid expansion of Western investment in the long run. The hazy consensus among many Western business executives is that the coup attempt was too short-lived to increase concerns about instability much. [D1.]
In a setback for the world environmental movement, a GATT panel has ruled that environmental concerns about a foreign industry cannot be a factor in barring imports. The panel ruled that the U.S. may not ban imports of tuna caught by Mexican boats, which kill more dolphins than the U.S. tuna fleet. [D1.]
 
MARKETS
Stock prices kept heading upward. The Dow gained 5.59, to 3,007.38, but two other indexes posted record highs. In Europe, markets rallied strongly. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities posted modest gains in fairly active trading as the tension of the last few days drained out of the credit markets. [D12.]
The dollar was mixed as traders continued moving away from the American currency after the failure of the Soviet coup. But the German mark continued to make gains. [D13.]
Platinum futures prices fell sharply as Japanese selling and fears of Soviet dumping pressed the market to 5 1/2-year lows. [D13.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
The Salomon Brothers scandal has further stirred anxieties about the integrity of financial markets. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
An S.E.C. case focuses on a backwater of the penny-stock business, where cheap yet overpriced securities are sold with high-pressure tactics. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
A commercial featuring Elizabeth Taylor is the centerpiece of an estimated $20 million campaign for a new Elizabeth Arden fragrance, White Diamonds. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]

HEADLINE: AFTER THE COUP;
Europeans Look at Costs of the Coup

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Amid expressions of relief and delight at the failure of the Moscow coup, European Community governments resumed economic aid to the Soviet Union today and expressed hope that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will now accelerate moves to introduce a full market economy.
But behind the euphoria, Western European governments began totting up how much the dramatic events of the last few days will cost them in terms of new economic assistance and trading opportunities for both the Soviet Union and the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe. 
 They also recognized that deep uncertainty still surrounds the political future of the Soviet Union, not least because the balance of power has been transformed by the emergence of the President of the Russian federation, Boris N. Yeltsin, as the savior of the country's developing democracy.
The immediate question facing major European capitals, as well as Washington and Tokyo, is whether the West should now step up economic aid to Moscow, a move that some European officials fear could imply recognition that Monday's coup might have been averted had they acted sooner.
 
More Aid Is Urged
 Indeed, this is the view of the leaders of Germany, France and Italy. They argued in favor of greater aid at the London summit meeting last month of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies and have now renewed their calls for more Western involvement in Moscow's long-debated economic reform program.
Though the leaders diplomatically urged an across-the-board increase and speedup of aid from all Western donors, their implicit message was that those countries that have been most reluctant about offering aid, including the United States and Japan, should now become markedly more generous.
"Whoever wants to support change and guard against danger must now help more and more quickly than before," Germany's Economy Minister, Jurgen Mollemann, said today. Germany is the Soviet Union's largest Western backer, having pledged $35 billion in credits since 1989.
President Francois Mitterrand of France said, "Now we have to make a bigger effort than we have so far made." His Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, added: "We must, all of us, think about the West's attitude to Gorbachev. Do we want to make the means available to fulfill certain aims?"
 
Others Resist Calls
 But other European leaders share the American and Japanese view that the Soviet Union must act first to modernize its economy. Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, said the Soviet Union needs "not just cash but assistance in how to do things, how to establish private enterprises, how to set up a stock exchange, how to operate a market."
Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek of the Netherlands, which holds the rotating presidency of the 12-nation Community, warned against "throwing money" at the Soviet Union. "Unless the system is changed, our money would be like a drop of water on a hot stove," he told the European Parliament.
The Community already has a $1.5 billion aid program with the Soviet Union, but this involves technical assistance and food credits rather than direct financial support. Most of the package was suspended Tuesday in reaction to the coup, but it was restored today along with an $80 million British technical assistance program.
For the moment, there is at least consensus that moves to associate the Soviet Union with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank should be sped up. "We'll be pushing to get them into the Fund as soon as possible," Italy's Foreign Minister, Gianni De Michelis, said today.
There are also signs that Community leaders are willing to consider greater aid to Moscow. They canceled a summit meeting scheduled for Friday to discuss the Soviet crisis. They instead proposed an early meeting with Mr. Gorbachev, and officials said such a meeting would be pointless unless the Community had more to offer.
The shock of the abortive Soviet coup has made itself felt on the Community's relations with Eastern Europe, with Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia pointing to it as evidence of the risks posed to their own new democracies unless they receive greater Western economic aid.
The Community is negotiating association agreements with the three countries, but until now it has resisted lowering protectionist barriers to their most competitive exports -- food, textiles, steel and coal -- and is reluctant to give them greater access to Western European credits.
 
Calling for Concessions
 Calling for such concessions, Jacques Delors, the president of the Community's Executive Commission, said this week, "It's no good making fine speeches about solidarity with Eastern Europe on Sunday and the next day refusing their demands to import more of their goods."
European governments that in the past paid scant attention to Mr. Yeltsin are also now busily adjusting to his new importance. Today he received official invitations to visit Germany, France and Italy, while European newspapers universally hailed him as the man of the hour.
After talking by telephone to Mr. Gorbachev today, Mr. Major had nothing but praise for the Soviet leader. "I don't know why you seem so keen to write him off," the Prime Minister told reporters. "He sounded like a man who was very fit, very confident and raring to get on with the job."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

After the Coup A8-15
President Gorbachev said his rescue from the failed coup had taught him that he must join more closely with "democratic forces" and speed the pace of reform. Meanwhile, one of the coup leaders killed himself. Page A1

PUB-DATE: August 23, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1523 words

HEADLINE: BUDGET IS PASSED FOR CONNECTICUT WITH INCOME TAX

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to the New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 22

 BODY:
After six months of anguished budget deadlock, capped by a 36-hour marathon of deal making and brinkmanship, the Connecticut legislature today approved Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s income tax plan and gave the state a budget for the fiscal year that began more than seven weeks ago.
The income tax, which was signed into law by Mr. Weicker at 4 P.M., less than an hour after the final vote in the House of Representatives, will take effect on Sept. 1, thus shortening to only nine the list of states without an income tax. Residents will feel the new tax in their paychecks by early October. The income tax has a nominal rate of 4.5 percent, but it is somewhat graduated through a system of standard deductions and credits. 
 The plan was a victory for Mr. Weicker, a former Republican who abandoned his party last year to run for governor as an independent anti-party politician and who after being elected made the establishment of an income tax the centerpiece of his first year in office.
 
Political Drama
 True to the form established over a summer of budget cliffhangers and false starts that included three full-year budget vetoes by Mr. Weicker and a partial shutdown of the state government last month, the race to the finish was political drama at its highest and lowest forms.
In the State Senate, the plan passed when Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark broke an 18-to-18 tie.
Five and a half hours later, in a vote that brought many exhausted lawmakers to tears, the House killed the plan, 81 to 69. But it was revived and finally was passed by a 75-to-73 vote later in the day after several hours of open bargaining on the floor of the House. Legislators sought to trade their votes for everything from promises about local property tax relief to pledges by the Governor to try to bring down the size of government.
 
Particularly High Stakes
 "When I sign this budget Connecticut will be closing the book on its past and it'll be facing toward the future," Mr. Weicker said at a signing ceremony.
But some legislators contended that the Weicker administration had simply pressured or bought out opponents with promises of local tax disbursements and pledges to consider pet projects.
Mr. Weicker denied that the budget was the result of any improperly applied pressure tactics. The Governor said his very lack of any party support in the legislature made it impossible for him to employ the kinds of party plums and other tools that are the ordinary give and take in traditional two-party politics.
But it was also clear as the dust settled over what has been at times a harsh and personal contest between Mr. Weicker and the General Assembly that Mr. Weicker's status outside the traditional political system did have an impact on Connecticut's struggles. It may also have some lingering consequences, especially if the income tax provokes the sort of public outcry that some lawmakers predict it will eventually draw.
For the majority Democrats, who have ruled Connecticut in both the legislative and executive branches of government for most of the last four decades and who led the charge to support Mr. Weicker's budget, the stakes are particularly high. Republicans, who remained largely united against Mr. Weicker's budget, have already vowed to use the Democrats' ties to the Weicker income tax like a bludgeon in next year's General Assembly elections.
Some Democrats said that with Mr. Weicker vetoing any budget that did not contain an income tax, as he did on three occasions since May, majority status simply required leadership, however people felt on the income tax issue.
"The time has come to act," said Representative Richard T. Mulready, a West Hartford Democrat, in arguing early this morning that statesmanship required a budget, like it or not. "If this bill doesn't go, we have genuine stalemate," he said.
Other lawmakers wrestled, sometimes in emotional terms, to express their concerns that passing an income tax into law would also clearly mark the end of an era in Connecticut.
Since at least the early 1950's, when Gov. Chester Bowles ran for re-election on an income tax platform and lost badly, through 1971, when the state briefly passed an income tax that lasted all of six weeks before being repealed under a howl of protest, the income tax has persisted as a symbol in the state's public vocabulary. To opponents it has meant grasping government growth, and to supporters, fairness in making those with the most means pay the most tax.
Representative Peter J. Fusscas, a Republican from Marlborough, said the passage of an income tax would bloat state government with new money and new spending. "It lets the genie out of the bottle," he said. "Once it's out, it ain't never going back in."
Now that Connecticut is getting an income tax, the nine states that still do not have an income tax are Alaska, Florida, Nevada, New Hampshire, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Washington and Wyoming.
Mr. Weicker, who took office in January and proposed his budget overhaul plan only a month later, argued that the recession and a huge revenue shortfall from the two main existing tax sources had forced the state's hand in throwing out the old system. He proposed cutting those two taxes -- the 8 percent sales tax and the 13.8 percent corporate profits tax -- and making up the difference with an income tax.
The Senate, especially, stood across the barricades during much of the 53 days that the state struggled since July 1 without a budget. The senators found they could block every attempt to pass Mr. Weicker's income tax, but they were also unable to prevail in overriding the Governor's vetoes of non-income-tax plans or to impose any vision of their own.
The result for much of the summer was a deepening gulf of bitterness and frustration that left lawmakers and residents alike fed up and exhausted.
Often the news seemed like a soap opera: In the House, where a majority was reached last month on an income tax plan, members broke a longstanding taboo by openly criticizing their Senate colleagues in floor debates. The Senate, which had a two-thirds majority ready to override Mr. Weicker's budget vetoes, bridled at the House's failure to muster the same majority needed to impose the non-income-tax budget.
The votes this morning came only about 30 hours after three previous holdout Democratic senators broke the deadlock by announcing their support for an income tax plan.
"People ask me if I'm committing political suicide," said Senator Steven Spellman, a Democrat from Pawcatuck, one of the swing-vote senators. "My answer is, I don't know."
 
Other Significant Changes
 The budget, while overshadowed by the introduction of the income tax, would also bring about significant changes in most other state taxes. The 8 percent sales tax would be lowered to 6 percent but extended to many new transactions, including lower-priced clothing, home repairs and tax preparation services.
The 13.8 percent corporate tax would be lowered to 10.5 percent over two years. The existing taxes on income from dividends and interest, which peak at 14 percent, and the 7 percent capital gains tax would both be eliminated entirely, with all income treated equally under the new 4.5 percent rate.
The income tax would be applied to all adjusted gross income over $12,000 a year for an individual, $19,000 for a head of household and $24,000 for a couple filing jointly. But the effective rates are also colored by an interlocking system of tax credits and phased-out deductions that would affect about 76 percent of all taxpayers, according to the bill's sponsors.
 
Spreading the Burden
 The tax credits would reduce the burden of the income tax on poor and middle-class families, while the phased-out deductions would increase tax payments by those at higher income levels. A couple earning $40,000, for example, would not pay any tax on the first $24,000 and would also receive a $252 tax credit, resulting in a net effective tax rate of 1.17 percent, owing $468.
A family earning $80,000, by contrast, would pay the income tax on the full amount, with no deduction allowed at all, and would get a tax credit of $360, resulting in an effective tax rate of 4.05 percent and a tax bill of $3,240.
State income taxes are deductible from Federal tax liability at lower incomes, which means that people who itemize on their Federal tax returns would get a part of their state income tax payments back in the form of a larger Federal tax refund.
 
Separate Package
 The budget was also tied to a separate package of government consolidation plans and spending controls that many lawmakers had insisted upon in return for their votes.
Both chambers also passed earlier in the evening a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would provide further restraints.
That bill, which would require approval by residents at the next general election -- in November 1992 -- would prohibit some categories of state spending from growing any faster than the rate of inflation or the growth in personal income.

Weicker Jr. signed into law a 4.5 percent income tax plan that gave the state a budget after a six-month deadlock. The House of Representatives had passed the bill less than an hour earlier. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s proposal on Feb. 13
 
Establish personal income tax of 6 percent on adjusted gross income over $25,000 for couples and $12,500 for individuals, beginning July 1.
 
Eliminate the tax oncapital gains, dividends and interest income, which would be taxed as personal income beginning July 1.
 
Reduce sales tax to 4.25 percent, from 8 percent, beginning July 1, and apply it to many goods and services that are now exempt, including clothing, gasoline, newspapers, haircuts and movie tickets.
 
Eliminate 20 percent corporate tax surcharge, as of Jan. 1, 1992.
 
 
The final budget enacted yesterday
 
Establish a 4.5 percent personal income tax for couples earning over $24,000, individuals earning over $12,000 and single heads of household earning more than $19,000. effective Sept. 1.
 
Eliminate the tax on capital gains, dividends and interest income, which would be taxed as personal income beginning Sept. 1.
 
Reduce sales tax to 6 percent, from 8 percent, beginning Oct. 1, and apply it to some goods and services that are now exempt, including newspapers, haircuts and movie tickets and some clothing. Gasoline would stay exempt at the pump.
 
Eliminate 20 percent corporate tax surcharge over two years, beginning Jan. 1, 1992.
 
Establish statutory caps on the future growth of state spending, linking future budgets to the rate of inflation or growth in personal income. Start process for having such caps in the State Constitution.
